Description:
Looking back at the #YearInPictures, October 2021 ‚Å£

Churchill, Manitoba, Oct. 31: Jasper Hunter, 10, ventured out on Halloween evening. Polar bear attacks are a real danger, so townspeople drive behind trick-or-treaters to protect them. üì∏ @damonwinter

La Palma, Canary Islands, Oct. 30: A house peeked through an ash-covered landscape more than a month after the Cumbre Vieja volcano first erupted, destroying hundreds of homes and forcing the evacuation of thousands of people. üì∏ Emilio Morenatti/@apnews

Baghdad, Oct. 10: A demonstration in Tahrir Square to commemorate activists killed by security forces and militias. An estimated 600 activists were killed during protests that began in 2019 to demand jobs and basic public services. üì∏ @andreadicenzo

Palm Springs, California, Oct. 2: A couple at a pool party during Dinah Shore Weekend, an annual festival for queer women that made a triumphant return after a two-year hiatus. üì∏ @michellegroskopf

Manhattan, Oct. 21: Eric Adams, the Democratic candidate for mayor of New York, spoke at the opening of the Summit One Vanderbilt observation deck in Midtown. üì∏ @andrewseng

Dhiam Dhiam, South Sudan, Oct. 21: Amour Abach, 16, wore a mask at a school housing children displaced in floods. With much of the country under water, coronavirus safety measures and vaccines were a tough sell. üì∏ @lynseyaddario

Churchill, Manitoba, Oct. 29: One of the several hundred polar bears that congregate around Churchill each year, waiting for sea ice to form in order to hunt. As the ice forms later in the year and melts earlier because of climate change, the bears‚Äô hunting season has dwindled. üì∏ @damonwinter

El sondeo revel√≥ que para un 56% de las y los encuestados el principal problema que les afecta es la #delincuencia e inseguridad ciudadana, seguido por un servicio de #salud deficiente (36%) y la #corrupci√≥n en la #pol√≠tica (32%). 

Tanto la delincuencia como los servicios de salud deficiente han liderado el listado desde la primera medici√≥n de este estudio, mientras que la corrupci√≥n por primera vez ocupa el tercer lugar. 

Ante estos resultados, P√≠a Mundaca, directora ejecutiva de Espacio P√∫blico se√±ala que el estudio "constata que los problemas que vienen afectando a las personas de manera persistente y con fuerza en los √∫ltimos cinco a√±os son la delincuencia y la salud‚Äù. En ese sentido, advierte que ‚Äúestos temas debieran ser prioridad para las autoridades". 

Por su parte, Alejandra Ojeda, directora de Estudios P√∫blicos de Ipsos Chile indica que "la ciudadan√≠a estar√° expectante de cu√°les son las medidas concretas que el nuevo gobierno anuncie".

Description:
A sus 47 a√±os, con cerca de 60 papeles repartidos a lo largo de cuatro d√©cadas, y asumido que el tiempo tambi√©n pasa para √©l, Leonardo DiCaprio reparte √∫ltimamente sus favores entre sus amigos Scorsese, Spielberg, Nolan y Tarantino como lo que es: una mega estrella que adem√°s tiene merecida aureola de excelente en lo suyo. A tan aventajado grupo de notables se une estos d√≠as Adam McKay, que le ha puesto al frente de la pel√≠cula 'No mires arriba', que estrena Netflix tras un r√°pido paso por los cines. Un film en clave de comedia negra que a√∫na su talento como actor con su activismo mediambiental.

La Vanguardia - Da un poco de miedo lo cerca que est√° la pel√≠cula de la realidad...

DiCaprio - Lo interesante para m√≠ es c√≥mo establece una analog√≠a perfecta con muchas de las cosas que est√°n ocurriendo ahora y que demuestran la incapacidad de buena parte de la sociedad para escuchar en general, y a los cient√≠ficos en particular. Muestra c√≥mo ignoramos a la ciencia, como si no tuviera nada que ver con nuestras vidas. Lo que ocurre con los negacionistas o con el cambio clim√°tico es un claro ejemplo. A menudo en mi carrera he buscado pel√≠culas que tuvieran un trasfondo ambiental, pero ocurre lo mismo que con la avalancha de noticias negativas sobre el cambio clim√°tico: mucha gente no quiere escucharlas. 

LV - Tambi√©n se acerca a pel√≠culas sobre las conspiraciones que est√°n tan de moda estos d√≠as‚Ä¶

LD - (...) Quer√≠amos justo eso. Llegar ah√≠ desde la franqueza sobre la crisis clim√°tica que es un asunto abrumador y deprimente que genera todo tipo de teor√≠as sobre conspiraciones, pero que, si lo dotas de un envoltorio de comedia, por oscura que sea, te ofrece una oportunidad de oro para llegar al gran p√∫bico. Como activista y como int√©rprete, para m√≠ ha sido una oportunidad que no pod√≠a obviar, encapsulada en este momento tan preciso, y tal vez podr√© mirar hacia atr√°s y pensar que logramos provocar conversaci√≥n y aportamos algo real para variar las cosas en una direcci√≥n espec√≠fica.

Lee la entrevista completa de Juan Luis √Ålvares, en la bio üì≤ https://bit.ly/3sqBfSu #cine #leonardodicaprio #dicaprio #actores

Description:
üçÅ Autumn colours could be cut short as climate change causes leaves to turn and drop earlier and more quickly, the National Trust has said in its annual review of nature in the UK.‚Å†
‚Å†
üåé Climate change is ‚Äúaltering our landscapes forever‚Äù, the Trust said, with the familiar red and gold of autumn leaves from September into December potentially one of the casualties.‚Å†
‚Å†
This year, dry conditions from a warm September led to concerns that some trees would shed their leaves before Autumn arrived, the Trust said.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚òÄÔ∏è Summer 2021 was one of the UK‚Äôs top ten hottest on record, despite dull skies in southern England for much of July and August.‚Å†
‚Å†
In the end, the extra September sunshine meant a ‚Äúspectacular‚Äù array of reds in leaves when the Autumn colours finally arrived in October.‚Å†
‚Å†
üçÇ Read more at the link in bioüçÇ‚Å†
‚Å†
#leaf #nationaltrust #autumn #nature

Description:
Storms and wildfires, partly caused by unseasonable weather conditions, have devastated wildlife in parts of the UK this year, in what is the "new normal" due to climate change, the National Trust has said. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Temperatures in parts of the UK could hit the mid-teens this week, forecasters say, in another example of unseasonal weather this year which included a dry spring that caused wildfires in Yorkshire and Northern Ireland. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The National Trust's annual review of wildlife and weather found that more frequent extreme weather events like Storm Arwen, which uprooted hundreds of trees across Wales and Northumberland, were putting even more pressure on the UK's threatened wildlife. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Ben McCarthy, head of nature conservation and restoration ecology at the National Trust, said: "Climate change is making some forms of extreme weather events the new normal.‚Å†
‚Å†
"Heatwaves and heavy rainfall are becoming more frequent and more intense.‚Äù‚Å†
ImageText: More storms and wildfires is 'new normal' in UK, National Trust says @channel4news

Description:
The climate crisis took a catastrophic toll across the globe in 2021. From the Arctic to Louisiana and to China's Henan province, signs that climate change is already altering our weather were everywhere.

In the United States, historic flooding trapped and killed residents in submerged basements. In Canada, an entire town was erased by a wildfire fueled by extreme heat. Rain fell at the summit of Greenland for the first time.

As climate disasters mounted, the world aligned around combating the crisis: Scientists published a landmark report that concluded humans are unequivocally to blame; US President Joe Biden reentered the Paris Agreement in the early days of his administration; world leaders met at the UN climate summit in Glasgow, Scotland, to negotiate solutions.

But promises were not met with action in 2021, and humans are pumping more planet-warming emissions into the atmosphere than ever.

Tap the link in our bio for more about 10 of the biggest climate crisis stories of the past year.

(üì∑: Noah Berger/AP | Dan Anderson/EPA-EFE/Shutterstock | Evan Vucci/AP | Noel Celis/AFP/Getty Images | Tamir Kalifa/New York Times/Redux)

Es war ein unfassbar schwieriges Nachrichtenjahr, das auch uns oft an die Grenzen gebracht hat (denn immerhin m√ºssen wir das alles auch lesen).

Description:
üêß The Royal Navy has made a "hazardous" trip to "one of the most remote places on earth" to help scientists study shrinking penguin populations.‚Å†
‚Å†
Research ship HMS Protector is studying colonies of the birds in the South Sandwich Islands ‚Äì so off the beaten track even the Royal Navy only calls in once a decade.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚õ∞Ô∏è Described by the Royal Navy as ‚Äúone of the most remote places on earth,‚Äù the chain of islands lie more than 1,300 miles east of the Falklands and are home to around three million of the flightless birds.‚Å†
‚Å†
By landing on the uninhabited islands, recording the penguins and using drones, scientists hope for a better understanding of the impact of climate change and other environmental factors on the colonies.‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
Beth Faulkner is a project manager at the Manta Trust, a conservation and research charity that studies manta rays, the harmless close relatives of sharks.‚Å†
‚Å†
"They have no sting, no teeth, nothing they can do to hurt humans. So they're absolutely wonderful to swim with in the water."‚Å†
‚Å†
Although manta rays pose no danger, the global population of reef manta rays is declining, mainly due to fishing, habitat degradation and global warming.‚Å†
‚Å†
"Everything has its place," she says, adding that when species are removed from an ecosystem, it can completely disrupt the way that ecosystem works. "So it's not just about protecting the mantas alone -- it's about protecting the entire ecosystem." Click the link in the bio for more.‚Å†
‚Å†
üì∏: Kaitlyn Zerr/The Manta Trust
ImageText: Meet the all-female team working to protect manta rays in the Maldives The Manta Trust is working to gather details about the way mantas live to stop their global population declining CNN

Description: Sobrevivientes tendr√°n acceso a la caja üòØ El proyecto llamado "Earth's Black Box", es una instalaci√≥n de acero gigante que prontamente se llenar√° de discos duros alimentados por paneles solares. Seg√∫n consigna National Geographic, cada disco estar√° documentando y preservando las actualizaciones y an√°lisis cient√≠ficos en tiempo real respecto a los principales problemas que amenazan el planeta tierra. Destacando as√≠ el cambio clim√°tico, contaminaci√≥n ambiental, extinci√≥n de especies o impactos en la salud.  El gran objetivo de este proyecto es que los sobrevivientes a un posible apocalipsis sepa qu√© hicimos mal. El aparato estar√° escondido en alg√∫n lugar de la isla australiana Tasmania y reci√©n estar√° completamente activa a mediados de 2022. ¬øQu√© te parece? üëá

Description:
Looking back at the #YearInPictures, April 2021 ‚Å£

New Delhi, April 23: As India recorded as many as 350,000 coronavirus infections per day ‚Äî more than any other country had since the pandemic began ‚Äî bodies were brought to a crematorium ground for Covid-19 victims. üì∏ @lokeatul

Jinggangshan, China, April 22: Tourists dressed as Red Army soldiers on a sightseeing tour, curated to show a sanitized version of the Communist Party‚Äôs history. ‚ÄúRed tourism‚Äù flourished ahead of the party‚Äôs centennial. üì∏ @gillessabrie

Svalbard, Norway, April 23: Svalbard Satellite Station, 800 miles from the North Pole, keeps satellites connected and plays a crucial role in supporting research on climate change. üì∏ @an_filip

Brooklyn Center, Minnesota, April 12: A standoff between the police and hundreds of protesters a day after the killing of Daunte Wright, a Black man who was shot by an officer during a traffic stop. üì∏ @joshua_rashaad

Washington, April 28: President Biden addressed a joint session of Congress as Vice President Kamala Harris and Speaker Nancy Pelosi looked on. It was the first time that two women sat on the dais behind the presidential podium. üì∏ @nytmills

Warri, Nigeria, April 24: Debra Emiko and her daughter Mala Elizabeth Emiko lamented that there was little fish to catch. Fisherwomen in the region began calling to account oil companies that have made billions in profits while leaving environmental ruin in their wake. üì∏ @yagazieemezi

Noborito, Japan, April 28: Members of the Japanese band Chai, who said their adoption of the color pink was a way of repudiating societal expectations about cuteness. üì∏ @shina.peng

Philadelphia, April 4: A picnic at the Horticulture Center in Fairmount Park as the city started to gradually lift coronavirus restrictions. üì∏ @hannah.beier

Una de las temporadas m√°s calurosas del a√±o. 

Groenlandia registr√≥ el 20 de diciembre 13 ¬∫C, cuando la temperatura media es de -5,3 ¬∫C. M√°s al norte, donde la temperatura suele alcanzar los -20,1 ¬∫C, se registraron 8,3 ¬∫C.

Si bien los expertos se√±alan que las temperaturas se elevaron por un viento c√°lido que es habitual en la isla, que esto se mantenga en el tiempo no lo es. Adem√°s, indicaron que el calentamiento global "apuntala las temperaturas elevadas" y hace que sean mucho m√°s alzadas.

Description:
2021 wrapped.

This year was another extraordinary period for news and investigations.

In our 200th anniversary year, twelve months of Covid stories ranged from the hope of vaccination through to government sleaze.

It was also the year of Cop26, with activists and world leaders gathering in an attempt to slow the climate crisis. There were protests against injustice, including those about violence against women. It was also a year of global political shifts, not least in Afghanistan.

Meanwhile, it was a year of sporting inspiration at the Euros, the Olympics, and with @emmaraducanu's improbable US Open triumph.

Here are some of the highlights of our journalism in 2021.

What stories would you like to see us cover more in the year to come?

#theguardian #journalism #news #environment #politics #health #sport

La ONG realiz√≥ un estudio titulado ‚ÄúChile: urgencias #medioambientales para 2022‚Äù que revel√≥ que el 94% de los encuestados cree que el #cambioclim√°tico es una emergencia en Chile. Del total, 9 de cada 10 chilenos consideran que la #crisisclim√°tica les afectar√° a ellos y sus familias, adem√°s de que 85% est√° en contra del proyecto mineroportuario #Dominga. Desde @greenpeacecl comentaron que ‚ÄúChile est√° fuertemente afectado por el cambio clim√°tico y su expresi√≥n m√°s clara es la #crisish√≠drica, por lo que son necesarias acciones decididas por parte del Estado que van desde la protecci√≥n del agua y los #ecosistemas h√≠dricos, hasta el abandono inmediato del carb√≥n y el fin de las #zonasdesacrificio‚Äù.

El desaf√≠o de reducir la #huelladecarbono en el planeta es una cruzada que mantuvo reunidos a decenas de cient√≠ficas, cient√≠ficos y delegados de diversos pa√≠ses, en el marco de la #COP26. Adem√°s, apunta a promulgar el Servicio de Biodiversidad, tambi√©n actualmente en el #Congreso, y apoyar a la #Convenci√≥nConstitucional para incorporar la tem√°tica ecologista en la futura Carta Fundamental.

En cuanto a #Escaz√∫, hay un compromiso de firmarlo inmediatamente. "Adem√°s la primera conferencia de las partes de Escaz√∫ va a ser en abril en Santiago, en la Cepal, as√≠ que ser√≠a muy simb√≥lico que el Presidente pueda abrir la primera COP de Escaz√∫ con #Chile habiendo ratificado ese acuerdo y del cual fue art√≠fice, y el cual por una raz√≥n inexplicable no se firm√≥ durante este Gobierno. As√≠ que, s√≠, eso est√° dentro de las prioridades", se√±ala.

Description:
Sen.¬†Joe Manchin‚Äôs announcement¬†that he won‚Äôt support President Joe Biden‚Äôs package to expand the nation‚Äôs social safety net and fight climate change could doom a series of initiatives that would benefit millions of Americans.

Initiatives like free preschool, subsidized child care and Medicaid expansion are among those in jeopardy if Manchin's, D-W. Va., decision sinks the roughly $2 trillion Build Back Better bill.

His opposition means the bill won‚Äôt be able to go forward in the Senate as written because the chamber is split 50-50 among Democrats and Republicans. GOP senators are united in their opposition to the bill, so every Democratic vote is needed for the bill to pass.

Here‚Äôs a closer look at what‚Äôs at risk if the Build Back Better bill does not pass. üëÜ

Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer pledged Monday that the Senate will take up President Biden's nearly $2 trillion plan to expand the social safety net and combat climate change despite West Virginia Senator Joe Manchin pulling his support for the legislation.‚Å†
‚Å†
Manchin, a moderate Democrat whose support for the measure is crucial in the evenly split Senate, cited concerns over inflation, the national debt and the COVID-19 pandemic as driving his decision to yank support for the plan.‚Å†

Description:
Die Erweiterung des bisherigen Wirtschaftsministeriums um den Bereich Klimaschutz ist ein Ergebnis der Koalitionsverhandlungen von SPD, Gr√ºnen und FDP. Damit ist Robert Habeck unter anderem zust√§ndig f√ºr die Pl√§ne, den Anteil der erneuerbaren Energien am deutschen Stromverbrauch bis zum Jahr 2030 auf 80 Prozent zu erh√∂hen. ‚ÄûWir m√ºssen den vermeintlichen Widerspruch zwischen dem Einsparen von CO2-Emissionen und industrieller Produktion aufl√∂sen‚Äú, sagte Robert Habeck (B√ºndnis 90/Die Gr√ºnen), Minister f√ºr Wirtschaft und Klimaschutz, im Deutschlandfunk.
.
Die Gro√üe Koalition sei diese Aufgabe nur halbherzig angegangen. ‚ÄûDie Wirtschaftsfelder der Zukunft werden global gesehen klimaneutrale Felder sein‚Äú, betonte der Vize-Kanzler. Die Welt arbeite daran, CO2-neutral zu werden, wenn auch in unterschiedlichen Geschwindigkeiten, Ans√§tzen und Technologien. Kein Klimaschutz sei daher die teuerste Antwort.
.
Den Link zum Interview findet Ihr in unserer Bio
.
.
.
#klimaschutz #co2emissionen #klimawandel #wirtschaft #politik #dlf @robert.habeck

Description:
At least 208 people are now known to have died after a powerful storm struck the Philippines on Thursday, police are quoted as saying by local media.

Super Typhoon Rai - with winds of about 195km/h (120mph) - sent some 300,000 people running for safety when it hit the country's south-eastern islands.

At least 239 people were injured and 52 others have been reported missing by local police.

"Homes, hospitals, school and community buildings have been ripped to shreds,‚Äù the chair of the Philippines Red Cross, Richard Gordon, told the BBC.

Rescue teams have described scenes of "complete carnage". But establishing the scale of the losses is difficult, as communication to a number of areas has been cut off.

Tap the link in our bio for more on this story, and how climate change may have caused typhoons to become more powerful.

(üì∑ Getty Images, EPA)

#Philippines #SuperTyphoonRai #BBCNews

Description:
‚Äã‚ÄãRising from the Antarctic is an alarm about climate change.

Around the frozen continent, a vast current circles the world, acting as Earth‚Äôs climate engine. New science is revealing the power the current holds over the future. Ice shelves are in retreat and, as they melt, researchers are alarmed at what they‚Äôre learning. They have discovered that global warming is affecting the Antarctic current in complex ways, and these shifts could complicate the ability to fight climate change in the future. 

Read more about the Antarctic Circumpolar Current by tapping the link in our bio. Video by Jeremy White, Henry Fountain and @pete_.r

Description:
#YearInPictures Special Print Section, Dec. 19, 2021

In 2021, our photographers captured the world around us all. Their lens bore witness to the shadow cast by a pandemic, an insurrection at the U.S. Capitol, falling governments, a postponed Olympic Games, devastating wildfires and the effects of climate change.

‚ÄúThis period has underscored the special communicative power of the image, as well as the risks and hardship that photographers take so they can show us the world,‚Äù Meaghan Looram, the director of photography at The Times, writes. 

‚ÄúPhotographers must be there to do their work, to bear witness firsthand. They must be in the hospital ICU, in the scrum of the protest, at the front line of the conflict, close to the wildfire, inside the homes of the struggling parents, or wading into the floodwaters of the storm,‚Äù Looram writes. ‚ÄúWe are the beneficiaries of their courage and their commitment, and the connections they make with others.‚Äù
‚Å£
To see the full #YearInPictures, tap the link in our bio. Cover photo by @maxwhittaker

Description:
Bolivia potentially finds itself among the newly anointed winners in the global hunt for the raw materials needed to move the world away from oil, natural gas and coal in the fight against climate change.

Bolivia, a nation of 12 million people, has a quarter of the world‚Äôs known lithium, a basic component of lithium-ion batteries. Demand for this lightweight metal is expected to grow exponentially over the next decade to power an expanding fleet of electric vehicles. Eight foreign companies have been competing in recent months to establish pilot lithium projects in the South American country, including four from China and one from Russia. Both countries have had friendlier relations with Bolivia‚Äôs government than the U.S. has.

Just as wildcatters have long sought riches prospecting for oil, the clean energy revolution is spawning a wave of gritty entrepreneurs who hope to ride a new boom, vaulting themselves into the intersection of geopolitics and climate change.

Tap the link in our bio to learn how a Texas energy start-up is hoping to beat out Chinese and Russian industrial giants in unlocking mineral riches that could one day power tens of millions of electric vehicles. Photos by @meridithkohut

Description:
‚ÄúYo creo que es un grave problema, s√≠, pero no el fin del mundo; y si lo afrontamos como si lo fuera, no lo solucionaremos del mejor modo‚Äù.

Bj√∏rn Lomborg ha alzado la bandera de la moderaci√≥n frente al cambio clim√°tico y la reacci√≥n en contra ha sido radical. Lo acusan de venderse a los intereses del lobby del carbono y de sesgar datos. √âl responde, a√∫n con m√°s moderaci√≥n, que el Copenhagen Consensus, del que es presidente, es estrictamente un grupo de cient√≠ficos y expertos y que en absoluto son negacionistas: el cambio clim√°tico es una grave amenaza, pero no el fin del mundo acelerado que profetiza el activismo.
 
M√°s que predicar la calma, recuerda que la tecnolog√≠a ha causado el problema y la tecnolog√≠a puede solucionarlo si invertimos m√°s y mejor.
 
LV - ¬øNiega que cada d√≠a hay m√°s inundaciones, sequ√≠as y se derriten glaciares y polos?

BL - Si mira a las v√≠ctimas de esos desastres, ver√° que hay menos que hace un siglo.

LV - ¬øCu√°ntas menos?

BL - ¬°Muchas menos! En 1920 cerca de medio mill√≥n de personas perecieron en esos desastres clim√°ticos. Este a√±o, la proyecci√≥n razonable es que acaben muriendo solo 7.000.

LV - Hay quien discute sus cifras.

BL - ¬øSabe por qu√© mueren menos por cat√°strofes naturales? No es por el clima, sino la tecnolog√≠a que nos empodera frente a la naturaleza.

LV - Pero las aguas subir√°n m√°s y m√°s...

BL - Nuestras tecnolog√≠as tambi√©n mejorar√°n. Es un problema, pero no el fin del mundo, y convertirlo en el √∫nico problema lo empeora. En realidad no muere cada vez m√°s gente por las cat√°strofes naturales, sino menos.

LV - ¬øVuelve a proponer no hacer nada?

BL - Propongo invertir m√°s en tecnolog√≠a, innovaci√≥n, ciencia... que salvaron del hambre con la revoluci√≥n verde a 1.000 millones de personas y ahora frenar√°n el calentamiento.

LV - ¬øQu√© tecnolog√≠as?

BL - No solo las nucleares, sino bater√≠as, solares, e√≥lica, la captura de carbono... Hay que invertir en todas para que haya una definitiva.

Lee la entrevista completa de Llu√≠s Amiguet a Bj√∏rn Lomborg en el enlace de la biograf√≠a. üì≤ https://bit.ly/3GGinTu #LaContra #entrevista #Bj√∏rnLomborg #cambioclim√°tico #tecnolog√≠a
ImageText: V "El cambio clim√°tico es una grave amenaza, pero no el fin del mundo" Bjorn Lomborg, preside el Copenhagen Consensus de cient√≠ficos y expertos

Estas cuatro misiones para monitorear el planeta ser√°n: #TROPICS, utilizar√° seis peque√±os sat√©lites para proporcionar mediciones r√°pidas y mejoradas de ciclones tropicales. #EMIT, rastrear√° el origen y la composici√≥n del polvo mineral que puede afectar el clima, los ecosistemas, la calidad del aire y la salud humana con un espectr√≥metro de im√°genes a bordo de la Estaci√≥n Espacial Internacional. Description:
First came the fires, and then the floods. Australia‚Äôs extreme weather has been supercharged by climate change.

Two years ago, the fields outside Christina Southwell‚Äôs family home near the cotton capital of Australia looked like a dusty, brown desert as drought-fueled wildfires burned to the north and south.

Last week, after record-breaking rains, muddy floodwaters surrounded her, along with the stench of rotting crops. She had been trapped for days with just her cat and still didn‚Äôt know when the sludge would recede.

Life on the land has always been hard in Australia, but the past few years have delivered one extreme after another, demanding new levels of resilience and highlighting the rising costs of a warming planet. For many Australians, moderate weather ‚Äî a pleasant summer, a year without a state of emergency ‚Äî increasingly feels like a luxury.

The Black Summer bush fires of 2019 and 2020 were the worst in Australia‚Äôs recorded history. This year, many of the same areas that suffered through those epic blazes endured the wettest, coldest November since at least 1900. Hundreds of people, across several states, have been forced to evacuate. 

And with a second year of the weather phenomenon known as La Ni√±a in full swing, meteorologists are predicting even more flooding for Australia‚Äôs east coast.
 
Tap the link in our bio to read more about Australia‚Äôs extreme climate change. Photos by @mattabbottphoto

El term√≥metro marc√≥ los 38 grados cent√≠grados. Lo ha confirmado la ONU para hacer un llamamiento de alarma sobre la intensidad del calentamiento global. Muestra de ello son tambi√©n los incendios forestales provocados por el calor extremo en la tundra norte de Rusia. 2020 fue uno de los tres a√±os m√°s c√°lidos desde que se tienen registros. Description:
Todo apunta a que continuar√° el alza en el precio del pan, que ya ha subido un 7% entre enero y noviembre de 2021, seg√∫n el Instituto Nacional de Estad√≠sticas.

La escasez en la producci√≥n del trigo, condicionada por la crisis clim√°tica y por problemas de log√≠stica, han afectado directamente en el precio del alimento consumido por la gran mayor√≠a de los chilenos.

Sergio Schmidt, gerente general de Comercializadora de Trigo S.A., advirti√≥ en El Mercurio que "en pa√≠ses relevantes para el mercado nacional, tales como Estados Unidos y Canad√°, se registran ca√≠das (de trigo) tanto en su producci√≥n como en su oferta exportable, que inciden en los niveles de precio".

El directivo de la empresa estatal destac√≥ que en la regi√≥n Metropolitana se registran valores de entre $31 y $32 mil por saco de 100 kilos de trigo, precios un 48% mayores a los registrados el a√±o 2020.

"Por ahora no se aprecian cambios sustanciales en los fundamentales de oferta y demanda que permitan proyectar un ajuste bajista. Y a la vez, es esperable que los fletes internacionales sigan altos", a√±adi√≥ Schmidt.

El empresario adelant√≥ que "en el mercado interno se debiera observar una activa comercializaci√≥n en cosecha, donde los poderes de compra tratar√°n de asegurar el producto nacional".

En tanto, el director regional de U.S. Wheat Assocaites, Miguel Galdos, explic√≥ al citado medio que el avance de la sequ√≠a tambi√©n ha influido en el alza del producto: "Chile tambi√©n ha disminuido su producci√≥n de trigo porque algunos productores han tenido que reconvertirse a otros cultivos m√°s rentables".

Finalmente, el presidente de la Federaci√≥n Chilena de Industriales Panaderos, Marcelo G√°lvez, asegur√≥ en el matutino que se est√° consumiendo m√°s de lo que se siembra, lo que ha provocado un alza de la harina entre un 25% al 30%.

"Creo que en los pr√≥ximos meses este precio deber√≠a estabilizarse porque va a entrar la cosecha nacional, pero es incierto", consign√≥.

Un grupo de creativos australianos dise√±a la "Caja Negra del Planeta" ¬∑ En caso de una futura cat√°strofe clim√°tica global, un grupo de creativos australianos ha decidido dise√±ar la llamada "Caja Negra del Planeta". Ser√° construida en 2022 en la rec√≥ndita costa oeste de la isla australiana de Tasmania. Se trata de una caja negra indestructible constru√≠da con acero de 7 cent√≠metros de grosor y de imposible acceso.  Estar√° conectada a Internet y usar√° un algoritmo para recopilar datos relacionados con el cambio clim√°tico como el aumento de la temperatura o el gasto energ√©tico. Se alzar√° con el objetivo de dejar evidencia de todos los pasos que la humanidad ha tomado para dar pie a un desastre clim√°tico. Adem√°s, pretende concienciar a los l√≠deres pol√≠ticos porque todas las acciones que tomen en cuanto al clima ser√°n registradas. Sin embargo, tambien servir√° como herramienta de aprendizaje ya que todos los datos podr√°n ser utilizados por escuelas y universidades. En definitiva una idea brillante que nos anima a ayudar a nuestro planeta. 

#Clima #CajaNegraDelPlaneta #Tasmania

La autora parte el libro comentando los conceptos b√°sicos para entender c√≥mo funciona el oc√©ano y el rol que juega la biodiversidad, adem√°s justifica la relevancia que tiene en la crisis clim√°tica actual. Description:
La vicepresidenta segunda del Gobierno y principal dirigente institucional de Unidas Podemos, Yolanda D√≠az, se ha reunido este s√°bado con el papa Francisco en el Vaticano en un encuentro que ha sido especialmente largo y ‚Äúmuy cordial‚Äù y ‚Äúemocionante‚Äù, seg√∫n fuentes cercanas a la tambi√©n titular de Trabajo. La conversaci√≥n ha durado 40 minutos ‚Äîalgo m√°s que la cita que tuvo Francisco con el presidente del Gobierno, Pedro S√°nchez, en octubre de 2020‚Äî y en ella se ha abordado, seg√∫n el equipo de la vicepresidenta, el cambio clim√°tico y la importancia del ‚Äútrabajo decente‚Äù para mejorar la vida de los espa√±oles. La visita de D√≠az ha sido como representante del Gobierno y no a t√≠tulo personal, remarcan las mismas fuentes. El Pont√≠fice no acostumbra a recibir a solas a ministros que ‚Äïcomo es el caso de Yolanda D√≠az‚Äï no est√©n tratando asuntos relacionados directamente con la Iglesia. La visita comenz√≥ a gestarse hace dos meses, durante el √∫ltimo viaje de la vicepresidenta segunda a Roma para tratar asuntos de empleo con su hom√≥logo italiano, Andrea Orlando. Pedro S√°nchez, seg√∫n se√±ala su entorno, estuvo en todo momento informado de la cita, que finalmente se ha producido este s√°bado a las once de la ma√±ana en la Biblioteca del Palacio Apost√≥lico. D√≠az y el Papa comparten una visi√≥n bastante parecida sobre el mundo del trabajo y la econom√≠a. De hecho, en la enc√≠clica Fratelli Tutti pueden leerse algunos pasajes aplicables al modo de entender el empleo de la ministra de Trabajo. Francisco se ha interesado tambi√©n por la situaci√≥n en la que se encuentra la reforma laboral en Espa√±a ‚Äîel entorno de D√≠az se√±al√≥ tras la reuni√≥n que ‚Äúest√° muy avanzada‚Äù‚Äî, por las cifras del paro y por la precariedad y las f√≥rmulas puestas en marcha para combatirla.

Description:
¬°S√≠! Pero no la humana, aunque s√≠ la del ave albatros. Las parejas de albatros de las Islas Malvinas se est√°n separando por el aumento de temperatura en el oc√©ano, seg√∫n descubri√≥ un estudio encabezado por la Universidad de Lisboa, la Universidad de Montana y otras instituciones. 

Los expertos revelaron que el agua m√°s caliente en la superficie no se mezcla lo suficiente con el agua m√°s fr√≠a debajo del mar, provocando que menos nutrientes alcancen la superficie y que por ello los albatros tengan una disminuci√≥n en la producci√≥n de huevos. 

Estas condiciones afectan a los niveles hormonales y aumentan el estr√©s en las aves, seg√∫n estiman los autores. 

Es por ello que, aunque los albatros son aves mon√≥gamas con parejas muy estables, el cambio clim√°tico parece "afectar indirectamente a su separaci√≥n a trav√©s de cambios en las tasas demogr√°ficas". 

¬øQu√© te parece? 

#Albatros #CambioClim√°tico #Noticia #Noticias #UnoTV

Description:
Tropical forests, a vital home to animal life and slowing down global warming, continue to disappear at an alarming rate. But a new study found that there is hope for already destroyed forests to almost fully regrow ‚Äî if humans leave them alone. 

Old-growth forests are rich in biodiversity, as their durability and stability allow numerous plant and animal species to thrive. But because of climate change and human interaction, these unburdened forests have become rarer. Scientists said their findings could be a "low-cost, natural solution" to help. 

Read more about their findings at the link in our bio.
ImageText: Destroyed tropical forests could almost fully regrow if humans leave them alone for 20 years, study says

Description:
Con su voz amable, discurso tranquilo y serena fotogenia, nadie podr√≠a pensar que ana Carrasco sea conocida como ‚Äúla fil√≥sofa del mal‚Äù. Tambi√©n profesora de Filosof√≠a en la Complutense de Madrid, reconoce que sus inquietudes la llevan a centrarse en el ‚Äúlado oscuro‚Äù de la realidad. "Al hablar del mal tendemos a pensar en situaciones muy cruentas, que nos permiten justificarlo, pero no pensamos en el mal de las peque√±as cosas, en cuando tratamos mal a quienes tenemos cerca", explica.

LV- ¬øPodemos evitar hacer el mal?

AC- Si cruzo por la calle, usted me saluda y yo no le contesto, le molestar√©. Esa torpeza, que tal vez sea involuntaria, puede hacerle da√±o. Son peque√±os gestos que hacen del mundo un lugar m√°s inh√≥spito. El mal est√° m√°s cerca de nuestras vidas de lo que pensamos.

LV- ¬øEl malo nace o se hace?

AC- Ninguna de las dos cosas. Estamos acostumbrados a pensar en t√©rminos antag√≥nicos, en dualidades, pero quiz√° sea un poco m√°s complejo.

LV - A nuestros hijos les ense√±amos a distinguir entre bien y mal.

AC- Lo que est√° bien genera equilibrio, cierta armon√≠a. Y el mal es un acto que genera un da√±o innecesario a otra persona, un desequilibrio. Pero tambi√©n hay otra dimensi√≥n: el mal necesario.

LV- Anta√±o todo era pecado: hoy, ¬øel pecado ya no es lo que era?

AC- La sociedad tan secularizada en la que vivimos no lo es tanto. Creo que tiene unos valores cristianos mucho m√°s interiorizados de lo que parece. Por ejemplo, cuando decimos que el cambio clim√°tico o la pandemia es un castigo o un aviso de la naturaleza, lo que est√° denotando ese argumento es que creemos que el hombre es malo por definici√≥n y que alguien nos tiene que castigar. Es la misma estructura, una manera de pensar muy similar, de los argumentos religiosos.

‚úçLee la entrevista completa de Teresa Amiguet para #LaContra en nuestra bio https://bit.ly/3y6ZYw0 #entrevistas #filosofia
ImageText: V "El mal siempre est√° m√°s cerca de lo que pensamos" Ana Carrasco-Conde, fil√≥sofa, publica 'Decir el mal: comprender no es justificar'

Description:
Los analistas pol√≠ticos Tom√°s Duval y Marta Lagos comentaron, este jueves en #LaSemanaPol√≠tica, el panorama presidencial de cara a la segunda vuelta del 19 de diciembre, entre @joseantoniokast (Frente Social Cristiano) y @gabrielboric (#AprueboDignidad).

Uno de los puntos que ha sido discutido en los √∫ltimos d√≠as, es la propuesta del candidato de Apruebo Dignidad de fortalecer la red ferroviaria del pa√≠s, lo que ha generado un conflicto con #loscamioneros. 

Al respecto, Lagos dijo que "esto explota de esta manera porque el #Transantiago se ha comido por d√©cadas toda la discusi√≥n del transporte en Chile (...). El tema del transporte nunca ha sido parte de la agenda. 

Tenemos una pol√≠tica de #vivienda que no considera el #transporte, que hace que la gente tenga que estar cuatro horas arriba de un transporte para ir y volver al trabajo (...). El transporte es uno de esos temas subsumidos en la ausencia de brillo, que salta a la luz porque la gente tiene problemas de transporte en todo Chile. Nosotros no podemos demorarnos en el transporte, porque es parte central del desarrollo".

Por su parte, Duval se√±al√≥ que "lo principal de aqu√≠ es que tenemos presente el cambio clim√°tico, necesitamos energ√≠a limpia en el transporte. Eso hizo que este tema del #tren reviviera. Hoy uno mira la ciudad de Santiago, y el Transantiago tambi√©n se est√° transformando en buses el√©ctricos. Ah√≠ hay un desarrollo, por eso la importancia del tema.

Pero al mismo tiempo, como toda pol√≠tica, va a golpear a grupos de inter√©s muy precisos, a los camioneros, al gremio del transporte. Al momento no hemos escuchado una palabra de las empresas de buses (...). 

Es una idea que a m√≠ me parece muy interesante a desarrollar en un futuro, y esto debiera quedar m√°s all√° de un Gobierno, porque no es la labor de un Gobierno, aqu√≠ estamos hablando de una pol√≠tica de Estado".

President Joe Biden is looking to harness the power of the federal government to fight climate change by requiring federal agencies to buy electric vehicles, modernizing federal buildings and changing how the government buys electricity.

Biden signed an executive order Wednesday that aims to use the federal government‚Äôs buying power to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 65 percent by 2030. The directive would put the government on a path to achieving net-zero emissions by 2050.

Description:
Estados Unidos deber√≠a estudiar c√≥mo utilizar los oc√©anos del mundo para eliminar de la atm√≥sfera el di√≥xido de carbono que calienta el planeta mediante m√©todos como el cultivo de algas o la manipulaci√≥n de nutrientes en el agua, seg√∫n un informe publicado el mi√©rcoles.

El informe llega en medio de una toma de conciencia cada vez mayor por parte de los cient√≠ficos y Gobiernos del mundo sobre el hecho de que reducir las emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero procedentes de actividades como la quema de combustibles f√≥siles no ser√° suficiente para evitar los peores impactos del cambio clim√°tico.

Tambi√©n hay que eliminar y almacenar enormes vol√∫menes de carbono mediante la aplicaci√≥n de estrategias que a√∫n no han demostrado su eficacia a gran escala.

El informe de las Academias Nacionales de Ciencias, Ingenier√≠a y Medicina se√±ala que los oc√©anos son un √°rea prometedora para estudiar debido a su tama√±o y capacidad para almacenar carbono.

Seg√∫n el documento, ya existen algunas t√©cnicas para acelerar la capacidad de absorci√≥n de carbono de los oc√©anos, que deben ser examinadas.

"Si la sociedad quiere estar bien informada, si estas decisiones deben tomarse en alg√∫n momento, necesitamos mejorar una base de conocimientos imparciales", dijo Scott Doney, un cient√≠fico de la Universidad de Virginia que ayud√≥ a dirigir el estudio.

Description:
"Our culture is disappearing".

Climate breakdown is crushing the way people have previously lived for hundreds of years.

As part of our push to hear more from those on the frontlines, we have been profiling individuals whose lives have been changed beyond recognition. From Taymyr in Russia, this is Gennadiy Shukin's story:

I was born in 1962 in a family of deer herders in Taymyr, on a peninsula in the very far north of Russia.

I am part of the Dolgan community: we are an Indigenous Russian group and there are around 6,000 left of us living in the tundra.

Growing up, the Soviet Union tried to deny us our traditional way of life, but since then climate change has become the biggest challenge to our survival.

Our community lives by hunting, fishing and herding deer. Scientists say that Taymyr has the most rapid temperature increase in Russia, and we can really feel it.

Because of the warmer winters, we have seen that deer are giving birth earlier in the year. Many are born too weak and don‚Äôt survive the long journeys they have to make. This means there is much less deer for us to hunt and it hurts the whole ecosystem.

Rivers and lakes that we use for fishing have also started to dry out. Others are too polluted after all the big oil and gas plants have sprung up over the years in our lands. Some days we don‚Äôt catch any fish at all.

For generations, we have sold the food we caught to local towns and cities to buy basic products like sugar and wheat. Without animals, we cannot survive.

Big craters are also forming because the Arctic permafrost is starting to melt under our feet. This means the routes that we have used for decades to travel, hunt and fish have to be adjusted as whole roads have sunk. It is also dangerous as you never know where the next crater will form.

The youth sees that climate change makes our traditional way of life impossible and they are forced to move to the bigger cities to find jobs, which are often low-paid. Our culture is disappearing.

#taymyr #–¥–æ–ª–≥–∞–Ω—ã #dolgans #russia #climatecrisis #climatechange #cop26

El proyecto, denominado ‚ÄúEarth's Black Box‚Äù, recopilar√° continuamente "cientos de datos, mediciones e interacciones relacionadas con la salud de nuestro planeta" que "se almacenar√°n de forma segura para las generaciones futuras", seg√∫n explican en la p√°gina web del proyecto: earthsblackbox.com 

"La idea es que, si la Tierra colapsa por el cambio clim√°tico, este dispositivo de grabaci√≥n indestructible estar√° ah√≠ para quien haya quedado aprenda de los errores", dijo el director creativo de la agencia australiana Clemenger BBDO, Jim Curtis, a ABC.

Description:
The Norwegian archipelago of Svalbard is ‚Äúperhaps the closest thing we have to a ticking clock,‚Äù the photographer Marcus Westberg writes for @nytimestravel. 

Viewed from the sea, Svalbard seems to be the very epitome of wilderness: a vast expanse of largely untouched water, ice and islands, free from human habitation and infrastructure, aside from the occasional passing boat.

Unfortunately, climate change all but guarantees an eventual (and probably fairly imminent) collapse of what is an exceptionally fragile ecosystem, Westberg writes. 

The 29 national parks, as well as other protected areas that cover two-thirds of the Svalbard archipelago, can protect its wild inhabitants from hunting and pollution, but not from increasing water and air temperatures. Every year brings further news of ever-shrinking glaciers and reduced ice cover ‚Äî ice upon which the 3,000 polar bears who live in the Svalbard archipelago and Barents Sea depend for their survival.

Tourism, as is so often the case, is simultaneously part of the problem and part of the solution. 

Tap the link in our bio to read the full story. Photos and text by @marcuswestbergphotography

‚≠ï El candidato del Frente Social Cristiano, @joseantoniokast, present√≥ un nuevo programa de gobierno, el que, seg√∫n sus propias palabras, recoge con "alegr√≠a y humildad" cada uno de los aportes realizados por todos los que se han sumado a la campa√±a.

De acuerdo a lo se√±alado por el aspirante a La Moneda, el plan "gira en torno a la persona, porque eso debe ser el centro de todas las pol√≠ticas p√∫blicas. Nuestro objetivo es la vida digna para todos los chilenos‚Äù.

1. Recuperar la paz, recuperar el orden y el Estado de Derecho.
2. Recuperar la econom√≠a para que haya m√°s trabajo, mejores sueldos y recursos que permita resolver los problemas sociales que tenemos pendientes.

Description:
Oregon produces roughly 40% of the nation's Christmas tree supply, according to the National Christmas Tree Association. But this past summer's heat waves have resulted in losses of Christmas tree crops in the state, as well as an increase in prices.

"There are literally fields with hundreds of acres of dead seedlings. Just 100% mortality across the entire field. If you produce a million trees a year, you don't have time to deal with that," says Tom Norby, a grower who is the president of the Oregon Christmas Tree Growers Association. 

"This is a global warming event that's impacting Christmas," Norby says.

More at the link in our bio.

Description:
Bill Jacobs is an ecologist and Catholic who lives on Long Island and believes that humans can fight climate change in their own backyards.

Many of the lawns in Jacobs‚Äôs neighborhood are mowed and trimmed with military precision. He says people need to reconnect with nature and experience the sort of spiritual transcendence he feels in a forest, on a mountain or amid the bounty of his own suburban yard. It‚Äôs a feeling that, for him, is akin to feeling close to God. 

‚ÄúWe need something greater than people,‚Äù said Jacobs, who worked at the Nature Conservancy for nine years before joining a nonprofit that tackles invasive species ‚Äî plants, animals and pathogens that squeeze out native varieties. ‚ÄúWe need a calling outside of ourselves, to some sort of higher power, to something higher than ourselves to preserve life on earth.‚Äù

Jacobs teamed up with a fellow Catholic ecologist, Kathleen Hoenke, to start the St. Kateri Habitats initiative, which encourages the creation of wildlife-friendly gardens that feature native plants and offer a place to reflect and meditate. They have since added an Indigenous peoples program and two Indigenous women to their board. Jacobs wants to spread his ethos around the world. 

Tap the link in our bio to read more about his vision for mitigating the climate crisis and addressing biodiversity collapse close to home. Photos by @karstenmoran

Description:
The Cop26 climate talks may now feel like a distant memory now, but this is the time where the real work must happen. 

Native Alaskan climate activist @charitieropati has been highlighting the urgent need to centre Black and Indigenous voices when we have conversations about the climate breakdown.

"My great grandfather predicted that the ice was rotting, that's how he described it [to my mother] in Yup'ik," says Charitie.

The 20-year-old @columbia student spoke to us about her people, who rely on Alaska's ice and sea for food, and how an intimate relationship and respect for the land makes Indigenous knowledge so crucial in caring for the future of the planet.

"It's hard for settlers to hear this," she says, "but one of the biggest things to combat climate change is giving sovereignty back to Indigenous peoples over their land. Giving land back."

This is the last episode in our new mini-series, which we created to help platform underrepresented Indigenous voices at a time when their knowledge and traditions could mean the difference of creating a habitable planet.

What climate issues would you like to see us address next?

Video: @neelamtailor + @nikhitachulani

Description:
Much of Brazil‚Äôs vast northeast is, in effect, turning into a desert ‚Äî a process called desertification that is worsening across the planet.

The country‚Äôs northeast, the world‚Äôs most densely populated drylands, with roughly 53 million people, is among the most at risk of desertification. And things are becoming worse. The region had its longest drought on record from 2012 through 2017, and this year, another drought desiccated much of Brazil.

Climate change is one culprit. But local residents, faced with harsh economic realities, have also made short-term decisions to get by ‚Äî like clearing trees for livestock and extracting clay for a newborn tile industry ‚Äî that have carried long-term consequences. 

Desertification, which is playing out from northern China to the American Southwest, does not generally lead to rolling sand dunes that evoke the Sahara. Instead, higher temperatures and less rain combine with deforestation and overfarming to leave the soil parched, lifeless and nearly devoid of nutrients, unable to support crops or even grass to feed livestock. ‚ÄúFifty years from now, there won‚Äôt be a soul living here,‚Äù said In√°cio Batista Dantas (second photo), a farmer, whose family has lived on the land in Carna√∫ba dos Dantas for more than 150 years. During a difficult dry season in 2010, Dantas, 80, said his family decided to sell the mud in an old reservoir to a company making clay tiles so they could feed themselves and their cattle.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about how desertification is affecting Brazil. Photos by @victormoriyama

Description:
Nine years after Hurricane Sandy, residents of Lower Manhattan are still vulnerable to rising seas. The fight over a plan to protect them shows why progress is so hard.
 
The storm caused tens of billions of dollars in damage all across the region and killed more than 100 people. After surveying the wreckage, President Barack Obama turned to Shaun Donovan, his secretary of housing and urban development, and teams of architects and engineers were invited to conceive creative flood-protection proposals in collaboration with the affected communities.
 
The ensuing plan imagined a redesigned East River Park that could withstand flooding from future Sandy-level events. But behind closed doors, city agencies later concluded that the plan was not feasible. So City Hall unveiled an alternative design, which would cost New Yorkers $1.45 billion. It required razing the entirety of East River Park, and then covering nearly all its 50-odd acres with eight to 10 feet of landfill while keeping Con Edison‚Äôs power lines accessible.

A group led by professors, artists and other Lower Manhattan residents started organizing protests. They argued that the city‚Äôs new plan did not go far enough to address the effects of climate change, and that demolishing the park with the shade of a thousand mature trees would leave the neighborhood without precious green space for years. But they also wanted something to protect them from the flooding of future Sandys ‚Äî and started to accept the merits of the city‚Äôs plan. A project devised to build community trust and overcome political gridlock seemed to be fracturing the community instead.

Construction has begun, but now, nearly a decade after Sandy, the Lower East Side is still vulnerable. 
 
What does it mean to save a neighborhood? Tap the link in our bio to read more from The New York Times‚Äôs architecture critic, @michael_kimmelman. Photos by @arnold_daniel

Description:
From @guardian_us: why is meaningful action to avert the climate crisis proving so difficult? It is, at least in part, because of ads.

The fossil fuel industry has perpetrated a multi-decade, multibillion dollar disinformation, propaganda and lobbying campaign to delay climate action by confusing the public and policymakers about the climate crisis and its solutions.

They‚Äôd now like us to forget many of them. But seeing the adverts in their shameless glory is a crucial part of understanding how we got here, and the half-truths, distortions and outright lies we're still being fed.

In 1962 Humble Oil (now ExxonMobil), released perhaps one of the most outrageous adverts ever made. ‚ÄúEach day," it boasted, "Humble supplies enough energy to melt 7 million tons of glacier!‚Äù

It was an early example of Big Oil's desperate push against climate science, which only grew louder and more cynical in the following decades, before pivoting towards greenwashing and "personal responsibility" narratives in the 2000s - and companies have been distorting reality in the 2020s too.

Swipe to see our visual timeline of the adverts, and click üëÜ for the link in our bio to read the full visual guide - including the remarkable detail of where exactly these ads have appeared.

#climatecrisis #bigoil #climatescience #fossilfuels #climatedenial #climatecatastrophe #cleanenergy #energycrisis #usnews

The narratives highlighted here are a selection of ‚Äúdiscourses of climate denial and delay‚Äù previously identified by the authors and other researchers. The advertisements selected to illustrate these discourses were identified by the authors based on a review of dozens of peer-reviewed studies, journalistic investigations, white papers, ad libraries, newspaper archives, social media reports and lawsuits.

Description:
Dangerous mining conditions plague the Democratic Republic of Congo, home to the world‚Äôs largest supply of cobalt, a critical ingredient in electric cars.

Batteries containing cobalt reduce overheating in electric cars and extend their range, but the metal has become known as ‚Äúthe blood diamond of batteries‚Äù because of its high price and the perilous conditions in Congo.

Albert Yuma Mulimbi (fourth photo) is a longtime power broker in Congo and chairman of a government agency that works with international mining companies to tap the nation‚Äôs copper and cobalt reserves, used in the effort to curb global warming.

Yuma‚Äôs professed goal is to turn Congo into a reliable supplier of cobalt and to help the country shed its reputation for tolerating an underworld where children are put to work and unskilled and ill-equipped diggers of all ages are injured or killed.

But to many in Congo and the U.S., Yuma himself is a problem. As chairman of G√©camines, Congo‚Äôs state-owned mining enterprise, he has been accused of helping to divert billions of dollars in revenues, according to confidential State Department legal filings reviewed by The New York Times and interviews with a dozen current and former officials in both countries.

üá™üá∏ Im S√ºdwesten Spaniens gibt es eine europaweit einzigartige Landschaft mit unendlich vielen B√§umen und zahllosen wilden Tieren: die Dehesa. 

‚ñ∂Ô∏è"Erlebnis Erde" jetzt in der @ARDMediathek!

√úber Jahrhunderte hinweg haben Menschen in der Dehesa ein Weideland f√ºr Nutztiere geschaffen. Aber auch zahllose wilde Tiere und die st√§ndige Einwirkung des mediterranen Klimas haben diese Gegend mit gestaltet. 

üêá Die weichen B√∂den mit zum Teil √ºppigem Unterholz liefern einen perfekten Lebensraum f√ºr Wildkaninchen. Allerdings ern√§hren sich mehr als 30 Raubtier- und Vogelarten von ihnen. Daher w√§re ohne Kaninchen ein Leben in der Dehesa unvorstellbar. Zum Gl√ºck bekommen sie bis zu f√ºnf Mal pro Jahr Nachwuchs und ihre Tierart kann dadurch √ºberleben.

ü¶Ö Trotzdem sind auch die Raubtiere extrem gef√§hrdet. Luchse und Kaiseradler w√§ren fast ausgestorben. Doch die Anwesenheit von Menschen machte die Gegend zu einer Schutzzone. Und diese Tiere wurden gerettet. Gef√§hrdet sind aber auch die W√§lder ‚Äì durch Seuchen und durch den Klimawandel. Aber zum Gl√ºck wachen alle Bewohner der Dehesa noch immer √ºber ihr Revier. Ein Anlass zur Hoffnung auf das Weiterbestehen dieser einzigartigen Region auf der Iberischen Halbinsel.

Un equipo internacional de investigadores ha reconstruido la evoluci√≥n del calentamiento del Oc√©ano √Årtico.

As√≠, constataron que las aguas de este fr√°gil ecosistema llevan calent√°ndose desde principios del siglo pasado, varias d√©cadas antes de lo que suger√≠an los registros.

El estudio, publicado en Science Advances, concluye que el √Årtico se ha ido calentando debido a la entrada de agua m√°s caliente desde el oc√©ano Atl√°ntico, un fen√≥meno conocido como Atlantificaci√≥n.

Los autores del estudio alertaron que en el futuro ‚Äúpodr√≠amos esperar una mayor atlantizaci√≥n del √Årtico debido al cambio clim√°tico‚Äù. Por eso, sostienen que sus resultados tambi√©n exponen ‚Äúun posible fallo en los modelos clim√°ticos, ya que no reproducen esta atlantizaci√≥n temprana a principios del siglo pasado‚Äù.

Description:
This is a story about a tree, a fisherman and a queen.

Each is profoundly connected to a South Carolina coastal community threatened by rising sea levels caused by climate change. And each uniquely represents what's at stake: the lives and livelihoods of those who call this area home.

The signs of the impact of rising seas levels are both subtle and clear, and taken together, point to the looming crisis climate scientists have been describing ‚Äî the kind that world leaders who gathered in Scotland at a global climate summit this week are trying to solve. Representatives from nearly 200 countries are negotiating efforts to cut global emissions to stem the rising sea levels. 

Tap the link in our bio for more.

(Images: @kcallop ‚Ä¢ Cameron Pollack for NPR)

Description:
Not long ago, the red sandstone walls of the Dolores River Canyon in southwestern Colorado towered over roaring rapids that teemed with native fish.

Now, it's largely empty.

Drought compounded by climate change has left the once robust river a ribbon of cobblestones, a trickle of water and small, shallow pools.

"It's really an unfortunate and tragic, incredible canyon with sort of a meek river that was once really a giant, wonderful symbol of the Wild West," said Jim White, an aquatic biologist for Colorado Parks and Wildlife.

Low water levels in the river leave fish like bluehead sucker and roundtail chub with nowhere to go, White says.

Tap the link in our bio for more.

(Images: @sharonchischillyy ‚Ä¢ Sharon Chischilly for NPR)

No en vano, 6 de cada 10 osos polares viven aqu√≠ y desde 2008, se considera una especie amenazada ya que el cambio clim√°tico reduce cada a√±o su h√°bitat natural.

Description:
üìö"On Tuesday evening the shortlists for the Costa Book Awards were announced. Of the four works shortlisted for the Novel of the Year award, one is about climate change, one is about war and migration, and one is about racial injustice (and all four are written by women). ‚Å†
‚Å†
"The First Novel category is also dominated by issue-led fiction: race, female identity, end-of-the-world anxiety (and three of the four are written by women). If one job of fiction is to reflect the world in which we live, it‚Äôs not surprising to see so many novels actively engaged in the big issues of our day.‚Å†
‚Å†
"Yet the eagerness of the Costa to reward social engagement in its novelists makes me a bit uneasy. Granted, there are some terrific novels on both shortlists: AK Blackmore‚Äôs debut, The Manningtree Witches, is a magnificent recreation of the 17th-century Essex witch trials. But I‚Äôd argue a good few others have been selected because of the piety of their subject matter rather than for their consummate storytelling skills."‚Å†
‚Å†
Read more at the #linkinbio‚Å†
‚Å†
#reading #book #read #library
ImageText: The crisis at the heart of literary fiction

It‚Äôs easy to despair at the climate crisis, or to decide it‚Äôs already too late to fix - but it‚Äôs not.

@guardianus columnist, Rebecca Solnit, says there's still time: ‚ÄúThe Covid-19 pandemic is proof that if we take a crisis seriously, we can change how we live, almost overnight, dramatically, globally, digging up great piles of money from nowhere, like the $3tn the US initially threw at the pandemic.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe must remake the world, and we can remake it better,‚Äù writes Solnit.

So how? Swipe through to read her tips on the best ways we can keep the climate fight alive.

Description:
One of the world‚Äôs most loyally monogamous creatures, Albatrosses, are ‚Äúdivorcing‚Äù more often ‚Äì and researchers say global heating may be to blame.

Typically after choosing a partner, only 1-3% albatross would separate in search of greener romantic pastures, but a new study has found warmer waters mean the birds are travelling further for food and that has caused the separation rate to rise up to 8%. For seabirds, warmer waters mean less fish, less food and a harsher environment. Fewer chicks survive. The birds‚Äô stress hormones increase. They are forced farther afield to hunt.

Albatross usually live for around 50-60 years. They have a long, awkward teen phase as they learn how to seduce a mate through dance, and take years-long trips away from home as they mature. They usually to mate for life, and loudly celebrate when greeting a partner after a long absence.

But now, they increasingly share another rite of passage that may sound familiar to young humans: under stress from the climate crisis, working longer hours to eat, and faced with the logistical difficulties of a traveling partner, some are struggling to maintain relationships.

The Royal Society study, which looked at a wild population of 15,500 breeding pairs in the Falkland Islands over 15 years, comes as many international albatross populations are in trouble.

Their numbers are plummeting by 5-10% every year, and have been dropping since around 2005, says Dr Graeme Elliot, principal science adviser at New Zealand‚Äôs department of conservation, who has been studying albatrosses for three decades. He says this is as a result of less prey, warming seas, and increasing encounters with tuna line-fishing boats, which accidentally catch and kill the birds.

Elliot now hopes that some of the sympathies people have for albatrosses could motivate changes in behaviour, to address the environmental threats the birds are facing ‚Äì particularly climate change, and tuna fishing. ‚ÄúWe kind of need an international campaign to save these birds. If we don‚Äôt turn it around, they‚Äôll go extinct.‚Äù

#albatross #endangered #divorce #wildlife #birds #climatecrisis #extinction #seabirds
ImageText: G New study Albatrosses are breaking up because of the climate crisis

Description:
Desde inicios del siglo XX, el oc√©ano Atl√°ntico se est√° infiltrando de forma creciente en el √Årtico. Viniendo del sur y sin el contrapeso del hielo, las aguas atl√°nticas aguas son m√°s c√°lidas y saladas. Esto hace que las masas marinas congeladas est√©n acelerando su deshielo, menguando su extensi√≥n cada vez m√°s. Este proceso se une al impacto ya conocido del calentamiento global. Entre los dos fen√≥menos, la regi√≥n √°rtica se est√° calentando a un ritmo que dobla la del resto de oc√©anos del planeta.

üì∏ Sara Giansiracusa

Description:
Albatrosses, some of the world‚Äôs most loyal creatures, are ‚Äúdivorcing‚Äù more, due to climate change.

Research published in the Royal Society journal looked at 15,500 breeding pairs in the Falkland Islands over 15 years.

Albatross divorce is basically just cheating, in human terms. It's when one part of a couple mates with a different individual.

Like humans, albatrosses also have an awkward growing-up phase, trying (and sometimes failing) to figure out the best way to get into a relationship.

But ultimately, when they find a good match, they normally stick together for life.

Just 1% of albatrosses separate after choosing their life partner - much lower than the human divorce rate in the UK.

But in the years covered by the study with warmer water temperatures, up to 8% of albatross couples split up.

Click the link in our bio to find out more about why Albatrosses usually ‚Äúdivorce‚Äù and what else could be behind the change.

(üì∑ Francesco Ventura)

#ClimateChange #BBCNews
ImageText: BBC NEWS Climate change causing albatross to break up, study says

Description:
Climate change is causing catastrophes worldwide, but for one of the poorest countries in South America, the risks are especially existential. Nonetheless, Guyana is hitching its future to the same fossil fuels that are accelerating climate change.

Click the link in bio for the story of how a poor country threatened by climate change tied its future to oil.

(Images: @rjckseen ‚Ä¢ Ryan Kellman/NPR )

1-2: An afternoon by the sea in Guyana, Georgetown offers a respite from the heat of the day. 
 
3.  Singer Jackie Jaxx has written a song inspired by the waters near Georgetown, which are dark with sediment carried from the inland rainforests. "Guyana is really special to us who live here," she says. "You know what I mean? We write songs about her." 

4. Syeada Manbodh and Bryan D'andrade, with the group Seawalls and Beyond, collect trash left on the beach. Other citizen-led environmental initiatives in Guyana are working to rebuild native mangrove forests, which act as natural sea defenses and prevent erosion.

5. A seawall stretches for hundreds of miles along the coast of Guyana. It protects the low-lying coastal lands where the majority of Guyana's population lives. The region is acutely threatened by rising sea levels, as well as other symptoms of climate change, yet Guyana is embracing the oil industry.

6.  Vice President Bharrat Jagdeo says he supports a rapid end to the oil industry. But he doesn't actually believe the world can pull it off. "It's not happening, and we don't see that happening any time soon," he says. 

7. This summer, relentless rain and unprecedented floods left a farming region under feet of water for months. Because of the flooding, Gagatnarine Ganpat had to move his animals to higher ground but still lost many of them from the shock of switching their feeding habits. 

8.Chandroutie Persaud lived in a home with a flooded first floor for months. It destroyed much of her home garden, as well as a season of rice and cash crops. "We carry great losses," she says.

9. Most of Guyana's population lives below sea level, making water a part of daily life. In Georgetown, waterways, which frequently overflow, crisscross the city.

Los ping√ºinos de la Ant√°rtida registran altos niveles de mercurio (sin llegar a ser t√≥xicos), seg√∫n un estudio de la Universidad de Murcia recogido en la revista 'International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health'.

Miguel Motas, investigador de la @umu, asegura que los niveles m√°s altos de este metal se encuentran en los ping√ºinos barbijo que viven en la isla Rey Jorge. 

Las regiones polares han sido identificadas como potenciales sumideros de mercurio procedentes de corrientes atmosf√©ricas y oce√°nicas que transportan el mercurio a lo largo de toda la Tierra. La alteraci√≥n del hielo que se est√° produciendo en algunas zonas del continente deja en evidencia la crisis clim√°tica que afronta el planeta mientras altera la emisi√≥n de mercurio y los impactos que supone para la flora y fauna.

Description:
Withered maize. Drowned cattle. Entire villages submerged beneath floodwaters, with parents wading through inundated streets carrying their young children in buckets balanced on their heads to keep them dry. Heavy rains have caused the White Nile to overflow‚Äìleaving people without shelter, food or a way to make a living. 

Peter Caton captured these unflinching scenes of the ongoing climate catastrophe in South Sudan in his series, Unyielding Floods. According to Caton, communities devastated by the floods in this region are diving under the floodwaters to collect the bulbs of water lilies to eat. "It's the only source of food people can forage for now," he says. "They grind them into a powder to produce a paste that's edible. It's hard work." According to UNHCR, the U.N. refugee agency, more than 700,000 people have been affected by this crisis.

Caton has been documenting the effects of extreme flooding brought on by climate change in South Sudan, which has struck the country three years in a row. In October, a selection of his photo series won first place in the 2021 International Photography Awards (IPA) in the environmental category. It is one of five photo awards that Unyielding Floods has won this year.

For the series, commissioned by the global humanitarian group Action Against Hunger USA, Caton traveled to Jonglei State, South Sudan, in November 2020 and September 2021 to document the villagers' struggles. Aid agencies are helping to provide food aid, emergency shelter and other necessities and local governments in South Sudan have set up projects to build dikes and redirect excess water through canals, but many communities remain underwater.

Tap the link in our bio to see the full photo essay and read the full story.

(Images: @petercatonpix ‚Ä¢ Peter Caton)
ImageText: (empty)

Description:
Much of South Sudan is under water from flooding induced by climate change. Crops and livestock are lost, and hunger and malaria are spreading. With so many worries, coronavirus vaccines are a tough sell.

In the small village of Pawel and other parts of the state of Jonglei, many people have fled, @lynseyaddario writes, ‚Äúwhile those who remain have lost their crops, their livestock and their homes.‚Äù 

‚ÄúWith fish almost the only food available, malnutrition is rampant, as is disease,‚Äù Addario writes.

A coronavirus born half a world away, even one that has killed an estimated five million people, cannot compete with the threat lapping at their homes. Although testing is scarce, there is a little evidence that South Sudan has a major Covid problem. Villagers in Pawel recognize the pandemic as a threat. Just perhaps not a very pressing one.

‚ÄúWe heard people are dying‚Äù of Covid, James Kuir Bior, Pawel‚Äôs leader, said, ‚Äúbut we haven‚Äôt seen anyone sick here.‚Äù And besides, he said: ‚ÄúWhen you are starving, you don‚Äôt think about other things ‚Äî you need to feed your stomach first.‚Äù

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the crisis in South Sudan. Photos by @lynseyaddario

Description:
The Democratic Republic of Congo is responsible for more than two-thirds of the world‚Äôs production of cobalt, a vital material for electric vehicles and the worldwide push against climate change. 

But the quest for Congo‚Äôs cobalt has demonstrated how the clean energy revolution, meant to save the planet from perilously warming temperatures, is caught in a familiar cycle of exploitation, greed and gamesmanship that often puts narrow national aspirations above all else, an investigation by The New York Times found.

Cobalt, typically extracted from copper deposits, has historically been of secondary interest to miners. But demand is set to explode worldwide because it is used in electric-car batteries, helping them run longer without a charge.

A wooded stretch of the southeastern Congo, called Kisanfu, holds one of the largest and purest untapped reserves of cobalt in the world. The land is now owned by a Chinese mining conglomerate, which bought it from an American company.

The Times dispatched reporters across three continents drawn into the competition for cobalt, a relatively obscure raw material that along with lithium, nickel and graphite has gained exceptional value in a world trying to rid itself of fossil fuels.

More than 100 interviews and thousands of pages of documents show that the race for cobalt has set off a power struggle in Congo and has lured foreigners intent on dominating the next epoch in global energy.

Tap the link in our bio to read the first part of the investigation by @dionnesearcey, Michael Forsythe and Eric Lipton. Photos by @ashgilbertson

Description:
Amazon deforestation in Brazil has soar 22% in the past year to a 15-year high, the government‚Äôs annual report has shown, undercutting president Jair Bolsonaro‚Äôs assurances that the country is curbing illegal logging.

Brazil‚Äòs space research agency, INPE, recorded 13,235sq km (5,110 square miles) of deforestation in the world‚Äôs largest rainforest in satellite data from August 2020 to July 2021.

That's nearly 17 times the size of New York City, nine times the size of Delhi and 8.5 times the size of London.

At the UN climate summit in Glasgow this month, Brazil‚Äôs government brought forward a pledge to end illegal deforestation by two years to 2028, a target that would require aggressive annual reductions in the destruction.

Though Bolsonaro, a far-right former army captain, still calls for more mining and commercial farming in protected parts of the rainforest.

The new INPE report showed deforestation rising in each of the last four cycles ‚Äì a first for the data series since at least 2000. ‚ÄúThe government went to Cop26 knowing the deforestation data and hid it,‚Äù said Brazilian advocacy group, Climate Observatory.

Brazil, as home to the majority of the world‚Äôs largest rainforest, was seen as crucial to that global pact. The Amazon‚Äôs trees absorb vast amounts of carbon dioxide that would otherwise warm the planet.

But some scientists warn that if enough of the forest is destroyed, it could cross a tipping point, dry out and turn into savannah. That would release huge amounts of carbon, virtually ensuring the world cannot hit the targets laid out to avoid the worst effects of the climate crisis.

#Cop26 #Brazil #Bolsonaro #Brasilia #Amazon #AmazonRainforest #carbonsink

Description:
The U.S.‚Äôs demand for leather in luxury SUVs is worsening deforestation of the Amazon in Brazil. 

A New York Times investigation into Brazil‚Äôs slaughterhouse industry has identified loopholes in its monitoring systems that allow hides from cattle, kept on illegally deforested Amazon land, to flow undetected through Brazil‚Äôs tanneries and on to buyers worldwide.
 
A luxury vehicle can require a dozen or more hides, and suppliers in the U.S. increasingly buy their leather from Brazil. This leather trade shows how the wealthy world‚Äôs shopping habits are tied to environmental degradation in developing nations, in this case by helping to fund destruction of the Amazon, despite its valuable biodiversity and the scientific consensus that protecting it would help to slow climate change.
 
To track the global trade in leather from illegal ranches in the Brazilian rainforest to the seats in American vehicles, The Times interviewed ranchers, traders, prosecutors and regulators in Brazil, and visited tanneries, ranches and other facilities. The Times spoke to participants at all levels of the illicit trade in the Jaci-Paran√° Extractive Reserve, an area in Rond√¥nia State that has been granted special protections because it is home to communities of people who, for generations, have lived off the land by tapping rubber trees.
 
These communities are now being forced out by ranchers who want the land for cattle. Tap the link in our bio to read about how hides from illegally deforested ranches can easily reach the global marketplace. Photos by @victormoriyama

JUST IN: US House votes 220 to 213 to pass President Biden‚Äôs $1.7T social safety net bill, sending the legislation to the Senate.‚Å†

The bill includes a monthly per-child cash payment of up to $300 for most parents, child care funding, universal pre-K, an extension of ACA subsidies and Medicare hearing benefits. It also commits $555B toward combating climate change, the largest such effort in US history.‚Å†

Description:
House Democrats have voted to pass President Joe Biden's sweeping $1.9 trillion legislation to expand the social safety net.‚Å†
‚Å†
It marks a victory for the party even as the legislation faces a tough road ahead in the Senate.‚Å†
‚Å†
The massive economic package stands as a key pillar of Biden's domestic agenda. It would deliver on longstanding Democratic priorities by dramatically expanding social services for Americans, working to mitigate the climate crisis, increasing access to health care and delivering aid to families and children.‚Å†
‚Å†
The vote took place on Friday morning after House GOP leader Kevin McCarthy stalled an effort to vote Thursday evening by delivering a record-breaking marathon floor speech overnight.‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
The House has passed President Biden‚Äôs $1.85 trillion Build Back Better bill, sending the measure to the Senate.

The $1.85 trillion package of Democratic social spending priorities includes:
 ¬∑  Free preschool
 ¬∑  Climate change initiatives
 ¬∑  Expansion of affordable housing

The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said it would add to the national debt, undercutting Biden's long-standing pledge the bill is not only fully paid for but would decrease the deficit.

Biden and Democrats negotiated for months on the measure that faced resistance from moderate lawmakers who objected to the original bill‚Äôs $3.5 trillion price tag and other provisions.

Description:
Last week world leaders agreed to end deforestation by 2030. A week later, data has revealed Brazil's Amazon rainforest has seen the highest levels of deforestation in over 15 years.

The Amazon provides a vital carbon store that slows down the pace of global warming, and as the world‚Äôs biggest rainforest is home to about three million species of plants and animals, and one million indigenous people.

Tap the link in our bio to read analysis of these latest figures and the impact they will have on President Jair Bolsonaro and his government.

#Brazil #AmazonRainforest #Environment #Ecology #BBCNews

Description:
Royal tours often involve showing off a country's major tourist attraction and Egypt was no exception.‚Å†
‚Å†
But Prince Charles and the Duchess of Cornwall weren't just touring the pyramids on the outskirts of Cairo for fun. With the Great Sphinx of Giza reclining in the background, the Prince of Wales took the opportunity to deliver his latest speech imploring the world to act on climate change.‚Å†
‚Å†
As he acknowledged in his speech, Egypt could not have been a more apt setting to make his comments. The country is "on the front line of urgent climate challenges", he said, from rising sea levels, to the loss of biodiversity as sea temperatures rise.‚Å†
‚Å†
The pyramids themselves are at risk from rising temperatures, flooding and other extreme weather. Egypt also has a very important role in future global discussions.‚Å†
‚Å†
Sky's Royal Correspondent Rhiannon Mills was there to hear it all. Click the link in our bio to read more.‚Å†
‚Å†
#PrinceCharles #DutchessofCornwall #Egypt #RoyalTour #ClimateCrisis

Videos difundidos en redes sociales mostraron carreteras con inundaciones que paralizaron la provincia de Columbia Brit√°nica, Canad√°. Algunas √°reas recibieron 20 cent√≠metros de lluvia el pasado domingo, y este lunes contin√∫an, con carreteras cubiertas por hasta 25 cent√≠metros de agua. 

Las fuertes lluvias atraparon a ocupantes de entre 80 y 100 veh√≠culos en la provincia de Columbia Brit√°nica y obligaron al desalojo en algunas zonas de ese lugar, al oeste del pa√≠s. 

El primer ministro de Canad√°, Justin Trudeau, pidi√≥ ‚Äúa todos los habitantes afectados que se mantengan a salvo‚Äù y que ‚Äúest√°n listos para brindar toda la asistencia que se necesite por el clima extremo‚Äù. 

Hasta el momento no se sabe el porqu√© de las lluvias tan fuertes, pero se cree que puede ser el cambio clim√°tico, pues hay que recordar que, a fines de junio de este a√±o, las temperaturas alcanzaron r√©cord, provocando incendios y afectaciones en el pa√≠s.

Una c√°mara ha grabado d√≠a y noche durante seis semanas el deshielo de un glaciar en Islandia. 

Las im√°genes muestran la gran velocidad a la que se derrite Brei√∞amerkurj√∂kull, un glaciar en el Parque Nacional Vatnaj√∂kull. La escena ha sido captada por el doctor Kieran Baxter de la Universidad de Dundee para sus estudios sobre cambio clim√°tico.
