Description:
President Biden will announce on Monday that his administration is moving to block new federal oil and gas leasing within a 10-mile radius around Chaco Canyon in New Mexico, one of the nation‚Äôs oldest and most culturally significant Native American sites, according to White House officials.

The announcement is to come as Biden hosts a tribal nations summit meeting at the White House.

The move to restrict fossil fuel drilling around a major Native American site dovetails two of Biden‚Äôs top policy priorities: addressing climate change and injustices against Native Americans.

Biden has come under fierce criticism from Native American environmental activists for his administration‚Äôs approval of Line 3, a $9 billion pipeline that would carry hundreds of thousands of barrels of oil through Minnesota‚Äôs delicate watersheds and tribal lands.

The Chaco Canyon park, an area of roughly 30,000 acres in the high desert mesas of northwest New Mexico, was established in 1907 by President Theodore Roosevelt. A UNESCO World Heritage site, it is home to a vast network of pre-Columbian ruins. Between the ninth and 13th centuries, the area was home to a large, complex society of Pueblo culture, with multiple settlements of multistory houses and sacred sites. But for the past decade, Pueblo and other Native groups have expressed concerns that oil and gas development was encroaching on the borders of the park.

Tap the link in our bio to read more. Photo by @burchamphoto
ImageText: Biden to Bar New Drilling Near Major Native American Cultural Site Nov. 15, 2021

Description: Un acuerdo hist√≥rico, pero te√±ido de decepci√≥n. Description:
The Northwest glaciers are melting.‚Å†
‚Å†
From Mount Adams in the south to Mount Baker near the Canadian border, the summer of 2021 left its mark on Washington‚Äôs high country.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúFor long-time residents of Washington state, it is jarring to see Mount Rainier without snow on its peak,‚Äù Rep. Marilyn Strickland said on the floor of the U.S. House of Representatives in September.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúIn just four days this summer, four days in late June, the peak of the heat dome, the mountain lost 30% of its total snow cover,‚Äù she said, standing in front of before-and-after pictures of the state‚Äôs highest peak. ‚ÄúThis is a visual demonstration that climate change is real.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúI've lived here for the better part of 38 years, and I've never seen the mountains bare like they were this year,‚Äù Abby Yates of Everson, Washington said.‚Å†
‚Å†
Like indigenous groups in much of the Northwest, the tribes of the Nooksack basin identify as salmon people. ‚Å†
‚Å†Tap the link in our bio for the @kuow story on how this change affects this region. ‚Å†

Description:
Vlad Sokhin's interest in climate change came from his own global upbringing.

Born in Russia, and having spent formative years in Portugal, Sokhin made a career as a documentary photographer capturing health and human rights issues in Europe, Africa and Asia. Yet it was a 2013 assignment to cover deforestation in Papua New Guinea that convinced him to train his lens on humanity's impact on the planet.

"I saw how the environment was changing because of illegal logging," Sokhin tells NPR. "But the big picture wasn't there. I thought, 'What if I extend a little bit?'"

Eight years and thousands of miles later, the result is Warm Waters, (Schilt Publishing, 2021) an exploration of climate change traveling across 18 countries and off-the-map territories seen by seldom few.

1. Teafua Tanu is an islet of Tokelau used by residents of Fakaofo atoll as a Catholic cemetery. Over the past two decades, the territory of Tokelau has proved extremely vulnerable to climate change and rising sea levels owing, partly, to its being a small land mass surrounded by ocean, and its location in a region prone to natural disasters.
2. Jack Pombo, 41, from Trin village, holds a dead bird of paradise. He finds many dead birds when he goes to logging areas. "Before our forest was full of birds. We had parrots, birds of paradise. Now many of them gone, because we don't have a forest anymore. Some birds died, some moved to different areas. Some come to our gardens and destroy our crops," he says.
3. Simanu, 25, enjoying water in Moata'a Mangrove Reserve in Apia, on Samoa's Upolu island. The Samoan government supports many local communities through replanting mangroves that protect people and their livelihoods from rising sea level and coastal erosion.
4. Steller sea lions rest on the rocks of Grotto Island in Kenai Fjords National Park, Alaska.
5. An Inupiat girl named Amaia, 11, stands on an ice floe on a shore of the Arctic Ocean in Barrow, Alaska. The anomalous melting of the Arctic ice is one of the many effects of global warming that has a serious impact on the life of humans and wildlife.

(Images: @lens_pacific ‚Ä¢ Vlad Sokhin)

Description:
Auf der Klimakonferenz in Glasgow hat sich die Staatengemeinschaft auf neue Ma√ünahmen gegen den Klimawandel geeinigt. Vor allem soll der Ausstieg aus der Kohleverbrennung eingeleitet werden. Das 1,5-Grad-Ziel kann damit allerdings nicht erreicht werden. Hoffnung macht ein Pakt zwischen China und den USA.

Dlf-Redakteur Georg Ehring, der die Konferenz vor Ort begleitete, kommentiert das Ende der Konferenz so: ‚ÄûDas Schlussdokument spricht vom Herunterfahren der Kohleverbrennung, es gibt jede Menge neue Selbstverpflichtungen zum Klimaschutz ‚Äì doch der Gipfel in Glasgow hat nicht sichergestellt, dass  das 1,5 Grad-Limit bei der Erderw√§rmung eingehalten wird. Ist das eine gute Bilanz? Ist das Glas nun halb voll oder halb leer. Gemessen an dem, was man vor der Konferenz erwarten konnte, ist es sogar ziemlich voll. Grund zur Zufriedenheit ist das aber nicht.
.
‚ÄûMit dem nahezu vollen Glas kann wirklich niemand zufrieden sein. Denn ‚Äì um im Bild zu bleiben: Gut gef√ºllt ist leider nur ein Schnapsglas, wo ein Ma√ükrug erforderlich w√§re. Nach wie vor fehlt es an dem, was am n√∂tigsten w√§re und dies hat der Gipfel nicht geliefert. Viel mehr Ambition und vor allem Tempo beim Klimaschutz.‚Äú
.

Description:
COP26 is over, but decisions made during the climate summit will live on for many years to come.
 
Daniel Rupaszov, 25, from Hungary, belongs to a group of artists and activists who visit COP every year to create art which highlights the climate crisis.
 
The Artivist Network, of which Daniel is a member, champion the catchphrase "Create, Connect, Disrupt".

Every year they paint a mural during COP, to leave something permanent and thought-provoking behind after the negotiations - so people don't forget that this happened in their city.

Description:
Birds' bodies are shrinking in response to climate change, even in places like the Amazon rainforest that are relatively untouched by human hands.‚Å†
‚Å†
Researchers studying 15,000 birds in the Amazon rainforest found that nearly all of the birds' bodies have become lighter since the 1980s, losing on average about 2% of their body weight every decade, according to a new study published Friday in the journal Science Advances.‚Å†
‚Å†
The study also revealed that wingspan was getting bigger in a third of the Amazon bird species studied.‚Å†
‚Å†
It's a pattern that's also been spotted in North American migratory birds.‚Å†
‚Å†
üì∏: Vitek Jirinec

Description:
An emotional Alok Sharma says he is "deeply sorry" for the way the #COP26 conference had unfolded after a number of nations joined Switzerland in echoing their "profound disappointment" at the watering down of the agreement's language on phasing out coal.

Holding back tears, the COP president says "I apologise for the way this process has unfolded, I am deeply sorry."

World leaders were able to reach the most significant climate change pact since the landmark Paris Agreement, following a turbulent two weeks of fraught negotiations in Glasgow.

With a stroke of the gavel, COP26 President Alok Sharma brought the talks to a close after almost 200 nations finally reached consensus on how to navigate the climate crisis.

Major outcomes include:

üå°Ô∏è supercharging 2030 emissions-cutting targets as soon as next year, potentially "keeping 1.5C alive," a key objective of the talks
üî• accelerating the phase-down of unabated coal and inefficient fossil fuel subsidies
doubling funding for developing nations to adapt to climate change by 2025
üí∞boosting up the agenda the conversation about how to pay for the loss and damage that climate change inflicts on developing countries
üè≠ finally agreeing rules on carbon offset markets, which the last two COPs have tried and failed to finalise

Description:
We have a new global deal aimed at staving off dangerous climate change.

The Glasgow Climate Pact, struck at COP26, is the first ever climate deal to explicitly plan to reduce coal.

The final deal also promises more money for developing countries - to help them adapt to climate change.

But the pledges don't go far enough to limit the global temperature rise to 1.5C. And an earlier commitment to phase out coal was watered down at the last minute.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about what this deal means.

(üì∑ Getty Images)

Almost 200 nations adopted on Saturday a compromise on how to curb climate change and to keep a key global warming target alive after 15 days of contentious climate talks. The compromise contained a last-minute change put forward by India to "phase down," rather than "phase out" coal power, the single biggest source of greenhouse gas emissions.‚Å†

El cambio clim√°tico es una amenaza constante. Aunque se tiene claro que la monta√±a ya tiene un aprendizaje con el que poder defenderse, los escenarios resultantes con aumento de temperaturas y de lluvias torrenciales cambiar√°n los ecosistemas y el paisaje tal y como lo conocen los habitantes de la Alpujarra.

El proyecto Life Adaptamed, que ha estado llevando a cabo acciones en la zona, tiene por objetivo la protecci√≥n de los servicios ecosist√©micos en el Cabo de Gata, Do√±ana y Sierra Nevada ante el desaf√≠o que supone el cambio clim√°tico. Las intervenciones se basan en lograr adaptar los espacios en vez de incidir directamente sobre las especies. La recuperaci√≥n de las acequias es un ejemplo de lucha contra la falta de agua.

Description:
NPR's Picture Show is taking a look at work by photographers from around the world that highlight climate change.

1. Chukotka, Russian Arctic: Walruses are on land outside Russian marine biologist Maxim Chakilev's hut, due to the absence of sea ice. ( @evgenia_arbugaeva ‚Ä¢ Evgenia Arbugaeva)
2. San Jose de Gracia, Mexico: San Jose de Gracia is nestled in the middle of the Pacific coast of Baja California, Mexico. While water first brought the settlement, the rainy season has shifted leaving the community without a waterfall. ( @sofialdinio ‚Ä¢ Sofia Aldinio)
3. Miguel in San Jose de Gracia, Baja California, Mexico. ( @sofialdinio ‚Ä¢ Sofia Aldinio)
4. Salton City: Lizette plays on her bicycle. Little water enters the area and the water that does enter is all agricultural run off laced with pesticides and fertilizers. ( @mettelampcov ‚Ä¢ Mette Lampcov)
5. Sao Paulo, Brazil: An important issue in times of climate emergency is the relationship between human beings and geography. ( @marpimenta ‚Ä¢ Marcio Pimenta)
6. Zanskar, India: Lobzang Tsamo threshes barley at her family farm. Due to water scarcity caused by receding Himalayan glaciers, villagers cannot support a large livestock herd. ( @neeta.satam ‚Ä¢ Neeta Satam)
7. Syracuse, New York: Onondaga Lake was a dumping ground for soda ash waste. After years of dredging, the water quality of the lake is slowly returning to levels. ( @fangqianqiao ‚Ä¢ Crystal Fang)
8. Punta Arenas, Chile:  An oceanographic sensor was deployed in the Strait of Magellan for 18 months to collect data like salinity, pH, CO2, and oxygen from the ocean water in the context of ocean acidification triggered by global warming. ( @ava.silvery ‚Ä¢ Akosua Viktoria Adu-Sanyah)
9. Giant kelp is under the threats of climate change. ( @ava.silvery ‚Ä¢ Akosua Viktoria Adu-Sanyah)
10. Pilcher, Okla.: Left: Terry Tyree, like many former residents of the town, said Picher was one big family before the buyout. Right: Looking north from the ghost town of Douthat, Oklahoma along Tar Creek a chat pile rises like a mountain from the ghost town of Picher, Oklahoma. ( @ethanaweston ‚Ä¢ Ethan Weston)

Jan Kowalzig, der Klimaexperte der Nichtregierungsorganisation Oxfam, sagte dazu im Deutschlandfunk: ‚ÄûDie von der Klimakrise besonders betroffenen L√§nder, wie die kleinen Inselstaaten und die Entwicklungsl√§nder, haben einen neuen Mechanismus gefordert, der finanzielle Ressourcen bereitstellt f√ºr die Bew√§ltigung von Klimafolgesch√§den, also wenn man trotz Anpassung an den Klimawandel und trotz Klimaschutz mit Sch√§den zu rechnen hat, wie St√ºrmen, Zerst√∂rungen, √úberschwemmungen und dem Meeresspiegelanstieg‚Äú.
.
Dlf-Wissenschaftsjournalist Georg Ehring berichtet zudem: Am Rande der Konferenz habe es wichtige Initiativen zum Ausstieg aus der Kohle und der internationalen Finanzierung von √ñl- und Gasprojekten gegeben, sowie zur Vermeidung von Methan und zum Schutz von W√§ldern. Die USA und China wollten beim Klimaschutz wieder zusammenarbeiten.
.
Das Interview mit Jan Kowalzig findet sich unter dem Link in unserer Bio.
.
.
.

Description:
Last month, the Muisyo family turned on the lights for the first time. As a small-scale farmer living with her three kids, Winifred Mumbua Muisyo had been relying on kerosene lanterns until now. The electric grid doesn't reach her neighborhood outside of Nairobi, Kenya. With more than 700 million people worldwide without electricity, Muisyo's decision is key to limiting heat-trapping emissions. Using solar means her power won't come from fossil fuels.

The light bulbs turning on in Muisyo's home also are directly tied to high-level climate talks going on in Glasgow, Scotland. Some of the financing the company that installed Muisyo‚Äôs solar home system received comes from "climate finance" funds from wealthier nations. Under the 2015 Paris climate agreement, industrialized countries promised $100 billion per year to help developing countries switch to renewable energy, limit their emissions and adapt to climate change impacts.

Developed countries recognized that poorer nations have done little to cause climate change, but are bearing the brunt of the impacts. Still, wealthier countries have yet to hit the funding goal. In 2019, they only provided about $80 billion. Developing countries say not enough went to the most vulnerable nations or to help them prepare for impacts that are already being felt.

Follow the link in our bio for more of the story.

(Images: @farahkhad ‚Ä¢ Khadija Farah for NPR )

1. Winifred Muisyo, right, and her 5-year-old daughter, Patience Kativa, watch Stanlas Kisilu, left, as he installs a TV tuner on the roof of her home. The TV is connected to a solar panel provided by d.light, a company partially funded by climate financing from wealthier nations.

2-5: Muisyo and her family utilize their new solar powered lights and television.

Description:
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs sad that climate change affects our language, also.‚Äù says @saraelvira_k, an activist from the S√°mi group - the only indigenous people within the European Union area.

We spoke with the 21-year-old about how the climate crisis is affecting her community who depend on cold snowy winters to keep up their livelihood in reindeer herding.

As the pivotal climate summit Cop26 comes to an end, Indigenous activists have fought to have their voices heard, but have still been drowned out by the bureaucracy and structural barriers which meant they had less access to the summit and its platform.

Ita Mendoza said, an Indigenous land defender from Mexico said: "The Cop is a big business, a continuation of colonialism where people come not to listen to us, but to make money from our land and natural resources."

What is the one thing you will take away from what Sara said in the latest episode of this mini-series?

Description:
El alem√°n que ha pasado tres meses rodando en una bola de hierro gigante para la Cumbre del Clima

A lo largo de sus tres meses de viaje para llegar a la Cumbre del Clima de Glasgow (COP26), el alem√°n Arnd Drossel lleg√≥ a pensar que tendr√≠a que dar media vuelta. Los obst√°culos asociados a ir rodando en una gran esfera de malla de hierro de 160 kilos no han sido pocos. La bola ha tenido que ser soldada de nuevo en algunas partes, no pasaba por algunos tramos y no llevaba nada bien los baches. Pero con lo que hoy se queda este artista que quer√≠a simbolizar ¬´la madre tierra¬ª y c√≥mo el cambio clim√°tico impacta en todos, es haber sentido ¬´el poder de las promesas¬ª clim√°ticas para conectar a las personas, asegura.

Su objetivo era lograr que la gente se diera cuenta de que se puede vivir de manera sostenible, protegiendo la tierra y el futuro de las siguientes generaciones.

Para ello, Drossel utiliz√≥ un transporte creado por √©l mismo. En la esfera, con un di√°metro de 2,10 metros, ha recorrido unos 1.500 kil√≥metros, en tramos de entre 8 y 10 kil√≥metros cada d√≠a. Sali√≥ de su ciudad, Paderborn, el viernes 30 de julio. Lleg√≥ a Glasgow el pasado 5 de noviembre, con algo de retraso sobre el calendario previsto. Entre medias, 60 ciudades, seis pa√≠ses y alg√∫n ferry.

Description:
Let us reap what we sow.

That's the title of the digital artwork on the cover of this gallery. It's rooted in the story of @kushiaania + @yo_janda's grandparents who emigrated to the UK in the 1960s after growing up in small farming villages in Punjab, India, where their love of the land was their livelihood.

"Black people, indigenous people and people of colour put so much love into the earth, only to suffer the catastrophic and often fatal consequences of our racist society and systems," the illustrator duo behind the UK-based Mush Studio explain.

The piece is part of a new climate exhibition is showcasing the work of 24 Black and other artists of colour exploring the relationship between racial injustice and climate injustice.

The Colour of the Climate Crisis, organised by the environmental social initiative Do The Green Thing, will form a permanent digital display at www.thecolouroftheclimatecrisis.art. Further gallery exhibitions will take place in London and New York in 2022.

Swipe to see some of the pieces being showcased.

#cop26 #climatecrisis #climatechange #globalheating #globalwarming #climatesummit #racialinjustice #climatejustice #glasgow #scotland

This summer, after an extended heat wave and the hottest day on record a fire burned down the whole of the town of Lytton in Canada.

Residents of the town say the the fire was a result of climate change and the drought that allowed it to start with just one spark.

They now face a Canadian winter in temporary accommodation as they wait for the town to be rebuilt.

Description:

The LMDC does not believe developing countries should have to have the same deadlines and ambitions on emissions as wealthy nations. Bolivia's chief negotiator, Diego Pacheco, who represents the LMDC group, said that the countries felt the developed world was trying to transfer its responsibilities for the climate crisis onto the developing world. ‚Å†

"We requested the presidency remove completely the section on mitigation," Pacheco said at a press conference in Glasgow. CNN is reaching out to Chinese and Indian officials for comment. Tap the link in our bio for more.

Description:
"Australia needs to wake up to themselves ... we need to do better in terms of our politicians," says Aboriginal climate activist Amelia Telford.

The 27-year-old has spoken to us for the latest episode in our mini-series profiling young Indigenous activists.

As the national director of the Australian Indigenous climate activism organisation @seedmob, Telford explains the importance of decolonising how we think of our place on Earth, the resources we use, and the things we 'need', and instead learning from Indigenous knowledge and values.

Video: @neelamtailor + @nikhitachulani

The water trickling down from the glaciers is what people in Kumik village, in the north Indian region of Ladakh, have depended on for centuries. 

But due to rising temperatures and less snowfall, their only water source has almost dried up.

Description:
Estados Unidos y China anuncian por sorpresa un plan conjunto para reducir sus emisiones.

En la recta final de las negociaciones de la cumbre de la ONU en Glasgow, el anuncio conjunto de China y Estados Unidos, primer y segundo pa√≠s que m√°s CO2 emiten, respectivamente, insufl√≥ optimismo de cara a lograr un acuerdo el viernes que haga viable el objetivo de frenar el cambio clim√°tico.

Las dos grandes potencias publicaron una declaraci√≥n en la que se comprometen a "reforzar la acci√≥n clim√°tica en la d√©cada de 2020 (...) para alcanzar los objetivos del Acuerdo de Par√≠s", de limitar el avance de las temperaturas a final de siglo por debajo de los 2 grados cent√≠grados y a intentar que no sobrepasen los 1,5 ¬∫C, anunci√≥ en rueda de prensa el negociador chino, Xie Zhenhua.

"Las dos mayores econom√≠as del mundo han acordado trabajar juntas", declar√≥ en rueda de prensa el enviado especial para el clima de Estados Unidos, John Kerry.

El anuncio dio un vuelco a la recta final de las negociaciones, primero porque suma a los esfuerzos a China, que hasta ahora hab√≠a mantenido perfil bajo en la COP26, y segundo porque se√±ala como objetivo acelerar la descarbonizaci√≥n en la presente d√©cada, a corto plazo, como senda para desprenderse del CO2 a mitad de siglo.

Description:
There is no way out of this climate emergency without the empowerment of women: that is the resounding message from many leaders and campaigners at Cop26.

Speaking to delegates at the climate summit, Angelica Ponce, executive director of the Plurinational Authority for Mother Earth in Bolivia, said: ‚ÄúThe world as designed by men has destroyed many things. The world should begin thinking like women. If it was designed by a woman, it would end violence against women and children.

‚ÄúWe want to be in the corridors of power and take part in decisions at international level to end this struggle of climate justice,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAs Indigenous women, we live day-by-day the cruel reality of climate change in our land.‚Äù

Women and girls around the world suffer disproportionately from the impacts of climate breakdown, as they are on average poorer, less educated and more dependent on subsistence farming. A UN report found 80% of those displaced by the climate emergency are women.

The focus on gender equality yesterday saw many more Indigenous women and politicians including Scotland‚Äôs first minister, Nicola Sturgeon, and Nancy Pelosi, speaker of the US House of Representatives, demand increased investment.

Sturgeon said: ‚ÄúWhen world leaders gathered here last week, of the 120 or so, a tiny minority were women ‚Äì that needs to change and it needs to change quickly. There is no doubt, we must ensure that climate change is a feminist issue. [But] women are not pleading to be supported. We‚Äôre demanding to be empowered.‚Äù

Pelosi said: ‚ÄúIf I ruled the world, the one thing that I would do is invest in the education of women. When women succeed, the world succeeds.‚Äù

Climate-related events will prevent at least 4 million girls in lower-income countries from completing their education in 2021, he said, citing a Malala Fund report. On current trends, the climate crisis will contribute to at least 12.5 million girls not completing their education each year, the report said.

Photo by Murdo Macleod in Glasgow on 3 November.

#womenempowerment #cop26 #cop26glasgow #climatesummit #climatecrisis #climatechange #womensrights #humanrights #un #climateemergency #education #school

El hombre que nada entre icebergs: ¬´El agua ya no est√° a 3 grados, sino a 10¬ª

De los 12 d√≠as que Lewis Pugh, , embajador de la ONU de los Oc√©anos, ha pasado este a√±o nadando entre las aguas heladas de Groenlandia, hay una imagen que no se puede quitar de la cabeza. Miles y miles de icebergs cayendo del fiordo de hielo Ilulissat, abri√©ndose camino al oc√©ano. ¬´Era una autopista de hielo¬ª, asegura Pugh, con todos los bloques uno detr√°s de otro. Las regiones polares llevan d√©cadas cambiando y √©l ha sido un testigo excepcional. Ha nadado donde nunca antes nadie lo hab√≠a hecho. Con apenas un ba√±ador, un gorro y las gafas, se ha sumergido en las aguas del Polo Norte o del Himalaya. Pero lo que est√° viendo ahora, dice, no es una crisis clim√°tica. Es, directamente, una ¬´cat√°strofe¬ª.

Description:
NASA has released the first snapshots of Earth taken with its new satellite that's designed to capture high-resolution images of the planet and help track the impacts of climate change.

Landsat 9, which launched in September, is equipped with two instruments that capture imagery and provide experts with data about crop health, irrigation use, water quality, wildfire severity, deforestation, glacial retreat and urban expansion.

Description:
Tuvalu‚Äôs foreign minister has recorded a speech for the United Nations climate conference in Glasgow ‚Äì standing knee-deep in seawater to highlight how the low-lying Pacific Island nation is on the frontline of the climate crisis.

Images of Simon Kofe standing in a suit and tie at a lectern set up in the sea, with his trouser legs rolled up, have been shared widely on social media, drawing attention to the fact that Tuvalu is one of the countries considered most at risk of disappearing due to sea level rise.

Before the Cop26 summit, it emerged that one-third of Pacific small island states and territories would be unable to send any government figures for the talks in Scotland due to Covid-19 travel restrictions.

Many big polluters have vowed to intensify their carbon cuts over coming decades with some aiming for net zero carbon emissions by 2050. But Pacific Island leaders have demanded immediate action, pointing out that the very survival of their low-lying countries is at stake.

#tuvalu #climatecrisis #sealevel #sealevelrise #climateemergency #pacificislandnations

Description:
Chacaltaya, la estaci√≥n de esqu√≠ m√°s alta del mundo que el cambio clim√°tico hizo desaparecer

La estaci√≥n de esqu√≠ boliviana de Chacaltaya fue en su d√≠a la m√°s alta del mundo. Situada a 5.300 metros sobre el nivel del mar, en la monta√±a del mismo nombre, a 30 km de distancia de La Paz. Y decimos fue, porque el √∫nico lugar de Bolivia donde practicar el esqu√≠ desapareci√≥ definitivamente en 2009 por culpa del cambio clim√°tico.

Ahora es una estaci√≥n de esqu√≠ fantasma con el refugio -construido en 1930 a imagen de los europeos- abandonado. "Es un cementerio", lamenta Bernardo Guarachi, alpinista de 68 a√±os, mientras se√±ala los postes oxidados y los cables de los telesillas y su mirada recorre la pista de 400 metros, y que desde hace tiempo no es m√°s que hierba corta y rocas.

Lo que en su d√≠a fue un lugar de esparcimiento para la clase media-alta de La Paz, hoy es solo monta√±a. En 1998, el glaciar -al que se le calculaba una antig√ºedad de 18.000 a√±os-  ya ten√≠a solo el 7% de la superficie que ten√≠a en 1940. En 2005, los cient√≠ficos pronosticaron que su esperanza de vida no ir√≠a m√°s all√° de 2015. Se equivocaron, las cosas fueron m√°s r√°pidas, y en 2009 hab√≠a desaparecido casi por completo, testigo del calentamiento acelerado del clima. 

La contaminaci√≥n de La Paz y la quema para ampliar √°reas agr√≠colas fundieron el hielo de 18.000 a√±os de antig√ºedad. Bolivia ha perdido aproximadamente la mitad de sus glaciares en los √∫ltimos cincuenta a√±os.

‚ÄúWhen it comes to climate, time really is running out,‚Äù Obama told climate advocates. ‚Å†

Description:
En la cumbre sobre el cambio clim√°tico , la COP26, el expresidente de Estados Unidos Barack Obama dijo que China, Rusia y los republicanos estadounidenses obstaculizan los avances en clima

El expresidente de Estados Unidos arremeti√≥ contra los que se escudan en la pol√≠tica para evitar tomar medidas contra el cambio clim√°tico, poniendo a Rusia y China en el mismo banquillo de acusados que a los pol√≠ticos republicanos de su pa√≠s.

‚ÄúFue particularmente desalentador ver que los l√≠deres de dos de los mayores emisores del mundo, China y Rusia, se negaron incluso a asistir a los procedimientos‚Äù , dijo Obama en la COP26.

Sus ‚Äúplanes nacionales hasta ahora reflejan lo que parece ser una peligrosa falta de urgencia y una voluntad de mantener el ‚Äòstatu quo‚Äô, y eso es una verg√ºenza‚Äù.

El expresidente Barack Obama, en su intervenci√≥n en el escenario principal de la cumbre clim√°tica COP26, tambi√©n apunt√≥ a los legisladores del Partido Republicano de Estados Unidos.

Obama dijo que tanto √©l como el actual presidente dem√≥crata, Joe Biden, se hab√≠an visto ‚Äúfrenados en gran parte por el hecho de que uno de nuestros dos principales partidos ha decidido no s√≥lo mantenerse al margen, sino expresar una hostilidad activa hacia la ciencia del clima y hacer del cambio clim√°tico una cuesti√≥n partidista‚Äù.

‚ÄúPara los que nos escuchan en Estados Unidos, perm√≠tanme decir esto: Si tu casa de Florida se inunda por la subida de los mares, o tus cosechas se pierden en las Dakotas o tu casa de California se incendia, no importar√° si eres republicano o dem√≥crata‚Äù.

‚ÄúA la naturaleza, a la f√≠sica, a la ciencia, no les importa la afiliaci√≥n partidista‚Äù, dijo.

Description:
La predisposici√≥n gen√©tica a la depresi√≥n combinada con la exposici√≥n a la contaminaci√≥n atmosf√©rica por part√≠culas hace crecer ‚Äúenormemente‚Äù el riesgo de que las personas sanas sufran ese trastorno, seg√∫n un estudio que publica Pnas.

"La conclusi√≥n de este estudio es que la contaminaci√≥n atmosf√©rica no solo repercute en el cambio clim√°tico, sino que tambi√©n afecta al funcionamiento del cerebro", seg√∫n Daniel Weinberger, coautor del estudio y del Instituto Lieber, que realiz√≥ la investigaci√≥n junto a la Universidad de Pek√≠n.

La contaminaci√≥n atmosf√©rica afecta a importantes circuitos cognitivos y emocionales del cerebro al cambiar la expresi√≥n de los genes, algo que ‚Äúno se hab√≠a demostrado antes‚Äù, lo que aumenta el riesgo de depresi√≥n, manifest√≥ Hao Yang Tan, tambi√©n del Instituto Lieber y que dirigi√≥ la investigaci√≥n

El experto indic√≥ que m√°s personas en zonas de alta contaminaci√≥n se deprimir√°n porque ‚Äúsus genes y la contaminaci√≥n de su entorno exageran los efectos individuales de cada uno".

Todas las personas tienen cierta propensi√≥n a desarrollar una depresi√≥n, pero algunas poseen un mayor riesgo inscrito en sus genes, lo que no significa que tengan que sufrirla, pero eleva el riesgo por encima de la media de la poblaci√≥n.

Description:
Former President Barack Obama on Monday took part in a session on Pacific islands, at the United Nations climate summit in Glasgow, seeking higher commitments from world leaders to help the islands, some of which are at risk of disappearing as the oceans rise.

Speaking to the crowd, he described the islands as representing "the canary in the coal mines" with regard to showing the rest of the world the very real problems that climate change will cause.

Rising sea levels has become a serious concern for many island nations.
Obama said how proud he was of the commitment the U.S. government and President Joe Biden have made in tackling climate change and stressed the responsibility of wealthy nations in helping more vulnerable countries in tackling environmental issues.

"Those of us who live in big wealthy nations, those of us who help to precipitate the problem, we have an added burden to make sure that we are working with and helping and assisting those who are less responsible and less able, but are more vulnerable to this oncoming crisis," Obama said.
ImageText: np OBAMA: WE HAVE TO ACT NOW' ON CLIMATE CRISIS November 8, 2021 TER In many ways our islands are COP26HOSTBROADCASTER/AP

üîéA melting Alpine glacier has revealed hidden WW1 tunnels and a bunker.‚Å†‚Å†
‚Å†‚Å†
It was once used by a platoon of Austro-Hungarian soldiers who repulsed suicidal assaults launched by Italian forces, but in the decades since was surrounded by a glacier.‚Å†‚Å†
‚Å†‚Å†
üèîÔ∏èThe ice preserved everything ‚Äì even scraps of paper, shreds of clothing and the hay that the soldiers used for bedding.‚Å†‚Å†
‚Å†‚Å†
But a century on, the glacier that once entombed the bunker, located on the slopes of Monte Scorluzzo in the Stelvio National Park, high in the Italian Alps, has largely melted as a result of global warming.‚Å†‚Å†

Description:
A minister from Tuvalu will address COP26 delegates from behind a podium, knee-deep in water out at sea, to highlight the risks his low-lying Pacific Island nation faces due to climate change.

In the pre-recorded statement, which will be played at the summit on Tuesday, Tuvalu's Minister of Justice, Communication and Foreign Affairs Simon Kofe spoke about rising sea levels affecting Pacific nations.

"The statement juxtaposes the COP26 setting with the real-life situations faced in Tuvalu due to the impacts of climate change and sea level rise and highlights the bold action Tuvalu is taking to address the very pressing issues of human mobility under climate change," the minister said in his video message.

Out of 15 Pacific nations, only three leaders from Palau, Fiji and Tuvalu have been able to attend the COP26 climate summit in Glasgow. The conference is now entering its second and final week, as leaders fight to reach an agreement to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels.

üì∏: Ministry of Justice, Communication and Foreign Affairs, Tuvalu Government

Foreign Minister Simon Kofe recorded the message last week to be shown at a conference event on Tuesday.

"The statement juxtaposes the COP26 setting with the real-life situations faced in Tuvalu due to the impacts of climate change and sea-level rise and highlights the bold action Tuvalu is taking to address the very pressing issues of human mobility under climate change," he said.

Images of the speech have been widely shared on social media - with many praising the effective message it sends.

Description:
How the climate crisis upended my life - by Vanessa Nieuwenhuizen in Samoa: 

It was the day before we were supposed to fly to Australia for a family reunion and Christmas in 2012, so it was a very exciting day to start off with. There was a cyclone due to hit Samoa. It started to rain really heavily and by the afternoon we started seeing water rising just around the house.

At around 4.30, I heard my husband screaming outside and I knew something was very wrong. By the time I made it outside, there was a massive gush of water coming towards our house, like an inland tsunami.

My husband yelled to grab the kids. My baby was sitting on the toilet. I grabbed him by the arm. The water was rising so quickly that by the time we made it out of the house, the water was up to our hips. 

We have four children and so my husband and I had one child on each arm as we waded through the water. There was one point where my husband and I looked at each other and in my anxious mind I thought: please, please, Heavenly Father, don‚Äôt let us have to make a decision to let one of our children go.

We all made it through, thank goodness. But the thought of having to let go of one of our children, I wouldn‚Äôt wish it upon any parent.

We made it into the workshop, and climbed the stairs towards the little storeroom. Our entire house was gone, our cars had been washed away, big machines in our workshop that had been bolted to the ground had washed away ‚Äì that‚Äôs how strong the water was. We stayed up in the storeroom for several hours, wrapped in old, dirty curtains to keep ourselves warm. I remember thinking: if we make it out alive, how and where are we going to start all over again?

We had an amazing life in Samoa but after we lost everything in that flash flood, we decided to move to Australia. Australia has been kind to us, but as much as we say this is home, Samoa will always be home. I miss Samoa. Every occasion, my thoughts turn to home, and I still cry.

---

Throughout the Cop26 summit, we will be publishing  stories of the people whose lives have been hit by the climate breakdown - tap the link in bio to read more.

Photo by David Kelly for the Guardian

#samoa #climatecrisis

Description:
From @nytopinion: 3,000 miles from Glasgow, a town and its polar bears are facing the future.

Churchill, an isolated town perched on the southern edge of the Arctic in Manitoba, Canada, bills itself as the Polar Bear Capital of the World. Climate change imbues daily life. Many people are focused on the opportunities global warming could bring to this cold-weather town. They dream of building a maritime city. For Churchill, innovation is the only reasonable course. 

Warmer weather, though, is endangering Arctic species, including the polar bears that gather there. The weather is opening the gates for other animals, like red foxes, wolves and brown bears, as well as a host of smaller species, to move north. The big white bears live out of rhythm with their southern cousins. In the winter, instead of sleeping, they roam across the surface of the frozen bay, looking for ringed seals. In the summer, when the ice melts, they rest on shore.

The bears are also the mainstays of the local tourism economy. And these days, every effort is made to keep the animals alive. Some bears may survive, at least for a time, by moving farther north. But over the coming decades, if greenhouse gas emissions continue to build at the current pace, the disappearance of polar bears from the Hudson Bay region is inevitable, according to a 2020 study conducted by scientists at Polar Bears International, a research and advocacy group.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about how Churchill and its famous polar bears are adapting to climate change. Photos by @damonwinter

Description:
Climate change is a big problem for everyone on Earth. 

Lots of human activity creates emissions which can cause climate change, but finding who creates most is key to helping reducing emissions and keeping global temperature rise below 2C.

Fossil fuel companies, rich countries and rich people all contribute a lot of emissions - whereas less developed nations, often most affected by climate change produce some of the lowest amounts of greenhouse gases. 

But, there are steps that all of us can take to reduce the emissions that we produce. 

Click the link in our bio to read more about the COP26 climate conference, currently under way in Glasgow.

Description:
Kinder, die gerade eingeschult worden sind, werden statistisch doppelt so viele Waldbr√§nde im Laufe ihres Lebens mitbekommen, f√ºnfmal mehr D√ºrren und 36-mal mehr Hitzewellen als heutige Erwachsene ‚Äì in einem eher pessimistischen Szenario der globalen Erw√§rmung um drei Grad. Das haben Forschende um den belgischen Klimaexperten Wim Thiery im September in der Wissenschaftszeitschrift ¬ªScience¬´ vorgerechnet. Dabei nimmt die Hitze in Deutschland regional, von Gemeinde zu Gemeinde, unterschiedlich stark zu.

Schon auf den ersten Blick zeigt sich: Die st√§rkste Erhitzung wird derzeit im sonnigen, relativ windarmen Oberrheingraben gemessen, aber auch die ostdeutschen Mittelgebirgslandschaften, gepr√§gt vom kontinentalen Klima, erw√§rmen sich deutlich. Die norddeutschen K√ºstenregionen dagegen sind wenig von Hitzewellen betroffen. Innerhalb Europas sind die regionalen Unterschiede noch viel gr√∂√üer.

Wenn man den Blick weitet auf die globalen Verh√§ltnisse, zeigt sich eine gravierende Ungleichverteilung. Afrikanische Nationen zum Beispiel tragen am wenigsten zum Klimawandel bei, weil sie kaum industrialisiert sind. Sie werden aber besonders stark von der Erw√§rmung getroffen. 

Lesen Sie im SPIEGEL, was die Klimakrise f√ºr Ihren Wohnort bedeutet. Den Link zum Artikel finden Sie in der Story. #Hitze #Klima #Klimawandel

Description:
Klima ist kein Schicksal. Klimaaktionspl√§ne setzen auf einfache Eingriffe: mehr Schatten, mehr Frischluftschneisen, mehr Gr√ºn, mehr Wei√ü, mehr Blau. 

Jeder Wohnort, jeder Stadtteil, jede Stra√üe braucht eigene Anpassungsma√ünahmen, um sich gegen die Erw√§rmung so gut es geht zu r√ºsten. Das Gute: Viele Methoden lohnen sich auf jeden Fall, egal wann und wie die n√§chste Hitzewelle einen Ort heimsucht. ¬ªNo regret¬´ nennen Fachleute dieses Prinzip: Egal, was kommt. Schattige Parks, gro√üz√ºgige Gr√ºnanlagen, einladende Wasserfl√§chen sind immer ein Gewinn, Klimawandel hin oder her.

Die lokalen Klimaanpassungen ersetzen dabei nat√ºrlich nicht die wichtigste Klimama√ünahme: das Verringern des Aussto√ües von klimawirksamen Gasen. Doch Nebelduschen und gr√ºne Fassaden k√∂nnen wie eine t√§gliche Erinnerung an die notwendigen Klimaziele wirken, als eine Art lebendes Denkmal zur Erinnerung an die gemeinsame Zukunft.

Description:
Siete veces m√°s olas de calor, el triple de sequ√≠as e inundaciones fluviales y el doble de incendios forestales. Este es el dram√°tico futuro que pronostica un grupo internacional de investigadores para las personas nacidas entre 2015 y 2020 si no cambia la actual pol√≠tica clim√°tica.

"Es una llamada a la acci√≥n. Necesitamos reducir las emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero dr√°sticamente para asegurar el futuro de las nuevas generaciones y contamos con los medios necesarios para hacerlo", asegura Wim Thiery, quien ha liderado este estudio, presentado hace unos d√≠as en Viena.

Titulado "Desigualdades intergeneracionales en la exposici√≥n a los extremos clim√°ticos", se trata de un trabajo conjunto de investigadores de diferentes universidades y expertos del renombrado Instituto Internacional de An√°lisis de Sistemas Aplicados (IIASA), situado al sur de Viena.

Una nueva rama de estudio
Hasta ahora, explica Thiery a Efe, la comunidad cient√≠fica hab√≠a estudiando los efectos del cambio clim√°tico comparando dos per√≠odos de tiempo concreto.

Este nuevo estudio cuantifica por primera vez la exposici√≥n a desastres naturales que tendr√° una persona nacida despu√©s de 2015 a lo largo de su vida.

Durante un a√±o y medio el equipo recab√≥ grandes cantidades de datos sobre la exposici√≥n en vida a cat√°strofes naturales para cada generaci√≥n nacida entre 1960 y 2020, de cada pa√≠s del mundo.

De este modo pudieron crear simulaciones para las futuras generaciones en funci√≥n de su pa√≠s y a√±o de nacimiento y el aumento de temperatura global hasta final de siglo y, a su vez, compararlas con la vida de los nacidos en los a√±os 1960.

Seg√∫n el Acuerdo de Par√≠s (2015), los pa√≠ses se comprometieron a mantener el aumento de temperatura global por debajo de los 2 ¬∞C en relaci√≥n a niveles pre-industriales.

Con un aumento de 3 grados en la temperatura global, los ni√±os y ni√±as nacidas en 2015 podr√≠an experimentar hasta 36 olas de calor m√°s que una persona nacida en 1960, mientras que ante una subida de 3,5 grados incluso ser√°n hasta 44.

Description:
Defying biting wind and steady rain, thousands took to the streets of Glasgow on Saturday in noisy and colorful protests, calling on global leaders to take action drastic enough to match the scale of a climate crisis already wreaking havoc on parts of the globe.

Waving banners, beating drums and chanting, an array of demonstrators ‚Äî including members of trade unions and faith organizations, as well as left-wing activists ‚Äî took over large parts of the Scottish city, which is hosting the COP26 climate summit. By midafternoon, a long, winding line of protesters was making its way through the city, taking more than an hour to pass a fixed point.

The protest illustrated how the battle to curb climate change had become an umbrella for a growing protest movement that aims to put global leaders under pressure for a broad range of causes, including racial justice and income equality.

Tap the link in our bio to read more from COP26. Photos by @kierandodds

Description:
Climate activist Maria Laura Rojas grew up comfortably in Bogota. But she always noticed suffering, whether it was people in pain or emaciated horses pulling carts on the street. "It gets to me very closely," she says.‚Å†
‚Å†
She went to law school, focused on discrimination based on ethnicity or gender, and eventually threw herself into advocacy for the rights of women. Then a friend recruited her for a job that seemed, on the face of it, completely different. She became a climate diplomat for the government of Colombia, a country that's squarely in the path of climate-related disruption. She joined delegations to international negotiations, including a pivotal one in Paris, in 2015, that produced a landmark agreement to cut global greenhouse gas emissions.‚Å†
Rojas realized that the fight against climate change is actually a fight on behalf of everyone who's powerless or left behind.‚Å†
‚Å†
After leaving Colombia's Ministry of Foreign Affairs she co-founded a group in Colombia called Transforma, focused on climate advocacy. They've developed proposals for protecting Colombia's forests and produced reports on whether foreign investments are helping to make the country more climate-resilient. Now she's back at this latest climate summit in Glasgow, but this time she's standing outside the negotiating rooms. She'll be pushing countries to provide more aid to communities that need help adapting to climate change, and releasing a podcast from the negotiations that's aimed at people in Latin America.‚Å†
‚Å†
(Image: @erikapineros ‚Ä¢ Erika Pi√±eros for NPR)‚Å†
‚Å†
‚Å†
Tap the link in our bio for more.‚Å†
ImageText: Fo Œ§Œø me, climate is aboutjustice. The injustice of it is what has always kept me moving and involved. It touches on everything that's important to me. Maria Laura Rojas, climate activist from Bogota, Colombia ErikaPi√±ePR

Conversamos con activistas de diversos puntos del orbe, mientras se dirig√≠an a la George Square, quienes criticaron la lentitud con que la clase dirigente enfrenta la destrucci√≥n del medio ambiente y expresaron el temor que les genera crecer en un planeta donde su voz no es escuchada. Description:
Francisco Vera, el ni√±o ambientalista que sigue el ejemplo de Greta Thunberg y que ha sido amenazado de muerte 

El colombiano Francisco Vera se autodefine como un ‚Äúactivista ambiental en defensa de la vida‚Äù y a su corta edad (12) ha sido amenazado de muerte por sus ideales. 

Vera es un firme defensor de los derechos del planeta. Forma parte del movimiento Guardianes por la vida, que aglutina a ni√±os y ni√±as que luchan contra el cambio clim√°tico, y su gran preocupaci√≥n es poder frenar a tiempo los efectos del cambio clim√°tico. Por ello, quiere meter presi√≥n a los Gobiernos para que cumplan lo que prometen: "Los discursos se deben aplicar. El Amazonas se est√° incendiando y deforestando, los oc√©anos est√°n llenos de pl√°stico y los polos se est√°n derritiendo".

Este ni√±o es toda una celebridad en Colombia y, pr√°cticamente, en toda Sudam√©rica. Salt√≥ a la fama por sus capacidades oratorias y opiniones sobre temas impropios para su edad. Incluso ha dado discursos en el Senado de su pa√≠s y se ha convertido en embajador de Buena Voluntad de la Uni√≥n Europea en Colombia.

Toda esta exposici√≥n le ha valido recibir numerosas amenazas de muerte por sus ideales ‚Äìha sido acusado de ser un ni√±o instrumentalizado por el poder‚Äì y burlas por su forma de ser y hablar. A principios de a√±o tuvo que grabar un v√≠deo casero en el que aseguraba que nadie le iba a callar. Iv√°n Duque, presidente de Colombia, sali√≥ en su defensa.

El papel de Vera es complicado. Colombia es el pa√≠s donde m√°s se asesinan a activistas medioambientales. Seg√∫n la ONG Global Witness, el 2020 se sald√≥ con la vida de 65 ambientalistas. Esta situaci√≥n ha provocado que Vera haya tenido varios episodios de ansiedad y haya tenido que ser tratado. No obstante, este ni√±o colombiano est√° dispuesto a lidiar con esta realidad para seguir haciendo pedagog√≠a sobre el cambio clim√°tico.

Ahora se encuentra en Escocia, donde ha podido mantener un breve encuentro con la activista sueca Greta Thunberg.

Lee la noticia completa de H√©ctor Farr√©s en el enlace de la biograf√≠a. üì≤ https://bit.ly/3bHRKA0 #FranciscoVera #ambientalista #GretaThunberg #COP26 #crisisclim√°tica üì∏ AFP / Twitter

Description:
Hay pocas dudas de que la protecci√≥n del medio ambiente y la gesti√≥n de los recursos naturales son el gran desaf√≠o que la humanidad afronta en el presente siglo.

Esta semana, con la #cop26 de Glasgow ya a pleno rendimiento, est√° m√°s presente que nunca en el debate p√∫blico, aunque el desaf√≠o no se agota en la lucha contra el calentamiento global y ata√±e a otros muchos aspectos, desde la ansiedad que sufrimos por la deriva de la contaminaci√≥n en el planeta a la gesti√≥n del agua, como ha revelado la 'sequ√≠a extraordinaria' que azota la cuenca del Guadalquivir.

El equipo de #DatosRTVE te lo cuenta en nuestra BIO.

Description:
A 24-year-old indigenous climate activist from the Brazilian Amazon has said global leaders have "closed their eyes" to climate change.

Txai Surui says her father told her to listen to the stars, moon, animals and trees.

"The Earth is speaking: she tells us we have no more time," she says.

She pleaded with leaders to put indigenous people at the centre of the decisions made as they are in "the front line of the climate emergency", adding her friend had been murdered for protecting the forest.

#ClimateChange #COP26 #Amazon #BBCNews
ImageText: Climate activist receives death threats after COP26 speech

Description:
If wine growers adapted relatively well to the Covid-19 crisis last year, they were now ‚Äúconfronting a much greater problem than the pandemic: climate change,‚Äù said director of the International Organisation of Vine and Wine (OIV) Paul Roca.

World wine production is expected to fall to one of its lowest levels on record after harsh weather battered vineyards in Europe‚Äôs major wine-producing regions.

The conditions ‚Äúseverely impacted‚Äù production in Italy, Spain and France, resulting in ‚Äúextremely low‚Äù production volumes, an international wine body has said.

In the midst of the shortage, demand is expected to recover to near levels seen before the coronavirus pandemic, according to the International Organisation of Vine and Wine (OIV).

They said a drop in production in Italy, Spain and France, the world‚Äôs largest wine producers, would outweigh what is forecast to be the highest-ever volume in the southern hemisphere.

Vineyards in western Europe were hit by spring frosts, while French producers also endured heavy rain, hail and mildew disease.

Global consumption trends were encouraging, with first-half data suggesting a rebound despite ongoing disruption to tourism and hospitality linked to the coronavirus pandemic, the OIV said.

‚ÄúWe still expect the global consumption to increase compared to 2020,‚Äù Pau Roca, the OIV‚Äôs director general, told reporters, noting first-half trade data showed volumes above pre-pandemic levels.

While ‚Äúthere is no vaccine‚Äù against climate change, he said ‚Äúthere are long-term solutions which will require major efforts in terms of sustainable practices for cultivating vines and producing wine‚Äù. He said adaptation was an ‚Äúurgent necessity‚Äù for the industry.

#wine #grapes #Europe #vineyard #covid #climatecrisis #globalheating
ImageText: G Warning over 'extremely low' wine production in Europe due to bad weather

Description:
Greta Thunberg ha asegurado que la cumbre del clima de Glasgow, la #COP26, "es un fracaso". Lo ha hecho ante miles de j√≥venes ecologistas, que han tomado este viernes las calles de la ciudad en una marcha organizada por la asociaci√≥n ambientalista Fridays For Future (FFF).

Description:
Thousands of activists march through Glasgow for climate action.

Young climate campaigners marched through the streets of Glasgow to demand action on climate change from leaders and politicians at COP26.

Greta Thunberg was among them and spoke at the end of the rally in George Square alongside other activists.

The Swedish campaigner said: "It is not a secret that COP26 is a failure. It should be obvious that we cannot solve a crisis with the same methods that got us into it in the first place."

#COP26 #FridaysforFuture #Scotland #Glasgow #COP26 #ClimateChange #World #Environment #UK #GretaThunberg #News #SkyNews

Description:
Photographer Ella Morton began documenting the Arctic and Subarctic in 2016, implementing analog techniques to warp the photos and illustrate climate change's effects in these areas.

"I feel a power and mystery in these areas that is hard to describe. I have also come to understand the accelerated pace at which the North is warming," Morton said. "I want to capture these areas before they are permanently altered by climate change."

Description:
Greta Thunberg has led thousands of people on a landmark demonstration through Glasgow, where the COP26 climate summit is taking place. 

The march was organised by a group founded by young people inspired by her activism.

Earlier in the week, she told protesters from ‚ÄúFridays for Future‚Äù that politicians attending COP26 were "pretending to take our future seriously".

She has said change would not come from politicians but from individuals showing leadership.

The Swedish teenager has become a powerful campaigning voice in recent years.

Description:
Climate activist Txai Suru√≠ received death threats after making a speech at the opening of the United Nations climate change conference, COP26.

Txai, who grew up in an indigenous community in the Amazon rainforest, told world leaders about the direct impacts of climate change that her tribe is already experiencing.

This prompted many people to send her abuse on social media.

Description:
The storms are more intense, and the sea has risen in southwest Bangladesh, because richer countries far away have released enormous amounts of heat-trapping gases into the atmosphere by burning coal, oil and gas. 

Activist Sufia Khatun helps lead an organization called Mothers Parliament, which is pushing for better water infrastructure in Bangladesh's coastal region.

 "That saline water is impacting our crops, livelihood, fishing, everything," Khatun says through an interpreter on an early-morning Zoom call. 

She says if she had a chance to speak to the international climate summit currently taking place in Glasgow, Scotland, she knows what she'd say. Her demands don't focus on reducing greenhouse gas emissions; she wants help dealing with the consequences of climate change that are already underway.

Images: (@mahmudhossainopu ‚Ä¢ Mahmud Hossain Opu for NPR)

Tap the link in our bio to learn about the struggles and successes in climate adaptation in Bangladesh.

Description:
"Indigenous peoples have done more than any government in fighting climate change".

Those are the words of @ninagualinga from the Kichwa peoples in the Ecuadorian Amazon. We spoken to her for the latest episode in our mini-series profiling young Indigenous climate activists during the Cop26 conference - looking at sustainable climate solutions based on centuries of Indigenous knowledge, spiritual customs and traditions.

Nina and her community have been protecting the Amazon rainforest from fossil fuel industries for decades: she explained to us why Indigenous people need to be given decision-making power at Cop26 and beyond.

Video: @neelamtailor + @nikhitachulani

Description:
Being eco-friendly, sustainable or green, is key to helping fight climate change.

But some companies which brand themselves in this way have been accused of exaggerating or making up their sustainable credentials - in a practise known as "greenwashing".

Delegates meeting at the COP26 climate conference are trying to work out how to ensure pledges made at the conference, by countries and corporations alike, cannot be seen as greenwashing.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the COP26 climate conference.

(Images: Getty Images)

#BBCNews #COP26BBC

Description:
Watch the moment a coal power station in the English village of Eggborough is demolished. It is just one of 14 coal plants the UK has laid to rest over the past decade. In 2012, 40% of the UK‚Äôs power came from coal. By 2020, it was below 2%. Last year, the country went 67 days without using any coal for power at all. Climate leaders at #COP26 talks in Glasgow, Scotland, have intensified their efforts to put an end date on the use of coal, the biggest single contributor to the climate crisis.

Tap the link in our bio for more on this story.

Description:
When celebrity royalty met the Prince of Wales.

Both keen environmentalists, the actor Leonardo DiCaprio spoke with Prince Charles at a fashion installation by designer Stella McCartney at the COP26 climate summit.

The ‚ÄòFuture of Fashion‚Äô exhibition is one of the events being staged in Glasgow, where world leaders and members of industry are meeting to try and limit the impacts of climate change.

Tap the link in our bio to find out more about the Hollywood star's visit and his interest in the environment.

Description:
As President Joe Biden‚Äôs administration puts its muscle behind wind power with plans to develop large-scale wind farms along the entire United States coastline, the administration can look at how the windiest nation in Europe is transforming its energy grid for an example of how to proceed.

In the search for renewable sources of energy, the United Kingdom has embraced wind power. In 2020, the country generated as much as 24 percent of its electricity from wind power ‚Äî enough to supply 18.5 million homes, according to government statistics. 

With usually reliable winds, the U.K. currently has the highest number of offshore turbines installed in the world, with China at a close second.

Experts and industry leaders say it offers valuable lessons on creating a viable market for wind power at the ambitious scale the Biden administration hopes to meet in order to confront climate change and help transition the U.S. economy to renewable energy.

Read more at the link in the bio.

üì∏ Duncan McGlynn for NBC News

Description: An Indonesian zoo says it is breeding Komodo dragons in an attempt to keep the species from extinction. Footage from this week shows the dragons in their enclosure at the Surabaya Zoo. The International Union for Conservation of Nature says the Komodo dragon population is increasingly threatened by climate change.
ImageText: Reuters

Description:
Europe can expect 50C heatwaves every three years if global emissions continue rising, according to new Met Office data.

This is under what's described as a "medium" emissions scenario.

The Met Office says that, unless the world takes significant action on climate change, by the year 2100 the continent can expect a similar heatwave every year.

#ClimateChange #BBCNews
ImageText: Wild weather

Description:
"I remember seeing metal fly up through the smoke. We saw burnt leaves just falling on the ground," recalled Harry, 11, as a bushfire approached his family home in Australia.

Across the world, pollution, rising temperatures, drought and changes is rain patterns are posing a serious threat to the health and wellbeing of millions - and causing untold trauma to young people.

Save the Children has been documenting the stories of kids living on the frontline of the climate crisis sending world-renowned photographers @mattabbottphoto, @limsokchanlina and @nadealy to Cambodia, Australia and Pakistan to learn about how they are being impacted.

Swipe to read more.

#climatecrisis #climatechange #rainfall #flooding #airpollution #pollution #bushfires #wildfires #cambodia #lahore #pakistan #australia #children #family #families #savethechildren @savethechildren

Description:
Philip Murphy was re-elected governor of New Jersey by a slim margin, overcoming an early deficit, public pushback over his coronavirus emergency orders and the unpopularity of President Biden.

Recent polling had suggested that Murphy would win by double digits. He became the first Democrat to be re-elected to the governor‚Äôs office in 44 years with his victory over his GOP challenger, Jack Ciattarelli, a former assemblyman who at one point on election night led by more than 50,000 votes.

The unexpectedly tight contest gave Democrats a measure of relief in deep-blue New Jersey, but it emboldened national Republicans as something that they could build on heading into next year‚Äôs midterm elections. Murphy‚Äôs narrow victory showed just how divided the state was over his tough policies to control the spread of the coronavirus and his liberal agenda on taxation, climate change and racial equity.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about Murphy and the governor‚Äôs race in New Jersey. Photo by Bryan Anselm for The New York Times.
ImageText: Democrat Philip Murphy Narrowly Wins N.J. Governor's Race Nov. Nov.3,2021 3, 2021

Description:
Protesters marched in Glasgow on Wednesday in opposition to ‚Äúgreenwashing‚Äù ‚Äî when companies claim to be protecting the environment while continuing to harm it ‚Äî as delegates inside the COP26 conference hall heard promises of new private-sector funding for climate change. 

Several hundred protesters, holding signs that read ‚ÄúAct now!‚Äù and ‚ÄúStop Funding Fossil Fuels,‚Äù gathered outside a shopping mall to demand that companies take more substantial steps.
‚ÄúFor us, there‚Äôs very little hope,‚Äù said Akke Houtsoma, an administrative worker who had traveled from the Netherlands to attend protests outside the climate conference. ‚ÄúI feel the most anxiety not about my future, but for the people right now who are suffering.‚Äù

A focus of the climate conference on Wednesday has been on how to pay for a global shift to cleaner energy sources. Even as a group of the world‚Äôs biggest investors, banks and insurers vowed to commit their more than $130 trillion in assets to pursuing climate goals, protesters were doubtful that the promises would be fulfilled.

Protests planned for Friday and Saturday in Glasgow are expected to draw tens of thousands. Tap the link in our bio for the latest from COP26. Photos by @andrew_testa

Description:
For "only the eighth time in 300 years‚Äù, the UK‚Äôs longest lasting patch of snow has disappeared.

Dubbed the Sphinx, the patch is in the Cairngorms national park in Scotland.

According to records, it has only previously fully melted in the 1700s, 1933, 1959, 1996, 2003, 2006, 2017 and 2018.

Snow patch expert Iain Cameron said climate change was a likely factor.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the history of this ancient snow patch, and what it means for the climate.

Description:
Right now in Glasgow, there are hundreds of protesters taking part in a 'Greenwash' march - as the Cop26 summit takes place around them.

The activists are trying to draw attention to the "climate criminals" who are "greenwashing rather than showing the real leadership needed to tackle climate breakdown", according to the event page of the group Extinction Rebellion - who organised the action.

The UN conference, which is taking place until 12 November, has already seen a score of promises and commitments by governments and world leaders to properly confront the climate crisis - and to set the world on a path to limit global heating to 1.5C.

But even just this week, Brazil's president Jair Bolsonaro was accused by activist of greenwashing as he made big promises to stop the deforestation in the Amazon rainforest.

Campaigners say they fear empty promises at Cop26 may gain countries access to conservation money, but that the world should pay more attention to the destructive policies of the recent past than vague promises about the future.

With world leaders set to depart Glasgow today - so that the crunch negotiations by their representatives, environment ministers or other high-ranking officials can begin - click the link in bio to follow the latest developments.

#greenwashing #sustainability #climatechange #ecofriendly #environment #climatecrisis #sustainableliving #sustainable #zerowaste #nature #green #eco #climateemergency #climatejustice #greenwash #fossilfuels #recycle #climateaction #globalwarming #Amazon #deforestation #Bolsonaro #XR #ExtinctionRebellion
ImageText: G greenwashing (noun): [ gri..woj.in] behaviour or activities that make people believe that a company, government, or organisation is doing more to protect the environment than it really is.

Description:
"Os pod√©is meter la crisis clim√°tica por el culo"

La activista adolescente Greta Thunberg vuelve a ser protagonista en la Cumbre del Clima que se est√° celebrando en Glasgow, donde no dud√≥ en cantar este duro duro mensaje a los l√≠deres reunidos en la ciudad escocesa.

La joven sueca ha pedido a los m√°ximos mandatarios mundiales "no m√°s bla, bla, bla" y que pasen a la acci√≥n, terminando con "la explotaci√≥n de las personas, la naturaleza y el planeta".

En un discurso junto a sus seguidores, Thunberg niega que el liderazgo est√© dentro de la COP26. "El cambio no vendr√° desde dentro. Eso no es liderazgo, esto es liderazgo", ha dicho se√±alando a los asistentes. 

"No m√°s lo que sea que est√°n haciendo ah√≠ dentro", acus√≥ Thunberg, se√±alando a los pol√≠ticos y personas en el poder que est√°n participando en la Cumbre del Clima.

Description:
üî¥IM√ÅGENES SENSIBLES | Turqu√≠a llora por la lenta muerte del lago Tuz, uno de sus parajes m√°s espectaculares que se apaga

El lago Tuz, el segundo m√°s grande de Turqu√≠a, ha sido durante a√±os uno de los mejores parajes naturales del pa√≠s. All√≠ han vivido grandes colonias de flamencos y se han podido contemplar incre√≠bles puestas de sol. Ahora, no hay agua ni flamencos.

Este inmenso lago de agua salada y 1.500 km¬≤ se ha convertido en un p√°ramo salpicado por charcos de agua: se ha secado completamente.
 
Los investigadores est√°n convencidos que el cambio clim√°tico y la sobreexplotaci√≥n de los humanos est√°n detr√°s de la nueva realidad del lago Tuz. Los agricultores realizan pr√°cticas muy agresivas para regar: desv√≠an el agua y cavan pozos para regar de forma intensiva. Por lo tanto, el calor extremo, la poca lluvia y la industria agr√≠cola se han llevado por delante este ic√≥nico lago salado y otros van por el mismo camino.

El Gobierno turco, sin embargo, no est√° muy de acuerdo con la versi√≥n de los expertos. Bekir Pakdemirli, ministro de Agricultura, dej√≥ claro en verano que la agricultura no ten√≠a nada que ver en los bajos niveles de agua pese a que asegur√≥ que se iban a tomar medidas.

Una de las peores consecuencias de esta transformaci√≥n es la muerte de centenares de ejemplares de aves. Los m√°s afectados han sido los flamencos. A lo largo de toda la extensi√≥n del lago Tuz se encuentran numerosos esqueletos de aves completamente fosilizados. Se est√° investigando las causas de la muerte pero se cree que est√°n relacionadas con la sequ√≠a del lago.

Las autoridades turcas han notificado que a lo largo de este a√±o han nacido en el lago alrededor de 5.000 aves mientras que las cifras habituales se elevan hasta los 12.000 de media.

‚úç Lee la noticia completa de H√©ctor Farr√©s en el enlace de la biograf√≠a. üì≤ https://bit.ly/3nP02M4 #lago #lagoTuz #Turqu√≠a 

(Las im√°genes 6 y 7 corresponden a los a√±os 2018 y 2020, respectivamente.)

üì∏ Getty Images

Description:
Finding usable water is a daily struggle for Bangladeshi villager Lalita Rani, who is struggling to cope with the effects of climate change.

To get fresh water, she has to go to a purification plant where water is treated and sold, but it costs 20 times more than in the capital city Dhaka. 

‚ÄúIf we don‚Äôt have money, then we have to drink pond water,‚Äù she said. 

Even then, she has to walk 1km to reach the nearest pond in her village.

Description:
Las decisiones que los estados tomen durante estas semanas en la cumbre del clima que se celebra en Glasgow podr√≠an ser decisivas para frenar el calentamiento global del planeta. Y las nuestras, como individuos, deber√≠an serlo tambi√©n.

Se calcula que solo el a√±o pasado cada espa√±ol emiti√≥ de media unas 4,5 toneladas de gases de efecto invernadero. Reducir esta cantidad con peque√±os gestos es clave para que el planeta 'respire' un poco m√°s tranquilo.

Description:
"Traici√≥n". As√≠ ha titulado la activista Greta Thunberg su clara y directa carta a los l√≠deres mundiales que se re√∫nen estos d√≠as en la COP26, la Cumbre del Clima, con las cinco cuestiones m√°s inminentes sobre la crisis clim√°tica que cree que deber√≠an tratarse de inmediato.

La intenci√≥n de la fundadora de la organizaci√≥n Fridays For Future es entregar esta carta-petici√≥n a los l√≠deres mundiales presentes en Glasgow con el apoyo de un mill√≥n y medio de firmas, recogidas a trav√©s de la plataforma Avaaz.

Concretando objetivos y calendario, Thunberg expone en su carta/petici√≥n: "Como ciudadanas del planeta, les rogamos que afronten la emergencia clim√°tica. No el a√±o que viene. Ni el pr√≥ximo mes. Ahora mismo. Pedimos:

- No abandonar el objetivo del 1,5 ¬∫C y conseguir una reducci√≥n inmediata, dr√°stica y sin precedentes de las emisiones anuales.

- Cortar inmediatamente todas las inversiones, subsidios y proyectos relacionados con los combustibles f√≥siles, y detener nuevos proyectos de exploraci√≥n y extracci√≥n.

- Poner fin a la contabilidad del carbono "creativa" publicando las emisiones totales de todos los √≠ndices de consumo, las cadenas de producci√≥n y distribuci√≥n, el transporte internacional a√©reo o mar√≠timo, y la combusti√≥n de la biomasa.

- Hacer entrega de los 100.000 millones de d√≥lares [anuales] prometidos a los pa√≠ses m√°s vulnerables, incluyendo fondos adicionales para enfrentar desastres clim√°ticos.

- Aprobar pol√≠ticas clim√°ticas para proteger a los trabajadores y a los m√°s vulnerables, y reducir todas las formas de desigualdad".

Para acabar con un tono positivo y esperanzador, la parte final de la carta concluye que todos estos objetivos se pueden alcanzar si existe decisi√≥n y valent√≠a.

Description:
El cambio clim√°tico y el calentamiento global es la fuente principal de los incendios forestales que afectan el oeste de Estados Unidos (EEUU), seg√∫n un grupo de investigadores.

Los incendios destruyeron un promedio de 1,35 millones de hect√°reas cada a√±o en el oeste de EEUU entre 2001 y 2018, el doble que entre 1984-2000.

‚ÄúHa sucedido mucho m√°s r√°pido de lo que anticipamos‚Äù, alert√≥ a Los √Ångeles Times Rong Fu, quien dirigi√≥ el estudio publicado por la Academia Nacional de Ciencias de Estados Unidos (PNAS).

Para comprender qu√© contribuy√≥ a un deterioro tan significativo de las condiciones y en tan poco tiempo, un equipo de investigadores estadounidenses dirigido por Fu analiz√≥ varios factores que act√∫an en el ‚Äúd√©ficit de presi√≥n de vapor‚Äù (VPD), que indica qu√© tan seco est√° el aire.

El VPD representa la diferencia entre la cantidad de agua realmente presente en la atm√≥sfera y el m√°ximo que la atm√≥sfera podr√≠a contener.

Cuanto mayor es el d√©ficit, m√°s agua se extrae del suelo y las plantas, sec√°ndolas y creando condiciones cada vez m√°s propicias para los incendios.

M√°s detalles en las stories.

Description:
He grasped nature's fragility when he travelled into space and now Amazon founder Jeff Bezos has pledged $2bn to restoring it.

The money from the Bezos Earth Fund will go to restoring landscapes and transforming food systems, he told the COP26 climate conference in Glasgow.

"In too many parts of the world, nature is already flipping from a carbon sink to a carbon source," he said.

The fund plans to spend $10bn fighting climate change overall.

Description:
Leaders of more than 100 countries, including Brazil, China, Russia and the U.S., vowed on Tuesday at climate talks in Glasgow to end deforestation by 2030, seeking to preserve forests crucial to absorbing carbon dioxide and slowing the rise in global warming.

The pledge will demand ‚Äútransformative further action,‚Äù the countries‚Äô declaration said, and it was accompanied by several measures intended to help put it into effect. But some advocacy groups criticized them as lacking teeth, saying they would allow deforestation to continue.
The pact encompasses about 85% of the world‚Äôs forests, officials said.

Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain announced the deforestation agreement at an event Tuesday morning attended by President Biden and the president of Indonesia, Joko Widodo.
‚ÄúThese great teeming ecosystems ‚Äî these cathedrals of nature ‚Äî are the lungs of our planet,‚Äù Johnson said.

Tap the link in our bio for live updates from COP26. Photo by @victormoriyama

Description:
Outside the COP26  summit in Glasgow, climate activist Greta Thunberg speaks at a protest and takes a swipe at politicians "pretending" to take the climate crisis seriously. 

The G20 including China, India and Western nations committed on Sunday to the Paris goal of limiting global warming to 1.5C. 

They also agreed to end funding for new coal plants abroad without carbon capturing technology by the end of 2021.

But the precise pathway to 1.5C was left largely undefined and campaigners expressed disappointment with the group, which collectively emits nearly 80 percent of global carbon emissions.

Preparations for the high-level summit had been dampened by a number of high-profile no shows.
Both Chinese President Xi Jinping -- who has not left his country during the Covid-19 pandemic -- and Russia's Vladimir Putin will not be in Glasgow. And Monday saw Turkish President Recip Tayyip Erdogan cancel his appearance, for unspecified reasons.
France's Emmanuel Macron called on the "largest emitters" to redouble their pollution cutting plans during COP26. 
"The key over the next 15 days at this COP, is that the largest emitters, whose national strategies do not align with our objective of 1.5C of warming, raise their ambition," he said.
Observers say the Glasgow gathering, which runs until November 12, will be tough going.
Most nations have already submitted their renewed emissions cutting plans -- known as "nationally determined contributions", or NDCs -- in advance of COP26.
But even these current commitments -- if followed -- would still lead to a "catastrophic" warming of 2.7 Celsius, according to the UN. - AFP
ImageText: GRETA S THUNBERG CALLS FOR 'CLIMATE JUSTICE' IN PROTEST OUTSIDE COP26 November 1, 2021 H √é STUART GRAHAM/AFPTV/ GRAHAM AFPTV -What do we want?

Description:
The president of the Pacific island nation of Palau has told the Cop26 summit that parallels can be drawn between the climate crisis and the tradition Palau story of a boy who grew into a giant who ‚Äúwouldn‚Äôt stop growing‚Äù.

‚ÄúDue to his unruly appetite, the whole island community was forced to feed him ... depleting all the natural resources," said Surangel Whipps Jr to fellow world leaders in Glasgow.

He explained how the islanders ultimately set the boy on fire after he turned on them and tried to eat them - and pointed out that the story was ‚Äúeerily reminiscent‚Äù of today‚Äôs climate emergency.

‚ÄúLarge emitters with insatiable appetites are continuing to abuse our environment, threatening our very survival. Cop26 must light the fire.‚Äù

He added that ‚Äúdevastated‚Äù island nations such as Palau, demand that commitments of $100bn annually be increased to meet the $4tn the World Bank says is needed to tackle the climate crisis.

‚ÄúWe see the scorching sun is giving us intolerable heat, the warming sea is invading us and the winds are blowing us every which way, our resources are disappearing before our eyes and our future is being robbed from us,‚Äù he added.

‚ÄúFrankly speaking, there is no dignity to a slow and painful death - you might as well bomb our islands instead of making us suffer only to witness our slow and painful demise.‚Äù

‚ÄúLeaders of the G20, we are drowning and our only hope is the life-ring you are holding. You must act now, we must act together.‚Äù

Description:
Climate activists have gathered in Glasgow to protest against the COP26 climate conference.

The UK is hosting a summit where world leaders will be asked how they plan to bring down carbon emissions.

Extreme weather events linked to climate change and harmful gases - including heatwaves, floods and forest fires - are intensifying and becoming more frequent.

For this conference, 200 countries are being asked for their plans to cut emissions by 2030.

Tap the link in our bio to find out how the decisions made at COP26 will affect you.

(üì∑ Reuters, Getty Images)

Description:
"I think Ghoramara will disappear underwater within 10 or 15 years."

Throughout the 2021 UN climate change conference, Cop26, we will be publishing the stories of the people whose lives have been devastated by the climate breakdown.

This is Sunil Kandar's story:

I live in the Hatkhola locality of Ghoramara [in India]. I remember how on this island, during my childhood, I had a very happy and enjoyable life. We had a big mud-walled house. We also had large farmland of our own where rice and other vegetables grew. We sold a big part of our farm produce in the market. Like some other families in the island we were pretty rich. The farmland owned by our family was our biggest strength.

Our island is located at the mouth of a river coming from the north. The northern edge of the island began sinking bit by bit under the river water when I was a child. Then, 20 or 25 years ago, the sea began eating away land around the southern edge of the island where we lived. Ghoramara began going underwater almost from all sides and the island began shrinking fast. Farmlands and houses of the people are constantly going underwater.

Cyclones are pounding our island more frequently in recent years. The fragile island is too feeble to keep away the tidal waves... Whatever farmlands are left on the island are turning unusable because of inundation by seawater and increasing salinity of the soil.

Once I owned four acres of farmland. In the past 20 years, three-quarters of it has been lost under the sea. This year I have been forced to buy rice for us, for the first time in my life.

I am over 50 now. I cannot go out of the island, learn a new skill and pick up another job. My son knew he cannot earn a living on this island. So, he left the island and has become a migrant day-wage labourer in south India and sends money to support our family.

Oceanographers and other experts came to the island and conducted studies five years ago. They said the water level around the island is rising and it will perhaps completely vanish underwater by 2050. But in the past five years, the island has been shrinking. I think Ghoramara will disappear underwater within 10 or 15 years.
