"La agenda y el tel√©fono no se detienen. Juan Carlos Jobet (46), biministro de las carteras de Miner√≠a y Energ√≠a, ocupa el cargo en un momento clave no solo para el sector en Chile, sino tambi√©n a nivel global. Tras la m√°s reciente publicaci√≥n del √∫ltimo informe del IPCC, se volvi√≥ esencial tomar medidas acordes a las necesidades del minuto y que ayuden a reducir nuestra huella ante el cambio clim√°tico. Pero Jobet ya hab√≠a apretado el acelerador durante el √∫ltimo tiempo.

Chile ya lleva dos a√±os trabajando en el cierre de centrales a carb√≥n, impulsando las energ√≠as limpias y la electromovilidad, y desarrollando las bases para instalar en el pa√≠s la nueva industria del hidr√≥geno verde (H2V) y que puede servir para la econom√≠a nacional. En palabras de Jobet, el H2V es producido a partir de ERNC como la energ√≠a solar, la e√≥lica, entre otras, y, al no emitir gases de efecto invernadero, es una de las alternativas energ√©ticas m√°s prometedoras para luchar contra el cambio clim√°tico y alcanzar la carbono neutralidad al 2050.

Jobet lleva dos a√±os en el cargo y, al comenzar con la iniciativa de hidr√≥geno verde, eran veinte los proyectos que ten√≠an en carpeta, frente a los m√°s de sesenta que son actualmente. De norte a sur, ubicados principalmente a ambos extremos del pa√≠s, se presentan como una alternativa sustentable y que podr√≠a ayudar a Chile en un futuro, frente a la exportaci√≥n del recurso."

Description:
In order to lessen their carbon footprint, many Americans have stopped driving gas-guzzling SUVs, eating steak every week, and even using plastic straws. 
 
But marine biologist and writer Ayana Elizabeth Johnson (@ayanaeliza) says that when focusing on our small individual actions, we can often lose sight of the larger, systemic, or corporate actions that negatively impact the earth‚Äôs climate.

On this episode of It‚Äôs Been a Minute with Sam Sanders, @samsanders talks to Ayana and @how2saveaplanet senior climate reporter Kendra Pierre-Louis (@Kendracanwrite) to answer YOUR questions about climate change. Questions include: Is there anywhere to live in the U.S. that‚Äôs safe from climate change? How do you talk to kids about global warming? And what changes can we make that actually have a positive effect?  Tap the link in the bio to learn more!

Description:
Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain kicked off the United Nations‚Äô COP26 summit in Glasgow on Monday with an urgent call for action, likening climate change to a bomb primed to explode, even as he acknowledged the challenges ahead.

‚ÄúThe tragedy is that this is not a movie and the doomsday device is real,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúHumanity has long since run down the clock on climate change. It is one minute to midnight on that doomsday clock, and we need to act now.‚Äù

The high-stakes summit has been called a last chance for countries to come together to stop catastrophic global warming. Almost 200 nations sent high-level delegations. They hope to put the world back on track to meet the goals set in Paris, including reducing global carbon emissions to zero by 2050, and limiting the planet's overall warming to 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit.

For more, click the link in our bio.

El presidente del Gobierno, Pedro S√°nchez, ha anunciado este lunes que Espa√±a elevar√° un 50 por ciento su financiaci√≥n clim√°tica para los pa√≠ses en desarrollo con la meta de alcanzar una aportaci√≥n de 1.350 millones de euros a partir de 2025.

Description:
Gestern hat im schottischen #Glasgow die 26. Uno-Klimakonferenz begonnen. W√§hrend Staatschefs und Delegierte auf internationalen Gipfeln um eine Begrenzung der #Klimakrise ringen, bricht die #Erw√§rmung fortw√§hrend neue Rekorde. Um rund 1,2 Grad hat sich die #Erde gegen√ºber der vorindustriellen Zeit bereits aufgeheizt ‚Äì in vielen Regionen sogar noch deutlich mehr. Und auch der Blick in die nahe Zukunft verbreitet wenig Hoffnung: Der Weltklimarat h√§lt es f√ºr wahrscheinlich, dass bereits in den fr√ºhen 2030er-Jahren die 1,5-Grad-Marke √ºberschritten werden wird ‚Äì mit gravierenden Folgen f√ºr Mensch und Klima.

Der #Klimawandel ist schon lange kein Ph√§nomen mehr, das sich irgendwann in der Zukunft abspielt ‚Äì er ist bereits jetzt vielerorts Realit√§t, wie auch diese Grafiken zeigen.

Description:
Sir David Attenborough told world leaders at the COP26 climate conference that the future of young people should provide impetus to "turn tragedy into triumph" on climate change.

The naturalist said: "In my lifetime I've witnessed a terrible decline. In yours you could - and should - see a wonderful recovery."

The burning of fossil fuels and other industrial activities jeopardises "everything we have achieved in the last 10,000 years," he said. "We are already in trouble, the stability we all depend on is breaking."

"This story is one of inequality as well as instability. Those who‚Äôve done the least to cause this problem are being the hardest hit."

Click the link in our bio for the latest news from the conference in Glasgow, Scotland.

Description:
Likening climate change to a bomb moments from exploding, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain kicked off the United Nations‚Äô COP26 in Glasgow on Monday with an urgent call for action even as he acknowledged the challenges ahead.

‚ÄúThe tragedy is that this is not a movie and the doomsday device is real,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúHumanity has long since run down the clock on climate change. It is one minute to midnight on that doomsday clock, and we need to act now.‚Äù

Underscoring the urgency of the moment, with leaders of more than 120 countries facing pressure to immediately curb greenhouse gas emissions, the United Nations secretary general, Ant√≥nio Guterres, said that the effects of a warming planet were already being felt ‚Äúfrom the ocean depths to the mountaintops.‚Äù

‚ÄúSea level rise has doubled from 30 years ago,‚Äù he said. Oceans are hotter than ever, parts of the Amazon rainforest emit more carbon than they absorb, and in the last decade about four billion people were affected by events related to the changing climate.

The conference‚Äôs aim is to prevent the average global temperature from rising more than 1.5 degrees Celsius compared with levels before the Industrial Revolution. That is the threshold beyond which scientists say the dangers of global warming ‚Äî such as deadly heat waves, water shortages, crop failures and ecosystem collapse ‚Äî grow immensely.

Tap the link in our bio for live coverage of COP26.
ImageText: "It's one minute to midnight on that doomsday clock, and we need to act now." Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain speaking at COP26

"Desde las profundidades oce√°nicas hasta las cimas de las monta√±as, desde el derretimiento de los glaciares hasta los implacables fen√≥menos meteorol√≥gicos extremos, se est√°n destruyendo los ecosistemas y las comunidades de todo el mundo", se√±al√≥ el secretario general de la ONU, Antonio Guterres, en v√≠deo, durante la presentaci√≥n del √∫ltimo informe de la OMM. En el informe preliminar de 2021 en el primer d√≠a de la conferencia del clima COP26 de Glasgow, Guterres pidi√≥ que se entienda como "un punto de inflexi√≥n (...) para proteger nuestro futuro y salvar a la humanidad". Existen cada vez m√°s pruebas cient√≠ficas que indican que algunos de estos fen√≥menos llevan el sello del cambio clim√°tico causado por las actividades humanas", declar√≥ en rueda de prensa el secretario general de la OMM, Petteri Taalas. Description:
In 2019, we made a pledge in service of the planet. We declared that the escalating climate crisis was the defining issue of our lifetime, and that quality, trustworthy reporting on the environment was a vital tool to confront it. We promised to provide journalism that showed leadership, urgency, authority and give the climate emergency the sustained attention and prominence it demanded.

Two years later, we are updating our readers and supporters on our work ‚Äì journalism that puts pressure on the decision-makers who hold our fate in their hands, and institutional commitments designed to ensure that we practice what we preach.

Swipe to see the six promises we've made to you - and all our readers - and click the link in bio to find out more about our progress so far.

Description:
The Queen has been spotted out and about for the first time since spending a night in hospital last week.

She was seen today driving her car around her Windsor estate, on the same day she had been due to attend the COP26 climate change summit in Glasgow.

Her Majesty was wearing a head scarf and dark glasses as she sat at the wheel of a Jaguar.

On Friday it was revealed that the 95-year-old had cancelled all working visits for the next two weeks and had been advised to stick to ‚Äúlight, desk-based duties‚Äù.

It means several of her royal engagements have been cancelled, including the COP26 climate change conference which starts today.

Description:
Die Welt blickt nach Schottland: Auf der Klimakonferenz in Glasgow verhandeln Regierungschefs und Experten ab Montag, wie sich der Klimawandel aufhalten l√§sst!
Streit ist programmiert. Denn vor allem die deutsche Entscheidung, statt aus der schmutzigen Kohle zun√§chst aus der Kernkraft auszusteigen, sorgt f√ºr Kritik.
Experten warnen: Ohne die Kernenergie gibt es auch keinen Klimaschutz. Sie fordern: Atomkraft? Ja, bitte!
Bei der Atomenergie fallen so gut wie keine CO¬≤-Emissionen an, lediglich die Windkraft produziert den Strom noch umweltfreundlicher. Die Vereinten Nationen (UN) kommen deshalb in einem neuen Bericht zum Schluss:
Um die Klimaziele zu erreichen, MUSS die Kernkraft eine Rolle spielen. Die Kilowattstunde Atomstrom kostet im Schnitt nur ein Drittel (ca. 2,5 Cent) des Wind-/Sonnenstroms (8,0 bis 11,5 Cent).
Der d√§nische Klima-Experte Bj√∏rn Lomborg erkl√§rt: ‚ÄûDas liegt daran, dass Deutschland bereits f√ºr den Bau des Kraftwerks bezahlt hat und dass Deutschland sich bereits verpflichtet hat, das Kraftwerk stillzulegen ‚Äì die beiden gr√∂√üten Kosten.‚Äú Deutschland braucht auch Strom bei Flaute und Wolkenhimmel. Die Entscheidung, aus Kernkraft bis 2022 und danach aus der Kohle auszusteigen, h√§lt Top-√ñkonom Prof. Hans-Werner Sinn deshalb f√ºr einen Fehler: ‚ÄûWir sind die Geisterfahrer auf der Autobahn.‚Äú 
Foto: picture alliance / Peter Kneffel
#Kernkraft #Atom #Atomenergie #Kernkraftwerk #Kernenergie #Klima #Glasgow #CO2

Description:
Bei der Weltklimakonferenz sind Gesandte aus rund 200 Staaten vertreten und wollen bis zum 12. November beraten, wie die 2015 in Paris vereinbarten Klimaziele eingehalten werden k√∂nnen. 

Zum Auftakt hat UNO-Klimachefin Espinosa an die Staatengemeinschaft appelliert, die Erderw√§rmung ehrgeiziger zu bek√§mpfen. Man stehe beim Klimaschutz an einem Wendepunkt der Geschichte, sagte die Exekutivsekret√§rin der Klimarahmenkonvention. Entweder w√ºrden die Emissionen schnell reduziert, um das 1,5-Grad-Ziel zu erreichen. Oder man akzeptiere, dass die Menschheit einer d√ºsteren Zukunft entgegenblicke. Aktuelle Prognosen gehen davon aus, dass bis zum Jahr 2100 mit einem Plus von 2,7 Grad Celsius zu rechnen ist.

Daher mehren sich Forderungen, beim Klimaschutz verst√§rkt auf Kernenergie und auch Gas zu setzen. In der Europ√§ischen Union fordert Frankreich im Verbund mit einer Reihe osteurop√§ischer Staaten, sie als klimafreundliche Technologien anzuerkennen. Doch Atomreaktoren und Gaskraftwerke sind Auslaufmodelle, kommentiert Georg Ehring. Die betreffenden Regierungen wollten damit Branchen st√ºtzen ‚Äì das habe so wenig Zukunft wie die Braunkohle.
.
.
.

World leaders from 120 countries are meeting in Glasgow, aiming to bring climate change under control.

Running from 31 October to 12 November, in Glasgow, Scotland, up to 25,000 people are expected to attend - ranging from world leaders to negotiators and journalists. 

At the climate change conference 200 countries will be asked for their plans to cut emissions by 2030.

Description:
‚ÄúThis island is me, and I am this island,‚Äù Wadhuam Pabai Pabai (pictured on the left) says of the homeland he‚Äôs known all his life.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt imagine being forced to leave Boigu ‚Ä¶ there are 65,000 years of wealth and experience here,‚Äù the father of seven says. Losing Boigu, his home in the Torres Strait, will mean losing all of it.

He and fellow islander Wadhuam Paul Kabai (pictured on the right), are leading a class action on behalf of their island communities, arguing the commonwealth of Australia is acting unlawfully in failing to stop climate change that, if unchecked, will destroy their homelands.

They are drawing inspiration - if not direct precedent ‚Äì from a case from the Netherlands know as the Urgenda case. This is where 886 plaintiffs argued the Dutch government had an obligation to protect its citizens from the impacts of climate change. That case, challenged all the way to the country‚Äôs supreme court by the government, succeeded at every level.

The result was a dramatic shift in Dutch government policy ‚Äì including the closure of coal-fired power stations, billions of euros of investment in renewable energy and energy efficiency, and binding commitments towards emissions reductions. Similar cases have followed in Belgium, Canada, Colombia, Germany, France, New Zealand, and elsewhere.

But the Urgenda decision relied significantly on the European Convention on Human Rights ‚Äì particularly articles two and eight, safeguarding the rights to life, and to a private and family life. That law does not apply to Australia, but lawyers will argue the commonwealth of Australia has a legal ‚Äúduty of care‚Äù towards Torres Strait Islander peoples, arising both from negligence law and the Torres Strait Treaty and Native Title.

Swipe to find out more about what exactly the class action - which was filed in the federal court last week - is calling for.

Follow @guardianaustralia for more.

Description:
Greta Thunberg has defended the tactics of environmental activists who have blocked roads, saying "sometimes you need to anger people".
 
But the teenage campaigner, who is in Glasgow for the COP26 summit, said that it was important to ensure no-one was hurt.
 
People needed to demonstrate "massive public pressure" on politicians to ensure they did enough to reduce carbon emissions, she told the BBC's Andrew Marr Show.
 
The activist, who shot to fame worldwide after leading school strikes to protest against climate change, said her own movement "would never have become so big if there wasn't friction".
 
Tap the link in our bio for more on her interview, and what she had to say when asked if she wanted to be a politician.
 
#ClimateChange #COP26BBC #BBCNews
ImageText: NEWS "Sometimes you need to anger some people" Greta Thunberg

Description:
President Joe Biden and leaders of some of the world's wealthiest nations on Saturday backed a 15% global minimum corporate tax, a dramatic restructuring of the international tax system intended to make sure big companies pay their fair share. 

Finance ministers of almost 140 countries had already backed the tax change. Biden and other G-20 leaders came out in support of the tax during the opening session of their first in-person summit in two years. 

The G-20's support of the international tax package amounted to a victory of sorts for Biden, who is pushing Congress to pass a 15% minimum tax on corporate earnings to help pay for one of his key domestic plans ‚Äî an ambitious package of climate change and social safety proposals.

Description:
Greta Thunberg mobbed as she arrives in Glasgow.

Greta Thunberg arrived ahead of the COP26 summit, where world leaders will discuss how to tackle the climate crisis.

It comes after the 18-year-old Swede revealed she had not been "officially" invited to the summit.

Despite being surrounded by police and other environmental activists upon leaving the train, she appeared in high spirits.

The international conference officially kicks off today, with a summit of 120 dignitaries and heads of state commencing the following day.

Las se√±ales de alarma que demuestran que el Mar Muerto va camino de desaparecer

"En un futuro puede que tengamos suerte de tener un canal de agua en el que la gente pueda meter los dedos de los pies", se lamenta Alison Ron, una residente de Ein Gedi que una vez trabaj√≥ en el spa que se convirti√≥ en el atractivo tur√≠stico de la zona en la d√©cada de 1960. A escasos metros del recinto, las saladas aguas del Mar Muerto eran un contraste √∫nico. Ahora, la playa queda mucho m√°s lejos y est√° perforada por cr√°teres enormes.

El Mar Muerto ha perdido un tercio de su superficie desde 1960. El agua azul retrocede alrededor de un metro cada a√±o, dejando atr√°s un paisaje lunar blanqueado por la sal y perforado con grandes sumideros, que pueden exceder los 10 metros de profundidad y son un testimonio del retroceso del mar. 

El agua salada deja dep√≥sitos de sal subterr√°neos a su paso, la escorrent√≠a de las inundaciones peri√≥dicas se filtra al suelo y disuelve las manchas de sal. Por tanto, sin ning√∫n tipo de apoyo la tierra de arriba se derrumba.‚ÄúAhora hay miles de sumideros alrededor de las costas del Mar Muerto, en Jordania, Israel y la Cisjordania‚Äù, explica Ittai Gavrieli, del Instituto Geol√≥gico de Israel.

Una situaci√≥n que no tiene nada de arbitr√°ria, sino que es un reflejo de la pol√≠tica humana que literalmente ha diezmado el flujo de agua hacia el Mar Muerto. Tanto Israel como Jordania han desviado las aguas del r√≠o Jord√°n para riego agr√≠cola y agua potable. Adem√°s, las empresas qu√≠micas han extra√≠do minerales del agua de mar.

Por si fuera poco, el cambio clim√°tico acelera a√∫n m√°s su evaporaci√≥n. Los grandes sumideros que se multiplican alrededor del Mar Muerto mientras sus aguas retroceden es un signo claro de ‚Äúla venganza de la naturaleza‚Äù.

Entonces, ¬øel Mar Muerto est√° condenado a evaporarse? Los cient√≠ficos dicen que su declive es inevitable durante al menos los pr√≥ximos 100 a√±os.

Mantener viable el objetivo del 1,5 requerir√° compromisos y acciones significativas y eficaces por parte de todos los pa√≠ses‚Äù, se√±ala el comunicado final. El documento tambi√©n contiene una promesa de acelerar los esfuerzos para eliminar y racionalizar subsidios a combustibles f√≥siles; contempla un compromiso de no financiar los tipos m√°s contaminantes de centrales de carb√≥n en el exterior; reafirma la ‚Äúimportancia‚Äù de cumplir con el acuerdo para movilizar unos 100.000 millones de d√≥lares anuales para los pa√≠ses m√°s vulnerables y acelerar la transferencia de tecnolog√≠a a esos pa√≠ses para facilitar su transici√≥n ecol√≥gica.‚Å†

From @nytopinion: Greta Thunberg has given up on politicians when it comes to actively working towards fixing the climate crisis. 

‚ÄúWe have passed a social tipping point,‚Äù @gretathunberg, the young climate activist, says in an @nytopinion video guest essay. ‚ÄúWe can no longer look away from what our society has been ignoring for so long.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt is an existential crisis. We must now do the seemingly impossible. And that is up to you and me because no one else will do it for us.‚Äù

In the guest essay, Thunberg criticizes the politicians who‚Äôve used her platform for their own political points, but have yet to do anything meaningful when it comes to the fight to fix the climate crisis. Tap the link to learn more.

Video by @crankbunny and @jaredpscott

From ‚Äúthe greenhouse effect‚Äù, through to ‚Äúglobal warming‚Äù and ‚Äúclimate chaos‚Äù, it can be difficult to work out how best to communicate what's happening to our planet.

The language we use is crucial in the fight against global warming. 

Climate change suggests something slow, gradual and managed ‚Äì but we know we need to act fast if we want to halt it. Global warming suggests it‚Äôs all to do with the planet getting hotter, whereas science tells us there might be all kinds of changes in weather and extreme variations.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the COP26 climate conference, and why politicians, scientists and all attendees will be looking to find solutions to help solve the problems we face with climate change.

Das ist das ¬ªHaus des Jahres¬´ 2021. 
Ja, richtig gelesen. Diese Villa in Z√ºrich hat den Architekturpreis des Callwey Verlags gewonnen ‚Äì trotz ihres Baustellencharakters. Trotz? Genau deswegen!

Die Architekten Gabrielle H√§chler und Andreas Fuhrimann haben das Haus gegen g√§ngige Sch√∂nheitskonventionen entworfen: ¬ªWir haben uns √ºber die Jahre eine exklusive Klientel erarbeitet, die sich Auseinandersetzung und einen kulturellen Mehrwert w√ºnscht¬´.

Auf knapp 250 Quadratmetern erstreckt sich das Ge√§ude rau und unverputzt vier Geschosse in die H√∂he. Das Handwerk sollte sichtbar bleiben ‚Äì und quillt nun in Form von M√∂rtel aus den Fugen der Au√üenw√§nde. F√ºr die Architekten ist das ein Kommentar auf Perfektionswahn und die ¬ªEntmaterialisierung von Oberfl√§chen¬´.

Die Jury um den Direktor des Deutschen Architekturmuseums zeigt sich begiestert: ¬ªVor der Folie der Herausforderungen, vor die uns der Klimawandel stellt, ist es wichtig, unsere √§sthetischen Positionen zu hinterfragen. Entw√ºrfe wie das Haus Alder leisten dazu einen wichtigen Beitrag¬´.

Frankie, as√≠ se llama, asegura que √©l mismo sabe "alguna que otra cosa sobre extinciones". Adem√°s, resalta la imprudencia de la raza humana: "¬øOs llev√°is a vosotros mismos a la extinci√≥n? En 70 millones de a√±os es lo m√°s rid√≠culo que he escuchado". Deja totalmente enmudecido al conocido como sal√≥n de las grandes promesas. Porque recuerda que ellos al menos tuvieron "un asteroide, ¬øcu√°l es vuestra excusa?" Es la nueva e impactante campa√±a de la ONU sobre el calentamiento global que ruge a las puertas de la Cumbre del Clima de Glasgow. M√°s de 120 l√≠deres mundiales tienen menos de dos semanas para arreglar asuntos pendientes en la lucha contra el cambio clim√°tico. Description:
Am 31. Oktober beginnt im schottischen Glasgow der UN-Klimagipfel mit rund 25.000 Teilnehmern und fast 200 Staaten. Viele erwarten von dieser Konferenz eine echte Wende in der globalen Klimapolitik, um das Ziel von maximal 1,5 Grad Erderw√§rmung zu erreichen.

Doch f√ºr diese Wende m√ºssten vor allem die Staaten auch tats√§chlich handeln und nicht nur Ma√ünahmen beschlie√üen. Ein Bericht des UN-Umweltprogramms UNEP zeigt die L√ºcke zwischen Anspruch und Umsetzung beim Klimaschutz: Wenn die Staaten umsetzen, was sie bisher als Ziele bei der UN-Klimarahmenkonvention eingereicht haben, dann sinken die CO2-Emissionen bis zum Jahr 2030 nicht etwa auf die H√§lfte, sondern lediglich um 7,5 Prozent. 

Das w√§re zwar auch eine Wende, denn bisher waren sie fast jedes Jahr gestiegen. Doch, so Inger Anderson, die Chefin des UN-Umweltprogramms: ‚ÄûDer Bericht zeigt: Die Welt muss ihre Ambitionen auf das siebenfache steigern, um uns auf dem Weg zu h√∂chstens 1,5 Grad zu halten. Und diese klaffende L√ºcke m√ºssen wir innerhalb von acht Jahren schlie√üen.‚Äú 

Ein wichtiger Faktor f√ºr die Wende: Gro√üe CO2-Emittenten wie die USA oder China m√ºssen an ihrer Klimapolitik schrauben. China hat sich jetzt vorgenommen, bis 2060 CO2-neutral zu werden. Der amerikanische Pr√§sident Joe Biden ist wieder dem Pariser Klimaabkommen beigetreten, nachdem sein Vorg√§nger Donald Trump den Austritt verk√ºndet hatte. 

Vor dem Start der Konferenz werden jetzt aber Forderungen laut, dass noch mehr getan werden m√ºsse: EU-Kommissionspr√§sidentin von der Leyen sagte, wenn die Staaten sich nicht st√§rker anstrengten, werde das dramatische Folgen haben. Europa k√∂nne eine Vorreiterrolle einnehmen und zeigen, dass man das Klima sch√ºtzen und gleichzeitig wirtschaftlich prosperieren k√∂nne.
.
.
.
Mehr zum Weltklimagipfel findet ihr √ºber den Link in der Bio.

For too long, many of us were fed a false narrative that we should feel individually guilty about the climate crisis.

The reality is that only a handful of powerful individuals bear the personal responsibility - while the actions of just a few climate supervillains have affected millions of people, disproportionately hurting the vulnerable who have done the least to contribute to global emissions.

In a new in-depth opinion piece for @guardian_us, journalists Georgia Wright, Liat Olenick and Amy Westervelt have compiled a list of 12 of America's worst polluters: enablers and profiteers they say have had an unimaginable sway over the fate of humanity.

Swipe to read more about how these individuals have helped the fossil fuel industry destroy our planet ‚Äì while also evading accountability and scrutiny for decades.

Description:
On Friday, President Biden was welcomed by papal officials as he arrived at the Vatican, where he met with Pope Francis to discuss global challenges like the pandemic and climate change.

The meeting ‚Äî the president‚Äôs first with Francis since his inauguration ‚Äî had deep emotional resonance for Biden, a Catholic. The president and the pope share common ground on many issues, and Biden seemed visibly excited as he headed into a private meeting, which lasted 90 minutes.

During their meeting, Biden thanked Francis for his advocacy for the world‚Äôs poor and people suffering from hunger, conflict and persecution, the White House said, adding that he had also lauded the pope‚Äôs leadership in the climate crisis and his advocacy on coronavirus vaccines.

The Vatican visit was the prelude to a five-day diplomatic marathon that is crucial not just for Biden, but also for the world. This weekend, at the Group of 20 summit of the world‚Äôs largest economies, leaders will gather amid a pandemic in which inequalities are increasingly stark and as supply chain woes and rising energy prices threaten economies worldwide.

After that, Biden and many of the same leaders will travel to Scotland for COP26, a worldwide summit on climate change that is billed by many as a make-or-break moment to save a warming planet from disaster.

Tap the link in our bio for the latest on Biden‚Äôs trip to Europe. Photo by @erinschaff

Description:
Joe Biden begins his European trip with a meeting with Pope Francis.

The world‚Äôs two most prominent Roman Catholics held talks for a 90-minutes, expected to cover the COVID-19 pandemic, climate change, poverty and more.

According to the Vatican, Biden presented Francis a woven chasuble, or liturgical vestment, made in 1930 by the famed papal tailor Gamarelli.

Francis gave the president a ceramic tile depicting the iconography of the pilgrim, as well as a collection of the pope‚Äôs main teaching document.

It is only the second time in history a Catholic US president has had a meeting with the pope.

Description:
La gran torre de refrigeraci√≥n de la central t√©rmica de Velilla del R√≠o Carri√≥n, en Palencia, cay√≥ en la tarde del jueves. Su demolici√≥n forma parte del proceso de desmantelamiento de esta central 56 a√±os despu√©s de su puesta en marcha y 15 meses despu√©s de su clausura. Espa√±a est√° viviendo un proceso de abandono del uso del carb√≥n para generar electricidad. Este combustible f√≥sil es el que m√°s contribuye a las emisiones de efecto invernadero y est√° en el punto de mira de la lucha contra el cambio clim√°tico.

Cinco segundos han bastado para decir adi√≥s a un s√≠mbolo de la era del carb√≥n: una torre que supera los cien metros de altura y tiene un peso de m√°s de 7.000 toneladas. Para hacer posible su derribo se han utilizado detonadores el√©ctricos con 82 kilogramos de explosivo. Su demolici√≥n representa la transformaci√≥n energ√©tica en la que est√° inmersa Espa√±a. Esta central era una de las dos t√©rmicas de carb√≥n que la empresa el√©ctrica Iberdrola ten√≠a en Espa√±a y que a d√≠a hoy ya no operan.

El meteor√≥logo de TVN, Iv√°n Torres, alert√≥ que el calor seguir√° siendo intenso en Santiago y el resto del pa√≠s como consecuencia del cambio clim√°tico.

Seg√∫n dijo el experto a 24 AM, lo registrado este jueves en Santiago -donde la extrema lleg√≥ a 33,4¬∞, siendo la m√°s alta para un d√≠a de octubre en 80 a√±os- podr√≠a ser un antecedente clave para lo que vendr√≠a.

Si bien dijo que en el sur del pa√≠s s√≠ han llegado en algunas oportunidades a los 40¬∞ de calor, advirti√≥ que "cada a√±o y d√≠a que pasa esto se acentuar√° m√°s".

"Es una caracter√≠stica del cambio clim√°tico. Tendremos eventos cada vez m√°s extremos", sentenci√≥.

Puntualmente, las oficinas Estaci√≥n Meteorol√≥gica Quinta Normal de Santiago, detectaron en la Regi√≥n Metropolitana la cifra de 33,4¬∞. Dicho n√∫mero no se registraba desde el a√±o 1941, cuando los term√≥metros marcaron 33,3¬∞.

Description:
2015 auf dem UN-Klimagipfel verpflichteten sich fast alle Staaten in dem sogenannten Pariser Abkommen, die Weltwirtschaft klimafreundlicher zu gestalten. 

Die L√§nder setzten sich zudem das Ziel die globale Erderw√§rmung auf m√∂glichst 1,5 Grad Celsius zu beschr√§nken. Nun steht der n√§chte UN-Klimagipfel (COP26) vom 31. Oktober bis zum 12. November in Glasgow an und soll das wichtigeste Treffen seit dem Gipfel vor sechs Jahren werden.¬†

Um¬†dem¬†Klimawandel entgegenzuwirken, muss in vielen Bereichen gehandelt werden ‚Äì zum Beispiel in der Zementindustrie.

Es wird so viel gebaut wie nie. Biologische Baumaterialen kommen wegen ihres schlechten Rufs weniger als Beton zum Einsatz. Die Zementindustrie ist weltweit allerdings f√ºr drei Mal so viel CO2 wie der Flugverkehr verantwortlich. Wie kann die Branche klimafreundlicher werden?

Description:
Desperate to meet its electricity needs, China is opening up new coal production exceeding what all of Western Europe mines in a year, at a tremendous cost to the global effort to fight climate change.

The campaign has unleashed a flurry of activity in China‚Äôs coal country. Idled mines are restarting. Cottage-size yellow backhoes are clearing and widening roads past terraced cornfields. Long columns of bright red freight trucks are converging on the region to haul the extra cargo.

China‚Äôs push will carry a high cost. Burning coal, already the world‚Äôs single biggest cause of human-driven climate change, will increase China‚Äôs emissions and toxic air pollution. It will endanger the lives of coal miners. And it could impose a long-term cost on the Chinese economy, even while helping short-term growth.

World leaders are gathering next week in Glasgow to discuss ways to halt climate change. But China‚Äôs extra coal by itself would increase humanity‚Äôs output of planet-warming carbon dioxide by a full percentage point, said Jan Ivar Korsbakken, a senior researcher at the Center for International Climate and Environmental Research in Oslo.

Tap the link in our bio to read the story. Photo by @gillessabrie

Description:
President Biden pleaded with House Democrats on Thursday to embrace his ‚Äúframework‚Äù for a $1.85 trillion economic and environmental bill, saying its fate would help determine that of his presidency and his party‚Äôs hold on Congress, and its success would restore the nation‚Äôs standing on the world stage.

The president, who delayed his departure for a trip to Europe to try to nail down an accord on his domestic agenda, used a morning meeting at the Capitol to try to rally House Democrats around the emerging deal.

Later, in public remarks at the White House, Biden hailed the plan as ‚Äúhistoric.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo one got everything they wanted, including me,‚Äù he said in the East Room before departing on a trip to Rome. ‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs what compromise is. That‚Äôs consensus. And that‚Äôs what I ran on.‚Äù

The package is considerably more modest than the cradle-to-grave expansion of the safety net that the president initially envisioned, having been stripped of ambitious climate change programs and provisions to provide federal paid leave, a broad expansion of Medicare and two years of free community college.

But provisions to provide universal preschool for more than six million 3- and 4-year-olds and subsidies to limit the costs of child care to no more than 7% of income for most families would offer a significant boost to the middle class.

And about $555 billion for programs to move Americans to electric vehicles and entice utilities away from natural gas and coal would be the largest federal investment in combating climate change.

Tap the link in our bio for the latest updates on Biden‚Äôs budget bill. Photo by @stefani_reynolds

Der luxemburgische Energieminister Turmes sieht in der Atomkraft keine L√∂sung, um in Europa Klimaneutralit√§t zu erreichen. Die Klimapolitik werde in den n√§chsten zehn Jahren entschieden. In dieser Zeit entstehe aber kein neues Atomkraftwerk, sagte Turmes im Deutschlandfunk.

Der Politiker der Gr√ºnen erkl√§rte, in Frankreich w√ºrden die geplanten neuen Kernkraftwerke erst 2038 beziehungsweise 2042 fertig. Ein massiver Ausbau der erneuerbaren Energien sei hingegen schnell realisierbar. Ob die EU-Kommission die Atomkraft als gr√ºne Energie anerkenne, h√§nge auch ma√ügeblich von Deutschland ab, sagte Turmes. Er hoffe, dass eine neue Bundesregierung aus SPD, Gr√ºnen und FDP sich klar gegen Atomkraft positioniere.

Beim letzten EU-Gipfel hatte insbesondere der franz√∂sische Staatschef Macron die Atomkraft favorisiert. Gro√übritannien plant gerade ein neues Kernkraftwerk, das helfen soll, den CO2-Aussto√ü des Landes zu reduzieren. International gesehen will etwa Japan zum Erreichen seiner Klimaziele auf einen Mix aus Erneuerbaren Energien und Atomkraft setzen. Bis Ende des Jahres wird eine Entscheidung der EU-Kommission erwartet, ob Gas und Atomkraft als nachhaltig eingestuft und gef√∂rdert werden.

Die EU sollte nach Ansicht der Energie√∂konomin Claudia Kemfert allerdings besser nicht auf Atomkraft setzen. Die Wissenschaftlerin vom Deutschen Institut f√ºr Wirtschaftsforschung sagte dem MDR: ‚ÄûDie Kosten sind einfach gigantisch.‚Äú F√ºr Atomkraft d√ºrften keine EU-Gelder verwendet werden. Wenn Frankreich sich diese Technologie wie angek√ºndigt leisten wolle, m√ºsse das Land den eigenen Staatshaushalt belasten.

Una investigaci√≥n encabezada por Andr√©s Mu√±oz-S√°ez, acad√©mico de la Facultad de Ciencias Agron√≥micas de la U. de Chile, determin√≥ que el 43,6% de la vegetaci√≥n nativa chilena estar√≠a en peligro frente al cambio clim√°tico.

Adem√°s demostr√≥ que araucarias, alerces, especies de Nothofagus y vegetaci√≥n de la estepa altipl√°nica registraron √≠ndices de vulnerabilidad por sobre el 95%.

La investigaci√≥n fue publicada en la revista Science of the Total Environment y cont√≥ con la participaci√≥n de investigadores de la Universidad Nacional de Se√∫l, de la Universidad de California Davis y de la Sociedad de Conservaci√≥n de Vida Silvestre (WCS).

Este aborda la sobreexplotaci√≥n de recursos naturales, la contaminaci√≥n, la invasi√≥n de especies ex√≥ticas o los incendios. A esto se suma el aumento de las temperaturas y el d√©ficit h√≠drico que afecta al pa√≠s.

El estudio elabor√≥ un detallado mapa del riesgo clim√°tico para los 24 tipos de vegetaci√≥n nativa existentes en el territorio nacional y 38 otras categor√≠as de coberturas; y demostr√≥ que si se contin√∫a con las tasas de emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero, un 43,6% de la vegetaci√≥n nativa estar√≠a expuesta a un alto riesgo clim√°tico.

Description:
What, or who, do you think is to blame for the climate crisis?

A majority of Americans want to see oil and gas companies held to account for lying about the climate crisis and contributing to global heating, according to a new YouGov poll commissioned by the @guardian_us, @vicenews, and @coveringclimate.

The survey reveals that the US remains sharply divided over the causes of the deepening environmental emergency following the fossil fuel industry‚Äôs long campaign to downplay and deny climate science.

The poll surveyed 1,000 American adults and found that 70% said global warming was happening. More than 60% said oil and gas companies were ‚Äúcompletely or mostly responsible‚Äù.

But Democrats and Republicans at odds over the source of climate disinformation. While Democrats overwhelmingly (89%) accept the scientific basis of the climate emergency, opinion is split among Republicans. Just 42% of Republicans agreed that global warming is a reality while 36% denied it. The remainder said they didn‚Äôt know.

Political division also emerges again when people were asked about the specifics of the fossil fuel industry‚Äôs misdeeds.

Democrats said oil and gas companies lied about the existence of climate change, and their part in creating it, at more than three times the rate of Republicans. Just under half of Republicans said oil and gas companies had done nothing wrong.

But one of the clearest divisions remains over scientific opinion on the climate crisis.

While 68% of Democrats said that most scientists think global warming is human-caused, just 22% of Republicans agreed. Half of Republicans said there is ‚Äúa lot of disagreement‚Äù on the issue among scientists, a position held by less than 15% of Democrats.

Tap the link in bio to find out more about exactly how Americans are divided over what oil companies should be financially accountable for.

#oil #oilcompanies #climatecrisis #climatechange #climate #globalheating #globalwarming #democrats #republicans #fossilfuel #science #environment
ImageText: G Revealed 60% of Americans say oil firms are to blame for the climate crisis

Description:
More than six inches of rain fell over Yosemite National Park in California over a 36-hour period, causing Yosemite Falls to surge Tuesday after a dry and drought-stricken summer.

‚ÄúWe had quite a storm,‚Äù the park said in an Instagram post.

Although the park said it did not have direct measurements, it said that ‚Äúsensors suggest a few feet of snow fell at the higher elevations,‚Äù and that the snow level for much of the storm ‚Äúwas high,‚Äù which caused rivers and creeks ‚Äúto rise substantially.‚Äù The Merced River at the Pohono Bridge rose 8.5 feet, the park said, noting it was 1.5 feet below flood stage.

At 2,425 feet high, Yosemite Falls is the tallest waterfall in North America. Its peak flow usually occurs in May, after most of the park‚Äôs snow melts, but by August it often slows to a trickle or is completely dry. Storms in the late fall can help restore the falls.

The rainfall at Yosemite was the result of two storms that converged in the Bay Area, bringing floods, high winds and some much-needed rain to California, which has wrestled with large wildfires and severe drought conditions that have been brought on by climate change.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the return of Yosemite Falls.
ImageText: Yosemite Falls, Yosemite National Park Oct. 24, 2021 Yosemite National Park's waterfalls and rivers surged after more than six inches of rain fell within 36 hours.

El Ministerio de Medio Ambiente, en un trabajo conjunto con las carteras de Miner√≠a, Energ√≠a y Ciencia, present√≥ su Estrategia Clim√°tica de Largo Plazo.

En √©sta se plantea un camino para que Chile sea carbono neutral y resiliente a m√°s tardar en 2050, con 407 metas de transici√≥n y transformaci√≥n de sectores claves para el pa√≠s, como agricultura, miner√≠a, salud, vivienda, obras p√∫blicas y transporte, entre otros, seg√∫n se√±al√≥ la ministra de Medio Ambiente, Carolina Schmidt.

El biministro de Energ√≠a y Miner√≠a, Juan Carlos Jobet, indic√≥ que la industria de recursos como el cobre y el litio, son esenciales para el desarrollo de un futuro sustentable.

Las autoridades de Gobierno afirmaron que Chile llegar√° a la COP26 como el primer pa√≠s de Am√©rica del Sur, que cumple con lo establecido en el Acuerdo de Par√≠s.

Sin embargo, el director del Observatorio Latinoamericano de Conflictos Ambientales, Lucio Cuenca, se√±al√≥ que este acuerdo internacional de cuidado ambiental es insuficiente, y que lo necesario es un mayor compromiso.

El experto agreg√≥ que ‚Äúse est√° planteando seguir creciendo en la extracci√≥n de la miner√≠a, bajo la justificaci√≥n de que esto se hace para contribuir a la crisis clim√°tica, y eso no est√° considerando los impactos locales que est√° dejando en Chile‚Äù, haciendo alusi√≥n a la crisis h√≠drica que se vive actualmente en el pa√≠s.

‚≠ï En conferencia de prensa el candidato de Chile Podemos M√°s, Sebasti√°n Sichel, realiz√≥ una amplia cr√≠tica en torno a los acuerdos con partidos que no se estar√≠an cumpliendo tras las primarias presidenciales, ofreciendo a las tiendas "libertad de acci√≥n" y que "tomen definiciones " de cara a las elecciones de noviembre.

El candidato enfatiz√≥ que "el 18 de julio ganamos una primaria con una amplia mayor√≠a (...) independiente, creyendo en los proyectos colectivos que particip√≥ en una primaria con partidos y con compromiso de apoyar al ganador, as√≠ funciona la democracia y as√≠ lo entendemos los dem√≥cratas"

"Quer√≠amos construir una gran mayor√≠a de centro, centro derecha, para liderar el Chile que viene (...) lo que queremos es el cambio, pero de verdad, en paz, en orden, en justicia (...) y no obsesionado con los problemas y dilemas de la pol√≠tica", se√±al√≥ Sichel.

En se sentido dijo que "nos hemos dado cuenta que otros, sali√©ndose del compromiso democr√°tico que hab√≠an tomado, quieren volver al pasado, apoyar una antigua derecha, entender y hacer que el pa√≠s retroceda en derechos que ya hab√≠a ganado para las diversidades, mujeres, minor√≠as, cambio clim√°tico (...) quieren volver a atr√°s simplemente porque no creen en un proyecto colectivo y est√°n parados en el pasado".

"No respetan los acuerdos de la primaria y no est√°n dispuestos a respetar las reglas b√°sicas de la democracia: apoyar al independiente que gan√≥ (...) claramente, parece ser que apoyaban este proyecto solo cuando les conven√≠a y por conveniencia, no ten√≠an una convicci√≥n de cambio democr√°tico", remarc√≥ el representante de Chile Podemos M√°s.

Junto a remarcar que para algunos pareciera ser "una tragedia" el triunfo de un independiente, tambi√©n asever√≥ que estas personas "no creen de verdad en los cambios".

Description:
Climate change is an issue that has not only prompted emotional public pleas from the royal family, but has united three generations of the monarchy ahead of the U.N.‚Äôs climate change conference, COP26, in Glasgow, Scotland.

Prince Charles, Prince William and their wives plan to lend their star power to the event. Queen Elizabeth had originally planned to attend in person, but pulled out after she received medical advice to rest following a recent hospital stay. Instead, she will deliver a recorded video address, Buckingham Palace said Tuesday.

The conference has been billed as a last chance for world leaders to get climate change under control. Otherwise, experts warn that temperatures will continue to rise far above the 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit target previously set out in the Paris climate agreement, resulting in further climate catastrophes, from fires and floods to the destruction of species.

Read more at the link in the bio.

üì∏ Samir Hussein / @GettyImages
ImageText: Climate change unites three generations of the royal family ahead of COP26 WORL D Wo

Description:
It can sometimes feel like constant bad news when it comes to climate change, global warming and the environment.

But there have been times in the past when the world has come together to try to fix an environmental crisis.

Tackling acid rain, the hole in the Ozone layer, and banning leaded petrol are just some examples of successful efforts to protect our planet.

Tap the link in our bio for more on these reheats and how we can learn from them today.

Description:
The Queen will not meet world leaders at the COP26 climate change summit, Buckingham Palace has confirmed.

The 95-year-old monarch underwent preliminary medical checks in hospital last Wednesday after cancelling a visit to Northern Ireland.
 
She carried out her first engagements via video link from Windsor Castle on Tuesday.
 
Buckingham Palace said she "regretfully" decided not to attend.
 
This is a breaking news story, tap the link in our bio for updates.
 
#BBCNews
ImageText: BBCNEWS NEWS The Queen will not attend COP26 climate change summit after being advised to rest

Description:
North Atlantic right whales, an already critically endangered species, have hit the lowest population numbers in nearly 20 years, researchers announced on Monday. The species has seen a sharp decline since around 2011 ‚Äî and experts say, humans and climate change are largely to blame. ‚Å†
‚Å†
"We are obviously discouraged by this estimate," one researcher said, "but quite frankly, not surprised." ‚Å†
‚Å†
Read more at the link in our bio.
ImageText: Critically endangered North Atlantic right whales hit lowest population in nearly 20 years and humans are largely to blame

Description:
The Queen will not be attending the #COP26 climate change summit in Glasgow which starts next weekend, Buckingham Palace has announced. 

A palace statement said: "Her Majesty is disappointed not to attend the reception but will deliver an address to the assembled delegates via a recorded video message."

Sky News understands that she remains in good spirits and continues to carry out light duties, including her first official engagements on Tuesday since being told to rest by doctors and spending a night in hospital.‚Å†
‚Å†
Her Majesty returned to royal duties with virtual audiences at Windsor Castle.‚Å†
‚Å†
She wore a yellow dress and her three-strand pearl necklace as she met the ambassador from the Republic of Korea, Gunn Kim and separately, the ambassador from the Swiss Confederation, Markus Leitner.‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
Sir David Attenborough has urged developed nations like the UK to "take moral responsibility" for climate change and helping poorer countries as they are affected by extreme weather events.

The broadcaster said it would be ‚Äùreally catastrophic" if we ignored the problems they face.

He spoke to the BBC on the set of his new documentary series, The Green Planet, which uses time-lapse to capture the world of plants up close.

The Green Planet will premiere at the COP26 climate summit in November.

#DavidAttenborough #ClimateChange #COP26 #BBCNews

‚Å†
Cop26 has been billed as the last best chance to keep global temperature rises to no more than 1.5C, with Sir David critical of those who deny the climate crisis.‚Å†

Description:
Feeling anxious about the climate crisis is a totally normal response, says ecotherapist Phoenix Smith. They say that climate change emotions can feel like grieving.‚Å†
‚Å†
"It can be denial at first, and then you may have some fear and anger and then sadness," they say.‚Å†
‚Å†
These feelings also manifest physically. "When you're in the fight-or-flight mode, you're grinding your teeth," Smith says. "You're holding your body tight."‚Å†
‚Å†
These feels probably won't go away, but here are five ways to recognize them, sit with them and use them.‚Å†
Tap the link in our bio for tools to build up resilience and deal with these feelings through the coming decades. ‚Å†(Video: @beckharlan ‚Ä¢ Becky Harlan/NPR)‚Å†
‚Å†
#nprlifekit
ImageText: LIFE KIT Climate anxiety isn't going away. Here's how you can manage it.

Description:
"La abundancia de gases de efecto invernadero que retienen el calor en la atm√≥sfera volvi√≥ a alcanzar un nuevo r√©cord el a√±o pasado, y la tasa de aumento anual registrada fue superior a la media del per√≠odo 2011-2020", seg√∫n el bolet√≠n de la OMM, y a d√≠as de la conferencia COP26 sobre el clima.

En su informe de este lunes (25.10.2021) la agencia de la ONU indica que ya se evidencia "la transici√≥n de una parte de la Amazon√≠a de sumidero a fuente de carbono".

"Es alarmante y est√° vinculado a la deforestaci√≥n en la regi√≥n", afirm√≥ el secretario general de la OMM, Petteri Taalas, en una conferencia de prensa.

La desaceleraci√≥n econ√≥mica causada por el covid "no tuvo ning√∫n efecto evidente en los niveles atmosf√©ricos de los gases de efecto invernadero ni en sus tasas de aumento, aunque s√≠ se produjo un descenso transitorio de las nuevas emisiones", dice el bolet√≠n.

La OMM indic√≥ que no se detienen las emisiones, "la temperatura mundial seguir√° subiendo". Como el di√≥xido de carbono (CO2) es un gas de larga vida, "el nivel de temperatura observado actualmente persistir√° durante varias d√©cadas aunque las emisiones se reduzcan r√°pidamente hasta alcanzar el nivel de cero neto", agreg√≥.

La conferencia de la ONU sobre cambio clim√°tico COP26 se celebrar√° en Glasgow desde el domingo 31 de octubre al 12 de noviembre.

Description:
El desierto florido de Atacama, un "milagro" amenazado por el cambio clim√°tico
 
¬øFlores en el desierto? S√≠, es completamente real, pero est√° en riesgo. Se trata de un fen√≥meno natural √∫nico en el mundo y que tiene lugar entre cada 5 y 10 a√±os. El desierto florido de Atacama, en el norte de Chile, es uno de los puntos m√°s √°ridos del planeta, pero con pocos mil√≠metros de precipitaciones se cubre con un manto de flores coloridas. Por ello algunos lo califican de "milagro" de la naturaleza.
 
Las flores, plantas y arbustos que logran sobrevivir en este ecosistema √∫nico han desarrollado sus propios mecanismos para hacer frente a la escasez h√≠drica durante largos periodos. Este aspecto es el que m√°s interesa a los cient√≠ficos. Dado que la crisis clim√°tica genera una subida generalizada de las temperaturas y se prev√© que la sequ√≠a azote a gran parte de Chile, comprender los procesos naturales de la vegetaci√≥n en Atacama puede ser crucial para implementarlo en otras partes. Para los expertos, el desierto florido es un "laboratorio natural" para estudiar c√≥mo la vegetaci√≥n sobrevive a la sequ√≠a.

Sin embargo, el desierto tampoco es inmune a la emergencia clim√°tica. Si actualmente ya es un "milagro" por el que los visitantes esperan a√±os, es previsible que disminuya su frecuencia y su variedad, ya que las 200 especies de plantas que alberga no tienen la misma capacidad de sobrevivir a la falta de agua.

Description:
2015 auf dem UN-Klimagipfel verpflichteten sich fast alle Staaten im sogenannten Pariser Abkommen, die Weltwirtschaft klimafreundlicher zu gestalten. Die L√§nder setzten sich zudem das Ziel die globale Erderw√§rmung auf m√∂glichst 1,5 Grad Celsius zu beschr√§nken.
.
Nun steht der n√§chte UN-Klimagipfel (COP26) vom 31. Oktober bis zum 12. November in Glasgow an und soll das wichtigeste Treffen seit dem Gipfel vor sechs Jahren werden. Doch was kann man selbst f√ºr mehr Klimaschutz tun ‚Äì zum Beispiel bei der Heizung?
.
Zwar kommt immer mehr Strom aus erneuerbaren Quellen, doch bei der Heizung sieht es noch anders aus: Die meisten H√§user werden mit Gas geheizt, auch √ñl hat noch einen gro√üen Marktanteil. Heizung und Warmwasser-Bereitung sind im privaten Haushalt die gr√∂√üten Energieverbraucher ‚Äì und das belastet das Klima, sagt Alexander Steinfeldt von der Beratungsgesellschaft CO2 online.
.
In privaten Haushalten ist das Heizen f√ºr einen gro√üen Teil des Energieverbrauchs verantwortlich. Was kann getan werden, um in diesem Bereich den CO2-Fu√üabdruck zu verringern und dem Klimawandel entgegenzuwirken?

Description:
Este 24 de octubre se conmemora el D√≠a Internacional contra el Cambio Clim√°tico, uno de los principales problemas a los que se enfrenta la humanidad en la actualidad.

Las consecuencias del cambio clim√°tico incluyen las sequ√≠as intensas, escasez de agua, deshielo de los polos, incendios forestales, aumento del nivel del mar, inundaciones, tormentas catastr√≥ficas y disminuci√≥n de la biodiversidad.

Se espera que en la COP26, que se realizar√° en Glasgow entre el 31 de octubre y el 12 de noviembre, se llegue a acuerdos mundiales para hacer frente a la crisis clim√°tica. En ese sentido, el presidente designado de la Conferencia, Alok Sharma, ha explicado que ‚Äúel principal objetivo de la COP26 es limitar el ascenso t√©rmico a 1,5 grados‚Äù.

Description:
Eines der Grundprobleme in der Debatte √ºber den Klimawandel ist, dass viele Aktivisten, aber auch viele Politiker keine sehr starken Argumente haben, sagt der Politikwissenschaftler Yascha Mounk im Deutschlandfunk. Sie h√§tten ein Narrativ zum Klimawandel entwickelt, das ‚Äûmehr oder minder hei√üt, wir haben uns gegen die Natur vers√ºndigt und jetzt m√ºssen wir Bu√üe tragen, indem wir leiden‚Äú. Im Sommer werde es ein bisschen zu hei√ü sein in den Wohnungen, ‚Äûweil eine Klimaanlage sowieso das Schlimmste ist. Und im Winter wird es uns ein bisschen zu kalt sein. Und in Urlaub sollen wir auch nicht fliegen.‚Äú
.
‚ÄûEs gibt aus meiner Sicht viel bessere Ans√§tze, wie man mit dem Klimawandel umgeht, wie man den Menschen versprechen kann, dass wir die Emissionen von CO2 sehr stark reduzieren, ohne unseren Wohlstand zu reduzieren‚Äú, betont Yascha Mounk. Es m√ºsse ein Narrativ zum Klimawandel entwickelt werden, das es erlaube, mit diesem riesigen Problem umzugehen und auch eine Mehrheit der Bev√∂lkerung zu √ºberzeugen, anstatt anzufangen, an der Demokratie zu zweifeln.
.
Das Interview finden Sie √ºber den Link in unserer Bio.
.
.
.
#deutschlandfunk #dlf #demokratie #krisederdemokratie #klimakrise #klimawandel #gesellschaft #yaschamounk

 En esa l√≠nea, en los pr√≥ximos d√≠as tendr√° lugar la COP26, donde las diferentes naciones se reunir√°n para dialogar sobre las acciones a tomar para contrarrestar el cambio clim√°tico.

Description:
El misterioso mundo bajo los glaciares de Austria cuenta la historia de su colapso.

Los glaci√≥logos Andrea Fischer y Martin Stocker-Waldhuber se est√°n aventurando dentro de cuevas de hielo debajo del glaciar Jamtalferner, en los Alpes tiroleses. Su objetivo es estudiar por qu√© se est√°n derritiendo incluso m√°s r√°pido de lo esperado y comprender el destino de los glaciares de otros lugares si no se detiene el cambio clim√°tico.

Seg√∫n los cient√≠ficos, ya es demasiado tarde para salvar los glaciares de los Alpes orientales, que ya han superado el punto de no retorno y desaparecer√°n por completo en las pr√≥ximas d√©cadas. "Ya no podemos hacer nada por salvar los glaciares alpinos orientales. Pero aqu√≠ podemos ver lo que sucede si no hacemos nada por los otros glaciares", asegura Andrea Fischer, director interino de El Instituto de Investigaci√≥n Interdisciplinaria de Monta√±a de la Academia de Ciencias de Austria.

En estas instant√°neas podemos ver la belleza de estas cavernas y, aunque sin ser expertos no lo podamos apreciar, se muestra las catastr√≥ficas consecuencias que la crisis clim√°tica est√° causando en este entorno. Los huecos est√°n erosionando los glaciares desde dentro, a medida que el aire m√°s c√°lido y el agua de deshielo entran en contacto con m√°s hielo, hasta que colapsan.

Lee la noticia completa de Neus Palou en el enlace de la biograf√≠a. üì≤ https://bit.ly/3E0i04Q 

#glaciar #Jamtalferner #Alpestiroleses #cambioclim√°tico 

üì∏ Reuters

Description:
From @nytopinion: What is the secret to saving a fragile ecosystem?

The Lummi, whose fishing grounds include most of the Salish Sea, count more commercial fishers among its 5,320 members than any other Indigenous nation in the Northwest. Their relationship to this catch, though, is more than financial: Like all Coast Salish tribes, the Lummi identify as ‚Äúsalmon people,‚Äù fluent in the chinook, sockeye, chum, coho and pinks that are born in freshwater rivers, migrate to sea as they enter adulthood, then return to spawn and die.

Yet over the past century, global warming, habitat destruction, pollution, shipping traffic and other factors have decimated the Pacific salmon population. So Lummi fishers have turned, with some reluctance, to crab and shellfish for sustenance and income. ‚ÄúWe should be out fishing salmon right now,‚Äù said Dana Culaxten Wilson, one of the most prolific fishers in the Lummi Nation.

Time and again, the Lummi have confronted existential threats and built broad, unlikely coalitions with environmental activists and white fishers. In a recent campaign against the fossil-fuel industry, the Lummi showed that it‚Äôs possible to stop the march of industry and extraction ‚Äî of growth at all costs. But there is always a new threat in the congested waterways of the Pacific Northwest.

Tap the link in our bio to read E. Tammy Kim‚Äôs full essay from @nytopinion. Photos by @damonwinter

Description:
Who should pay the world's climate debt? üí∞‚Å†
‚Å†
Climate finance - and how we distribute the costs of climate change - is set to be one of the most hotly debated topics at the #COP26 climate conference.‚Å†
‚Å†
Under the Paris agreement, developed countries committed to provide $100bn (¬£72bn) a year by 2020 to help less wealthy nations shoulder the cost of climate damage.‚Å†
‚Å†
But, they failed to deliver by this deadline.‚Å†
‚Å†
Now, leading scientists say the developed world needs to face up to "climate colonialism" and commit almost double this amount - $190bn (¬£138bn) a year - until 2100.‚Å†
‚Å†

Description: üòØüòØ Una imagen satelital tomada con la herramienta #GoogleMaps se volvi√≥ viral tras ser publicada en la red social Reddit y desat√≥ todo tipo de especulaciones por su misteriosa apariencia. La imagen original fue publicada sin coordenadas y los usuarios curiosos no tardaron en empezar a especular, ya que el accidente geogr√°fico parece un "agujero negro". Su forma parece la de una isla, pero a diferencia de las otras, salvo los contornos, el resto de la superficie es completamente negra. Muchos no descartaron que se trataba de un agujero negro oce√°nico, pero tambi√©n se ofreci√≥ la explicaci√≥n de que podr√≠a ser un volc√°n subterr√°neo, cuyas rocas √≠gneas eran la causa de la profunda negrura. ¬øQu√© es? üßê Finalmente, alguien simplemente explic√≥ que era una mala imagen satelital de una isla deshabitada en el Pac√≠fico e incluy√≥ un v√≠nculo al sitio GeoEye que la muestra con claridad. Se trata de la isla Vostok, parte de la Rep√∫blica de Kiribati que est√° formada por una serie de atolones e islas coralinas, se√±ala BBC. Description:
A principios de agosto, el Grupo Intergubernamental de Expertos sobre el Cambio Clim√°tico (IPCC) de la ONU entreg√≥ su m√°s reciente informe, texto en el cual concluy√≥ que el cambio clim√°tico efectivamente est√° siendo magnificado por los humanos y que las acciones para frenar el alza de las temperaturas no est√°n surtiendo efecto, por lo cual el aumento podr√≠a llegar a 1,5¬∞C en 2030, diez a√±os antes de lo que la instancia predijo hace solo tres a√±os.

Las conclusiones, alcanzadas por miles de cient√≠ficos de casi todos los pa√≠ses del mundo, causaron preocupaci√≥n internacional y el documento fue catalogado como una ‚Äúalerta roja‚Äù.

Pero empresas, gobiernos y otros agentes est√°n haciendo lobby para que el candente reporte se suavice y la ONU haga modificaciones a lo establecido por la ciencia.

Cerca de 32 mil documentos fueron entregados a Unearthed, un grupo de periodistas de investigaci√≥n de Greenpeace Reino Unido, quienes luego compartieron la filtraci√≥n con la BBC.

Parte de las presiones en la materia provienen de pa√≠ses donde los combustibles f√≥siles son parte importante de la econom√≠a. Por ejemplo, un consejero del Ministerio del Petr√≥leo de Arabia Saudita solicit√≥ eliminar frases como ‚Äúla necesidad de acciones de mitigaci√≥n urgentes y aceleradas a toda escala‚Äù.

Argentina y Brasil tambi√©n aparecieron en la filtraci√≥n peleando por uno de sus productos estrella: la carne. Ambos pa√≠ses argumentaron contra la evidencia cient√≠fica, que arroj√≥ que reducir el consumo de carne es necesario para paliar el alza en la emisi√≥n de gases de efecto invernadero.
ImageText: Filtran lista de pa√≠ses haciendo lobby para suavizar alarmante reporte clim√°tico ONU VOLVO M√°s detalles en biobiochile.cl

En una columna publicada en #TheGuardian, la joven activista hizo √©nfasis en la falta de compromiso de los gobiernos de todo el mundo para frenar el calentamiento global, indicando que "La verdad es que no hay l√≠deres clim√°ticos. No por ahora". Adem√°s, apunt√≥ al dilema que tenemos las personas al decidir si hacemos cambios en beneficio del planeta o no: "Nos negamos a reconocer que ahora tenemos que elegir entre salvar el planeta viviente o salvar nuestra forma de vida insostenible" üòÆ ¬øQu√© te parece? üëá

Description:
On a small island in the Pacific, Russia is testing its battle plan for climate change.

Last week, President Vladimir Putin said Russia would stop adding carbon dioxide to the atmosphere by 2060. It was a remarkable reversal since Putin has long dismissed climate science and many in his country see international efforts to combat global warming as part of a Western plot to weaken Russia. But fires, disasters and foreign pressure have prompted him to change course.

It‚Äôs unclear, however, if Russia is sincere in its new pledge. Russian energy experts and government officials acknowledge the moves are largely driven by economics, with the European Union‚Äôs plans for tariffs on heavily polluting countries threatening exports from Russia, the fourth biggest among nations in terms of greenhouse gas emissions. And the country continues to invest in heavily polluting industries.

Russia‚Äôs climate contradictions are on display on the 600-mile-long island of Sakhalin, just north of Japan. The relatively wealthy region of 500,000 people is rich in hydrocarbons, the backbone of its economy. But the regional government last year pledged to make Sakhalin Russia‚Äôs first ‚Äúcarbon neutral‚Äù region by 2025 ‚Äî one that absorbs as much carbon out of the air as it emits. 

For now, Sakhalin‚Äôs plans to meet its goal of going carbon-neutral ‚Äî which also include emissions trading, hydrogen power, renewable-energy plants and developing carbon ‚Äúsinks‚Äù ‚Äî exist mainly on paper. But they are indicative of the changing dynamics in a country where temperatures are rising more than twice as fast as the global average.

Tap the link in our bio to see more photos from Sakhalin and to read about how its forests tell the story of Russia‚Äôs role in fighting climate change ‚Äî and of its vulnerability to it. Photos (some taken with Chamonix 45F-2 with Fujinon SF 1:5.6/250) by @sergeyponomarev

Casi 200 personas han muerto en India y Nepal en inundaciones y deslizamientos de tierra causados por fuertes lluvias esta semana, indicaron las autoridades este jueves, que advirtieron de m√°s episodios de intensas precipitaciones.

En India, el n√∫mero de muertos por estas situaciones alcanz√≥ las 102 personas y en el vecino Nepal las autoridades elevaron hoy el anterior balance de 31 v√≠ctimas hasta 88.

Los expertos vinculan la frecuencia de estos fen√≥menos meteorol√≥gicos extremos, cada vez m√°s recurrentes en el sur de Asia, a la aceleraci√≥n del cambio clim√°tico y a factores como la deforestaci√≥n y la construcci√≥n de presas.

Entre los fallecidos en Nepal figura una familia de seis personas, incluidos tres ni√±os, cuya casa fue enterrada por una avalancha de tierra y escombros.
ImageText: Muertos por fuertes lluvias suben a casi 200 en India y Nepal M√°s detalles biobiochile.cl

Description:
Flash floods, drought, desertification and deadly heatwaves makes Nigeria one of the world's most affected countries by climate change.

Here, young people share their stories of the climate emergency - the second group of teenagers around the world to do so as part of our NextGen International project.

With support from our charity partner @savechildrenuk, some have written news reports about devastating flooding from their towns and cities while others share personal tragedies caused by the climate crisis.

Temperatures in the north of the country can reach the mid 40s and by 2060, scientists predict a 1.1 - 2.5¬∞C increase in temperatures.

The country is plagued by severe flooding during the rainy season, made worse by extreme weather resulting from climate change, droughts during the dry season and desertification.

Click the link in our bio for the full story and to find out how you can help by donating to Save the Children‚Äôs emergency fund.

#nextgen #savethechildren #dailymirror #nextgeninternationalproject #nigeria #climatechange #climatechangenigeria #nextgeneration

Eine Solaranlage auf vier Quadratmetern Fl√§che br√§uchte f√ºr dieselbe Energiemenge im Schnitt einen ganzen Tag. Wie viel verbrauchen wir, und wie k√∂nnen wir das realistisch nachhaltig erzeugen?

Description:
No state in the contiguous U.S. is more exposed to flood damage than West Virginia, according to data released last week.

But Senator Joe Manchin of West Virginia, a Democrat whose vote is crucial to passing his party‚Äôs climate legislation, is opposed to its most important provision that would compel utilities to stop burning oil, coal and gas and instead use solar, wind and nuclear energy, which do not emit the carbon dioxide that is heating the planet. Last week, the senator made his opposition clear to the Biden administration, which is now scrambling to come up with alternatives he would accept.

Manchin has rejected any plan to move the country away from fossil fuels because he said it would harm West Virginia, a top producer of coal and gas. Manchin‚Äôs own finances are tied to coal: He founded a family coal brokerage that paid him half a million dollars in dividends last year.

The new data shows that Manchin‚Äôs constituents stand to suffer disproportionately as climate change intensifies. Unlike those in other flood-exposed states, most residents in mountainous West Virginia have little room to relocate from the waterways that increasingly threaten their safety.

The measure that Manchin opposes, a clean electricity program, may be the last chance for Congress to reduce planet-warming emissions before the effects of climate change become catastrophic. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how climate change is affecting West Virginia. Photos by @erinschaff

Description:
Fotograf√≠as del paisaje de flores en el desierto de Atacama, un fen√≥meno natural conocido como el Desierto Florido que ocurre entre cada 5 y 10 a√±os aproximadamente, el 7 de octubre de 2021, en la norte√±a ciudad de Caldera (Chile). Algunos lo definen como un "misterio", otros como un "milagro": cada cierto tiempo, el desierto de Atacama, una de las zonas m√°s √°ridas del mundo, se recubre con un manto de miles de flores en un vibrante y colorido espect√°culo que, seg√∫n los expertos, podr√≠a verse amenazado por el cambio clim√°tico. Las lluvias son las que despiertan a las m√°s de 900 especies de flora aut√≥ctona que durante un espacio de tiempo de entre cinco y siete a√±os, aproximadamente, permanecen latentes, en forma de semillas o bulbos, bajo los secos suelos de la regi√≥n atacame√±a, a 1.000 kil√≥metros al norte Santiago de Chile. 

(Fotos de EFE/ Jos√© Caviedes y Martin Bernetti)

Description:
This might sound a little odd given the title, but a warning: these images contain nudity, especially the more you swipe along.

About 200 people wearing only white body paint have walked across a stark desert expanse near the Dead Sea - to highlight that it is receding by about a metre a year.

It is part of the latest photography project of American artist Spencer Tunick, who has staged dozens of large-scale nude shoots around the world. The 54-year-old visited the spot in southern Israel as a guest of the tourism ministry to portray for the third time the shrinking turquoise lake.

Doctoral student Anna Kleiman, 26, said she joined the shoot to bring awareness to the environmental crisis. ‚ÄúIt feels really natural, once you take your clothes off,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúYou kind of don‚Äôt want to put them back on. I think we just struggled with the rocks a little bit.‚Äù

A decade ago, Tunick photographed more than 1,000 nude models on the shores of the salty Dead Sea. By the time he returned five years later, the placid waters of his first shoot had receded, leaving behind crusty sand and gaping sinkholes.

Israel and Jordan have diverted much of the upstream water for agriculture and drinking water, while mineral extraction and evaporation accelerated by the climate crisis have made the problem worse.

#deadsea #climatechange #climatecrisis #bodypaint #climateactivists #spencertunick #artist #photography #water #saltwater

Description: The idea that any carbon emitting process, from a long-haul flight to electricity generation, can be offset by paying someone else to plant trees or create renewable energy is something many people and businesses are turning to to reduce their environmental impact. Tap the link in our bio to find out everything you need to know about carbon offsetting, and if it‚Äôs really a solution to the climate crisis.

Description:
Kriege, die Klimakrise und Corona hat die Zahl der hungernden Menschen wieder ansteigen lassen. Laut dem Welthungerindex 2021, der vor kurzem ver√∂ffentlicht wurde, sind 20 Millionen mehr Menschen akut unterern√§hrt als noch 2019. Nach Angaben der Welthungerhilfe hungerten weltweit 811 Millionen Menschen. 

Laut Stephan Lessenich, Leiter des Instituts f√ºr Sozialforschung in Frankfurt/Main, sind diese Entwicklungen ‚Äûeine mittelbare Folge unserer Wirtschafts-, Produktions- und Konsumweise.‚Äú Der deutsche Wohlstand beruht laut Lessenich auf einer extrem asymmetrischen globalen Wirtschaftsordnung.

Gesellschaftlich gebe es bereits Tendenzen zu einer nachhaltigeren Lebensweise. Es gebe Menschen, die ihre individuelle Lebensweise √ºberpr√ºfen, weniger Ressourcen verbrauchen und ihre Ern√§hrung umstellen. Dadurch w√ºrden Industrien zwar unter Druck gesetzt, ihre Produktion anzupassen. ‚ÄûAber‚Äú, so Lessenich, ‚Äû√ºber individuellen Konsum und individuelle Konsumentscheidungen wird das Problem nicht zu l√∂sen sein. Auch nicht √ºber die Summierung von vielen Millionen individuellen Konsumentscheidungen, sondern es m√ºssen Strukturen ge√§ndert werden.‚Äú

Das ganze Interview mit Stephan Lessenich findet ihr unter dem Link in unserer Bio.

#dlf #deutschlandfunk #welthungerindex #Armut #Ungleichheit #Global #Konsum #Nachhaltigkeit

En el marco del debate sobre el cambio clim√°tico y la crisis mundial, constantemente se habla de desigualdad alimentaria, enfermedades, la salud de las personas y del planeta, las cuales han llegado a un punto cr√≠tico. La urgencia por soluciones para evitar una cat√°strofe mundial est√° indudablemente ligada a lo que comemos y la forma en la que lo producimos.

En el marco del D√≠a Mundial de la Alimentaci√≥n, la Comisi√≥n EAT-Lancet urge a reducir el consumo mundial de carne y a duplicar la ingesta de frutas, vegetales, nueces y legumbres. En la actualidad, hablar de alimentaci√≥n, es hablar desde la producci√≥n hasta el consumo, y de las implicaciones ambientales, econ√≥micas, sociales y de salud que implica nuestros h√°bitos alimentarios.

Durante tres a√±os, un grupo de la Comisi√≥n EAT-Lancet, conformado por 37 cient√≠ficos de primer nivel, trabajaron para desarrollar la primera revisi√≥n cient√≠fica de lo que es una dieta saludable a partir de un sistema alimentario sostenible.

La obra es una recreaci√≥n de la emblem√°tica pintura "El labrador del caf√©" (1934), del modernista C√°ndido Portinari, en la que el protagonista, originalmente un trabajador negro en un cafetal que deja en evidencia la desigualdad social, da lugar a un brigadista que ahora combate los fuegos y pone el foco en la urgencia clim√°tica.

Description:
El pr√≠ncipe Guillermo, ferviente defensor del medio ambiente, sugiri√≥ en una entrevista que los empresarios deben centrarse en salvar la Tierra ante la crisis clim√°tica antes que emprender el turismo espacial.

El duque de Cambridge, nieto de la reina Isabel II y segundo en la l√≠nea de sucesi√≥n a la corona brit√°nica, consider√≥ imperioso -en una entrevista con el podcast Newscast de la cadena p√∫blica BBC divulgada este jueves, 14 de octubre de 2021-, que haya esfuerzos para ‚Äútratar de reparar este planeta, no tratar de encontrar el pr√≥ximo lugar para ir a vivir‚Äù.

El pr√≠ncipe hizo esta observaci√≥n antes de que entregue este fin de semana del premio ‚ÄúEarthshot‚Äù, creado por √©l para reconocer a las personalidades que hacen esfuerzos por salvar el planeta.

El hijo del pr√≠ncipe Carlos agreg√≥ que es ‚Äúbastante crucial‚Äù que la gente se centre en el planeta Tierra antes de ‚Äúir hacia el espacio para tratar de pensar en soluciones para el futuro‚Äù.

Los comentarios de Guillermo se conocieron un d√≠a despu√©s de que el actor William Shatner, de 90 a√±os, mundialmente famoso por el personaje del capit√°n Kirk en la serie Star Trek, se convirtiera en la persona m√°s anciana en viajar al espacio tras abordar la c√°psula Blue Origin del fundador de Amazon, Jeff Bezos.

Los empresarios Richard Branson y Elton Musk tambi√©n est√°n desarrollando sus negocios de turismo espacial.

En su conversaci√≥n con la BBC, el pr√≠ncipe dijo que no tiene inter√©s en viajar al espacio por el impacto de carbono que tienen estos vuelos espaciales.

Al mismo tiempo, advirti√≥ de que los j√≥venes sienten cada vez m√°s ‚Äúansiedad clim√°tica‚Äù porque ven ‚Äúamenazado‚Äù su futuro.

La crisis clim√°tica ser√° abordada por los l√≠deres mundiales en la cumbre del clima COP26 que tendr√° lugar en Glasgow (Escocia) a principios del mes pr√≥ximo.

Description:
Es sei eine Schande f√ºr die Weltgemeinschaft, f√ºr Europa und f√ºr Deutschland, dass mehr als 800 Millionen Menschen hungern, kommentiert Manfred G√∂tzke den aktuellen Welthunger-Index. Neben kriegerischen Konflikten sei die wichtigste Ursache f√ºr die weltweite Zunahme von Hunger inzwischen der menschengemachte Klimawandel:

"Die Tatsche ist bekannt: Die √Ñrmsten und Schw√§chsten, die f√ºr den Klimawandel nicht verantwortlich sind, zahlen den h√∂chsten Preis. Hunderttausend mit ihrem Leben. Millionen Menschen entzieht der Klimawandel schon jetzt ihre Lebensgrundlage ‚Äì sie m√ºssen fliehen, weil ihre Heimat zur W√ºste wird. 

Und so gibt es viele Schuldige f√ºr die Hungerkrise: Schuldig ist jeder einzelne korrupte Potentat, der Hilfsgelder und Lieferungen selbst einsteckt, statt sie an die eigene Bev√∂lkerung zu verteilen. Schuldig ist der Westen, der Klimapolitik bis heute vor allem darin versteht, Jahr f√ºr Jahr neue Ziele zu definieren - statt wirksame  Ma√ünahmen umzusetzen, die den Klimawandel mindern."

Zwar habe sich die Weltgemeinschaft zum Ziel gesetzt, bis 2030 den Hunger weltweit zu besiegen. Es deute aber nichts darauf hin, dass dies gelinge, meint Manfred G√∂tzke.

Den ganzen Kommentar findet ihr √ºber den Link in der Bio.

#hunger #welthunger #welthungerhilfe #klimakrise #kommentar #dlf #deutschlandfunk

Description:
Is this a future we're willing to accept?

The land on which 10% of the world's population lives could be lost to rising sea levels, according to new projections by @climatecentral.

The non-profit group has produced a collection of images which visualize what future sea level rise could look like if collectively we fail to meet carbon emissions reduction targets.

Fifty major cities, mostly in Asia, and at least one large nation on every continent but Australia and Antarctica are at risk. Many small island nations are threatened with near total loss of their land - taking with them the heritage and history of these coastal communities.

Meeting the most ambitious goals of the Paris climate agreement could reduce the sea level rise exposure by roughly half. But the world is not on course to limiting global warming to 1.5C (2.7F), as outlined in the 2015 Paris agreement.

Based on current emissions, the Earth is expected to reach and even exceed 3C (5.4F) warming by 2100.

‚ÄúA picture is worth 1,000 words, or 1,000 years in this case,‚Äù says Benjamin Strauss, the CEO and chief scientist at Climate Central.

Next month, representatives from every country in the world will meet in Glasgow for the Cop26 climate conference, where parties will be expected to commit to goals in response to the ongoing climate emergency.

‚ÄúThe decisions that we make at Glasgow and the actions that we take this decade will ramify for hundreds and thousands of years,‚Äù Strauss said. ‚ÄúThis group is going to be remembered for what they chose: did you choose a thriving future with a liveable climate or did you choose to drown the coastal places of the world?‚Äù

Swipe to see what famous sites around the world will look like if we sharply cut carbon pollution (‚âà1.5C) vs keep our current path (+3C).

Cover image: Santa Monica Pier, California

The Duke of Cambridge has criticised the space race - and space tourism - saying the world‚Äôs greatest minds need to focus on trying to fix our planet instead.

Prince William‚Äôs comments, in an interview with Newscast on BBC Sounds, were aired the day after actor William Shatner made history by becoming the oldest person in space. The 90-year-old, known for his role in Star Trek, lifted off from the Texas desert on Wednesday in a rocket built by the Amazon founder Jeff Bezos‚Äôs space travel company Blue Origin.

The duke, who was interviewed about the climate crisis ahead of his inaugural Earthshot prize awards and global Cop26 summit also expressed his concerns about a rise in climate anxiety in young people. He said it would be an ‚Äúabsolute disaster‚Äù if his eldest son, Prince George, was having to talk about the same issue in 30 years when it would be too late - and warned world leaders against ‚Äúclever words but not enough action‚Äù.

William added that his viewpoint had changed since he had kids: ‚ÄúI want the things that I‚Äôve enjoyed ‚Äì the outdoor life, nature, the environment ‚Äì I want that to be there for my children, and not just my children but everyone else‚Äôs children.

‚ÄúIf we‚Äôre not careful we‚Äôre robbing from our children‚Äôs future through what we do now. And I think that‚Äôs not fair.‚Äù

#climatecrisis #Earth #spacerace #Bezos #PrinceWilliam #royal #DukeOfCambridge #planet #space #climatechange #environment #sustainability #nature #globalwarming #climate #ecofriendly #climateaction #zerowaste #sustainable #climatechangeisreal #green #sustainableliving #recycle #climateemergency #pollution #fridaysforfuture #eco #climatestrike #climatejustice
