Description:
C√©sar Coll es uno de los siete expertos que han dise√±ado el modelo de aprendizaje en el que se basa el nuevo curr√≠culo del curso escolar que empezar√° a aplicarse en septiembre del 2022. El borrador de decreto de infantil, primaria y secundaria ya ha sido enviado a las comunidades aut√≥nomas para su √∫ltima revisi√≥n. 

Muchos son los cambios y, como siempre, no exentos de pol√©mica: Se rebajan contenidos que hoy son obligatorios en beneficio de la consolidaci√≥n de conocimientos. Las propuestas en clase estar√°n vinculadas a situaciones de la vida cotidiana, incluyendo tem√°ticas actuales como el feminismo, lgtbi o sostenibilidad.

LV - ¬øPor qu√© hay que cambiarlo todo? ¬øHa quedado obsoleto?

CC- Absolutamente. El anterior se gest√≥ entre los a√±os 2004 y 2005. F√≠jese cu√°ntas cosas han pasado desde entonces: globalizaci√≥n, tecnolog√≠a, sostenibilidad, cambio clim√°tico, ciudadan√≠a global... 
 
LV - Un joven, tras la ESO, ¬øpodr√° ser aut√≥nomo en la vida? ¬øAbrir una cuenta, planificar un viaje‚Ä¶?

CC- Esto es lo que se tiene que concretar ahora. En qu√© queremos que sean competentes y para qu√©. Todo contenido es importante en la medida que ese conocimiento sea necesario para desarrollar una competencia. Es decir, la capacidad de actuar ante un determinado tipo de situaci√≥n.

LV - La educaci√≥n es reflejo de una batalla pol√≠tica inacabable. En otros pa√≠ses se llega a consensos.

CC- Es un campo de batalla ideol√≥gico, y de los pocos que quedan. No hay que escandalizarse. Cuando hablamos de curr√≠culo hablamos de qu√© tipo de persona queremos contribuir a formar, y por tanto, de qu√© sociedad. Lo que no es normal es que no nos pongamos de acuerdo sobre lo m√≠nimo.

LV - Con esta propuesta, pareceque el alumno estar√° m√°s c√≥modo. ¬øSe busca que sea feliz?

CC- Una vez escuch√© a un alumno decir: ‚ÄúYo s√© cuando aprendo porque me emociono‚Äù. Los alumnos, como los adultos, no se esfuerzan cuando no est√°n motivados. Se puede estudiar por obligaci√≥n, claro. Pero el objetivo no es conseguir que los alumnos se esfuercen sino conseguir que se motiven, y entonces se esforzar√°n.

Description:
What one word would you use to describe these works of art?

They are from an unusual climate crisis exhibition in Indonesia.

An environmental activist group in the country spent three months building a museum made entirely out of plastic bags and bottles collected from several rivers around the city of Gresik.

Over 10,000 plastic items are on display.

As well as a tunnel built from plastic bottles, there's also a statue of Dewi Sri, the Javanese goddess of prosperity, also entirely constructed of local plastic waste.

The museum's founder, Prigi Arisandi, said the ECOTON (Ecological Observation and Wetlands Conservation) group wanted to remind to people to stop the use of single-use plastic "which eventually pollutes our oceans and the world."

Photos: Prasto Wardoyo/Reuters & Robertus Pudyanto/Getty Images

#plastic #singleuseplastic #saynotoplastic #pollution #ocean #plasticwaste #plasticbottles #plasticbags #Gresik #Indonesia #museum

Description:
England faces more floods and droughts, rising sea levels and greater demand on water supplies due to the climate crisis, the Environment Agency has warned.

Ahead of the UN Cop26 climate talks in Glasgow, the government agency is warning that adaptation ‚Äì becoming resilient to the already inevitable effects of climate change ‚Äì is just as important as actions to cut greenhouse gases.

It is a case of ‚Äúadapt or die‚Äù, said the Environment Agency‚Äôs chair, Emma Howard Boyd, warning that deadly events such as the flooding in Germany this summer would hit the UK if the country did not make itself resilient to the more violent weather the climate emergency was bringing.

In a report to the government, the EA said global heating would exacerbate the pressure on England‚Äôs water environment, which is suffering from problems such as pollution and increased demand, and make it harder to ensure clean and plentiful water.

There will be more and worse environmental incidents, such as flooding, water shortages and pollution; regulation is not ready for climate change; and the natural world cannot adapt as fast as the climate is changing, the EA said.

The report notes that population growth and climate change will increase water demands and mean that, if no further action is taken between 2025 and 2050, more than 3.4bn extra litres of water a day will be needed for resilient public water supplies.

The Environment Agency said it was working with government, businesses and communities on flood protection and with watchdog Ofwat on water supplies. It said it was focusing on restoring and creating peatlands, wetlands and other habitats to create resilient places for wildlife, reduce the risk of flooding, improve water quality and boost access to green spaces for people.

Photo: Oli SCARFF / AFP on Marsden Moor, near Huddersfield in northern England on April 27, 2021

#england #flooding #floods #extremeweather #cop26 #environmentagency #climatecrisis #climatechange #globalheating #water #watersupply #sealevel

Description:
Maine's population of rare Atlantic puffins took a hit this year, as the number of chicks to survive a tough summer plummeted.

The state's coastal bays and the Gulf of Maine is among the fastest-warming large water bodies on the planet, making the puffins' fate a test-case for how climate change could disrupt marine ecosystems worldwide.

The little clown-colored birds are abundant in Canada, but in the U.S. they were hunted to near extirpation by the early 1900s. Scientists and volunteers later helped them to re-establish several island colonies off Maine, where they now number around 3,000.

Over the last decade, though, a series of "marine heatwaves" and intense storms upended their living conditions. This year was one of the worst yet, and the number of puffin chicks to live through the season plunged.

Tap our link in bio for more.

(Images: Brian Bechard/Maine Public ‚Ä¢ @mainepublic)

El nuevo Superman es  ambientalista y, pr√≥ximamente, tambi√©n sexualmente diverso, anunci√≥ DC Comics, la compa√±√≠a editora de la legendaria tira c√≥mica.

El protagonista es Jonathan (Jon) Kent, hijo de Clark Kent y Lois Lane. "La idea de reemplazar a Superman con otro hombre blanco y heterosexual nos pareci√≥ que ser√≠a una oportunidad perdida", afirm√≥ Tom Taylor, uno de los escritores de la serie.

"El nuevo Superman debe enfrentarse a nuevas batallas, problemas del mundo real en la actualidad, ante las cuales debe mostrarse como lo que se supone que es: una de las personas m√°s fuertes del mundo", asegur√≥.

La nueva serie de la tira Superman comenz√≥ a circular en Estados Unidos el verano pasado, bajo el nombre de Superman: el hijo de Kal-El. En ella, el nuevo Superman combate al mal, pero tambi√©n ayuda a sofocar incendios causados por el cambio clim√°tico, impide tiroteos en escuelas, y protesta contra la deportaci√≥n de refugiados en la ciudad de Metropolis, m√≠tica sede de la serie.

Description:
"Everyone needs heroes and everyone deserves to see themselves in their heroes."

DC Comics has confirmed that the new iteration of Superman, Jonathan Kent, is bisexual.

In the new comic, the traditionally heterosexual superhero will embark on a same-sex relationship with a friend, Jay Nakamura, a reporter who cares for him after he ‚Äúmentally and physically burns out from trying to save everyone that he can‚Äù.

Kent, who is the son of Clark Kent and Lois Lane, started his tenure in July.

‚ÄúThe idea of replacing Clark Kent with another straight white savior felt like a missed opportunity,‚Äù Tom Taylor, the series writer, said in an interview with the New York Times.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve always said everyone needs heroes and everyone deserves to see themselves in their heroes and I‚Äôm very grateful DC and Warner Bros share this idea".

The news follows other recent attempts to add queerness to the world of comics. In August, it was announced that the latest version of Robin would have a boyfriend - while in March, Marvel also made the decision to pass the mantle of Captain America to a gay character.

Kent‚Äôs sexuality is not the only way in which Superman has been updated for a new audience and time.

Recent issues have seen the character protesting against the deportation of refugees, stopping a high school shooting and trying to put out wildfires that were the cause of the climate crisis.

Attention now turns to the big-screen worlds of Marvel and DC which remains less progressive than the comics.

This November‚Äôs Eternals is set to change things with the Marvel Cinematic Universe‚Äôs first LGBTQ+ kiss between Brian Tyree Henry‚Äôs Phastos, the first openly gay superhero in a Marvel movie, and Haaz Sleiman, who plays his husband.

#superman #clarkkent #loislane #jonathankent #marvel #dccomics #marveluniverse #lgbtq #lgbtq+ #lgbtrights #equality
ImageText: DC Comics reveal that latest Superman character is bisexual Superman's symbol has always stood for hope, for truth and for justice. Today, that symbol represents something more. Today, more people can see themselves in the powerful superhero in comics. Tom Taylor Series writer

Prince Charles has urged world leaders to attend the COP26 climate change conference in Glasgow in three weeks' time.

It comes as Australia‚Äôs Prime Minister Scott Morrison said he has still "not made any final decisions" about being there.

The COP26 global climate summit is seen as crucial if climate change is to be brought under control. 

Almost 200 countries are being asked for their plans to cut emissions, and it could lead to major changes to our everyday lives.

Description:
This year marks the 57th edition of the Wildlife Photographer of the Year competition, held annually at the Natural History Museum.‚Å†
‚Å†
Two new categories have been introduced this year, to illustrate the impact of climate change.‚Å†
‚Å†
Nayan Khanolkar captured this photo of flamingos gathered on Talawe wetland in an estuarine creek bordering Navi Mumbai, India. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Nayan captured the spectacle with his drone in 2020 but says it isn‚Äôt always this eye-catching. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Reduced human activity, as a result of the Covid-19 lockdown, meant record numbers of birds and exceptionally clear air. ‚ÄòI have never seen such blue skies in Mumbai,‚Äô he says. The gathering of flamingos is also tuned to the tides. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The birds move close to the city only during high water, when the mangrove creeks are too flooded for them to feed. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Talawe is one of few wetlands in the area to have escaped the urban sprawl, but it is now threatened by a golf-course development, which will displace the flamingos and other birds, many of them migrants, dependent on this wetland for stopovers. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The winners of the competition will be announced on Tuesday evening.

Mac Stone took this photo of a racoon carrying its newborn cub through floodwater in Florida.‚Å†
‚Å†
Unseasonable heavy rain in late October caused a sudden spike in the water levels in Audubon‚Äôs Corkscrew Swamp Sanctuary. ‚Å†
‚Å†
This ancient Everglades swamp forest contains one of the world‚Äôs largest remaining stands of old-growth bald cypress, providing valuable habitat for many species. ‚Å†
‚Å†
These include raccoons, which like to nest in tree cavities. But in this particular area, the dominant trees are pond cypress, which are smaller and generally lack large cavities, driving raccoons to nest on the ground or in trees that might be more susceptible to storm damage. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Raccoons typically have litters of three to five cubs, though over several days, the rescue of only this one cub was captured by Mac‚Äôs camera trap. ‚Å†

Description:
"Expect us."

Hundreds of protesters led by Indigenous activists from across the country demonstrated in front of the White House yesterday to demand that Joe Biden stop approving fossil fuel projects and declare the climate crisis a national emergency.

The rally marks the start of five days of demonstrations calling for greater attention to climate injustices as Native American leaders and tribal members head to the capital to publicize their demands.

Outside the White House, the words ‚ÄúExpect Us‚Äù were spray-painted on the base of a statue of Andrew Jackson, the seventh US president who is infamous for, among other things, leading the violent and lethal repression of Native American peoples in a displacement known as the Trail of Tears.

‚ÄúExpect Us‚Äù is part of the phrase ‚ÄúRespect Us, or Expect Us,‚Äù which many Indigenous women have been using while demonstrating against the Canadian oil company Enbridge‚Äôs $9bn upgrade of an oil pipeline designed to carry oil from Alberta, Canada, to Wisconsin.

The Indigenous Environmental Network ‚Äì a broad alliance of tribes, Indigenous rights groups, labor organizations and others ‚Äì have criticized Biden for not moving to block Enbridge‚Äôs Line 3 replacement project.

IEN said they'd had "enough of Biden's empty words" and urged him to swiftly "mitigate the climate chaos that has engulfed our communities.‚Äù

Monday‚Äôs demonstrations fell on a federal holiday in the US that until recently was officially dedicated to Christopher Columbus. However, spurred by national calls for racial equity and decolonization, communities across the country have over the years paired or replaced it with Indigenous Peoples‚Äô Day.

The demonstration was mostly peaceful, although protesters were subjected to police use of a long-range acoustic device, which emits a piercing sound, according to video footage captured by Indigenous campaigners. There were also a few arrests.

Photos: Allison Bailey/NurPhoto/REX/Shutterstock + Yasin Ozturk/Anadolu Agency/Getty Images & Kevin Lamarque/Reuters Evelyn Hockstein/Reuters

‚Å†
Two new categories have been introduced this year, to illustrate the impact of climate change.‚Å†
‚Å†
This photo, taken by David Doubliet, shows the impact of coral bleaching on a reef in the Great Barrier Reef.‚Å†
‚Å†
Doubliet said: "The print in my hand is from a 2009 picture of a vibrant coral tower on Opal Reef, Great Barrier Reef. I returned to photograph the same tower in 2018 after 2016 and 2017 back to back coral bleaching events devastated much of this great reef. The tower of coral was dead, a stark, but still standing monument surrounded by a crumbling cemetery of coral."‚Å†
‚Å†
The winners of the competition will be announced on Tuesday evening.‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
This year marks the 57th edition of the Wildlife Photographer of the Year competition, held annually at the Natural History Museum.‚Å†
‚Å†
Two new categories have been introduced this year, to illustrate the impact of climate change.‚Å†
‚Å†
Doug Gimesy captured this photo of Flying fox bats congregated on a tree in Victoria, Melbourne during an extreme heat wave in the region.‚Å†
‚Å†
Gimesy said: "Grey-headed flying foxes descend from the safety of the tree canopy in a desperate search for somewhere cooler and less exposed.‚Å†
‚Å†
"Ironically, and sadly, this behaviour results in what experts call ‚Äòclumping‚Äô where large numbers of bats congregate in close proximity, and with no evaporative cooling they become even hotter.‚Å†
‚Å†
"This behaviour is often a precursor to mass deaths, where one may fall, taking others down with them. On the ground, exhausted, and unable to climb, the bodies pile upon each other compounding their heat stress and suffocating some.‚Å†
‚Å†
"Park Ranger and grey-headed flying fox Project Officer Stephen Brend estimated that during this day, over 4,500 Grey-headed Flying-foxes died at the colony - maybe 10% of the population at the time, with over 50% being infants, and a significant proportion of the next generation."‚Å†
‚Å†
The winners of the competition will be announced on Tuesday evening.‚Å†
‚Å†
¬© Doug Gimesy, @doug_gimesy‚Å†
‚Å†
@nhm_wpy‚Å†

Description:
This year marks the 57th edition of the Wildlife Photographer of the Year competition, held annually at the Natural History Museum.‚Å†
‚Å†
Two new categories have been introduced this year, to illustrate the impact of climate change.‚Å†
‚Å†
Wildlife photographer Mick Watson captured this photo of a seal wrapped tightly in fishing rope, at Donna Nook in Lincolnshire.‚Å†
‚Å†
Watson said: "A young seal has been captured in fishing rope. As it has grown, the rope has cut into its body leaving deep wounds to its neck. The suffering and pain can be seen on it as it screams in pain, getting worse as it grows.‚Å†
‚Å†
"The local Wildlife Trust was called and the seal sanctuary as well. I stayed with the seal until they arrived. It was cut free, treated with pain meds and antibiotics and allowed to go free.‚Å†
‚Å†
"I stayed a few hours and watched it return to its large group. This is not an unusual occurrence and shows the things we leave in the sea have a profound impact upon wildlife. This one was lucky, others will be less so."‚Å†
‚Å†
The winners of the competition will be announced on Tuesday evening.‚Å†
‚Å†
¬© Mick Watson‚Å†

Description:
Prince Charles doesn't fill up his favourite car in the usual whey.

Speaking to the BBC about his effort to reduce his carbon footprint, he revelaed: ‚ÄúMy old Aston Martin‚Ä¶ runs on‚Ä¶ surplus English white wine and whey from the cheese process".

He said the car had been modified to run on a fuel called E85 - made up of 85% bioethanol and 15% unleaded petrol.

Bioethanol can be derived from different sources - including in the case of the prince's car - surplus wine and alcohol extracted from fermented whey.

He said most of the vehicles used on his estates were now electric.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the Prince‚Äôs views about climate change and why he says he totally understood the "frustration" climate campaigners felt.

Para su segundo texto sobre la Amenaza Ecol√≥gica, el Instituto para la Econom√≠a y la Paz (IEP) evalu√≥ 178 estados y territorios independientes. Esto, para encontrar los m√°s propensos a los conflictos relacionados con la amenaza ecol√≥gica.‚ÄØ

Description:

Two new categories have been introduced this year, to illustrate the impact of climate change.‚Å†

Buddhilini de Soyza took this photo of five cheetahs crossing a river during floods in Masai Mara, Kenya, in January 2020.‚Å†
‚Å†
De Soyza said: "The world‚Äôs only recorded coalition of five male cheetahs were looking to cross this river in terrifyingly powerful currents. It seemed a task doomed to failure, with many famous cheetahs dying trying to cross much fewer daunting waters.‚Å†
‚Å†
"After hours of careful searching along the banks, they suddenly jumped into the water and began trying to swim across this maelstrom of water as we watched terrified, they would be washed away or eaten by crocodiles. Their aim was to cross over to the other side, which was part of their territory and full of game.‚Å†
‚Å†
"We screamed with delight as we saw them finally cross over about a 100m downstream from where they jumped."‚Å†
‚Å†
The winners of the competition will be announced on Tuesday evening.‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
Der Anruf aus Stockholm kam f√ºr Klaus Hasselmann v√∂llig √ºberraschend. Hier erz√§hlt der Physiker, wie er den menschengemachten Klimawandel nachgewiesen hat ‚Äì und warum er trotzdem optimistisch in die Zukunft blickt.

SPIEGEL: Herr Professor Hasselmann, herzlichen Gl√ºckwunsch zum Physik-Nobelpreis. Erz√§hlen Sie: Wie haben Sie den Tag der Verk√ºndung erlebt?

Klaus Hasselmann: Na ja, das war alles sehr irreal. Dieser Anruf, der so aus dem Nichts passierte. Richtig begriffen habe ich das immer noch nicht.

SPIEGEL: Was bedeutet dieser Preis jetzt f√ºr Sie?

Hasselmann: Auf mein Leben hat das keinen Einfluss. Aber es ist irgendwie ganz lustig. Wie gesagt: Es hat mich vollkommen √ºberrascht. Ich muss das erst noch richtig verarbeiten. Aber im Ernst: Ich finde es wichtig, dass das Nobelpreiskomitee auf diese Weise die Bedeutung des Klimaproblems unterstreicht. Das ist eine Neuerung in Stockholm.

Description:

Una de las constantes de la obra de Jaume Plensa es el silencio. La fabricaci√≥n del silencio. El silencio "como un motor para escuchar los latidos de tu coraz√≥n, la vibraci√≥n de tu cuerpo y de tus pensamientos". Pero tras dieciocho meses de pandemia, cree que "es muy importante reivindicar ese silencio activo para poder escuchar el latido del coraz√≥n de los otros, de estar m√°s pendientes que nunca de los otros". El artista, que celebra que por fin podamos volver a estar juntos, "cada uno con su individualidad y su memoria", reflexionaba as√≠ durante la entrega del Gran Gresol, galard√≥n que ha recibido este martes en el Palau Macaya de manos del presidente de la Fundaci√≥ Gresol Emili Correig.

El pr√≥ximo d√≠a 21 estar√° en Nueva York para reencontrarse con Water's Soul, su escultura m√°s monumental hasta la fecha -mide 22 metros de altura- que quedar√° instalada de forma permanente en New Jersey, a orillas del r√≠o Hudson, frente al Bajo Manhattan. La escultura representa el rostro sereno de una joven que se lleva un dedo a los labios en un estado de contemplaci√≥n silenciosa. "Es como si estuviera pidiendo silencio a Manhattan para que escuchemos la voz del agua, que es fuente de vida", se√±ala Plensa. Description:
Entre el pr√≥ximo 1 y 12 de noviembre se vivir√°n jornadas claves en Glasgow, Escocia, la nueva edici√≥n de la COP. Tras la publicaci√≥n en agosto del sexto informe del IPCC (Grupo Intergubernamental de Expertos sobre el Cambio Clim√°tico de las Naciones Unidas), quedaron expuestas alarmantes cifras con respecto a la situaci√≥n a nivel global. El incremento medio del nivel del mar, el aumento de las emisiones de CO2 y otros gases son solo algunos de los factores. Pero la que caus√≥ mayor alerta fue la posibilidad de que el planeta llegue a los 1.5¬∞C para 2040 y se transforme en un camino sin retorno.

Y la crisis proveniente por la situaci√≥n global se manifiesta en distintos aspectos. Chile y otros pa√≠ses pasan por una cr√≠tica situaci√≥n h√≠drica, mientras que zonas como Australia sufren graves incendios que se mantuvieron durante meses, entre otras. Ante eso, los distintos expertos, gobiernos y ambientalistas se preparan para ver cu√°les ser√°n las medidas y acuerdos a los que lleguen.

Chile, por ejemplo, buscar√° consolidar los avances realizados durante su presidencia, iniciada en 2019. Si bien en 2015 se firm√≥ el Acuerdo de Par√≠s en la COP21, a√∫n faltan afinar algunos detalles y es este el momento preciso para hacerlo. Tambi√©n se har√°n presentes las voces j√≥venes. @TremendasCL se presentar√° en dos instancias de esta edici√≥n y mostrar√° uno de sus proyectos m√°s bullados, con el que ni√±as aprenden a combatir algunos de los principales desaf√≠os globales.

Description:

Los bomberos y equipos de emergencia siguen trabajando para acabar con el fuego que asola a las secuoyas gigantes del Sequoia National Park. Las llamas ya han arrasado alrededor de 39.000 hect√°reas de este emblem√°tico parque estadounidense, y el equipo de prevenci√≥n solo tiene controlado al 56% del incendio. Cerca de la ruta The Trial of 100 Giants -conocida as√≠ por la inmensidad de las secuoyas que la rodean y que pueden superar los cien metros de altura- el fuego ha acabado ya con 44 ejemplares.

En los √∫ltimos a√±os el cambio clim√°tico ha empeorado las condiciones de los parques nacionales, que son cada vez m√°s secos y con temperaturas extremas. Las secuoyas rojas, una subespecie milenaria que puede llegar a vivir 3.000 a√±os, han empezado a desaparecer a ritmo acelerado.

Description:
2021 has been a year of climate disasters.

From -25C temperatures in Spain to a record-equalling 54.4C in Death Valley, the extremes of our climate are becoming more acute.

And it is increasingly having a real-life impact. Just this summer - hundreds of sudden deaths in Canada were linked to a record heatwave; more than 200 people died in floods across Europe and more than 300 deaths were recorded in flash floods in China.

This is a reminder of some of the worst climate events this year and why November‚Äôs COP26 climate change conference in Glasgow is so important.

Producer: Ryan Ramgobin

The Nobel Prize in physics has been awarded to scientists Syukuro Manabe, Klaus Hasselmann and Giorgio Parisi, whose groundbreaking work over the past 60 years predicted climate change.‚Å†
‚Å†
Parisi acknowledged the timeliness of the award while speaking with reporters after the announcement. He said it is "urgent that we take a very strong position, and we move at a very strong pace," adding: "It's clear that for the future generations, we have to act now, in a very fast way."‚Å†

Description:
La Real Academia de las Ciencias Sueca ha concedido el premio Nobel de F√≠sica 2021 de manera conjunta al alem√°n Klaus Hasselman, el japon√©s nacionalizado estadounidense Syukuro Manabe, y el italiano Giorgio Parisi, por sus contribuciones al entendimiento de los "sistemas f√≠sicos complejos". 

Hasselman y Manabe han trabajado sobre el modelo f√≠sico del clima terrestre que permite interpretar el cambio clim√°tico. Parisi ha trabajado sobre "el desorden y las fluctuaciones en sistemas f√≠sicos, del √°tomo a los sistemas planetarios".

Description:
Cities around the world are rethinking public transit.
 
Urban transportation is central to the effort to slow climate change, but it can‚Äôt be done by just switching to electric cars. Berlin, Bogot√° and several other cities are taking creative steps to cut gas and diesel from their public transit systems ‚Äî and doing so despite striking differences in geography, politics and economics that complicate the transformation.
 
Berlin is reviving electric tram lines that were ripped out when the Berlin Wall went up. Bogot√° is building cable cars that cut through the clouds to connect working-class communities perched on faraway hills. Bergen, a city by the fjords in western Norway, is moving its public ferries away from diesel and onto batteries ‚Äî a remarkable shift in a petrostate that has for decades enriched itself from the sale of oil and gas and that now wants to be a leader in marine vessels for the electric age.
 
Bergen‚Äôs buses, too, are now electric, supplied by Chinese bus makers that have seized on the market in cities as far afield as Los Angeles and Santiago. The change is audible. ‚ÄúYou can hear voices again in the streets,‚Äù said Jon Askeland, the mayor of the county that includes Bergen.
 
Cities, home to more than half the world‚Äôs population, account for more than two-thirds of global carbon dioxide emissions. And transportation is often the largest, and fastest growing, source. The cities that most need to make the shift to electric have faced the biggest challenges. They include the most crowded and polluted metropolises of Asia and Africa, where people rely on informal mass transit such as diesel minivans or motorcycle taxis.

But where cities are succeeding, they‚Äôre finding that electrifying public transit can solve more than just climate problems. It can clean the air, reduce traffic jams and, ideally, make getting around town easier for ordinary people. Tap the link in our bio to read more. Photos by @historiassencillas and @lynseyaddario

Description:
Wenn die Flugbranche eine Zukunft haben soll, dann muss sie klimavertr√§glich sein. Das ist die Flugbranche derzeit √ºberhaupt nicht. Zum Treibhauseffekt durch Flugbenzin kommen weitere Klimasch√§den dazu, die dadurch entstehen, dass die Maschinen in gro√üer H√∂he unterwegs sind und Kondensstreifen hinterlassen.

In Werlte im Emsland ist nun eine Anlage in Betrieb genommen worden, in der synthetisches Kerosin hergestellt wird. Es handelt sich um die weltweit erste Anlage zur Produktion dieses CO2-neutralen Treibstoffs. Bauherr der Anlage ist die Organisation ‚ÄûAtmosfair‚Äú. Deren Gesch√§ftsf√ºhrer Dietrich Brockhagen sieht im E-Kerosin die einzige M√∂glichkeit, die Klimawende im Luftverkehr zu schaffen. 

Andere Optionen wie Biokraftstoffe fielen aus, da die Flugzeuge daf√ºr nicht umgebaut werden k√∂nnten, sagte Brockhagen im Deutschlandfunk.

Das vollst√§ndige Interview findet ihr √ºber den Link in der Bio.

El p√°jaro carpintero de pico de marfil, una de las aves m√°s majestuosas de Estados Unidos, y otras 22 especies fueron declaradas extintas permanentemente por autoridades norteamericanas. 

Entre las especies que los cient√≠ficos han perdido la esperanza de volver a ver con vida se encuentran el ave reinita de Bachman, dos tipos de peces de agua dulce, ocho clases de mejillones y una planta. 

El comunicado del Servicio Federal de Pesca y Vida Silvestre de los Estados Unidos subraya ‚Äúc√≥mo la actividad humana puede llevar a las especies al declive y a la extinci√≥n, contribuyendo a la p√©rdida de h√°bitat, a la sobreexplotaci√≥n y a la introducci√≥n de especies invasoras y enfermedades‚Äù.

Description:
Climate change is causing once-mighty rivers to dry up and temperatures to rise to deadly levels in Mexico.

Paramedics are struggling to treat those with heat-related illnesses, while the community campaigns for water to be released so that the Colorado river can flow once again.

#Mexico #ClimateChange #Rivers #BBCNews
ImageText: Mexico's struggle for water

Description:
"The sun is beating down directly on you, and it‚Äôs just unbearable."

Climate change events such as heatwaves and flooding are disproportionately affecting those from poorer backgrounds around the world.

Children born in high-income countries will experience twice as many extreme climate events as their grandparents, new research suggests.

But for children in low-income countries, it will be worse - as they will see three times as many, say researchers at the University of Brussels.

#ClimateChange #Climate #Environment #BBCNews
ImageText: How climate change makes inequality worse

La Amazon√≠a, que abarca nueve pa√≠ses, perdi√≥ entre 1985 y 2020 un 17% de su vegetaci√≥n nativa, un √°rea equivalente al territorio de Chile, y el 52% de sus glaciares, ubicados en su regi√≥n andina, seg√∫n un informe independiente.

En la indagaci√≥n, la plataforma colaborativa Mapbiomas revel√≥ que en este periodo se perdieron 74,6 millones de hect√°reas de selva y otras formaciones naturales no forestales.

Adem√°s, advirti√≥ que a ese ritmo podr√≠a alcanzarse en esta d√©cada el ‚Äúpunto de ruptura para los servicios ecosist√©micos de la Amazon√≠a‚Äù, un bioma vital para frenar el cambio clim√°tico.

Los datos, a partir del mapeo satelital de cambios del uso del suelo a nivel de toda la Amazon√≠a, muestran que mientras en 1985 solo el 6% de la mayor selva tropical del planeta hab√≠a sido convertida en las llamadas ‚Äú√°reas antr√≥picas‚Äù (zonas urbanas o tierras destinadas a la agricultura, la ganader√≠a o la miner√≠a), en 2020 ese porcentaje representaba el 15% de toda la regi√≥n.

Description:
Greenland is famous for its frozen landscapes, remote fjords and glaciers, but increasingly the island is known for something else: rare minerals.
 
It‚Äôs all because of climate change and the world‚Äôs mad dash to accelerate the development of green technology. As global warming melts the ice that covers 80% of the island, it has spurred demand for Greenland‚Äôs potentially abundant reserves of hard-to-find minerals. These so-called rare earths, used in wind turbines, electric motors and many other electronic devices, have become essential raw materials as the world tries to break its addiction to fossil fuels.
 
Mining companies, global superpowers and billionaire investors are coveting Greenland‚Äôs reserves of rare minerals. But those expecting to exploit the island‚Äôs riches will have to contend with Mariane Paviasen (third photo) and the predominantly Indigenous residents of the village of Narsaq. The rocky heights above the village contain what may be some of the richest concentrations of rare minerals anywhere. These deposits  attracted an Australian company backed by Chinese investors that had hoped to blast an open-pit mine ‚Äî until it ran into Paviasen.
 
In elections this past April for Greenland‚Äôs Parliament, Paviasen and her protest group overcame a lobbying effort by the mining company, Greenland Minerals, and swayed public opinion in favor of a party that promised to stop the mine. The victory for Paviasen and her alliance of sheep farmers, fishermen and other residents sent a signal to all those eying Greenland‚Äôs mineral wealth: Any project that threatened livelihoods or the environment  was going to run into trouble from local people who were quite capable of standing up to powerful interests. 

Tap the link in our bio for more. Photos by @carstensnejbjerg

Die Biodiversit√§tskrise k√∂nnte das langfristige √úberleben der Menschheit noch st√§rker bedrohen als der Klimawandel. Im Jahr 2010 tagten daher Unterh√§ndler der UN-Konvention zum Schutz der Artenvielfalt. Um den Verlust der biologischen Vielfalt zu verlangsamen, einigten sie sich auf 20 Kernziele, die bis 2020 erreicht werden sollten. Sie werden auch als ‚ÄûAichi-Ziele‚Äú bezeichnet ‚Äì benannt nach der japanischen Pr√§fektur, wo sie ausgehandelt wurden.

Die meisten dieser Ziele zum weltweiten Schutz der Artenvielfalt hatten eine Laufzeit von zehn Jahren. Nur einige wenige waren so dringend, dass sie schon 2015 erreicht werden sollten. So etwa der Schutz der Korallen. Das Aichi-Kernziel 10 lautete deshalb:

‚ÄûBis 2015 sind die zahlreichen menschengemachten Stressoren f√ºr Korallenriffe und andere dem Klimawandel und der Meeresversauerung gegen√ºber sensiblen √ñkosysteme minimiert, so dass ihre Integrit√§t und ihre Funktion erhalten bleiben.‚Äú
Denn: Korallen sind st√§rker vom Aussterben bedroht, als jede andere Tiergruppe. Trotzdem wurde das Ziel weder bis 2015 noch bis heute erreicht.

Unseren Beitrag √ºber das weltweite Korallensterben findet ihr √ºber den Link in der Bio.

Description:
A western lowland gorilla walking through a cloud of butterflies in the Central African Republic has been announced as the winner of the Nature Conservancy 2021 Photo Contest.

Photographer Anup Shah, who captured the photograph entitled Malui, was chosen from more than 100,000 entrants from 158 countries.

The Nature Conservancy‚ÄØis a global conservation organisation that works in 72 countries, and is dedicated to conserving the lands and waters on which all life depends.

It says it is guided by science to create on-the-ground solutions to the world's toughest challenges, including climate change.

Here are winners from other categories, click the link in our bio to see more incredible pictures from the competition.

2. People and nature winner: Saving Orangutans, by Alain Schroeder, Belgium
3. Wildlife winner: A turbulent swim, by Buddhilini de Soyza, Australia
4. Landscape winner: Drought, by Daniel De Granville Man√ßo, Brazil
5. People's Choice winner: Fireflies, by Prathamesh Ghadekar, India
6. Water winner: Water, by Kazi Arifujjaman, Bangladesh

Wahlkampf ist, wenn Politik auf Wirklichkeit trifft. Doch klappt das unter Pandemiebedingungen? Die Fotografen Volker Crone (@volker_crone) und Rafael Heygster (@rafahey) haben eingefangen, was die Menschen in den vergangenen Wochen bewegt hat. Und sie erlebten einen Wahlkampf, in dem die Politik oft auf Abstand blieb. 

[1] Aktivisten blockieren am 31. Juli einen geplanten Gasterminal in Brunsb√ºttel. Der Konflikt mit der Staatsmacht ist Teil der Inszenierung. 

[2] Am 24. September gehen wieder Tausende f√ºr mehr Klimaschutz auf die Stra√üe. 

[3] Leipzig feiert 1700 Jahre Judentum in Deutschland. Peter Muschinsky (mit Kippa) aus Kopenhagen besucht das Grab einer Vorfahrin. 

[4] Junge Menschen verfolgen das EM-Achtelfinale gegen Englnad in einem Biergarten in Hannover. Deutschland verliert. 

[5] Die K√ºnstlerin Peaches er√∂ffnet am 8. Juli ein Festival auf der gesperrten Raschplatzhochstra√üe in Hannover. 

[6] Wahlkampfauftritt von Armin Laschet in Braunschweig. Das Publikum schwnakt zwischen N√§he und Distanz. 

[7] Mit Gott gegen den Klimawandel: Eine christliche Gruppe pilgert Mitte Juli von Gorleben nach Garzweiler. 

[8] Die Rennfahrer Kevin und Oliver Eriksson kommen von einem Autorennen. F√ºr Trucks gilt auch in Deutschland ein Tempolimit.

Description:
President Biden and Speaker Nancy Pelosi spoke in the dugout during the annual Congressional Baseball Game on Wednesday, played as Congress raced to fund the government and avoid a shutdown. The Republicans won the game, and Pelosi spent the evening working the phones from the stands as she fought to keep the infrastructure measure on track.

Democrats face a consequential day Thursday on Capitol Hill as they scramble to avert a government shutdown at midnight and salvage two crucial pieces of President Biden‚Äôs domestic agenda imperiled by deep internal divisions.

With just hours before government funding is set to lapse, the Senate is scheduled Thursday morning to take a series of votes on a spending package that would keep the government open through early December and provide emergency aid to assist Afghan refugees and natural disaster recovery efforts across the country. The measure is expected to pass and move quickly to the House, where it is also expected to be approved, and then sent to Biden for his signature.

But a planned vote in the House on a $1 trillion infrastructure bill is in doubt amid an intraparty stalemate. Liberal Democrats have threatened to bring down the infrastructure bill unless Congress first acts on a much larger, $3.5 trillion social policy package that includes a vast climate change initiative, expansions of health care, public education, paid leave and child care programs, and an array of tax increases.

Both are major priorities for Biden, who invested ample political capital in the infrastructure compromise and has staked his presidency on the enactment of a transformational social policy package. But centrists have resisted the $3.5 trillion plan, and given Democrats‚Äô slim margins of control, there is currently no clear path for passing it.

Tap the link in our bio for the latest from Washington and to read about the four key issues facing Congress right now. Photo by @nytmills

Description:
The ivory-billed woodpecker - pictured above - and 22 more birds, fish and other species are expected to be declared extinct by the US Fish and Wildlife Service.

It‚Äôs a rare move for wildlife officials to give up hope on a plant or animal, but government scientists have exhausted efforts to find these 23 species and warned that the climate crisis, on top of other pressures, could make such disappearances more common.

‚ÄúEach of these 23 species represents a permanent loss to our nation‚Äôs natural heritage and to global biodiversity,‚Äù Bridget Fahey, who oversees species classification for the Fish and Wildlife Service, told the New York Times. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a sobering reminder that extinction is a consequence of human-caused environmental change,‚Äù he said.

The ivory-billed woodpecker was perhaps the best known species the US Fish and Wildlife Service on Wednesday will announce is extinct.

It went out stubbornly and with fanfare, making unconfirmed appearances in recent decades that ignited a frenzy of ultimately fruitless searches in the swamps of Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi and Florida.

Around the globe, some 902 species have been documented as extinct.

The actual number is thought to be much higher because some are never formally identified, and many scientists warn the earth is in an ‚Äúextinction crisis‚Äù with flora and fauna now disappearing at 1,000 times the historical rate.

The factors behind the disappearances vary ‚Äì too much development, water pollution, logging, competition from invasive species, birds killed for feathers and animals captured by private collectors. In each case, humans were the ultimate cause.

But several scientists are staying positive, saying that it's possible one or more of the 23 species included in Wednesday‚Äôs announcement could reappear.

Photo: Tomasz Cofta/BirdLife Internatio/PA

#extinction #woodpecker #extinctspecies #species #endangered #endangeredspecies #fishandwildlifeservice #climatecrisis #naturalhabitat #habitat #threat #preservation

La activista sueca contra el cambio clim√°tico Greta Thunberg aprovech√≥ su discurso ante la Conferencia Juvenil sobre el Clima de la ONU, que se inici√≥ este martes en Mil√°n (Italia), para burlarse de los l√≠deres pol√≠ticos mundiales, a los que acus√≥ de ofrecer promesas vac√≠as que no son seguidas por acciones.

"Eso es todo lo que o√≠mos de nuestros llamados l√≠deres. Palabras, palabras que suenan genial, pero que hasta ahora no han llevado a ninguna acci√≥n", dijo la joven de 18 a√±os de edad.

"Nuestras esperanzas y sue√±os se ahogan en sus palabras y promesas vac√≠as. Claro que necesitamos el di√°logo constructivo, pero ellos ya llevan 30 a√±os de bla, bla, bla y ¬øad√≥nde nos han llevado?", se pregunt√≥.

Pese a sus cr√≠ticas, Thunberg dijo que a√∫n es posible darle la vuelta a la situaci√≥n planteada por el cambio clim√°tico.

"Es completamente posible. Requerir√° dr√°sticos recortes anuales de emisiones como el mundo no ha visto nunca antes", dijo Thunberg.

"No podemos seguir dejando que las personas en el poder decidan qu√© es pol√≠ticamente posible o no. No podemos seguir dejando que las personas en el poder decidan lo que es la esperanza. La esperanza no es pasiva. La esperanza no es bla, bla, bla. La esperanza es decir la verdad. La esperanza es actuar. Y la esperanza siempre viene de la gente", concluy√≥.

Unos 400 j√≥venes procedentes de 186 pa√≠ses participan en la Cumbre Juvenil sobre el Clima que durar√° tres d√≠as y de donde se esperan que emerjan propuestas para ser presentadas en la pr√≥xima conferencia internacional de cambio clim√°tico (COP26) en Glasgow (Reino Unido), que debe realizarse entre el 1 y el 12 de noviembre.

Description:
Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg slammed governments for "shamelessly congratulating themselves" for insufficient pledges to cut emissions and promises of financing, during a speech at the Youth4Climate conference in Milan on Tuesday.
"There is no Planet B, there is no planet blah, blah, blah," Thunberg, 18, said to warm applause. Echoing a speech by COP26 summit host Boris Johnson in April, she continued: "This is not about some expensive politically correct dream of bunny hugging, or build back better, blah blah blah, green economy, blah blah blah, net zero by 2050, blah blah blah, climate neutral blah blah blah.

"This is all we hear from our so-called leaders: words, words that sound great but so far have led to no action, our hopes and dreams drowned in their empty words and promises," said Thunberg.

Some 400 youth activists from nearly 200 countries gathered in Milan will submit a joint declaration to a ministerial meeting at the end of the week, as a lead-in to COP26 in November in Glasgow. COP26 is vital for the effective implementation of the 2015 Paris Agreement, which saw countries commit to limit global temperature rises to "well below" 2 degrees Celsius. The landmark deal aims for a safer warming cap of 1.5C. But six years after the accord was struck, countries still haven't agreed how it will work in practice. 
-AFP
ImageText: npr GRETA THUNBERG BLASTS WORLD LEADERS OVER CLIMATE CRISIS September 28, 2021 FPTV/AFP of bunny hugging, or blah blah blah.

Description:
Death's come knocking a last time for the ivory-billed woodpecker and 22 more birds, fish and other species including the tubercled-blossom pearly mussel and the Bachman's warbler. The U.S. government is declaring them extinct.

It's a rare move for wildlife officials to give up hope on a plant or animal, but government scientists say they've exhausted efforts to find these 23. 

They warn climate change, on top of other pressures, could make such disappearances more common as a warming planet adds to the dangers facing imperiled plants and wildlife. Visit www.usatoday.com for more.

Description:
A child born in 2021 will live on average through seven times as many heat waves, twice as many wildfires and nearly three times as many droughts, crop failures and river floods as their grandparents, according to a study that looks at how different generations will be affected by climate change.‚Å†
‚Å†
The results, published in the journal Science, found that global warming will disproportionately affect the lives of young people and children, particularly when it comes to extreme events worsened by climate change. ‚Å†
‚Å†
"We found that everyone under 40 today will live an unprecedented life in terms of their lifetime exposure to heat waves, droughts and floods," said Wim Thiery, a climate scientist who led the research. "This is true even under the most conservative scenarios."‚Å†
‚Å†
Read more at the link in our bio.‚Å†
‚Å†
üì∏ Sean Rayford / @gettyimages
ImageText: L6914BX Under 40? Expect an 'unprecedented' life of extreme heat waves, droughts and floods CLIMATE IN CRISIS

Description: Climate activist Greta Thunberg opened an international youth climate summit in Milan, Italy on Tuesday, with an impassioned speech, blasting world leaders for their "empty words and promises" in addressing the climate crisis."
ImageText: Words.

Description:
"Blah, blah, blah..."

Greta Thunberg used a climate speech to mock the words of world leaders, including the UK‚Äôs Boris Johnson and President Joe Biden.

The 18-year-old used soundbites from Mr Johnson, such as "expensive bunny hugging" and "build back better", to highlight what she called the "empty words and promises" of politicians.

Many countries have announced ambitious targets to reduce their emissions to tackle climate change.

The UK, for example, has pledged to cut 78% of its emissions by 2035, from a 1990 baseline. But the government's current plans are projected to deliver less than a quarter of the cuts needed to meet the goal.

#GretaThunberg #ClimateChange #Environment #BBCNews
ImageText: ASISH 'Build back better, blah, blah, blah'

Description:
Greta Thunberg has slammed global leaders over their promises to address the climate emergency, dismissing them as ‚Äúblah, blah, blah‚Äù.

In a speech to the Youth4Climate summit in Milan, Italy, today Thunberg quoted statements by UK prime minister, Boris Johnson: ‚ÄúThis is not some expensive, politically correct, green act of bunny hugging‚Äù, and Narendra Modi: ‚ÄúFighting climate change calls for innovation, cooperation and willpower‚Äù but said the science did not lie.

‚ÄúOf course we need constructive dialogue,‚Äù said @gretathunberg. ‚ÄúBut they‚Äôve now had 30 years of blah, blah, blah and where has that led us? We can still turn this around ‚Äì it is entirely possible. It will take immediate, drastic annual emission reductions. But not if things go on like today. Our leaders‚Äô intentional lack of action is a betrayal toward all present and future generations.‚Äù

The Cop26 climate summit starts in Glasgow, UK, on 31 October and all the big-polluting countries must deliver tougher pledges to cut emissions to keep the goal of 1.5C within reach.

Carbon emissions are on track to rise by 16% by 2030, according to the UN, rather than fall by half, which is the cut needed to keep global heating under the internationally agreed limit of 1.5C.

Research published on Monday showed that children born today would experience many times more extreme heatwaves and other climate disasters over their lifetimes than their grandparents, even if countries fulfil their current emissions pledges.

Thunberg, @vanessanakate1 from Uganda, and hundreds of other young people from across the world are attending the Youth4Climate Summit. It is hosted by the Italian government, the UK‚Äôs partner in running Cop26.

Thunberg said: ‚ÄúThey invite cherry-picked young people to meetings like this to pretend that they listen to us. But they clearly don‚Äôt listen to us. Our emissions are still rising. The science doesn‚Äôt lie.

‚ÄúWe can no longer let the people in power decide what is politically possible. We can no longer let the people in power decide what hope is. Hope is not passive. Hope is not blah, blah, blah. Hope is telling the truth. Hope is taking action. And hope always comes from the people.‚Äù
ImageText: G Build back better. Blah, blah, blah. Green economy. Blah blah blah. Net zero by 2050. Blah, blah, blah. Greta Thunberg lambasts world leaders on climate inaction HUNOA

Description:
There's one month to go until COP26 in Glasgow, the United Nations' climate change conference. We're often scrolling through images of extreme weather and hearing about endangered animals and it can all take a toll on our mental health. Experts are calling this eco-anxiety, or climate anxiety, so what can we do to help our own wellbeing? Keep swiping for some simple solutions and we want to see your suggestions in the comments below.

Description:
Guardian Grange aims to use nature to help veterans cope with trauma, post-traumatic stress disorder and other issues that come with transitioning back to civilian life. The nonprofit organization not only provides a safety net for veterans, but also teaches them about conservation, sustainability and regenerative agriculture while leveraging skills honed over years in the military.

One of the group‚Äôs first major initiatives is to help construct a preserve for Western monarch butterflies, a pollinator species that has been pushed to the brink of extinction in recent years due to habitat loss, pesticide use and¬†climate change.

The organization converted part of a 206-acre ranch into the so-called¬†West Marin Monarch Sanctuary, where members placed around 100 plants and built a fence to protect it.

"The biggest thing I've noticed about trauma and people going through the process of healing is that the strongest medicine is just being around other people," Guardian Grange founder and former Navy SEAL Mark Matzeldelaflor said. "I want to create a space for healing, but even beyond that, the creation of better ways of life."

Read more at the link in our bio.

üì∏ @claramokriphoto / @nbcnewsart

Description:
Scientists are warning politicians immersed in climate change policy not to forget that the world is also in the middle of a plastic waste crisis.

They fear that so much energy is being spent on emissions policy that tackling plastic pollution will be sidelined.

Plastic pollution and climate change are intertwined, making each other worse, according to a scientific paper from the Zoological Society of London (ZSL) and Bangor University.

Manufacturing plastic items adds to greenhouse gas emissions, while extreme weather such as floods and typhoons associated with a heating planet will disperse and worsen plastic pollution.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the impact of plastic pollution.

(üì∑ Getty Images)

#ClimateChange #Plastic #PlasticPollution #Environment #BBCNews
ImageText: BBC NEWS Don't sideline plastic problem, nations urged

Description:
Fungi, parasites, root rot: Climate change is increasing the risk of trees weakening and dying. Falling trees have increased power outages nationwide, which threaten public health and safety.‚Å†
‚Å†
Igor Lacan, horticulture adviser for the University of California Cooperative Extension, says of the local acacias in Oakland, California, "We have never seen the sort of mass mortality that we're seeing now."‚Å†
‚Å†
Climate change has stoked a host of threats to trees, not just in California but across the country. Extreme storms, droughts, disease and insects are stressing and killing trees, and these trees pose a growing threat of wildfires and to grid reliability, many large utilities say. ‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
Humanity needs to "grow up" and deal with the issue of climate change, British Prime Minister Boris Johnson told world leaders at the United Nations General Assembly in New York on Wednesday. Johnson, a last-minute addition to the speakers' list that day, slammed the world's inadequate response to the climate crisis and urged humanity to "listen to the warnings of the scientists," pointing to the Covid-19 pandemic as "an example of gloomy scientists being proved right." 

(üì∏: Photo by Eduardo Munoz - Pool/Getty Images)
ImageText: "We trash our habitats, again and again, with the inductive reasoning that we've gotten away with it so far, and therefore, we'll get away with it again. My friends, the adolescence of humanity is coming to an end and must come to an end." CNN UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson Speaking on climate change at the UNGA

Description:
Air pollution is even more dangerous than previously thought, the World Health Organization has warned.

It says air pollution is on a par with smoking and unhealthy eating,¬†with¬†an estimated seven million people die prematurely each year from diseases linked to it.

The WHO is urging its 194 member states to cut emissions and take action on climate change, ahead of the¬†COP26 climate conference¬†later this year.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about COP26 Summit and what is being done to curb air pollution.

(üì∑ Getty Images, Reuters)

#ClimateChange #AirPollution #BBCNews

Description:
Large crowds of people gathered in Washington, D.C., on Tuesday to campaign for immigration and climate reform. 

Protesters were demanding Congress to ensure a pathway to citizenship that stays within the budget reconciliation package, investments in the care economy and green infrastructure that will fight climate change, one grassroots immigrant advocacy organization said.

Description:
The government has won a court ruling to stop the climate change action group, Insulate Britain, from protesting on the M25.‚Å†
‚Å†
Over 200 protesters from the campaign group Insulate Britain have been arrested after they shut down parts of London's M25 motorway five times in just over a week.‚Å†
‚Å†
The High Court injunction means that activists will face contempt of court with possible imprisonment if they continue blocking roads.‚Å†
‚Å†
The group want the government to commit to providing insulation for 29 million homes by 2030, and all social housing by 2025.‚Å†
‚Å†
Transport Secretary Grant Shapps wrote on Twitter: "Invading a motorway is reckless & puts lives at risk. I asked National Highways to seek an injunction against M25 protestors which a judge granted last night. Effective later today, activists will face contempt of court with possible imprisonment if they flout."
ImageText: Motorway protesters face jail threat INSU BRIT @channel4news

Description:
Die Weltgesundheitsorganisation hat neue Leitlinien zur Luftqualit√§t ver√∂ffentlicht und empfiehlt deutlich strengere Grenzwerte. Zur Begr√ºndung verweist sie auf neue Erkenntnisse zu den gesundheitssch√§dlichen Folgen.

Die bislang g√ºltigen Empfehlungen der WHO sind bereits 15 Jahre alt. In dem neuen Papier b√ºndelt sie nach eigener Aussage seither hinzugewonnene wissenschaftliche Erkenntnisse zum Zusammenhang zwischen Luftqualit√§t und gesundheitlichen Folgen. So liege inzwischen eine eindeutige Evidenz vor, dass sich die negativen gesundheitlichen Auswirkungen von Luftverschmutzung bei noch niedrigeren Konzentrationen als bisher angenommen zeigten. Neben Stickstoffdioxid und Feinstaub sind in den Empfehlungen auch Ozon, Schwefeldioxid und Kohlenmonoxid aufgef√ºhrt.

Description:
New Jersey's Atlantic white cedar forests are turning from green to a pale white, a sign of creeping sea levels and more frequent superstorms.‚Å†
‚Å†
Along much of the Eastern Seaboard, the once-healthy coastal woodlands are dwindling rapidly ‚Äî to the extent that if the rate of decline continues, these forested wetlands will reach the ‚Äúpoint of no return within the century,‚Äù according to University of Virginia and Duke University researchers focused on studying the ecosystems.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúTo be able to look at these forests and see that this is a direct result from climate change is frightening,‚Äù says Kristin Meistrell, a Stewardship Project director for the New Jersey Audubon Society, which focuses on environmental awareness and conservation.‚Å†
‚Å†
Read more on this story at the link in the bio.‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
The global production of food is responsible for a third of all planet-heating gases emitted by human activity, a major new study has found.

Meanwhile, the report revealed that use of animals for meat causes 60% of this pollution, which is twice that of plant-based foods.

The entire system of food production, such as the use of farming machinery, spraying of fertilizer and transportation of products, causes 17.3bn metric tonnes of greenhouse gases a year, according to the research. This enormous release of gases that fuel the climate crisis is more than double the entire emissions of the US and represents 35% of all global emissions, researchers said.

‚ÄúThe emissions are at the higher end of what we expected, it was a little bit of a surprise,‚Äù said Atul Jain, a climate scientist at the University of Illinois and co-author of the paper, published in Nature Food. ‚ÄúThis study shows the entire cycle of the food production system, and policymakers may want to use the results to think about how to control greenhouse gas emissions.‚Äù

The raising and culling of animals for food is far worse for the climate than growing and processing fruits and vegetables for people to eat, the research found, confirming previous findings on the outsized impact that meat production, particularly beef, has on the environment.

Source for second slide: Xu, et al., 2021, ‚ÄúGlobal greenhouse gas emissions from animal-based foods are twice those of plant-based foods‚Äù

Via @guardian_us

#environment #foodproduction #science #food #animals #meat

Lo han demostrado ahora de nuevo. Y es por eso que volveremos a las calles ". El evento del 24 de septiembre , organizado por #FridaysForFuture, espera incorporar miles de manifestaciones clim√°ticas en ciudades de todo el mundo. El objetivo es mostrar que la crisis clim√°tica no ha disminuido durante la pandemia del Covid-19. ‚ÄúHa sido un a√±o y medio muy extra√±o debido a la pandemia, pero por supuesto que nuestra crisis clim√°tica no ha desaparecido‚Äù, dijo. Es incluso m√°s urgente ahora que antes". ¬øQu√© te parece? ¬øParticipar√°s? üëÄüëá

Description:
South Korean K-pop stars BTS spoke at the United Nations this morning as part of the Sustainable Development Goals conference, which focuses on climate change, poverty, inequality and how the pandemic has affected these and other global priorities.

The seven band members, who are all in their 20s, talked optimistically about how life can return to normal after the pandemic.

‚ÄúToday, people in their teens and early 20s are being referred to as COVID‚Äôs 'Lost Generation,'‚Äù said Kim Namjoon, who goes by the stage name RM. ‚ÄúThat they've lost their way at a time they need the most diverse opportunities. But are they lost just because the path they tread can‚Äôt be seen by grown-up eyes?" 

‚ÄúThere will be choices we make that may not be perfect, but that does not mean there will be nothing we can do. That‚Äôs what I think,‚Äù added Min Yoongi, who goes by the stage name SUGA.

One of these choices that the band was referring to is vaccination. 
 
‚ÄúVaccinations were sort of a ticket to meeting our fans waiting for us and to being able to stand here before you today just like we said in our message today. We too are able to do the things we are able to do right now,‚Äù Namjoon said. 

To close their speech, the band played a video performance of their song ‚ÄúPermission To Dance,‚Äù which was filmed in an empty Assembly Hall where the U.N. delegates are meeting.
ImageText: BTS ADDRESSES THE U.N. GENERAL ASSEMBLY September 20, 2021 [JIN] There were times during the past two years when I, too, felt bewildered and troubled.

¬ªAlles ist drin¬´, lautet ein gr√ºner Wahlkampfslogan. Alles, das hie√ü: st√§rkste Partei, neue Volkspartei, das Kanzleramt, die gr√ºne Wende, ein anderes Land.

Ein bisschen verr√ºckt klang das immer, doch im April, da sah es wirklich aus, als k√∂nnte es klappen: 30 Prozent f√ºr die Gr√ºnen, die Union abgeschlagen bei 23, die SPD bei 15. Nicht mal f√ºnf Monate ist das her.

Es war eine historische Chance f√ºr die Gr√ºnen. Die SPD steckte in ihrer gr√∂√üten Krise der Nachkriegsgeschichte, die CDU im Bruderkampf mit der CSU um den richtigen Kandidaten, schwer besch√§digt auch noch durch h√§ssliche Geschichten von Gier und Selbstbezogenheit, eine Partei im Maskenfilz. Und die beliebte Kanzlerin stellte sich nicht zur Wiederwahl.

Viele im Land schienen offen f√ºr gr√ºne Ideen zu sein, mittlerweile nimmt die breite Masse den Klimawandel als unmittelbare Bedrohung wahr, auch wegen des Drucks von Fridays for Future. Ein gro√ües Umdenken hat begonnen, selbst in der Wirtschaft. Und Regierungserfahrung k√∂nnen die Gr√ºnen vorweisen, in den L√§ndern sind sie an zehn Koalitionen beteiligt. Eine gr√ºne Kanzlerin war damals, im April, pl√∂tzlich nicht undenkbar.

Umfragen sind keine Wahlergebnisse, aber sie liefern Hinweise. Und die Gr√ºnen liegen jetzt bei 15 bis 17 Prozent. Seit April ist es konsequent nach unten gegangen. Es war ein Sinkflug ‚Äì oder besser: ein Absturz. Wie konnte das passieren? Die SPIEGEL-Titelstory. Den Text lesen Sie bei SPIEGEL+, den Link teilen wir in der Story.

Von Vulkanausbr√ºchen wei√ü man, dass kleine Partikel in der Atmosph√§re die Erde betr√§chtlich k√ºhlen k√∂nnen.

Der kanadische Physiker David Keith und der deutsche Chemiker Frank Keutsch erforschen die M√∂glichkeiten und Gefahren des solaren Geoengineerings. Beide arbeiten an der Harvard-University im Solar Geoengineering Research Program.

Wie genau solares Geoengineering funktioniert, welche Schwierigkeiten es bei der Umsetzung der Feldexperimente gibt und welche Risiken die Methode hat, h√∂ren Sie in unserem Dlf-Podcast "Deep Science".

Description:
Climate change activists have returned to their protest on the M25 as rush hour traffic builds.

Insulate Britain protestors are set to attempt to block the roads for the fourth time since they took action to disrupt the major motorway's traffic last week.

The group are demanding the government insulate every home in the UK, beginning with social housing, by 2030.

Protesters have been pictured sitting at a roadside junction near Rickmansworth, Hertfordshire, on the outskirts of London.

And Hertfordshire Police said officers were called at 8.12am Monday to reports of protestors near J18 at Chorleywood.

Description:
Scientists have created the whitest paint in the world. 

Even better? It could eliminate the need for air conditioning.

‚ÄúWhen we started this project about seven years ago, we had saving energy and fighting climate change in mind,‚Äù said Xiulin Ruan, a professor of mechanical engineering at Purdue.

The idea was to make a paint that would reflect sunlight away from a building, researchers said. 

The paint reflects 98.1% of solar radiation while also emitting infrared heat. Because the paint absorbs less heat from the sun than it emits, a surface coated with this paint is cooled below the surrounding temperature without consuming power.

Using this new paint to cover a roof area of about 1,000 square feet could result in a cooling power of 10 kilowatts. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs more powerful than the air conditioners used by most houses,‚Äù Ruan said.

Photo courtesy of Purdue University/Jared Pike

Description:
The base of the world's largest tree has been wrapped in a flame-resistant blanket, in an attempt to save it from wildfires raging through California.‚Å†
‚Å†
The General Sherman Tree, located in a national park in the Sierra Nevada, was covered in an aluminium wrapping that can withstand intense heat for short periods.‚Å†
‚Å†
In Sequoia National Park's Giant Forest some other large sequoias, the Giant Forest Museum and other buildings were wrapped for protection against the possibility of intense flames.‚Å†
‚Å†
Historic drought and heatwaves linked to climate change have made wildfires harder to fight in the American West.‚Å†
‚Å†
The wildfires are among the latest in a long summer of blazes that have scorched nearly 3,550 square miles in California and destroyed hundreds of homes.‚Å†

.
SPD-Kanzlerkandidat und Bundesfinanzminister Olaf Scholz mahnte angesichts der Forderung der Gr√ºnen und von Markus S√∂der nach einem Kohleausstieg bis 2030 dagegen zu Realismus. 
.
Priorit√§t habe ein entschiedener Ausbau der Versorgung Deutschlands mit erneuerbaren Energien, sagte Scholz im Deutschlandfunk. Schon im ersten Jahr m√ºsse eine neue Regierung ‚Äûsofort alle Gesetze √§ndern, damit wir auch rechtzeitig fertig werden mit dem Ausbau der erneuerbaren Energien, sonst werden n√§mlich alle Pl√§ne, die wir gefasst haben, nichts werden‚Äú.

Description:
¬øPor qu√© han ense√±ado a ir al ba√±o a estas vacas de una granja alemana?

Una granja alemana ha llevado a cabo una curiosa iniciativa para intentar que su ganado produzca menos gases contaminantes.

De esta manera, en lugar de hacer sus necesidades en cualquier lado lo hacen en una zona espec√≠fica donde se recogen sus residuos y se les da un tratamiento espec√≠fico. 

El amon√≠aco producido en los desechos de las vacas no contribuye directamente al cambio clim√°tico, pero cuando se filtra en el suelo los microbios lo convierten en √≥xido nitroso, el tercer gas de efecto invernadero m√°s importante despu√©s del metano y el di√≥xido de carbono. 

La agricultura es la mayor fuente de emisiones de amon√≠aco, y la ganader√≠a representa m√°s de la mitad de esa contribuci√≥n.

La idea es de un equipo internacional de investigadores del Instituto de Investigaci√≥n de Biolog√≠a de Animales de Granja (FBN) en Alemania y de la Universidad de Auckland (Nueva Zelanda).

Para ense√±ar a los terneros a hacer sus necesidades, los investigadores idearon el entrenamiento "MooLoo" que b√°sicamente consist√≠a en recompensar a los terneros cuando orinaban en la letrina y en conseguir que asociasen el hecho de orinar fuera de la letrina con una experiencia desagradable.

Homero G√≥mez fue el primero de los 30 ambientalistas asesinados en M√©xico el a√±o pasado. En Colombia fueron 65 y, en todo el mundo, se lleg√≥ a la cifra r√©cord de 227.

Los m√°s atacados son los pueblos ind√≠genas que defienden sus tierras de la explotaci√≥n forestal o minera, la agroindustria o de los megaproyectos.

Description:
Aparece muerto a orillas del Mediterr√°neo un misterioso 'pez cerdo' que gru√±e al salir del agua ¬∑ La naturaleza est√° llena de criaturas poco conocidas que llaman nuestra atenci√≥n, muchas de ellas en peligro de extinci√≥n debido a las consecuencias del cambio clim√°tico. En Italia ha aparecido un tibur√≥n √°spero angular (Oxynotus centrina), m√°s conocido como ‚Äúpez cerdo‚Äù por la forma de su hocico y porque gru√±e al salir del agua, que no se deja ver con frecuencia. Su aparici√≥n en la isla italiana de Elba, en el Mediterr√°neo no muy lejos de la Toscana, el pasado 3 de septiembre pill√≥ por sorpresa a todos los presentes, que en la mayor√≠a de los casos estaban viendo la especie por primera vez. Es rechoncho, tiene la cabeza peque√±a y una aleta prominente en el dorso. Su color var√≠a seg√∫n la zona donde vive, entre gris oscuro y pardo, y no suele superar los 250 cent√≠metros de largo. A pesar de su apariencia inofensiva, el pez cerdo es en realidad un tibur√≥n. Se alimenta principalmente de huevos de otros animales que habitan las profundidades marinas, puesto que nada aproximadamente en los 200 metros bajo la superficie, aunque se han llegado a ver a 800 metros de profundidad.

#Tibur√≥n #PezCerdo #Naturaleza #Mediterr√°neo #PeligroDeExtinci√≥n

Description:
A group of scientists and adventure athletes are working to unravel the mysteries hidden in vast glacier caves around the world.

@jason_gulley_science, an associate professor of geology at the University of South Florida and an environment, science and expedition photographer, has been studying glacial caves since 2004. He has traveled to Alaska, Greenland, Nepal and Svalbard to study the caves ‚Äî exploring them and learning their secrets.

In 2018, Gulley teamed up with Will Gadd, one of the world‚Äôs top professional ice climbers, who wanted to make an expedition film that focused attention on climate change. Together they explored the one place Gulley had yet to explore: the inside of the Greenland ice sheet.

‚ÄúHaving worked in so many different glacier caves, I thought I had them figured out,‚Äù Gulley writes for @nytimestravel. ‚ÄúBut as I dangled in the middle of that massive, icy shaft in the Greenland ice sheet, perplexed by its sheer size, I realized that glacier caves still held surprises for me, and that there were more mysteries left to solve.‚Äù

Tap the link in our bio to read more about these icy labyrinths and how scientists are working to understand them. Photos by @jason_gulley_science

Description:
The spotted lanternfly (Lycorma delicatula), an invasive pest from Asia, arrived in the U.S. seven years ago and in New York City last year. The insects zealously feed on the sap of more than 70 plant species, leaving them susceptible to disease and destruction from other natural antagonists, threatening to set back the fight against climate change. ‚Å£
‚Å£
They immediately landed on the Most Wanted list of local environmentalists, who have brought a General Patton-ish energy to the project of expunging it. There are no natural predators that go after them and no organic pesticides to shut down their operation, so if you see one, ‚Äúsquish it,‚Äù said Ronnit Bendavid-Val, the director of horticulture at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs the message.‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£
In Pennsylvania, the issue is taken so seriously that the state issued a Spotted Lanternfly Order of Quarantine and Treatment, which imposes fines and even potential criminal penalties on anyone who intentionally moves the bug, at any stage of its life, from one sort of location to another via ‚Äúrecreational vehicles, tractors, mowers, grills‚Äù as well as ‚Äútarps, mobile homes, tile, stone, deck boards‚Äù or ‚Äúfire pits.‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£
New York State‚Äôs Department of Agriculture, concerned about the lanternfly‚Äôs affinity for grapes and all the resulting danger posed to vineyards in the Finger Lakes and on Long Island, would ask you to go beyond combat and perform reconnaissance. It would like you to collect a specimen when you come across one, put it in a bag and freeze it, or put it in a jar and kill it, then write to the agency providing additional details about your sighting, pointing out the ‚Äústreet address and ZIP code, intersecting roads, landmarks, or GPS coordinates,‚Äù according to the website.‚Å£
‚Å£
Tap the link in our bio to read more about the spotted lanternfly and how to help eradicate it. Photo by @dave_sanders‚Å£
ImageText: If You See This Beautiful Insect, Please Kill It

Description:
The Eastern Barred Bandicoot has been brought back from the brink of extinction.‚Å†
‚Å†
The status of the marsupial has changed from ‚Äúextinct in the wild‚Äù to ‚Äúendangered‚Äù -  a first for Australian wildlife.‚Å†
‚Å†
The bandicoot‚Äôs population shrank to just 150 animals in the wild in 1989.‚Å†
‚Å†
The population was nearly wiped out due to habitat destruction, as well as predators like foxes and cats.‚Å†
‚Å†
Volunteers and government agencies ran captive breeding programs, reintroducing the population to national parks and reserves - some had the addition of guard dogs to keep away foxes.‚Å†
‚Å†
The population of the Eastern Barred Bandicoot is now at an estimated 1,500.‚Å†
‚Å†
The Victoria‚Äôs Minister for Energy, Environment and Climate Change Lily D‚ÄôAmbrosio said: ‚ÄúThis success is due to the efforts of every member of the recovery team.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúCommunity volunteers have played a big role at many of the reintroduction sites, helping check fences, count bandicoots and remove weeds and pests.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Australia has the worst mammal extinction rate of any country in the world, according to World Wildlife Fund Australia.
ImageText: Bandicoot saved from brink of extinction @channel4news

Description:
Can you see the resemblance?

The cultural icon @rupaulofficial has become the first drag queen to be forever enshrined as a soldier fly.

The RuPaul fly is part of a new Australian genus named Opaluma (from the Latin words for opal and thorn), because they look like ‚Äúlittle gems buzzing around the forest floor‚Äù and have a distinctive thorn tucked under their abdomen.

It is 50th species to be named by @csirogram entomologist Bryan Lessard. A decade ago, the first insect he named after a pop culture icon was the Beyonc√© fly ‚Äì Scaptia beyonceae, in 2011.

At the time, it caused quite a stir, and was ‚Äúfrowned upon‚Äù by some taxonomists, but @bry_the_fly_guy said the growing naming practice had helped threatened species gain attention in response to environmental threats such as climate change.

Lessard said naming the soldier fly Opaluma rupaul came as an ‚Äúobvious decision‚Äù.

‚ÄúI was watching a lot of RuPaul‚Äôs Drag Race while examining the species and I know it would challenge RuPaul on the runway serving fierce looks,‚Äù Lessard said.

‚ÄúIt has a costume of shiny metallic rainbow colours, and it has legs for days. I think once (Ru) sees the fly she‚Äôll realise it‚Äôs quite fierce and hopefully appreciate the name.‚Äù

He hopes CSIRO's work will encourage citizen scientists and conservationists to help to monitor wildlife and insects, part of a national push for scientists to document and name every Australian species.

‚ÄúWe really need to encourage next generation to help us name and describe and protect our unique biodiversity in Australia.‚Äù

Follow @guardianaustralia for more.

#rupaul #drag #dragqueen #culturalicon #fly #flies #insects #insectspecies #species #australianwildife #wildlife #conservation #preservation #environment #australia #CSIRO
ImageText: 'Rainbow colours and legs for days' Fly species named after drag star RuPaul The Opaluma rupaul soldier flies have been describedas 'little gems buzzing around the forest floor'.

Description:
üêÆüêÑ Aunque el amon√≠aco de los desechos de las vacas no contribuye directamente al #cambioclim√°tico, cuando se filtra en el suelo se convierte en √≥xido nitroso, el tercer gas de efecto invernadero m√°s contaminante. Para evitar este da√±o indirecto, en una granja de #Alemania han ense√±ado a las vacas a ir al ba√±o.

El objetivo es simple: evitar que se acumulen y propaguen por el suelo los residuos de los desechos de las vacas, heces y orina que combinados generan amon√≠aco, un gas que contamina el suelo y los cursos de agua locales.

El amon√≠aco producido en los desechos de las vacas no contribuye directamente al cambio clim√°tico, pero cuando se filtra en el suelo los microbios lo convierten en √≥xido nitroso, el tercer gas de efecto invernadero m√°s importante despu√©s del metano y el di√≥xido de carbono. La agricultura es la mayor fuente de emisiones de amon√≠aco, y la ganader√≠a representa m√°s de la mitad de esa contribuci√≥n.

Description:
Las espectaculares im√°genes de Marte que ha compartido la NASA.

La NASA captur√≥ la primera foto de Marte en 1965. Desde entonces, los avances tecnol√≥gicos han permitido revelar miles de centenares de im√°genes que han contribuido a descubrir la fascinante historia del planeta rojo. Ahora, un equipo de t√©cnicos especializados de la NASA ha conseguido remasterizar y ampliar unas espectaculares im√°genes de Marte capturadas por varios veh√≠culos -como el Opportunity o el Perseverance- mientras se desplazan por la superficie del planeta rojo. 

Todas las im√°genes est√°n disponibles p√∫blicamente en la p√°gina web de la NASA. Estas son algunas de las m√°s impresionantes. 

1. Un campo de dunas de arena ocupa este cr√°ter helado de 5 kil√≥metros de di√°metro en las latitudes m√°s altas de las llanuras del norte de Marte.

2 . El cr√°ter Meridianum Plani, conocido como la llanura ecuatorial de Marte.

3. El Perseverance de la NASA se dirige hacia la superficie de Marte a medida que va descendiendo a trav√©s de la atm√≥sfera.

4. El Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter (MRO) de la NASA observ√≥ unas dunas de arena en las regiones polares del norte de Marte.

5. No es muy com√∫n ver cr√°teres en colinas empinadas porque las rocas que caen cuesta abajo pueden da√±arlos.

6. La capa de hielo de Marte es como un pastel en el que cada capa cuenta una historia. En este caso, la historia del cambio clim√°tico en Marte.

7. Dunas de arena en Noctis Labyrinthyus, una regi√≥n muy fracturada en el extremo occidental del Valles Marineris.

8. Una roca originada hace m√°s de 3 mil millones de a√±os.

9. La regi√≥n de Nili Fossae, ubicada en el borde noroeste de la cuenca de Isidis, es una de las regiones m√°s coloridas de Marte. Esta regi√≥n es muy antigua.

10. HiRISE ha sido testigo de muchos cambios durante los √∫ltimos diez a√±os, incluidos cientos de nuevos cr√°teres formados por impactos continuos.

üì∏ NASA

‚ö†Ô∏èLos osos polares caen cada vez m√°s en la endogamia y crece el riesgo de la superviviencia de la especie, por culpa de la crisis clim√°tica

Un equipo de cient√≠ficos observ√≥ que las poblaciones de osos polares estudiadas en Svalbard, el archipi√©lago noruego en el mar de Barents, ten√≠an hasta un 10% de p√©rdida de diversidad gen√©tica durante los √∫ltimos 20 a√±os, lo que se correlacion√≥ con una "r√°pida desaparici√≥n del hielo marino del √Årtico", seg√∫n un estudio publicado el mi√©rcoles en Royal Society Journals. 

A medida que el hielo se fue derritiendo, el h√°bitat de los osos polares se fragment√≥ y creci√≥ r√°pidamente el aislamiento gen√©tico y la endogamia debido a la reducci√≥n del contacto con los osos polares desde el exterior, explican. Simo Maduna, el autor del estudio del Instituto Noruego de Investigaci√≥n de Bioeconom√≠a, explic√≥ que los resultados fueron "alarmantes" y "sorprendentes".

La especie est√° "en peligro" como resultado de la endogamia, ya que podr√≠a afectar el estado f√≠sico y la salud de la especie y provocar una disminuci√≥n a√∫n mayor de las poblaciones, explic√≥ Maduna. La falta de diversidad gen√©tica tambi√©n podr√≠a eventualmente conducir a la incapacidad de la especie para producir descendencia f√©rtil o resistir enfermedades, agreg√≥. 

Los osos polares son aut√≥ctonos del √Årtico y son una especie dependiente del hielo, que cada vez es menor por culpa del calentamiento global. Un estudio de 2020 publicado en Nature Climate Change apunta a que los osos polares podr√≠an extinguirse para el 2100 si el hielo del √Årtico contin√∫a derriti√©ndose al ritmo previsto.

üì∏ Un oso polar juega con el hielo en el archipi√©lago Franz Josef Land #crisisclim√°tica #osopolares #artico #calentamientoglobal

De esta forma pretenden que en el futuro el que el gigante de la edad de hielo con colmillos sea restaurado a su h√°bitat natural üôå Los esfuerzos recibieron un gran impulso el lunes con el anuncio de una inversi√≥n de $ 15 millones de d√≥lares.
