Description:
Una empresa estadounidense especializada en gen√©tica anunci√≥ este lunes que busca ser pionera en la "desextinci√≥n" de especies animales y "recuperar" al mamut lanudo de la tundra √°rtica, desaparecido hace miles de a√±os, para combatir el cambio clim√°tico y "sanar" la Tierra.

Colossal, cofundada por los empresarios y cient√≠ficos Ben Lamm y George Church, ha recaudado 15 millones de d√≥lares de capital para un proyecto que pretende crear, mediante el sistema de edici√≥n gen√©tica CRISPR, un "h√≠brido elefante-mamut" que pueda sobrevivir en el √Årtico, seg√∫n dijo en un comunicado.

"Nunca antes ha podido la humanidad aprovechar el poder de esta tecnolog√≠a para reconstruir ecosistemas, sanar nuestra Tierra y preservar su futuro a trav√©s de la repoblaci√≥n de animales extintos", indic√≥ Lamm, fundador de conocidas empresas como Hypergiant y que es consejero delegado de Colossal. 

La firma aprovecha "el progreso exponencial que se ha hecho en tecnolog√≠as de lectura y escritura de ADN y lo aplica a problemas ic√≥nicos de conservaci√≥n ecol√≥gica y secuestro de carbono", agreg√≥ Church, profesor de Gen√©tica en Harvard y experto mundial que ha contribuido a descubrimientos en este campo.

As√≠, el primer candidato a diputado nacional por la coalici√≥n La Libertad Avanza, Javier Milei, encendi√≥ la campa√±a legislativa y su discurso antiestablishment termin√≥ por dar la sorpresa en las primarias argentinas del domingo, despu√©s de convertirse en la tercera fuerza m√°s votada en la ciudad de Buenos Aires, abriendo una nueva opci√≥n pol√≠tica radical detr√°s de la oposici√≥n y el oficialismo.¬†

Contrario a las cuarentenas, el aborto y pol√≠ticas medioambientales y a favor de la eliminaci√≥n de la moneda argentina, el porte de armas y la legalizaci√≥n de drogas, el economista busca instalarse como una figura polarizadora de cara a las elecciones de noviembre. 

Autodenominado un ‚Äúlibertario‚Äù y ‚Äúanarcocapitalista‚Äù, Milei utiliza su histrionismo para defender la urgencia de un cambio profundo en la econom√≠a argentina,¬†rechazando un sistema impositivo y defendiendo una desregulaci√≥n del sistema financiero, la disminuci√≥n del gasto p√∫blico y la reducci√≥n de los impuestos, porque ‚Äúson una r√©mora de la esclavitud‚Äù, as√≠ como la suspensi√≥n del funcionamiento del Banco Central.

Seguidor de Jair Bolsonaro, Donald Trump y Vox, el partido espa√±ol de extrema derecha, su discurso frontal le gener√≥ denuncias por ‚Äúdiscriminaci√≥n contra los discapacitados‚Äù y por violencia de g√©nero al tratar a una periodista de ‚Äúburra‚Äù.

Description:
How has the climate crisis affected your outlook on having kids?

Four in 10 young people around the world are hesitant to have children as a result of global heating, and fear that governments are doing too little to prevent climate catastrophe, a poll in 10 countries has found.

Nearly six in 10 young people, aged 16 to 25, were very or extremely worried about climate change, according to the scientific study - the biggest yet on climate anxiety and young people.

A similar number said governments were not protecting them, the planet, or future generations, and felt betrayed by the older generation and governments.

Young climate activists said feelings of anxiety over the climate were now widespread among today‚Äôs youth.

Mitzi Tan, 23, from the Philippines, said: ‚ÄúI grew up being afraid of drowning in my own bedroom. Society tells me that this anxiety is an irrational fear that needs to be overcome, one that meditation and healthy coping mechanisms will ‚Äòfix‚Äô.‚Äù At its root, our climate anxiety comes from this deep-set feeling of betrayal because of government inaction. To truly address our growing climate anxiety, we need justice.‚Äù

The poll of about 10,000 young people covered Australia, Brazil, Finland, France, India, Nigeria, the Philippines, Portugal, the UK and the US. It was paid for by the campaigning organisation Avaaz.

Three-quarters of those who took part agreed with the statement ‚Äúthe future is frightening‚Äù, and more than half felt they would have fewer opportunities than their parents.

Nearly half reported feeling distressed or anxious about the climate in a way that was affecting their daily lives and functioning.

Earlier this month, Unicef found that children and young people around the world were bearing the brunt of the climate crisis, with 1 billion children at ‚Äúextreme risk‚Äù from the impacts of climate breakdown.

#climatecrisis #climatechange #environment #nature #sustainability #globalwarming #savetheplanet #climate #ecofriendly #climateaction #earth
ImageText: Four in 10 young people G scared of having children due to climate crisis

Description:
This summer has seen forest fires across southern Europe amid record heat waves, which scientists say were fueled by climate change. The once-idyllic Greek island of Evia was the epicenter of this in the Mediterranean basin and lost much of its forests, the island's source of livelihood and joy. Members of the community reflected on their losses with NPR.

Tap the link in our bio for more. (Images: @demetriosioannou ‚Ä¢ Demetrios Ioannou for NPR)

1. Zoe Chalasti examines the remains of Noufaro (Water Lily), the pastry shop in the village of Rovies in northern Evia that she owned with her husband for 38 years. The recent fires destroyed it, and she will not rebuild. "We can't afford it," she says.
2. Kostas Christodoulou, 70, says he crouched in a small cave as catastrophic fires swept through the forest where his sheep were grazing near his village of Kourkouloi. Most of his sheep perished. "Everyone thought I was dead," he says. "I survived but this village may not."
3. Stathis Steffos hugs his 11-year-old son, Kostas, outside their burned home in the village of Rovies. Kostas used a makeshift broom to help his father beat back flames as they rescued the family sheep. "But he cried when he saw what was happening to us," Stathis Steffos says of his son. "He saw it firsthand."
4. Konstantina Tsamouras, 9, holds her favorite stuffed animals at her home in the village of Limni in northern Evia. Now that the forest where she used to play has burned, she worries that it will be even hotter in the village. The heat already makes her feel "like my brain's crazy, with like 2,000 layers of blankets on me."
5. "This used to be paradise. Now it's hell," says pine resin producer Giorgos Anagnostou, 38, standing on top of a mountain near his village of Kourkouloi in northern Evia. The fire wiped out the forest's pine trees and his livelihood.
6. Catastrophic fires last month destroyed a large swath of forest in the north of Evia, Greece's second-largest island. It also burned fields of olive trees.

‚Å†
In a white gown by Brother Vellies, progressive stalwart Ocasio-Cortez had the words ‚ÄúTax the rich‚Äù scrawled in bright red down the back of her dress. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Ocasio-Cortez has proposed raising the marginal tax rate to 70% for people who earn more than $10 million a year. The funds raised from such a tax increase on the very wealthy could fund public investments to combat the climate crisis, as the congresswoman has pushed. ‚Å†

Description:
Geneticists, led by Harvard Medical School's George Church, aim to bring the woolly mammoth, which disappeared 4,000 years ago, back to life. Proponents say bringing back the mammoth in an altered form could help restore the fragile Arctic tundra ecosystem, combat the climate crisis and preserve the endangered Asian elephant. However, it's a bold plan fraught with ethical issues.‚Å†
‚Å†
"Our goal is to have our first calves in the next four to six years," said tech entrepreneur Ben Lamm, who with Church has cofounded Colossal, a bioscience and genetics company to back the project.‚Å†
‚Å†
(üì∏: Jean-Marc Zaorski/Gamma-Rapho/Getty Images)
ImageText: Scientists Scier want to resurrect the woolly mammoth. They just got $15 million to make it happen CNN

Description:
Could controlling toilet habits of cows be the key to more environmentally friendly farming?

In Germany, one herd has been ‚Äúpotty-trained‚Äù in an experiment to teach calves to use a toilet area in their barn, meaning that urine could be collected and treated.

Scientists trained the cows via a system of rewards and mild punishments. When they urinated in the assigned area, they were given a sweet drink or some mashed barley, and when they relieved themselves elsewhere, they were surprised by a short blast of water from above.

Waste from cattle farms often contaminates soil and waterways and contributes to greenhouse gas emissions and the acidification of soil.

For this reason, toilet-training cattle has long been viewed as desirable, but several previous attempts have been unsuccessful.

Within a few weeks, after about 15 training sessions, 11 out of the 16 calves in the experiment had been successfully toilet-trained, according to the study published in the journal Current Biology.

‚ÄúCattle, like many other animals, are quite clever and they can learn a lot,‚Äù said Jan Langbein, an animal psychologist at the Research Institute for Farm Animal Biology (FBN) in Germany. ‚ÄúWhy shouldn‚Äôt they be able to learn how to use a toilet?‚Äù

Langbein said a future ambition would be to teach cows to also defecate in a toilet area.

The ammonia produced in cow urine doesn‚Äôt directly contribute to the climate crisis, but when it leaches into the soil, microbes convert it into nitrous oxide, which is the third most significant greenhouse gas after methane and carbon dioxide.

#cows #cow #farmanimals #farming #farm #pottytraining #toilettraining #cattlefarm #science #biology #climatecrisis #greenhousegas #nitrusoxide #methane #carbondioxide #ammonia

Description:
Climate change has had a devastating impact on Nigeria. 

Fertile lands are turning into deserts in the north, while flash floods have become more common in the south.

Nigeria‚Äôs oil industry is making the situation worse, as the practice of flaring - the burning of natural gas that is released when oil is extracted from the ground - is common, despite being illegal, and is a major source of greenhouse gases and a contributor to climate change.

Joy and her family are among two million Nigerians living within 4km of a gas flare in the country‚Äôs oil-rich south.

#Nigeria #ClimateChange #BBCNews

Aunque el amon√≠aco de los desechos de las vacas no contribuye directamente al cambio clim√°tico, cuando se filtra en el suelo se convierte en √≥xido nitroso, el tercer gas de efecto invernadero m√°s contaminante. Para evitar este da√±o indirecto, en una granja de Alemania han ense√±ado a las vacas a ir al ba√±o.

El objetivo es simple: Evitar que se acumulen y propaguen por el suelo los residuos de los desechos de las vacas, heces y orina que combinados generan amon√≠aco, un gas que contamina el suelo y los cursos de agua locales.

El amon√≠aco producido en los desechos de las vacas no contribuye directamente al cambio clim√°tico, pero cuando se filtra en el suelo los microbios lo convierten en √≥xido nitroso, el tercer gas de efecto invernadero m√°s importante despu√©s del metano y el di√≥xido de carbono. La agricultura es la mayor fuente de emisiones de amon√≠aco, y la ganader√≠a representa m√°s de la mitad de esa contribuci√≥n.

La idea es de un equipo internacional de investigadores del Instituto de Investigaci√≥n de Biolog√≠a de Animales de Granja (FBN) en Alemania y de la Universidad de Auckland (Nueva Zelanda) y los detalles se publican hoy en la revista Current Biology.

El estudio ha demostrado que las vacas pueden ser entrenadas para ir al ba√±o, lo que permite recoger y tratar los desechos, mantener el establo limpio, reducir la contaminaci√≥n del aire y crear granjas m√°s abiertas y respetuosas con los animales.

La clasificaci√≥n de incendios por generaciones se utiliza en el argot de los t√©cnicos de extinci√≥n para categorizar los distintos tipos de fuego y mostrar c√≥mo han evolucionado estos sucesos en el tiempo: no existen unos par√°metros cuantitativos espec√≠ficos que determinen de qu√© generaci√≥n es cada fuego, pero s√≠ unas particularidades que los hacen muy diferentes. Description:
Sally Rooney, 30, ist eine der Starautorinnen ihrer Generation. Ihre ersten beiden Romane ¬ªGespr√§che mit Freunden¬´ und ¬ªNormale Menschen¬´ handelten von jungen Erwachsenen, deren Umfeld, ihren Gedanken zur Welt und vor allem von ihrem Liebes- und Sexleben. 

Bei ihrem einzigen Deutschland-Interview zu ihrem neuen Roman ist sie aufmerksam, freundlich, atemlos, lacht oft, denkt zwischendurch vor sich hin und sagt, was sie denkt. 

Rooney, die sich als Marxistin bezeichnet, lebt noch heute in ihrem Geburtsland Irland, wo auch ihr neues Buch spielt. ¬ªSch√∂ne Welt, wo bist du¬´ erz√§hlt die Geschichte von zwei Freundinnen um die drei√üig und den beiden M√§nnern, die sie daten. Die Schriftstellerin Alice und die Redaktionsassistentin Eileen schreiben sich E-Mails, in denen sie ausf√ºhrlich philosophischen und sozialwissenschaftlichen √úberlegungen nachgehen ‚Äì und nat√ºrlich ihrem Verh√§ltnis zueinander. Irgendwann treffen sich alle vier, mehr passiert an der Oberfl√§che nicht. Alle reden gern und ausf√ºhrlich √ºber ihre Gef√ºhle, die Freundschaften sind innig, die Frauen werden beim Sex gern gedem√ºtigt ‚Äì und alle sorgen sich um den Klimawandel.

Das Interview mit Sally Rooney lesen Sie bei SPIEGEL+, den Link teilen wir in der Story.

‚Å†
Earlier this summer, protesters demonstrated against the oil company's sponsorship of its exhibition because of its contribution to the climate crisis.‚Å†
‚Å†
In July, Channel 4 News revealed that the museum had signed a gagging clause, whereby it agreed to take care not to say or do anything that would discredit or damage Shell's reputation.‚Å†
‚Å†
In a statement, the Science Museum Group said it had collected placards donated by London climate protestors "in a professional and sensitive manner".‚Å†
‚Å†
It added: "Having today been alerted to the strong feelings of a donor, and in light of all the circumstances around this request, we have decided to remove this item from display and are contacting the donor directly."‚Å†
‚Å†
The museum has not yet confirmed whether it will remove other placards from its exhibition.‚Å†
‚Å†
UKSCN campaigner Izzy Warren welcomed the Science Museum's response but said that "their refusal to say that the placard is being removed due to Shell‚Äôs involvement highlights the influence that the gagging clause in the sponsorship contract has over them."‚Å†
‚Å†
"Removing one placard is ultimately not enough; the Science Museum needs to drop Shell sponsorship,‚Äù she added.‚Å†
‚Å†
Responding to Channel 4 News' story in July, a Shell spokesperson said: ‚ÄúWe fully respect the museum‚Äôs independence. That‚Äôs why its exhibition on carbon capture matters and why we supported it. Debate and discussion ‚Äì among anyone who sees it ‚Äì are essential.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Image courtesy of Ron Fassbender‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
The United States had its hottest summer on record this year, narrowly edging out the previous milestone that was set 85 years ago during the Dust Bowl.‚Å†
‚Å†
NOAA announced that the average temperature this summer for the contiguous U.S. was 74 degrees Fahrenheit, or 2.6 degrees warmer than the long-term average. The heat record caps off a season full of extremes, with parts of the country experiencing persistent drought, wildfires, record-breaking heat waves, hurricanes and other extreme weather exacerbated by climate change.‚Å†
‚Å†
This summer beat the previous record set in 1936 by a hair, coming in at less than 0.01 degrees warmer than during the Dust Bowl year, when huge portions of the West and Great Plains were parched by severe drought.‚Å†
‚Å†
Read more at the link in our bio.‚Å†
‚Å†
üì∏ Olivier Douliery / @afpphoto
ImageText: The U.S. just had its hottest summer on record CLIMATE CI

Description: üòÆ Un estudio publicado en la revista Trends in Ecology & Evolution, revel√≥ que algunos #animales de sangre caliente est√°n desarrollando cambios en la forma de su cuerpo debido al #cambioclim√°tico. Ahora los animales poseen picos, patas y orejas m√°s grandes que les permiten regular mejor su temperatura corporal a medida que el planeta se calienta, especialmente en las aves. Los mayores cambios en el tama√±o de los ap√©ndices en m√°s de 30 animales que analizaron los investigadores, arroj√≥ que algunas especies de loros australianos son los que aumentaron el tama√±o de sus picos entre un 4% y 10% de medida desde 1871. "Significa que los animales est√°n evolucionando, pero no significa necesariamente que est√©n haciendo frente al cambio clim√°tico. Podemos ver que algunas especies han aumentado el tama√±o de sus bocas hasta ahora, pero no sabemos si podr√°n seguir el ritmo a medida que se agrave la crisis clim√°tica", dijo  Sara Ryding, investigadora de la Universidad de Deakin, Australia. Tambi√©n han experimentado cambios los ratones y musara√±as, ya que crecieron sus colas y por otra parte los elefantes han crecido sus orejas. Description:
The Barents Sea is experiencing the "fastest loss of sea ice" throughout the Arctic. Now, a new study has found the polar bears that depend on that ice are struggling to survive, and have resorted to inbreeding in an attempt to make their populations last. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Read more at the link in our bio.
ImageText: Polar bears forced to inbreed as climate change melts away Arctic ice

Description:
Thousands of homes were destroyed last year in the Almeda fire ‚Äî Oregon‚Äôs most destructive in years. So why do people stay? ‚Å£
‚Å£
‚ÄúI know the people here,‚Äù said Gladiola Garcia, whose family has been living in a string of temporary accommodations with help from relief organizations and the state government. ‚ÄúIf I go to another place I will be lost, more than I‚Äôm lost here.‚Äù ‚Å£
‚Å£
Last September, after high winds pushed flames through a drought-parched strip of southern Oregon called the Rogue Valley, razing entire communities, as many as 8,500 people found themselves suddenly homeless. A year after the Almeda fire, hundreds who are still in trailers, hotels and other temporary homes continue to grapple with the decision to stay or to leave. They have faced vast challenges in rebuilding their lives in a region where affordable homes are in short supply and the competition is fierce. Above all, as more wildfires burn across parts of the West, there‚Äôs a looming sense that more destruction is sure to come.‚Å£
‚Å£
‚Å£
The New York Times followed six families as they struggled to preserve their place in this valley. What little they still have is here, they say. It‚Äôs home.‚Å£
‚Å£
Tap the link in our bio to read their stories, and to share how climate change has upended your life. Photos by @rachelbujalski‚Å£
ImageText: (empty)

Description:
Animals around the world are having to "shapeshift" so they can deal with climate change.

Scientists say warm-blooded species are evolving to have larger beaks, legs, ears and tails to regulate body temperature as the planet warms up, as overheating can cause them die.

However, they say that this doesn‚Äôt mean the animals are coping with climate change.

This year has seen some countries record their highest temperatures in decades - with July recorded as the world's hottest month ever.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about how animals are adapting to survive the warmer planet.

(üì∑ Getty Images)

#Animals #ClimateChange #BBCNews
ImageText: (empty)

Description:
Ice floats around boats in the port in Ilulissat, Greenland. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Greenland in 2021 is experiencing one of its biggest ice-melt years in recorded history. Scientists studying the Greenland Ice Sheet observed rainfall on the highest point in Greenland for the first time ever this August. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Researchers from Denmark estimated that in July of this year enough ice melted on the Greenland Ice Sheet to cover the entire state of Florida with two inches of water. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The observations come on the heels of the recent United Nations report on global warming which stated that accelerating climate change is driving an increase in extreme weather events.

üì∏: Mario Tama / Getty Images

Description:
California is leading the world in confronting climate change. Its push toward renewable electricity is inspiring other states and countries to step up their goals. 

Meanwhile, an unregulated cottage industry of firms selling credits to corporations eager to brand as ‚Äúcarbon-neutral‚Äù is exploding in the U.S., peddling offset projects that many experts warn quite frequently are not soaking up the greenhouse gases claimed.

There is heated debate among scholars and scientists about the extent to which the state‚Äôs climate laws should be relied on to reduce ‚Äúco-pollutant‚Äù health hazards such as benzyne and nitrogen oxide at refineries.

Read more at link in bio.

Die Folgen der Klimakrise sind seit Jahren bekannt und doch passiert viel zu wenig. Jetzt dr√§ngt die Zeit: Will man die Erderw√§rmung auf 1,5 Grad Celsius begrenzen - so wie im Pariser Vertrag angestrebt - bleiben der Menschheit beim heutigen Tempo nicht einmal mehr sieben Jahre, bis sie gar kein CO‚ÇÇ mehr emittieren darf.

Aber wie das genau passieren soll, da unterscheiden sich die Konzepte zum Teil doch sehr. Was davon ist vielversprechend, welche Pl√§ne gehen nicht weit genug? Das h√∂ren Sie in der kompletten Folge unter sz.de/dasthema.

Description:
Some warm-blooded animals are experiencing shifts in their body shapes, likely as a response to the pressures of climate change, according to a study published on Tuesday in the journal Trends in Ecology & Evolution. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Animals are getting larger beaks, legs and ears that allow them to better regulate their body temperatures as the planet gets hotter, with birds particularly affected, said researcher Sara Ryding.‚Å†
‚Å†
(üì∏: Ryan Barnaby)
ImageText: Animals are 'shape shifting' in response to climate change Australian parrot species had some of the biggest shifts their beak size increased 4% to 10% on average since 1871 CNN

Description:
As President Biden visited parts of New York and New Jersey affected by Hurricane Ida, he warned Americans on Tuesday that the storm‚Äôs deadly destruction had been caused by a changing climate and that action was needed to prevent extreme weather patterns from worsening.‚Å£
‚Å£
‚ÄúClimate change is here. We‚Äôre living through it now,‚Äù Biden said in New Jersey. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre at one of those inflection points where we act, or we‚Äôre going to be in real, real trouble.‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£
In New York, Biden met with Governor Kathy Hochul, Senators Kirsten Gillibrand and Chuck Schumer, and Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, visiting a neighborhood damaged by flooding in Queens. Earlier, he attended a briefing with local leaders about the impacts of Ida in New Jersey and delivered remarks in Hillsborough Township and toured areas that were damaged by flooding.‚Å£
‚Å£
The trip gave Biden another opportunity to demonstrate his commitment to the federal government‚Äôs storm response and to build support for an infrastructure package that he has promised would help safeguard against future storms.‚Å£
‚Å£
On the same day as Biden‚Äôs visit, the White House sent Congress an ‚Äúurgent‚Äù funding request for $14 billion to aid recovery from natural disasters that occurred before Hurricane Ida and to avert a government shutdown on Oct. 1. The request forecast that billions in additional funding would be necessary to respond to Ida, and it included $6.4 billion to assist with the processing of Afghan refugees overseas and in the U.S.‚Å£
‚Å£
Tap the link in our bio to read more about Biden‚Äôs trip to New York and New Jersey. Photo by @sbmaneyphoto‚Å£

Description:
President Biden traveled to New York and New Jersey on Tuesday to survey damage from Hurricane Ida, which produced deadly flash flooding in the Northeast as the storm tore through the region last week.

Mr. Biden's visit to the two states comes against the backdrop of his administration's broader legislative push to revitalize the nation's infrastructure through a pair of spending packages.

The president told reporters before leaving the White House that he is "hoping to see the things that we're going to be able to fix permanently with the bill that we have in for infrastructure."

Description:
Warm-blooded animals are getting larger beaks, legs and ears to adapt to a hotter climate and to better regulate their temperature.

When animals overheat, birds use their beaks and mammals use their ears to disperse the warmth. Some creatures in warmer climates have historically evolved to have larger beaks or ears to get rid of heat more easily. These differences are becoming more pronounced as the climate warms.

If animals fail to control their body temperature, they can overheat and die. Beaks, which are not covered by feathers and therefore not insulated, are a site of significant heat exchange, as are ears, tails and legs in mammals if not covered by fur.

The review, published in the journal Trends in Ecology & Evolution, found that the differences are particularly pronounced in birds.

The author of the study, Sara Ryding of Deakin university, a bird researcher, said: ‚ÄúShapeshifting does not mean that animals are coping with climate change and that all is fine.

‚ÄúIt just means they are evolving to survive it ‚Äì but we‚Äôre not sure what the other ecological consequences of these changes are, or indeed that all species are capable of changing and surviving.‚Äù

While the scientists say it is difficult to pinpoint climate breakdown as the sole cause of the shapeshifting, it is what the instances studied have in common across geographical regions and across a diverse array of species.

Examples include several species of Australian parrot that have shown a 4-10% increase in bill size since 1871, positively correlated with the summer temperature each year.

Click the link in the bio to read more of Helena Horton's article.

Photo: William Robinson/Alamy

#shapeshifting #shapeshifter #adjusting #adjustment #climatecrisis #animals #birds #science #environment #bodytemperature #acclimatize #mammals

Description:
Dragonflies are moving northwards across Britain and Ireland as temperatures rise.

Experts from the British Dragonfly Society say it's an indicator of the effects of climate change.

While some dragonflies and damselflies are expanding their range, others are being driven out of their natural habitats.

Factors such as the use of pesticides, water pollution and habitat loss continue to threaten the health of dragonfly populations within species' existing ranges.

Climate change is affecting many insects with one scientific review of insect numbers in 2019 pointing to 40% of species undergoing "dramatic rates of decline" around the world.

Click the link in our bio to learn more about how dragonflies and damselflies are moving north.

üì∑ (Dave Smallshire, Iain Leach, Pam Taylor, Chris Giles/BBC)

Description:
The world's largest lizard ‚Äãis threatened with extinction as rising water levels driven by the climate crisis shrink its habitat, according to the latest ‚Äúred list‚Äù update.

The komodo dragon moves from vulnerable to endangered on the IUCN red list of threatened species.

The latest update is the first for the komodo dragon in more than 20 years. It comes after the first peer-reviewed paper on how global heating would affect the giant lizards concluded ‚Äúurgent conservation actions are required to avoid risk of extinction‚Äù.

The komodo dragon can only be found on a handful of Indonesian islands, where they live on the edge of forest or in open savannah, rarely venturing higher than 700 metres above sea level.

As well as being unable to move to higher ground, the komodo dragons‚Äô habitat is becoming increasingly fragmented by human activity, which makes populations less genetically healthy and more vulnerable.

Rising water levels are set to affect 30% of its habitat in the next 45 years.

#komododragon #lizard #conservation #endangeredspecies #endangered #globalheating #climatecrisis #Indonesia #habitat #naturalhabitat #wildlife #environment #risingsealevels

Description:
What happens after everything falls apart? The end of the Bronze Age was a moment when an entire network of ancient civilizations collapsed, leaving behind only clues to what happened. Today, scholars have pieced together a story where everything from climate change to mass migration to natural disasters played a role. What the end of the Bronze Age can teach us about avoiding catastrophe and what comes after collapse.‚Å†
‚Å†
This is the fifth and final episode of Throughline‚Äôs Movies For Your Mind series, featuring the best and most cinematic episodes in their catalog. ‚Å†

Description:
After Hurricane Katrina, an ambitious and expensive system of levees, walls, storm gates and pumps was installed around New Orleans to protect against the kind of flooding and horror that so deeply scarred the city in 2005. And when Hurricane Ida hit last week, exactly 16 years later, those hopes were largely fulfilled. The flooding was minimal.
 
But 60 miles away, in the small community of Larose, the situation was different. In William Lowe‚Äôs neighborhood, storm surge from Ida overtopped a modest levee maintained by the Lafourche Parish government near his elevated house, sending water from a nearby canal up over his floorboards. Days later, his neighborhood was still waterlogged, and he and his family were getting to and from the house by boat.
 
‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got lives destroyed down here,‚Äù Lowe said. 

In the working-class bayou country south and west of New Orleans, local government officials have been trying for decades to secure federal funding for a system similar to the one in New Orleans, to little avail. As sea levels rise and a warming ocean brings more fearsome storms, the fight over hurricane protection in Southern Louisiana is only the latest example of a growing dilemma for the United States: which places to try to save, and how to decide.
 
‚ÄúA lot of these places aren‚Äôt going to be around that much longer,‚Äù said Jesse Keenan, a professor at Tulane University who focuses on how to adapt to climate change.
 
The cost of rebuilding has skyrocketed as disasters have become more severe. Extreme weather has caused more than $450 billion in damage nationwide since 2005; the number of disasters causing more than $1 billion in damage reached 22 last year, a record. And the increasing frequency and severity of hurricanes poses another dilemma: Even if the money could be found for projects to protect places like Larose, are such efforts a good way to spend public money, especially as the need for climate resilience around the country is growing and coastlines disappear further every year? Tap the link in our bio to read more. Photos by @thecadejo.

La manifestaci√≥n pac√≠fica, que busca generar conciencia en torno a la importancia de proteger esta cuenca y la urgencia de clausurar Alto Maipo en el contexto actual de crisis clim√°tica y emergencia h√≠drica en la zona, se realiz√≥ de manera autoconvocada y cont√≥ con el apoyo  la marca de ropa outdoor Patagonia.

La cuenca del Maipo es √∫nica e invaluable y provee de una serie de servicios ecosist√©micos, entre ellos, el abastecimiento de agua al 40% de la poblaci√≥n nacional, y forma parte de uno de los 35 lugares de biodiversidad end√©mica m√°s importantes del mundo. Adem√°s, el Caj√≥n del Maipo, forma parte de la historia de muchas personas que tuvieron all√≠ su primera aventura al aire libre, es hogar de rutas inspiradoras y grandes desaf√≠os de monta√±a. Se ha demostrado que el proyecto tendr√° un alto impacto sobre el medio ambiente, poniendo en riesgo la posibilidad de que la comunidad, y las futuras generaciones, puedan disfrutar de estos paisajes y tener una conexi√≥n m√°s profunda con la naturaleza.

Description:
The death toll from floods and tornadoes in the US north-east rose past 40 on Thursday, as authorities continued to digest the full impact of the remnants of Hurricane Ida.

The storm ultimately dumped more than 9in of rain in parts of New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts and Rhode Island, and nearly as much on Staten Island in New York City.

In New York City, police said at least 13 people died, one in a car and 11 in flooded basement apartments that often serve as relatively affordable homes in one of the nation‚Äôs most expensive housing markets.

Major flooding along the Schuylkill River in Pennsylvania swamped highways, submerged cars and disrupted rail service.

Officials said at least five people died in Pennsylvania, including one killed by a falling tree and another who drowned in his car after helping his wife to escape.

In Connecticut, a state police sergeant perished after his cruiser was swept away. A 19-year-old man was killed in flooding at an apartment complex in Rockville, Maryland, police said.

New York‚Äôs resilience to flooding was under renewed scrutiny. It was the second time in recent weeks that subway stations and streets were submerged.

In a speech at the White House in Washington on Thursday, Joe Biden said: ‚ÄúThese extreme storms, and the climate crisis, are here. We must be better prepared. We need to act.‚Äù

Photos: Caitlin Ochs/Reuters + Craig Ruttle/AP + Bastiaan Slabbers/Reuters +
Gary Hershorn/Getty Images & Kena Betancur/AFP/Getty Images 

#USflooding #HurricaneIda #Flooding #Floods #ExtremeWeather #NewYork #NewJersey #Pennsylvania #Massachusetts #Hoboken #SchuylkillRiver

Description:
Ida slammed into the Louisiana coast on Sunday as a Category 4 hurricane, making it one of the strongest storms ever to make landfall in the state.

But it was in the Northeast, hundreds of miles from the Louisiana coast, that the downgraded storm toppled rainfall records, caused rivers to swell to near historic highs and spawned tornadoes in New Jersey and Pennsylvania. Climate change no doubt supercharged the storm‚Äôs broad, devastating impact in many ways.

Description:
Al menos uno de cada tres #√°rboles en estado silvestre se enfrenta a la #extinci√≥n en todo el mundo, seg√∫n las conclusiones de un reciente informe.

El reporte Estado de los √°rboles en el mundo, elaborado por Botanic Gardens Conservation International (BGCI), una organizaci√≥n con sede en #Londres, concluy√≥ que entre un tercio y la mitad de las especies de √°rboles en todo el planeta podr√≠a desaparecer.

Las especies amenazadas van desde #robles y #magnolias hasta √°rboles tropicales.

Los expertos dicen que 17.500 especies se encuentran en peligro, el doble de la cantidad de mam√≠feros, aves, anfibios y reptiles amenazados todos juntos.

Los grupos conservacionistas est√°n pidiendo esfuerzos de protecci√≥n urgentes en medio de amenazas como la deforestaci√≥n, tala y el cambio clim√°tico.

"Tenemos cerca de 60.000 especies de √°rboles en el planeta; y por primera vez sabemos cu√°les de estas especies necesitan acciones de conservaci√≥n, cu√°les son las mayores amenazas para ellas y d√≥nde se encuentran", dijo Malin Rivers, de la BGCI.

Description:
Los desastres clim√°ticos se quintuplicaron en los √∫ltimos 50 a√±os y causaron importantes da√±os, aunque la mejora en los sistemas de alerta permiti√≥ reducir el n√∫mero de muertes, inform√≥ la ONU en un informe este mi√©rcoles.

La Organizaci√≥n Meteorol√≥gica Mundial (OMM) de la ONU estudi√≥ la frecuencia, mortalidad y las p√©rdidas econ√≥micas causadas por desastres vinculados a fen√≥menos meteorol√≥gicos extremos entre 1970 y 2019.

‚ÄúEl n√∫mero de estos fen√≥menos extremos est√° aumentando. Debido al cambio clim√°tico ser√°n m√°s frecuentes y severos en muchas partes del mundo‚Äù, dijo en un comunicado el secretario general de la OMM, Petteri Taalas.

En total, se registraron m√°s de 11.000 desastres atribuidos a esos fen√≥menos extremos en todo el mundo desde 1970. Se calcula que causaron m√°s de dos millones de muertes y p√©rdidas materiales que superan los 3,64 billones de d√≥lares.

El hurac√°n Ida que golpe√≥ Luisiana y Misisipi es un ejemplo claro. Seg√∫n Taalas podr√≠a ser la cat√°strofe meteorol√≥gica m√°s cara de la historia, superando al hurac√°n Katrina en 2005, en Nueva Orleans, que cost√≥ 163.600 millones de d√≥lares.

Description:
Air pollution is cutting short the lives of billions of people by up to six years, according to a new report, making it a far greater killer than smoking, car crashes or HIV/Aids.

Coal burning is the main culprit, and India is worst affected, with the average citizen dying six years early.

China has slashed air pollution in the last seven years, but dirty air is still cutting 2.6 years from its people‚Äôs lifespan.

Fossil fuel burning is causing air pollution and the climate crisis, but nations have much greater power to cut dirty air within their own borders.

The climate crisis is now also adding to air pollution by driving wildfires, completing a vicious circle, the scientists said.

The team said recent events had illustrated the different futures possible depending on whether governments act or not.

‚ÄúAir pollution is the greatest external threat to human health on the planet, and that is not widely recognised, or not recognised with the force and vigour that one might expect,‚Äù said Prof Michael Greenstone, who developed the Air Quality Life Index (AQLI), which converts air pollution levels into their impact on life expectancy.

‚ÄúFurthermore, we‚Äôre not just letting it happen, we‚Äôre actually causing it."

He said switching to cleaner energy and enforcing air quality measures on existing power plants have cut pollution in many countries.

China began a ‚Äúwar against pollution‚Äù in 2013 and has reduced levels by 29%. This is adding an average of 1.5 years on to lives, assuming the cuts are sustained, the scientists said, and shows rapid action is possible.

#airpollution #beatairpollution #delhiairpollution #stopairpollution #airpollutionmask #airpollutionawareness #airpollutionindex #pollution #environment #climatechange #cleanair #nature #fossilfuel #climatecrisis #sustainability #globalwarming #oil #fossilfuels #climateaction #environment #climate #energy #greenhousegases #saveourearth #renewables #renewablenergy #solarpower

Description:
Faced with drought conditions and rising temperatures from climate change, California has hit many grim fire milestones in the last few years.

The Dixie fire is now the second-largest in state history and still burning out of control. The Caldor fire is much smaller but now threatens more than 33,000 homes in the Lake Tahoe Basin, an area many residents believed was fairly well protected from fires.

Read more at link in bio.
üì∏:@jason_armond
ImageText: (empty)

Description: The Caldor fire has burned about 191,000 acres as of Tuesday morning and destroyed more than 650 structures, putting much of the South Lake Tahoe Basin under an evacuation warning. Just two weeks ago, the Dixie fire, which has burned more than 770,000 acres and is currently the state's second-largest blaze on record, crossed the mountains. These wildfires are inextricably linked to human-induced climate change. Read more through the link in bio. (üì∏: Josh Edelson / AFP via Getty Images)
ImageText: BuzzFeed News THE CALDOR FIRE A Dangerous Wildfire Forced Thousands Of People To Flee Lake Tahoe, And Firefighters Are Blaming Climate Change

Description:
As the sun rose over the city of New Orleans, the streets quiet but for the crunch of detritus under foot, residents in the city‚Äôs Lower Ninth Ward awoke to assess the damage.

This neighbourhood bore some of the worst scars of Hurricane Katrina in 2005, when New Orleans‚Äôs levee system failed and submerged the Lower Ninth in a storey of water, sweeping away lives and livelihoods.

That was 16 years ago. But it played heavily on many people‚Äôs minds as they hunkered down on Sunday, the anniversary of Katrina‚Äôs impact in Louisiana, and braced for another storm.

Wesley Foster, a 74-year-old retiree and lifelong Ninth Ward resident, remembered that time vividly as he watched Ida pound the walls of the home he had rebuilt after Katrina.

He had seen news reports as the storm picked up intensity over the Gulf, eventually making landfall as a category 4 hurricane, one of the most powerful ever to hit the US. ‚ÄúIt went from one to two to three, to four so quickly,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI knew it was going to be bad ‚Äì but 10 hours of pounding wind ‚Ä¶‚Äù

He paused.

‚ÄúIt looked like a monster was trying to get inside.‚Äù

Foster was not alone in pointing to the storm‚Äôs rapidly increasing ferocity, a growing trend in the Atlantic hurricane season that scientists link to the climate crisis.

Ida formed just four days ago out in the Caribbean Sea, intensifying so quickly that officials in New Orleans said they simply did not have the time to order the evacuation of the city.

It came ashore with 150mph winds before trudging slowly through New Orleans and into the state‚Äôs capital, Baton Rouge. Quite simply, a storm path born of nightmares.

Click the link in bio to read more of Guardian's US southern bureau chief, Oliver Laughland's report on the devastation caused by Hurricane Ida and the people who have been affected by it.

Scott Olson/Getty Images

Description:
Campaigner Greta Thunberg says she doesn't regard Scotland as a world leader on climate change ahead of Glasgow's COP26 talks in November.

The Swedish activist tells the BBC she recognised that some countries "do a bit more than others" but that none were coming close to what was needed.

"It's a hopeful sign that people want something that's more 'green' - whatever green means - but in order to solve this we need to tackle this at a more systemic approach,‚Äù says the climate advocate.

The Scottish government has previously described its climate change legislation, which includes a target to reach net-zero emissions by 2045, as "world leading".

(üì∏:BBC Studios / PBS)

#GretaThunberg #ClimateChange #Environment #BBCNews
ImageText: NEWS "It should be all about climate justice and we can't achieve climate justice if everyone is not contributing on the same terms" Greta Thunberg

Governments, companies and individuals already participate in carbon offsetting schemes that try to balance their emissions by finding other ways to reduce carbon in the atmosphere by an equivalent amount.

Description:
Pizzlys sind B√§ren mit cremefarbenem Fell, die ein bisschen an Eisb√§ren erinnern ‚Äì aber auch an Grizzlys. Bei Ligern handelt es sich um Gro√ükatzen, die gleichzeitig mit M√§hne und gestreiftem Fell aufwarten. Beide haben gemeinsam, dass ihre Eltern zu unterschiedlichen Spezies z√§hlen ‚Äì Eisb√§r und Grizzly beziehungsweise L√∂we und Tiger. Hybride werden solche Lebewesen genannt, die entstehen, wenn sich Tiere unterschiedlicher Art, Unterart oder auch Gattung miteinander paaren.
.
Pizzly, Liger und einige andere Hybride m√∂gen wie kuriose Einzelf√§lle erscheinen. Tats√§chlich entstehen bestimmte Paarungen nur in Gefangenschaft oder durch gezielte Z√ºchtung, zum Beispiel bei Haustieren oder Nutzpflanzen. Inzwischen zeigt sich allerdings: Hybridisierung ist auch in der freien Natur viel st√§rker verbreitet als bislang angenommen. Mit Hilfe moderner Genomanalyse untersuchen Forschende Erbgutproben im Labor und identifizieren dabei immer wieder neue Kreuzungen ‚Äì bis hin zu solchen aus Blau- und Finnwal.

Description:
Smoke from the Caldor fire is overwhelming Lake Tahoe, one of California‚Äôs most iconic regions, confounding thousands of newcomers who fled there in recent months to escape the coronavirus pandemic.

With a fast-expanding wildfire roaring just one ridge away from the Tahoe basin, residents took flight this week from smoke so toxic and thick that readings spiked past the highest levels on air-quality charts. Amid the exodus, which has become a way of life in parts of the West, there has been a creeping concern that the notion of a safe haven is gone and soon there will be nowhere to run.

Everyone from Bay Area billionaires who bought homes along the shores to workers stunned by surging real estate prices is watching their haven suffocate. ‚ÄúThis is what climate change looks like,‚Äù said Daniel Swain, a climate scientist at the University of California, Los Angeles, and the Nature Conservancy. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs overlapping crises. People try to escape one crisis and stumble into another one.‚Äù

The crisis extends far beyond the lake. In the nearby high desert of Nevada, wildfire smoke this summer has closed schools, canceled sports events and led longtime residents to ask how much longer they can hold out.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about how climate change, the pandemic and extreme weather are making it harder for Californians to find a safe haven. Photos by @maxwhittaker

Description:
Blue whales, the world‚Äôs largest mammals, are returning to Spain‚Äôs Atlantic coast after an absence of more than four decades.

The first one was spotted off the coast of Galicia in north-west Spain in 2017 by Bruno D√≠az, a marine biologist who is head of the Bottlenose Dolphin Research Institute in O Grove, Galicia.

Another was spotted in 2018, another the following year, and then in 2020 they both returned. Just over a week ago a different specimen was sited off the Islas C√≠es, near O Grove.

There was a centuries-old whaling industry and a dozen whaling ports in Galicia. Spain did not ban whaling until 1986, by which time the blue whale was all but extinct in the region.

D√≠az said it was not yet clear whether the climate crisis was leading the creatures to change their habits and return to the area out of a form of homesickness, or ancestral memory. Researchers believe this type of folk memory, or cultural knowledge, exists in many species and is key to their survival. However, not everyone sees the whales‚Äô return as good news.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm pessimistic because there‚Äôs a high possibility that climate change is having a major impact on the blue whale‚Äôs habitat,‚Äù Alfredo L√≥pez, a marine biologist at a Galician NGO that studies marine mammals, told the newspaper La Voz de Galicia.

A typical blue whale is 20-24 metres long and weighs 120 tonnes ‚Äì equivalent to 16 elephants ‚Äì but specimens of up to 30 metres and 170 tonnes have been found.

Video courtesy of the Bottlenose Dolphin Research Institute.

‚ÄúWe got lucky. If the wind blew the other way, if it‚Äôd been later when people were sleeping, we would have had deaths,‚Äù Jack Willingham said of the CO2 pipeline rupture in Satartia, Mississippi.¬†

For the past 19 months, HuffPost and Climate Investigations Center have been documenting the Satartia CO2 pipeline rupture that sent 49 people to the hospital.¬†

Even months later, the town‚Äôs residents reported mental fogginess, lung dysfunction, chronic fatigue and stomach disorders. They said they have trouble sleeping, afraid it could happen again.

At the same time, the federal government has plans to vastly increase the size of the nation‚Äôs carbon dioxide pipeline network as a way of fighting climate change. Our investigation reveals that such pipelines pose threats that few are aware of and even fewer know how to handle.

Description:
The U.S., like most of the world, is becoming both drier and wetter in the era of climate change. But it depends on where you live.

The map above, created using data from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, shows the Eastern half of the country receiving more rain, on average, over the last 30 years than it did during the 20th century, while precipitation has decreased in the West. (Thirty-year averages are often used by scientists to glean big-picture climate trends from temperature and precipitation data that varies substantially year-to-year.)

It‚Äôs not clear whether these changes in precipitation are a permanent feature of our warming climate or whether they reflect long-term weather variability. But they are largely consistent with predictions from climate models, which expect more precipitation overall as the world warms, with big regional differences.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the increase in extreme weather.
ImageText: This Map Shows Two Americas: One Parched, One Soaked Change annual average precipitation, in inches In the ast 30 years, compared to the 20th century -4in. -2 0 +2 Aug. 24, 2021 Source: NOAA's National Centers for Environmental Information

Description:
Die Klimakrise ist nach Ansicht von Eckhart von Hirschhausen die gr√∂√üte Gesundheitsgefahr des 21. Jahrhundert: ‚ÄûMenschen sterben durch Flut, D√ºrre und Hitze ‚Äì jetzt auch in Deutschland, aber in v√∂llig anderen Dimensionen in anderen Regionen der Welt‚Äú, sagt der Arzt und Wissenschaftsjournalist im¬†Deutschlandfunk. 

Deshalb muss die Politik seiner ‚Äì medizinischen ‚Äì Ansicht nach viel mehr f√ºr Klimaschutz tun. Dass allein der freie Markt f√ºr mehr Klimaschutz sorgen k√∂nnte, glaubt der Autor und Fernsehmoderator nicht. Dem Markt seien die Menschen egal und f√ºr Pr√§vention gebe es kein Gesch√§ftsmodell, denn an gesunden Menschen verdiene niemand.

Der klimapolitische Sprecher der FDP-Bundestagsfraktion, Lukas K√∂hler, hingegen ist davon √ºberzeugt, dass die Marktwirtschaft die effizienteste Klimapolitik macht. Zwar m√ºsse die Politik die Rahmenbedingungen so setzen, dass das 1,5-Grad-Ziel des Pariser Abkommens erreicht werden k√∂nne und dazu etwa ein klares CO2-Limit setzen.

Der Markt aber k√∂nne am besten f√ºr neue Innovationen sorgen und neue L√∂sungen f√ºr alte Probleme finden. K√∂hler setzt dabei auf Ingenieure, Techniker und ‚Äûalle, die ihr Leben leben‚Äú. Sie zusammen sorgten dann daf√ºr, dass die notwendige Reduktion von Treibhausgasen erreicht werde, dass CO2 gespeichert werden k√∂nne, dass W√§lder wieder aufgeforstet und Moore renaturiert w√ºrden.

Description:
Madagascar is on the brink of experiencing the world's first "climate change famine", according to the UN.

The drought - the worst in four decades - has devastated isolated farming communities in the south of the country, leaving families to scavenge for insects to survive.

"I clean the insects as best I can but there's almost no water," said Tamaria, a mother of four, who has been feeding her family in the remote village of Fandiova with locusts.

"My children and I have been eating this every day now for eight months because we have nothing else to eat and no rain to allow us to harvest what we have sown," she added.

The drought's impact is also being felt in larger towns, with many children forced to beg on the streets for food.

"These are famine-like conditions and they're being driven by climate, not conflict," said the UN World Food Programme's Shelley Thakral.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about what can be done to improve the ‚Äúcatastrophic‚Äù levels of hunger there after four years without rain.

(üì∏: Reuters)

Description:
The House approved a $3.5 trillion budget blueprint Tuesday in a straight party-line vote, setting up a fall clash over the details of President Joe Biden's proposed expansion of social programs that Republicans blasted for higher taxes and "wasteful" spending.

The budget outlines spending goals that committees must now detail in legislation, such as for free pre-kindergarten and community college, paid family and sick leave, and a Medicare expansion for hearing, dental and vision benefits.

The outline includes contentious provisions. For climate change, the goal is to generate all of the country‚Äôs electricity without increasing carbon dioxide emissions by 2035. For immigration, the goal is to provide a pathway to lawful permanent residence for undocumented children, people who arrived from unsafe countries and farm workers. And it calls for higher taxes on corporations and people with incomes higher than $400,000.

Republicans blasted the budget outline for increasing deficit spending and raising taxes. Rep. Tom Cole, R-Okla., also criticized Democrats for linking the contentious budget outline with the bipartisan infrastructure package. Democrats had divided over whether to approve infrastructure before the more expansive budget.

The House approved the budget outline as part of a rule governing floor debate for the $1.2 trillion Senate infrastructure bill and a voting-rights bill named for the late Rep. John Lewis, a civil rights icon.

The Senate approved the budget outline Aug. 11 on a 50-49 party-line vote.

#congress #infrastructure #democrats #republicans
ImageText: House approves $3.5 trillion budget outline, setting up fall clash on Biden's priorities for climate, immigration USA TODAY

Description:
The record-shattering rainfall that caused deadly flooding across Germany and Belgium in July was made up to nine times more likely by the climate crisis, according to research.

The new study also showed that human-caused global heating has made downpours in the region up to 20% heavier. Last month, parts of Rhineland-Palatinate and North Rhine-Westphalia were inundated with 148 litres of rain per sq metre within 48 hours in a part of Germany that usually sees about 80 litres in the whole of July.

The flooding in Germany and Belgium killed at least 222 people and caused massive damage.

The new study, which focused on the region around two areas that were particularly badly affected: the German districts by the Ahr and Erft river, was conducted by Prof Maarten van Aalst at the University of Twente, in the Netherlands and 38 other scientists.

They used meteorological measurements, high resolution computer models and peer-reviewed research methods to compare the frequency of extreme rainfall like that behind the flooding in Germany, Belgium and the Netherlands in today‚Äôs heated climate with the frequency expected in a world where there had been no human-caused climate change.

The work reinforces the findings of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change‚Äôs landmark report this month that there is ‚Äúunequivocal‚Äù evidence that greenhouse gas emissions from human activities are the main cause of worsening extreme weather.

‚ÄúThe huge human and economic costs of these floods are a stark reminder that countries around the world need to prepare for more extreme weather events, and that we urgently need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to avoid such risks from getting even further out of hand,‚Äù van Aalst said.

In recent months there has been devastating flooding in western Europe and China, extreme heatwaves in north-west America and forest fires in Russia, Greece, Turkey and the US.

#germany #belgium #climatecrisis #climateemergency #environmentalimpact #flooding #floods #climatechange #environment #climate #globalwarming #globalheating

Pasar el Apocalipsis en Nueva Zelanda. 

La crisis de la covid ha puesto de manifiesto las debilidades de la globalizaci√≥n y, como consecuencia, ha resucitado la moda de las teor√≠as del colapso. El cambio clim√°tico, la inestabilidad pol√≠tica y la amenaza de nuevas pandemias amenazan a las civilizaciones industriales, que se hallan ‚Äúen peligro‚Äù debido al abuso de los recursos naturales y la destrucci√≥n de ecosistemas.

Con tan solo cinco millones de habitantes, una econom√≠a modernizada y un 43% de territorio cultivable, los neozelandeses tendr√≠an la capacidad de mantenerse aislados y abastecidos.

Description:
The heavy rainfall that led to deadly floods in Germany and Belgium in July was influenced by human-induced warming, scientists said.

The floods, which had shocked weather forecasters and local authorities, killed at least 220 people as towns and villages were swamped.

Researchers said global heating made rainfall events like this up to nine times more likely in Western Europe. Meanwhile, human-driven climate change also made downpours in the region more intense by 3% to 19%.
 
With continued greenhouse gas emissions and rising temperatures, the heavy rainfall that brought misery to parts of Europe will become more common, experts warned.

"We must reduce greenhouse gas emissions as quickly as possible, as well as improving emergency warning and management systems and making our infrastructure 'climate resilient',‚Äù said Professor Hayley Fowler from Newcastle University.

Tap the link in our bio for more on this story.

(üì∏: Getty Images)

El anuncio fue claro: Chile comienza a trabajar oficialmente con hidr√≥geno verde (H2V), a trav√©s de la creaci√≥n y producci√≥n de la primera mol√©cula del elemento qu√≠mico. La noticia fue revelada por el presidente Sebasti√°n Pi√±era, junto al biministro de Miner√≠a y Energ√≠a, Juan Carlos Jobet, desde Colina.

¬øQu√© objetivo tiene esta iniciativa? Ser utilizada en la industria de la miner√≠a y transporte, adem√°s de detener los efectos del cambio clim√°tico. El mandatario destac√≥ que se trata de ‚Äúun combustible limpio, que se puede transportar, es competitivo y nos va a permitir disminuir enormemente la contaminaci√≥n. Estamos dando un nuevo paso hacia adelante en el combate al cambio clim√°tico‚Äù.

La noticia forma parte de la Estrategia Nacional de Hidr√≥geno Verde.

Para obtenerlo, se separa el hidr√≥geno del ox√≠geno de una mol√©cula de agua. El ox√≠geno es devuelto a la atm√≥sfera y el hidr√≥geno se almacena, siendo utilizado como energ√≠a. El H2V se genera a partir del agua y electricidad, la que producir√° una planta fotovoltaica ubicada en Las T√≥rtolas (Colina). Luego el agua pasa por un proceso de desmineralizaci√≥n, alimentando un electrolizador, donde se desarrolla el proceso de electr√≥lisis.

Description:
We are in an emergency. Wildfires are raging across the world as scorching temperatures and dry conditions fuel the blazes that have cost lives and destroyed livelihoods.

The combination of extreme heat, changes in our ecosystem, and prolonged drought have in many regions led to the worst fires in almost a decade, and come after the IPCC handed down a damning landmark report on the climate crisis.

But technically, there are fewer wildfires than there have been in the past - the problem now though is that they are worse than ever before and we are running out of time to act, as the Guardian's global environment editor Jonathan Watts explains.

Video: @nikhitachulani + @meital_mem + Jamie Macwhirter

Description:
Bruce, an evacuated resident, wades through high water following a flash flood, as Tropical Storm Henri makes landfall, in Helmetta, New Jersey.

Tropical Storm Henri slammed into Rhode Island on the US east coast Sunday, knocking out power to thousands of Americans, canceling scores of flights and bringing record rainfall. 

The storm -- earlier downgraded from a Category 1 Hurricane -- hit land near the town of Westerly, the National Weather Service said.

Henri is a rare tropical storm to hit America's northeastern seaboard and comes as the surface layer of oceans warms due to climate change.

Description:
Ob Hochwasser, St√ºrme oder Erdbeben, die Sch√§den durch Naturkatastrophen nehmen weltweit stark zu. Die globalen Schadenssummen durch Katastrophen haben sich seit den Siebzigerjahren verzehnfacht, unter anderem durch Extremwetter und die immer dichter werdende Bebauung von Risikogebieten.

Dass auch Deutschland immer mehr von Naturkatastrophen betroffen sein wird, zeigte sich zuletzt mit den Hochwasser in NRW und Rheinland-Pfalz oder durch die Coronapandemie ‚Äì doch Deutschland ist nicht gut vorbereitet. 

Ende August ver√∂ffentlicht das Zukunftsforums √ñffentliche Sicherheit (ZOES) ein Bericht 
dar√ºber, wie gut die Bundesrepublik auf Krisen reagieren kann. Am Beispiel der Coronapandemie soll er zusammenfassen, was klappt ‚Äì und was nicht. F√ºr den Vorstandsvorsitzenden des ZOES, Albrecht Broemme, ist klar: Es braucht weniger B√ºrokratie, mehr Koordination und internationale Vernetzung. ¬ªWas wir gut k√∂nnen, ist im Nachhinein die Schadensbehebung und Nothilfe ‚Äì aber kl√ºger w√§re es, die Not nicht zu lindern, sondern zu verhindern.¬´
Jeder Euro Vorsorge spare zehn Euro an verhinderten Sch√§den. Mindestens.

Deutschland m√ºsse sich deutlich besser f√ºr eine Zeit wappnen, in der komplexe Katastrophen viel h√§ufiger auftreten. Die gr√∂√üte Sorge bereitet Broemme dabei nicht die Pandemie sondern eine ganz andere Bedrohung: ein massiver Stromausfall. Dass es dazu komme, sei nur eine Frage der Zeit, egal, ob ausgel√∂st durch Extremwetter, Hacker oder einen Transformatorbrand. 

F√ºr ihn steht fest: ¬ªF√ºr diesen Ernstfall m√ºssen wir dringend planen.¬´

Description:
Alteraciones nutricionales y una sobrecarga del trabajo en los recintos de atenci√≥n sanitaria, pueden ser solo algunos de los efectos del #cambioclim√°tico en las personas, seg√∫n afirm√≥ el director de Salud del Estudiante de la Universidad de Talca, Daniel Jim√©nez.

El especialista advirti√≥ de las severas consecuencias de esta situaci√≥n, cada vez m√°s evidente en nuestro pa√≠s.

El aumento de la #temperatura del #planeta tiene su efecto en el #medioambiente, y con ello en la vida de todos sus habitantes. La preocupaci√≥n de los especialistas tambi√©n radica en su impacto en las condiciones de #salud de las personas.

De acuerdo a la Organizaci√≥n Panamericana de la Salud, OPS, este fen√≥meno es ‚Äúla mayor amenaza para la salud mundial del siglo XXI‚Äù, y pone especial √©nfasis en el impacto que suponen las olas de calor, sequ√≠as, tormentas y el aumento de nivel del mar, adem√°s de los denominados impactos indirectos, es decir las enfermedades respiratorias, la inseguridad alimentaria y del agua; la desnutrici√≥n y los desplazamientos forzados de las personas.

‚ÄúHemos observado el √∫ltimo tiempo que el cambio clim√°tico se ha acentuado. De hecho, hemos sido testigos presenciales de la sequ√≠a que afecta a la zona centro-sur de nuestro pa√≠s. Eso -obviamente- trae efectos directos. Esto no solo impacta al territorio sino a la salud de las personas‚Äù, afirm√≥ Jim√©nez.

Description:
The artist behind the world's first underwater sculpture park unveiled his latest sub-aquatic project: The Museum of Underwater Sculpture in Cyprus. It costs $1.1 million to make and is made up of 93 sculptures by Jason deCaires Taylor. The museum explores the relationship between man and nature.

"I tried to incorporate as many references to climate change and habitat loss and pollution as I could, because those are really the defining issues of our era," Taylor told CNN.

(üì∏: MUSAN/Costas Constantinou/@jasondecairestaylor)

Description:
Agosto ha sido un mes clave en la lucha contra el cambio clim√°tico. Mientras se suced√≠an desastres naturales como los incendios en California, Siberia o el Mediterr√°neo, sal√≠a a la luz la primera parte del principal informe sobre el calentamiento global, el elaborado por el Grupo Intergubernamental de Expertos para el Cambio Clim√°tico (IPCC). 

Antonio Turiel (Le√≥n, 1970) es doctor en f√≠sica, investigador del CSIC y experto en energ√≠a y cambio clim√°tico. En una entrevista con RTVE.es asegura que las conclusiones del borrador trasladan mensajes m√°s "contundentes" de lo que suele ser habitual en el normalmente cauto IPCC. 

Cita, por ejemplo, el "cambio radical" respecto a la tendencia actual que supone la recomendaci√≥n de llegar al m√°ximo de las emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero en 2025, o que pida no abrir nuevas centrales t√©rmicas, aunque se muestra pesimista respecto al cumplimiento de estas medidas por parte de los pa√≠ses.

So viele Kinder sind dem Bericht zufolge weltweit ¬ªextrem stark gef√§hrdet¬´ ‚Äì durch √úberschwemmungen, D√ºrre, Feuer und Hitze, durch Krankheiten, die sich ausbreiten, und durch verschmutzte Luft.

Description:
Greta Thunberg says claims the UK is a climate leader are ‚Äúa lie‚Äù. She made the comments at the launch of a new UNICEF report looking at climate change impacts on children. 

Prime Minister Boris Johnson said at the Leaders‚Äô Climate Summit earlier this year, the UK has reduced its CO2 emissions by about 42% compared with levels recorded in 1990. 

The 18-year-old activist says the UK is ‚Äúvery good at creative carbon accounting‚Äù but  it ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt mean much in practice‚Äù.

‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt include all emissions then the statistics are going to look much nicer.‚Äù Thunberg believes the likes of aviation, shipping and biomass burning have not been taken into account.

Description:
Rain fell for several hours at the highest point on the Greenland ice sheet ‚Äî the first rainfall event in recorded history at a location that rarely creeps above freezing temperatures.‚Å†
‚Å†
Scientists confirm that rain was observed at Summit Station, a research facility that sits atop the Greenland ice sheet and is operated year-round by the National Science Foundation. It was the first report of rain at the normally frigid summit, and it marks only the third time in less than a decade that above-freezing temperatures were recorded at the Arctic research station, according to the National Snow and Ice Data Center.‚Å†
‚Å†
The rare rainfall caused significant melting at the summit and along the ice sheet's southeastern coast over the weekend and occurred just weeks after the region experienced a separate extensive melting event in late July. The recent warm spell adds to concerns that climate change is rapidly melting ice in the Arctic, which accelerates sea-level rise around the world.‚Å†
‚Å†
Read more at the link in our bio.‚Å†
‚Å†
üì∏ Brennan Linsley / @apnews
ImageText: It rained for the first time at the summit of Greenland's ice sheet CLIMATE

Description:
From @nytopinion: Three years after Greta Thunberg‚Äôs strike against climate change began, adults are failing children on a global scale.‚Å£
‚Å£
"Last week, some of the world‚Äôs leading climate change scientists confirmed that humans are making irreversible changes to our planet and extreme weather will only become more severe,‚Äù write @gretathunberg, Adriana Calder√≥n, Farzana Faruk Jhumu and Eric Njuguna, youth climate activists from Sweden, Mexico, Bangladesh and Kenya. ‚ÄúThis news is a 'code red for humanity,' said the United Nations secretary general. It is ‚Äî but young people like us have been sounding this alarm for years. You just haven‚Äôt listened." ‚Å£
‚Å£
A new UNICEF analysis will be released on Friday, the three year anniversary of Thunberg‚Äôs lone protest outside the Swedish Parliament, providing a comprehensive view of where and how this crisis affects children. In the analysis, researchers found that nearly half the kids in the world ‚Äî a billion children ‚Äî face ‚Äúextremely high risk‚Äù because of climate change. ‚Å£
‚Å£
"The fundamental goal of the adults in any society is to protect their young and do everything they can to leave a better world than the one they inherited," write the youth climate activists. "The current generation of adults, and those that came before, are failing at a global scale." ‚Å£
‚Å£
Tap the link in our bio to read the full essay. Photo by @tom__jamieson‚Å£

Description:
The swift fall of Afghanistan to Taliban fighters has triggered a humanitarian crisis, with thousands trying to flee the country. It's also brought renewed focus on Afghanistan's vast untapped mineral wealth, resources that could transform its economic prospects if ever developed.‚Å†
‚Å†
Supplies of minerals such as iron, copper and gold are scattered across the country. There are also rare earth minerals and, perhaps most importantly, what could be one of the world's biggest deposits of lithium ‚Äî an essential but scarce component in rechargeable batteries and other technologies vital to tackling the climate crisis.‚Å†
‚Å†
(üì∏: Matthew C. Rains/Tribune News Service/Getty Images)

Description:
Wildfires have spread across Europe as many countries experience extreme heatwaves.

While these fires have a natural role to play in the ecological cycle, climate change means they may be more likely and severe.

The fires are not just being seen in Europe - countries like the US, Israel and Algeria have also battled with out-of-control blazes.

Aqu√≠ Paula fue la que cruz√≥ a otra primaria".

Otro punto √°lgido lleg√≥ cuando Provoste lanz√≥ una pregunta a Narv√°ez respecto a una declaraci√≥n que lanz√≥ cuando era vocera de la campa√±a del ex Presidente Eduardo Frei en 2009: "Estoy absolutamente convencida de lo que se ha hecho por Chile en los gobiernos de la Concertaci√≥n. Torrential rains that pounded the Black Sea provinces of Bartin, Kastamonu and Sinop caused flooding that demolished homes, severed at least 5 bridges, swept away cars and rendered numerous roads unpassable.‚Å†

Climate scientists unequivocally say that climate change is leading to extreme weather events as the world warms because of the burning of coal, oil and natural gas. Such calamities are expected to happen more frequently as the planet warms.‚Å†
‚Å†
Experts in Turkey, however, say interference with rivers and improper construction also were contributors to the massive damage in Turkey‚Äôs floods.‚Å†

Description:
July was the world's hottest month ever recorded, a US federal scientific and regulatory agency has reported.‚Å†
‚Å†
The data shows that the combined land and ocean-surface temperature was 0.93C (1.68F) above the 20th Century average of 15.8C (60.4F).‚Å†
‚Å†
It is the highest temperature since record-keeping began 142 years ago. The previous record, set in July 2016, was equalled in 2019 and 2020.‚Å†
‚Å†
Experts believe this is due to the long-term impact of climate change.‚Å†

Description:
Uno de los datos m√°s sorprendentes del reciente informe de la #ONU sobre el #cambioclim√°tico fue el elevado protagonismo del #metano como responsable del aumento de las temperaturas.

Por lo tanto, una campa√±a agresiva para cortar las emisiones de metano podr√≠an darle al mundo un tiempo adicional para enfrentar el cambio clim√°tico, dicen los expertos.

El informe del Panel Intergubernamental de Expertos sobre el Cambio Clim√°tico (#IPCC, por sus siglas en ingl√©s) sugiere que entre el 30 y el 50% del incremento en las temperaturas se debe a este gas, poderoso pero de corta vida.

Las mayores fuentes de metano incluyen la #agricultura y tambi√©n filtraciones de campos de explotaci√≥n de #petr√≥leo y #gas, as√≠ como de vertederos.

Por d√©cadas, los mayores esfuerzos para enfrentar el calentamiento global han estado enfocados en limitar las emisiones de di√≥xido de carbono (CO2) derivadas de actividades humanas como la generaci√≥n de energ√≠a o la deforestaci√≥n.

Esto se ha basado en buena evidencia cient√≠fica, ya que el CO2 ha sido el responsable de cerca del 70% del aumento en el calentamiento global que ha tenido lugar desde la revoluci√≥n industrial.

El metano (CH4), en cambio, no ha recibido esta atenci√≥n.

Esto puede estar cambiando, ya que a comienzos de este a√±o un importante estudio de las Naciones Unidas ha subrayado su impacto ambiental.

Description:
La Oficina Nacional de Administraci√≥n Oce√°nica y Atmosf√©rica (NOAA, por sus siglas en ingl√©s) entreg√≥ una dura sentencia en materia del cambio clim√°tico: julio del 2021 fue el mes m√°s caluroso desde que se tiene registro en el planeta. desde 1872 , primer a√±os desde que se tienen registros oficiales,

Seg√∫n indic√≥ Rick Spinrad, ocean√≥grafo y administrador general del NOAA, julio suele tener el mayor peak de temperaturas anualmente, pero el 2021 super√≥ a todos los a√±os anteriores con las extremas m√°s altas.

"Este nuevo r√©cord se suma al perturbador camino que el cambio clim√°tico ha establecido para el mundo", afirm√≥ el experto, calificando la actual situaci√≥n como "el peor lugar para estar".

Se√±alar que el NOAA contempla datos desde hace 142 a√±os, sentenciando que lo vivido en el mes pasado lo transforma en el tramo m√°s c√°lido del que se tenga registro.

La instituci√≥n explic√≥ que en julio de 2021 la temperaturas combinada de las superficies oce√°nicas y terrestres fue de 0,93¬∞ C, "estando por encima de la media registrada a la fecha".

Asimismo, hubo un rompimiento del r√©cord que reg√≠a desde el 2016, pero que hab√≠a sido igualado en 2019 y 2020.

En el hemisferio norte tambi√©n se bati√≥ el peak de temperatura terrestre, con 1,54¬∞ celcius, superando lo ocurrido en 2012.

A nivel regional, Asia vivi√≥ el julio m√°s calurosos en toda su historia conocida, mientras que Europa fue el segundo con mayor calor. Am√©rica del Norte, Am√©rica del Sur, √Åfrica y Ocean√≠a, por su parte, registraron √≠ndices que lo incluyen entre los 10 julios m√°s acalorados.

Description:
It's been a summer of sweltering heat waves and raging wildfires, and now it's confirmed: July 2021 was the hottest month on Earth since record-keeping began. 

NOAA announced the findings on Friday, calling it an "unenviable distinction" and part of a worsening trend related to climate change.

"In this case, first place is the worst place to be," NOAA Administrator Rick Spinrad said in a statement.

For more, click the link in our bio.

Description:
Hundreds of fires are burning across the Mediterranean, displacing thousands and causing irreparable damage as human-made climate change causes record-breaking summer heatwaves.

From Algeria to Turkey - via Portugal, Spain, France, Tunisia, Italy, Greece and Lebanon - click the link in bio to read more about how people across the region have been affected - and how the crisis threatens to spread with weeks of scorching summer weather still to come.

Photograph by Konstantinos Tsakalidis on the Greek island of Evia.

2: More than 50 polar bears have been roaming the streets of a Russian Arctic military settlement since December. Shifts in sea ice due to climate change may or may not be a factor, but the community is scared, and people are staying indoors as much as possible.
The Polar Bear Programme / Russian Geographical Society

3: In this July 15, 2021 file photo destroyed houses are seen close to the Ahr river in Schuld, Germany. Due to heavy rain falls the Ahr river dramatically went over the banks the evening before.

4: The aftermath of a coral bleaching event at Lizard Island, on the Great Barrier Reef, off Queensland's coast, Australia, on May 14, 2016. Bleaching events are often caused by warmer sea temperatures caused by climate change.

üì∏: Kevin Frayer (Getty Images), The Polar Bear Programme / Russian Geographical Society, Michael Probst (AP), XL Catlin Seaview Survey (EPA) | #climatechange #climatecrisis

Description:
El lago Poop√≥ de Bolivia fue una vez una fuente de vida para los habitantes locales, que pescaban en sus abundantes aguas y cultivaban a lo largo de sus orillas. Ahora es un desierto. Los cient√≠ficos dicen que el antiguo lago, que se extiende a lo largo del altiplano de gran altitud ba√±ado por el sol de Bolivia, ha sido v√≠ctima de d√©cadas de desviaci√≥n de agua para cubrir las necesidades regionales de riego. Y un clima m√°s c√°lido y seco ha hecho que su recuperaci√≥n sea cada vez m√°s improbable. ‚ÄúEs como una tormenta perfecta‚Äù, dice Jorge Molina, investigador de la Universidad Mayor de San Andr√©s. ‚ÄúCada a√±o que pasa la situaci√≥n empeora‚Äù. El lago, el segundo m√°s grande de Bolivia, es muy poco profundo y tradicionalmente ha refluido y fluido, seg√∫n los cient√≠ficos y los antiguos habitantes aymaras. Valerio Rojas, quien una vez se gan√≥ la vida pescando en el lago, dice que los ancianos del pueblo cuentan que el lago se recarga cada 50 a√±os. Pero al mirar hacia el desierto de sal reseco y bordeado de blanco que queda, tiene sus dudas. ‚Äú¬øSe volver√° a llenar el lago? Con este cambio clim√°tico y la contaminaci√≥n, me parece que ya no se puede predecir el clima‚Äù, reflexiona. ‚ÄúEn nuestro idioma aymara se dice que: ‚ÄòNuestra madre tierra est√° cansada‚Äù.

üì∏ Claudia Morales (Reuters)

Description:
This Greek island is the new epicenter of Europe‚Äôs summer of calamity.

Fires on Evia, Greece‚Äôs second largest island, have destroyed 120,000 acres of forest, razed homes and displaced hundreds of people. They have brought assistance from more than 20 countries and been declared ‚Äúa natural disaster of unprecedented dimensions‚Äù by the Greek prime minister.

The fires, fueled by a record-breaking heat wave that has touched temperatures of up to 46 degrees Celsius, or 115 degrees Fahrenheit, have caused economic disaster and almost biblical scenes of destruction. But they seem less a random act of God than another inevitable episode of Europe‚Äôs extreme weather brought on by climate change.

Virtually no corner of Europe has been untouched by a bewildering array of calamities, whether fire, flood or heat. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not just Greece,‚Äù said Vasilis Vathrakoyiannis, a spokesman for the Greek fire service. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the whole European ecosystem.‚Äù

The shifting epicenter of natural disaster has now fallen on Evia, a densely wooded island northeast of Athens, once best known for its beekeepers and resin producers, its olive groves and seaside resorts.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the Greek island Evia. Photos by @eirinivour.
ImageText: (empty)

Description:
Leah Thomas watched a video of the ocean on fire and was filled with a "sense of hopelessness."

"I remember just not wanting to move the next day... I just didn't want to get out of bed," recalled the 26-year-old founder of The Intersectional Environmentalist. "What do you do when the ocean's on fire? What do you do when a climate report comes out and suggests that we only have a couple more years to maybe reverse the impacts of climate change?"

Climate anxiety is the "fear or worry about natural disasters and climate events like wildfires or flooding," said Melissa Dowd, a therapist at virtual mental health and primary care company PlushCare.

Though climate anxiety is not a specific diagnosable condition, it is very real for the people who experience it. 

For young people especially, climate anxiety can also impact decision-making. For Thomas, climate was front-of-mind when she was determining where to live. For others, fear about the climate can impact whether to have kids and how to spend their money.

Thomas hopes that others, especially those in older generations, will start to feel seriousness of the situation. 

üì∑: Courtesy of Leah Thomas 

#climatechange #climateanxiety #environment #environmentalist
ImageText: " I started to feel sad. And then just feel really anxious, so it's kind of a paralyzing feeling. would also say my climate anxiety was intensified by a lot of social injustice, because that's also connected with environmental injustice. -Leah Thomas The Intersectional Environmentalist Founder USA TODAY USATODAFE LIFE

Description:
The sweltering temperatures seen in western Canada and the Pacific Northwest earlier this summer not only shattered records - they also cost lives.‚Å†
‚Å†
From 25 June to 1 July, over 700 deaths were reported to the British Columbia's coroner's office - three times the normal amount - the majority of which are believed linked to the extreme heat.‚Å†
‚Å†
Heatwaves, among the worst climate-related threats to human health, are becoming more likely and more intense because of human-induced climate change.‚Å†
‚Å†
Yet it's only in recent years that cities have become more concerned with their dangers.‚Å†
‚Å†
Tap the link in our bio to see how leaders are preparing for the rise of extreme heatwaves.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚Å†
#Heatwave #BBCNews‚Å†
