Description:
Sicilian meteorologists claim they have recorded a temperature of 48.8C, which if confirmed could be the hottest temperature ever recorded in Europe. 

It was recorded in the Sicilian city of Syracuse, and could have broken the official record of 48C, which according to the World Meteorological Organisation was set in Athens in 1977.

A recent heatwave in Italy has worsened wildfires in the south of the country.

This week, the UN released a major report stating that the effects of climate change are even more severe than previously thought. It also warned severe weather patterns that can fuel wildfires, such as heatwaves and droughts, will become more common if action is not taken soon.
ImageText: Sicily 'breaks highest ever temperature' record in Europe @channel4news

Description:

Es en el norte de Argelia donde 37 civiles y 28 militares ‚Äîque apoyaban en la emergencia‚Äî, perdieron la vida por las llamas que arrasan varias regiones de Cabilia, incluida la ciudad de Tizi Ouzou y alrededores. Actualmente hay activos 69 incendios en 17 wilayas.

Si bien el tiempo en la zona ha agravado los siniestros, tambi√©n se han observado focos que encendieron simult√°neamente, lo que hace sospechar de intencionalidad humana.

Un informe preliminar de la ONU califica la regi√≥n mediterr√°nea de "punto caliente del cambio clim√°tico".

Description:
Island nations across the world are warning that they face catastrophic consequences of rising sea levels and possible extinction, after a landmark U.N. report warned of the effects of a warming world.

An alliance of 39 coastal and low-lying nations said the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change report was a "major alert for the world" and called on more powerful countries to do all they can to keep global warming to no more than 1.5 degrees Celsius to "save lives and livelihoods."

Mohamed Nasheed, president of the Maldives, one of the world's lowest-lying countries, which has for years campaigned for climate action, said the situation could not be more serious.

"This report is devastating news for the most climate-vulnerable countries like the Maldives. It confirms we are on the edge of extinction. Climate emergency is intensifying, we are on the front lines. Our nations are already battered by extreme climate," he said on Twitter.

Read more at the link in the bio.

üì∏ Jonas Gratzer / LightRocket via @gettyimages
ImageText: Small island nations warn climate change and rising seas may lead to their extinction Wa WORL D

Description:
Oceans campaigner and champion swimmer Lewis Pugh will attempt "the coldest swim on Earth" to highlight the damaging effects of climate change.‚Å†
‚Å†
The UN patron of oceans will tackle the 10km mouth of the Ilulissat Icefjord in Greenland over the course of two weeks.‚Å†
‚Å†
A heritage site, it is the world's fastest-moving glacier - shifting an average of 30m per day and calving over 30 cubic km of ice into the sea every year.‚Å†
‚Å†
To prepare for the challenge, Pugh is currently training in Iceland as part of his cold-water adaptation program.‚Å†
‚Å†

Description: üî¥ Caus√≥ revuelo a nivel mundial. El √∫ltimo informe del Panel Intergubernamental sobre Cambio Clim√°tico (IPCC), titulado "Climate Change 2021", revel√≥ que el #cambioclim√°tico que sufrimos actualmente no tiene precedentes en cientos de miles de a√±os. En el informe que participaron 234 cient√≠ficos de todo el mundo (algunos chilenos), se detall√≥ la larga lista de eventos como consecuencia del fen√≥meno en los que se incluye: alzas de temperaturas, deshielo de glaciares, sequ√≠as, ascenso en el nivel del mar, olas de calor, inundaciones, tormentas, entre otros. Seg√∫n La Tercera, #Chile es mencionado 98 veces en el documento, donde 34 de ellas en directa relaci√≥n a los fen√≥menos que enfrenta el pa√≠s. ‚ÄúLos registros del ancho de los anillos de los √°rboles han proporcionado evidencia de que los recientes per√≠odos de sequ√≠a prolongados en Chile no tienen precedentes en el √∫ltimo milenio‚Äù, dice el documento. Explica que a pesar de las sequ√≠as y a los a√±os de aridez extrema son una caracter√≠stica propia del clima de Chile central. ‚ÄúLa actual #megasequ√≠a es una expresi√≥n del clima regional sin precedentes en cuanto a su duraci√≥n y severidad para este per√≠odo de tiempo. La sequ√≠a de Chile central entre 2010 y 2018 est√° asociada, en parte, al calentamiento global. En el centro de Chile, la ocurrencia de sequ√≠as prolongadas, como la reciente mega sequ√≠a experimentada en 2010-2015 (que todav√≠a est√° generando impactos), se prev√© que aumente de uno a m√°s de cinco eventos cada 100 a√±os‚Äù, a√±ade el informe. ‚ÄúSobre Am√©rica del Sur, hay evidencia observacional y paleoclim√°tica de disminuci√≥n de la cantidad de precipitaciones durante los √∫ltimos 50 a√±os en el Altiplano y el centro de Chile‚Äù, se√±ala en otra parte el informe. ¬øQu√© te parece? üëá

Description:
The Dixie Fire and other megafires of the West are leaving a footprint much larger than the evergreen forests they burn and the towns they decimate.

Captured by an astronaut‚Äôs camera, the Dixie Fire appears as a thick and sickening miasma pouring from the earth‚Äôs surface. At its center in the eastern mountains of California, the fire has become the second largest blaze in the state‚Äôs history, burning nearly 490,000 acres. Many people who live in the town of Greenville suffered major losses when it was burned.

Summer after summer, California sends giant clouds of haze filled with health-damaging particles across the country. In Denver ‚Äî 1,100 miles to the east ‚Äî the Dixie Fire has helped create a pall of noxious smoke during an already hot summer. Smoke from other wildfires across Western Canada, Oregon and California have fouled the air as far away as Iowa, Minnesota and even New York City.

By one measure, wildfires ‚Äî intensified by drought and climate change ‚Äî are the largest source of potentially deadly air pollution in California. In recent weeks, the accumulating haze and smoke from California‚Äôs fires and high ozone levels have turned the air in Salt Lake City and Denver into some of the dirtiest in the world, more harmful than Delhi‚Äôs or Beijing‚Äôs on many recent days.

Recent research suggests that the smoke may actually grow more toxic as it ages and undergoes chemical changes, reacting with sunlight and other molecules floating in the air. Over time, it may form reactive compounds that can be damaging to the body once they are inhaled.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the extreme weather conditions in California.
ImageText: Greenville, Calif.| Aug. 9, 2021 Calif RSD Residents of Greenville, Calif., were left in shock after the Dixie Fire destroyed their town. Reuters

Description:

M√°s de 900 personas murieron en la destrucci√≥n. En #Am√©rica del Norte, el Oeste luchaba contra los incendios en medio de una intensa sequ√≠a que est√° afectando a los sumnistros de agua y energ√≠a.

Los peligros relacionados con el agua pueden ser excepcionalmente destructivos, y el impacto del #cambioclim√°tico en eventos extremos relacionados con el agua como estos es cada vez m√°s evidente.

En la nueva evaluaci√≥n internacional del clima reci√©n publicada, el Grupo Intergubernamental de Expertos sobre el Cambio Clim√°tico advierte que el ciclo del agua se ha intensificado y seguir√° intensific√°ndose a medida que el planeta se calienta.

El informe, en el que he trabajado como autor principal, documenta un aumento tanto de los extremos h√∫medos, con lluvias m√°s intensas en la mayor√≠a de las regiones, como de los extremos secos, como la desecaci√≥n en el Mediterr√°neo, el suroeste de Australia, el suroeste de Sudam√©rica, Sud√°frica y el oeste de Norteam√©rica. Tambi√©n muestra que tanto los extremos h√∫medos como los secos seguir√°n aumentando con el calentamiento futuro.

Such extremes, and their connection to human-caused climate change, are just one main theme in the blistering climate report released Monday by the U.N.'s Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change ‚Äî the most significant climate report published in years by the international science community.

UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres called the report "a code red for humanity," adding that the "alarm bells are deafening, and the evidence is irrefutable."

Description:
Nations have delayed curbing their fossil-fuel emissions for so long that they can no longer stop global warming from intensifying over the next 30 years, though there is still a short window to prevent the most harrowing future, a major new United Nations scientific report has concluded.

Humans have already heated the planet by roughly 1.1 degrees Celsius, or 2 degrees Fahrenheit, since the 19th century, largely by burning coal, oil and gas for energy. And the consequences can be felt across the globe: This summer alone, blistering heat waves have killed hundreds of people in the United States and Canada, floods have devastated Germany and China, and wildfires have raged out of control in Siberia, Turkey and Greece.

But that‚Äôs only the beginning, according to the report, issued on Monday by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a body of scientists convened by the United Nations. Even if nations started sharply cutting emissions today, total global warming is likely to rise around 1.5 degrees Celsius within the next two decades, a hotter future that is now essentially locked in.

Not all is lost, however, and people can still prevent the planet from getting even hotter. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the report and how global warming will impact specific regions of the world.

Description:
De acuerdo a un nuevo informe del Grupo Intergubernamental de Expertos para el Cambio Clim√°tico (IPCC), el mundo se enfrenta a su per√≠odo m√°s c√°lido en 2000 a√±os, lo que tendr√° efectivos irreversibles para el planeta.

Andrea Sep√∫lveda, directora de Ingenier√≠a en Energ√≠a y Sustentabilidad Ambiental USS, explic√≥ en conversaci√≥n con 24 AM que este aumento en las temperaturas "se vino antes de lo que esper√°bamos. Nosotros esper√°bamos un aumento de la temperatura de ¬∞1,5 hacia el 2040, pero se nos vino antes del 2030".

Por ello, apunt√≥ a que "las modificaciones van a tener que ser mucho m√°s r√°pidos. Los gobiernos van a tener que tomar decisiones ahora", adem√°s de implementar medidas como la carbono neutralidad, proceso vital para contribuir a frenar el calentamiento global.

Sep√∫lveda indic√≥ que se puede "fomentar la electromovilidad, tener empresas m√°s sustentables, ojal√° alcanzar cierre de las empresas a carb√≥n (...) Hay otra parte que es muy importante que tiene que ver con la captura del CO2, que viene desde la naturaleza, y cuidar los bosques".

Asimismo, sostuvo que aunque pareciera que todas las acciones anteriores dependen del Estado, eso no es as√≠ y las personas naturales pueden contribuir. "Lo m√°s relevante es que a los ni√±os, desde chiquititos, les podamos transmitir el cuidado del medio ambiente, el cuidado del agua" .

Ejemplific√≥ con el lavado de los dientes, hacer lo propio con la loza ojal√° en una fuente y luego enjuagar: "El tema de luz, no dejar cosas prendidas. Tener ampolletas que sean eficientes. Son peque√±as cosas que finalmente generan un cambio de paradigma".

Respecto de la escasez h√≠drica, la acad√©mica sostuvo que "el agua es de todos y todos tenemos que cuidarla" y, por lo mismo, se debe ser consciente de que es probable que lleguemos a una racionalizaci√≥n de ella.

"El Embalse El Yeso tiene un nivel de agua tranquilizador, pero eso no siempre va a ser as√≠. Hay que cuidarla para que no vivamos una escasez m√°s terrible de la que estamos viviendo hoy", a√±adi√≥.

Description:
Wildfires raging across Greece‚Äôs second largest island for an 8th day, forcing thousands to flee their homes, are the direct result of climate change, a global consortium of weather and climate experts said on Monday.

The Greek coastguard has evacuated more than 2,000 people from Evia, a popular vacation destination northeast of Athens, since fires broke out there last Tuesday, a spokesperson told the Associated Press.

Firefighters from more than 20 European countries are on Evia to help authorities stop the progress of the fires, which are destroying acres of tinder-dry forests and some homes.

The World Meteorological Organization said that the fires, which have blocked out the sun amid the hottest weather Greece has seen for 30 years, are part of a chain of extreme weather caused by climate change as a result of human behavior.

Read more at the link in our bio.

üì∏ Angelos Tzortzinis / @afpphoto

Description:
Hace apenas unos meses la Organizaci√≥n Meteorol√≥gica Mundial (OMM) advert√≠a de que la temperatura global del planeta podr√≠a llegar a superar, con una probabilidad del 40%, a la de la √©poca preindustrial durante el pr√≥ximo lustro, por lo que podr√≠a estar por encima de los 1,5 ¬∞C antes de 2026. 

No es ninguna advertencia nueva, los expertos llevan a√±os alertando del crecimiento de la temperatura en todo el planeta y de sus consecuencias. A esto se suma el reciente informe del Grupo Intergubernamental de Expertos para el Cambio Clim√°tico (IPCC), publicado esta semana, que considera cinco posibles escenarios, uno de ellos aquel al que se llegar√≠a en caso de mantener la situaci√≥n actual: sin cambios, se podr√≠a registrar un aumento de 1,5 grados en 2040, dos grados en 2060 y 2,7 en 2100. 

"C√≥digo rojo para la humanidad". 

La principal novedad de este informe es que analiza el cambio clim√°tico a nivel regional, as√≠ como los fen√≥menos clim√°ticos generadores de impactos, "con especial atenci√≥n a los fen√≥menos extremos, regi√≥n por regi√≥n". 

No hay duda: el cambio clim√°tico ya est√° afectando a todas las regiones del mundo, lo que aumenta las posibilidades de que tengan lugar distintas "combinaciones" de eventos clim√°ticos extremos, como fuertes precipitaciones u olas de calor ‚Äîesta semana, de hecho, arranca la primera ola de calor veraniega en Espa√±a‚Äî, espec√≠ficas para cada regi√≥n. Todos estos cambios, explica el Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Cient√≠ficas (CSIC), ser√≠an "m√°s generalizados a partir [del aumento] de los 2¬∫‚ÄØC, en comparaci√≥n con el calentamiento global de 1,5¬∫".

Description:
This is Kiritimati or Christmas Island - a coral atoll - which is part of Kiribati, a remote and low-lying nation in the Pacific Ocean.

Experts have warned places like this could be lost entirely due to the climate crisis. They've said global heating above 1.5C will be ‚Äúcatastrophic‚Äù for Pacific island nations and within the century we may see the loss of entire countries due to sea level rise.

Significant parts of places like Kiribati, as well as Vanuatu and Solomon Islands could become uninhabitable if greenhouse gas emissions aren't halved to limit heating to 1.5C above pre-industrial levels as outlined in yesterday's IPCC landmark report on the climate crisis.

The Pacific has long suffered from king tides, catastrophic cyclones, increasing salinity in water tables making growing crops impossible, sustained droughts, and the loss of low-lying islands to sea level rise. These crises are expected to increase in frequency and severity as the world heats.

Satyendra Prasad, Fiji‚Äôs ambassador and permanent representative to United Nations, admitted the IPCC report "is very alarming" but added that the impact of global heating had been felt across the Pacific for years.

Joseph Sikulu, Pacific managing director of climate activist group 350.org, also described the IPCC report as "sobering ... but not unexpected." He points out that the recent devastating real-world examples of the climate crisis playing out around the world, wildfires in the US, heatwaves in Canada, fires in Siberia, Turkey, and Greece, floods in China, are things that the Pacific has been warning about for years.

"The conversation is shifting, everybody is now understanding the reality of the climate crisis, that‚Äôs why it‚Äôs import to centre frontline communities more than ever.‚Äù

But there are reasons to be hopeful despite the damning report. Click the link in bio to find out why.

Description:
Niemals zuvor wurde so drastisch vor den Folgen des Klimawandels gewarnt wie im aktuellen Sachstandsbericht des Weltklimarats IPCC. Die Forscherinnen und Forscher lassen keinen Zweifel mehr daran, dass der Klimawandel menschengemacht ist. Werde nicht radikal umgesteuert, werde die Erw√§rmung des Planeten um 1,5 Grad bereits 2030 festzustellen sein, zehn Jahre fr√ºher als bisher gedacht ‚Äì mit katastrophalen Auswirkungen, warnen sie.

Bundesumweltministerin Svenja Schulze (SPD) mahnt deshalb nun erneut einen schnelleren Ausbau der erneuerbaren Energien an. ‚ÄûJe schneller wir erneuerbare Energien ausbauen, desto schneller kann auch der Kohlestrom vom Netz gehen‚Äú, sagte sie im Deutschlandfunk. ‚ÄûIch bin pers√∂nlich davon √ºberzeugt, dass es nicht 2038 wird, sondern fr√ºher.‚Äú Daf√ºr m√ºsse der Klimaschutz die zentrale Aufgabe im Kanzleramt werden. Ein konkretes Datum wollte sie nicht nennen.

Schulze verwies auf das k√ºrzlich bereits versch√§rfte Klimaschutzgesetz der Gro√üen Koalition. Darin sei nun auch f√ºr die Zeit nach 2030 der Weg raus aus den Treibhausgasen beschrieben. Die Umstellung der Industrie brauche aber auch Zeit, so Schulze. ‚ÄûDas ist einfach schwierig, so ein Stahlwerk CO2-frei zu kriegen.‚Äú Damit die Grundstoffindustrie die Chance habe, nachhaltig zu produzieren, sei beispielsweise gr√ºner Wasserstoff n√∂tig. ‚ÄûDas ist jetzt eine Riesen-Infrastrukturleistung, eine riesige Ver√§nderung der Grundlagen unserer Gesellschaft, die wir voranbringen m√ºssen. Die n√§chsten zehn Jahre sind die entscheidenden daf√ºr.‚Äú

Sale a la luz el Sexto Informe de Evaluaci√≥n del IPCC sobre el cambio clim√°tico y las conclusiones que trae no son del todo esperanzadoras. 

Un documento que seg√∫n el secretario general de la ONU, es "un c√≥digo rojo para la humanidad".

Alrededor de 250 cient√≠ficos del clima de todo el mundo han revisado durante tres a√±os 14.000 art√≠culos de literatura cient√≠fica para realizar este trabajo. 

"Es un hecho que el hombre es causante de una gran parte del cambio clim√°tico. Nos olvidamos del debate negacionista. No hay ninguna base cient√≠fica, ninguna prueba que permita plantearse lo contrario", dice Jos√© Manuel Guti√©rrez, director del Instituto de F√≠sica de Cantabria. 

Tras su exhaustiva evaluaci√≥n concluyen que las consecuencias del cambio clim√°tico pueden percibirse regionalmente. Sus efectos se sienten ya en todo el planeta y adem√°s, se est√°n intensificando a un ritmo muy r√°pido.

Description:
In a historic first, smoke from the raging wildfires in Siberia has travelled to the North Pole.‚Å†
‚Å†
Satellite images from NASA showed the smoke stretched about 3,200km from east to west, and 4,000km from north to south.‚Å†
‚Å†
The smoke travelled 3,000km from the Sakha Republic to reach the North Pole, while reports from Chinese media claimed parts of Mongolia 1,200km away were clouded in smoke as well.‚Å†
‚Å†
Russian forest agencies estimate 14 million hectares  have been engulfed in flames this year, with two million in the Sakha Republic alone.‚Å†
‚Å†
The emissions of carbon dioxide estimated by the European Union‚Äôs Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service suggest emissions since June total more than 505 megatons of carbon dioxide.‚Å†
‚Å†
This comes as the United Nations released a damning report on the climate crisis, stating this current situation is a ‚Äúcode red for humanity‚Äù.‚Å†
‚Å†
The report also states that climate change could push the world‚Äôs temperature to 1.5 degrees above pre-industrial levels within the next decade.

Description:
As a verdict on the climate crimes of humanity, the new Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change report could not be clearer: we're guilty as hell.

The repeatedly ignored warnings of scientists over past decades have now become reality. Humanity, through its actions, or lack of action, has unequivocally overheated the planet. Nowhere on Earth is escaping rising temperatures, worse floods, hotter wildfires or more searing droughts.

The future looks worse. ‚ÄúIf we do not halt our emissions soon, our future climate could well become some kind of hell on Earth,‚Äù says Prof Tim Palmer at the University of Oxford.

So what do we need to know about the IPCC's most damning report to date - and what needs to come next? Swipe to read more.

Description:
Cow farmers in Canada are racing to save their cattle from a dry season made worse by climate change.

This year's drought could spell the end for farmers who raise cattle for income, upending their tradition and way of life. Field after field of ranchlands that keep the cattle fed have been stunted, parched or mowed down by an infestation of grasshoppers, with farmers running out of alternatives for food. In places like Manitoba, some farming families are considering selling the livestock that took many generations to breed.

‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt starve these animals,‚Äù Michael Duguid said of the cows on his farm in the heavily agricultural Interlake region. ‚ÄúThey have the right to eat and drink water just like us, and the humane thing to do is let them go.‚Äù

Researchers say the dryer seasons began around 2018 and have broken records. Last year was the driest ever recorded in Winnipeg, said Natalie Hasell, a warning preparedness meteorologist with Environment and Climate Change Canada, a federal agency.

The country‚Äôs scorching temperatures and its ‚Äúheat dome‚Äù ‚Äî hot air trapped under high-pressure atmospheric conditions ‚Äî would not have been possible without the influence of human-caused climate change, according to a team of researchers.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about how extreme weather is changing this way of life in Canada. Photos by @brett_gundlock

Description:

Dirk Notz von der Universit√§t Hamburg ist einer der Leitautoren des Weltklimaberichts f√ºr das Kapitel zu Eis und Meeresspiegel. W√ºrde die Menschheit jetzt auf ehrgeizigen Klimaschutz umschwenken, w√ºrde sich das laut Bericht "binnen Jahren" auf die gemessenen CO‚ÇÇ-Konzentrationen auswirken. Innerhalb von 20 Jahren w√ºrde sich der Temperaturunterschied im Vergleich zu Szenarien mit hohen Emissionen zeigen. 

Andere Effekte w√ºrden l√§nger brauchen, besonders lang ist die Reaktionszeit der Eisschilde. Doch sp√§testens zum Ende des Jahrhunderts und dar√ºber hinaus sind die Unterschiede zwischen den Szenarien nach wie vor dramatisch.

Description:
El cambio clim√°tico, causado "indudablemente" por la actividad humana, ha llevado al mundo a su periodo m√°s c√°lido en 2.000 a√±os, y tendr√° efectos irreversibles durante milenios, advierte un nuevo informe del Grupo Intergubernamental de Expertos para el Cambio Clim√°tico (IPCC).

La indagatoria del IPCC, que desde 1988 analiza para Naciones Unidas los efectos del cambio clim√°tico en el planeta, indica por ejemplo que los glaciares de monta√±a y en los polos van a seguir derriti√©ndose durante d√©cadas o incluso siglos, incluso reduciendo emisiones.

"El informe es un ba√±o de realidad. Ahora tenemos una visi√≥n mucho m√°s clara del clima pasado, presente y futuro, algo esencial para entender ad√≥nde vamos, lo que podemos hacer, y c√≥mo debemos prepararnos", destac√≥ al presentar el informe la copresidenta del grupo de expertos que lo ha elaborado, Val√©rie Mason-Delmotte.

Asimismo, el documento prev√© asimismo cambios irreversibles a escala de miles de a√±os en la temperatura, acidificaci√≥n y desoxigenizaci√≥n de los oc√©anos.

Predice por otro lado que el nivel del mar seguir√° aumentando irremediablemente, entre 28 y 55 cent√≠metros a finales de siglo con respecto a los niveles actuales incluso logrando emisiones netas cero.

"Durante d√©cadas el IPCC nos ha advertido de los peligros del calentamiento global, el mundo escuch√≥ pero no actu√≥ con la suficiente contundencia, y como resultado el problema est√° aqu√≠ y nadie est√° a salvo", subray√≥ la directora ejecutiva del Programa de la ONU para el Medio Ambiente, Inger Andersen.

El informe asegura que el ser humano ha tenido un papel "innegable" en el calentamiento de la atm√≥sfera, el oc√©ano y el suelo, llevando al mundo a una subida de temperaturas que no tiene parang√≥n en los √∫ltimos 2.000 a√±os.

Igualmente, el estudio, que aprovecha mejoras en la investigaci√≥n paleoclim√°tica, muestra que el aumento de temperaturas actual es comparable al que hasta ahora se considera el periodo m√°s c√°lido de los √∫ltimos 100.000 a√±os, ocurrido hace 6.500 (el llamado m√°ximo clim√°tico del Holoceno).

Description:
Humanity's damaging impact on the climate is a "statement of fact", say UN scientists in a landmark study.

The report says that since 1970, global surface temperatures have risen faster than in any other 50-year period over the past 2,000 years.

This warming is "already affecting many weather and climate extremes in every region across the globe‚Äù, like the deadly wildfires in Greece and the US and the floods in India.

Prof Ed Hawkins, one of the report's authors, says the scientists cannot be any clearer on this point.

"It is a statement of fact, we cannot be any more certain; it is unequivocal and indisputable that humans are warming the planet."

But there is new hope that deep cuts in emissions of greenhouse gases could stabilise rising temperatures.
 
Tap the link in our bio to read more about what can be done to help turn the tide of climate change.

(üì∑ Reuters, EPA, Getty Images)

#ClimateChange #Wildfires #Floods #Weather #BBCNews

Description:
Hundreds of top scientists released a devastating report Monday on the danger that human-caused climate change poses to the world. 

Calling it "code red for humanity," the landmark report was released in Geneva, Switzerland, by the United Nations' Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). 

Many of the changes seen in the world's climate are unprecedented in thousands, if not hundreds of thousands of years, and some of the changes already set in motion ‚Äì such as continued sea-level rise ‚Äì are irreversible over hundreds to thousands of years, according to the report.

Wild weather events ‚Äì from storms to heat waves ‚Äì are also expected to worsen and become more frequent.

The evidence is clear that carbon dioxide (CO2) is the main driver of climate change, even as other greenhouse gases and air pollutants play a role.

The authoritative report, which calls climate change clearly human-caused and ‚Äúunequivocal,‚Äù makes more precise and warmer forecasts for the 21st century than it did last time it was issued in 2013.

#climatechange #environment #weatherforecasts
ImageText: 'Code red for humanity' Human-caused climate change is unequivocal' new U.N. report says USA TODAY

Description:
‚Äú‚Äã‚ÄãIt is unequivocal.‚Äù

Those three words are the first in the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change‚Äôs new report - their starkest warning yet on global heating.

It has laid out how the climate crisis is unequivocally caused by human activities and is unequivocally affecting every corner of the planet‚Äôs land, air and sea already.

The report, produced by hundreds of the world‚Äôs top scientists and signed off by all the world‚Äôs governments, says within the next two decades temperatures are likely to rise by more than 1.5C above pre-industrial levels bringing widespread devastation and extreme weather.

The collapse of major Atlantic currents, ice caps, or the Amazon rainforest ‚Äúcannot be ruled out‚Äù, the report warns.

Ant√≥nio Guterres, the UN secretary-general, warned: ‚Äú[This report] is a code red for humanity. The alarm bells are deafening, and the evidence is irrefutable: greenhouse gas emissions from fossil fuel burning and deforestation are choking our planet and putting billions of people at immediate risk.‚Äù

But the report is clear that there are no cliff-edges to the climate crisis. Each tonne of carbon pumped out increases the impacts and risks of extreme heat, floods and droughts and so every tonne of carbon matters. It will never be too late to act, the report shows. Instead, the real question is how bad will it get?

Description:
Climate change is changing Earth in ways that are "unprecedented" in thousands ‚Äî and in some cases, hundreds of thousands ‚Äî of years, according to a blistering report released by the United Nations on Monday.

The sobering assessment also found that some changes that are already playing out, such as warming oceans and rising sea levels, are "irreversible for centuries to millennia."

The report is the most comprehensive assessment from the U.N.'s Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) since 2013 and provides the strongest case yet for human-caused global warming, saying it's "unequivocal that human influence has warmed the atmosphere, ocean and land."

The report also found that climate change is intensifying, occurring at an accelerated pace and is already affecting every region of the planet.

"It has been clear for decades that the Earth's climate is changing, and the role of human influence on the climate system is undisputed," Val√©rie Masson-Delmotte, co-chair of the IPCC's Working Group I, said in a statement.

Read more at the link in the bio.

üì∏ Angelos Tzortzinis / @afpphoto @gettyimages
ImageText: Climate change is changing Earth in ways that are 'unprecedented,' UN report finds CLIMATE CHANGE

Die Erde habe sich durch menschliche Aktivit√§ten vom Ende des 19. Jahrhunderts bis zum vergangenen Jahrzehnt um 1,07 Grad Celsius erw√§rmt. Description:
After deadly floods weeks ago, the German village of Rech is rethinking its relationship to nature.
 
People in the Ahr Valley in western Germany are still in shock after a megaflood killed 189 people last month. There is grief, desperation, fear of the next heavy rain and anger at politicians who did not heed urgent warnings in the days before. German prosecutors have opened an investigation into two officials in the region on suspicion of ‚Äúnegligent homicide.‚Äù
 
But amid the cacophony of recriminations, there is also something else: a sense of humility in the face of a calamity that no one had thought possible. The disaster brought home the realization that climate change is here, already, and even a rich country like Germany is living its effects. And it forced a painful recognition that the flooding was made worse by many bad economic decisions that over decades turned the Ahr Valley into a death trap.
 
Dominik Gieler, the mayor of Rech, a small village in the valley, lost his home and his mother to the floods. ‚ÄúWe have to rebuild, but we have to rebuild differently,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe have to completely rethink how we live with our environment.‚Äù Tap the link in our bio to read more. Photos by @lena_mucha.

Mesmo enquanto milhares de pessoas morriam e outras milh√µes perdiam seus empregos em meio √† pandemia de Covid-19 na √Åfrica do Sul, no ano passado, Thembakazi Stishi, uma m√£e solo, foi capaz de alimentar sua fam√≠lia com o apoio regular do pai, um mec√¢nico em uma f√°brica da Mercedes.

Quando uma nova onda da Covid-19 chegou em janero, o pai de Stishi foi infectado e morreu em poucos dias. Ela procurou trabalho, e at√© bateu de porta em porta oferecendo faxina por pouco mais de R$ 50, sem sucesso. Pela primeira vez, ela e seus filhos v√£o dormir com fome.

‚Äî Tento explicar que nossa situa√ß√£o √© diferente agora, ningu√©m est√° trabalhando, mas eles n√£o entendem ‚Äî disse Stishi, de 30 anos, enquanto a filha de 3 anos puxava sua blusa. ‚Äî Essa √© a parte mais dif√≠cil.

A cat√°strofe econ√¥mica deflagrada pela Covid-19, agora em seu segundo ano, atingiu milh√µes de pessoas como Stishi e sua fam√≠lia, que j√° viviam precariamente. Agora, na √Åfrica do Sul e em muitos outros pa√≠ses do continente, muitos foram empurrados para o abismo.

Estima-se que 270 milh√µes de pessoas enfrentar√£o escassez de alimentos com potencial risco de vida este ano ‚Äî em compara√ß√£o com 150 milh√µes antes da pandemia ‚Äî, de acordo com an√°lises do Programa Mundial de Alimentos (PMA), a ag√™ncia de combate √† fome das Na√ß√µes Unidas. O n√∫mero de pessoas √† beira da fome, a fase mais severa de uma crise alimentar, saltou para 41 milh√µes de pessoas atualmente, de 34 milh√µes no ano passado, mostrou a an√°lise.

O PMA acionou o alarme na semana passada em um relat√≥rio conjunto com a Organiza√ß√£o das Na√ß√µes Unidas para Alimenta√ß√£o e Agricultura (FAO, na sigla em ingl√™s), alertando que ‚Äúconflitos, repercuss√µes econ√¥micas da Covid-19 e a crise clim√°tica devem levar a n√≠veis mais elevados de inseguran√ßa alimentar aguda em 23 focos de fome nos pr√≥ximos quatro meses‚Äù, principalmente na √Åfrica, mas tamb√©m na Am√©rica Central, Afeganist√£o e Coreia do Norte.

Description:
Jeder rote Punkt ein Feuer: Griechenland und Teile S√ºdeuropas brennen, Kalifornien k√§mpft seit Wochen gegen die Flammen, und auch in Deutschland lodern aktuell mehr als 40 Waldbr√§nde. Einen √úberblick √ºber all die Feuer bietet die Nasa mit Bildern aus dem All.

Im vergangenen Jahr gab es allein in Deutschland 1360 Waldbr√§nde, konzentriert auf die Sommermonate. Dass es brennt, ist also normal. Wie heftig es aber lodert, das ist neu.

Vermehrte Waldbr√§nde sind in den Sommermonaten und vor allem in allen Weltgegenden mit ausgedehnten Savannenlandschaften nicht √ºberraschend. Dort ist das ¬ªWildfeuer¬´ seit jeher ein Ph√§nomen, das typisch ist f√ºr den Lebensraum. Rund 70 Prozent aller wild ausbrechenden Br√§nde sollen sich auf Savannenlandschaften konzentrieren. Wer sich die aktuellen Bilder und Karten des weltweiten Feuer-Monitorings ansieht, wird das best√§tigt sehen: Unterhalb des Regenwald-Bereiches Zentralafrikas sieht es so aus, als w√ºrde der ganze Kontinent brennen, die einzelnen Feuer sind kaum voneinander zu unterscheiden.

Die US-Weltraumbeh√∂rde Nasa f√ºhrt die Daten auf einer Art Echtzeit-Weltkarte der Waldbr√§nde zusammen, die auf ihrem √∂ffentlich zug√§nglichen FIRMS-Server hinterlegt ist.

Description:
How low is Lake Powell? Photos show the toll the megadrought has taken on the lake and tourism ‚û°

Amid a climate change-fueled megadrought engulfing the U.S. West, water levels are more than 50 feet lower than last year at Lake Powell, the second-largest reservoir in the U.S. and a popular tourist destination.

A thick, white band of newly exposed rock face stretches high above boaters‚Äô heads at Lake Powell, creating a sharp contrast against the famous red desert terrain.

One boat ramp is so far above the water, people have to carry kayaks and stand-up paddleboards down a steep cliff face to reach the surface.

Government officials had to begin releasing water from sources upstream last month to keep the lake's level from dropping so low it would have threatened hydropower supplied by the Glen Canyon Dam.

‚ÄúThe park service has failed to plan,‚Äù area homeowner Bill Schneider said. ‚ÄúIf it gets to the point where we‚Äôre so low that you can‚Äôt put boats in the water and you can‚Äôt come up with a solution to put boats in the water, why would you come to Lake Powell?‚Äù

üì∏: Justin Sullivan(@gettyimages), Rick Bowmer (@apnews) | #lakepowell #lakepowellhouseboats #drought #arizona #coloradoriver #reflectioncanyon

Description:
The coronavirus pandemic is deepening global hunger. Relentless waves of the virus, combined with crises caused by conflict and climate change, have left tens of millions of people around the world on the brink of famine.

An estimated 270 million people are expected to face potentially life-threatening food shortages this year ‚Äî compared to 150 million before the pandemic ‚Äî according to analysis from the World Food Program, the anti-hunger agency of the United Nations. The number of people on the brink of famine, the most severe phase of a hunger crisis, jumped to 41 million people from 34 million last year, the analysis showed.

The situation is particularly bleak in Africa, where new infections have surged. In recent months, aid organizations have raised alarms about Ethiopia ‚Äî where the number of people affected by famine is higher than anywhere in the world ‚Äî and southern Madagascar, where hundreds of thousands are nearing famine after an extraordinarily severe drought. In South Africa (pictured above), typically one of the most food-secure nations on the continent, hunger has rippled across the country.

‚ÄúI have never seen it as bad globally as it is right now,‚Äù Amer Daoudi, senior director of operations of the World Food Program. ‚ÄúUsually you have two, three, four crises ‚Äî like conflicts, famine ‚Äî at one time. But now we‚Äôre talking about quite a number of significant crises happening simultaneously across the globe.‚Äù

Tap the link in our bio to read more about how the coronavirus pandemic has killed tens of thousands of breadwinners ‚Äî leaving families unable to buy food. Photos by ‚Äã‚ÄãJo√£o Silva/The New York Times

Description:
A thick, white band of newly exposed rock face stretches high above boaters‚Äô heads at Lake Powell, creating a sharp contrast against the famous red desert terrain as their vessels weave through tight canyons that were once underwater.‚Å†
‚Å†
It‚Äôs a stark reminder of how far the water level has fallen at the massive reservoir on the Utah-Arizona border. Just last year, it was more than 50 feet higher. Now, the level at the popular destination for houseboat vacations is at a historic low amid a climate change-fueled megadrought engulfing the U.S. West.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really sad that they‚Äôre allowing such a beautiful, beautiful place to fall apart,‚Äù said Bob Reed, who runs touring company Up Lake Adventures.‚Å†
‚Å†
Lake Powell is the second-largest reservoir in the United States, right behind Nevada‚Äôs Lake Mead, which also stores water from the Colorado River. Both are shrinking faster than expected, a dire concern for a 7-state region that relies on the river to supply water to 40 million people and a $5 billion-a-year agricultural industry.‚Å†

Description:
This is the photo that has come to define the Turkey wildfires.

The image of a little boy ready for a swim, his gaze distracted by a firefighting plane in smoke-filled skies, has for many come to symbolise the destruction wreaked by Turkey's wildfires over the past nine days.

Taken apparently by a Russian holidaymaker in Antalya last week the photograph has been shared widely by Turkish social media users, many of whom are reeling from the unprecedented wildfires, which experts say have been caused by the climate crisis and incompetent management from Ankara‚Äôs forestry department.

More than 180 fires have killed at least eight people, devastated vast swathes of pine forest and agricultural land.

The Turkish president, Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan, faces a rising tide of anger from the Turkish public over his government‚Äôs slow and lacklustre response to the disaster.

Photo: Mishka Bochkaryov

#Wildfires #Turkey #Antalya #Mediterranean #coastline #climatecrisis #extremeweather

Description:
Can this iconic cactus survive wildfires?

Saguaros, a celebrated symbol of the Southwest and a keystone species of the Sonoran Desert, can be exceptionally resilient. But fires accelerated by climate change, along with invasive plants, threaten the cactuses‚Äô survival.

Some troubling signs are already raising alarm bells for admirers of the tallest cactus in the U.S. Of the 10,000 saguaros surveyed in Saguaro National Park for a National Park Service report on climate change and the saguaro, only 70 were younger than 11 years old, and they were found almost exclusively in rocky foothill habitats.

Such findings are troubling for a plant that relies on what scientists describe as a ‚ÄúGoldilocks‚Äù set of favorable conditions to become established. Saguaros, each of which can disperse hundreds of thousands of short-lived seeds in attempts to reproduce, grow only in the northern reaches of the Sonoran Desert ‚Äî in southern Arizona, southeastern California and parts of Sonora State in northwestern Mexico.

In places with relatively low precipitation, it can take a century for a saguaro to sprout the limbs that can give the cactuses a humanlike appearance; one saguaro in Arizona with 78 arms is well over a hundred years old and known as Shiva, after the Hindu deity.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about these masters of desert survival. Photos by @cassidy_araiza

Description:
‚ÄôWe lost Greenville tonight.' Dixie Fire destroys much of California town ‚û°

California's largest wildfire, the Dixie Fire, has leveled much of the downtown and some surrounding homes in the small town of Greenville on Wednesday evening as the sky was cast in an orange glow.

A gas station, hotel and bar were among many structures gutted in the town, which dates to California‚Äôs Gold Rush era and has some buildings more than a century old.

Firefighters were able to save homes and hold large stretches of the blaze. But flames jumped perimeter lines in a few spots Tuesday, prompting additional evacuation orders for about 15,000 people east of Lake Almanor, fire officials said.

Heat waves and historic drought tied to climate change have made wildfires harder to fight in the American West. Scientists say climate change has made the region much warmer and drier in the past 30 years and will continue to make weather more extreme and wildfires more frequent and destructive.

#california #wildfires #dixiefire | üì∏ : Noah Berger (AP), Josh Edelson (Getty Images)

Ahora se convirti√≥ en un #desierto. Seg√∫n consigna La Tercera, cient√≠ficos explicaron que el lago ha sido v√≠ctima de d√©cadas de "desviaci√≥n de sus aguas" para las necesidades de riego. El clima es mucho m√°s c√°lido y seco provocando que su recuperaci√≥n sea cada vez m√°s improbable. ‚ÄúEs como la tormenta perfecta. A√±o que pasa se agrava la situaci√≥n‚Äù, se√±al√≥ Jorge Molina, investigador de la Universidad Mayor de San Andr√©s. Seg√∫n la cultura #Aymara el lago se llena cada 50 a√±os y la pr√≥xima vez deber√≠a llenarse en 2026, pero esta vez ellos creen que no ocurrir√°. ‚Äú¬øSer√° verdad que se llene otra vez el lago? Description:
‚ÄúEste a√±o ha sido dram√°ticamente seco. Si no fuera por las lluvias del verano esto ser√≠a m√°s dram√°tico‚Äù, asegura Mart√≠n Jacques, investigador del Centro de Ciencia del Clima y Resiliencia (CR)2.

La ausencia de precipitaciones, y las altas temperaturas en este invierno, en los valles del centro-norte del pa√≠s, dan cuenta de un escenario angustiante en relaci√≥n a la condici√≥n de nuestro planeta.

De acuerdo a Ren√© Garreaud, subdirector del (CR)2, con solo un mes de invierno por delante ‚Äúexiste el riesgo no menor que 2021 sea una nueva hipersequ√≠a con impactos potencialmente graves en el medio natural, la sociedad y diversos sectores econ√≥micos‚Äù.

Sobre esto, Jacques afirma que, a causa del calentamiento global, ‚Äúse proyecta una desertificaci√≥n y aridificaci√≥n de Chile central en las pr√≥ximas d√©cadas‚Äù, apuntando a un panorama desesperanzador en lo clim√°tico.
ImageText: FUTURO 360 "Lo que ahora consideramos muy seco ser√° normal en el futuro" Aseguran expertos, quienes advierten una hipersequ√≠a

Description:
Bolivia‚Äôs Lake Poopo was once a fountain of life for local inhabitants, who fished from its teeming waters and farmed along its banks. Now it is a desert.‚Å†
‚Å†
Scientists say the one-time lake, which sprawls across Bolivia‚Äôs sun-drenched, high-altitude altiplano, has fallen victim to decades of water diversion for regional irrigation needs. And a warmer, drier climate has made its recovery increasingly unlikely.‚Å†
‚Å†
The lake, Bolivia‚Äôs second largest, is very shallow, and has traditionally ebbed and flowed, according to both scientists and the lake‚Äôs long-time Aymara inhabitants.‚Å†
‚Å†
Valerio Rojas, who once made a living from fishing the lake, says village elders tell of the lake recharging every 50 years. But looking out across the parched, white-rimmed salt flat that remains, he has his doubts.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúWill the lake fill again? With this climate change and pollution, it seems to me that the weather can no longer be predicted,‚Äù Rojas said. ‚ÄúIn our Aymara language it is said that: ‚ÄòOur mother earth is tired‚Äô.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Tap the link in our bio for more.‚Å†
‚Å†
üì∏ David Mercado / @reuters

Description:
At least eight people have been killed and many more injured after dozens of forest fires broke out in Turkey.

Thousands have fled coastal towns, both residents and tourists, to escape the flames that have been blazing on the country's southern coast for six days. In Mugla province, 10,000 people were evacuated, according to Interior Minister Suleyman Soylu.

Drone footage captured in the Manavgat area on Thursday shows burned out buildings, singed trees and thick clouds of smoke. Some have escaped by car, others by boat. The fires are part of over 100 blazes that occurred in more than 30 Turkish provinces, most of which have been contained or extinguished. 

Fed by strong winds and high temperatures, experts are pointing to climate change and human accidents as the culprits, although the causes of the fires remain under investigation. Southern Europe currently bakes in a heat wave that has also fed wildfires in Greece and Sicily.

Tap the link in our bio for more.
ImageText: npr DRONE FOOTAGE CAPTURES WILDFIRE DEVASTATION IN TURKEY M/STORYFUL

Description:
En pa√≠ses de distintos continentes, como India y China, por el lado de Asia, y Alemania, B√©lgica e Italia, por Europa, han venido ocurriendo √∫ltimamente diversos #fen√≥menosclim√°ticos extremos y de riesgo geol√≥gico, derivados de los efectos del #cambioclim√°tico a nivel global. Nevazones, deslizamientos e inundaciones han aumentado en tal grado su frecuencia en las  latitudes mencionadas, que un grupo de acad√©micos y cient√≠ficos de la Universidad de Concepci√≥n (@udeconcepcion) advierte, con preocupaci√≥n y desde una mirada multidisciplinaria, que nada impide que lo visto en Asia y Europa se repita en Am√©rica del Sur.

Raz√≥n suficiente para tomar en serio las advertencias de la vocera de la Organizaci√≥n Meteorol√≥gica Mundial (OMM), Clare Nullis, que subray√≥ que era indispensable que se "intensifique la #acci√≥nclim√°tica".

Mart√≠n Jacques Coper, acad√©mico del Departamento de Geof√≠sica de la Facultad de Ciencias F√≠sicas y Matem√°ticas UdeC, advierte que ‚Äúlos montos de precipitaci√≥n en los eventos de Europa superaron los 150 mm en 24 horas. Esto es much√≠simo en comparaci√≥n con los 90 mm que suelen caer en todo el mes de julio en esa zona, donde, sin embargo, las lluvias de verano son esperables‚Äù. 

En cuanto a qu√© tan extrapolable es esta situaci√≥n a nuestro pa√≠s, el tambi√©n investigador del Centro de Ciencia del Clima y la Resiliencia, (CR)2, explic√≥ que, si bien las fuentes de humedad que generan estas lluvias intensas son diferentes en Europa y en Chile, los eventos s√≠ son comparables.

"En nuestro pa√≠s, la humedad suele provenir del Oc√©ano Pac√≠fico. En Chile se han registrado precipitaciones comparables e incluso superiores a los eventos en Alemania y B√©lgica. Ahora, lo que puede marcar una gran diferencia entre eventos extremos es la intensidad horaria: considerando sus consecuencias en el entorno natural, la sociedad y la infraestructura, no es lo mismo que estos montos tan pronunciados se distribuyan en 24 horas o en pocas horas, como fue el caso de los eventos de Alemania y B√©lgica. Estos √∫ltimos son mucho m√°s destructivos‚Äù, afirm√≥. 

üëâcontin√∫a leyendo en el link de la bio‚ùó

Con el fin de proteger las zonas rurales, de construcciones que no presenten las regulaciones correspondientes, la Municipalidad de Valdivia orden√≥ la detenci√≥n de seis proyectos inmobiliarios que pretend√≠an ser construidos en plena zona costera.

Carla Amtmann, alcaldesa de la comuna, expres√≥, en #CNNChile, que la medida busca ‚Äúcumplir la ley‚Äù, en el marco de sus responsabilidades en la planificaci√≥n territorial del lugar, y tambi√©n para hacer frente a los efectos adversos del cambio clim√°tico.

Description:
‚ÄúIf something breaks down, if the grid drops out, all of this modern technology fails us instantaneously,‚Äù Hobel says. ‚ÄúVery few people in the country are foraging and hunting each day, but there is no other technology that‚Äôs going to save you. These skills will keep you alive ‚Äî period.‚Äù‚Å†
That sort of rhetoric may sound alarmist, but there are some ominous clouds on the horizon.‚Å†
‚Å†
The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has forecast a temperature rise of 2.5¬∞F to 10¬∞F over the next century. Some scientists consider even that a conservative estimation.‚Å†
‚Å†
As temperatures rise, so do the repercussions.‚Å†
‚Å†
It is increasingly likely that periodic disasters will force city dwellers to at least temporarily evacuate their homes, which is why urban-preparedness courses at survival school are becoming particularly popular.‚Å†

Description:
Survivalist school instructors across the country say there has been an increasing interest in their wilderness and urban-disaster preparedness courses from Americans worried about climate change. As rising temperatures bring more wildfires, droughts and destructive storms, those types of courses are no longer the domain of campers and hunters. One of these schools‚Äô fastest-growing demographics is now young families.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúIt was never like that before,‚Äù says Shane Hobel, founder of the Mountain Scout Survival School.‚Å†
‚Å†
Hobel estimates that increased interest in his courses is fueled by ‚Äú50 percent climate change and 50 percent the ‚Äòpolitical stuff.‚Äô‚Äù Whichever their particular nightmare scenario, there is a shared concern among some of his clientele that the foundation on which modern society rests is increasingly fragile.‚Å†

Description:
At least eight people have died as wildfires rip through southern Turkey.

Blazes have destroyed villages and holiday resorts, forcing thousands to flee.

At least 828 vehicles, 45 helicopters and 13 planes have been involved with the fire-fighting efforts, according to Turkish forestry minister Bekir Pakdemirli.

Fires are also burning in Greece, Italy and Spain.

Experts say heatwaves and strong winds caused by the climate crisis are increasing both the frequency and intensity of wildfires around the globe.

Turkish authorities say more than 130 fires have now been contained.

Description:
The Met Office have said that 2020 was the third warmest, the fifth wettest and the eighth sunniest since the Met Office records began in 1884.

According to The State of the UK Climate report, it was the sunniest spring on record and May was England's driest calendar month since August 1995, which scientists say made conditions difficult for farmers.

It also shows that Britain is already in the midst of a climate crisis, which will increase due to the effects of global warming.

Mike Kendon, the report's lead author, said "...it's the shift in the baseline, what we regard as normal weather, that is changing".

"We are seeing a trend for more high temperature and more high rainfall extremes emerging in our climate and we expect that to continue."

Liz Bentley, head of the Royal Meteorological Society said that in the UK, ‚Äúwe are likely to see temperatures of 40C.‚Äù¬†

She said: ‚ÄúAs we get 1.5C warming, that‚Äôll be something we see on a regular basis.

The State of the UK Climate report is based on observations of temperature, precipitation, sunshine and wind speed in the UK.

The month of July has already seen catastrophic flood sweeping across northwest Europe and an unprecedented heatwave in Canada, which saw temperatures reach heights of 40 degrees.

Wildfires also continue to rage in parts of Europe and the US.
ImageText: UK to see 40C heatwaves and more floods =

Description:
The UK is already undergoing disruptive climate change with increased rainfall, sunshine and higher temperatures, scientists say.

The year 2020 was the third warmest, fifth wettest and eighth sunniest on record, scientists said in the latest UK State of the Climate report.

In the space of 30 years, the UK has become 0.9C warmer and 6% wetter.

"A lot of people think climate change is in the future ‚Äì but this proves the climate is already changing here in the UK," said the report's lead author Mike Kendon.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about what scientists have said about the changing climate.

(üì∑ PA Media)

#Climate #Environment #ClimateChange #UK #Weather #BBCNews
ImageText: BBC N·∫∏WS 1 HH Âá∫ Âá∫E UK already undergoing disruptive climate change, scientists say

La OMM advierte que existe cerca de un 40‚ÄØ% de probabilidades de que, por lo menos en uno de los pr√≥ximos cinco a√±os, la temperatura media anual del planeta suba temporalmente 1,5‚ÄØ¬∞C por encima de los niveles preindustriales.

‚ÄúEso significa m√°s deshielo, un mayor nivel del mar y m√°s olas de calor y fen√≥menos meteorol√≥gicos extremos con mayores repercusiones en la seguridad alimentaria‚Äù, se√±ala.

Description:
The Queen‚Äôs lawyers secretly lobbied Scottish ministers to change a draft law to exempt her private land from a major initiative to cut carbon emissions, documents reveal.

The exemption means the Queen, one of the largest landowners in Scotland, is the only person in the country not required to facilitate the construction of pipelines to heat buildings using renewable energy.

Her lawyers secured the dispensation from Scotland‚Äôs government five months ago by exploiting an obscure parliamentary procedure known as Queen‚Äôs consent, which gives the monarch advance sight of legislation.

In a series of reports into Queen‚Äôs consent in recent months, the Guardian revealed how the Queen repeatedly used her privileged access to draft laws to lobby ministers to change UK legislation to benefit her private interests or reflect her opinions between the late 1960s and the 1980s.

The new documents, uncovered by Lily Humphreys, a researcher for the Scottish Liberal Democrats using freedom of information laws, disclose how the monarch used her special access to Scottish legislation to intervene in the parliamentary process as recently as February.

The documents also suggest Nicola Sturgeon‚Äôs government failed to disclose the monarch‚Äôs lobbying this year when a Scottish politician used a parliamentary debate to query why the Queen was securing an exemption from the green energy bill.

The move appears at odds with the royal family‚Äôs public commitment to tackling the climate crisis, with Prince William recently joining his father, Charles, in campaigning to cut emissions and protect the planet.

Tap the link in the bio to read more about the Queen's consent investigations.

#Monarchy #TheQueen #TheRoyalFamily #Monarch #Headofstate #BuckinghamPalace #CarbonEmissions #Scotland #lobbying #environment #greenenergy #climate
ImageText: Exclusive Queen secretly lobbied to exempt her private land from law to cut carbon emissions

Description:
Las temperaturas nocturnas est√°n aumentando de forma m√°s acelerada que las diurnas, con impactos significativos en el clima y el #medioambiente.

Es un patr√≥n que cient√≠ficos y expertos del #clima han observado en los √∫ltimos a√±os en todo el planeta, con una posible relaci√≥n con eventos clim√°ticos extremos, como la ola de calor que est√° afectando al noroeste de #EstadosUnidos y parte de #Canad√°.

Esto ocurre porque el incremento de las temperaturas m√≠nimas, normalmente las que ocurren durante las horas en las que no hay sol, se est√°n acelerando en comparaci√≥n con las temperaturas m√°ximas, usualmente diurnas.

Es decir, noches m√°s c√°lidas. Lo que contrasta con la idea de que las noches son generalmente m√°s frescas.

Es lo que algunos cient√≠ficos llaman "asimetr√≠a de calentamiento", y pasa porque el efecto del incremento de las temperaturas no es uniforme en todo el planeta todo el tiempo.

Con temperaturas m√°ximas r√©cord, el foco de atenci√≥n se ha centrado este a√±o en el domo de calor en Norteam√©rica, un evento del tipo "solo uno en 1.000 a√±os" y "virtualmente imposible" si no fuese por el efecto de la acci√≥n humana sobre el ambiente, seg√∫n dijo la red World Weather Attribution.

Pero no todo se trata de medir cu√°nto suben las temperaturas m√°ximas. Los cient√≠ficos le est√°n poniendo un ojo a las variaciones en las temperaturas m√≠nimas, un detalle que ser√≠a crucial para entender el cambio clim√°tico.

Description:
La intenci√≥n del presidente de la #COP26 (que se celebrar√° en #Glasgow en noviembre), #AlokSharma, es llegar a esbozar cu√°l deber√≠a ser el resultado que se espera de la cumbre, seg√∫n un comunicado de la organizaci√≥n.

Los ministros de 51 pa√≠ses, entre ellos la espa√±ola #TeresaRibera y los de potencias fundamentales como #EstadosUnidos o #China, participar√°n de forma presencial y virtual en la reuni√≥n, que marcar√° el comienzo de la cuenta atr√°s para la Conferencia de las Partes de la Convenci√≥n Marco de #NacionesUnidas sobre #cambioclim√°tico (#COP).

Sharma pretende "aunar el objetivo" que persiga la cita, de forma que se pongan a disposici√≥n de ese prop√≥sito las herramientas necesarias.

Londres defender√° su intenci√≥n de limitar el #calentamientoglobal a los 1,5 grados cent√≠grados, algo complicado a tenor de las resistencias expresadas por #China y la India, dos de los mayores contaminantes, a comprometerse con ese objetivo durante la reci√©n clausurada cumbre de ministros de Energ√≠a del #G20.

Entre los asuntos que se abordar√°n en #Londres estar√°n la movilizaci√≥n de financiaci√≥n clim√°tica, aumentar los recursos para adaptaci√≥n a los efectos del calentamiento global y finalizar el reglamento para la implementaci√≥n del #AcuerdodePar√≠s, especialmente en lo referido al art√≠culo 6, que fija el funcionamiento de los mercados de #carbono.

"Es esencial que todos nos arremanguemos, encontremos los puntos en com√∫n y esbocemos colectivamente c√≥mo construiremos un futuro m√°s verde y mejor", dijo Sharma, seg√∫n el comunicado.

Para el presidente de la COP26 ser√° fundamental "no tener miedo a expresar las discrepancias al tiempo que se conserva un esp√≠ritu de cooperaci√≥n".

"Espero que aprovechemos esta oportunidad para tratar soluciones tangibles, y que nuestros amigos se vayan de la reuni√≥n con una visi√≥n m√°s clara de los resultados (que se esperan) de Glasgow, as√≠ como el prop√≥sito com√∫n de alcanzarlos", agreg√≥.

Description:
El Grupo Intergubernamental de Expertos sobre el #CambioClim√°tico (#IPCC) iniciar√° este lunes, y hasta el 6 de agosto, una reuni√≥n virtual para aprobar un informe clave.

El texto ser√° el √∫nico informe del IPCC que se publicar√° este a√±o antes de las esperadas negociaciones de la #COP26, que se celebrar√°n en #Glasgow en noviembre, inform√≥ la #Asociaci√≥nCivilPeriodistasporelPlaneta.

El informe abarcar√° cuestiones como la atribuci√≥n -la influencia mensurable de la humanidad en el #clima-, los niveles de emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero, el aumento de la temperatura, las retroalimentaciones clim√°ticas (tambi√©n conocidas como impactos), el cambio del nivel del mar, el papel de los bosques y los #oc√©anos como sumideros de carbono hasta ahora, y c√≥mo podr√≠an comportarse en el futuro en funci√≥n de las decisiones que las autoridades tomen ahora.

Informe anterior

El informe del #IPCC de 2018 sobre el objetivo del 1,5‚ÑÉ cambi√≥ permanentemente el discurso p√∫blico sobre el #clima, con los #gobiernos y las empresas bajo m√°s escrutinio que nunca, y dio lugar a movimientos como #FridaysfortheFuture y #ExtinctionRebellion.

Las principales conclusiones del IPCC SR15 mostraron que el mundo necesita un cambio sist√©mico urgente y sin precedentes para reducir las emisiones a la mitad en 2030 y alcanzar las emisiones netas cero en 2050 a m√°s tardar, si los gobiernos se toman en serio el ambicioso objetivo de #Par√≠s de 1,5‚ÑÉ.

Sin embargo, las emisiones no han dejado de aumentar. La actualizaci√≥n de mayo del #ClimateActionTracker mostr√≥ que las #pol√≠ticas actuales sit√∫an al planeta en torno al 2,9‚ÑÉ, y los compromisos clim√°ticos entre el 2-2,4‚ÑÉ. A principios de este a√±o, el informe de la #AgenciaInternacionaldelaEnerg√≠a (#AIE) afirmaba que un mundo alineado con el 1,5‚ÑÉ significa el fin inmediato de las nuevas inversiones en combustibles f√≥siles, y un sector energ√©tico global neto cero para 2040.

Description:
Mindestens 176 Menschen Menschen haben in Deutschland ihr Leben durch die Fluten nach dem Starkregen verloren und auch die Sachsch√§den sind immens. Zahlreiche Hausbesitzer haben all ihr Hab und Gut verloren ‚Äì und viele davon sind gegen diesen Schaden nicht versichert. Der Gesamtverband der Deutschen Versicherungswirtschaft gibt an, dass nur 46 Prozent der deutschen Privath√§user √ºber eine Elementarschadenversicherung gegen Hochwassersch√§den gesch√ºtzt sind.
.

Die Versicherungsquote m√ºsse auf √ºber 80 bis 90 Prozent gesteigert werden. Hausbesitzer sollten schon bei der Finanzierung darauf hingewiesen werden, dass sie ihr Haus gegen Elementarsch√§den versichern sollten.
.
F√ºr das eine Prozent, das nicht versicherbar sei, brauche es gesamtgesellschaftliche L√∂sungen f√ºr die Verteilung der Risiken und Kosten. Diese Risiken w√ºrden in Folge des Klimawandels weiter zunehmen, eine verpflichtende Elementarversicherung k√∂nne dieses Problem nicht alleine l√∂sen. ‚ÄûEine Versicherung alleine kann die Folgen des Klimawandels nicht tragen‚Äú, sagte Asmussen. ‚Å†‚Å†
Hundreds of wildfires are ripping through Russia‚Äôs forests, releasing high amounts of carbon into the atmosphere.‚Å†‚Å†

Description: La investigaci√≥n en Marte contin√∫a haciendo grandes descubrimientos üò±üî≠ El robot de la #NASA, Perseverance, est√° recopilando muestras de la superficie para continuar con la b√∫squeda de vida pasada üßê Fue en las muestras de arcilla del Cr√°ter de Gale, en d√≥nde se cree que se pudo albergar vida, pero los vestigios fueron eliminados üòØ Se cree que este cr√°ter era parte del sistema de lagos en la superficie que pudo haber sido el hogar de miles de bacterias. Los cient√≠ficos teorizan que estas masas de agua se perdieron cuando el planeta pas√≥ por su periodo de cambio clim√°tico. Lentamente, los lagos se fueron secando, dejando evidencia en la tierra de salmueras o presencia de agua muy salada en las profundidades del suelo. Pero aparentemente habr√≠an estado equivocados. Luego de comparar muestras tomadas del cr√°ter, separadas solo por 400 metros entre s√≠, descubrieron grandes diferencias. Sorprendentemente, en una de las √°reas faltaba la mitad de los minerales que se deb√≠an encontrar üî¨ Los cient√≠ficos creen que la misma salmuera que queda en el fondo de la tierra, habr√≠a sido la responsable de eliminar cualquier evidencia minera. ¬øQu√© te parece? üëá Los detalles en www.meganoticias.cl üì±

ImageText: ‚ÄûDer gr√∂√üte Brocken S√∂ders Regierungserkl√§rung zum Klimaschutz war sein Beharren auf dem Kohleausstieg schon 2030. Niemand in Bayern wird deshalb in Unruhe versetzt. Denn es gibt hier kaum Kohlekraftwerke. Andere L√§nder sind verantwortlich, wenn nichts daraus wird. Angesprochen f√ºhlen muss sich aber Armin Laschet, dem es S√∂der damit im Wahlkampf nicht leichter macht." Jasper von Altenbockum kommentiert S√∂ders Forderung zum Kohleausstieg

Description:
Das war Tag 1 des #SZSummit zum Thema ‚ÄûWirtschaft nachhaltig denken‚Äú: @luisaneubauer von #FridaysforFuture spricht mit Joe Kaeser, Aufsichtsrat bei Siemens Energy, √ºber die Frage nach der richtigen #Klimapolitik. Neubauer kritisiert die Unt√§tigkeit der regierenden Politikerinnen und Politiker in Sachen #Klimaschutz. Kaeser weist auf ein ‚Äûgesellschaftliches Dilemma‚Äú hin: #FFF bilde den wichtigsten Teil der Gesellschaft ab, doch die Generation der Unter-30-J√§hrigen mache demografisch nicht einmal 15 Prozent der W√§hlerinnen und W√§hler aus. 

Mit Bayerns Ministerpr√§sident Markus #S√∂der sprechen die stv. SZ-Chefredakteurin Alexandra Foederl-Schmid und Marc Beise, Ressortleiter Wirtschaft, √ºber die Rolle der Union beim Klimaschutz. S√∂der sagt: ‚ÄûMan macht in Bayern gute gr√ºne Politik ohne Gr√ºne.‚Äú

√úber #Nachhaltigkeit als unternehmerische Verantwortung diskutieren Antje von Dewitz (Vaude), Andrea Euenheim (Metro), Andrea F√ºtterer (Forum Fairer Handel) und Wolfgang Grupp (Trigema). Von Dewitz zeigt die Probleme auf, die die globale Textilindustrie beitr√§gt (Klimawandel, Mikroplastik, Umweltverschmutzung) und sieht sich als Unternehmerin in der Pflicht, Teil der L√∂sung zu sein.

Morgen geht‚Äôs weiter beim SZ-Nachhaltigkeitsgipfel, u.a. mit Gr√ºnen-Fraktionschefin @goeringeckardt, den Branchenpanels zu Nachhaltigkeit in Energie und Finanzen, M√ºnchens OB @dieter_reiter_089 und Schauspieler Hannes Jaenicke. Alle Informationen unter www.sz-summit.de

Description:
Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è There are 80 large fires burning across 13 states this week, and the effects of the blazes stretch all the way to the East Coast. Extraordinary plumes of wildfire smoke are reaching so far up into the atmosphere that they are being carried thousands of miles east by high-level winds. The smoke's effect on light causes the sun to look red at sunset as the sky takes on a burnt-orange color, and it also affects air quality. The climate crisis has made deadlier and more destructive wildfires the new normal. Tap the link in our bio to learn more.‚Å†
‚Å†
(üì∏: NASA Modis)
ImageText: Wildfire smoke from the West's blazes stretches all the way to the East Coast CNN

Description:
Smoke from the Western wildfires made it to New York City on Tuesday, tinting the sun red and contributing to the haze in the city and elsewhere on the East Coast.‚Å£
‚Å£
‚ÄúThe haze or the smoke that you see there is coming from the wildfires out in the West,‚Äù said John Cristantello, a meteorologist with the New York office of the National Weather Service, ‚Äúand that‚Äôs helping scatter the light, which leads to those more vivid sunrises and sunsets.‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£
New York State issued an air quality health advisory for Tuesday, lasting until midnight, because of high levels of fine particulate matter in the air, which wildfires contribute to. By late afternoon, the Air Quality Index for New York City had reached 170, well above average. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Hazy skies are nothing new during a New York City summer, Cristantello said. ‚ÄúThat happens with or without smoke. You have those hazy days‚Äù in part because of air pollution. But the long-traveling smoke is part of the mix, he said.‚Å£
‚Å£
Climate change is making wildfires larger and more intense, with results visible from satellites and on the ground. The Bootleg Fire in Oregon now covers more than 388,000 acres and is so intense that it is essentially making its own weather. Satellite images from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration show smoke from that fire and others making its way across wide swaths of the U.S. and Canada. It first reached New York City around July 15.‚Å£
‚Å£
Tap the link in our bio to see how wildfire smoke has spread across the U.S. and our latest wildfire tracker. Photo by @bryananselm‚Å£

Description:
At least 25 people have died in floods in China's central Henan province, authorities say, after what some experts say is the region's heaviest rain in 1,000 years. 

The catastrophic floods in China come as floods in Western Europe and the recent deadly heat wave in parts of the Western U.S. and Canada place a new focus on the climate crisis, as politicians and climate experts alike warn that the global community must ramp up its efforts to combat climate change.

Read more at the link in the bio. 

üì∏ @@afpphoto / @gettyimages
ImageText: (empty)

Description:
Demand for FEMA funds to help communities prepare for climate change has outpaced the available money. Advocates fear the consequences could leave poorer communities with weaker defenses against the intensifying crisis.‚Å†
‚Å†
Three of the wealthiest states ‚Äî California, New Jersey and Washington ‚Äî are on track to receive more than half of the money from a new FEMA program helping communities prepare for extreme weather, including flood mitigation, a tsunami shelter and the removal of dense undergrowth to prevent wildfires. Plenty of poorer communities will receive funding as well, but dozens will not.‚Å†
‚Å†
The long list of more than 500 communities that received no funding ‚Äî many without the resources to prepare for extreme weather on their own ‚Äî has raised concerns among environmental justice and civil rights advocates that better resourced communities won big, while disadvantaged areas remain in need. In some cases, that‚Äôs because poorer communities don‚Äôt have the money for the matching part of the grant, or lack the resources to prepare a competitive grant application.‚Å†
‚Å†
Click the link in bio for more.‚Å†
‚Å†
üì∑ @ewrabetz / @nbcnewsart @gettyimages @apnews

Description:
Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è The Bootleg Fire in Oregon has become so intense that it is creating its own weather. The fire has scorched 537 square miles -- an area larger than Los Angeles and about half the size of Rhode Island. Hot, dry weather conditions continue to fuel wildfires across much of the United States, and the Bootleg Fire grew to nearly 364,113 acres Monday and is 30% contained, Oregon Department of Forestry spokesperson Marcus Kauffman told CNN. The climate crisis has made deadlier and more destructive wildfires the new normal. Tap the link in our bio to learn more.‚Å†
‚Å†
(üì∏: PAYTON BRUNI/AFP via Getty Images)
ImageText: The Bootleg Fire in Oregon is so large, it's creating its own weather CNN

Description:
Globs of feathery goo are literally choking the life out of Turkey's Marmara Sea. Scientists say rising sea temperatures and untreated wastewater being dumped into the sea combined to create the perfect conditions for the issue to thrive. ‚Å†
‚Å†
There are no quick fixes to the problem, and experts warn that urgent action must be taken to curb the local pollution, and the global climate change fueling the growth of mucilage. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Read more at the link in our bio.
ImageText: PRIMETIME Sea snot is suffocating the life out of Turkey's waters

Description:
Der Journalist und Moderator Claus Kleber sieht die wichtigste Aufgabe der Berichterstattung zur Hochwasserkatastrophe bei der Frage, wie so viele Menschen ums Leben kommen konnten. Die Frage, ob der Klimawandel, der bei der Berichterstattung oft auch eine Rolle spielt, menschengemacht sei, m√ºsse man gerade zur√ºckstellen, so Kleber im Deutschlandfunk.

"Dass wir unseren Kindern und Enkeln nicht eine Welt √ºberlassen wollen, in der das noch h√§ufiger, noch schlimmer, noch drastischer ist, steht auf einem anderen Blatt, ist ebenso wichtig, aber heute nicht ganz so dringend", sagte Kleber weiter. 
.

Description:
The Met Office has announced its first ever ‚Äòextreme weather‚Äô warning, amid sweltering temperatures across the UK.‚Å†
‚Å†
The warning has been applied to South Wales, West Midlands, southern and southwestern England‚Å†
The new warning is in place until Thursday at 11:59pm, as temperatures are set to cool on Friday.‚Å†
‚Å†
This comes after parts of the UK experienced soaring temperatures over the weekend, with all four nations recording their hottest temperatures of the year so far.‚Å†
‚Å†
Extreme heat warnings were introduced into the National Severe Weather Warning Service (NSWWS) on 1st June, after consultations with Public Health England and other health agencies.‚Å†
‚Å†
Experts say extreme heat events are now more likely because of climate change.‚Å†
‚Å†
In 2018, record-breaking summer temperatures experienced in the UK were made 30 times more likely by human-induced climate change that it would be naturally, according to the Met Office.

Description:
Ben & Jerry's has said it will end the sale of its ice cream in the Palestinian territories.

The company said on Monday it was "inconsistent with our values for Ben & Jerry's ice cream to be sold in the Occupied Palestinian Territory (OPT)".

The OPT typically refers to the West Bank, which has been under Israeli control since 1967.

Ben & Jerry's said the move reflected the concerns of "fans and trusted partners".

The company, which has a track record of campaigning on social issues such as LGBTQ+ rights and climate change, has faced years of pressure from activists.
Tap the link in our bio to learn more about why they made this decision. 
#Ben&Jerrys #BBCNews

Description:
As the globe heats up, cities across America are taking a fresh look at their trees. They keep urban neighborhoods cooler, make air conditioning bills manageable and, most importantly, protect lives during heat waves. They help capture stormwater runoff, and as trees grow they remove heat-trapping carbon dioxide from the air. Some cities are now moving to increase their tree canopy, in part to shield against the worst effects of climate change.

The tree canopy in Cleveland, once commonly called "Forest City," has been shrinking. The city has now pledged to reverse that trend as part of its official plan to deal with climate change and promote economic and racial equity at the same time. Follow the link in bio for the full story. (Photos: @rjckseen ‚Ä¢ Ryan Kellman/NPR)

1. A coalition of city agencies, nonprofit organizations (including the Holden Forests & Gardens, pictured here), and corporations has adopted an ambitious plan to expand tree cover in Cleveland from its current level of 19% to 30% by 2040.
2. A tree distribution event organized by the Western Reserve Land Conservancy.
3. Sandra Albro, director of community partnerships at Cleveland's Holden Forests and Gardens, says tree disparities in Cleveland reflect broader patterns of racial discrimination.
4. Cleveland's tree planting plan has been long on aspiration and short on follow-through, so far. Planting that many trees would cost just over $8 million per year, and it's not clear who will pay.
5. Trees in the Mount Pleasant area, Shirley Bell-Wheeler says, only half-joking, deserve the same attention as forests in the Amazon. "If it's vital to other people, it's vital to us, too!
6. Lower temperatures, which trees help create, can save lives. One recent study estimated that more than 5000 people die each year in the U.S. from heat-related illness.
7. Courtney Blashka, director of community forestry & conservation at Holden Forests & Gardens, tidies up the soil around a newly planted oak tree that's a clone of a tree that track star Jesse Owens planted.

Description:
Northeastern Siberia has the coldest winters outside Antarctica. But as the planet warms, summer now brings 100-degree days and enormous wildfires.‚Å£
‚Å£
For the third year in a row, residents are reeling from the worst wildfires they can remember, and many are left feeling helpless, angry and alone.‚Å£
‚Å£
Some forest fires are normal, but scientists say they have accelerated to an extraordinary pace in the past three years, threatening the sustainability of the ecosystem of the northern forest, known as the taiga. Now the forests in Yakutia ‚Äî a region four times the size of Texas, with its own culture and Turkic language ‚Äî are burning again. ‚Å£
‚Å£
‚ÄúIf we don‚Äôt have the forest, we don‚Äôt have life,‚Äù said Maria Nogovitsina, who lives in the village of Magaras, population of about 1,000, located 60 miles outside Yakutsk, the region‚Äôs capital and the coldest city in the world.‚Å£
‚Å£
Villagers and local volunteers are consumed by the battle with fire, shoveling trenches to keep it away from their homes and fields.‚Å£
‚Å£
Last year, wildfires scorched more than 60,000 square miles of forest and tundra, an area the size of Florida. That is more than four times the area that burned in the U.S. during its devastating 2020 fire season. This year, more than 30,000 square miles have already burned in Russia, according to government statistics, with the region only two weeks into its peak fire season.‚Å£
‚Å£
Scientists say that the huge fires have been made possible by the extraordinary summer heat in recent years in northern Siberia, which has been warming faster than just about any other part of the world. And the impact may be felt far from Siberia. The fires may potentially accelerate climate change by releasing enormous quantities of greenhouse gases and destroying Russia‚Äôs vast boreal forests, which absorb carbon out of the atmosphere.‚Å£
‚Å£
Tap the link in our bio to read more. Photos by @nannaheitmann‚Å£

As buscas ocorrem ap√≥s chuvas e transbordamentos de rios nesta semana que destru√≠ram casas e custaram pelo menos 157 vidas, segundo os c√°lculos mais recentes.

Cerca de 133 pessoas morreram no Oeste da Alemanha, no pior desastre natural do pa√≠s em mais de meio s√©culo. Centenas de pessoas ainda est√£o desaparecidas.

‚Äî Os n√≠veis de √°gua t√™m se estabilizado desde a noite passada, pode-se dizer que a situa√ß√£o est√° est√°vel. √â muito cedo para afirmar que o perigo passou, mas estamos cautelosamente otimistas ‚Äî disse o prefeito de Wassenberg, Marcel Maurer.

Na B√©lgica, o n√∫mero de mortos subiu para 24, de acordo com o centro nacional de crise, que coordena o esfor√ßo de resgate.

"Infelizmente, temos que assumir que esse n√∫mero continuar√° a aumentar nas pr√≥ximas horas e dias", informou o centro em um comunicado. Cerca de 20 pessoas ainda est√£o desaparecidas.

Os n√≠veis da √°gua ca√≠ram lentamente nas partes mais atingidas da B√©lgica, embora o centro da crise tenha informado que a situa√ß√£o pode piorar na tarde deste s√°bado ao longo do Rio Demer, perto de Bruxelas, com cerca de 10 casas sob amea√ßa de destrui√ß√£o.

Os servi√ßos de emerg√™ncia na Holanda tamb√©m permaneceram em alerta m√°ximo, pois o transbordamento de rios amea√ßou cidades e vilas em toda a prov√≠ncia de Limburg, no Sul.
