Description:
Die Ausma√üe der Starkregenf√§lle in Deutschland sind verheerend: √úberflutungen, Erdrutsche, Hauseinst√ºrze und in der Folge viele Menschen, die ums Leben gekommen sind. 

Klimawissenschaftler haben bereits eine deutliche Zunahme von sommerlichem Extremwetter wie D√ºrre, aber auch Starkregen prognostiziert. Die Wetterextreme in unseren Breiten seien die ‚ÄûFolgen der dramatischen Erw√§rmung der Arktis‚Äú, sagt Markus Rex, Alfred-Wegener-Institut f√ºr Polar- und Meeresforschung. Im aktuellen Fall kamen drei Komponenten zusammen: feucht-warme Luft, dazu ein tr√§ges Tief und die ‚ÄûKonvektion‚Äú, also das Aufsteigen warmer, feuchter Luft, die als Folge der Hebung als Niederschlag niedergeht.

Zuk√ºnftig k√∂nnten uns also solche Extremwetter h√§ufiger besch√§ftigen. Daher w√§re ein Umdenken beim St√§dtebau n√∂tig, sagt Lamia Messari-Becker. Der Bau von Gewerbe- und Wohngebieten sorgt f√ºr versiegelte Fl√§chen. Dadurch kann das Regenwasser nicht mehr ausreichend in den Boden versickern und flie√üt stattdessen noch schneller an der Oberfl√§che in Kan√§le und Fl√ºsse ab. Kommen dann noch intensive und langanhaltende Regenf√§lle dazu, ist das Kanalisationssystem schnell √ºberlastet. Die vor Jahrzehnten geplante Infrastruktur in Deutschland ist auf extreme Wetterph√§nomene meist nicht ausgelegt. Gleichzeitig wurde vers√§umt, Gew√§sser in einen naturnahen Zustand (zur√ºck) zu versetzen. 

Die Auswirkungen von Unwettern wie dem jetzigen h√§tten durch eine nachhaltigere Politik gemindert werden k√∂nnen, sagte Holger Sticht, der Vorsitzende der Umweltschutzorganisation BUND in Nordrhein-Westfalen, im Dlf. So versiegele man allein in NRW im Durchschnitt pro Tag acht Hektar, also elf Fu√üballfelder, f√ºr den Bau von Siedlungen und Verkehrsfl√§chen. ‚ÄûDas sind aus unserer Sicht hausgemachte Probleme.‚Äú

Al menos 110 personas murieron en las devastadoras inundaciones que azotan partes del oeste de #Alemania y #B√©lgica, mientras contin√∫a la b√∫squeda de cientos de desaparecidos.üåßÔ∏è

Alrededor de 1.300 personas segu√≠an desaparecidas en Alemania, dijeron las autoridades el jueves 15 de julio en la noche, aunque advirtieron que la elevada cifra podr√≠a deberse a la duplicaci√≥n de datos y a los problemas para dar con ellas por cortes en carreteras y conexiones telef√≥nicas.

Description:
Deforestation and climate change are altering the Amazon rainforest's ability to soak up carbon, according to a new study.
 
Scientists say the south-east region is worst-affected, with higher rates of tree loss and an increasing number of fires.
 
The lands and forests of the Earth act like a sponge in soaking up harmful greenhouse gases, like carbon dioxide, which damage the atmosphere.
 
The researchers say "this is very bad news for everybody but mainly for Brazil," as it is "accelerating climate change".

Description:
‚ÄúClimate chance isn‚Äôt abstract anymore. We are experiencing it up close and painfully.‚Äù

These photos show Bad Neuenahr-Ahrweiler in the German state of Rhineland-Palatinate before and after catastrophic flooding. Around 1,300 people are unaccounted for in the district, the regional administration said on Friday.

‚ÄúI fear that we will only see the full extent of the disaster in the coming days," German chancellor Angela Merkel, said from Washington late on Thursday, calling it a day ‚Äúcharacterised by fear, by despair, by suffering‚Äù.

The death toll from the floods in Germany and Belgium have risen to more than 100.

In Germany, parts of Rhineland-Palatinate and North Rhine-Westphalia were inundated with 148 litres of rain per sq metre within 48 hours in an area of the country that usually sees about 80 litres in the whole of July.

Authorities said 93 people had died in the two states, including at least nine residents of an assisted living facility for people with disabilities in Rhineland-Palatinate.

Belgian authorities said on Friday morning the country‚Äôs death toll had risen to 12. Switzerland, Luxembourg and the Netherlands have also been severely affected by flooding, but have so far reported no loss of life.

The intensity and scale of the devastation this week have shocked climate scientists, who did not expect records to be broken this much, over such a wide area or this soon.

After the deadly heatwave in the US and Canada, where temperatures rose above 49.6C two weeks ago, the deluge in central Europe has raised fears that human-caused climate disruption is making extreme weather even worse than predicted.

Malu Dreyer, the governor of Rhineland-Palatinate, said the disaster showed the need to speed up efforts to curb global warming. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve experienced droughts, heavy rain and flooding events several years in a row, including in our state,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúClimate chance isn‚Äôt abstract anymore. We are experiencing it up close and painfully.‚Äù

Click the link in bio to read more.

Description:
At least 93 people have died and 1,300 have been reported missing in Germany, following heavy flooding across western Europe.

Extreme rainfall has seen the Rhine and other rivers break their banks - sweeping away houses, and knocking out power and mobile networks.

German Chancellor Angela Merkel has called the flooding a "catastrophe", saying houses have become "death traps".

The army has been deployed to help rescue efforts.

Neighbouring countries have also seen flooding, with Belgium reporting at least 12 deaths.

Further rainfall is expected.

Earlier this week, the European Flood Awareness System (EFAS) issued an extreme flood warning.

German local authorities have been criticised for not responding to the warning with evacuations.

As the climate crisis worsens, experts say extreme weather events like this will become more frequent and severe.

Description: More than a third of Earth's tropical rainforests are "completely gone," and half of what remains is in the Amazon Rainforest. But now, parts of that jungle are in jeopardy, as deforestation and climate change are ruining its ability to absorb carbon dioxide ‚Äì which is vital for the planet's future. Scientists say it's a "really big warning," and if steps aren't made soon to fix it, "we're going to be in more trouble."
ImageText: " It's a really big warning that we're seeing happening over a really pretty significant area. And if we don't take steps now to try and adjust our policies on both deforestation and emissions reduction from fossil fuel burning, things are going to get worse. JOHN MILLER, AMAZON RESEARCHER

Description:
For the first time ever, scientists have confirmed the Amazon rainforest is now emitting more carbon dioxide than it is able to absorb.

The giant forest had previously been a carbon sink, absorbing the emissions driving the climate crisis, but is now causing its acceleration, researchers said.

The emissions amount to a billion tonnes of carbon dioxide a year, according to a study. Most are caused by fires, many deliberately set to clear land for beef and soy production. But even without fires, hotter temperatures and droughts mean the south-eastern Amazon has become a source of CO2, rather than a sink.

Growing trees and plants have taken up about a quarter of all fossil fuel emissions since 1960, with the Amazon playing a major role as the largest tropical forest. Losing the Amazon‚Äôs power to capture CO2 is a stark warning that slashing emissions from fossil fuels is more urgent than ever, scientists said.

The government of Brazil‚Äôs president, Jair Bolsonaro, has been harshly criticised for encouraging more deforestation, which has surged to a 12-year high, while fires hit their highest level in June since 2007.

#amazon #amazonrainforest #amazonrainforestemergency #climatechange #climatecrisis #environment #deforestation #co2 #carbonemissions #globalwarming #FaceTheClimateEmergency #EcologicalBreakdown

Description:
Im Dezember 2019 Jahr hatte EU-Kommissionspr√§sident Ursula von der Leyen (CDU) das ambitionierte Projekt ‚ÄûEuropean Green Deal‚Äú zur Bek√§mpfung der Erderw√§rmung vorgestellt, das eine klimaneutrale EU bis zum Jahr 2050 anstrebt. Nun k√ºmmert sich die EU-Kommission zun√§chst um ein Etappenziel auf dem Weg zur Klimaneutralit√§t: die Reduktion der CO2-Emissionen um 55 Prozent bis zum Jahr 2030 (im Vergleich zum Jahr 1990). 

Der Weg, wie dieses 55-Prozent-Reduktionsziel erreicht werden soll, stand lange Zeit nicht fest ‚Äì bis jetzt. Mit dem Gesetzespaket ‚ÄûFit f√ºr 55‚Äú legt die EU-Kommission nun zw√∂lf konkrete Vorschl√§ge vor, wie die europ√§ische Wirtschaft klimafreundlich umgebaut werden kann und was die einzelnen Sektoren der Wirtschaft daf√ºr tun sollten. 

Manche Instrumente sind neu, andere Vorhaben bauen auf bestehender Klimaschutz-Gesetzgebung auf. Sie sind bisher nur teilweise schon genauer bekannt. Vorgesehen sind neue Steuern und Z√∂lle, das faktische Ende des Verbrennermotors und eine Kerosinsteuer f√ºr innereurop√§ische Fl√ºge sowie eine Abgabe f√ºr Importe aus Drittl√§ndern, die klimasch√§dlicher produzieren als die EU. Insbesondere die geplante Ausweitung des Emmissionshandels wird Auswirkungen auf Verbraucherinnen und Verbraucher in der EU haben.

EU-Kommissionspr√§sidentin von der Leyen sagte bei der Vorstellung des ‚ÄûFit for 55‚Äú-Pakets am 14. Juli 2021 in Br√ºssel, der Klimawandel zwinge die europ√§ischen Staaten dazu, ihre Wirtschaft grundlegend umzubauen. Nur mit einer nachhaltigen Kreislaufwirtschaft k√∂nne man das Ziel eines klimaneutralen Kontinents erreichen. 

Die Umsetzung der Klimaschutzpl√§ne wird zum Teil √ºber Jahre gestreckt, um √úbergangsfristen zu gew√§hrleisten. Auch der Gesetzgebungsprozess selbst wird sich voraussichtlich noch Jahre hinziehen, denn nun beraten zun√§chst die Mitgliedsstaaten und das EU-Parlament dar√ºber. Manche osteurop√§ische L√§nder, die sich nur gegen Widerstand zum 55-Prozent-Ziel bekannt haben, werden m√∂glicherweise auf finanzielle Hilfen pochen.

Den kompletten Beitrag finden Sie √ºber den Link in der Bio.

#fitforfifty50 #klimawandel #klimakrise #eu #nachhaltigkeit #fridaysforfuture

Description:
It's been reported that the highest ever daily average temperature on Earth has been recorded in Death Valley, California, at 54¬∞C.

The Washington Post said that at dawn on Sunday, the low temperature recorded was 42¬∞C and by late afternoon the temperature rose to 54¬∞C¬†- making the day‚Äôs average temperature the highest ever recorded on this planet.¬†

However the temperature still needs to be verified by the World Meteorological Organization.

The US West has experienced extreme weather for some weeks now, and more than 60 active large wildfires are currently burning in the West and Alaska.

The wildfires were sparked by lightening strikes, which were triggered by the recording breaking heat.

Scientists say climate change has made the West much warmer and drier and they warn that weather will get more extreme as the world warms.

Description:
La #desalaci√≥n de #agua de #mar para potenciar distintas actividades no es nueva, y ya en el Siglo I el historiador Plinio el Viejo la incluy√≥ en su Enciclopedia de Historia Natural. Hoy esta pr√°ctica se realiza en 177 pa√≠ses, y en que se procesan 93 millones de metros c√∫bicos al d√≠a.

Si bien ya existen 24 plantas desaladoras operativas en #Chile y otras 22 en construcci√≥n, la desalaci√≥n -orientada principalmente a actividades de alto consumo, como por ejemplo la miner√≠a- es evaluada como la soluci√≥n para otras actividades, como consumo humano y tambi√©n la agricultura, considerando que actualmente existen 4.000 proyectos de distinto tipo para ir en ayuda de la Agricultura Familiar Campesina, y no han sido suficientes para mitigar completamente la situaci√≥n de escasez h√≠drica.

El pasado 8 de julio se realiz√≥ el seminario online ‚ÄúDesalaci√≥n: la agricultura mirando al mar‚Äù, evento organizado por la Comisi√≥n Nacional de Riego (CNR), la Fundaci√≥n para la Innovaci√≥n Agraria (FIA) y la Fundaci√≥n de Comunicaciones, Capacitaci√≥n y Cultura del Agro (Fucoa).

En la actividad se analizaron las oportunidades que ofrece la desalaci√≥n como alternativa frente a la escasez h√≠drica que afecta a la agricultura. Son 104 comunas las que se mantienen bajo esta situaci√≥n, lo que equivale a un tercio del total de las comunas del pa√≠s. En tanto, se sigue registrando una menor carga natural de los acu√≠feros, debido a la menor acumulaci√≥n de nieve en la cordillera y menos lluvia durante el invierno.

Por Tatiana Hern√°ndez üñäüì∞

Description:
As wildfires burn throughout the US west on the heels of record heatwaves, experts are warning that the region is caught in a vicious feedback cycle of extreme heat, drought and fire, all amplified by the climate crisis.

More than 60 wildfires were burning across at least 10 states in the parched American west on Tuesday, with the largest, in Oregon, consuming an area nearly twice the size of Portland.

The fires erupted as the west was in the grip of the second bout of dangerously high temperatures in just a few weeks.

The fires have torched homes and forced thousands to evacuate from Alaska to Wyoming, according to the National Interagency Fire Center. Arizona, Idaho and Montana accounted for more than half of the large active fires.

The July heatwave follows an unusual June siege of broiling temperatures in the west and comes amid worsening drought conditions throughout the region.

Click the link in bio to listen to our latest podcast on how this heatwave forcing America to confront climate reality.

Video courtesy of NOAA

Millones de mejillones y almejas cocidos en plena playa por la ola de calor en Canad√°

La devastadora ola de calor vivida en la Columbia Brit√°nica, en Canad√°, ha provocado la muerte de una forma masiva de mejillones, almejas y otros animales marinos que viven en las playas del oeste canadiense.

As√≠ lo ha revelado Christopher Harley, profesor del departamento de zoolog√≠a de la Universidad de Columbia Brit√°nica. √âl mismo encontr√≥ innumerables mejillones muertos abiertos y pudri√©ndose en sus conchas en la playa de Kitsilano, a pocos metros de su residencia en Vancouver, como los de esta imagen que ha compartido.

Harley estudia los efectos del cambio clim√°tico en la ecolog√≠a de las costas rocosas donde viven almejas, mejillones y estrellas de mar, por lo que quer√≠a ver c√≥mo les estaba afectando a los invertebrados marinos la ola de calor r√©cord que azot√≥ la zona del 26 al 28 de junio.

El experto, que no esperaba encontrar una imagen tan devastadora, estima que millones de estos animales, e incluso miles de millones, podr√≠an haber muerto por el calor como si se hubieran cocido.

Description:
Last month was the hottest June on record in North America. 

More than 1,200 daily temperature records were set in the final week alone. But there was an even greater number of daily records set by a different ‚Äî and maybe more dangerous ‚Äî measure: overnight temperatures. 1,503 records were broken that same week. The higher nighttime temperatures are part of a global trend fueled by climate change.

The extreme temperatures that scorched the Pacific Northwest in late June led to nearly 200 deaths in Oregon and Washington State as people struggled to keep cool in poorly air-conditioned homes, on the street and in fields and warehouses.

The same ‚Äúheat dome‚Äù effect that enveloped the Northwest ‚Äî in which hot, dry ground traps heat and accelerates rising temperatures ‚Äî descended on California and parts of the Southwest this weekend. The temperature in Death Valley reached 130 degrees Fahrenheit, one of the highest temperatures ever recorded on Earth, matching a similar one from August 2020.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about why these record temperatures are so dangerous.

El ministro de Agricultura, Luis Planas, ha se√±alado que considera la campa√±a "tan err√≥nea como la de 'el az√∫car mata'" y pedido "respeto al sector ganadero", mientras que el presidente del Gobierno, Pedro S√°nchez, quiso zanjar la pol√©mica diciendo que¬†"un chulet√≥n al punto es imbatible".

La Organizaci√≥n Mundial de la Salud y la Agencia Espa√±ola de Consumo, Seguridad Alimentaria y Nutrici√≥n recomiendan¬†un "consumo moderado" de carne roja (ternera, cerdo, cordero y cabra) y procesada (salchichas y resto de embutidos) para reducir el riesgo de problemas de salud.¬†En t√©rminos de impacto ambiental, la Uni√≥n Europea reconoce que, si bien nuestro continente ha reducido un 20% las emisiones agr√≠colas desde 1990 [en Espa√±a,¬†las emisiones de la ganader√≠a suponen actualmente el 9% del total], los sistemas alimentarios siguen siendo "uno de los principales impulsores del cambio clim√°tico y la degradaci√≥n ambiental".¬†

Description:
Giant pandas are no longer endangered in the wild, but they are still vulnerable with a population outside captivity of 1,800, Chinese officials have said after years of conservation efforts.

The head of the environment ministry‚Äôs department of nature and ecology conservation, Cui Shuhong, said the reclassification was the result of ‚Äúimproved living conditions and China‚Äôs efforts in keeping their habitats integrated‚Äù.

He said the announcement reflected China‚Äôs national efforts to preserve biodiversity in recent years. The authorities have worked to expand giant pandas‚Äô habitats and replanted bamboo forests to feed them.

The number of Siberian tigers, amur leopards, Asian elephants and crested ibis have also ‚Äúvisibly increased‚Äù as a result of continuing conservation efforts in recent years, Cui told a press conference this week.

The decision by China‚Äôs own conservation authority comes five years after the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) removed giant pandas from its endangered species list and classified them as vulnerable.

This week‚Äôs announcement was met with delight on social media. Related hashtags on Weibo have been read nearly 10m times.

Pandas, however, still face long-term threats. IUCN has said climate change could destroy more than 35% of their bamboo habitat in the next 80 years.

#panda #pandas #China #conservation #giantpanda #endangered #vulnerable #specieswatch #animals #wildlife #habitat #pandabear #endangeredspecies #nature #wildlifeconservation #bamboo

Description:
Chicago is a city built for a different time. The time before climate change.‚Å£
‚Å£
Throughout its first two centuries, Chicago became famous as a city that pushed water around like no other. Now, in our warming world, the water is pushing back.‚Å£
‚Å£
Climate change has started pushing Lake Michigan‚Äôs water levels toward uncharted territory as patterns of rain, snowfall and evaporation are transformed by the warming world. The lake‚Äôs high-water cycles are threatening to go higher; the lows lower. Already, the swings between the two show signs of happening faster than any time in recorded history.‚Å£
‚Å£
‚ÄúThere are buildings just teetering on the edge of the lake,‚Äù said Josh Ellis, a former vice president of the Metropolitan Planning Council, an 87-year-old nonprofit in Chicago. ‚ÄúA few years ago, they had a beach. Now the water is lapping at their foundations. This is an existential problem for those neighborhoods and, ultimately, for the city.‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£
Tap the link in our bio to read more about how the climate crisis haunts Chicago‚Äôs future. Photos and video by @_lyndonfrench_

Description:
Mussels on Canada's coast were effectively cooked by the abnormally warm water following last week's record heatwave.

More than 1 billion marine animals along Canada‚Äôs Pacific coast are likely to have died, experts warn, highlighting the vulnerability of ecosystems that aren't used to such extreme temperatures.

The ‚Äúheat dome‚Äù that settled over western Canada and the north-western US for five days pushed temperatures in communities along the coast to 40C (104F) ‚Äì shattering longstanding records and offering little respite for days.

The intense and unrelenting heat is believed to have killed as many as 500 people in the province of British Columbia and contributed to the hundreds of wildfires currently burning across the area.

Christopher Harley, a marine biologist at the University of British Columbia who calculated the 1 billion figure, said: ‚ÄúThe shore doesn‚Äôt usually crunch when you walk on it. But there were so many empty mussel shells lying everywhere that you just couldn‚Äôt avoid stepping on dead animals while walking around."

Harley was struck by the smell of rotting mussels. Snails, sea stars and clams were decaying in the shallow water. ‚ÄúIt was an overpowering, visceral experience,‚Äù he said.

The mass death of shellfish would temporarily affect water quality because mussels and clams help filter the sea, Harley said, keeping it clear enough that sunlight reaches the eelgrass beds while also creating habitats for other species.

Experts have cautioned that the province needs to adapt to the reality that sudden and sustained heatwaves are likely to become more common as a result of climate change.

#globalwarming #climatechange #heatwave #heatwaves #globalheating #environment #nature #climatecrisis #marinelife #biodiversity #climateemergency #climatechangeisreal #ocean #conservation #wildlife #science #heatdome #Canada #BritishColumbia #Vancouver
ImageText: 1bn marine animals likely killed on Canada coast after record heatwave

Cal Fire department says the state's fire season is starting earlier and ending later each year ‚Äì and climate change is considered a key driver of the trend.

Description:
‚Å†The United States is poised for the birth of a brand new industry, one that will invest tens of billions of dollars in our economy, reshape our coastal communities, and one that could be one of the sharpest knives in our fight against climate change: offshore wind. ‚Å†
‚Å†
It may also represent the first time truly massive companies have retooled their entire business models to train their sights at the climate problem. And that last point raises sticky questions about how capitalism - which, you could argue, got us into this whole climate mess - could be the best path out of the worst impacts of climate change.‚Å†
‚Å†
The federal government has sold 16 lease areas to wind developers off the east coast, but so far, only 11 projects have landed contracts to sell their electricity to coastal states. ‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
The average body size of humans has fluctuated significantly over the last million years and is linked to a changing climate, according to research published Thursday in the journal Nature Communications. Colder, harsher climates were linked to larger bodies, while warmer climates were linked to smaller bodies, the team found. ‚ÄúLarger bodies can buffer individuals from cold temperatures ‚Äì the larger you are, the smaller your surface compared to your volume, so you conserve heat more efficiently,‚Äù said Andrea Manica, a professor of evolutionary ecology at the University of Cambridge.‚Å†
‚Å†
(üì∏: Dr. Manuel Will)
ImageText: Climate change altered the size of human bodies, new research finds CNN

Description:
The extraordinary heat wave that scorched the Pacific Northwest last week would almost certainly not have occurred without global warming, an international team of climate researchers said Wednesday.

Temperatures were so extreme ‚Äî including readings of 116 degrees Fahrenheit in Portland, Oregon, and a Canadian record of 121 in British Columbia ‚Äî that the researchers had difficulty saying just how rare the heat wave was. But they estimated that in any given year there was only a 0.1 percent chance of such an intense heat wave occurring.

‚ÄúAlthough it was a rare event, it would have been virtually impossible without climate change,‚Äù said Geert Jan van Oldenborgh of the Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute, who conducted the study with 26 other scientists. Friederike Otto, one of the researchers from Oxford University in England, said, ‚ÄúFor heat waves, climate change is an absolute game changer.‚Äù

Temperature records for cities and towns in the region were broken, and by a much larger margin than the researchers had ever seen in a heat wave. Perhaps, they said, the climate was passing a threshold to a point where just a relatively small rise in global temperatures could greatly increase the likelihood of a big jump in extreme heat.

‚ÄúWe are worried,‚Äù van Oldenborgh said. ‚ÄúWe are much less certain about how heat waves behave than we were two weeks ago.‚Äù

Tap the link in our bio to read more about last week‚Äôs extreme heat and global warming. Photo by @ashponders
ImageText: Climate Change Drove Western Heat Wave's Extreme Records, Analysis Finds

Description:
El hielo del √Årtico retrocede con m√°s rapidez que antes
 ¬∑ El hielo del √Årtico retrocede con m√°s rapidez cada vez. Es el resultado del mayor estudio realizado hasta la fecha sobre el impacto del cambio clim√°tico en esta parte del mundo. La conclusi√≥n a la que han llegado es que la expansi√≥n del √Årtico durante los meses fr√≠os es la mitad de grande que hace unas d√©cadas, y el grosor, la mitad que hace un siglo. Estamos llegando, dicen, a un punto de no retorno. "Hay varios puntos de no retorno en el sistema clim√°tico lo que conduce a cambios repentinos, irreversibles", dice Markus Rex, l√≠der de la expedici√≥n. De seguir as√≠, que es lo m√°s previsible, el hielo desaparecer√° cada verano. Han participado m√°s de cuatrocientas personas de 40 pa√≠ses. Para obtener los datos un equipo internacional de cient√≠ficos liderados por Alemania se embarcaron en una expedici√≥n que permaneci√≥ entre el hielo desde septiembre de 2019 hasta octubre de 2020.

"Climate impacts including extreme heat, fire, and drought are hitting us now. They are like punches to our civilization and they will keep coming both faster and stronger," NASA scientist Dr. Peter Kalmus said. "These and other impacts will keep intensifying so long as we burn fossil fuels."‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
Fermenting beer produces carbon dioxide (CO2), which is usually released into the atmosphere.

To combat this, a craft brewery in Sydney has partnered with climate change scientists and developed a way to use microalgae to capture that CO2, and turn it into oxygen.

The brewers estimate their algae releases as much oxygen as two hectares of bushland.

#Australia #Sydney #BBCNews
ImageText: 13/12 Alga Co UTS Beer and algae fight climate change

Description:
Jeff Bezos has officially stepped down as the CEO of Amazon.‚Å†
‚Å†
It comes exactly 27 years after he founded the company.‚Å†
‚Å†
The 57-year-old multi-billionaire is expected to dedicate more of his time to personal projects, including space travel, fighting climate change and overseeing The Washington Post.‚Å†
‚Å†
Andy Jassy takes the helm as CEO.‚Å†
‚Å†
Amazon, which employs 1.3 million people globally and is valued at ¬£1.2 trillion, has faced global criticism of its work practices during the pandemic.‚Å†
‚Å†
In April, Mr Bezos pushed back against the criticism but said the firm needs to "do a better job for our employees".‚Å†
‚Å†
Mr Bezos will still hold a highly influential position in the company, moving to an advisory role as executive chair.

Description:
Native Americans across the U.S. are facing severe climate challenges, the newest threat in centuries of distress and dislocation. ‚Å£
‚Å£
While other communities struggle on a warming planet, Native tribes are experiencing an environmental peril exacerbated by policies ‚Äî first imposed by white settlers and later the federal government ‚Äî that forced them onto the country‚Äôs least desirable lands. Now, climate change is quickly making that marginal land uninhabitable. ‚Å£
‚Å£
In the Pacific Northwest, coastal erosion and storms are eating away at tribal land, forcing native communities to move inland. In the Southwest, severe drought means the Navajo Nation is running out of drinking water. At the edge of the Ozarks, heirloom crops are becoming harder to grow, threatening to disconnect the Cherokee from their heritage.‚Å£
‚Å£
Many tribes have been working to meet the challenges posed by the changing climate. And they have expressed hope that their concerns would be addressed by President Biden, who has committed to repairing the relationship with tribal nations. He also appointed Deb Haaland, the first Indigenous cabinet secretary, to run the Interior Department.‚Å£
‚Å£
Biden‚Äôs most ambitious climate proposal, written into his $2 trillion infrastructure plan, included just two references to tribal lands: unspecified money for water projects and relocation of the most vulnerable tribes. ‚Å£
‚Å£
‚ÄúThe stakes are very, very high,‚Äù said Fawn Sharp, president of the National Congress of American Indians. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre running out of time.‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£
Tap the link in our bio to read more about how climate change is affecting Native Americans. Photos by @josue_foto, @ashadamsphoto and @kalengoodluck

Description:
Tackling climate change will mean a change to "the way we do things", the Queen has said as she met experts on global warming in Edinburgh, Scotland.

The Queen and the Princess Royal visited the Edinburgh Climate Change Institute ahead of the COP26 climate summit in Glasgow in November.
 
Regarding the impact of tackling the global issue, she said: "It does mean we are going to have to change the way we do things really, in the end."

Click the link in our bio to find out more about her traditional Royal Week visit to Scotland.

Description:
An area of the Arctic Ocean critical for the survival of polar bears is fast becoming vulnerable to climate change, a new study has found.

The region, to the north of Greenland dubbed the "last ice area", had been expected to stay frozen far longer than other parts of the Arctic, however high winds and rising temperatures is changing that.
 
Polar bears in the area use the ice to hunt for seals who build dens to raise their young on the frozen water.
 
Tap the link in bio to read more about the study and how climate change will impact the animals that live there.
 
(üì∑PA)
 
#PolarBears #ClimateChange #BBCNews

Description:
At least 486 sudden deaths were reported over five days during British Columbia‚Äôs unprecedented heatwave - suggesting the extreme weather that affected western Canada in recent days was far deadlier than initially believed.

Typically, 165 sudden deaths would occur in the province over that period, the province‚Äôs chief coroner said, suggesting more than 300 deaths could be attributed to the heat. The new tally, announced on Wednesday, marks a 195% increase over normal years.

‚ÄúOur thoughts are with people who have lost loved ones‚Äù said prime minister Justin Trudeau, warning the blistering temperatures in a region of the country ill-prepared for such heat was a reminder of the need to address climate change.

Many of those who died over the five day period were seniors, lived alone and were found in residences that were hot and not well ventilated, officials said.

The town of Lytton, British Columbia reached 49.5C (121.1F) on Tuesday, smashing the national record three days in a row. Lytton was evacuated on last night after a fire hit the town and threatened residential buildings.

The ‚Äúheat dome‚Äù that blanketed much of western Canada and the United States broke 103 heat records across British Columbia, Alberta, Yukon and Northwest Territories on Monday.

Experts say the heat was so dangerous because it persisted throughout the night in many communities, giving residents little relief. Because of its typically mild climate, residents along the Pacific Coast often don‚Äôt install air conditioning units.

#BCheat #heatwave #canada #climatechange #britishcolumbia #heatwave #canada #vancouver #bcweather #climatecrisis #globalheating #extremeweatherevents #heatdome

Description:
Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis told Fox News on Wednesday that global warming does not appear to have had an impact on the tragic condominium collapse in Surfside in Miami-Dade County, Fla. last week.

At least 145 people remain missing with 18 confirmed dead from the collapse. DeSantis told "The Story" he wants an investigation into what truly caused the tragedy.

On Tuesday, Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm suggested during a TV interview that global warming and ocean water levels could have played a part in the destruction at Champlain Towers South, located along the famous beachfront strip, A1A.

DeSantis pushed back on Granholm on Wednesday, remarking that while the recovery effort is foremost at this time, a study must be done to see if the cause of the collapse has implications for other Florida properties.

"What we're not going to do is use this to advance any pre-existing agenda. There's no agenda here," he said.

Go to the link in our bio for more on this story.
ImageText: Sipa ia AP mages r DeSantis: we're not going to use this tragedy 'to advance any pre-existing agenda'

Description:
Dozens have died during a heatwave in the Pacific Northwest, over the last four days.

From Friday to Monday there were 233 reported deaths in the Canadian province of British Columbia, as temperatures hit a record high of 46.6C (115.88F) - almost double the expected number of deaths for a four-day period in the region.

The extreme weather has also impacted transport links, as train cables have melted and roads have cracked due to the high temperatures.

Meteorologists say the heatwave has been caused by a dome of high pressure over the Northwest and worsened by human-caused climate change, which is making such extreme weather events more likely and more intense.

During an infrastructure speech in Wisconsin, President Joe Biden commented on the Pacific Northwest heatwave: ‚ÄúAnybody ever believe you‚Äôd turn on the news and see it‚Äôs 116 degrees in Portland Oregon? 116 degrees."

The President made a dig at climate change deniers and added: ‚ÄúBut don‚Äôt worry, there is no global warming because it‚Äôs just a figment of our imaginations.‚Äù

Description:
Der Klimaforscher Michael E. Mann hat in seinem neuen Buch "Propagandaschlacht ums Klima. Wie wir die Anstifter klimapolitischer Unt√§tigkeit besiegen" eine gute Nachricht: Klimakrisen-Leugner werden weniger. Zumindest leugne kaum noch jemand Ernstzunehmendes die Klimakrise.
.
Die schlechte Nachricht: Die Bremser haben jetzt einfach ihre Taktik ge√§ndert. Sie leugnen nicht mehr, sie lenken ab. Sie tun alles, um nichts tun zu m√ºssen. Mann nennt sie deshalb: die Tatenlosen. Ihren Einfluss spielten sie aus √ºber konservative Politiker, √ºber Medien, aber auch √ºber offene oder verdeckte Social-Media-Kampagnen.
.
Dazu z√§hlt Michael E. Mann nicht nur die gro√üen Energiekonzerne, sondern auch das Kohleexportland Australien, die √ñlf√∂rderl√§nder Saudi-Arabien und Russland. Besonders Russland habe viel zu verlieren:

‚ÄûDass Russland weiterhin soziale Medien nutzt, um die amerikanische √ñffentlichkeit zu manipulieren, ist bekannt. Was weniger Aufmerksamkeit erregt hat, ist die Frage nach dem Warum. Die russische Wirtschaft ist von der fortgesetzten F√∂rderung und Monetarisierung von Russlands prim√§rem Wirtschaftsgut ‚Äì den √ñlreserven ‚Äì abh√§ngig.‚Äú
.
Das gro√üe Ziel der tatenlosen Akteure: verhindern, dass Gesetze kommen, die die Wirtschaft entschieden dekarbonisieren; vor allem mit einem CO2-Preis, der der Freisetzung von klimasch√§dlichen Gasen ein Preisschild aufklebt.

Und hier ist die Wahl der Mittel extrem interessant. Diese hat Michael E. Mann analysiert.
.

Los proyectos en desarrollo eliminar√°n solo una fracci√≥n de la cantidad de di√≥xido de carbono (CO2) del aire que debe extraerse para 2025 para cumplir con el objetivo clim√°tico global de Par√≠s y evitar un calentamiento catastr√≥fico, seg√∫n un estudio.

M√°s de 190 pa√≠ses firmaron el acuerdo de Par√≠sdise√±ado para limitar el calentamiento global a 1,5 grados Celsius, pero pese a las promesas de grandes reducciones en las emisiones muchos cient√≠ficos creen que se necesitar√°n de tecnolog√≠as para alcanzar el objetivo.

"Sin acciones para entregar una gigatonelada (Gt) de emisiones negativas a nivel mundial para 2025, mantener el calentamiento global dentro del objetivo del Acuerdo de Par√≠s de 1,5¬∞C ser√° imposible", dijo el informe de la Coalici√≥n por las Emisiones Negativas (CNE, por sus siglas en ingl√©s) y la consultora McKinsey.

Description:
Una ola de calor con temperaturas "hist√≥ricas" afecta el oeste de Canad√° y Estados Unidos.

El calor extremo, rozando los 48 grados, ha obligado a cerrar escuelas y centros de vacunaci√≥n. Incluso algunos ciudadanos se han tenido que refugiar en centros de "refrigerio".

En Portland (Oreg√≥n) y Seattle (Washington), dos grandes ciudades del noroeste de Estados Unidos conocidas por sus climas fr√≠os y h√∫medos, la temperatura alcanz√≥ su nivel m√°s alto jam√°s registrado desde que comenzaron los archivos, en 1940. El lunes por la tarde fue de 46,1 grados Celsius en el aeropuerto de Portland (despu√©s de un r√©cord de 44,4 grados el d√≠a anterior) y de 41,6 grados en Seattle, seg√∫n las lecturas del Servicio Meteorol√≥gico de Estados Unidos (NWS).

Pero es el oeste de Canad√° el que se lleva la palma. En Lytton, un pueblo al noreste de Vancouver, el r√©cord establecido el d√≠a anterior se rompi√≥ nuevamente: el mercurio subi√≥ el lunes a 47,9 grados. La temperatura m√°s alta jam√°s registrada en Canad√° antes de esta ola de calor fue de 45 grados en 1937.

La intensidad de esta "c√∫pula de calor" es "tan estad√≠sticamente rara que solo deber√≠a producirse una vez cada miles de a√±os, pero el cambio clim√°tico inducido por el hombre ha hecho que este tipo de eventos excepcionales sea cada vez m√°s probable", afirman especialistas climatol√≥gicos.

Description:
Three years after she shocked the Democratic establishment and won her New York primary, AOC is continuing to hold her party to account ‚Äì and not just from the inside. 

On Monday she joined a lively climate protest outside the White House. Organized by the Sunrise Movement, activists and a handful of Democratic politicians, including Cori Bush and Jamaal Bowma,n marched to put pressure on Joe Biden, who they believe is not doing enough to tackle the climate crisis.

Along with other progressive Democrats, they've been left disappointed by the infrastructure deal announced by the president last week which only includes trimmed down funding for climate change protections.

Responding to protesters chanting "AOC!", Ocasio-Cortez responded with her own chant ‚Äì "GND!" ‚Äì referencing the Green New Deal climate resolution that she introduced in 2019 with the Democratic senator Ed Markey (and recently re-introduced).

‚ÄúThey want you to think, ‚ÄòOh, this is a new idea, this is too ambitious, this is too crazy.‚Äô How about this? The last time we introduced the Civilian Climate Corps in this country, we hired and mobilized a quarter-million people in three months,‚Äù Ocasio-Cortez told the crowd, referring to the program that was introduced under Franklin D Roosevelt's tranformative New Deal in 1933.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to get that into this infrastructure bill,‚Äù she added.

Photo: Evelyn Hockstein/Reuters

Description:
@danieljaduejadue ha presentado su programa presidencial. Quiz√°s con la excepci√≥n de la propuesta #tributaria, representa una propuesta moderada.  Lleva como t√≠tulo ‚ÄúPrograma de #gobierno para un #Chile digno, verde y soberano, #plurinacional e #intercultural, #feminista y #paritario‚Äù. La ausencia del concepto ‚Äú#descentralizaci√≥n‚Äù en el t√≠tulo se traduce en propuestas muy conservadoras en el campo de la #regionalizaci√≥n. No hay medidas relevantes que vayan m√°s all√° de lo avanzado actualmente. El concepto ‚Äúverde‚Äù resulta insuficiente para dar cuenta de la magnitud del desaf√≠o del #cambioclim√°tico y de la tarea de entender la #naturaleza como sujeto de derechos. El #feminismo, que s√≠ aparece en el t√≠tulo, se diluye a lo largo del programa. M√°s a√∫n, el documento ‚Äúchutea al c√≥rner‚Äù la necesidad de paridad en los cargos p√∫blicos, proponiendo una ley que consagre, para el 2030, que ning√∫n sexo podr√° superar el 60% en los primeros niveles jer√°rquicos de las instituciones del #PoderEjecutivo central (pp. 183-184).

Se trata de un programa plano que hace dif√≠cil identificar las prioridades. Carece de un relato que articule las diferentes propuestas, muchas de las cuales est√°n desarrolladas con un detalle que acent√∫a la dificultad de identificar las l√≠neas matrices del programa. Este problema queda en evidencia en la entrevista con El Mercurio (20.6.2021, pp. B.6 y B.7) del jefe del programa #econ√≥mico, #Ram√≥nL√≥pez. No hay en la entrevista (que se leer√° mucho m√°s que el largo texto del programa, que s√≠ alude a esta cuesti√≥n) pr√°cticamente alusi√≥n alguna al cambio del modelo de desarrollo; tampoco a la prioridad que debe tener la lucha contra el cambio clim√°tico, ni a la necesidad de repensar la #econom√≠a a partir del cuidado, de manera de pensar simult√°neamente la producci√≥n, articulada, con la reproducci√≥n de la vida. Si se suman estos diversos elementos, se infiere que se trata de una mirada program√°tica tradicional, que no termina de captar el sentido profundo del escenario surgido del 18/O.

Por Eugenio Rivera üñäüíª

Dem Gericht ging das erste Gesetz, das 2019 beschlossen worden war, nicht weit genug.

Description:
Bis 2045 soll die Bundesrepublik nach dem Willen der schwarz-roten Koalition klimaneutral sein. Auf wichtige Eckpunkte f√ºr den Weg dahin haben sich Union und SPD nun geeinigt ‚Äì noch in dieser Woche soll die Novelle des Bundesklimaschutzgesetzes im Bundesrat verabschiedet werden. 

Es sieht mehr Anreize f√ºr gr√ºnen Wasserstoff vor und die Ziele f√ºr Wind- und Solarenergie sind zumindest f√ºr das kommende Jahr verabredet. Au√üerdem sollen Genehmigungsverfahren vereinfacht werden ‚Äì etwa f√ºr das Repowering alter Anlagen.

Keine Einigung gab es hingegen bei der von der SPD geforderten Aufteilung des CO2-Preises bei den Heizkosten zwischen Mietern und Vermietern. Auch bei der CO2-Bepreisung bleibt es beim bisher festgelegten Preissteigerungspfad, eine Pflicht f√ºr Solard√§cher wird es offenbar nicht geben, ebenso wenig ein Tempolimit.

Das von Union und SPD beschlossene Klimapaket sei ‚Äûbei weitem nicht ausreichend‚Äú, um die deutschen Klimaziele zu erreichen, kritisiert Patrick Graichen vom Thinktank Agora Energiewende im Dlf. Dringende Themen des Klimaschutzes w√ºrden wieder vertagt und in die n√§chsten Koalitionsverhandlungen geschoben.

Das vollst√§ndige Interview finden Sie √ºber den Link in der Bio.

 
#deutschlandfunk #dlf #klimaneutralit√§t #winstrom #solastrom #co2 #strompreis #koalition #spd #cdu @cdu @spdde #umwwelt #klimakrise #klimaschutz

Description:
A panel of 12 lawyers from around the world has proposed a legal definition for a new crime that the lawyers want to see outlawed internationally: ecocide, or widespread destruction of the environment.‚Å†
‚Å†
The definition‚Äôs unveiling on Tuesday is the first major step in a global campaign aimed at preventing environmental catastrophes like the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, the deforestation of the Amazon rainforest ‚Äî and, more broadly, climate change.‚Å†
‚Å†
If the campaign to criminalize ecocide succeeds, the International Criminal Court would be able to hold accountable those most responsible for major ecological harms, including business and government leaders.‚Å†
‚Å†
See more at the link in our bio. ‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
The Great Barrier Reef could have its prestigious World Heritage status downgraded after a report from the U.N. said Australia wasn't doing enough to protect it from the effects of climate change.‚Å†
‚Å†
The U.N. World Heritage Committee's draft report Monday found that there was "no possible doubt" that the network of colorful corals off Australia's northeast coast was "facing ascertained danger" due to climate change.‚Å†
‚Å†
Australia, which attracts millions of snorkeling tourists and beachgoers each year, vowed Tuesday to fight any change of status that could hurt its travel industry or see the U.N. step in to take tougher measures to reduce the country's greenhouse gas emissions.‚Å†
‚Å†
"This is a complete subversion of normal process," Australian Environment Minister Sussan Ley said. "The reef is an icon internationally and we are here to fight for the reef and we are here to challenge the decision."‚Å†
See more at the link in our bio. ‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
The United Nations says the Great Barrier Reef has suffered such extensive damage that it should be listed as "in danger." The warning prompted an immediate rejection from the Australian government. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The UNESCO committee warned Tuesday that "urgent" action is needed to combat the effects of climate change and preserve the remaining coral. The designation could mean the world's largest coral reef system loses its status as a UNESCO World Heritage Site ‚Äî which could significantly impact tourism and Australia's economy.‚Å†
‚Å†
Head to the link in our bio for the reaction. ‚Å†
ImageText: Australia rejects U.N. warning to list Great Barrier Reef as "in danger"

Description:
The Great Barrier Reef should be put on a list of World Heritage Sites that are "in danger" due to climate change, Unesco has said.

It urged Australia to take "accelerated action" on global warming - but the government said it would "strongly oppose" the move.

The UN's cultural body says the world's biggest coral reef system should be placed on the list at a meeting next month.

The reef, stretching for 2,300km (1,400 miles) off Australia's north-east coast, gained World Heritage ranking in 1981 for its "enormous scientific and intrinsic importance".

For more on the ongoing dispute between Unesco and the Australian government over the site‚Äôs status, read the link in our bio.

(üì∏Getty)

#BBCNews #GreatBarrierReef #Oceanography #MarineBiology
ImageText: BBC NEWS Great Barrier Reef should be listed as 'in danger,' Unesco says

Fermin Muguruza, Ska-P, La Polla Records, La Vela Puerca, Banda Bassotti, Miguel R√≠os, Rozal√©n o Hamlet son alguno de los firmantes. Un grupo de m√∫sicos han presentado y le√≠do el texto este lunes en el Auditorio Marcelino Camacho de Comisiones Obreras de Madrid, con perspectivas de crear una asociaci√≥n para actuar y concienciar sobre la xenofobia, el machismo, el negacionismo del cambio clim√°tico y las intolerancia de las nuevas (pero viejas) posturas fascistas.

Mariano Muniesa de Mariskalrock arrancaba el acto explicando que la iniciativa y el posicionamiento antifascista viene porque ‚Äúaunque parece que venimos de una sociedad m√°s culta y avanzada, cuando el movimiento social crece y planta cara al poder, los poderes y las √©lites econ√≥micas que son quien manejan el fascismo, tienen miedo y se movilizan, sacan fuerza e intentan parar cualquier conato de mejora social‚Äù. Muniesa considera que el rock naci√≥ precisamente como grito de libertad, ‚Äúfue la m√∫sica que estuvo en las marchas por la paz, en los movimientos contra la Guerra del Vietnam, fue banda sonora del movimiento hippy o de la reivindicaci√≥n de la sexualidad libre‚Äù.

Description:
Last week, Catholic bishops in the U.S. voted overwhelmingly to draft guidelines for the Eucharist, advancing a conservative push to deny President Biden communion over his support for abortion rights.

It was the most dramatic example of the conservative Catholic movement‚Äôs reach since President Biden was elected. But the contingent had been gaining strength throughout the Trump era, clashing with the Vatican, wresting influence away from Pope Francis‚Äô top representatives in the U.S. and further polarizing the Catholic faithful in the process. Now, American Catholics are facing an internal war over one of the church‚Äôs most sacred rituals, the Eucharist, which represents the body and blood of Christ.

Leading U.S. allies of Pope Francis sided with the Vatican‚Äôs warning against proceeding with the eucharistic document, but they were ultimately drowned out. The measure passed with a vote of 73% who approved it compared with 24% who opposed it.

That 73% represents emerging conservative momentum, at odds with Pope Francis‚Äô broader range of priorities on issues like immigration, poverty and climate change, not only among bishops but also in parishes across the country. Although the church has a hierarchical structure, bishops have significant autonomy in their own dioceses. 

‚ÄúWe are at a new moment in the pro-life movement,‚Äù Archbishop Joseph Naumann of Kansas City,  who leads the bishops‚Äô Committee on Pro-Life Activities, told the bishops. ‚ÄúThose who advocate for abortion no longer talk in the language of choice ‚Äî they talk about it as a right.‚Äù

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the rift between Catholic bishops and President Biden. Photo of President Biden greeting a priest after attending Mass at St. Joseph on the Brandywine Church, his local parish, on Saturday in Wilmington, Delaware, by @tom_brenner
ImageText: Catholic Bishops Push to Deny Biden Communion Over His Support for Abortion Rights

Description:
Schon im kommenden Jahrzehnt k√∂nnte sich die Erde im Vergleich zur vorindustriellen Zeit um 1,5 Grad Celsius erw√§rmt haben. Damit kommt ein Bereich n√§her, in dem erste Elemente im Erdsystem unumkehrbar in einen neuen Zustand kippen k√∂nnten. 

Wie der Gr√∂nl√§ndische Eisschild, dessen Abschmelzen ab einer gewissen Schwelle nicht mehr aufzuhalten ist. Wie der Amazonas-Regenwald, von dem sich der Gro√üteil in eine Savanne verwandeln k√∂nnte. Oder wie der Westantarktische Eisschild, der wom√∂glich bereits seinen Kipppunkt √ºberschritten und damit einen unumkehrbaren Meeresspiegelanstieg von dreieinhalb Metern √ºber die kommenden Jahrhunderte eingeleitet hat.

Als ob das noch nicht gen√ºgen w√ºrde, k√∂nnen sich diese einzelnen Kipppunkte auch noch gegenseitig destabilisieren: Wie bei einem Dominospiel k√∂nnte das Kippen eines Elements unter Umst√§nden weitere Elemente zum Kippen bringen. Droht irgendwann eine unkontrollierte Erderw√§rmung?

Description:
The race to become New York City‚Äôs next mayor is one of the most consequential political contests in a generation, with the recovery of the nation's largest city at stake. There are eight leading Democratic candidates (shown above in alphabetical order):

Eric Adams, 60, a former NYPD officer and current Brooklyn borough president who has advocated police reform but does not support the ‚Äúdefund the police‚Äù movement.

Shaun Donovan, 55, a veteran of the Obama and Bloomberg administrations who wants to create ‚Äú15-minute neighborhoods.‚Äù

Kathryn Garcia, 51, a respected expert in city operations who is focused on combating climate change and helping small businesses.

Raymond McGuire, 64, a former Wall Street executive running as a fiscal expert who can help the city recover from the economic woes caused by the pandemic.

Dianne Morales, 53, a former nonprofit executive who is campaigning to improve the lives of poor and working-class New Yorkers.

Scott Stringer, 61, former Manhattan borough president and a veteran of city government who is running on a progressive platform to address issues like affordable housing  and climate change.

Maya Wiley, 57, a former civil rights lawyer and former counsel to Mayor Bill de Blasio who is proposing a ‚ÄúNew Deal‚Äù for New York.

Andrew Yang, 46, a former presidential candidate who has proposed direct payments to the city's poorest.

Election Day is on Tuesday, June 22, but early voting is open in locations across the city until Sunday afternoon. Those who are registered with a political party will be able to vote for candidates for mayor, comptroller, public advocate, borough president and the City Council. There‚Äôs also a competitive Democratic primary to be Manhattan district attorney.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the candidates on this year‚Äôs ballot and to see a guide on ranked-choice voting. Photos by @jamesestrin, @hlswift, @josealvarado, @michelleagins, @jordangalephoto and @andrewseng

Description:
El v√≠deo acelerado que mejor demuestra la r√°pida p√©rdida de hielo en la Ant√°rtida.

Un estudio muestra la creciente destrucci√≥n del glaciar Isla Pine, que por s√≠ solo supone un 25% del aumento del nivel del mar por p√©rdida de hielo en la superficie terrestre.

Este v√≠deo es una nueva prueba del proceso de aceleraci√≥n del glaciar Isla Pine y, por extensi√≥n, del complejo y preocupante proceso de reducci√≥n de las masas de hielo en la superficie de la Ant√°rtida y su relaci√≥n con el cambio clim√°tico.

El glaciar Isla Pine ha perdido alrededor de una quinta parte de su superficie entre 2017 y 2020, seg√∫n confirma un estudio elaborado por el Centro de Ciencias Polares en el Laboratorio de F√≠sica Aplicada de Universidad de Washington. Nuevos datos de velocidad muestran una aceleraci√≥n mayor del 12% del deshielo del glaciar en los √∫ltimos 3 a√±os, coincidiendo con un retroceso de 19 km de la plataforma de hielo. Los autores del estudio recuerdan que "la aceleraci√≥n del glaciar Isla Pine durante las √∫ltimas d√©cadas lo ha convertido en el mayor contribuyente de la Ant√°rtida al aumento del nivel del mar".

El estudio cient√≠fico publicado adjunta como documentaci√≥n un v√≠deo en 'time lapse' que incluye im√°genes captadas desde sat√©lites del proyecto Copernicus- Sentinel, de la Agencia Espacial Europea, desde enero de 2015 hasta marzo de 2020. Durante los primeros a√±os de este per√≠odo, los sat√©lites tomaron im√°genes de alta resoluci√≥n cada 12 d√≠as; luego, durante m√°s de tres a√±os, captaron im√°genes de la plataforma de hielo cada seis d√≠as.

Description:
A woman dubbed ‚Äúthe human swan‚Äù has said she is feeling excited as she prepares to launch a world-first circumnavigation of mainland Britain to raise awareness about climate change.

Sacha Dench is making the 3,000-mile journey to mark the Cop26 UN climate change conference taking place in Glasgow later this year.

She will take off from a location near Glasgow on Monday June 21, weather permitting, in an adapted electric paramotor, flying anti-clockwise around the coast and returning to land in the area around six weeks later.

The Australian is known for global expeditions with migratory species but has turned her focus to climate change after losing her family home to bushfires last year.

On the #WeeklyClimateShow, Sky's Africa correspondent John Sparks explains what it was like to report from South Sudan witnessing climate change firsthand.

Two years of unprecedented flooding has changed the way the country looks. People of Jonglei state have managed to survive by fishing in the floodwater that now submerge their farmlands.

Bundesumweltministerin Svenja Schulze (SPD) hat den Koalitionspartner CDU/CSU im Streit um den CO2-Preis bei den Heizkosten f√ºr Mieter kritisiert. "Der Union ist die Immobilienlobby an dieser Stelle wichtiger", sagt Schulze im Interview der Woche im Deutschlandfunk. Man h√§tte die Vermieter dazu bringen m√ºssen, den CO2-Preis zu zahlen, denn die k√∂nnten ja auch √ºber die Heizung im Haus entscheiden. "Das war in der Regierung beschlossen. Das will die Union jetzt nicht mehr." Damit verfehle der CO2-Preis da schon mal seine Lenkungswirkung, kritisierte die Ministerin und sprach von einer "v√∂lligen Fehlkonstruktion an dem Punkt".

Die Bundesregierung hatte Mitte Mai einen Kompromiss verk√ºndet, nach dem k√ºnftig Vermieter die H√§lfte der Kosten f√ºr den seit 1. Januar geltenden CO2-Preis auf √ñl und Gas tragen sollen. Nach Bekanntgabe der Einigung im Mai hatten Vermieter- und Eigent√ºmerverb√§nde heftig gegen die geplante Neuregelung protestiert. Daraufhin r√ºckte die Union vom Kompromiss mit der SPD ab. Gem√§√ü der derzeit geltenden Regelung k√∂nnen Vermieter die Zusatzkosten f√ºr den CO-Preis von derzeit 25 Euro pro Tonne g√§nzlich auf Mieter abw√§lzen. Das Thema ist ‚Äì wie viele andere Ma√ünahmen f√ºr mehr Klimaschutz ‚Äì l√§ngst zum Streitfall im Bundestagswahlkampf geworden.

Es sei wichtig, so Schulze, dass der CO2-Preis "langsam verl√§sslich steigt, dass man sich darauf verlassen kann" ‚Äì etwa bei der Entscheidung √ºber den Kauf eines neuen Autos. "Diese Lenkungswirkung kann man kaputt machen, indem man alle paar Wochen √ºber einen neuen Preis diskutiert", sagt die SPD-Politikerin. "Deswegen will ich diese Verl√§sslichkeit da drin haben, damit das Instrument funktioniert. Ansonsten konterkarieren wir uns." Die derzeit laufende Debatte diskreditiere das Instrument CO2-Preis.

Das vollst√§ndige Interview der Woche mit Bundesumweltministerin Svenja Schulze (SPD) finden Sie √ºber den Link in der Bio.

Description:
En noviembre, el #ReinoUnido dar√° la bienvenida a los pa√≠ses del mundo en #Glasgow para la 26¬™ Conferencia de las Naciones Unidas sobre #CambioClim√°tico, #COP26. Esta es nuestra oportunidad de encaminar al mundo para combatir la enorme amenaza del cambio clim√°tico, construyendo un futuro m√°s limpio y brillante para todas las personas.

Sabemos lo que tenemos que hacer porque ya hemos acordado los objetivos. En 2015, el mundo firm√≥ el #AcuerdodePar√≠s, un tratado internacional para abordar la crisis clim√°tica. Ese Acuerdo nos compromete a limitar los aumentos de temperatura global muy por debajo de los dos grados, apuntando a 1,5 grados, porque la ciencia nos dice que evitar√≠a los peores efectos del cambio clim√°tico.

Cada fracci√≥n de grado marca la diferencia. Un aumento promedio de la temperatura global de dos grados, en comparaci√≥n con 1,5, har√≠a que cientos de millones de personas m√°s se vieran afectadas, y el doble de plantas y tres veces m√°s especies de insectos perder√≠an vastas extensiones de su h√°bitat.

Sin embargo, desde que se estableci√≥ el objetivo de 1,5 grados, el mundo no ha hecho lo suficiente y nuestro planeta se est√° calentando. En mi papel como presidente designado de la COP26 he sido testigo de primera mano del impacto: el derretimiento de los glaciares, la degradaci√≥n de los cultivos y los pobladores obligados a abandonar sus hogares. Si continuamos tal y como estamos, estos efectos empeorar√°n y se acelerar√°n.

El #ClimateActionTracker estima que, si los pa√≠ses cumplen con sus objetivos de reducci√≥n de emisiones, estamos en camino de incrementos de temperatura promedio de 2,4 grados. Este es un avance comparado con sus estimaciones del a√±o pasado, sin embargo, a√∫n queda mucho camino por recorrer. Para limitar el calentamiento a 1,5 grados debemos reducir a la mitad las emisiones globales para 2030. As√≠ que esta es la d√©cada decisiva.

Por Alok Sharma üñäüíª

¬øQu√© les pasa a los tiburones de arrecife de punta blanca en Malasia? Las lesiones y manchas como √©stas en la cabeza preocupan a los bi√≥logos. Cerca de la isla de Borneo unos buceadores captaron esta imagen y ahora los expertos creen que la temperatura del agua del mar puede ser la culpable. "Es casi seguro, dice este bi√≥logo marino, que el calentamiento de los oc√©anos es la causa porque el √°rea est√° protegida de la pesca y no hay industrias cercanas". Un equipo de expertos ha constatado que aqu√≠ la temperatura del agua en mayo era de 29 grados y medio. Un grado m√°s que hace 25 a√±os. "No podemos ignorar que el calentamiento del agua tiene consecuencias", dice este profesor de Estudios Veterinarios Acu√°ticos. Description:
El modelo de la Escuela de Ciencias Veterinarias de la Universidad de Sydney sugiere que la presi√≥n sobre los ecosistemas, el cambio clim√°tico y el desarrollo econ√≥mico son factores clave asociados con la diversificaci√≥n de pat√≥genos (agentes causantes de enfermedades, como virus y bacterias). Esto tiene el potencial de provocar brotes de enfermedades.

La investigaci√≥n, realizada por el Dr. Balbir B Singh, el profesor Michael Ward y el profesor asociado Navneet Dhand, publicada en la revista internacional Transboundary and Emerging Diseases, encontr√≥ una mayor diversidad de enfermedades zoon√≥ticas (enfermedades transmitidas entre animales y humanos) en pa√≠ses de ingresos m√°s altos con √°reas de tierra m√°s grandes, poblaciones humanas m√°s densas y una mayor cobertura forestal.

Los autores utilizaron 13.892 combinaciones √∫nicas de pat√≥genos y pa√≠ses y 49 variables socioecon√≥micas y ambientales para desarrollar este modelo. Se analiz√≥ informaci√≥n de 190 pa√≠ses utilizando modelos estad√≠sticos para identificar los impulsores de enfermedades emergentes y zoon√≥ticas.

El estudio tambi√©n confirma que el crecimiento y la densidad de la poblaci√≥n son los principales impulsores de la aparici√≥n de enfermedades zoon√≥ticas. La poblaci√≥n humana mundial ha aumentado de unos 1.600 millones en 1900 a unos 7.800 millones en la actualidad, lo que ejerce presi√≥n sobre los ecosistemas.

A medida que aumenta la poblaci√≥n humana, tambi√©n lo hace la demanda de vivienda. Para satisfacer esta demanda, los humanos est√°n invadiendo h√°bitats silvestres. Esto aumenta las interacciones entre la vida silvestre, los animales dom√©sticos y los seres humanos, ‚Äúlo que aumenta la posibilidad de que los insectos salten de los animales a los humanos‚Äù, sostuvo en el comunicado emanado por la instituci√≥n el profesor asociado Navneet Dhand.

The UK is woefully unprepared to deal with changes occurring to the climate, government advisers say.

Global warming will hit the UK harder than first thought, a report by the independent Climate Change Committee predicts.

This means there could be both more severe heatwaves and more flooding across the country.

They'll be a need to insulate buildings to save emissions but also protect against deadly overheating ‚Äì especially in flats.

Power cuts due to extreme weather could also hurt the country more, as the UK becomes more reliant on electricity as it makes the transition to a low-carbon economy.

Description:
La rara ‚Äònieve de sangre‚Äô podr√≠a ser clave para comprender los impactos del cambio clim√°tico.

En lo alto de los Alpes franceses la nieve, normalmente blanca, se derrite con la llegada del verano y curiosamente empieza a cambiar de color. El manto blanco empieza a adquirir un ligero tono rosado hasta alcanzar un rojo intenso. 

Este cambio, aunque sorprendente y extraordinario, tiene un origen natural. De hecho, el responsable de esta coloraci√≥n son unas microalgas que afectan a la tonalidad de la nieve mediante su pigmentaci√≥n. Esta variaci√≥n de color permite a las algas absorber mejor la luz del sol y por tanto facilita la fotos√≠ntesis.

Pero, aunque se trate de un fen√≥meno natural que ha sucedido hist√≥ricamente en algunas partes del mundo, en los √∫ltimos a√±os la aparici√≥n de estas algas se ha multiplicado. Esta floraci√≥n repentina de algas en la nieve no es algo que se haya estudiado en profundidad, pero los cient√≠ficos apuntan a que no es una buena se√±al y que el motivo podr√≠a ser el cambio clim√°tico.

Por eso, un grupo de cient√≠ficos ha viajado recientemente a los Alpes para estudiar estos misteriosos organismos. La expedici√≥n es parte del proyecto AlpAlga.

Un in√©dito trabajo conjunto elaborado por 50 l√≠deres mundiales de la Plataforma Intergubernamental de Ciencia y Pol√≠tica sobre Biodiversidad y Servicios de los Ecosistemas (#IPBES) y el Panel Intergubernamental sobre Cambio Clim√°tico (#IPCC), advirti√≥ que el #cambioclim√°tico reduce la disponibilidad de #agua y comida.

‚ÄúEl cambio clim√°tico causado por el hombre amenaza cada vez m√°s a la #naturaleza y sus contribuciones a las personas, incluida su capacidad para ayudar a mitigar el cambio clim√°tico. Cuanto m√°s se calienta el #mundo, menos comida, agua potable y otras contribuciones clave puede hacer la naturaleza a nuestras vidas, en muchas regiones‚Äù, dijo el climat√≥logo #HansOttoP√∂rtner, copresidente del Comit√© Directivo Cient√≠fico.

Cambios en #biodiversidad 

‚ÄùLos cambios en la biodiversidad afectan el #clima, especialmente a trav√©s de impactos en los ciclos del nitr√≥geno, el carbono y el agua‚Äù, advirti√≥ P√∂rtner.

‚ÄúLa evidencia es clara: todav√≠a se puede lograr un futuro global sostenible para las personas y la naturaleza, pero requiere un cambio transformador con acciones r√°pidas y de largo alcance de un tipo nunca antes intentado, basado en ambiciosas reducciones de emisiones", subray√≥.

El climat√≥logo alem√°n a√±adi√≥ que resolver algunas de las compensaciones fuertes y aparentemente inevitables entre el clima y la biodiversidad, implicar√° un profundo cambio colectivo de valores individuales y compartidos relacionados con la naturaleza, como alejarse de la concepci√≥n del progreso #econ√≥mico basado √∫nicamente en el crecimiento del #PIB, a una que equilibre los valores humanos, desarrollo con m√∫ltiples valores de la naturaleza para una buena calidad de vida, sin sobrepasar los l√≠mites biof√≠sicos y sociales.

Los autores tambi√©n indican que las acciones de enfoque restringido para combatir el cambio clim√°tico pueden da√±ar directa e indirectamente la naturaleza y viceversa, pero existen muchas medidas que pueden hacer contribuciones positivas significativas en ambas √°reas.

Mexican President Andr√©s Manuel L√≥pez Obrador said this week that in-person meetings on the migration crisis with Vice President Kamala Harris went so well that he called her "president."

"It's a completely new phase," L√≥pez Obrador said during a news conference about the meetings on Wednesday, according to Reuters. "It was such a good meeting that I called her 'president.‚Äô"

Harris was in Mexico earlier this week as part of a two-day trip to the region to solve what the White House has described as the "root causes" behind the crisis at the southern border -- including poverty, violence and climate change in Central America.

Harris has come under fire for failing to visit the border, instead holding virtual meetings with officials and business leaders -- before jetting off on the two-day visit this week.

Mit Beginn des Jahres 2021 wurde in Deutschland ein CO2-Preis auf Kohle, Benzin, Diesel, Heiz√∂l und Gas eingef√ºhrt, um den Treibhausgas-Aussto√ü zu reduzieren und die Klimaziele zu erreichen. Er liegt derzeit bei 25 Euro pro Tonne Kohlenstoffdioxid und soll bis zum Jahr 2025 schrittweise auf bis zu 55 Euro steigen. Bis Ende der 2020er-Jahre werde er sogar auf mehr als 100 Euro steigen m√ºssen, sagte der Pr√§sident des Bundesumweltamtes, Dirk Messner, im Interview der Woche des Deutschlandfunks. Ohne eine solche Anhebung wirke der Preis wie eine Subvention der fossilen Energietr√§ger, die viele Umweltsch√§den anrichteten. Gegen diese verzerrte Preiskonstellation ‚Äûanzuf√∂rdern‚Äú, koste die B√ºrger dann wirklich Geld. Messner bem√§ngelte in Verbindung mit der im Oktober anstehenden Vertragsstaatenkonferenz der UN-Biodiversit√§tskonvention auch, dass der Schutz der Artenvielfalt zu wenig Aufmerksamkeit erhalte. Dabei sei die Biodiversit√§t ein wichtiger Teil der Probleml√∂sung bei der Klimaerw√§rmung. Denn Meere, W√§lder, Boden speichern als Senken CO2. Allerdings w√ºrde diese Senkenf√§higkeit geschw√§cht, wenn zum Beispiel W√§lder gerodet oder Moore f√ºr landwirtschaftliche Fl√§chen trockengelegt w√ºrden.

Neben der Klimakrise ist das Artensterben die gr√∂√üte Bedrohung f√ºr unsere Erde. Verschiedene Pflanzenarten und Tierpopulationen verzeichnen einen R√ºckgang um 80%. Doch was kannst du gegen das Artensterben tun?

Description:
Esta semana, con solo un par de horas de diferencia, el pa√≠s ha sido testigo de una cadena de eventos clim√°ticos: marejadas, trombas marinas y olas de calor. Aunque no tienen una relaci√≥n directa entre ellos, si tienen un responsable com√∫n: el cambio clim√°tico.

El mi√©rcoles comenzaron marejadas en la zona central, con olas de m√°s de ocho metros, fen√≥meno que se ha extendido en gran parte del borde costero de Chile. Ese mismo mi√©rcoles, en el sur del pa√≠s, una tromba marina arras√≥ con m√°s de 50 √°rboles, provoc√≥ un incendio y dej√≥ heridos. Finalmente, la ausencia del Fen√≥meno de la Ni√±a ha generado un junio caluroso en Santiago, con temperaturas superiores a 20¬∞C y escasez de precipitaciones. Este s√°bado se esperan hasta 25¬∞C en Santiago.

Roberto Rondanelli, investigador del Centro de Ciencia del Clima y la Resiliencia (CR)2 y acad√©mico del Departamento de Geof√≠sica FCFM de la Universidad de Chile, explica que en cualquier invierno normal existen muchos eventos llamativos de tiempo atmosf√©rico y oce√°nico que son parte de la normalidad del clima de Chile. ‚ÄúSin embargo, las marejadas son an√≥malas y se producen por efecto de la formaci√≥n de un cicl√≥n completamente an√≥malo que se gener√≥ costa afuera, en el Oc√©ano Pac√≠fico‚Äù.

Ra√∫l Cordero, climat√≥logo de la Universidad de Santiago, se√±ala que desafortunadamente el cambio clim√°tico hace m√°s frecuentes e intensos los eventos extremos. ‚ÄúEntre estos se encuentran, no solamente las olas de calor o las trombas, sino tambi√©n las sequ√≠as y las tormentas extremas en alta mar cuyos vientos originan las marejadas‚Äù.

Es una situaci√≥n que va a continuar empeorando a medida que pasa el tiempo. ‚ÄúLa frecuencia de las marejadas por ejemplo, se ha duplicado en las √∫ltimas dos d√©cadas. La frecuencia e intensidad con la que se producen las marejadas, sumado al alza en el nivel del mar producto del derretimiento glacial, va a provocar cada vez m√°s frecuentes inundaciones en nuestras costas y la erosi√≥n acelerada de nuestras playas‚Äù, advierte Cordero.

Sigue leyendo en el link de la bio.
ImageText: Qu√© PASA Trombas marinas, marejadas, olas de calor en invierno: el cambio clim√°tico ya est√° en Chile

Description:
Around 500 people joined a climate change rally in St. Ives near the site of the Group of Seven leaders‚Äô summit in southwest England. 

The rally was organized by the Extinction Rebellion climate activism group. Protesters wore blue and green gowns and headdresses while holding flags that read ‚ÄúG7 drowning in promises‚Äù and ‚ÄúAction not words.‚Äù

Climate change is a top issue on the G-7 summit agenda, along with recovery from the coronavirus pandemic.
ImageText: npr CLIMATE PROTESTORS GATHER FOR G7 SUMMIT June 11, 2021 SOUND THE ALARM

Description:
üåé Protests have taken place in Cornwall as the G7 summit gets underway.

One of the protests by Cornwall Climate Youth Alliance in partnership with Fridays for Future and Climate Live, shows people holding signs encouraging the leaders to speak out about climate change in Falmouth.

Another protest shows climate change activists wearing masks representing world leaders in St. Ives, and also, some climate change activists dressed up as black birds.

Environmental issues will be a large part of discussions at the summit, as Prince Charles is to host a reception for the leaders and CEOs of some of the world's largest companies to discuss how the private sector can work with governments to tackle the climate emergency.

Prime Minister Boris Johnson wants the G7 nations to promise to halve their carbon emissions by 2030, in order to limit the rise in global temperatures to 1.5 degrees.

Catch the latest from the summit on today‚Äôs #G7 special of the #DailyClimateShow, live on Sky News at 6:30pm.

#summit #G7summit #politics #world #leaders #primeminister #borisjohnson #climatechange #protest #climateaction #globalwarming #cornwall
ImageText: (empty)

Description:
Hundreds of activists are in Cornwall calling on leaders of the G7 countries to take action on climate change and for excess vaccines to be distributed to poorer nations.

Protesters from various groups¬†gathered on a beach in St Ives, waving signs demanding climate action and wearing masks depicting the seven leaders.

Yesterday, it was announced that all countries in the G7 had pledged to donate up to a billion coronavirus vaccine jabs to struggling countries around the world, with 100 million coming from the UK.

US President Joe Biden told reporters: "We're going to help lead the world out of this pandemic working alongside our global partners."

Leaders of the Group of Seven countries are in Carbis Bay this weekend and will discuss a range of issues, ranging from Covid vaccines and economic recovery to climate change.

Description:
President Biden and Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain ‚Äî joined by their wives, Jill and Carrie ‚Äî met on Thursday for the first time since Biden was elected president.‚Å£
‚Å£
‚Å£With the world confronting the immediate crisis of a pandemic and the long-term challenge of climate change, Biden and Johnson turned for inspiration to another period of peril and deep uncertainty. They announced a renewal of the Atlantic Charter ‚Äî the declaration of cooperation that Prime Minister Winston Churchill and President Franklin D. Roosevelt laid out during World War II.‚Å£
‚Å£
‚Å£However, at the core of the president‚Äôs message during the trip is a central animating theme: The U.S. and its allies are engaged in an existential struggle between democracy and autocracy.‚Å£
‚Å£
‚Å£In what he hopes will be a powerful demonstration that democracies ‚Äî and not China or Russia ‚Äî are capable of responding to the world‚Äôs crises, Biden formally announced on Thursday that the U.S. would buy 500 million Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine doses and donate them for use by about 100 low- and middle-income countries over the next year.‚Å£
‚Å£
‚Å£As the leaders of the G7 nations prepare to meet in England starting on Friday, they are pledging to help close the vaccination gap. ‚ÄúThis is about our responsibility, our humanitarian obligation, to save as many lives as we can,‚Äù Biden said in a speech on Thursday. ‚ÄúWhen we see people hurting and suffering anywhere around the world, we seek to help any way we can.‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£
Tap the link in our bio for live coverage of Biden‚Äôs trip. Photo by @nytmills.

Description:
The Texas Republican congressman Louie Gohmert has asked a senior US government official if changing the moon‚Äôs orbit around the Earth, or the Earth‚Äôs orbit around the sun, might be a solution to tackle the climate crisis.

Bizarrely, the question was not posed to anyone from Nasa or even the Pentagon. Instead it was asked of a senior forestry service official during a House natural resources committee hearing on Tuesday.

Speaking with Jennifer Eberlien, associate deputy chief of the US Forest Service, Gohmert asked if it was possible to alter the orbits of the moon, or the Earth, as a way of combating climate change.

‚ÄúI understand from what‚Äôs been testified to the Forest Service and the BLM [Bureau of Land Management], you want very much to work on the issue of climate change,‚Äù Gohmert said, adding that a past director of Nasa had once told him that orbits of the moon and the Earth were indeed changing.

‚ÄúWe know there‚Äôs been significant solar flare activity, and so ‚Ä¶ is there anything that the National Forest Service or BLM can do to change the course of the moon‚Äôs orbit, or the Earth‚Äôs orbit around the sun?‚Äù Gohmert asked. ‚ÄúObviously that would have profound effects on our climate.‚Äù

Eberlien said she would have to ‚Äúfollow up with you on that one, Mr Gohmert.‚Äù

Though he seemed to be entirely earnest, some observers have posited that Gohmert was seeking to express a belief that climate change was a phenomenon of natural changes in the orbits of celestial bodies, and so any other efforts to address it would be futile."

Via @guardian_us
ImageText: Texas Republican asks: can we fix the moon's orbit to fight climate change? G Louie Gohmert

üáÆüá© A cave painting thought to be the oldest in the world is rapidly peeling off due to climate change.

The 44,000 year old artwork on Indonesia's island of Sulawesi, is being "exfoliated" off due to increasing salt erosion in the cave.

Scientists say that warming temperatures, alongside prolonged drought combined with heavy monsoonal rainfall has created conditions intensifying the salt crystallisation.

Desde el coraz√≥n del #DesiertodeAtacama, se inaugur√≥ oficialmente #CerroDominador, la primera planta #termosolar de #Latinoam√©rica que actualmente se encuentra sincronizando la entrega de 110MW de energ√≠a limpia al sistema el√©ctrico nacional, las 24 horas del d√≠a.

En la actividad, particip√≥ el Presidente de la Rep√∫blica, Sebasti√°n Pi√±era; el ministro de Energ√≠a, Juan Carlos Jobet; el vicepresidente Ejecutivo de Corfo, Pablo Terrazas; el CEO de Cerro Dominador, Fernando Gonz√°lez; el CEO de Eig Global Energy Partners, Blair Thomas; y otras autoridades que aportaron al proyecto.

Hoy estamos orgullosos de poder inaugurar esta gran iniciativa que ser√° capaz de combatir los efectos del cambio clim√°tico, entregando energ√≠a renovable al sistema el√©ctrico nacional. Corfo es la agencia de desarrollo econ√≥mico del Estado que ha ido preparando al pa√≠s para los desaf√≠os del futuro, y por eso fue una instituci√≥n clave para levantar este proyecto innovador y sostenible, que nos permitir√° avanzar hacia la carbono neutralidad‚Äù, destac√≥ el Vicepresidente Ejecutivo de Corfo, Pablo Terrazas.

La iniciativa que utiliz√≥ un innovador modelo de financiamiento, gestionado a trav√©s de #Corfo, la #Uni√≥nEuropea y el Banco de Desarrollo Alem√°n KfW, permitir√° evitar la emisi√≥n de cerca de 870.000 toneladas de #CO2 al a√±o y abastecer√° con energ√≠a verde a la red el√©ctrica de m√°s de 380.000 hogares chilenos. Description:
Cuarenta a√±os han pasado desde la primera emisi√≥n de la serie estadounidense "#Cosmos" (1980), que entusiasm√≥ a grandes y chicos con los misterios del #universo y que fue el resultado audiovisual del c√©lebre libro hom√≥nimo de #CarlSagan.

La escritora y activista #AnnDruyan fue una de las responsables de la obra y la semana pasada particip√≥, v√≠a telem√°tica, en el cierre de la Semana de Oro de los webinars de Astrof√≠sica UC, iniciativa que durante un a√±o ha tra√≠do cada semana a destacadas personalidades de la #astronom√≠a internacional, incluyendo a ganadores del #PremioNobel.

Druyan, viuda de Carl Sagan, particip√≥ con la exposici√≥n ‚ÄúHacia las estrellas o ninguna parte: la misi√≥n de la ciencia‚Äù, tras lo cual adem√°s respondi√≥ las preguntas de varios astr√≥nomos participantes.

Serie anticipatoria

"Cosmos" anticip√≥ una serie de fen√≥menos, como el #cambioclim√°tico. Desde entonces han "cambiado tantas cosas, otras han seguido igual", dice en entrevista con el #ElMostrador.

"Lo que ha cambiado es que en aquel momento a√∫n nos faltaba descubrir alg√∫n exoplaneta, fuera del sistema solar. Y ahora hemos visto miles. Incluso hemos desarrollado estrategias para determinar la presencia de vida en distancias #interestelares, y la #naturaleza de #planetas y #lunas en otras #estrellas. Un gran cambio", destaca.

Druyan recuerda que uno de los ataques que recibi√≥ la serie fue respecto a su "especulaci√≥n" sobre otros mundos, pero ella se√±ala que la "imaginaci√≥n cient√≠fica" de Sagan era muy disciplinada. "√âl revis√≥ las teor√≠as", puntualiza.

Lo mismo sucede con el tema del cambio clim√°tico, que entonces parec√≠a lejano, y hoy est√° en marcha con la extinci√≥n de algunas especies, con el impacto en los corales y los oc√©anos, las tormentas e inundaciones.

Por @marcofajardoescritor üñäüíª
