Description:
Durante la jornada de este martes se inaugur√≥ en Chile la primera planta de concentraci√≥n solar de Am√©rica Latina. 

En la instancia particip√≥ el presidente Sebasti√°n Pi√±era y indic√≥ que "la ciencia ha hablado de forma fuerte y clara, si no cambiamos el rumbo vamos a un desastre ecol√≥gico".

El mandatario enfoc√≥ sus palabras en la lucha contra el cambio clim√°tico, resaltando que "el mundo del futuro o es sustentable o no va a ser".

"Mientras m√°s cuidemos la naturaleza, m√°s la naturaleza nos va a cuidar a nosotros", agreg√≥. 

Por √∫ltimo Pi√±era dijo que nuestro pa√≠s era m√°s bien pobre en las energ√≠as del pasado, pero "muy rico en las energ√≠as del futuro".

La planta, ubicada en la regi√≥n de Antofagasta, cuenta con 1.000 hect√°reas de superficie y 110 MW de capacidad total.

Description:
During Martina Navratilova‚Äôs heyday in the 1980s, the world did not have much appetite for an outspoken, openly gay tennis champion who won 18 Grand Slam singles titles. Today, that combination of success and fearlessness ‚Äî consider Naomi Osaka ‚Äî can make you an icon. 

The 64-year-old @martinanavratilova, an enthusiastic supporter of Osaka and a vocal champion of causes including climate change and animal welfare, may simply have been born too soon. She paved the way for the modern athlete, standing up for gay and women‚Äôs rights long before it was popular. Navratilova still has plenty to say. And the world seems more willing to listen, though not everyone agrees with her.

She faced vehement backlash from LGBTQ advocates when she argued in the Sunday Times of London in support of rules for transgender female athletes competing against other women, and was dropped from the advisory board of Athlete Ally, a group focused on supporting LGBTQ athletes. She expresses her opinions on social media, even if the next day she is providing analysis on The Tennis Channel from the French Open. She is critical of the Republican Party. And do not get her started on vaccine conspiracy theories. (She doesn‚Äôt believe them.)

Defecting from Czechoslovakia at 18 saved her soul, she said, and living as an openly gay superstar athlete set her free. ‚ÄúI lived behind the Iron Curtain,‚Äù she said, her eyes still capable of the glare that terrified opponents on the court. ‚ÄúYou really think you are going to be able to tell me to keep my mouth shut?‚Äù

Tap the link in our bio to read more about @martinanavratilova, who led the way for today‚Äôs tennis champions. Photos by @kiehart and Leo Mason/Popperfoto via Getty Images, who took the photograph of Navratilova after she won the 1983 U.S. Open.

üåä ¬øQu√© es el moco marino o muc√≠lago que ahoga el mar de M√°rmara?

La presencia de espumas y muc√≠lagos en aguas pr√≥ximas a la costa es relativamente frecuente en muchos puntos del planeta. Sin embargo, el episodio m√°s espectacular y preocupante de este fen√≥meno de los √∫ltimos a√±os se est√° registrando esta primavera en el mar de M√°rmara (Turqu√≠a), entre el mar Negro y el mar Egeo.

La formaci√≥n de estos compuestos flotantes con apariencia de moco es de origen natural en ocasiones pero, sin duda, existen diversos factores agravantes relacionados con actividades humanas, desde el vertido de contaminantes hasta el cambio clim√°tico (el aumento de la temperatura del agua del mar facilita la proliferaci√≥n de algunos organismos).

Como demuestran las im√°genes y datos cient√≠ficos difundidos, el problema es est√©tico pero tambi√©n, y sobretodo, de sanidad p√∫blica, calidad ambiental (con diversos ecosistemas y especies afectadas), pesca y turismo.

Description:
Our closest relatives, the great apes, are predicted to lose a devastating 90% of their homelands in Africa over the next 30 years, according to a new study.

All gorillas, chimpanzees and bonobos are already endangered or critically endangered. But a combination of the climate crisis, the destruction of wild areas for minerals, timber and food, and human population growth is on track to decimate their ranges by 2050, the scientists said.

The study analysed data from the International Union for Conservation of Nature‚Äôs apes database on species populations, threats and conservation action at hundreds of sites over 20 years. It then modelled the combined future impacts of global heating, habitat destruction and human population growth.

‚ÄúIf we add climate change to the current causes of territory loss, the picture looks devastating,‚Äù said Joana Carvalho, a biologist and computer modeller at Liverpool John Moores University in the UK and who led the study.

Some new areas will become climatically suitable for the apes, but the researchers doubt they will be able to migrate into these regions in time.

The biggest protection for great apes could come from consumers in rich nations demanding sustainably produced goods. Currently the export of minerals for mobile phones, timber, and palm oil are major drivers of great ape population falls.

.
.
.
#apes #bonobo #gorilla #chimpanzee #African #habitatloss #climatechange #wildlife #ourplanet #biodiversity
ImageText: Great apes predicted to lose 90% of homelands in Africa by 2050

Description:
A growing body of research shows that FEMA, the government agency responsible for disaster recovery in the U.S., often helps white disaster victims more than people of color, even when the amount of damage is the same. 

Not only do individual white Americans often receive more aid from FEMA; so do the communities in which they live, according to several recent studies based on federal data.

Leaders at FEMA are wrestling with the complicated question of why these disparities exist ‚Äî and what to do about them. The problem seems to stem from complex systemic factors, like a real estate market that often places higher values on properties in communities with many white residents, or the difficulty of navigating the federal bureaucracy, which tends to favor people and communities that have more resources from the beginning.

The imbalance comes as climate change fuels more frequent and more destructive storms, wildfires and other disasters, and marginalized communities tend to be both the most exposed to damage and the least able to recover financially.

FEMA declined to comment on individual cases, citing privacy concerns, and said it had created an internal working group to examine the issue. In April, it asked the public for examples of policies ‚Äúthat perpetuate systemic barriers to opportunities and benefits for people of color and/or other underserved groups,‚Äù as well as ideas for improvement.

‚ÄúWe are advancing this work,‚Äù said Justin Knighten, FEMA‚Äôs director of external affairs, adding that the agency is working on a comprehensive public response. ‚ÄúThat is a top priority for the administrator.‚Äù

Tap the link in our bio to read more about inequities in FEMA‚Äôs disaster relief policies. Photo by @misterwidmer of homes in Lake Charles, Louisiana, bracing for Hurricane Delta, which arrived just six weeks after Hurricane Laura in 2020.
ImageText: FRADS Federal Disaster Aid Favors White People Over People of Color, Research Shows

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said on Saturday that untreated waste dumped into the Marmara Sea and climate change had caused the sea snot bloom. Click the link in our bio for the full story.

Description:
Could Hoover Dam be running dry?üíß Swipe through ‚è©  to see pics from over the years.

Eighty-six years after its completion in 1935, the infrastructure at Hoover Dam continues doing what it was designed to do: holding water and sending it coursing through intake tunnels, spinning turbines and generating electricity. 

But the latest projections show that by the end of 2021, Lake Mead will decline below an elevation of 1,066 feet, far below the threshold ‚Äî 1,075 feet ‚Äî for the federal government to declare a shortage. That‚Äôs expected to happen in August, triggering the largest water cuts to date next year for Arizona, Nevada and Mexico.

The effects of years of severe drought and temperatures pushed higher by climate change are strikingly visible along Lake Mead‚Äôs retreating shorelines near Las Vegas, where the growing ‚Äúbathtub ring‚Äù of whitish minerals coats the rocky desert slopes.

The reservoir has declined more than 16 feet over the past year and is forecast to fall about 9 feet more by the end of this year.

üì∏: Mark Henle, @azcentral; Jae C. Hong, @apnews; Justin Sullivan, Ethan Miller @gettyimages

Description:
Animals are being forced to contend with busy roadways as climate change and expanding infrastructure continue to erode wildlife habitat. So the state Department of Transportation joined with the state wildlife agency and nonprofit groups to create a series of structures across the U.S. to help wildlife cross highways safely.

‚ÄúI was really only expecting maybe a handful of successful crossings in the first year,‚Äù said Nicki Frey, a wildlife biologist with Utah State University who studied the effectiveness of a crossing set up in the state. ‚ÄúWe expected to see a lot of animals approach the overpass, sort of sniff around, maybe make some anxious looking movements and then decide not to use it.‚Äù

But when she reviewed the images from the trail cameras, she was stunned. A wide variety of animals are using them: Images from trail cameras show how deer, black bears, mountain lions, porcupines and alligators use overpasses, underpasses and tunnels to safely cross the road. Within the first several months of her study, she documented hundreds of crossings. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre actually just using it on a daily basis,‚Äù she said.

Wildlife crossings save lives ‚Äî those of the animals, and of the drivers who might otherwise hit the animals with them in cars on the highways. Research shows that, across the country, there are one to two million collisions between vehicles and large animals each year. 

These accidents cause more than 26,000 human injuries and about 200 human deaths. Funding for crossings is a challenge, but that may become easier, too: A bipartisan Senate version of the transportation bill being hammered out in Congress includes $350 million for wildlife crossings and corridors. 

Tap this link to see more animal crossings. https://nyti.ms/3uH7hY2

Y es que hace 37 a√±os que no se hablaba de viajes de investigaci√≥n. La apuesta por el planeta vecino har√° que se sume un bill√≥n de d√≥lares a la investigaci√≥n exclusiva de Venus. Al ser un planeta muy parecido a la #Tierra, pero que por razones que se desconocen, se convirti√≥ en una caldera t√≥xica gigante, podr√≠a vislumbrar informaci√≥n sobre el cambio clim√°tico en nuestro planeta. Para esta investigaci√≥n ser√° importante el trabajo de DAVINCI+ que buscar√° recopilar lecturas qu√≠micas de la atm√≥sfera del planeta, para as√≠ descubrir definitivamente si alguna vez tuvo un oc√©ano. Hist√≥ricamente los #humedales han sido subvalorados a nivel mundial lo que ha llevado a que hoy est√©n desapareciendo tres veces m√°s r√°pido que los #bosques, y que s√≥lo en los √∫ltimos 50 a√±os se haya perdido un 35% de estos ecosistemas, de acuerdo a lo se√±alado por el informe Global Wetland Outlook, desarrollado por la Convenci√≥n Ramsar para la protecci√≥n de los humedales. Su vulnerabilidad frente al cambio clim√°tico y las consecuencias de la #urbanizaci√≥n, incrementan la p√©rdida de estos ecosistemas.

En los √∫ltimos 10 a√±os, en #Chile la protecci√≥n de los humedales y las organizaciones ciudadanas dedicadas a su defensa, han ganado espacio en la opini√≥n p√∫blica. Gracias a su presi√≥n y a un trabajo continuo de denuncias y defensa de estos ecosistemas hoy contamos con una Ley de Humedales Urbanos, que reconoce a estos ecosistemas, su importancia para el desarrollo sustentable de las ciudades y regula su intervenci√≥n.

‚ÄúEsta ley es un importante cambio de paradigma en la legislaci√≥n ambiental chilena, ya que reconoce al ecosistema como tal y su valor ambiental. Gracias a esta ley cualquier proyecto o actividad a ser desarrollada en un humedal urbano requiere su ingreso al Servicio de Evaluaci√≥n Ambiental, sin importar su naturaleza‚Äù, comenta Enrique Cruz, director ejecutivo de la Fundaci√≥n Forecos, parte de la Red Plurinacional de Humedales, que re√∫ne a m√°s de 40 organizaciones dedicadas a la defensa de estos ecosistemas y que fue parte activa durante la creaci√≥n de la ley, aportando en diferentes etapas del proceso con comentarios t√©cnicos derivados de la praxis ciudadana en la defensa de los humedales de norte a sur.

Durante marzo de 2021 esta red organiz√≥ un curso en l√≠nea sobre esta ley y su reglamento que cont√≥ con m√°s de 600 inscritos. El curso de 5 sesiones est√° disponible en la p√°gina de Facebook de la red.

Por Ver√≥nica Lyon üñäüì∞

Miami is facing the hard choices of climate change. Now, a proposal to construct a 20-foot tall, six-mile-long seawall has South Floridians divided.‚Å£
‚Å£
Three years ago, not long after Hurricane Irma left parts of Miami underwater, the federal government embarked on a study to find a way to protect the vulnerable South Florida coast from deadly and destructive storm surge. But already, no one likes the answer.‚Å£
‚Å£
The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers proposed the sea wall in its first draft of the study, now under review. The wall would be mostly inland, running parallel to the coast through neighborhoods ‚Äî except for a one-mile stretch right on Biscayne Bay, past the gleaming sky-rises of Brickell, Miami‚Äôs financial district.‚Å£
‚Å£
The $6 billion proposal remains tentative and at least five years off. But the startling suggestion of a massive sea wall up to 20 feet high cutting across beautiful Biscayne Bay was enough to jolt some Miamians to attention: The hard choices that will be necessary to deal with the city‚Äôs many environmental challenges are here, and few people want to face them.‚Å£
‚Å£
In Miami, the U.S. metropolitan area that is perhaps most exposed to sea-level rise, the problem is not climate change denialism. Not when hurricane season, which begins this week, returns each year with more intense and frequent storms. Not when finding flood insurance has become increasingly difficult and unaffordable. Not when the nights stay so hot that leaving home with a sweater to fend off the evening chill has become a thing of the past.‚Å£
‚Å£
The trouble is that the magnitude of the interconnected obstacles the region faces can feel overwhelming, and none of the possible solutions are cheap, easy or pretty.‚Å£
‚Å£
Tap the link in our bio to read more about how South Florida is confronting climate change. Photos by @zackwittman‚Å£
‚Å£

Description:
Arrayed across a plateau on an island in the high Norwegian Arctic, the 100 domes of the Svalbard Satellite Station look like abstract mushrooms sprouting from the snowy landscape.
 
From outside, there seems to be little going on. But each geodesic dome shelters a dish antenna that whirs to life throughout the day and night, precisely aiming at satellites as they rise above the horizon and staying locked onto them as they arc across the sky. 
 
SvalSat, as the station is known, is a crucial, behind-the-scenes workhorse supporting scientific research. Located just outside the town of Longyearbyen in the Svalbard Archipelago, it is 800 miles from the North Pole, making it the northernmost satellite station in the world. It is also one of the largest. The 100 antennas at the station, some as large as 42 feet in diameter, track more than 3,500 passes each day by several hundred satellites, including many Earth-observing ones that are essential for studying the impacts of climate change.
 
Among them are the two active satellites for Landsat, the joint program of NASA and the United States Geological Survey that provides images of shrinking glaciers, changing forests, eroding coastlines and other symptoms of global warming.
 
Maja-Stina Ekstedt, the station‚Äôs director, manages a staff of about 40 who operate the antennas and repair and maintain equipment. While the domes are transparent to radio waves, snow can degrade the signals. So, in a location that averages about 170 days with snow a year, clearing the outside of the domes is a frequent task.
 
The weather can affect access to the station itself, as well. 
 
‚ÄúJust to drive here it can be quite interesting,‚Äù Ekstedt said. ‚ÄúEvery day during winter we watch the weather very closely due to challenging driving conditions and avalanche danger.‚Äù Tap the link in our bio to read more about the arctic station that keeps satellites connected. Photos by @an_filip

Description:
Las personas negras en la mayor√≠a de las ciudades de #EstadosUnidos padecen el doble del impacto de las #altastemperaturas que sus contrapartes blancas, seg√∫n un nuevo estudio.

Los autores aseguran que las diferencias no se explican por la pobreza sino por el #racismo hist√≥rico y la segregaci√≥n.

Como resultado, las personas de color en general viven en √°reas con menos #espaciosverdes y m√°s #edificios y v√≠as de transporte, lo que exacerba el efecto del aumento en las temperaturas y del cambio clim√°tico.

Las ciudades son bien conocidas por amplificar el impacto del calor.

El llamado "efecto de la isla de calor urbana" es el t√©rmino t√©cnico para designar el efecto que los edificios y la infraestructura de las ciudades en general tienen sobre las temperaturas.

Todo ese #cemento y asfalto atrae y guarda m√°s calor, por lo que tanto los d√≠as como las noches en grandes √°reas urbanas son mucho m√°s c√°lidos que las √°reas circundantes.

Sin embargo, dentro de las ciudades, a menudo hay grandes diferencias en la isla de calor. Las zonas ricas en √°rboles y espacios verdes son notablemente m√°s frescas que aquellas con gran densidad de viviendas, comercios o industrias.

Un estudio anterior en EE.UU. encontr√≥ una correlaci√≥n entre los vecindarios m√°s calurosos en las grandes ciudades y las pr√°cticas de vivienda racistas que se remontan a la d√©cada de 1930.

En aquel entonces, las √°reas con grandes poblaciones de afroamericanos o inmigrantes fueron "demarcadas en rojo" en documentos por funcionarios federales y consideradas demasiado "peligrosas" para pr√©stamos e inversiones hipotecarias.

Esto llev√≥ a una concentraci√≥n de la pobreza y a bajas tasas de propiedad de viviendas en algunas zonas de las grandes ciudades.

üëâConitn√∫a leyendo en el link de la bio‚ùó

Description:
Hitzewellen kosten im Sommer viele Menschen das Leben. Eine internationale Studie hat jetzt versucht, genau zu ermitteln, wie viele es sind. Laut den Daten aus mehr als 740 St√§dten weltweit l√§sst sich jeder dritte Todesfall bei Hitze dem Klimawandel zuschreiben.

Vicedo-Cabrera und ihre Ko-Autoren werteten insgesamt 30 Millionen Todesf√§lle aus. Alle traten w√§hrend der hei√üen Sommermonate auf, in den Jahren 1991 bis 2015. F√ºr jede einzelne Stadt der Studie ermittelten sie dann den Zusammenhang zwischen Todes- und Hitzerate ‚Äì also wie stark die Sterblichkeit mit der Lufttemperatur vor Ort steigt.

Abschlie√üend wurden zwei verschiedene Welten im Computer simuliert: eine reale, wie sie wirklich war, und eine fiktive ohne die Treibhausgas-Emissionen des Menschen. Das Real-Szenario lieferte dabei viel h√∂here Zahlen von st√§dtischen Hitzetoten als das fiktive. Die Differenz sei der Anteil, der auf das Konto des Klimawandels gehe, so Ana Maria Vicedo-Cabrera ‚Äì eben jene 37 Prozent.

Den vollst√§ndigen Beitrag finden Sie √ºber den Link in der Bio.

Description:
New Zealand‚Äôs rare, highly endangered alpine parrots may have headed for the mountains to avoid people.

The kea - an alpine parrot - is thought to be the only parrot to live in the mountains, but scientists analysing DNA sequencing and fossil records have found the species were once present in other parts of the country.

The news is something of a knock to the kea‚Äôs internationally unique ‚Äúalpine parrot‚Äù status. But it may also be a saving grace for the endangered bird, making it more capable of surviving habitat loss or increased competition.

Being an alpine specialist can make species like kea particularly vulnerable to the climate crisis. Research from Europe has found up to 22% of species studied on glaciers in the Italian Alps would disappear from the area once the glaciers had gone.

Associate professor Michael Knapp, one of the paper‚Äôs lead authors, said the idea that kea had moved specifically to avoid people was still speculative. But given kea were physically able to survive in a variety of habitats, it made sense to examine what the primary differences were.

Follow the link in bio to read more about the bird, which is described as having a unique personality.

Photo: Murdo MacLeod

Description:
Taiwan is experiencing its worst drought in more than half a century. 
 
The monthslong drought has nearly drained the island‚Äôs major reservoirs, contributed to two severe electricity blackouts and forced officials to restrict the water supply. It has brought drastic changes to the island‚Äôs landscape: The bottoms of several reservoirs and lakes have been warped into cracked, dusty expanses that resemble desert floors.
 
And it has transformed how many of Taiwan‚Äôs 23.5 million residents use and think about water. Restrictions have forced many to modify how they shower, wash dishes and flush. One woman has stopped washing her car. A chef stopped cooking last month for lack of water. A bubble tea shop will stop serving ice with drinks until water restrictions are lifted.
 
‚ÄúWe used too much water before,‚Äù Lin Wei-Yi, in the central city of Taichung, said this week. ‚ÄúNow we have to adapt to a new normal.‚Äù
 
No typhoons made landfall in Taiwan last year, the first time since 1964. Tropical cyclones are a prime source of precipitation for the island‚Äôs reservoirs. Some scientists say the recent lack of typhoons is part of a decades-long pattern linked to global warming, in which the intensity of storms hitting Taiwan has increased but their annual frequency has decreased. Ordinary rainfall has also been drastically lower than normal this year, particularly in the central region that includes Taichung, a city of 2.8 million people and the second-largest on the island.
 
In a few cases, the usual residents of the island‚Äôs lakes and reservoirs ‚Äî fish ‚Äî were replaced by other species: tourists and social media influencers taking pictures of the visually startling terrain.
 
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been meltingly hot in Taichung for a while now,‚Äù said Huang Ting-Hsiang, a chef who works out of his home and stopped cooking last month for lack of water. ‚ÄúThe images of the dangerously low levels at those reservoirs are scary, but there‚Äôs nothing we can do.‚Äù Tap the link in our bio to read more about how Taiwan‚Äôs residents are scrambling to save water. Photos by @billyhckwok.

Description:
La activista clim√°tica Greta Thunberg hizo un llamamiento para que se produzca un cambio en la producci√≥n y el consumo de alimentos ante las reiteradas crisis que amenazan al mundo.

As√≠, Thunberg ha advertido que la humanidad debe cambiar r√°pidamente a una dieta basada en #plantas para evitar m√°s crisis #ecol√≥gicas y sanitarias. En un v√≠deo publicado en Internet, la activista clim√°tica sueca inst√≥ a la gente a cambiar lo que come, advirtiendo sin rodeos: "Si no cambiamos, estamos jodidos".

"La crisis clim√°tica, la crisis ecol√≥gica y la crisis sanitaria est√°n interrelacionadas", dijo Thunberg en un v√≠deo publicado en las redes sociales con motivo del D√≠a Internacional de la Biodiversidad.

"Millones de personas han muerto por el COVID-19, el Zika, el √âbola, la fiebre del Nilo Occidental, el SARS, el MERS, el VIH-SIDA", ya que los virus saltan de los animales a los humanos, a√±adi√≥.

"La forma en que cultivamos y tratamos la naturaleza, talando bosques y destruyendo h√°bitats, estamos creando las condiciones perfectas para que las enfermedades pasen de un animal a otro, y a nosotros", dijo la joven de 18 a√±os.

"Cuando pensamos en los villanos de la crisis clim√°tica, por supuesto que nos imaginamos a las empresas de combustibles f√≥siles, pero la agricultura y el uso de la tierra juntos son una cuarta parte de nuestras emisiones, esto es enorme", dijo.

üëâContin√∫a leyendo en el link de la bio‚ùó

Description:
Vice President Kamala Harris achieved another first for women on Friday when she addressed the graduating class of the U.S. Naval Academy, becoming the first female commencement speaker in the school‚Äôs nearly 175-year history.

The vice president‚Äôs speech focused on some of the Biden administration‚Äôs most urgent challenges, like the coronavirus pandemic, climate change and a host of increasingly sophisticated cybersecurity threats ‚Äî occurrences she called ‚Äúwarning shots‚Äù that would require a military trained to counter them.

‚ÄúA gang of hackers can disrupt the fuel supply of a whole seaboard,‚Äù Harris said. ‚ÄúOne country‚Äôs carbon emissions can threaten the sustainability of the whole earth. This, midshipmen, is the era we are in ‚Äî and it is unlike any era that came before.‚Äù

The vice president‚Äôs speech at the Naval Academy, in Annapolis, Maryland, was her first to focus on the military, and it came as the Biden administration accelerated its withdrawal of troops from Afghanistan, well ahead of the Sept. 11 deadline President Biden set in April.

Harris told the graduates that the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attack had ‚Äúshaped your entire life, and it shaped our entire nation.‚Äù She said that the pandemic had similarly redefined American life. ‚ÄúIf we weren‚Äôt clear before, we know now: The world is interconnected. Our world is interdependent. And our world is fragile.‚Äù

Tap the link in our bio to read more about Harris‚Äôs historic moment at the Naval Academy. Photo by Jim Lo Scalzo/EPA, via Shutterstock

Description:
'An amazing decision'

The Australian environment minister has a duty of care to protect young people from the climate crisis, that's according to the country's federal court.

The judgment has been hailed by lawyers and teenagers, who brought the case, as a world first.

Eight teenagers and an octogenarian nun had sought an injunction to prevent the environment minister, Sussan Ley, approving a proposal to expand a coal mine in New South Wales, arguing she ‚Äãhad a common law duty of care to protect younger people against future harm from climate change.

The judge, Justice Mordecai Bromberg, found the minister had a duty of care to not act in a way that would cause future harm to younger people. But he did not grant the injunction as he was not satisfied the minister would breach her duty of care.

David Barnden, a lawyer representing the children, said it was a historic and ‚Äúamazing decision‚Äù with potentially significant consequences.

‚ÄúThe court has found that the minister owes a duty of care to younger children, to vulnerable people, and that duty says that the minister must not act in a way that causes harm ‚Äì future harm ‚Äì from climate change to younger people,‚Äù he said outside court. ‚ÄúIt is the first time in the world that such a duty of care has been recognised, especially in a common law country.‚Äù

More at @guardianaustralia
ImageText: Australian court rules government has a duty of care to protect young people from the climate crisis

Description: An Australian judge has ruled the country‚Äôs environment minister has a duty of care to protect young people from climate change,  after teenage activists lost their court bid to ban a coal mine expansion on Thursday.

Description:
Lots of people believe that fields of wind turbines or solar panels ruin a gorgeous view, and that doesn‚Äôt make them climate deniers.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a common opinion, I‚Äôve found ‚Äî not just in wealthy coastal communities like Nantucket island, the Massachusetts enclave where wealthy homeowners helped defeat a proposal for America‚Äôs first offshore wind farm, but also in rural areas across the West, where many residents value the uncluttered views and distinctly non-industrialized character of the landscapes,‚Äù writes Sammy Roth in the latest edition of the Boiling Point newsletter.

But if we‚Äôre going to confront climate change, dealing with visual impacts is key. There will be difficult conversations about where to put solar farms, wind turbines and transmission lines.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no question in my mind that we need to be building renewable energy projects, and it could be that ultimately the decision must be taken by society that we don‚Äôt give a crap what the visual impacts are,‚Äù one expert said.

Read more at link in bio.
ImageText: Los Angeles Times Solar and wind farms are often seen as terrible eyesores. Will that stop people from supporting them? "Local opposition could be as significant a roadblock as any to climate action," writes Sammy Roth

El corto fue escrito por la joven en colaboraci√≥n con Mercy For Animals, el cual insta a los espectadores a basar su dieta en frutas y verduras, dado que la agricultura animal juega un papel fundamental en la crisis clim√°tica.

"Si cambiamos hacia una dieta basada en plantas, podr√≠amos ahorrar hasta 8 mil millones de toneladas de CO2 cada a√±o. Podr√≠amos alimentarnos con un [76%] menos de tierra. Y la naturaleza podr√≠a recuperarse", declar√≥ la activista.

Mit NordLink ist eine Stromverbindung zwischen Deutschland und Norwegen entstanden ‚Äì zum Austausch von Windenergie und Wasserkraft. Ein norwegisches und ein deutsches Energieunternehmen teilen sich die Baukosten von 1,8 Milliarden Euro. Stromtrassen wie Nordlink seien wichtig, wenn die Energiewende gelingen soll, sagt Wirtschaftsminister Peter Altmaier (CDU) im Deutschlandfunk. 

Vier weitere Projekte sind noch in Planung: Suedlink soll von Schleswig-Holstein nach Baden-W√ºrttemberg, Suedostlink von Sachsen-Anhalt nach Bayern f√ºhren. Ultranet soll Emden mit Baden-W√ºrttemberg verbinden und der B-Korridor Schleswig-Holstein mit NRW. Es brauche solche ‚Äûgro√üen Strom-Autobahnen‚Äú, betonte Peter Altmaier. Description:
It's increasingly likely that a key temperature limit will be reached in one of the next five years.
 
The impacts of climate change are far more severe when the increase is greater than 1.5C, a landmark 2018 report said.
 
In the last decade, it was estimated that the chance of any one year reaching the 1.5C threshold was only 20%.
 
This new assessment puts that risk at 40%.

"What it means is that we're approaching 1.5C - we're not there yet but we're getting close," says Leon Hermanson, a senior Met Office scientist.

"Time is running out for the strong action which we need now."

Tap the link in our bio to read more from @david.shukman about the predictions.
 
(üì∑: Nantou in Taiwan, Reuters)
 
#Climate #GlobalWarming #Environment #bbcnews
ImageText: BBC NEWS World at risk of hitting temperature limit soon

Description:
Follow @emergencyc4 for more stories like this...

A thick blanket of¬†‚Äúsea snot‚Äù¬†is spreading¬†along the Turkish coastline¬†because of global heating.¬†The gelatinous substance, also known as marine mucilage, forms occasionally in the Mediterranean basin. But the most recent event has grown into the biggest accumulation of sea snot ever seen in Turkey, driven by rising sea temperatures in recent years.

Sea snot is a mucus-like substance generated by tiny sea plants called phytoplankton when they are stressed. They can proliferate to excessive levels in warm, calm seas with high levels of nitrogen and phosphorus - which can be found in the wastewater being discharged into the Sea of Marmaris.¬†It¬†can attract viruses and bacteria, including e-coli, and can suffocate marine life.

The blanket of sea snot has prevented local fisherfolk from casting their nets in the waters since it was first recorded in December,¬†damaging the local economy. There are fears it could also affect tourism, shipping and other coastal industries if it continues to spread unchecked.¬†

Prof Mustafa Sari,¬†dean of the¬†Maritime Faculty at¬†Bandirma Onyedi Eylul University, is monitoring the¬†situation.¬†He told Channel 4 News that "a new waste management policy based on climate change" is needed to reduce the oversupply of nutrients causing the phytoplankton to multiply.

#California‚Äôs three largest investor-owned #utilities expect to de-energize hundreds of thousands of homes and businesses this year to prevent #powerlines from sparking #wildfires during high-risk weather conditions. State regulators have also warned that heatwaves could stretch #electricity resources across the West. 

The potential for #blackouts and #powershutoffs this summer and fall mark another test for Gov. Gavin Newsom whose first term in office has been defined by emergencies beyond his control and whose political survival is likely to hinge on how voters view his leadership in times of #crisis.

The problems aren‚Äôt new for California or #Newsom, who has pushed his administration to offset the potential effects on the public and pointed to climate change and mismanagement of Pacific Gas & Electric Co. as the driving causes of the state‚Äôs electricity problems.

Read more about how this could impact Newsom during the recall election at link in bio.

"People will ultimately hold him responsible for the state of California, and if they can't turn their lights on right around the time they're voting, they re going to be thinking about that." DAVE GILLIARD // REPUBL ICAN STRATEGIST

BREAKING: President Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin are expected to meet in Geneva next month, a source familiar with the arrangements said, maintaining that the meeting will serve as a tool to manage what will continue to be a deeply challenging relationship between the U.S. and Russia.

The meeting is expected to take place on June 16, when Biden and Putin are slated to discuss issues like Iran and North Korea‚Äôs nuclear capabilities, Syria, the Arctic, strategic stability, arms control, climate change, COVID-19 and more.

The meeting, according to the source, will take place next month while Biden is already in Europe. The source said that Biden will meet with Putin after meeting with G-7 allies, so that he can understand their concerns and perspectives on Russia.

La investigaci√≥n ‚ÄúReducci√≥n del albedo glaciar y efectos de la sequ√≠a en los Andes extratropicales, 1986-2020‚Äù, de Thomas Shaw, Genesis Ulloa, David Far√≠as-Barahona, Rodrigo Fernandez, Jos√© Lattus y James McPhee, publicada en el Journal of Glaciology, demuestra que los glaciares de las regiones de Valpara√≠so, Metropolitana y O‚ÄôHiggins est√°n cada vez m√°s vulnerables a procesos de p√©rdida de masa, producto del oscurecimiento del hielo y su efecto en la absorci√≥n de radiaci√≥n solar, conocido como efecto de albedo.

Description:
As sea ice melts and potentially opens new security threats, Russia is deploying soldiers to the Far North in what some have called the beginnings of a Very Cold War.

For its entire history, Russia was effectively defended from the north by the frozen Arctic Ocean. But the minimum summertime ice pack on the ocean in recent years is about one-third less than the average in the 1980s, when monitoring began, researchers with the Colorado-based National Snow and Ice Data Center said last year. The ocean has lost nearly a million square miles of ice and is expected to be mostly ice-free in the summertime by around the middle of the century.

The big melt is Russia‚Äôs strategic ‚Äúworst nightmare,‚Äù said Michael Kofman, a senior researcher at CNA, a think tank based in Arlington, Va. ‚ÄúIt opens an entire new theater in the event of conflict with the United States‚Äù that will prove difficult to defend, he noted. Of the five nations with significant Arctic coastline ‚Äî Canada, Denmark, Norway, Russia and the United States ‚Äî Russia has by far the longest.

The Russian government and companies have developed various moneymaking ideas to take advantage of climate change. Exploiting newly accessible reserves of oil, gas and coal ‚Äî the very resources causing the problem in the first place ‚Äî is high on the list. Moscow also hopes to turn an Arctic Ocean seaway between Europe and Asia, the Northern Sea Route, into essentially a toll road by requiring payments for pilots and icebreaker escorts.

That could become a flash point because Washington sees the waterway as an international trading route. The Department of Defense says it reserves the right to conduct freedom of navigation exercises in the Arctic, as it does now in the South China Sea.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about how climate change is affecting how Russia defends its borders. Photos by @emileducke

Description:
Demographers now predict that by the latter half of this century ‚Äî or possibly earlier ‚Äî the global population will enter a sustained decline for the first time.‚Å£
‚Å£
Maternity wards are already shutting down in Italy. Ghost cities are appearing in China. Universities in South Korea can‚Äôt find enough students. And in Germany, hundreds of thousands of properties have been razed, with the land turned into parks.‚Å£
‚Å£
Like an avalanche, the demographic forces ‚Äî pushing toward more deaths than births ‚Äî seem to be expanding and accelerating. Though some countries continue to see their populations grow, especially in Africa, fertility rates are falling nearly everywhere else, as women have gained more access to education and contraception.‚Å£
‚Å£
A planet with fewer people could ease pressure on resources, slow climate change and reduce burdens for women. But the data also points to changes that are hard to fathom. The strain of longer lives and low fertility, which lead to fewer workers and more retirees, threatens to upend how societies are organized ‚Äî around the notion that a surplus of young people will drive economies and help pay for the old. It may also require a reconceptualization of family and nation. Imagine entire regions where everyone is 70 or older. Imagine governments laying out huge bonuses for immigrants and mothers with lots of children. Imagine a gig economy filled with grandparents and Super Bowl ads promoting procreation.‚Å£
‚Å£
‚ÄúA paradigm shift is necessary,‚Äù said Frank Swiaczny, a German demographer who was the chief of population trends and analysis for the United Nations until last year. ‚ÄúCountries need to learn to live with and adapt to decline.‚Äù Tap the link in our bio for more on how countries are confronting population stagnation and a fertility bust that could reshape society. Photos by  @gillessabrie, @nytchangster, @poraschaudhary, @justingellerson and @giannicipriano.

Description:
Las mejores fotograf√≠as de PHotoEspa√±a 2021. 

El festival fotogr√°fico PHotoEspa√±a en diferentes espacios de Madrid arranca entre los meses de junio y septiembre con una selecci√≥n de fotograf√≠as africanas, miradas femeninas, autores consagrados y voces j√≥venes. 

A continuaci√≥n adelantamos 6 de las im√°genes que podr√°n verse en las distintas exposiciones.

Somos Agua de Isabel Mu√±oz, m√°s all√° del valor po√©tico de las im√°genes, la obra apela al calentamiento global y el agotamiento de los recursos naturales. 

El Museo Nacional del Romanticismo acoger√° 'En danza', la muestra de otra de las grandes de la fotograf√≠a, la norteamericana Barbara Morgan, "figura clave del arte visual y el mundo de la danza por sus penetrantes estudios de bailarines modernos estadounidenses".

En el Real Jard√≠n Bot√°nico, bajo patrocinio de la Fundaci√≥n Enaire, podr√° verse Doom City, de Montserrat Soto: "una reflexi√≥n acerca del nomadismo y sus consecuencias sobre el hombre y el territorio".

La Real Sociedad Fotogr√°fica dedicar√° una muestra a otra de las pioneras de la fotograf√≠a espa√±ola, la artista navarra Lydia Anoz (1925-2017), "creadora valiente e inconformista que abordaba su arte como una manera de trascender la realidad".

La Fundaci√≥n Mapfre ofrecer√° una monogr√°fica de Bill Brandt, "uno de los padres de la fotograf√≠a moderna", as√≠ como "un autor fundamental para entender las claves de la sociedad inglesa de mediados del siglo XX".

Noches blancas, en el C√≠rculo de Bellas Artes de Madrid, con las series Crazy Horse, de Timm Rautert, y Studio 54, de Tod Papageorge mostrar√°n sendos retratos de las veladas canallas en los locales m√°s de moda en los a√±os setenta en Par√≠s y Nueva York. 

üì∏ Isabel Mu√±oz, Barbara Morgan, Montserrat Soto, Lydia Anoz, Bill Brandt, Tod Papageorge

üî¥Un virulento incendio arrasa la pen√≠nsula griega y se acerca a Atenas tras arrasar ya con 5.000 hect√°reas de bosque.

El fuego recorre la regi√≥n de √Åtica en Grecia y ha obligado a evacuar a los habitantes de siete poblaciones y dos monasterios. El humo provocado por las llamas es visible desde la Acr√≥polis ateniense, el sur de la pen√≠nsula y las islas de Egeo.

El fuego se inici√≥ el mi√©rcoles por la noche cerca de un hotel en el golfo de Corintia, a tan solo 90 kil√≥metros de Atenas. El fuerte viento propag√≥ las llamas hacia el oeste de la pen√≠nsula, en direcci√≥n a las monta√±as de Geraneia. Los esfuerzos de 250 bomberos se centran en evitar que el incendio llegue a la ciudad de Megara, donde viven m√°s de 30.000 personas. "La situaci√≥n sigue siendo peligrosa y el fuego se ha reactivado en algunos lugares", afirma el portavoz del Departamento de Bomberos Vassilis Vathrakoyiannis. 

Tres helic√≥pteros y 17 aviones tratan de apagar el fuego con agua del mar, aunque no pueden continuar con sus labores durante la noche. Adem√°s, ha ardido parte del tendido el√©ctrico, lo que ha provocado apagones en la regi√≥n. "Va a ser otra noche dura y las condiciones van a ser dif√≠ciles", afirma Nikos Hardalias, jefe de Protecci√≥n Civil, pero asegura que "todos los recursos disponibles est√°n siendo utilizados".

Los incendios se han vuelto muy comunes en Grecia durante los veranos a causa del aumento de temperaturas y el cambio clim√°tico. El √∫ltimo fue en julio 2018, un fuego que lleg√≥ al este de Atenas y en el que murieron 102 personas.

Description:
What does police reform look like in New York City? 

The race to become New York City‚Äôs next mayor is one of the most consequential political contests in a generation, with the recovery of the nation's largest city at stake. Policing and what that means for the city will be a huge undertaking for its next leader.

The New York Times spoke with the eight leading Democratic candidates and asked them about their views on serious topics such as police reform, climate change and recovery from the coronavirus pandemic.

After last summer‚Äôs swell of protests ‚Äî following the deaths of George Floyd and Breonna Taylor ‚Äî many left-leaning progressives have called for the defunding of police departments across the nation, including in New York City. The NYPD is considered one of the biggest law enforcement agencies in the country, where in 2020 $1 billion was cut from the department‚Äôs $6 billion operating budget. 

For many supporters of the ‚ÄúDefund the Police‚Äù movement, this was still not enough. Others argue that defunding is too divisive, and instead suggest shifting the conversation to reforming the police department from within. Among the mayoral candidates, Eric Adams, Brooklyn borough president and former NYPD officer, supports this perspective. But Dianne Morales, a former nonprofit executive, would like to divest from the police department and focus on community-based services. Many of the other candidates have proposed shifting more funds to social services. 

So where do the leading candidates agree on police reform? Tap this link to watch the full interviews and to view a guide on the candidates before the primaries on June 22.

https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2021/nyregion/nyc-mayor-candidates-video.html
ImageText: What What Is the Most Important Police Reform You Would Pursue as Mayor?

Description:
Climate change is forcing the Park Service to make brutal choices at National Parks ‚Äî including what to save.‚Å£
‚Å£
For more than a century, the core mission of the National Park Service has been preserving the natural heritage of the U.S. But now, as the planet warms, and ecosystems are transformed, the agency is conceding that its traditional goal of absolute conservation is no longer viable in many cases.‚Å£
‚Å£
Late last month the service published an 80-page document that lays out new guidance for park managers in the era of climate change. The document, along with two peer-reviewed papers, is essentially a tool kit for the new world. It aims to help park ecologists and managers confront the fact that, increasingly, they must now actively choose what to save, what to shepherd through radical environmental transformation and what will vanish forever.‚Å£
‚Å£
The new research and guidance ‚Äî which focus on how to plan for worst-case scenarios, decide what species and landscapes to prioritize, and how to assess the risk of relocating those that can‚Äôt survive otherwise ‚Äî represent a kind of ‚Äúreckoning‚Äù for the Park Service.‚Å£
‚Å£
Decisions about what to protect are especially imminent for forests, where changes are leading some researchers to wonder if the age of North American woodlands is coming to an end.‚Å£
‚Å£
In the Southwest, for example, research suggests that, in the event of wildfires, up to 30% of forestland might never grow back because global warming favors shrubs or grasslands in their ranges. Joshua trees, for example, appear likely to lose all of their habitat in their namesake national park by the end of the century.‚Å£
‚Å£
In the wake of climate change, ecologists are being forced to do triage, deciding what to safeguard ‚Äî and what to let slip away.‚Å£
‚Å£
Tap the link in our bio to read more about the future of U.S. National Parks. Photos by @maxwhittaker, @jtully and @stuartpalley

Description:
Just 20 companies are responsible for producing more than half of all the single-use plastic waste in the world, new research has revealed.

If you swipe across, you can see a full list of these global businesses.

The firms, who are being blamed for fuelling the climate crisis, are both state-owned and multinational corporations, including oil and gas giants and chemical companies.

They are behind 55% of the world‚Äôs plastic packaging waste, according to the Plastic Waste Makers index, who for the first time have revealed the companies who produce the polymers that become throwaway plastic items, from face masks to plastic bags and bottles, which at the end of their short life pollute the oceans or are burned or thrown into landfill.

Just 10%-15% of single-use plastic is recycled globally each year - and by 2050 plastic is expected to account for 5%-10% of greenhouse gas emissions.

The enormous plastic waste footprint of the top 20 global companies amounts to more than half of the 130m metric tonnes of single-use plastic thrown away in 2019, the groundbreaking analysis says.

But who are funding these producers?

Click the link to find out which big banks back these businesses.

Description:
Rock art, painted more than 40,000 years ago, is decaying at an alarming rate due to climate change.

On the Indonesian island of Sulawesi, the world's oldest animal cave painting, and other pictures of hunting scenes and supernatural beings, are crumbling faster as temperatures increase.
 
The artwork provides the earliest evidence of human settlement in the region.

Tap the link in bio to find out more about why parts of the pictures are flaking off and how scientists are hoping to conserve the artefacts.

(üì∑Basran Burhan, Linda Siagian)
 
#Archaeology #ClimateChange #BBCNews

La OMS en conjunto con la Organizaci√≥n Internacional del Trabajo (OIT), analiz√≥ el v√≠nculo entre las muertes y el trabajo prolongado. El an√°lisis arroj√≥ una estimaci√≥n de 745 mil personas que habr√≠an fallecido en 2016 luego de trabajar al menos 55 horas a la semana.

Description:
The race to become New York City‚Äôs next mayor is one of the most consequential political contests in a generation, with the recovery of the nation's largest city at stake.

We spoke with the eight leading Democratic candidates and asked them about their views on serious topics like police reform, climate change and what they would do to help New York recover from the coronavirus pandemic. 

But as many New Yorkers know, candidates are judged, too, on whether they root for the Yankees or Mets, their favorite Broadway shows and how they eat their pizza and bagels. (Remember the uproar when Mayor Bill de Blasio ate a piece of pizza with a knife and fork?) So we asked the candidates to tell us their favorite restaurant, park, bagel order, sports team and Broadway show. Here is what they said.

Kathryn Garcia enjoys an everything bagel, open-faced, topped with cream cheese, lox, tomato, onion and capers and frequents Outerspace, a restaurant owned by her sister. Eric Adams has seen the ‚ÄúLion King‚Äù five times, but he doesn‚Äôt eat bagels because he‚Äôs vegan. ‚ÄúNo questions about my cats?‚Äù asked Maya Wiley, who is a fan of Prospect Park.

‚ÄúMy favorite New York City park is Central Park,‚Äù said Andrew Yang, laughing. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt judge. But it is ‚Äî Central Park! It‚Äôs enormous!‚Äù And Shaun Donovan‚Äôs favorite Broadway show is one that he was in. ‚ÄúLittle known fact, when I was in high school we did a performance of ‚ÄòOliver‚Äô at the Shubert Theater,‚Äù Donovan said. ‚ÄúAnd I will never forget that moment.‚Äù Did he star as Oliver? ‚ÄúOf course not,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI was in the chorus.‚Äù

Tap the link in our bio to watch the full interviews and to see a guide on the candidates before the primaries on June 22.

Entre las propuestas, por ejemplo, est√° la protecci√≥n del patrimonio natural y el deber del Estado a garantizar el derecho a contar con una naturaleza protegida y tutelar su preservacioÃÅn y/o conservacioÃÅn, sin olvidar el contexto de cambio clim√°tico.

Para eso se debe reconocer el deber del Estado de velar por la integridad o salud de los ecosistemas, asegurando siempre avanzar y no retroceder en los niveles de proteccioÃÅn de la naturaleza ya alcanzados, y reconocer que el cambio climaÃÅtico es la principal amenaza que enfrenta la humanidad, incorporando el tema en la nueva ConstitucioÃÅn, para que poliÃÅticas puÃÅblicas y legislaciones futuras contemplen siempre evitar riesgos y danÃÉos relacionados con el #cambioclimaÃÅtico.

Description:
A new report has found some of the biggest polymer producers are responsible for 55% of the world‚Äôs single-use plastics.‚Å†
‚Å†
The study, done by researchers at the Minderoo Foundation, found ExxonMobil and Dow were the top culprits, followed by China-based company Sinopec.‚Å†
‚Å†
These three companies alone generate 16% of plastics.‚Å†
‚Å†
'130 million metric tonnes of plastic were thrown away in 2019, with 35% burned, 31% buried in managed landfills and 19% dumped directly on land or into the ocean, the report found.'‚Å†
‚Å†
The research also traced back which banks were financing the companies, finding that Barclays, HSBC and Bank of America were the three top funders.‚Å†
‚Å†
Former US vice-president and environmentalist Al Gore said: The trajectories of the climate crisis and the plastic waste crisis are strikingly similar- and increasingly intertwined.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúWhile the scale of the problem can seem overwhelming, this report shows that fewer than 100 companies are the ultimate source of these harmful products. Tracing the root of causes of the plastic waste crisis empowers us to help solve it.‚Äù
ImageText: 20 companies produce half the world's single-use plastics @emergencyC4

Description:
El calentamiento de la tundra √°rtica dificultar√° la tarea de frenar el cambio clim√°tico, ya que el deshielo del permafrost y los incendios forestales liberan gases de efecto invernadero que no se tienen en cuenta en los acuerdos mundiales sobre emisiones, seg√∫n un estudio publicado el lunes.

A medida que aumentan las temperaturas y se descongela el permafrost, se liberan el di√≥xido de carbono y el metano atrapados en el suelo congelado durante mucho tiempo. Cuanto m√°s profundo es el deshielo, m√°s gas se libera.

Eso podr√≠a crear un bucle de retroalimentaci√≥n que contribuya a calentar a√∫n m√°s la atm√≥sfera, advierten los cient√≠ficos en un estudio publicado en la revista Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

"El √Årtico est√° en proceso de desintegraci√≥n tal y como lo conocemos, y el permafrost es uno de sus principales componentes, con implicaciones bastante graves", afirma Rafe Pomerance, que preside Arctic 21, una red que pone de relieve los retos clim√°ticos de la regi√≥n polar.

Siberia registr√≥ en 2020 las temperaturas m√°s altas de la historia, cuando la ciudad de Verkhoyansk, en el extremo norte, alcanz√≥ los 38 grados Celsius.

Tambi√©n el a√±o pasado, los incendios forestales sin precedentes en la regi√≥n liberaron alrededor de un 35% m√°s de di√≥xido de carbono que en 2019, que vio las emisiones m√°s altas de los incendios en Rusia desde 2003, sostiene el estudio.

Sin embargo, los niveles de emisiones estimados a partir del descongelamiento gradual del permafrost -que cubre el 25% del hemisferio norte- no tienen en cuenta los incendios forestales y el descongelamiento abrupto observados recientemente, por lo que probablemente sean demasiado bajos, dicen los autores. 

Esa omisi√≥n "nos deja un agujero importante en esas predicciones", dijo la coautora Rachael Treharne, especialista en el √Årtico del Centro de Investigaci√≥n Clim√°tica Woodwell de Massachusetts.
ImageText: DESHIELO DEL PERMAFROST √ÅRTICO E INCENDIOS FORESTALES SON CRECIENTE AMENAZA PARA EL CLIMA REUTERS 24>HORAS

Description:
Miles de toneladas de #salmones aparecieron muertos por falta de ox√≠geno en el fiordo #Comau y canales #Jacaf y #Puyuhuapi; en las regiones de #LosLagos y de #Ays√©n hace unas semanas tras un episodio de floraci√≥n de algas nocivas. Este suceso, calificado como "cat√°strofe ambiental", moviliz√≥ a m√°s de 60 organizaciones medioambientales chilenas que exigieron la salida de la industria salmonera de lagos, fiordos y canales de la #Patagonia.

Seg√∫n denunciaron en un comunicado conjunto, se trata de "sucesos ampliamente conocidos de da√±o ambiental durante d√©cadas". Por este motivo, reclamaron al gobierno chileno que no se entregue nuevas concesiones a esta industria, que no se ampl√≠en las concesiones actuales y que en estas tampoco se permita aumentar el n√∫mero de peces criados.

"Las floraciones de algas han sido normales en Chile, sin embargo √∫ltimamente han estado pasando con mayor recurrencia", alert√≥ a DW Liesbeth van der Meer, directora de Oceana Chile, apuntando al cambio clim√°tico como una de las causas.

"Un verano seco con poca precipitaci√≥n, el resultado de eso es que el agua superficial, que normalmente es una capa de agua dulce, con baja salinidad, se pone m√°s salina y eso crea las condiciones para que las algas nocivas puedan crecer", explic√≥ a DW Vreni Ha√ºsserman, investigadora de la Universidad San Sebasti√°n en la Patagonia. "Adem√°s la radiaci√≥n solar aumentada por tiempos con pocas nubes y el calentamiento del agua superficial tambi√©n aumenta el crecimiento de algas", agreg√≥.

No obstante, las organizaciones medioambientales chilenas acusan a las propias empresas salmoneras de la cat√°strofe #medioambiental. "Los efectos del cambio clim√°tico pueden ser a√∫n m√°s devastadores si se dan en ecosistemas que se encuentran enfermos. Ese es el caso de lo que est√° sucediendo en los fiordos y canales del sur de Chile donde se ha instalado la industria salmonera", dijo a DW Mauricio Ceballos, vocero de la campa√±a de Oc√©anos en Greenpeace Chile.

Esto resaltar√≠a la gran importancia de los #√°rboles dentro de la lucha contra el cambio clim√°tico y porsupuesto sus graves efectos. ‚ÄúPara evitar un #cambioclim√°tico peligroso, debemos detener la deforestaci√≥n y restaurar los bosques naturales‚Äú, indic√≥ William Baldwin-Cantello del Fondo Mundial para la Naturaleza (WWF) manifest√≥ a la BBC. Adem√°s, el equipo se√±al√≥  que cada a√±o se queman y talan muchas m√°s hect√°reas en todo el mundo de las que se vuelven a cultivar o regenerar naturalmente. ‚ÄúPara hacer realidad el potencial de los bosques como soluci√≥n clim√°tica, necesitamos apoyo para la regeneraci√≥n en los planes clim√°ticos y debemos abordar a los impulsores de la deforestaci√≥n‚Äù, recalc√≥. ¬øQu√© te parece? üëá

El Pleno del Congreso de los Diputados ha aprobado hoy de manera definitiva el proyecto de Ley de Cambio Clim√°tico y Transici√≥n Energ√©tica tras un a√±o de tr√°mite parlamentario y en un √∫ltimo debate en el que se han refrendado cinco enmiendas incorporadas a su paso por el Senado. 

El proyecto de Ley ha salido adelante con los votos en contra de Vox, la abstenci√≥n de PP y M√°s Pa√≠s, y entre cr√≠ticas generalizadas por parte de los partidos de la oposici√≥n, que lo califican de "insuficiente". 

Su objetivo es la descarbonizaci√≥n en Espa√±a de aqu√≠ a 2050 y establece un articulado que servir√° de hoja de ruta para la transici√≥n ecol√≥gica.. 

La norma, que entrar√° en vigor al d√≠a siguiente de su publicaci√≥n en el Bolet√≠n Oficial del Estado, es la primera en el ordenamiento legislativo nacional para luchar contra el calentamiento global, y ha sido aprobada seis a√±os despu√©s de la firma del Acuerdo del Clima de Par√≠s y cuatro desde que Espa√±a lo ratific√≥.

Description:
üî¥ Espa√±a aprueba por fin su primera ley contra el cambio clim√°tico.

Con diez a√±os de retraso (cinco desde que se aprob√≥ el acuerdo de Par√≠s), el Congreso ha aprobado finamente la Ley de Cambio Clim√°tico, cuyos borradores fueron manejados por el gobierno del PP sin ver la luz. La ley sienta las bases para afrontar la crisis clim√°tica, transformar el modelo energ√©tico y favorecer la sustituci√≥n de combustibles f√≥siles. Una consecuencia inmediata es la prohibici√≥n de explorar nuevos yacimientos de petr√≥leo y gas, y la previsi√≥n de que en 20 a√±os ya no se pondr√°n en el mercado nuevos turismos de combusti√≥n interna.

Impulsada por Unidas Podemos y PSOE, el texto ha contado desde el primer momento con el apoyo de ERC, EH-Bildu, PNV y Teruel Existe, mientras que PP, VOX y M√°s Madrid no le han dado apoyo. 

Fue muy significativa la intervenci√≥n del portavoz de ERC, Gabriel Rufi√°n, que supli√≥ a su compa√±ero en la ponencia, Joan Capdevila, para dar un respaldo entusiasta a la ley. "Hay que dejar de proteger con dinero p√∫blico a petroleras y a gas√≠sticas", solt√≥.

La primera norma en Espa√±a para mitigar el calentamiento global era (y es) una de las grandes apuestas de legislatura del Gobierno, y ha servido para demostrar la cohesi√≥n de los partidos que integran el Gobierno. 

Las cr√≠ticas de la oposici√≥n se centraron en el retraso de la ley y en la falta de consenso (aunque C,s tambi√©n se sum√≥), mientras que M√°s Pa√≠s tach√≥ de insuficiente el objetivo de reducci√≥n de emisiones de gases para el 2030 (cifrado en un 23% respecto a 1990).

La  vicepresidenta cuarta y ministra para la Transici√≥n Ecol√≥gica, Teresa Ribera, admiti√≥ que a partir del 2023 (como se fija en la ley) se debe revisar al alza esos objetivos. "Debemos acelerar y profundizar en la acci√≥n clim√°tica", dijo.

La ley incluye la previsi√≥n de prescindir de los veh√≠culos convencionales de combusti√≥n interna en el a√±o 2040 (gasolina, di√©sel e h√≠bridos no enchufables) y prohibir las nuevas autorizaciones de exploraci√≥n, permisos de investigaci√≥n y concesiones de explotaci√≥n de hidrocarburos, incluidas las zonas costeras.

Description:
Tesla will no longer accept Bitcoin as payment due to concerns about climate change, its CEO Elon Musk said in a tweet.
 
Bitcoin fell by more than 10% after the tweet and Tesla shares also dipped.
 
The company's announcement in March that it would accept the cryptocurrency was met with an outcry from some environmentalists and investors.
 
In February it revealed it had bought $1.5bn (¬£1bn) of the world's biggest digital currency - but on Thursday, it backtracked.
 
"We are concerned about rapidly increasing use of fossil fuels for Bitcoin mining and transactions, especially coal, which has the worst emissions of any fuel," Elon Musk wrote.

Click the link in our bio to find out how the company intends to spend their Bitcoin.
 
(üì∑Reuters)
 
#ElonMusk #Tesla #Bitcoin #BBCNews
ImageText: NEWS "Cryptocurrency is a good idea... but this cannot come at great cost to the environment" Elon Musk

Description:
In the Russian republic of Kalmykia, the encroaching desert has transformed the landscape, threatening the livelihoods of the farmers who live there.‚Å£
‚Å£
In the last several decades, droughts and unrelenting winds in Kalmykia, on the northwestern shores of the Caspian Sea, destroyed the once-productive land. Pastures were grazed beyond their sustainable limits. Climate change is exacerbating an already dire situation. In many places, an encroaching sea of sand is overtaking farmers‚Äô camps, swallowing their animals‚Äô food supplies.‚Å£
‚Å£
In Kalmykia, distance is an inescapable reality, writes the photographer @maksimbabenko of his trip there. ‚ÄúThe nighttime silence is broken only by the sounds of the wind and by a fox scratching at the walls.‚Äù Kalmykia is sparsely populated; only about 300,000 people live there, in a territory of some 30,000 square miles. You can drive for hours on end without meeting a single person.‚Å£
‚Å£
There, some 1,400 years ago, the Khazars, a seminomadic Turkic people, formed one of the most influential trading empires in the medieval world, profoundly shaping the histories of Europe and Asia. The Kalmyk people came much later ‚Äî descendants of the nomadic Oirat Mongols who, in the 16th and 17th centuries, traveled west from what is now Kazakhstan, Russia, Mongolia and China in search of pastureland.‚Å£
‚Å£
Erdni, who lives and works there, said hardly any grass grew in 2020 for the sheep to graze upon. ‚ÄúAfter the past year, I no longer wish for my son to continue my traditions here, or to live on this spot in the steppe,‚Äù he said. Conditions have become too difficult. People are beginning to leave, he said. Even Erdni has considered moving north in search of work.‚Å£
‚Å£
‚ÄúOur people have already been deported to Siberia once,‚Äù he said, referring to a forced resettlement by the Soviet government in 1943. ‚ÄúNow nature itself is forcing us to leave.‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£
Tap the link in our bio to read more from @nytimestravel about how changes to the Kalmyk steppe are impacting the people who live there. Photos by @maksimbabenko‚Å£

Description:
In 2020, Vanessa Nakate was cropped out of a news photo featuring her and four white climate activists at Davos, drawing global attention that she has since harnessed to expand her work in Uganda and beyond.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
@vanessanakate1, a now 24-year-old Ugandan, had participated in a news conference at the World Economic Forum with young climate activists, including the Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg. But when The Associated Press released a picture of the five from the event, Nakate had been cropped out.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
The omission shocked and saddened Nakate, who in a tearful 10-minute video posted on Twitter denounced the ‚Äúracism‚Äù in the global environmental movement and the erasure of Black and African voices from conversations around climate activism, even as their communities and countries are disproportionately affected by the crisis.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
‚ÄúI felt like I had wasted time going to Davos,‚Äù she said in a recent interview in the Ugandan capital, Kampala. ‚ÄúI felt that I shouldn‚Äôt have been at the news conference.‚Äù‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Yet her presence at the event and the effect that the episode had on her elicited a response that reverberated across the world. And by the time Nakate‚Äôs flight landed in Uganda a day after she posted her video, she had solidified her place as a leading voice among young Africans passionately arguing for action against climate change.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
 ‚ÄúYou cannot have climate justice without racial justice,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt isn‚Äôt justice if it doesn‚Äôt include everyone.‚Äù‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Tap the link in our bio for more on how the deletion of the sole Black activist from the image highlighted both racial injustice globally and the disproportionate effects that climate change and other environmental issues are having on countries that are predominantly home to people of color. Photo by @esther_mbabazi.‚Å£
ImageText: "You cannot have climate justice without racial racial justice." Vanessa Nakate Climate activist

Description:
Sir David Attenborough will try again later this year to convince world leaders that immediate climate action is vital.

Sir David has been named the "people's advocate" at the COP26 summit, to be held in Glasgow in November.

As part of the role, the 95-year-old will address political leaders about why action is needed to prevent the catastrophic consequences of climate change.

#SirDavidAttenborough #COP26 #ClimateChange
ImageText: sky news 'There could not be a more important moment'

Description:
The climate crisis is putting the British cuppa at risk, a new report has warned.‚Å†
‚Å†
The research by Christian Aid suggests rising global temperatures and extreme weather could see tea production fall by as much as 39 percent in some regions.‚Å†
‚Å†
It could even impact the taste of tea, affecting leaf quality and reducing its healthy compounds.‚Å†
‚Å†
The UK and Ireland drink more tea per person than anywhere else on the planet ‚Äì and half of the UK‚Äôs black tea comes from Kenya, the world‚Äôs biggest tea exporter.‚Å†
‚Å†
But Kenya will face increasingly erratic rainfall in coming years, due to climate change.‚Å†
‚Å†
And by 2050, the country could see as much as a 26 percent decrease in optimum tea growing conditions.‚Å†
‚Å†
Kenyan tea farmer Richard Koskei, 72, said, ‚ÄúClimate change poses a real threat to us.‚Å†
‚Å†
"We cannot predict seasons anymore, temperatures are rising, rainfall is more erratic, more often accompanied by unusual hailstones and longer droughts which was not the case in the past.‚Å†
‚Å†
"If this continues then it will make growing tea much harder and life for us extremely difficult."‚Å†
‚Å†
The report‚Äôs warning comes as the UK prepares to host the COP26 climate talks in November.
ImageText: Climate crisis threatens tea production, report warns @emergencyC4

Seg√∫n los especialistas, las ballenas grises normalmente migran a lo largo de la costa oeste de #EstadosUnidos, pero creen que con el calentamiento global abriendo las rutas del norte, la ballena se perdi√≥ y nad√≥ hacia el oc√©ano Atl√°ntico a trav√©s del √Årtico. Esta joven ballena gris de 8 metros de largo se ha perdido en el Mediterr√°neo, a miles de kil√≥metros de California, en el  oc√©ano Pac√≠fico, muy lejos de su habitat natural. Desesperada, Wally, como la han bautizado,  busca la forma de regresar a casa y se teme por su superviviencia. El bi√≥logo frances Eric Hansen cree que la ballena pudo cometer un error. El calentamiento global  ha derretido el  hielo de los pasillos que conectan el oc√©ano pac√≠fico con el atlantico. Antes s√≥lo ocurr√≠a en verano. El cet√°ceo deber√≠a haber descencido por la costa del Pac√≠fico desde Alaska hasta Califorinia. En su lugar vir√≥ por el atlantico hasta la costa Francesa. A la investigadora Celine Tardy le preocupa que ha bajado mucho de peso y no puede encontrar los invertebrados de los que  se alimenta en el Meditarreo. Aqui nada bueno le espera. Hay demasiado tr√°fico de barcos y ya cay√≥ en unas redes de pesca, de las que se liber√≥ por si misma. Description:
Amid a rise in anti-Asian racism, activists in California‚Äôs Bay Area are fighting for a future in which Asian and other communities of color feel safe ‚Äî from hate crimes, but also from climate change, the housing crisis and more.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúThink about safety in a more grounded, expansive way,‚Äù said Vivian Huang, deputy director of the Oakland-based Asian Pacific Environmental Network, ‚Äúabout people feeling connected to one another, having access to resources they need, the stability that comes from stable housing, food and health care access.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
For Huang and other activists, the violence this past year against Asians ‚Äî including high-profile attacks on older people in the Bay Area ‚Äî did not happen in a vacuum: It‚Äôs part of a long history of anti-Asian racism in this country. The solutions are complex and require long-term planning, including organizing with other people of color and demanding investments in their communities‚Äô livelihoods and health.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúWe all deserve safety. We‚Äôre not safe if only one part of our community is safe,‚Äù Huang said, adding that the multiracial groups have a common cause: ‚Äúcombating white supremacy.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Click the link in bio to read about how Bay Area organizers like @apen4ej and @aypalpower are working to solve issues around racism, climate change, the housing crisis and so much more. // üñäÔ∏è: @sarahruizgrossman; üì∑: @kristenmurakoshi
ImageText: HUFFPOST " "We all deserve safety. We're not safe if only one part of our community is safe." Vivian Huang APAHM 2021

Description:
El Grupo Asesor en #MedioAmbiente (GAMA UC) public√≥ los resultados de la 15¬∞ versi√≥n de su ‚ÄúReporte Anual de Votaciones Ambientales‚Äù, revelando una "escasa actividad legislativa" en la materia y con un tercer a√±o de Gobierno del Presidente #Sebasti√°nPi√±era que termina con "grandes pendientes".

As√≠ lo se√±al√≥ Francisca Reyes, directora del proyecto e investigadora de CAPES y CESIEP. "Sin duda este fue un a√±o duro para los avances de la agenda ambiental en el Congreso". Adem√°s de la "escasa actividad legislativa, el tercer a√±o de mandato del Presidente Pi√±era termina con grandes pendientes, como la aprobaci√≥n del proyecto de ley que crea el Servicio de Biodiversidad y √Åreas Protegidas y el Sistema Nacional de √Åreas Protegidas (actualmente en su √∫ltima instancia en el Congreso), proyecto clave para la institucionalidad ambiental del pa√≠s que lleva en la pr√°ctica una d√©cada tramit√°ndose".

Sin embargo, agreg√≥ que "es importante destacar el avance que significa el ingreso e inicio de la tramitaci√≥n del proyecto que fija la Ley Marco de Cambio Clim√°tico, el que tiene el gran desaf√≠o de incorporar el gran n√∫mero de indicaciones realizadas para seguir avanzando en su tramitaci√≥n".

Las claves de reporte

A d√≠as de haberse cumplido el tercer a√±o de gobierno del Presidente Pi√±era, el reporte consigna que en este tiempo se votaron 12 proyectos de ley en materia #ambiental (7 menos que en el per√≠odo anterior), al tiempo que solamente 22 iniciativas de este tipo fueron ingresados para tramitaci√≥n (56% menos que durante el periodo anterior). De estos, 20 nacieron de la iniciativa de parlamentarios en la forma de mociones.

El documento tambi√©n destaca que durante el periodo analizado solo se aprob√≥ una ley de la Rep√∫blica ‚Äîla que establece el Estatuto Chileno Ant√°rtico‚Äî cuya tramitaci√≥n se alargaba desde el a√±o 2014. Aun as√≠, los revisores enfatizaron que esta ley es s√≥lo parcialmente beneficiosa para el medio ambiente, ya que tiene una relevancia ambiental calificada como baja.

üëâContin√∫a leyendo en el link de la bio‚ùó

Description:
GOP lawmakers are expected to press Biden administration climate envoy John Kerry on his dealings with Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif during a hearing before the House Foreign Affairs Committee next Wednesday.

Kerry will testify at the hearing, dubbed "Driving a Global, Whole-of-Society Response to Climate Action." The hearing will utilize a hybrid format, raising the possibility that Kerry will appear in person.

The hearing will focus on steps to combat climate change as the Biden administration moves forward with its goal of cutting U.S. carbon emissions in half by 2030. But the event will mark Kerry‚Äôs first public appearance since reports surfaced of an audio file in which Zarif purportedly claimed that Kerry had leaked sensitive information while serving as secretary of state under the Obama administration.

Go to the link in our bio for more on this story.
ImageText: Sipa SipaviaAPImages via Images Kerry likely to face qustions on Iran dealings at House Foreign Affairs climate hearing

Description:
Every 10 years NOAA releases a new set of "climate normals" ‚Äî what is considered normal, typical or average weather in a given location at a given time of year. To ensure that these normals are not subject to the ebb and flow of yearly weather, these averages are based on 30-year time periods to even out any short-term swings.‚Å†‚Å†
‚Å†‚Å†
In the U.S., NOAA's new climate normals reveal that our nation is about on pace with the global average of warming. What's more, the pattern of recent regional changes in our climate validate scientists' understanding of how man-made climate change is unfolding. ‚Å†‚Å†
‚Å†‚Å†
Read more at the link in our bio.
ImageText: U.S.ANNUAL TEMPERATURE COMPARED TO20-ER AVERAGE 1901-1930 1911-1940 1921-1950 1931-1960 1941-1970 1951-1980 1961-1990 1971-2000 1981-2010 1991-2020 NOAA's "new normal" climate report is anything but normal

Description:
Mozambique is experiencing an environmental renaissance ‚Äî and one of the results is a brand new national park.‚Å£
‚Å£
Located on the Zimbabwe border about 90 miles southwest of Gorongosa, Mozambique‚Äôs most famous national park, Chimanimani National Park is the latest triumph for the environment in a country where, just 30 years ago, armies were still funding wars with the blood of poached wildlife.‚Å£
‚Å£
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not every day that a country with a past rife with war and environmental destruction fulfills an ambitious conservation goal,‚Äù Jen Guyton, a photographer and ecologist, writes for @nytimestravel. ‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs exactly what happened last year in Mozambique when, after overhauling its environmental code, the country officially designated Chimanimani as a new national park.‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£
After finishing her Ph.D. in 2018, Guyton shifted to a career in photojournalism and went on two biodiversity surveys in Chimanimani as the photographer. At the end of the two surveys, scientists in Chimanimani had found more than 1,400 species: 475 plants, 43 mammals, 260 birds, 67 amphibians and reptiles, and at least 582 species of insects. Some are new to science.‚Å£
‚Å£
The incredible diversity uncovered by the surveys is only a part of what‚Äôs known. As a whole, the Chimanimani Mountains are known to contain almost 1,000 plant species alone. Seventy-six plant and animal species are endemic to the Chimanimani Mountains, meaning they exist nowhere else on Earth.‚Å£
‚Å£
Because endemic species are threatened by climate change, human population growth and deforestation, ‚ÄúChimanimani‚Äôs future is anything but certain,‚Äù Guyton writes. ‚Å£
‚Å£
‚ÄúBut as I reflect on these surveys and my time in Mozambique, I can‚Äôt help but feel full of hope. I am inspired every day by the passion of young Mozambican conservationists to safeguard their country‚Äôs disappearing wilderness.‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£
Tap the link in our bio to see more of @jenguyton‚Äôs photos and to read her essay for @nytimestravel. ‚Å£

Description:
A new bill is being considered in Brazil that could accelerate deforestation in the Amazon.

It would mean land that has been illegally occupied could be put up for sale, potentially allowing illegal occupants to buy it.

Almost 40 UK food businesses have threatened to stop sourcing products from the country if it passes the vote, in the worry that the land could be cleared for farming.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about how rainforests are critical in slowing the impact of climate change and why this new bill matters.

(üì∑Reuters)

#Brazil #AmazonRainforest #BBCNews

Description:
üåä Two years ago, the world's largest coral reef restoration project started off the coast of Sulawesi, in Indonesia.

Since then, around 40,000 square meters of reef has been restored - increasing coral cover from five to 55 percent. 

The reef can be seen on Google Earth, and has been regrown to spell the word 'hope' to drive awareness of the ongoing threat of climate change - and show how positive change can happen.

Find out more on the #DailyClimateShow at 6:30pm and 9:30pm every weekday.

Description:
Die Bundesregierung arbeitet fieberhaft an einer Antwort auf die Entscheidung des Bundesverfassungsgerichts von voriger Woche. Nach der regul√§ren Kabinettssitzung trafen am Mittwoch die zust√§ndigen Minister zusammen, um √ºber eine Versch√§rfung des deutschen Klimaschutzgesetzes zu beraten. 

Dabei sei man grunds√§tzlich einig gewesen, das Ziel f√ºr 2030 anzuheben, hie√ü es aus Koalitionskreisen. So sollen die deutschen CO‚ÇÇ-Emissionen gegen√ºber 1990 nicht mehr um 55, sondern um 65 Prozent sinken. Deutschland m√ºsste also am Ende dieser Dekade j√§hrlich 125 Millionen Tonnen Kohlendioxid weniger aussto√üen als bisher geplant.

Auch das Fernziel soll versch√§rft werden. Nach Informationen der S√ºddeutschen Zeitung will die Bundesregierung nun nicht erst f√ºr 2050 das Ziel der Klimaneutralit√§t ausrufen, sondern dieses Ziel schon vorher erreichen. Was das f√ºr ein Klimaziel etwa im Jahr 2040 bedeutet, blieb zun√§chst unklar.

Description:
El #bi√≥logomarino y Premio Nacional de Ciencias Aplicadas y Tecnol√≥gicas, #JuanCarlosCastilla, proyecta que los efectos de la #pandemia sobre el #cambioclim√°tico tardar√°n al menos cinco a√±os en observarse. ‚ÄúEstamos en una fase muy preliminar para hacer an√°lisis‚Äù, se√±ala el integrante de la #AcademiaChilenadeCiencias.

Si bien la disminuci√≥n de la actividad humana e industrial, como consecuencia del #confinamiento, alcanz√≥ en promedio un 40%, la reducci√≥n de gases de efecto invernadero no lo hizo en la misma proporci√≥n: seg√∫n cifras del #PanelInternacionalcontraelCambioClim√°tico, en 2010 estas alcanzaron un 17-20% menos con respecto a 2019.

‚ÄúTenemos que esperar por lo menos cinco o seis a√±os porque son impactos en el #clima, no en la temperatura de ma√±ana o de la semana que viene. Aunque detengamos hoy todas las emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero tendremos, por alg√∫n tiempo, las mismas 420 part√≠culas por mill√≥n de CO2 (anh√≠drido carb√≥nico o di√≥xido de carbono) de hoy en la atm√≥sfera. Esto tambi√©n demuestra que se necesita buscar soluciones de largo plazo a la problem√°tica‚Äù, explica.

Castilla, investigador del Centro de Cambio Global de la @ucatolicaoficial, recuerda que los cambios sobre el clima deben ser estudiados en un horizonte de mediano y largo plazo, y que a√∫n no es posible establecer con exactitud el impacto de estas alteraciones en el largo plazo.

‚ÄúEn este caso, no podemos decir ‚Äòdespu√©s de la pandemia fui a medir la concentraci√≥n en la atm√≥sfera de mol√©culas de CO2 y muestran la misma concentraci√≥n que antes, por lo tanto, la inactividad mundial no influy√≥ en nada‚Äô. Ello, porque una vez que las mol√©culas de CO2 llegan a la atm√≥sfera, se mantienen all√≠ por bastante tiempo. Por ejemplo, la mol√©cula de metano se mantiene por a lo menos doce a√±os y la de anh√≠drido carb√≥nico puede permanecer hasta 100 o m√°s a√±os‚Äù, detalla el bi√≥logo marino.
