Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è Eleven Madison Park, a three-Michelin-starred New York restaurant, will be going completely plant-based when it reopens next month, it announced Monday -- becoming one of the most high-profile restaurants to do so. The move reflects a growing trend in the food industry, as more and more institutions transition toward more sustainable ingredients and food practices. Epicurious, a well-known online food publication, announced just last week it would no longer publish new recipes that include beef, saying beef's production creates large quantities of greenhouse gas emissions and thus impacts climate change. In an interview with NPR's "How I Built This," chef and owner Daniel Humm said the way people eat meat is "not sustainable," similar to the reasons Epicurious gave. NHS workers at Wales‚Äô largest hospital are creating a woodland to offset the carbon emissions and waste that came from the machines needed to treat patients with Covid-19. 

Staff on the critical care unit at the University Hospital of Wales in Cardiff say they hope their woodland in Crickhowell inspires other hospital trusts and industries to do the same.

The woodland will be given a Welsh name and should be open to the public later this year. üå≥üå≥üå≥

En una iniciativa de las organizaciones internacionales Partners of the Americas y Seconde Nature, investigadores y representantes de diferentes instituciones de educaci√≥n superior de todo el mundo est√°n formando parte de un Comit√© de Co-Creaci√≥n destinado a aunar los esfuerzos de estas entidades en contribuir a frenar la #crisisclim√°tica por la que atraviesa, actualmente, nuestro planeta.

Desde la regi√≥n m√°s austral de #Chile se sumaron en 2020 los investigadores de la Universidad de #Magallanes (UMAG) Claudia MacLean y Ricardo Rozzi, quienes pasaron a conformar un selecto grupo de 22 miembros alrededor del globo, provenientes de pa√≠ses como Estados Unidos, M√©xico, Panam√°, Costa Rica, Brasil y Colombia. ¬øSu misi√≥n? Trabajar en red en pos a los objetivos de esta alianza que tiene como fin √∫ltimo impulsar la acci√≥n clim√°tica desde las fortalezas que tiene la educaci√≥n superior.

La iniciativa

Seg√∫n afirman las organizaciones impulsoras de esta iniciativa ‚Äúlas instituciones de educaci√≥n superior, como anclas de sus comunidades y los educadores de los l√≠deres del ma√±ana, tienen un papel y responsabilidad √∫nica en el esfuerzo por abordar el cambio clim√°tico‚Äù.

Al respecto, agregan que ‚Äúson estas instituciones las que determinar√°n si los l√≠deres emergentes de hoy est√°n equipados para abordar la crisis clim√°tica, ya sea a trav√©s de la ciencia, los negocios, el servicio p√∫blico o cualquier otro camino profesional. Si las universidades, las instituciones t√©cnicas y polit√©cnicas, y los institutos de tecnolog√≠a de la regi√≥n se movilizan juntos para abordar el cambio clim√°tico, su impacto podr√≠a ser significativo‚Äù.

Description:
The UK is being taken to court by three young people who claim their human rights are being breached by the government‚Äôs failure to act decisively on the climate crisis.

Adetola Stephanie Onamade, Marina Tricks and Jerry Amokwandoh, all students in their early 20s, will tomorrow ask for a judicial review of government actions to cut national carbon emissions.

The three claimants say that despite enshrining a net zero goal by 2050 in law and parliament declaring a climate emergency, the government does not have an adequate roadmap to match the scale of the crisis.

Frustrated at the pace of action, they will argue that the UK has disregarded their rights to life, family life and not be discriminated against, which are protected under articles 2, 8 and 14 of the Human Rights Act.

Mexican-born Tricks, the youngest claimant aged 20, said she felt she had a duty to hold her government accountable. She told the Guardian: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre in the epicentre of destruction. It‚Äôs almost about weaponising the privileges we have of being in the global north.‚Äù

The other two young claimants are also from diaspora backgrounds: Onamade from Nigeria and Trinidad and Tobago and Amokwandoh from Ghana. They say they are also eager to highlight links between the climate crisis and wider social injustice, be it gender, race or wealth, pointing out that environmental harm is not shared equally.

In the UK, illegal levels of air pollution disproportionately affect racially marginalised communities, while the country is exporting its plastic pollution problem to poorer countries rather than tackling it domestically.

The Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy, which has lead responsibility for climate change, declined to comment on the lawsuit.

But in its response to a pre-legal action letter, the government‚Äôs legal team called the claim ‚Äúpointless‚Äù given that the government had published plans to meet its net zero target and was due to publish a net zero strategy before the Cop26 climate talks in November.

Photo: Plan B campaign material from 2020
ImageText: Students sue UK government over human rights impact of the climate crisis G MARINA TRICKS ADETOLA ONAMADE JERRY AMOKWANDOH 19D 23ARSOD 22VEARSOLD

Description:
Im Klimaschutzgesetz von 2019 hat die deutsche Regierung festgeschrieben, dass der CO2-Aussto√ü bis 2030 um 55 Prozent im Vergleich zu 1990 reduziert werden muss. Wie es danach weitergeht, ist nicht konkretisiert, obwohl die Europ√§ische Union inzwischen gesetzlich festgeschrieben hat, dass sie bis 2050 klimaneutral werden m√∂chte. Das Bundesverfassungsgericht hat nun geurteilt: Die Bundesregierung muss die Planungen f√ºr 2030 bis 2050 konkretisieren. 
Mit diesem Urteil sei die Klimapolitik zu Recht und mit guten Argumenten korrigiert worden, sagte Bundeswirtschaftsminister Peter Altmaier (CDU) im Deutschlandfunk. Der Bundestag habe mit dem Klimaschutzgesetz im Jahr 2019 ein sehr weitgehendes Gesetz beschlossen. Erst danach habe man sich in der EU auf Klimaneutralit√§t bis 2050 verst√§ndigt. Dieses Ziel sei im Klimaschutzgesetz ‚Äûnoch nicht ausreichend reflektiert‚Äú. 
Altmaier sagte, man m√ºsse ‚Äûalles, was Karlsruhe von uns verlangt, auch tats√§chlich umsetzen.‚Äú 
.
.Das Interview mit Peter Altmaier finden Sie √ºber den Lonk in der Bio. 
.

En la primera investigaci√≥n de la Cumbre de la Tierra de R√≠o de Janeiro, en el a√±o 1990 y luego en 1992, los expertos del #IPCC (Grupo Intergubernamental de Expertos sobre el Cambio Clim√°tico / GIEC) nos hab√≠an fijado una meta. Tuve la oportunidad de participar en esta cumbre junto al entonces presidente franc√©s, #Fran√ßoisMitterrand. Se trataba de impedir el cambio clim√°tico que ya empezaba a manifestarse.

En aquel momento, habl√°bamos de pasar a un modelo de desarrollo sostenible. La humanidad ya estaba entrando en una deuda #ecol√≥gica en plazos que se reduc√≠an muy claramente. Este objetivo no ha sido alcanzado y es necesario admitirlo para saber c√≥mo retomar la acci√≥n. La alerta no se tom√≥ en serio. El resultado est√° ante nuestros ojos. El cambio clim√°tico ha comenzado. Es irreversible. La modificaci√≥n de todo el entorno f√≠sico de nuestras sociedades est√° alterando todos los aspectos de nuestro modo de vida y muchos de los aspectos fundamentales de la civilizaci√≥n humana en general. Y, adem√°s, la din√°mica de este cambio obedece a leyes f√≠sicas que modifican fundamentalmente las condiciones y la manera de tomar las decisiones pol√≠ticas. Estamos entrando en una era de incertidumbre permanente.

Por Jean Luc M√©lenchon üñäüíª

Rep. Dan Crenshaw returned to his committee duties on Thursday after recovering from eye surgery due to complications of his combat injuries, saying wounds like his are sometimes the sacrifice of military service.

Crenshaw got back in the saddle Thursday, returning to the House Energy and Commerce Committee‚Äôs climate change subcommittee for a hearing featuring Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Michael Regan.

The Texas Republican had emergency surgery last month to fix a detached retina that occurred due to the injuries he sustained while serving as a Navy SEAL in Afghanistan.

Description:
President Biden has laid out his vision ‚Äî now Senator Chuck Schumer has to bring it to life.

Biden outlined his ambitious plan for a post-pandemic America in his first address to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday night. It‚Äôs now up to Schumer, the New York Democrat and Senate majority leader, to navigate resistant Republicans dismayed at the more than $4 trillion in new Democratic spending proposals and Democrats insisting on a bipartisan approach to delivering the second monumental piece of legislation of his tenure. He says he understands that some of his colleagues won‚Äôt be rushed into pushing through the expansive approach outlined by the president over Republican objections. Schumer said he is willing to give bipartisan efforts some time, but the time will quickly come for Democrats to leave Republicans behind, should their view of what‚Äôs needed fail to align with Biden‚Äôs and his own.
 
‚ÄúIf and when it becomes clear that Republicans won‚Äôt join us in big, bold action, we will move in that direction‚Äù without them, he acknowledged.
 
Like Biden, Schumer is celebrating his first 100 days in a new leadership position. He said the weight of the task hit him as he scrolled through Georgia runoff returns in the early morning hours of January 6.
 
‚ÄúI realized the huge responsibility on the shoulders of our Democratic majority, narrow though it is,‚Äù Schumer said. Democrats needed to provide added pandemic relief and attack deep-seated problems such as racial injustice and climate change while restoring public faith in elections and government. Events at the Capitol riot later on January 6 would add to the burden.
 
Despite the crush, Schumer and Democrats see themselves as having surpassed expectations with a broad $1.9 trillion pandemic relief bill already on the books, confirmation of the president‚Äôs cabinet with only one candidate withdrawn, and an impeachment trial that drew Republican support for conviction of Donald Trump and met Democratic demands to hold him accountable for the assault on the Capitol. Tap the link in our bio to read more. Photo by @nytmills.

Description:
New York Times reporters fact-checked President Biden‚Äôs address to a joint session of Congress Wednesday evening.‚Å£
‚Å£
In his first nationally televised address to a joint session of Congress, Biden laid out an ambitious agenda to rewrite the American social compact by vastly expanding family leave, child care, health care, preschool and college education for millions of people to be financed with increased taxes on the wealthiest earners. He also covered issues including job creation, gun control, climate change and immigration. ‚Å£
‚Å£
The president called for legislation to improve policing across the U.S. and to restrict access to high-powered firearms. He expressed hope that negotiations to rein in police abuses may reach bipartisan agreement and called on lawmakers to come to a deal by next month, one year after George Floyd‚Äôs death, but no consensus across the aisle appears likely for meaningful gun legislation.‚Å£
‚Å£
The president, who has struggled to respond to a surge of migrants at the southwestern border since taking office, highlighted his proposed overhaul of the immigration system, discussed his goals to stem climate change and urged legislation to expand voting rights.‚Å£
‚Å£
While Biden promoted his decision to pull all troops out of Afghanistan by Sept. 11 after nearly 20 years of war there, he said little new about how he would address challenges from increasingly antagonistic adversaries like China, Russia, Iran and North Korea other than repeating his intent to take a tough line when necessary while seeking cooperation where possible.‚Å£
‚Å£
But the president‚Äôs costly proposals amount to a risky gamble that a country polarized along ideological and cultural lines is ready for a more activist government.‚Å£
‚Å£
Tap the link in our bio for the full fact check and to read more analysis of the speech. ‚Å£

Description:
As these graphics change from white to blue, you can see how quickly our world's glaciers are shrinking.

A new report has suggested that the rate of ice loss roughly doubles every 10 years - and scientists are saying that the rapid disappearance of mountain glaciers ‚Äì separate from the Greenland and Antarctic ice shields ‚Äì is one of the most dramatic signs of global heating.

According to figures compiled exclusively for the Guardian, 10% of the planet's mountain glacier ice will have melted by the middle of this century even if humanity meets the goals of the Paris climate agreement.

The loss is equivalent to more than 13,200 cubic kilometres of water ‚Äì enough to fill Lake Superior, or more than 10 million Wembley Stadiums.

But what do we lose when we lose our glaciers?
Click the link in bio to find out - and to see more of our interactive database, which reveals how the climate crisis is reshaping glaciers around the world.

Description:
President Biden issued calls on Wednesday night for a broad reshaping of American society, vastly expanding family leave, child care, health care, preschool and college education for millions of people to be financed with increased taxes on the wealthiest earners.

Biden unveiled a $1.8 trillion social spending plan to accompany previous proposals to build roads and bridges, expand other social programs and combat climate change, representing a fundamental reorientation of the role of government not seen since the days of Lyndon B. Johnson‚Äôs Great Society and Franklin D. Roosevelt‚Äôs New Deal.

‚ÄúWe have to prove democracy still works, that our government still works and we can deliver for our people,‚Äù Biden said in his first nationally televised address to a joint session of Congress.

For Biden, who watched such speeches as a senator or vice president for nearly a half-century, it was the first time behind the microphone setting the agenda for what was the functional equivalent of a State of the Union address. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good to be back,‚Äù he said as he greeted lawmakers.

Biden spoke directly to the transgender community in his address to Congress and called on lawmakers to pass the Equality Act, which would provide protections to LGBTQ Americans. Biden also called on Congress again to raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour, a move that lacks even enough Democratic votes to pass the Senate. An effort to add it to the stimulus plan in March by Senator Bernie Sanders was scuttled.

On the advice of the Capitol physician, only 200 members of Congress and other officials were invited instead of the usual 1,600, all wearing masks in assigned seats at least six feet apart. The president, who fist-bumped his way down the aisle, arrived amid tighter security than usual, with streets around the building closed and patrolled by swarms of police officers and National Guard troops.

Tap the link in our bio for complete analysis and fact checks of Biden‚Äôs address to Congress. Photos by @nytmills

Description:
Estudiar la evoluci√≥n de la captaci√≥n de di√≥xido de carbono (#CO2) de los #oc√©anos, es de vital importancia para la #Unesco, y de acuerdo con el nuevo informe de la Comisi√≥n Oceanogr√°fica Intergubernamental (COI) de la Unesco, ‚Äúcorremos el riesgo de que se invierta el proceso. En lugar de absorber el carbono, los oc√©anos contribuir√≠an al calentamiento causado por el efecto invernadero del CO2‚Äù, explica la organizaci√≥n.

El informe titulado ‚ÄúInvestigaci√≥n integrada sobre el carbono oce√°nico: resumen de los conocimientos sobre el carbono oce√°nico y visi√≥n de la investigaci√≥n y observaci√≥n coordinada del carbono oce√°nico para el pr√≥ximo decenio‚Äù, presenta una s√≠ntesis del estado de los conocimientos sobre el papel de los oc√©anos en el ciclo del #carbono y tambi√©n establece una hoja de ruta. Su objetivo es proporcionar a los responsables de la toma de decisiones los conocimientos necesarios para desarrollar pol√≠ticas de mitigaci√≥n y adaptaci√≥n al #cambioclim√°tico para el pr√≥ximo decenio.

El informe destaca el papel que ha desempe√±ado el oc√©ano, desde la revoluci√≥n industrial, como sumidero del carbono generado por las actividades humanas. De hecho, sin los sumideros oce√°nicos y terrestres, los niveles de CO2 atmosf√©rico se acercar√≠an a las 600 ppm (partes por mill√≥n), un 50 % m√°s que las 410 ppm registradas en 2019, ya muy por encima de lo necesario para limitar el calentamiento global a dos grados cent√≠grados.

Seg√∫n los expertos, la teledetecci√≥n por sat√©lite del estado de la superficie del mar, la temperatura, el viento, la salinidad, el hielo, la lluvia y la clorofila-a desempe√±a un papel fundamental en la cuantificaci√≥n del carbono oce√°nico.

Description:
Casi todos los glaciares del mundo est√°n perdiendo masa a un ritmo acelerado, seg√∫n un nuevo estudio publicado el mi√©rcoles que podr√≠a influir en las proyecciones futuras de derretimiento del hielo.

El estudio, que se publica en la revista cient√≠fica Nature, ofrece una de las panor√°micas m√°s amplias hasta la fecha sobre la p√©rdida de masa de hielo de unos 220.000 glaciares de todo el mundo, una de las principales fuentes de aumento del nivel del mar.

Utilizando im√°genes de alta resoluci√≥n del sat√©lite Terra de la NASA entre 2000 y 2019, un grupo de cient√≠ficos descubri√≥ que los glaciares, a excepci√≥n de las capas de hielo de Groenlandia y la Ant√°rtida - que se excluyeron del estudio-, perdieron una media de 267 gigatoneladas de hielo al a√±o.

Una gigatonelada de hielo llenar√≠a el Central Park de Nueva York y tendr√≠a 341 metros de altura.

Los investigadores tambi√©n descubrieron que la p√©rdida de masa de los glaciares se aceler√≥.

Los glaciares perdieron 227 gigatoneladas de hielo al a√±o entre 2000 y 2004, pero eso aument√≥ a una media de 298 gigatoneladas anuales despu√©s de 2015.

El derretimiento tuvo un impacto significativo en el nivel del mar de unos 0,74 mil√≠metros al a√±o, o el 21% del aumento global del nivel de los oc√©anos observado durante el per√≠odo.

Los glaciares tienden a tener una respuesta m√°s r√°pida al cambio clim√°tico en comparaci√≥n con las capas de hielo de Groenlandia y la Ant√°rtida, y actualmente contribuyen m√°s al aumento del nivel del mar que cualquiera de las capas de hielo individuales, dijeron los cient√≠ficos.

Dort lichtet man Waldbest√§nde aus, damit sie nicht so viel brennbares Baumholz enthalten, und man schafft Schneisen im Forst, an denen sich Feuersbr√ºnste totlaufen. Description:
Wie wir konsumieren, uns ern√§hren, welche Ressourcen wir verbrauchen ‚Äì das ist in Zeiten von Globalisierung, Klimakatastrophe und steigender sozialer Ungleichheit zu einer moralischen Frage geworden. 
.
Und Moral ist wichtig, sagen Christian Neuh√§user und Christian Seidel im Vorwort ihres Buches ‚ÄûKritik des Moralismus‚Äú. Aber man k√∂nne sie auch zu wichtig nehmen. Zum Beispiel, wenn Moralapostel allenthalben ihre Zeigefinger erheben und von anderen die Einhaltung bestimmter Gebote fordern.
.
Denn Moralismus gehe h√§ufig mit Komplexit√§tsreduktion und Prinzipienreiterei einher, so Christian Neuh√§user und Christian Seidel. Indem der Moralisierende die Gegenseite ins schlechte Licht stellt, erscheint sein eigenes moralisches Blitzeblanksein umso strahlender. Auch in √∂ffentlichen Diskursen wird gerne der moralische Zeigefinger erhoben: Konsumenten werden durch verschiedene Labels beispielsweise daran erinnert, dass sie mit ihrer Kaufentscheidung auch eine moralische Entscheidung treffen. So k√∂nne man eine ‚Äûzunehmende Moralisierung der Lebenswelt konstatieren‚Äú, so Neuh√§user und Seidel, ‚Äûdie moralische Bewertung dieser Entwicklungen‚Äú sei aber ambivalent.
.
Der Beitrag ‚ÄûMoralismusfalle. Wenn jeder besser wei√ü, was richtig ist‚Äú findet sich im Link unter unserer Bio.
.
.
.

Description:
Sabemos que seguir una dieta equilibrada es, fuera de toda duda, un beneficio para nuestra #salud. Adem√°s, bajo el concepto de ‚Äúestar a dieta‚Äù o ‚Äúseguir una dieta‚Äù se pueden encontrar otras fuerzas motrices como, por ejemplo, aspectos est√©ticos o de respeto por el #medioambiente.

Por eso, es importante determinar las propiedades nutricionales y de #sostenibilidad en cualquier #dieta. De esta forma, podremos orientar nuestras decisiones hacia la armon√≠a entre beneficios, tanto de salud como ambientales.

Indicadores de sostenibilidad y nutrici√≥n

Uno de los indicadores ambientales con mayor impacto medi√°tico es la #huelladecarbono (HC), relacionada con el calentamiento global asociado a la emisi√≥n de gases de efecto invernadero. Se define como la cantidad de di√≥xido de carbono equivalente que un producto genera en un per√≠odo de tiempo a lo largo de su ciclo de vida.

En el art√≠culo Cinco reglas para elegir alimentos que mejoren su salud y la del planeta, se pueden encontrar valores t√≠picos de huella de carbono para diferentes alimentos.

Este indicador ha cuajado de forma importante en el sector de la alimentaci√≥n, existiendo diversas ecoetiquetas que certifican su valor (figura 1). Dichas ecoetiquetas se pueden agrupar en funci√≥n de la informaci√≥n que transmiten al consumidor. Por ejemplo, pueden indicar bajos niveles de emisiones (Climatop ‚Äì Suiza), el ranking de los niveles de emisi√≥n (ConsciousTM ‚Äì EE. UU.), la puntuaci√≥n con la emisi√≥n (Carbon Trust ‚Äì Reino Unido) y el neutro en carbono (Climate Neutral Product ‚Äì Holanda).

Existen a su vez diversos indicadores nutricionales en la literatura cient√≠fica que analizan los beneficios de diferentes patrones diet√©ticos. Uno de ellos es la dieta rica en nutrientes (NRD 9.3), un valor adimensional relacionado con la ingesta de 12 nutrientes. De ellos, 9 ponderan positivamente (prote√≠nas, fibra, calcio, hierro, magnesio, potasio, vitamina A, vitamina C, vitamina E) y 3 negativamente (sodio, grasas saturadas y az√∫cares totales), en base a los valores recomendados por la #FAO y la #OMS.

Youth climate activists have written an open letter to the Science Museum demanding it drop Shell sponsorship of its new ‚ÄòOur Future Planet‚Äô exhibition. 

The letter from the UK Student Climate Network calls Shell‚Äôs sponsorship of the exhibition ‚Äòbrazen greenwashing‚Äô.

It has been signed by more than 130 scientists, activists and organisations, including George Monbiot.

Sir Ian Blatchford of the Science Museum Group said, ‚ÄúClimate change is the defining issue of this century and when we reopen the Science Museum, visitors can look forward to lots of public programming engaging with this issue, including new exhibition Our Future Planet.‚Äù

A Shell spokesperson said, ‚ÄúShell and the Science Museum have a longstanding relationship, based on a shared interest in promoting engagement in science.

‚ÄúAt Shell our target is to become a net-zero emissions energy business by 2050, in step with society.‚Äù

The UK Student Climate Network says it will call for a boycott of the exhibition if the museum doesn‚Äôt drop the sponsorship.

California‚Äôs ambition to retake the lead on climate change policy in the United States received a major boost on Monday, as the Biden administration moved toward allowing the state to once more set its own car pollution standards, a right revoked under former President Trump.

The EPA‚Äôs action has national significance as transportation remains the largest source of planet-warming emissions in the United States, and California, with nearly 40 million people, is the country‚Äôs largest auto market. The state‚Äôs unique ability to set its own car pollution rules has influenced federal policy for decades, leading to stricter nationwide standards.

‚ÄúI am a firm believer in California‚Äôs long-standing statutory authority to lead,‚Äù EPA Administrator Michael S. Regan, said in a statement. ‚ÄúThe 2019 decision to revoke the state‚Äôs waiver to enforce its greenhouse gas pollution standards for cars and trucks was legally dubious and an attack on the public‚Äôs health and well-being.‚Äù

Der Tag der Nuklearkatastrophe von Tschernobyl j√§hrt sich zum 35. Mal. Am 26. April 1986 explodierte der vierte Reaktorblock von Tschernobyl n√∂rdlich von Kiew. Das ehemalige Atomkraftwerk liegt auf dem Gebiet der Ukraine, die damals noch Teil der Sowjetunion war. Der Supergau wurde Wirklichkeit ‚Äì ein Gebiet von 2600 Quadratkilometern zur Sperrzone. Doch der radioaktive Fallout breitete sich viel weiter aus, er zog auch Richtung Westen bis nach Deutschland. 

Der Supergau von Tschernobyl galt eigentlich als Wendepunkt. Die Katastrophe f√ºhrte vor Augen, dass das Risiko der Atomkraft real ist. Dennoch ist die Atomkraft in einigen L√§ndern auf dem Vormarsch.

Mojib Latif ist Klimaforscher, Hochschullehrer, Pr√§sident der Deutschen Gesellschaft Club of Rome und Atomkraftgegner. Er hat Tschernobyl damals miterlebt und mitverfolgt als junger Wissenschaftler. Die sowjetische Regierung habe damals versucht, die Reaktorkatastrophe ‚Äûunter der Decke‚Äú zu halten, sagte er in den Informationen am Morgen. Doch das sei nicht m√∂glich gewesen. Der Supergau von Tschernobyl habe noch einmal gezeigt, dass Atomkraft nicht beherrschbar ist. Schon davor habe es bereits Atomunf√§lle gegeben.

Description:
Derrick Johnson is at the helm of the NAACP, fighting for social change at a time when the U.S. is gripped by the most intense and sustained reckoning over racial justice in generations. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Being the president and chief executive officer of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (@naacp), the country‚Äôs foremost civil rights organization, requires a versatile skill set. He sued former President Donald Trump in 2017 over the fate of the Dreamers, and again this year over the Capitol riot. He has walked the streets with protesters in Minneapolis and, before President Biden was inaugurated, pressed him to create a civil rights envoy in the West Wing.‚Å£
‚Å£
This week, Johnson was on the phone with other civil rights leaders when the jury reached its guilty verdict in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the police officer charged with murdering George Floyd.‚Å£
‚Å£
‚ÄúIt was an important moment for this nation,‚Äù Johnson said in an interview with The New York Times. ‚ÄúIf we do this right, this can be our Selma, Alabama, moment.‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£
In his job, Johnson has struck a balancing act with the business world, welcoming its expressions of solidarity and pledges to create more diverse workplaces, while calling it out on unfulfilled promises and empty rhetoric.‚Å£
‚Å£
As the business world gets more involved in social and political issues ‚Äî including voting rights, immigration and climate change ‚Äî Johnson is looking to companies to help advance positive social change.‚Å£
‚Å£
‚ÄúThere is a responsibility of corporations to ensure that we maintain a stable democracy,‚Äù he said.‚Å£
‚Å£
‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt address the structural racism that has existed in this country for 400 years with a few checks,‚Äù he continued.‚Å£
‚Å£
Tap the link in our bio for the full interview with @derricknaacp. Photo by @misterwidmer‚Å£

Das Fenster der Gelegenheit steht sperrangelweit auf: Im Herbst wird die Weltgemeinschaft in Glasgow zur wichtigsten UN-Klimakonferenz seit dem Pariser Abkommen zusammentreffen. Bis dahin muss jeder Staat erkl√§ren, wie er die Erderw√§rmung auf deutlich unter zwei Grad oder sogar 1,5 Grad begrenzen will.

Sollte die Corona-Pandemie dank massenhafter Impfungen absehbar bew√§ltigt werden, d√ºrfte die Klimapolitik schnell ins Zentrum des Bundestagswahlkampfes r√ºcken. Die Gr√ºnen sind in den Umfragen so stark wie nie, und sie haben ihre f√ºhrende Klimapolitik-Expertin zur Kanzlerkandidatin gek√ºrt. 

All das zeigt Wirkung bei den √ºbrigen Parteien. Die CDU hat einen eigenen Klimarat gegr√ºndet, kein Zufall. Die SPD will laut Wahlprogramm nun klimasch√§dliche Subventionen abbauen. Dabei h√§tte ihr Kanzlerkandidat Olaf Scholz als Finanzminister vier Jahre lang Gelegenheit dazu gehabt. Doch die schwarz-rote Bundesregierung hat wertvolle Jahre verstreichen lassen. Das wird die Bilanz der √Ñra Merkel in Zukunft schwer tr√ºben. Dass die Kanzlerin handelt, wenn sie nur will und von den Bundesl√§ndern unterst√ºtzt wird, hat sie in der Corona-Pandemie bewiesen. Beim Kohleausstieg h√§lt Merkel hingegen an der deutschen Zielmarke 2038 fest, obwohl das Pariser Abkommen damit Makulatur w√§re.

Ten state attorneys general have announced a lawsuit against President Biden‚Äôs administration over his executive order regarding the "social cost of carbon."

The lawsuit was announced on Friday, with the group calling the president‚Äôs executive order on tackling climate change "an act of executive overreach that will kill thousands of jobs throughout the country threatens to impose more burdens and harms on the American people."

Georgia Attorney General Chris Carr warned that Biden‚Äôs order would have "life-altering consequences" for the people of his state.

Description:
The vast Zinder region in Niger, west Africa, is the most populated part of the country. Its people are now being profoundly affected by the climate crisis.

Spanish photographer, Luis Tato, took this photograph of a girl in a baobab tree during a 2019 visit while working on stories about the crisis, reforestation and resilience projects.

This girl, who was 10 or 11, has confidently climbed to the very top of the tree, collecting leaves for her family's dinner. Baobab leaves are a popular meal in the region, and the tastiest are usually higher up.

@luistatophoto says he loves the gentle and poetic nature of the image; "The area has been scarred by conflict and drought but life also goes on in a quiet way. This tree, and what it represents, makes me feel positive and peaceful."

Lato is the Sony World Photography awards 2021 professional winner in the wildlife and nature category.

Description:
Este es el discurso de la joven activista mexicana Xiye Bastida que ha eclipsado a los parlamentos de los l√≠deres mundiales durante la primera jornada de la cumbre clim√°tica convocada por el presidente Joe Biden para demostrar al mundo el renovado compromiso de Estados Unidos con la lucha contra el calentamiento global.

Invitada como una l√≠der m√°s, Bastida se permiti√≥ poner en duda el compromiso de Biden si no hay un cambio pol√≠tico real y cuestion√≥ incluso el formato de la cita.

‚ÄúLa mayor√≠a de los 40 l√≠deres que participan en esta cumbre proceden del norte global, que hist√≥ricamente ha perpetuado los sistemas de opresi√≥n y colonialismo. Las comunidades m√°s afectadas, las que sufren desplazamientos por las sequ√≠as, inundaciones o fuegos (...) no est√°n plenamente representadas aqu√≠‚Äù, les dijo. El punto de partida de las soluciones debe ser el convencimiento de que ‚Äúla justicia clim√°tica es justicia social‚Äù, defendi√≥.

El car√°cter virtual del encuentro impidi√≥ ver la cara de los invitados de Biden al o√≠r a esta joven de 19 a√±os. Pero Bastida, miembro del movimiento Viernes por el Futuro iniciado por Greta Thunberg, no se qued√≥ ah√≠. Despu√©s de casi tres horas de discursos en los que una vez m√°s los l√≠deres mundiales reafirmaron con su mejor ret√≥rica su compromiso en la lucha contra la crisis clim√°tica, Bastida les acus√≥ de buscar lagunas legales en sus propios compromisos para no hacer nada con un impacto real.

Description:
Humanity's original fuel ‚Äî wood ‚Äî has taken on a new identity: a solution to climate change. But not everyone's on board.‚Å£
‚Å£
Huge U.S. factories that dry and press wood into roughly cigarette-filter-size pellets are booming right now. In barely a decade, the Southeast‚Äôs wood pellet industry has grown from almost nothing to 23 mills with capacity to produce more than 10 million metric tons annually for export. It employs more than 1,000 people directly, and has boosted local logging and trucking businesses. The industry, too, is courting new markets in Asia and it is lobbying for greater prominence in the U.S. ‚Å£
‚Å£
Supporters see it as a climate-friendly source of rural jobs. For others, it‚Äôs a polluter and destroyer of nature. Some 500 ecologists, conservationists and others wrote to heads of state, including President Biden, urging them to reject wood burning as a tool for fighting climate change.‚Å£
‚Å£
Michael Regan, the new administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency is also seen as lukewarm on the issue. During his previous job running the North Carolina Department of Environmental Quality, the department granted permits to mills but also required them to address air pollution and recommended against including wood bioenergy in the state‚Äôs clean energy mix.‚Å£
‚Å£
The growth of the industry has its roots in 2009, when European officials decided to declare biomass energy ‚Äî basically, the burning of wood or other plants, rather than fossil fuels ‚Äî to be carbon neutral. The idea is that regrowing plants, over time, would ultimately reabsorb the carbon dioxide released by the burning.‚Å£
‚Å£
Many scientists have long been skeptical of the climate benefits of biomass. Wood releases more carbon dioxide per unit of electricity produced than coal or gas, and a newly planted tree can take decades to reabsorb the carbon dioxide emitted by burning.‚Å£
‚Å£
Tap the link in our bio to read more about the wood pellet industry and its impact on the environment, the economy and climate change. Photos by @erinschaff.

Description:
We often hear about how the planet is on fire, apparently it's also tilted it's rotation.

The massive melting of glaciers as a result of global heating has caused marked shifts in the Earth‚Äôs axis of rotation since the 1990s, research has shown - and scientists say this demonstrates the profound impact we are having on the planet.

If you imagine a metal rod going through the centre of the Earth - around which the planet spins - that is the Earth's axis. It determines what angle the Earth is at. The north and south poles are the point where that that pole enters and exists the globe. But those points are not fixed.

Changes in how the Earth‚Äôs mass is distributed around the planet cause the axis, and therefore the poles, to move.

In the past, only natural factors such as ocean currents and the convection of hot rock in the deep Earth contributed to the drifting position of the poles.

But the new research, from the Institute of Geographic Sciences and Natural Resources Research at the Chinese Academy of Sciences, shows that since the 1990s, the loss of hundreds of billions of tonnes of ice a year into the oceans resulting from the climate crisis has caused the poles to move in new directions.

Follow the link in bio to read more about these eye-opening findings.
ImageText: G The climate crisis has 'shifted the Earth's axis'

So will die USA ihren Aussto√ü von klimasch√§dlichen Gasen bis 2030 im Vergleich zu 2005 halbieren. Biden will mit dem virtuellen Treffen zudem eine neue US-F√ºhrungsrolle im Kampf gegen die Erderw√§rmung unterstreichen. 

Auch die EU hat ihre Klimaziele verk√ºndet: F√ºr 2030 will die EU mindestens 55 Prozent weniger klimasch√§dliche Treibhausgase aussto√üen als 1990. Im EU-Klimagesetz ist nun auch festgeschrieben, dass Europa bis 2050 klimaneutral werden soll. 

Dass sowohl die EU als auch die USA in den kommenden neun Jahren ihre CO2-Emmissionen deutlich senken wollen, bezeichnet der Klimaforscher Christoph Bertram vom Potsdam-Institut im Deutschlandfunk als eine sehr gute Nachricht. ‚ÄûWir wissen nat√ºrlich auch, global reichen die Ziele bis 2030 nicht‚Äú, betonte Bertram.

Climate activist Greta Thunberg has hit out at US politicians for subsidising the fossil fuel industry and ‚Äúignoring the climate crisis‚Äù.

Speaking to an environmental committee, Ms Thunberg said they will be held accountable by future generations for their inaction.

‚ÄúHow long do you honestly believe that people in power like you will get away with it?‚Äù, the 18-year-old said in an impassioned speech.

‚ÄúYou get away with it now, but sooner or later, people are going to realise what you have been doing all this time, that's inevitable.‚Äù

This comes as President Joe Biden hosts a two-day Climate Summit with world leaders.

He has pledged to halve US carbon emissions by 2030.

The United States under Biden rejoined the Paris agreement in February, after former President Donald Trump pulled out.

Description:
Greta Thunberg has changed her Twitter description to "bunny hugger" in an apparent dig at Boris Johnson who used the phrase at a virtual global summit on climate change.

In his speech the prime minister said that "it's vital for all of us to show that this is not all about some expensive, politically correct green act of bunny hugging".

He added: "This is about growth and jobs." 

Earlier in the day, climate activist Ms Thunberg, 18, posted a video to social media which said that the targets set by world leaders were "very insufficient".

She also said that leaders' "bull****" on the issue was the biggest elephant in the room.

Outdoor retailer #REI calls climate change ‚Äúthe largest existential threat facing our members‚Äô enjoyment of life outdoors and the survival of REI Co-op.‚Äù The company has pledged to cut its planet-warming #emissions in half over the next decade.

But that isn‚Äôt stopping REI from using its eco-friendly image to help #Ford promote gas-guzzling #SUVs.

In a series of ads and videos sponsored by the carmaker, REI chronicles the journey of four cyclists traversing a 220-mile route through #Arizona known as the #SkyIslandsOdyssey. The videos feature plenty of glamour shots and praise of Ford‚Äôs #BroncoSport as it accompanies the bikers through off-road desert terrain, loaded with gear.

Cars and trucks are America‚Äôs biggest source of #climate #pollution, with transportation responsible for nearly 30% of the nation‚Äôs #carbonemissions.

Description:
Greta Thunberg called on Congress to enact more concrete measures on climate change when she appeared virtually before a House subcommittee on Thursday. 

‚ÄúWe are the ones who get to decide how you will be remembered,‚Äù the teenage climate activist warned lawmakers. ‚ÄúChoose wisely.‚Äù

@gretathunberg‚Äôs speech came as 40 world leaders attended a virtual climate summit organized by the White House. In remarks Thursday morning, President Biden formally pledged that the U.S. would cut its greenhouse gas emissions at least in half from 2005 levels by 2030. 

Other world leaders also vowed to fight climate change. President Xi Jinping said China would ‚Äústrictly limit increasing coal consumption‚Äù in the next five years and repeated his pledge from last year to draw down carbon emissions to net zero by 2060.

Prime Minister Justin Trudeau pledged that Canada would reduce its greenhouse gas emissions 40 to 45% from 2005 levels by 2030. Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India made no new commitments, but reiterated his country‚Äôs promise to install 450 gigawatts of renewable energy capacity by 2030. Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga announced that Japan would cut emissions 46% below 2013 levels by the end of the decade, a significant show of solidarity with the U.S.

President Vladimir Putin of Russia, the world‚Äôs fourth-largest greenhouse gas polluter, made only a vague pledge to ‚Äúsignificantly reduce the net accumulated emissions in our country by 2050.‚Äù He highlighted a carbon pricing pilot program that he said would allow the Sakhalin region to become carbon neutral by 2025, but he said nothing about construction of the Nord Stream 2, a major natural gas pipeline that both climate advocates and U.S. national security advisers oppose.

Tap the link in our bio to read the latest from the summit.

Description:
Feeling green? If you'd like to do something to slow down climate change, even if it's just a small thing, you can get started in your own apartment or house.‚Å†
‚Å†
Homes and commercial buildings account for about a third of the country's greenhouse gas emissions, because it takes energy to heat and cool them and to power all the gadgets we've got plugged in. Much of that energy, whether it's electricity from a power plant far away or heat from a gas furnace in your basement, comes from burning fossil fuels, which releases greenhouse gases.‚Å†
‚Å†
But you can change that. "If you want to do something about climate change, your home is among the most important places to look," says Donnel Baird, CEO of BlocPower, a startup company that's carrying out energy upgrades of buildings in several cities, including New York. (image: @gabble_gabs ‚Ä¢ Kaz Fantone for NPR)

Description:
Greta Thunberg appeared virtually before a US House panel to call on officials to do more, saying it's 'not too late' to make real changes in the fight against climate change. 

"The simple fact and uncomfortable fact is that if we are to live up to our promises and commitments in the Paris agreement, we have to end fossil fuel subsidies, stop new exploration and extraction, completely divest from fossil fuels and keep the carbon in the ground," the climate activist said. 

Her testimony came during a hearing on 'The role of fossil fuel subsidies in preventing action on the climate crisis', and also Earth Day.

Follow @guardian_us for more
ImageText: CLIMATE CRISIS Greta Thunberg toUS: Use your common sense'

Description:
For the homeless, natural disasters prove torturous for more than the obvious fact that it's worse to be outside than inside during a storm.‚Å†
‚Å†
It's an immutable truth of the climate crisis that the most vulnerable are hit first and hardest. At a time of rising homelessness in the US and as climate-related disasters become common ‚Äî wildfires in California, monster hurricanes that thrash the East Coast and the Gulf of Mexico, an arctic blast in Texas ‚Äî the rule holds.‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
Las #NacionesUnidas decidieron en 1970 designar el 22 de abril como el ‚ÄúD√≠a Internacional de la Madre Tierra‚Äù, luego de la gran revuelta ambientalista realizada ese a√±o en #EEUU, donde 20 millones de personas se manifestaron en las calles.

De esta forma se busca dar mayor visibilidad y reconocimiento a la necesidad de resguardar la #Tierra y los #ecosistemas que la habitan, por tanto, ‚Äúsi buscamos lograr un equilibrio entre las necesidades econ√≥micas, alimentarias y ambientales de las generaciones presentes y futuras, es necesario promover una alimentaci√≥n mucho m√°s consciente‚Äù, comenta Kerstin Reichmann, coordinadora de VeggieChallenge.org, un programa totalmente gratuito de fundaci√≥n Vegetarianos Hoy que acompa√±a durante 30 d√≠as a quienes deseen realizar un cambio de alimentaci√≥n.

El informe SOFA 2020 (State Of Food and Agriculture) de la #FAO, entrega cifras alarmantes en cuanto al uso de suelo y gasto de recurso h√≠drico para la producci√≥n de alimentos de origen animal, necesitando m√°s de 15.400 litros de agua y 120 m2 la producci√≥n de 1 kilo de carne de vacuno, versus los 3.300 litros de agua en promedio y no m√°s 5 m2 para producir 1 kilo de cereales. La diferencia es equivalente al gasto de agua de entre 4 y 6 meses de duchas diarias de una sola persona.

En este informe se detalla como la #agricultura, la #desforestaci√≥n y la #ganader√≠a son los responsables de cerca del 30 % de las emisiones de gases de invernadero relacionadas con la acci√≥n humana, donde se estima que para la producci√≥n de 100 grs de prote√≠na de origen animal liberan 50 kgs gases de efecto invernadero a la atm√≥sfera, mientras que 100 grs de prote√≠na vegetal solo emiten 4.2 kgs de gases. Respecto a lo mismo, la ONU dice ‚Äúun cambio global hacia una dieta basada en plantas es vital para salvar al mundo del hambre, la escasez de combustible y los peores impactos del cambio clim√°tico‚Äù.

Description:
This Earth Day, take a minute to learn what we can do to help build a better future for our planet. Through the use of fossil fuels like coal, oil and gas, humans are causing CO2 levels to rise and at an unprecedented rate. This could lead to up to an increase of average global temperatures of 9 degrees Fahrenheit by the end of this century, great disturbances in ecosystems, and millions of people suffering from water scarcity and crop failures. 

If we continue down the path we‚Äôre on, the planet will keep getting hotter and the effects of climate change will get worse. While the science on climate change is settled, the future is not. 

To see an illustrated guide for kids, and everyone else, about climate change ‚Äî and what we can do about it, tap the link in our bio.
ImageText: The science on climate change is settled, but the future is not. Five things humans can change: Switch from fossil fuels to renewable energy Use more sustainable agriculture practices Protect forests and biodiversity Drive electric cars ‚Ä¢Fly less = H # 51 FaS‡Ææ·ûè 00

Description:
President Joe Biden pledged to cut U.S. greenhouse gas pollution in half by 2030 at a virtual climate summit Thursday, outlining an aggressive target that would require sweeping changes to America's energy and transportation sectors. ‚Å†
‚Å†
"Scientists tell us that this is the decisive decade, this is the decade we must make decisions that will avoid the worst consequences of a climate crisis," Biden said. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The White House's goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 50% to 52% percent, from a baseline of 2005 emissions, is nearly double the target set by Obama administration in 2015. An administration official, who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity, did not detail how the White House plans to achieve the 50% reduction in emissions.
ImageText: POLITICS DERS SUMMI IMATE Biden promises 50% reduction in US greenhouse emissions by 2030 at the Earth Day climate summit. USA TODAY

Nachdem die vorige US-Regierung unter Donald Trump den Klimawandel ignorierte, will Nachfolger Biden nun die Anstrengungen erh√∂hen. Doch wie stark ist der R√ºckhalt der eigenen Bev√∂lkerung f√ºr diesen Kurs? 

Anthony Leiserowitz, Professor an der renommierten Yale University in New Haven, Connecticut, forscht seit Jahren zur √∂ffentlichen Wahrnehmung des Klimawandels und geh√∂rt zu den einflussreichsten Klimawissenschaftlern der USA.

Description:
President Biden on Thursday declared that the U.S. ‚Äúhas resolved to take action‚Äù on climate change and called on world leaders to significantly accelerate their own plans to reduce greenhouse gas emissions or risk a disastrous collective failure to stop catastrophic climate change.
 
In a show of renewed commitment after four years of the Trump administration‚Äôs unvarnished climate denial, Biden formally pledged that the United States would cut its emissions at least in half from 2005 levels by 2030. Barely three months into Biden‚Äôs presidency, the contrast with his science-denying predecessor, Donald Trump, could not have been more striking.
 
‚ÄúThe signs are unmistakable, the science is undeniable and the cost of inaction keeps mounting,‚Äù Biden said.
 
While the summit is an international one, Biden‚Äôs speech was also aimed at a domestic audience, focusing not just on America‚Äôs obligation to help cut its global emissions but also on the jobs he believes are available in greening the U.S. economy. But one of Biden‚Äôs biggest political obstacles is international: Republicans say the U.S. should not be asked to sacrifice if the world‚Äôs largest emitters will swallow U.S. efforts in their pollution.
 
The two-day summit comes at a time when scientists are warning that governments must take decisive action to prevent global temperatures from rising more than 1.5 degrees above preindustrial levels. The consequences of exceeding that threshold include mass species extinctions, water shortages and extreme weather events that will be most devastating to the poorest countries least responsible for causing global warming. Tap the link in our bio for more. Photo by @al_drago.

Description:
Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è President Joe Biden on Thursday kicked off a virtual climate summit attended by 40 other world leaders by announcing an ambitious cut in greenhouse gas emissions as he looks to put the US back at the center of the global effort to address the climate crisis and curb carbon emissions. At the White House summit, which is taking place on Thursday and Friday, Biden committed the United States to reducing its greenhouse gas emissions by 50%-52% below its 2005 emissions levels by 2030. While the goals are a part of the Paris climate agreement that Biden rejoined upon taking office, they are non-binding and the administration has not rolled out a plan on how the US will meet them. Officials said Biden and his team arrived at the final number in a meeting at the White House on Wednesday morning.‚Å†

Description:
Joe Biden has vowed to cut the US's planet-heating emissions by at least 50% by the end of the decade.

The move comes as America scrambles to regain international credibility after the climate denialist presidency of Donald Trump and in a ramping up of ambition aimed at rallying other countries to do more to confront the climate crisis.

Ahead of a virtual gathering of dozens of world leaders in a climate summit called by Biden, the White House announced that the US will aim to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by between 50% and 52% by 2030, based on 2005 levels.

The Biden administration has reiterated it wants the US electricity grid to run 100% on clean sources such as solar and wind by 2035 in order to meet its goals and has framed an explosion in renewable energy and electric car production as a boon to American jobs.

Some climate activists have said Biden needs to do even more, however, pointing out that the US is lagging after four years of Trump and the rest of the world has made scant progress to date in cutting emissions, with greenhouse gases already rising again after a dip last year due to pandemic-related shutdowns.

Follow @guardian_us for more.
ImageText: G US VOws to halve emissions by 2030

Description:
Follow @emergencyc4 for more stories like this...‚Å†
‚Å†
More than 100 Nobel Laureates, including the Dalai Lama, are calling on governments around the world to phase out the burning of fossil fuels.‚Å†
‚Å†
In an open letter, experts in fields from peace and literature to physics and chemistry said "governments have lagged, shockingly, behind what science demands" to tackle the climate crisis.‚Å†
‚Å†
They urged world leaders to sign up to the Fossil Fuel Non-Proliferation Treaty, which calls for an end to fossil fuel expansion and to phase out existing production. It also demands greater investment in renewable energy and a "just transition" for communities which are currently economically dependent on fossil fuels. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The letter said: "Fossil fuels are the greatest contributor to climate change. Allowing the continued expansion of this industry is unconscionable. The fossil fuel system is global and requires a global solution [...] And the first step is to keep fossil fuels in the ground."‚Å†
‚Å†
It's addressed to delegates of the Leaders' Climate Summit which will be hosted tomorrow by US President Joe Biden.‚Å†
You can read the full letter here: https://fossilfueltreaty.org/nobel-letter‚Å†
‚Å†
#nobel #nobellaureates #dalailama #treaty #international #climate #climatechange #climatecrisis #climateemergency #globalheating #globalwarming #greenhousegasses #carbon #emissions #fossilfuels #co2 #netzero #politics #science #climatescience #sustainability #nature #environment

Description:
Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è Coal country is in free fall and is pleading for help from Washington. That's why the largest union in one of the dirtiest industries is broadly backing President Joe Biden's $2 trillion green infrastructure package. Climate groups largely support Biden's infrastructure plan, although some argue it should go further to respond to the climate crisis. The coal industry would benefit from the Biden proposals to rebuild bridges, ports and airports ‚Äî all steps that would boost demand for steel, which typically uses coal as a key ingredient. "We're for infrastructure. We're for jobs. We're for moving manufacturing into coalfields. We'll work the president on that," Cecil Roberts, president of the United Mine Workers of America, the country's largest mine workers union, told CNN.‚Å†

(üì∏: Luke Sharrett/Bloomberg/ Getty Images)

Description:

The UK government has set what it claims is "the world‚Äôs most ambitious" climate change target to cut its carbon emissions by 78% by 2035 compared to 1990 levels.‚Å†
‚Å†
It means the government is aiming for a further 10% in reductions compared to its existing goal. Aviation and shipping emissions will also be included in the target for the first time. It will become enshrined in law by the end of June.‚Å†
‚Å†
The move has been roundly welcomed by campaigners, though large questions remain over how the targets will be met.‚Å†
‚Å†
Jess Ralston, an analyst at the Energy and Climate Intelligence Unit said the target "does place the UK at the forefront of international ambition" but added that "actually realising our goals is another question entirely. While targets make clear that the UK‚Äôs future is green, they need to be backed by equally as ambitious policy and sectoral plans to be credible."‚Å†
‚Å†
The UK says it wants to encourage other countries to be more ambitious when setting their climate targets ahead of the COP26 climate conference in Glasgow in November. Westminster has been accused of making policy moves that are counter to its own climate commitments, including slashing overseas aid, continuing to consider plans for a new deep coal mine to go ahead in Cumbria, allowing new oil and gas exploration in the North Sea and scrapping its flagship energy efficiency policy, the Green Homes Grant.‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
Greta Thunberg, the 18-year-old Swedish environmental activist, is now lobbying world leaders to make sure that COVID vaccines are distributed equitably around the globe.

Speaking at a Monday press conference for the World Health Organization, Thunberg called it is "unethical" that young people at low-risk from COVID in rich nations are being vaccinated before health care workers in low-income countries.

"The only morally right thing to do is to prioritize the people who are the most vulnerable, no matter whether they live in a high-income country or a low-income country," she said.

"The international community, governments and vaccine developers must step up their game and address the tragedy that is vaccine inequity."

Thunberg tied the issue of COVID vaccine equity to her hallmark issue of climate change.

"As we are cutting down forests and destroying habitats, we are creating the ideal conditions for diseases to spill over from one animal to another and then to us," she said. "We can no longer separate the health crisis from the ecological crisis. We cannot separate the ecological crisis from the climate crisis. It's all interlinked in many ways."

(2021 The Associated Press)
ImageText: npr GRETA THUNBERG: "THE MORAL THREAT OF VACCINE INEQUALITY" April 20, 2021 must step up their game and address the tragedy that is vaccine inequity.

Description:
‚ùÑÔ∏èLa 'Bestia del Este', el fr√≠o primaveral que atraviesa Europa.

Hielo y nieve sobre frutales en flor, agricultores encendiendo estufas improvisadas en bidones para proteger sus cultivos incipientes... El inicio de primavera se ha presentado este a√±o meteorol√≥gicamente alterado en diversas zonas de Europa, con nevadas y temperaturas algo bajas para esta √©poca, especialmente en la zona central y norte del continente que est√° perjudicando a los agricultores. 

La explicaci√≥n a esta repentina ola de fr√≠o conocida como 'Bestia del Este' ser√≠a la p√©rdida del hielo marino en el mar de Barents, en el √Årtico, seg√∫n indica un estudio liderado por expertos de la Universidad de Oulu (Finlandia) y la Universidad del √Årtico de Noruega. Una relaci√≥n que se ha observado desde 1979 y, este 2021, la situaci√≥n ha sido muy parecida en algunas zonas del continente, como se lamentan por ejemplo los viticultores de Burdeos y la Champa√±a. 

‚ÄúEl cambio clim√°tico no siempre se manifiesta de las formas m√°s obvias. Es f√°cil extrapolar modelos para mostrar que los inviernos se est√°n volviendo m√°s c√°lidos y pronosticar un futuro pr√°cticamente sin nieve en Europa, pero nuestro estudio m√°s reciente muestra que esta interpretaci√≥n es demasiado simplista", explica el profesor Alun Hubbard, coautor del estudio, que revela que el vapor atmosf√©rico que viajaba en 2018 hacia el sur desde el √Årtico llevaba una huella geoqu√≠mica √∫nica, que revelaba que su origen era la superficie c√°lida y abierta del mar de Barents. As√≠, este mar habr√≠a suministrado hasta el 88% de la nieve que cay√≥ sobre Europa ese a√±o.

Sus hallazgos indican que en los pr√≥ximos 60 a√±os, un mar de Barents sin hielo, como indican algunas predicciones, se convertir√° probablemente en una fuente importante de aumento de la lluvia y la nieve para Europa continental.

üì∏  EFE / AFP

Description:
Frankreich meint es ernst mit seiner Umweltpolitik!
Als eine von mehreren Ma√ünahmen gegen Umweltverschmutzung und Klimawandel hat das franz√∂sische Parlament am Samstag die Einf√ºhrung eines Straftatbestandes ‚Äû√ñkozid‚Äù bef√ºrwortet. Die Ma√ünahme soll auf ‚Äûdie ernstesten F√§lle von Umweltsch√§digungen von nationaler Bedeutung‚Äù anwendbar sein, sagte Umweltministerin Barbara Pompili.

Die Nationalversammlung nahm den ‚Äû√ñkozid‚Äù-Vorschlag mit 44 zu zehn Stimmen an. Anwendbar sei dieser Straftatbestand beispielsweise bei der Verschmutzung eines Flusses in Frankreich, sagte die Ministerin. Eine Anwendung au√üerhalb des Landes, wie etwa bei der Besch√§digung des brasilianischen Regenwaldes, unterliege nicht dem franz√∂sischen Recht. Das sp√§tere Gesetz solle strengere Strafen f√ºr die vors√§tzliche ‚Äûernste und anhaltende‚Äù Verschmutzung von Wasser, Luft und Boden erm√∂glichen.
 
Mehrere rechtsgerichtete Abgeordnete kritisierten eine Entwicklung hin zu einer ‚ÄûStraf√∂kologie‚Äù. Unternehmen drohe ‚Äûrechtliche Unsicherheit‚Äù. Linksgerichteten Abgeordneten gehen die geplanten Ma√ünahmen nicht weit genug. Statt nur vors√§tzliches Handeln zu bestrafen, m√ºssten auch Umweltsch√§den einbezogen werden, die durch Fahrl√§ssigkeit oder Leichtsinn verursacht worden seien. 

Das gesamte Gesetzespaket wird der Nationalversammlung im kommenden Monat zur Abstimmung vorgelegt und wandert im Falle einer Annahme danach in den Senat.

Foto: Leo Novel / dpa 

#Umweltschutz #Frankreich #Europa #Umweltpolitik #Umweltverschmutzung #Politik  #√ñkozid #Zukunft #BILD

Description:
Para Antonella Pellegrini, encargada del equipo de #econom√≠acircular y proyectos sostenibles de @enelchile, uno de los principales desaf√≠os que pone de manifiesto la #crisissanitaria actual en torno al #cambioclim√°tico y calentamiento global, es ‚Äúeliminar el hacinamiento, electrificar los consumos energ√©ticos y tambi√©n disminuir las brechas en la pobreza multidimensional‚Äù.

La ejecutiva sostiene, en esta entrevista con @elmostrador_braga, que ‚Äúes necesaria una movilizaci√≥n colectiva de todos los actores, porque la situaci√≥n que estamos viviendo no requiere de un esfuerzo solo del #Gobierno o del sector sanitario. En #Chile, as√≠ como en el mundo, todos los rubros se han activado para colaborar en el periodo de m√°xima urgencia. Sin embargo, hay brechas que han definido √°mbitos de m√°s vulnerabilidad. Seguramente unas ciudades sin hacinamiento y m√°s descontaminadas favorecen una vida de mejor calidad y, por supuesto, cuentan con m√°s resiliencia respecto a las contingencias sanitarias".

"El desaf√≠o que tenemos como humanidad ‚Äìprosigue‚Äì es redise√±ar nuestras ciudades de acuerdo a los criterios de sostenibilidad urban√≠stica, social y ambiental para aumentar su resiliencia frente a situaciones an√°logas a esta que vivimos. El transporte p√∫blico est√° avanzando mucho hacia la electrificaci√≥n, descontaminando el aire, no es lo mismo para los veh√≠culos privados. Tambi√©n la calefacci√≥n con combustibles f√≥siles determina impactos en la salud p√∫blica. La emergencia reside en la ciudades, en convertir nuestras ciudades en lugares de desarrollo humano, social y econ√≥mico, ambientalmente sostenibles‚Äù, se√±ala.

A new series of Google Earth timelapse videos reveals how the world has transformed because of the climate crisis over the last 37 years.‚Å†

The platform has compiled more than 24 million satellite images of the earth's surface from 1984 to 2020 to reveal how landscapes have been altered dramatically by the impacts of climate change - including melting ice, drought, wildfires and deforestation.‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
Does this paint look extra white to you?

It's the whitest-ever paint and has been produced by academic researchers with the aim of boosting the cooling of buildings and tackling the climate crisis.

It can even give a greater cooling power than common central air conditioners.

The new paint reflects 98% of sunlight as well as radiating infrared heat through the atmosphere into space. In tests, it cooled surfaces by 4.5C below the average air temperature, even in strong sunlight.

Currently available reflective white paints are far better than dark roofing materials, but they can't cool surfaces below the average air temperature like this new paint can.

White-painted roofs have been used to cool buildings for centuries. As global heating pushes temperatures up, the technique is also being used on modern city buildings, such as in Ahmedabad in India and New York City in the US.

Project Drawdown, a charity that assesses climate solutions, estimates that white roofs and green roofs could avoid between 600m and 1.1bn tonnes of carbon dioxide by 2050, roughly equivalent to two to three years of the UK‚Äôs total annual emissions.

Follow the link bio to read more about this 'cool' invention.
ImageText: This is the whitest paint ever G ‚Ä¶¬∑ ..and it could help cool down our heating Earth

Description:
If a week is a long time in politics, the past year has been an eternity for Jerome Foster.

Every Friday for 58 weeks in a row, the 18-year-old was holding forlorn protests outside the White House calling for action on global heating. Now, the computer science student has been ushered into the seat of American power to help craft climate policy.

In a sign of the growing political clout of the youth climate movement that has blossomed around the world, Foster has been included among a group of advisers to Joe Biden who will inform the US president on issues related to environmental justice, where low-income communities and people of colour face the greatest fallout from climate change and pollution.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt expect this to happen so soon, it was like, ‚ÄòWow, this is crazy,‚Äô‚Äù said Foster, who posted a tweet summing up the dramatic upgrade in his influence.

@JeromeFosterII added: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm the only person under 40 on the whole panel, so when I got there I was like, ‚ÄòAm I supposed to be here?‚Äô But it was their intention to bring in the youth perspective on climate change. I was a bit startled at first but now I‚Äôm getting used to it.‚Äù

Click the link in bio to read his full interview with @guardian_us.

Description:
Just 3% of the planet remains ecologically intact with healthy populations of all its original animals and undisturbed habitat, a new study suggests.

These fragments of wilderness undamaged by human activities are mainly in parts of the Amazon and Congo tropical forests, east Siberian and northern Canadian forests and tundra, and the Sahara.

The new assessment combines maps of human damage to habitat with maps showing where animals have disappeared from their original ranges or are too few in number to maintain a healthy ecosystem.

Invasive alien species including cats, foxes, rabbits, goats and camels have had a major impact on native species in Australia, with the study finding no intact areas left.

The researchers have suggested reintroducing a small number of important species to some damaged areas, such as elephants or wolves ‚Äì a move that could restore up to 20% of the world‚Äôs land to ecological intactness.

Some scientists said the new analysis underestimates the intact areas, because the ranges of animals centuries ago are poorly known and the new maps do not take account of the impacts of the climate crisis, which is changing the ranges of species.

But it is widely accepted that the world is in a biodiversity crisis - what are the biggest threats though? Swipe to read more and click the link in bio for the full story.

Description:
The Mesopotamian marshes, a series of wetlands along Iraq‚Äôs southeast border, feel like an oasis in the middle of the desert. 

The photojournalist and writer @emiliennemalfatto began documenting the marshes in 2016, searching for a different view of Iraq than the battle for Mosul, which she had been covering for the previous year and a half. The marshes are home to a people called the Ma‚Äôdan, also known as the Marsh Arabs, who are mostly buffalo breeders who live in isolated settlements reachable only by boat. Others live in small cities on the banks of the Tigris or Euphrates rivers, which feed the marshes. 

During the Iran-Iraq war, waged between 1980 and 1988, the wetlands‚Äô proximity to the Iranian border turned the area into a theater for bloody battles. In the early 1990s, Saddam Hussein drained the region ‚Äî where many of the Shiite rebels had fled ‚Äî as punishment and a way to stifle the insurrection. The marshes turned into a desert for more than a decade and, by the early 2000s, less than 10 percent of the area‚Äôs original wetlands existed. 

Today, after being re-flooded and partially restored, the marshes are once again endangered by climate change and the construction of dams upriver in Turkey, Syria and Iraq. Over the years, Malfatto saw drought and abundance, freezing winters and burning summers. She even got used to the huge water buffaloes, known locally as jamous.

Malfatto recalled her most recent trip to see Sayeed Hitham, a buffalo breeder she visited over the years as he and his family moved around the marsh. As they wrapped up breakfast, he burst into exuberant laughter. ‚ÄúYou still know nothing, Emi,‚Äù he told her. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt even tell the mean jamous in the herd.‚Äù

Then, serious, and still smiling, he said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs OK. You have time to learn.‚Äù‚Äù

Tap the link in our bio to see Malfatto‚Äôs photos and read more about the resilience of the Mesopotamian marshes and the people who live there.

Description:
The NFT market has exploded, driving up the price of digital artworks to fantastical levels. But these digital artworks rely on blockchain technology, which also forms the basis of cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin and produces enormous greenhouse-gas emissions.
 
‚ÄúIt turns out my release of six crypto-artworks consumed in 10 seconds more electricity than the entire studio over the past 2 years,‚Äù wrote Joanie Lemercier, a French artist. ‚ÄúIt felt like madness to even consider continuing that practice.‚Äù
 
In a nutshell, when an artist uploads a piece of art and clicks a button to ‚Äúmint‚Äù it, she or he starts a process known as mining, which involves complex puzzles, awesome computing power and a huge load of energy. That‚Äôs because Ethereum, the platform of choice for NFTs, uses a method called proof of work to create digital assets like nonfungible tokens. To successfully add an asset to the blockchain‚Äôs master ledger, miners must compete to solve a cryptographic puzzle, their computers rapidly generating numbers in a frenzied race of trial and error. As of mid-April, miners were making more than 170 quintillion attempts a second to produce new blocks, according to the trading platform Blockchain.com. (A quintillion is 1 followed by 18 zeros.)
 
The miner who arrives at the right answer first is the winner and gets her or his asset added to the blockchain.
 
According to an estimate backed up by independent researchers, the creation of an average NFT has a stunning environmental footprint of over 200 kilograms of planet-warming carbon, equivalent to driving 500 miles in a typical American gasoline-powered car.
 
‚ÄúI know it‚Äôs difficult to comprehend,‚Äù said Susanne K√∂hler, an expert in life cycle analysis at Aalborg University in Denmark who carried out an assessment of blockchain technology. ‚ÄúYou just click on a button or type a few words, and then suddenly you burn so much energy.‚Äù Tap the link in our bio to read more on how NFTs may be contributing to global warming.
ImageText: "It turns out my release of six crypto-artworks consumed in 10 seconds more electricity than the entire studio over the past 2 years." Joanie Lemercier A French artist who said he would put future NFT releases on hold

Description:
For more posts like this, follow @emergencyc4‚Å†

New Zealand is to introduce the world's first national law which would force banks and financiers to disclose their activities' climate impacts.‚Å†
‚Å†
Banks, asset managers and other financiers have come under increasing pressure from campaigners for their facilitating of climate-damaging industries, including oil and gas.‚Å†
‚Å†
As well as disclosing climate risks of any investments and financing by the financial sector, New Zealand's new law would require that plans are presented on how organisations will manage those climate risks.‚Å†
‚Å†
The legislation is part of New Zealand's commitment to reach net zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050, and will receive its first reading in New Zealand's parliament this week. If passed it is expected to make climate-related disclosures mandatory for around 200 financial organisations.‚Å†
‚Å†
Climate Change Minister James Shaw said: "We simply cannot get to net-zero carbon emissions by 2050 unless the financial sector knows what impact their investments are having on the climate. This law will bring climate risks and resilience into the heart of financial and business decision making."‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
The richest people in the world need to radically change their lifestyles to help tackle climate change, a report says.

The wealthiest 1% in the world produce double the combined carbon emissions of the poorest 50%, according to the UN.

In fact, the so-called "polluter elite" - the wealthiest 5% - contributed some 37% of emission growth between 1990 and 2015.

The authors of the report want people to fly less, ditch SUVs and better insulate their homes. 

Tap the link in our bio to read more about what the climate report recommends.

(üì∏ Getty Images)

#ClimateChange #Climate #Environment #GlobalWarming #BBCNews
ImageText: BBC NEWS World's wealthiest 'at heart of climate problem'

Description:
Follow @emergencyc4 for more stories like this....‚Å†
‚Å†
Experts are calling on UK policy makers to target the "polluter elite" in order to hit the goals of the Paris Agreement. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The recommendation was made in a report by the Cambridge Sustainability Commission, which looked at changes in behaviour needed to tackle climate change. It says the richest 10 per cent of people are responsible for nearly half the total growth in global emissions - with the wealthiest five per cent contributing more than a third. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The authors say the richest one per cent of the global population need to reduce their emissions to at least 30 times lower than their current level by 2030 in order to reach the Paris Agreement goal to limit global heating to at least below 2¬∞C. They add that the poorest 50 per cent could afford to increase their emissions by three times their current level and still be in line with the target.‚Å†
‚Å†
The report's recommendations include a frequent flyer tax, a ban on selling SUVs and reinstating the UK government's Green Homes Grant, which was axed last month.‚Å†
‚Å†
The report's lead author, Professor Peter Newell from the University of Sussex, told Channel 4 News that "providing better low carbon housing, transport and energy for the rest of society" will also be essential alongside targeting wealthy polluters.‚Å†
‚Å†
#pollution #frequentflyer #suv #greenhomesgrant #ukpolitics #climatepolicy #polluterelite #parisagreement #climate #climatechange #climatecrisis #climateemergency #globalheating #globalwarming #greenhousegasses #carbon #emissions #fossilfuels #co2 #netzero #politics #science #climatescience #sustainability #nature #environment

Description: Russia's Lake Baikal is the oldest and deepest lake in the world, holding about 20% of the world's fresh water and currently facing increasing environmental threats from climate change and mass tourism. Description:
Aktuell steuert die Welt auf mindestens drei Grad Erw√§rmung zu. Eine Studie zum Artensterben zeigt, dass das Risiko f√ºr das Aussterben endemischer Arten um mehr als das Zehnfache steigt, wenn die im Pariser Abkommen festgelegten Klimaziele von 1,5 Grad bis maximal zwei Grad verfehlt w√ºrden.

Der Klimawandel wird insbesondere in Regionen, in denen viele verschiedene Tier- und Pflanzenarten leben, gro√üen Schaden anrichten: Bei einer Erderw√§rmung um mehr als drei Grad Celcius sind demnach ein Drittel (34 Prozent) der auf dem Land lebenden endemischen Arten und etwa die H√§lfte (46 Prozent) der im Meer lebenden endemischen Arten vom Aussterben bedroht. Auf Bergen sind sogar 84 Prozent bedroht, auf Inseln steigt diese Zahl auf 100 Prozent an. Zu endemische Arten werden Arten oder Gattungen gez√§hlt, die nur in einem bestimmten Gebiet vorkommen. Dazu geh√∂ren zum Beispiel die Lemurenarten, der Blaue Kranich oder der Schneeleopard.
.

Description:

Se ha aprobado la primera ley en Espa√±a de Cambio Clim√°tico y Transici√≥n Energ√©tica. La norma que contiene las l√≠neas b√°sicas de actuaci√≥n para ir reduciendo la dependencia de actividades y energ√≠as contaminantes para acabar en 2050 en lo que se llama neutralidad clim√°tica, que s√≥lo emitamos los gases contaminante que la naturaleza pueda absorber por s√≠ misma. 2050 dir√°n ustedes, largo me lo fiais, pero para llegar all√≠ hay que empezar ya mismo y es un cambio serio que afecta a la econom√≠a, al empleo, al consumo, al modo de vida. ¬øO no? ¬øLa transici√≥n energ√©tica consiste solo en cambiar una energ√≠a contaminante por otra limpia y seguir viviendo, gastando y consumiendo como hasta ahora? ¬øO tenemos que empezar a cambiar m√°s cosas aqu√≠ en Espa√±a? Se lo vamos a preguntar a las diez y media a la vicepresidenta Ribera.

Pero adem√°s la ley ha salido adelante por amplia mayor√≠a. Ha votado a favor o se ha abstenido toda la c√°mara, incluido el PP, menos Vox, que se ha quedado solo votando en contra. En un momento de extrema polarizaci√≥n como este, este resultado tiene indudable valor pol√≠tico en el presente y tambi√©n de cara al futuro, de cara a mantener las medidas que contempla esta ley que no derogar√≠a el siguiente inquilino en la Moncloa. El √∫nico 'no' el de Vox y para hacernos una idea de sus argumentos escuchen a su diputado Francisco Jos√© Contreras. Para que sepamos de qu√© se habla cuando se habla de meterlos en un gobierno.

Ha sido mientras se debat√≠a la nueva Ley de Cambio Clim√°tico, que se ha aprobado hoy a falta de su paso por el Senado. El diputado de Vox se ha preguntado "¬øqui√©n decret√≥ que la temperatura √≥ptima para la humanidad fuera la de 1850?", para luego asegurar que "hoy en d√≠a mueren de fr√≠o 17 veces m√°s personas que de calor".
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
La cifra, adem√°s, es falsa: en Espa√±a mueren m√°s personas por calor, pero las olas de fr√≠o ocupan menos d√≠as por lo que, aunque los fallecidos son menos, se reportan m√°s muertes por d√≠a de ola de fr√≠o que por d√≠a de ola de calor.

Description:
Human activity is destroying the equivalent of a soccer field of seagrass every 30 minutes around the world, according to the U.N Environment Program.‚Å†
‚Å†
Seagrass plays an important role in helping regulate ocean environments, storing more than twice as much carbon from planet-warming carbon dioxide as forests do on land. ‚Å†
The grass also curbs the acidity of surrounding waters.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúThis has massive implications for the (world‚Äôs) climate change mitigation efforts,‚Äù said Dimos Traganos, lead scientist on a German Aerospace Center project developing software to improve seagrass tracking using satellite imagery and other data.‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
A small but growing number of world leaders have begun citing an offense they say poses a threat to humanity and remains beyond the reach of international criminal law: ecocide, or widespread destruction of the environment.‚Å†
‚Å†
Pope Francis has endorsed a campaign by environmental activists and legal scholars to make ecocide the fifth crime before the International Criminal Court in The Hague as a legal deterrent to the kinds of far-reaching environmental damage that are driving mass extinction, ecological collapse and climate change.‚Å†
‚Å†
The monumental step, which faces a long road of global debate, would mean political leaders and corporate executives could face charges and imprisonment for ‚Äúecocidal‚Äù acts.‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
Kelp forests along Northern California have almost vanished. Divers and scientists are racing to stop purple sea urchins from taking over critical habitat.

Kelp forests provide a crucial ecosystem for a broad range of other marine life and animals, so their demise threatens the ecology across the entire stretch of California coast. 

The kelp's abrupt decline is being driven by warming waters, and it's a case of how climate change is helping push already-stressed ecosystems over the edge. Tap the link in our bio for the story. (Image: Steve Lonhart/NOAA MBNMS; Maps: Zach Levitt/NPR; Data Source: Meredith L. McPherson, PhD)

Description:
Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è Japan‚Äôs famous cherry blossoms, which experience a "peak bloom" that only lasts a few days, have been revered in Japan for more than a thousand years üå∏ But this year, "sakura" season has come and gone in the blink of an eye, in one of the earliest blooms on record ‚Äî and scientists warn it's a symptom of the larger climate crisis threatening ecosystems everywhere. This year's change in flowering dates isn't limited to just Japan; the cherry blossoms that adorn the Tidal Basin in Washington, DC, have also bloomed early. According to the National Park Service, the peak bloom date of the Washington cherry blossoms has advanced forward by nearly a week from April 5 to March 31.‚Å†
‚Å†
(üì∏: Soichiro Koriyama/Bloomberg via Getty Images)

Description:
The UK government has backed a campaign to protect seals from human disturbance this Easter weekend.‚Å†
‚Å†
It comes just weeks after internet star ‚ÄòFreddie the Seal‚Äô died following a dog attack in Barnes, London.‚Å†
‚Å†
Launched by The Seal Alliance, the campaign ‚ÄòGive Seals Space‚Äô urges the public to keep ‚Äúwell away‚Äù from the popular marine mammal over the bank holiday.‚Å†
‚Å†
It also asks the public never to feed seals, to keep dogs on a lead and to take all litter home.‚Å†
‚Å†
The UK is home to 38% of the world‚Äôs grey seal population, but factors such as plastic pollution, climate change and even lockdown have left seals increasingly vulnerable.‚Å†
‚Å†
Environment Secretary George Eustice said, ‚ÄúDisturbance by members of the public can be detrimental to seals, but this is entirely preventable.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúI would urge everyone to follow the guidance, give seals the space that they need and respect this vulnerable marine species."
