Description:
President Biden introduced on Wednesday afternoon what he called a transformational plan to overhaul and upgrade America‚Äôs physical infrastructure, promising it would create the ‚Äúmost resilient, innovative economy in the world.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt is not a plan that tinkers around the edges,‚Äù Biden said. ‚ÄúIt is a once-in-a-generation investment in America. Unlike anything we have seen or done since we built the interstate highway system and the space race decades ago. In fact, the largest American jobs investment since World War II.‚Äù

Biden appeared at a carpenters training center outside Pittsburgh to unveil his $2 trillion infrastructure plan, a far-reaching proposal that he will seek to pay for with a substantial increase in corporate taxes.

The price tag would translate into 20,000 miles of rebuilt roads, repairs to the 10 most economically important bridges in the country, the elimination of lead pipes and service lines from the nation‚Äôs water supplies and a long list of other projects intended to create millions of jobs in the short run and strengthen American competitiveness in the long run.

The measure, called the American Jobs Plan, is the first step in a two-part agenda to overhaul American capitalism, fight climate change and try to improve the productivity of the economy. Biden said the second step, the American Family Plan, would come in a matter of weeks.

‚ÄúThese are investments we have to make,‚Äù he said.
Tap the link in our bio to read more about Biden‚Äôs speech and what‚Äôs in the infrastructure plan.  Photo by @anna.money
ImageText: Biden Unveils $2 Trillion Plan to Rebuild Infrastructure

Description:
¬øCu√°ntas veces crees que las palabras ‚Äú#ciencia‚Äù, ‚Äú#tecnolog√≠a‚Äù e ‚Äú#innovaci√≥n‚Äù est√°n en la actual #Constituci√≥n?: Cero. Y, sin embargo, estas mismas materias son la clave de un desarrollo futuro que logre la independencia de una econom√≠a basada en la extracci√≥n de recursos naturales y en la creaci√≥n de conocimiento.

Es as√≠ como en este 2021, marcado por diversas elecciones y la discusi√≥n que trazar√° los principios para la ruta de Chile en los pr√≥ximos a√±os, #Caf√©delFuturo busca colaborar con este proceso constitucional planteando una pregunta ¬øEs la ciencia parte de este debate? ¬øC√≥mo la nueva Constituci√≥n integrar√° su participaci√≥n en un mundo que tanto necesita evidencia frente a aspectos como el cambio clim√°tico, la inteligencia artificial o los desaf√≠os sanitarios?

Estas materias ser√°n abordadas en la nueva versi√≥n de Caf√© del Futuro, que como ya es costumbre, se transmitir√° gratuitamente a la comunidad en el sitio web de @congresofuturo . Adem√°s, esta vez el evento tendr√° un doble prop√≥sito: el lanzamiento de la temporada y el lanzamiento de la candidatura de Estefy Lococo, postulante a constituyente por la lista ‚ÄúB+‚Äù.

Lococo es una de las diversas aspirantes que ha planteado como eje articulador de sus propuestas, la necesidad de instalar en el centro de la discusi√≥n la construcci√≥n de un pa√≠s basado en el conocimiento y la urgencia de integrar perspectiva cient√≠fica para la toma de decisiones.

Description:
Former President Donald Trump called President Biden's jobs plan a "monstrosity" that "would be among the largest self-inflicted economic wounds in history."

Biden's American Jobs Plan, announced Wednesday, calls for $2.25 trillion to be raised primarily by increasing the corporate tax rate from 21% to 28% and the global minimum tax on U.S. corporations from 13% to 21%. It is meant to improve infrastructure and pump money into manufacturing, transportation, renewable energy, and combating climate change.

President Biden is set to unveil one of the most ambitious federal spending proposals in American history on Wednesday, a more than $2 trillion plan that would reshape the American economy by renovating some of the nation's most iconic landmarks, rebuilding aging schools and spending billions of dollars to fight climate change. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Debate over the new legislation is expected to dominate Washington well into the summer and is already drawing strong Republican opposition. Head to the link in our bio for the details.

Description:
Google Maps is to begin highlighting trips with the lowest emissions in an effort to combat climate change.
 
The search engine said it will highlight journeys that generate the lowest carbon footprint using mainly traffic data and road inclines.
 
Google said the feature, which will be the default setting, would launch first in the US later this year "with a global expansion on the way".

The new feature is part of its commitment to fight climate change.

Tap the link in our bio for more on the new feature.

Description:
People in Tokyo take photos of Japan's famous cherry blossoms, which have bloomed earlier this spring than they have for the past 1,200 years.

The peak bloom arrived on 26 March in Kyoto, the earliest since 27 March 1409, while in Tokyo they reached full bloom on 22 March - the second-earliest date since 1953.

The full bloom, or Sakura, historically occurs on 17 April - but in recent times, warmer and earlier springs have meant earlier blooms, according to climate change experts.

Between 1971 and 2000, this type of tree was found to bloom on average a week earlier than all previous averages recorded in Kyoto - so 2021's bloom is the result of a long-standing trend.

Photo üì∏: AP

#CherryBlossom #Blossom #Spring #Climate #Nature #Flowers #Sakura #Tokyo #Kyoto #Japan

The Sea Life Kelly Tarlton‚Äôs Aquarium, in Auckland, has recently introduced its newest addition to the public ‚Äì an adorable six-week-old penguin chick.

The aquarium has now launched a competition to name the king penguin chick, which hatched on Valentine‚Äôs Day.

‚ÄúThe fluffy little chick spent the first month of its life with its head tucked under dad Loaf‚Äôs tummy, but has recently started venturing out and standing up in front,‚Äù said Laura Seaman, a team leader at the aquarium.

The aquarium runs the only king penguin breeding program in New Zealand. The species is ‚Äúunder threat from overfishing, invasive species and climate change,‚Äù they said.

Description:
Dass die meisten Menschen in den Industriestaaten √∂kologisch gesehen √ºber ihre Verh√§ltnisse leben, ist kein Geheimnis. Der konsumorientierte Lebensstil erhitzt den Planeten und dezimiert die Biodiversit√§t in alarmierendem Tempo.

Auch die Abholzung der Regenw√§lder geht zu einem betr√§chtlichen Teil auf das Konto der Industriestaaten. F√ºr die Produktion vieler Agrarprodukte wird im gro√üen Stil Urwald gerodet. 

Mit einer detaillierten Datenanalyse haben Forscher jetzt erstmals ermittelt, wie breit die Schneise der Zerst√∂rung ist. Die Autoren w√§hlten dabei die G-7-Staaten als Beispiel. Das sind Japan, Kanada und die USA, Frankreich, Italien, Gro√übritannien und Deutschland.

Den kompletten Beitrag zum Thema finden Sie hier.

Description:
Follow @EmergencyC4 for more stories like this‚Å†
‚Å†
The average consumer from a G7 country is responsible for the loss of nearly four trees each year, according to new research.‚Å†
‚Å†
That's because consumption of things like coffee, chocolate, meat, palm oil and soya are all the primary drivers of global deforestation, especially in the tropics, as land is often cleared before these products can be raised. The products are mostly consumed in rich countries, driving deforestation in other parts of the world through trade.‚Å†
‚Å†
The precision of the new research, published in Nature Ecology and Evolution, was made possible by analysing global trade relationships between deforestation and 15,000 industry sectors, from 2001 to 2015. Using individual countries' population figures, the researchers were able to identify a "deforestation footprint" for different nations.‚Å†
‚Å†
Different consumption patterns in different countries mean different impacts. Consumers in Singapore were responsible for around five trees being felled a year, mostly via neighbouring countries in south east Asia, as the picture shows. Whereas UK consumers were responsible for around half as many trees, impacting deforestation in West Africa.‚Å†
‚Å†
The loss of forests and their ability to suck carbon from the atmosphere is a driver of the climate crisis as well as biodiversity.‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
üå∏ Esta primavera marca la floraci√≥n de los cerezos de Jap√≥n m√°s temprana de los √∫ltimos 1.200 a√±os. ¬øEl motivo? El cambio clim√°tico.

La floraci√≥n de los cerezos en Jap√≥n es uno de los procesos naturales mejor documentados en la historia de la humanidad. Algunos escritos, dibujos y pinturas muestran este proceso lleno de belleza desde hace unos 1.200 a√±os, con indicaci√≥n exacta en algunos casos de la fecha en que estos √°rboles frutales y ornamentales se visten de blanco.

Las fechas de florescencia de estos √°rboles de la familia de las ros√°ceas en Jap√≥n (y en buena parte del hemisferio norte) se ajustan a un periodo m√°s o menos largo entre finales de marzo y principios de abril, dependiendo en muchos casos de condiciones locales como la temperatura o la humedad.

En 2021, despu√©s de una primavera inusualmente c√°lida, Kioto -uno de los lugares simb√≥licos en este fen√≥meno- ha marcado la floraci√≥n de los cerezos en la fecha m√°s temprana de los √∫ltimos 1.200 a√±os.

Un fen√≥meno puntual como este puede mostrar una variaci√≥n natural sin mayor trascendencia pero, analizando los datos de los √∫ltimos a√±os, los expertos han observado que claramente se est√° produciendo un adelanto en la floraci√≥n de los cerezos en este pa√≠s; un fen√≥meno -el de las floraciones tempranas- que tambi√©n se produce en muchas otras partes del planeta.

Examinando esta serie de 1200 a√±os, los cient√≠ficos han observado una tendencia clara hacia el adelanto, paralela al aumento de las emisiones a la atm√≥sfera de gases de efecto invernadero y el calentamiento global.

Cuando los cient√≠ficos muestran con ayuda de gr√°ficos las fechas de plena floraci√≥n de Kioto a lo largo del tiempo se dibuja una curva plenamente coincidente con la del cambio clim√°tico.

Kioto no es la √∫nica ciudad con datos hist√≥ricos que apuntan en el mismo sentido. Algo muy parecido ha sido documentado en Tokio, donde la floraci√≥n se ha avanzado 12 d√≠as en las √∫ltimas cuatro d√©cadas.

Description:
The cherry blossom season, Japan's traditional sign of spring, has peaked at the earliest date since records began 1,200 years ago, research shows. üå∏

The 2021 season in the city of Kyoto peaked on 26 March,¬†according to data collected by Osaka University.

The records from Kyoto go back to 812 AD in imperial court documents and diaries.

Increasingly early flowerings in recent decades are likely to be as a result of climate change, scientists say.

The city has experienced an unusually warm spring this year.
The previous record there was set in 1409, when the season reached its peak on 27 March.

Tap the link in our bio to see more of the beautiful blossoms.

Description:
La p√©rdida de #bosques es tambi√©n uno de los principales responsables de las emisiones que contribuyen al calentamiento del #clima, ya que la densa vegetaci√≥n de los bosques tropicales representa la mayor reserva viva de carbono.

La tala y la conversi√≥n de tierras, principalmente para la #agricultura, han eliminado el 34% de los #bosquestropicales antiguos originales del mundo, y han degradado otro 30%, dej√°ndolos m√°s vulnerables a los incendios y a futuras destrucciones, seg√∫n un an√°lisis de la Fundaci√≥n Rainforest de Noruega.

M√°s de la mitad de la destrucci√≥n desde 2002 se ha producido en la #Amazon√≠a sudamericana y en las selvas tropicales lim√≠trofes.

A medida que se destruye m√°s selva tropical, aumenta el potencial de cambio clim√°tico, lo que a su vez dificulta la supervivencia de los bosques restantes, dijo el autor del informe, Anders Krogh, investigador de bosques tropicales.

"Es un ciclo aterrador", dijo Krogh. El total perdido s√≥lo entre 2002 y 2019 fue mayor que la superficie de Francia, sostuvo.

El ritmo de p√©rdida en 2019 igual√≥ aproximadamente el nivel anual de destrucci√≥n de los √∫ltimos 20 a√±os, con la desaparici√≥n de un campo de f√∫tbol de bosque cada 6 segundos, seg√∫n otro informe reciente del Instituto de Recursos Mundiales.

La Amazon√≠a brasile√±a ha estado bajo una intensa presi√≥n en las √∫ltimas d√©cadas, ya que un auge agr√≠cola ha llevado a los agricultores y especuladores de la tierra a incendiar parcelas para criar ganado o producir soja y otros cultivos. La tendencia ha empeorado desde 2019, cuando el presidente derechista Jair Bolsonaro asumi√≥ el cargo y comenz√≥ a debilitar la vigilancia ambiental.

Description:
Una hora a oscuras por el planeta

Como cada 27 de marzo desde 2007, este s√°bado se ha celebrado la hora del planeta, en la que monumentos y edificios de todo el mundo apagan sus luces entre las 20.30 y las 21.30.

No se trata de un problema global, sino m√°s bien de la b√∫squeda de una soluci√≥n para otro. La hora del planeta ha vuelto, un a√±o m√°s, a usar la oscuridad para poner el foco sobre la naturaleza. 

"Queremos llamar la atenci√≥n sobre lo importante que es contactar con la naturaleza", explica Luis Su√°rez, coordinador de conservaci√≥n de WWF Espa√±a. √âsta, asegura, "nos tiene que proteger de futuras pandemias" y, en cualquier caso, de su salud precisamente depende la lucha "contra el cambio clim√°tico".

En las im√°genes: El Coliseo de Roma, la Puerta de Brandenburgo en Berl√≠n, Budapest, la Torre del Oro en Sevilla, los Jardines de la Bah√≠a de Singapur y la Ciudad del Vaticano. (EFE | Reuters)

Eine US-amerikanische Studie kommt zum Schluss, dass Umweltverschmutzung dazu f√ºhrt, dass M√§nner mit kleineren Geschlechtsorganen zur Welt kommen. Greta Thunberg bekam davon mit und l√§dt Direktbetroffene via Twitter kurzerhand zum n√§chsten Klimastreik ein.
Die Umweltmedizinerin Shanna Swan sorgt f√ºr News der anderen Art: Gem√§ss mehrerer ihrer durchgef√ºhrten Studien, ist die Umweltverschmutzung durch Plastik daf√ºr verantwortlich, dass Buben mit immer kleineren Penissen zur Welt kommen. Das berichtet¬†‚ÄûSky News‚Äú.
Grund daf√ºr seien die Auswirkungen von Plastik auf den menschlichen K√∂rper. Hat eine schwangere Frau sogenannte ‚ÄûPhthalate‚Äú, also Chemikalien, die vor allem in der Plastik-Produktion zum Einsatz kommen, im K√∂rper, k√∂nnen sich diese negativ auf ihre m√§nnlichen Babys auswirken ‚Äì und zwar auch wenn es um die Gr√∂√üe des besten St√ºcks geht.
Greta Thunberg nutze diese Vorlage charmant, zitierte den Tweet des Fernsehnetzwerks und schrieb ‚ÄûWir sehen uns alle beim n√§chsten Klimastreik.‚Äú An wen dieser Tweet nun gerichtet sein mag, bleibt dahingestellt. Description:
Durante la celebraci√≥n de la Semana Mundial del #Agua, diversos desaf√≠os quedaron expuestos con respecto al panorama, tanto mundial como nacional, de la situaci√≥n del agua en medio de la crisis clim√°tica que afecta los recursos naturales. Una de las principales tareas a nivel pa√≠s es seguir asegurando el suministro de agua potable a lo largo del pa√≠s y garantizar este derecho a toda la poblaci√≥n. Para esto, diversas entidades y actores han recalcado la importancia trabajar en conjunto para refortalecer el suministro y contar con una ciudad m√°s segura.

‚ÄúTodos los desaf√≠os se centran en la escasez y en la necesidad que tenemos de valorizar la disponibilidad y la falta. Hoy d√≠a en Chile, vivimos una situaci√≥n que es casi √∫nica en el mundo cuando las cifras de Naciones Unidas nos dicen que el 27% de la poblaci√≥n mundial tiene abastecimiento de agua potable las 24 horas del d√≠a por sistemas de redes, uno puede pensar lo privilegiado que somos los chilenos, pero esta situaci√≥n no est√° garantizada‚Äù, afirm√≥ Juan Eduardo Saldivia, abogado y ex superintendente de Servicios Sanitarios. 

Actualmente, la vulnerabilidad del acceso a este recurso se evidencia cada d√≠a m√°s. Es as√≠, como hemos sido testigos de diversos sucesos naturales en el √∫ltimo tiempo. #Aluviones, #lluvias intensas durante el verano, inundaciones y sequ√≠as en zonas del pa√≠s que antes no se ve√≠an han marcado el panorama del pa√≠s y las repercusiones del #cambioclim√°tico. 

En esa misma l√≠nea, Juan Eduardo Saldivia, agreg√≥ que ‚Äúla sequ√≠a nos est√° golpeando fuertemente, por ende, ya hay lugares que sufren escasez y racionamiento, ciudades como Illapel est√°n muy cerca en caer en situaci√≥n de racionamiento. El principal desaf√≠o es enfrentar la escasez y para eso hay que mejorar legislaci√≥n, hay que hacer inversiones y mejorar las pol√≠ticas p√∫blicas‚Äù.

Description:
En las im√°genes, agentes de polic√≠a se llevan a activistas de Extinction Rebellion que bloqueaban el paso frente al Ministerio de Sanidad, en el paseo del Prado de Madrid, durante una protesta para exigir acciones contra el cambio clim√°tico, este viernes 26 de marzo.

El Congreso de los Diputados est√° a punto de completar el texto del proyecto de ley de Cambio Clim√°tico, que mantiene la previsi√≥n de prescindir de los veh√≠culos convencionales de combusti√≥n interna en el a√±o 2040 (gasolina, di√©sel e h√≠bridos no enchufables), entre otros aspectos.

Las oeneg√©s echan en falta, sin embargo, las asambleas ciudadanas sobre cambio clim√°tico. Formadas por unas 100 o 150 personas elegidas por sorteo, funcionan como un jurado popular que debate y adopta sus propias resoluciones. 

El 21 de enero de 2020 el Consejo de Ministros prometi√≥ en su declaraci√≥n de emergencia clim√°tica que iba a convocar las asambleas ciudadanas en cien d√≠as y que as√≠ se buscaba "reforzar los mecanismos de participaci√≥n ya existentes con una Asamblea Ciudadana del Cambio Clim√°tico" pero m√°s de un a√±o despu√©s "no ha habido avances en este sentido", se queja Extinction Rebellion.

Los desbordamientos del Nilo Blanco, en Sud√°n del Sur, son cada vez m√°s graves. En los √∫ltimos meses ha colapsado grandes √°reas de ribera del pa√≠s africano. Pueblos enteros desaparecen y sus habitantes se convierten en refugiados, v√≠ctimas de los fen√≥menos extremos de la era del cambio clim√°tico.

Cada a√±o, las inundaciones se vuelven m√°s fuertes y devastadoras. Desde mediados de 2020, Sud√°n del Sur se ha visto azotado durante meses por este fen√≥meno en la zona del Nilo Blanco. A massive tree felling operation has been going on in the Kielder Forest in Northumberland, England for the last few weeks.

It will help restore an ancient ecosystem ‚Äì bogland ‚Äì that should help tackle climate change.

A bog can store carbon for thousands of years, so it's even better for the environment than forests.

#England #UK #Environment #Climate #ClimateChange #BBCNews

Description:
What do the floods in New South Wales tell us about a climate crisis future?

Days of heavy rain and flooding along Australia‚Äôs east coast have caused widespread damage and triggered the evacuation of thousands of residents ‚Äì from western Sydney to the mid-north coast.

Experts say it‚Äôs unusual to see so many places with such high rainfall across such a wide area, but identifying the cause is complicated.

With the weather finally easing and the recovery set to begin, @guardianaustralia's environment reporter Graham Readfearn has been looking at the what may have caused the disaster - and examines how much of it can be attributed to global heating.

To listen our entire podcast, Full Story, click the link in bio.
ImageText: What Australia's flood disaster tells us about the climate crisis WATER OVER ROAD

Description:
Los Angeles could become one of the country's first major cities to nearly eliminate fossil fuels from its power supply.

In a first-of-its-kind study released today, the National Renewable Energy Laboratory concluded L.A. is capable of achieving 98% clean energy within the next decade and 100% by 2035, meeting one of President Biden's most ambitious #climate goals.

The benefits of reaching 100% clean energy would be immense: not only helping to counteract the climate crisis, but also slashing deadly air #pollution. Many of those benefits would come from expanding the electric grid and limiting the need to burn oil and natural gas.

Every pathway outlined by NREL includes geothermal power plants, which tap the Earth's subterranean heat, as well as pumped hydropower, which can store solar and wind longer than a typical battery. The study also assumes that as many as 80% of cars on L.A. roads would be electric by 2045.

Want more details about how #LosAngeles can reach 100% #cleanenergy by 2035? Visit our link in bio to read more.

‚úçÔ∏è: Sammy Roth
üì∏: Irfan Khan
ImageText: Los Angeles now has a road map for 100% renewable energy

Description:
Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è Summer weather could grow to half a year in length by the end of this century if no mitigation efforts are done on climate change, according to a new study. In about the past 60 years, summer has increased by 17 days on average across the globe. "Summers are getting longer and hotter while winters shorter and warmer due to global warming," said Yuping Guan, lead author of the study. Sure, longer summers may sound great for a family vacation or enjoying the outdoors, but this extended season could significantly impact our health, the environment and agriculture. Heat waves could grow longer, mosquito-borne illnesses could become more widespread, allergy season from pollen could turn more severe and the growing season of crops will be longer. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the study.‚Å†
‚Å†
(üì∏: Loic Venance/AFP via Getty Images)‚Å†
ImageText: CNN By the year 2100, summer weather could last half a year (and that's not a good thing) Longer summers may sound great for vacations, but this extended season could significantly impact our health, the environment and agriculture

Description:
For more stories like this, follow @EmergencyC4‚Å†
‚Å†
Only one quarter of corporate net zero targets are fully "robust", according to a new report.‚Å†
‚Å†
As prevailing public and consumer attitudes toward the climate crisis have changed in recent years, there has been increased incentive for companies to be seen to be acting on reducing their climate impact.‚Å†
‚Å†
One outcome of this, said today's report by the Energy and Climate Intelligence Unit (ECIU) and University of Oxford, is that at least 21 per cent of the world's largest 2,000 public companies have announced net zero carbon emissions targets. The "rapid uptake of net zero targets is encouraging", said one of the report's authors.‚Å†
‚Å†
But the devil in the detail, the report warned, as targets with poor plans of how to get there risk greenwashing - meaning 'green' credentials are publicised which aren't backed up by real action.‚Å†
‚Å†
The research found that of existing corporate net zero targets, only 26 per cent meet the "minimum set of robustness criteria" set out by the UN Race to Zero Campaign. This means they include transparency rules, interim as well long term targets, and information on how much carbon offsetting they intend to include.‚Å†
‚Å†
Even fewer national net zero targets meet the robustness criteria, at 12 percent of 124 pledges by countries.‚Å†
‚Å†
Richard Black, one of the ECIU authors on the report, said: "There is logic to setting a target and then building a plan and reporting mechanisms to meet that, but companies and countries alike will need to make progress on this in the run-up to COP [climate conference in Glasgow this year]."‚Å†
‚Å†
In total, the report found that 124 countries, 73 states & regions, 155 cities, and 417 companies have made some level of net zero pledge.‚Å†
‚Å†
#emergencyc4 #channel4news #news #currentaffairs #international #climate #climatechange #climatecrisis #climateemergency #globalheating #globalwarming #greenhousegasses #carbon #emissions #fossilfuels #co2 #netzero #politics #science #climatescience #sustainability #nature #environment #netzero #greenwashing #transparency #corporategovernance #research #oxforduniversity #eciu

Description:
Wie wir derzeit mit der Natur umgingen, das ‚Äûwird zum Selbstmordtrip‚Äú, sagt der Historiker und Autor Philipp Blom im Deutschlandfunk. ‚ÄûEs braucht ein gemeinsames gesellschaftliches Projekt‚Äú, aber kein Politiker biete derzeit eine Vision einer besseren Zukunft. Die Reaktion auf die Corona-Krise mache aber Hoffnung.

Er sei weder gegen Kapitalismus noch gegen Globalisierung, aber unser Konsum auf Kosten der Natur sei ein ‚Äûenden wollendes Modell‚Äú. Die Kritik daran sei aber immer abgeprallt. In der Corona-Krise h√§tte man nun aber als Staaten die Z√ºgel in die Hand genommen und innerhalb von wenigen Tagen umgesteuert.

Dennoch lernten sich die Menschen gerade ganz neu kennen ‚Äûals ein kleines R√§dchen im gigantischen Mechanismus der Natur.‚Äú Dieser Prozess bedeute aber auch, dass sich die Menschen von alten Logiken verabschieden m√ºssten, beispielsweise von Eroberung, Herrschaft und Unterdr√ºckung. Aus der Notwendigkeit k√∂nne man zu einer Logik der Kooperation √ºbergehen. ‚ÄûNicht, weil wir bessere Menschen geworden sind, sondern weil es als die einzige Weise zu schein seid, wie wir unser √úberleben sichern k√∂nnen‚Äú, so Blom.

Volker Quaschning von der Hochschule f√ºr Technik und Wirtschaft in Berlin hat im Deutschlandfunk vor den Folgen der menschgemachten globalen Erderw√§rmung gewarnt - man m√ºsse aus den Fehlern, die man beim Umgang mit der Coronakrise gemacht habe, lernen. 
.
Deutschland m√ºsse sich beispielsweise beim Kohleausstieg beeilen und an anderen europ√§ischen L√§ndern orientieren, um die Klimaziele einzuhalten. Auch m√ºsse das Ausbautempo f√ºr Solar- und Windenergie gesteigert und der Pro-Kopf-Fleischbedarf reduziert werden. Quaschning sagte zudem, dass man eigentlich einen sofortigen Stopp der Produktion von Benzin- und Dieselmotoren brauche.

Description:
Protesting underwater down in the heart of the western Indian Ocean.

That's what Mauritian scientist and climate change activist Shaama Sandooyea has done to highlight the need to protect the world's largest seagrass meadow within the Mascarene plateau, Mauritius.

The photo, taken on 6 March, has been released to coincide with today's Fridays for Future, a global climate strike movement that started in August 2018, when [then] 15-year-old Greta Thunberg began a school strike for climate.

Protesters from as many as 60 countries gathered in person and online today calling for urgent measures and concrete action to combat climate change and global warming.

24-year-old Sandooyea said she became an activist from a young age after seeing the vulnerability of the ocean and witnessing oil spills: ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt keep treading water on the climate crisis. I‚Äôve taken a stand here in this beautiful, remote area of the Indian Ocean to deliver a simple message - we need climate action and we need it now.‚Äù

Mauritius has been the envy of the world for its alluring beaches and marine riches, but the island is still trying to recover from its worst-ever ecological disaster caused in July last year, when a Japanese ship hit a coral reef and leaked about 900 tons of fuel into the sea.

Photo: Tommy Trenchard/Greenpeace via Reuters
ImageText: YOUTH STRIKE FOR CLIMATE

Description:
Shama Sanduya es una activista de 24 a√±os de las islas Mauricio, implicada totalmente en la lucha contra el cambio clim√°tico, que ha decidido realizar una curiosa protesta. Lo ha hecho en la falda de malla, el banco subacu√°tico m√°s grande del mundo, en las Seychelles. Reclama que se protejan los pastos marinos, porque alimentan a muchas especies, pero sobre todo absorben el di√≥xido de carbono que calienta nuestro planeta. Una huelga necesaria para concienciarnos.  El mundo est√° perdiendo al a√±o alrededor de un 7% de estos pastos, debido al dragado y al aumento de la temperatura en los oc√©anos. Por eso ella se planta junto a Greenpeace, en v√≠speras de la Huelga Clim√°tica Mundial de ma√±ana. Para que declaren protegida esta √°rea marina y provoque un efecto domin√≥. Porque del futuro del planeta depende el nuestro.

#ShamaSanduya #Mauricio #CambioClim√°tico #Greenpeace

Description:
üåç La joven cient√≠fica y defensora del clima, Shaama Sandooyea, ha realizado la primera huelga clim√°tica submarina del mundo, en el coraz√≥n del Oc√©ano √çndico. 

Mientras estaba bajo el agua, Sandooyea, de 24 a√±os, exhibi√≥ un cartel con los mensajes ‚ÄúHuelga juvenil por el clima‚Äù y ‚ÄúNou Reklam Lazistis Klimatik‚Äù: ‚ÄúExigimos justicia clim√°tica‚Äù. 

‚ÄúNo podemos seguir aguantando la crisis clim√°tica‚Äù, dijo Sandooyea. ‚ÄúHe elegido este lugar, en esta hermosa y remota √°rea del Oc√©ano √çndico, para transmitir un mensaje simple: necesitamos acci√≥n clim√°tica y la necesitamos ahora. Con otros activistas de Fridays for Future en todo el mundo, quiero que la crisis clim√°tica se tome en serio. Reducir las emisiones y proteger nuestros oc√©anos son algunas de las mejores formas de hacerlo‚Äù.
.

.

Description:
La Feria de Turismo ITB de #Berl√≠n 2021, que est√° dirigida a profesionales de la industria y p√∫blico general, otorg√≥ a #Futaleuf√∫ el primer lugar con el reconocimiento ‚ÄúEarth Award‚Äù, por ser el destino que mejor ejemplifica a nivel mundial la resiliencia tur√≠stica y las buenas pr√°cticas sostenibles, llevadas a cabo por sus m√°s de 2 mil habitantes.

La ITB Berl√≠n es la plataforma de negocios m√°s importante para la oferta tur√≠stica global reuniendo en un solo lugar a los tomadores de decisiones de 180 pa√≠ses, de los 5 continentes, y a√±o a a√±o re√∫ne a m√°s de 100 mil personas.

Paulina Ros, directora de Sernatur #LosLagos, enfatiz√≥ que ‚Äúse est√° visibilizando el trabajo que realizan los empresarios tur√≠sticos, la comunidad en general y el departamento de turismo municipal de Futaleuf√∫ por ser cada d√≠a un destino m√°s sostenible y responsable‚Äù.

En este concurso Futaleuf√∫ fue la √∫nica comuna que represent√≥ al pa√≠s y compiti√≥ con destinos de #Brasil, #Filipinas y #Estonia, entre otros.

Fue premiado por sus buenas pr√°cticas en materia de medio ambiente, por sus acciones en relaci√≥n al cambio clim√°tico y cuidado del entorno natural. Espec√≠ficamente por el trabajo que comenz√≥ a gestarse en 2012 con el Plan de Minimizaci√≥n de Residuos S√≥lidos Domiciliarios, la construcci√≥n del Centro de Tratamiento Integral de Residuos en 2016, la Ordenanza de Manejos de Residuos Domiciliarios y las acciones que realiza toda la comunidad en forma diaria.

Natalia Baeza, coordinadora de la oficina de Turismo de Futaleuf√∫, explic√≥ que ‚Äúel primer lugar tiene que ver con el impulso que necesitamos como destino, sobre todo en estos tiempos de pandemia, para poder seguir mejorando para seguir avanzando, porque si bien es cierto que obtuvimos un primer lugar, ning√∫n destino es cien por ciento sostenible y hay cosas en las que hay que avanzar. Entonces no significa que ahora no vamos a hacer nada m√°s, sino que al contrario tenemos otro impulso m√°s para poder seguir creciendo‚Äù.

Description:
A UK startup is hoping to develop an ultra-quiet, bioelectric plane that will help in the fight against climate change. 

Faradair is working on a short-hop 18-seat plane that will use electric motors to power take-off and landing, the part of any flight with the highest noise and carbon emissions.

Once cruising, at a speed of about 230mph, the plane, known as the Beha,  will switch to its turbogenerator, powered by biofuel, which will also recharge the motors with assistance from solar panels, ready for the aircraft‚Äôs descent.

It will be the first aircraft produced since the 1920s to have a three-winged box design. It will be able to convert from passenger to cargo in just 15 minutes because of its palletised interior.

While the creators are hopeful the plane will be carbon neutral eventually, going all electric straight away was not going to be possible, and the Beha will go hybrid to begin with, using sustainable aviation fuels.

The hope is to have the Beha flying passengers by 2026, in which case, you‚Äôll have to keep your eyes peeled, as your ears won‚Äôt be of much use in locating this ultra-quiet plane.
ImageText: G A three-winged, ltra-quet hybrid electric plane may be taking off soon

Description:
Un proyecto financiado por el Fondo Verde para el Clima (GCF), organismo dependiente de la Convenci√≥n Marco de Naciones Unidas sobre #CambioClim√°tico y orientado a apoyar a los pa√≠ses en desarrollo a reducir las emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero, se est√° ejecutando en nuestro pa√≠s.

+Bosques es la iniciativa de gesti√≥n forestal sustentable m√°s grande de Latinoam√©rica y una de los m√°s grandes de la Organizaci√≥n de las #NacionesUnidas para la Alimentaci√≥n y la Agricultura (FAO) que se realiza en #Chile como reconocimiento a los logros del pa√≠s en la lucha contra el cambio clim√°tico y la gesti√≥n de sus recursos vegetacionales.

Este es uno de los proyectos de Pagos Basados en Resultados de la FAO en el mundo, es decir, de pagos monetarios por la reducci√≥n de emisiones generadas y verificadas logradas a trav√©s de la ejecuci√≥n de actividades REDD+.

Chile se adjudic√≥ este proyecto por haber demostrado la reducci√≥n de 6.136.473 toneladas promedio anuales de #CO2 equivalentes entre 2014-2016, mediante la reforestaci√≥n, restauraci√≥n y manejo sustentable de los recursos vegetacionales.

Desde agosto de 2020 y hasta 2026 se busca gestionar m√°s de 25 mil hect√°reas de bosque nativo en seis regiones del sur del pa√≠s,  entre las regiones de #ElMaule y #LosLagos.

Con un presupuesto de USD 63.607.552, en las regiones El Maule, √ëuble, Biob√≠o, La Araucan√≠a, Los R√≠os y Los Lagos se realizar√°n acciones de manejo sustentable, restauraci√≥n, revegetaci√≥n, forestaci√≥n y prevenci√≥n de incendios (25.000 ha) y para fortalecer la institucionalidad para la acci√≥n clim√°tica seg√∫n las metas establecidas en la Estrategia Nacional de Recursos Vegetacionales y Cambio Clim√°tico (ENCCRV).

Description:
The oil industry knew at least 50 years ago that air pollution from burning fossil fuels posed serious risks to human health, only to spend decades aggressively lobbying against clean air regulations, a trove of internal documents seen by the Guardian reveal.

The documents, which include internal memos and reports, show the industry was long aware that it created large amounts of air pollution, that pollutants could lodge deep in the lungs and be ‚Äúreal villains in health effects‚Äù, and even that its own workers may be experiencing birth defects among their children.

But these concerns did little to stop oil and gas companies, and their proxies, spreading doubt about the growing body of science linking the burning of fossil fuels to an array of health problems that kill millions of people around the world each year.

‚ÄúThe response from fossil-fuel interests has been from the same playbook ‚Äì first they know, then they scheme, then they deny and then they delay,‚Äù said Geoffrey Supran, a researcher at Harvard University who has studied the history of fossil-fuel companies and climate change. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôve fallen back on delay, subtle forms of propaganda and the undermining of regulation.‚Äù

Follow @guardian_us for more
ImageText: Exclusive Oil firms knew at least 50 years ago that fossil fuels posed grave health risks, files reveal

Description:
Luego de recorrer fiordos y canales de la #Patagonia chilena, el velero cient√≠fico Tara llegar√° este jueves 18 de marzo a #PuertoMontt, segunda escala de la expedici√≥n cient√≠fica "Tara Microbiomes" tras #PuntaArenas. Posteriormente har√° escalas en #Concepci√≥n, #Valpara√≠so e #Iquique.

La misi√≥n - una colaboraci√≥n entre la Fundaci√≥n Tara Oc√©an y Ceodos Chile - tiene por objetivo realizar un muestreo integral de la #costa chilena, desde la #Ant√°rtica hasta Iquique, con el fin de comprender de mejor manera el impacto del cambio clim√°tico, contribuyendo a la capacidad chilena de adaptarse a √©ste y mitigar sus efectos.

En el estudio interdisciplinario colaboran 9 centros de investigaci√≥n de excelencia de nuestro pa√≠s: Centro de Modelamiento Matem√°tico (CMM), Centro de Ciencia del Clima y la Resiliencia (CR2), Centro de Investigaci√≥n Din√°mica de Ecosistemas Marinos de Altas Latitudes (IDEAL), Centro de Investigaci√≥n en Ecosistemas de la Patagonia (CIEP), Centro de Investigaci√≥n Oceanogr√°fica (COPAS Sur-Austral), Centro de Regulaci√≥n del Genoma (CRG), Centro Interdisciplinario para la Investigaci√≥n Acu√≠cola (INCAR), el Laboratorio Internacional Asociado ‚ÄúEstrategias Adaptativas Multiescala‚Äù (LIA MAST), y el Instituto Franc√©s de Investigaci√≥n en Ciencias y Tecnolog√≠as Digitales (INRIA-Chile).

‚ÄúEsta misi√≥n est√° enfocada en estudiar a los microorganismos oce√°nicos, tales como bacterias, hongos y virus, as√≠ como algunos crust√°ceos, contaminantes emergentes como el micropl√°stico, agentes pat√≥genos, metales en el oc√©ano y el comportamiento de gases de efecto invernadero, entre muchas otras cosas. Se trata de una iniciativa a largo plazo que busca monitorear el oc√©ano chileno cada cinco a√±os y as√≠ seguir su transici√≥n hacia la nueva normalidad que trae el cambio global‚Äù, explica Camila Fern√°ndez, profesora visitante del Departamento de Oceanograf√≠a de la Universidad de Concepci√≥n, investigadora del CNRS y de los centros INCAR, IDEAL y COPAS SUR AUSTRAL, y co-coordinadora de la misi√≥n en #Chile.

Description:
On the Outer Banks in North Carolina, the tiny town of Avon is struggling with the rising sea, and who should pay to protect the community from the onslaught.
 
Property owners in Avon are confronting a tax increase of almost 50% to protect their homes, the only road into town and, perhaps, the community‚Äôs existence. The risk to the town from climate change is particularly dire ‚Äî it is on a mere sandbar of an island chain, in a relentlessly rising Atlantic. But people in the town are facing a question that is echoing along the American coastline as seas rise and storms intensify. What price can be put on saving a town, a neighborhood, a home where generations have built their lives?
 
Communities large and small are reaching for different answers. Officials in Miami, Tampa, Houston, San Francisco and elsewhere have borrowed money, raised taxes or increased water bills to help pay for efforts to shield their homes, schools and roads. Along the Outer Banks ‚Äî where tourist-friendly beaches are shrinking by more than 14 feet a year in some places ‚Äî other towns have imposed tax increases similar to the one Avon is considering.
 
County officials are turning to beach nourishment: dredging sand from the ocean floor a few miles off the coast and then pushing it to shore through a pipeline and layering it on the beach. The county wants to put about one million cubic yards of sand on the beach ‚Äî a project that would cost $11 million to $14 million and would need to be repeated about every five years. The high cost and impermanence have led some in Avon to question whether beach nourishment is worth the money.
 
They point to Buxton, the next town south of Avon, whose beach got new sand in 2018, paid for through higher taxes. Now, most of that sand has washed away, leaving a beachfront motel and vacation rentals teetering over the water. ‚ÄúEvery bit of it‚Äôs gone,‚Äù said Michael David, who grew up in Avon and owns a garage in Buxton. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just masking a problem that never gets fixed.‚Äù Tap the link in our bio to read more about the climate struggle faced by coastal cities. Photos and video by @erinschaff.

Description:
Deutschland hat seine Klimaziele im Jahr 2020 eingehalten. Das geht aus der Klimabilanz hervor, die Bundesumweltministerin Svenja Schulze gemeinsam mit dem Umweltbundesamt in Berlin vorgestellt hat. Allerdings: Etwa ein Drittel der Einsparungen laÃàsst sich auf die Corona-Krise zuruÃàckfuÃàhren. Demnach lagen die CO2-Emissionen im vergangenen Jahr um 40,8 Prozent unter dem Stand von 1990 und um 8,7 Prozent unter dem Stand von 2019. 
.
Schulze fuÃàhrte aus, dass fast alle Sektoren die Vorgaben aus dem Klimaschutzgesetz einhalten konnten. Am deutlichsten sei der Fortschritt bei der Energiewirtschaft. Nach EinschaÃàtzung der SPD-Politikerin zeigen sich hier vor allem die Folgen des Kohleausstiegs. Im Verkehrsbereich mache sich dagegen vor allem die Corona-Pandemie bemerkbar. Hier gehe es darum, die erreichten Fortschritte in Nach-Corona-Zeiten zu retten. Im GebaÃàudesektor wurden etwas mehr Emissionen verzeichnet, als nach dem Klimaschutzgesetz eigentlich erlaubt ist. Deshalb greift eine Sonderregel: Nachdem ein unabhaÃàngiger Expertenrat die Defizite in diesem Bereich bestaÃàtigt hat, muss das Bundesbauministerium ein Sofortprogramm erarbeiten, um schnelle Einsparungen zu erreichen.
.
Laut Umweltbundesamt laÃàsst sich rund ein Drittel der Minderung auf die Folgen der Corona-Pandemie zuruÃàckfuÃàhren. Der PraÃàsident des Umweltbundesamtes Messner sagte nun, ohne die Folgen der Corona-Krise waÃàre das Klimaziel 2020 insgesamt wohl knapp verfehlt worden. Gerade im Bereich Verkehr sieht er CO2-Einsparungen durch die Krise sowie nun gro√üen Handlungsdruck. Denn sobald der Verkehr nach dem Lockdown wieder an Fahrt aufnimmt, duÃàrfte das Klimaziel des Verkehrssektors fuÃàr 2022 in weite Ferne ruÃàcken.
.
Die so genannte ‚ÄûKlima-Allianz Deutschland‚Äú, die aus Dutzenden namhaften Klima- und SozialverbaÃànden besteht, kritisiert die Bundesregierung trotz des erreichten Klimaziels. Die GeschaÃàftsfuÃàhrerin des BuÃàndnisses, Christiane Averbeck, sagte, der RuÃàckgang der Emissionen sei ein Einmaleffekt der Corona-Krise. 
.
Den kompletten Beitrag finden Sie uÃàber den Link in der Bio,
.

Description:
For more stories like this follow @EmergencyC4‚Å†
‚Å†
The worst air pollution in any city last year was in Gotan in northwest China, according to a new global analysis of air quality. But rather than the typical culprits of transport and industry, the poor air quality was partly caused by sandstorms made worse by the climate crisis.‚Å†
‚Å†
Sandstorms are an increasing issue for cities in China, as the climate crisis dries and degrades land around them, the IQAir's 2020 World Air Quality Report said. In the picture above, the Beijing skies turned a glowing red after a sandstorm clouded visibility earlier this week.‚Å†
‚Å†
The gasses and pollutants which harm our health are often separate from those which cause global heating through the greenhouse effect. Although in the cases of transport and industry, they often come from the same sources.‚Å†
‚Å†
But the 2020 analysis highlights how the crises of pollution and the climate are inextricably linked. Head of IQAir Frank Hammes said: "While many cities recorded temporary improvements in air quality due to lockdowns, the health impact of burning fossil fuels remained severe."‚Å†
‚Å†
The coronavirus pandemic did lead to a temporary improvement in air quality last year, the report said, as 84 per cent of monitored sites improved on 2019. "In 2021, we will likely see an increase in air pollution due to human activity, again," added Hammes.‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
The largest and strongest dust storm in a decade swept across northern China on Monday, grounding hundreds of flights, closing schools in some cities and casting a ghastly shroud over tens of millions of people ‚Äî from Xinjiang in the far west across to the Bohai Sea, according to China‚Äôs meteorological service.

The storm, coming after weeks of smog, recalled the ‚Äúairpocalypses‚Äù that the country routinely experienced a few years ago, spurring crash government efforts to address what had become a political and public health crisis. Those efforts improved the air quality significantly, especially in Beijing. But this week, three forces ‚Äî the post-Covid industrial rebound, the continued impact of climate change on the deserts of northern China, and a late winter storm ‚Äî combined to create a dangerous, suffocating pall.

‚ÄúBeijing is what an ecological crisis looks like,‚Äù Li Shuo, the policy director for Greenpeace China, wrote on Twitter.

In Beijing, the authorities ordered children, the elderly and the sick to remain indoors, and told everyone else to avoid unnecessary activity outside. The pollution, which turned the air yellow-orange in the morning and a soupy gray by afternoon, was expected to last until Tuesday morning.

The dust was churned up by a snowy squall that moved through Mongolia over the weekend. The storm there toppled electrical towers, knocking out power in several regions, and killed at least nine people. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the dust storm sweeping across China. Photos by @gillessabrie.

Description:
Acercarse a las riquezas de las cuencas del r√≠o #Maipo, pero tambi√©n exponer las amenazas y da√±os causados en esta zona ubicada a solo 40 minutos de Santiago son parte de los objetivos de la nueva investigaci√≥n ‚ÄúHumanidad en las cuencas - Usos y abusos: R√≠o Maipo‚Äù, desarrollada por la ONG #Ecosistemas.

‚ÄúCasi el 50% de las especies categorizadas de los reinos animal y vegetal, y un 10% del reino fungi se encuentran amenazadas‚Äù, se√±ala un extracto del documento que evidencia el avanzado estado de deterioro y la urgencia de proteger y restaurar esta cuenca estrat√©gica para casi 8 millones de personas en la #Regi√≥nMetropolitana.

En 10 cap√≠tulos, la investigaci√≥n aborda la situaci√≥n poblacional, bioecol√≥gica y usos y abusos en el #territorio, poniendo √©nfasis en la utilizaci√≥n de las aguas para actividades industriales como riego, saneamiento, generaci√≥n el√©ctrica, entre otros.

En el documento, la ONG enfatiza la necesidad de protecci√≥n y restauraci√≥n de la cuenca para revertir la degradaci√≥n y genere sustentabilidad social y ecol√≥gica.

‚ÄúHacer este recorrido de cordillera a mar, por la cuenca del r√≠o Maipo es una traves√≠a dolorosa, pero conocerla en mayor profundidad, y evidenciar su historia socioambiental, sus valores y atributos, abre la posibilidad de un cambio de rumbo, de encontrar soluciones a los problemas, de recuperar lo perdido y restaurar, antes de que sea a√∫n m√°s tarde y dif√≠cil, dados los cambios macro que est√°n ocurriendo, tales como la megasequ√≠a producto de la hist√≥rica deforestaci√≥n y el cambio clim√°tico provocados por la humanidad‚Äù, explica Juan Pablo Orrego, presidente de Ecosistemas y quien estuvo a cargo de la coordinaci√≥n de la investigaci√≥n.

Description:
The Senate voted on Wednesday to confirm President Joe Biden's pick to lead the Environmental Protection Agency, making the state regulator the first Black man to be administrator of the agency. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Michael Regan, 44, was confirmed with a bipartisan vote of 66-34, with sixteen Republicans joining all Democrats in voting to confirm him.‚Å†
‚Å†
The North Carolinian will lead the agency in an administration that has promised to aggressively fight against climate change and environmental injustice. ‚Å†
‚Å†
He worked at the EPA from 2001-08 in the Office of Air Quality Planning and Standards. He joined the Environmental Defense Fund in 2008 and left in 2015 to found M. Regan and Associates, a consulting firm on environmental issues. In 2017, he became cabinet secretary for North Carolina‚Äôs Department of Environmental Quality.
ImageText: ‚Äé1 person, ‚Äé'‚Äé◊ê Michael Regan confirmed to lead the Environmental Protection Agency, the first Black man to run the department USA TODAY‚Äé'‚Äé‚Äé

Description: The Senate voted Wednesday to confirm Michael Regan to lead the Environmental Protection Agency, where he has pledged to prioritize climate change after the Trump administration worsened the crisis. Regan has also said he will fight for environmental justice, reducing pollution‚Äôs disproportionate impact on people of color and communities living in poverty. ‚ÄúWe will move with a sense of urgency on climate change. We will stand up for environmental justice and equity," Regan said. Click our link in bio for more. (üì∏: Caroline Brehman / CQ-Roll Call, Inc via Getty Images)
ImageText: US NEWS Michael Regan Will Be The First Black Man To Lead The EPA BuzzFeed .News

Rep. Katie Porter (D-Calif.) didn‚Äôt need a whiteboard to deliver one of her textbook takedowns Tuesday when an oil company executive argued that his industry doesn‚Äôt get any special tax breaks.‚Å†
‚Å†
Following her recent appointment as chair of the House Natural Resources subcommittee on oversight, Porter was one of several Democrats to introduce legislation last week that would raise royalty rates on oil and gas companies for the first time in over a century.‚Å†
‚Å†
Mark Murphy, president of Strata Production Co., argued in a subcommittee video hearing Tuesday, ‚ÄúThere seems to be a misconception out there that you‚Äôre operating from that somehow the oil and gas industry have benefits from some special sort of tax structure. We don‚Äôt.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúYou do benefit from special rules,‚Äù Porter said, after interrupting him. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a special tax rule for intangible drilling costs that does not apply to other kinds of expenses that businesses have. You get to deduct 70% of your costs immediately, and other businesses have to amortize their expenses over their entire profit stream. So please don‚Äôt patronize me by telling me that the oil and gas industry doesn‚Äôt have any special tax provisions. Because if you would like that to be the rule, I would be happy to have Congress deliver.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Porter serves also on the Energy and Mineral Resources and the Public Lands and National Parks subcommittees. She‚Äôs working in those roles to advance policies that address the climate crisis, get fair value for taxpayers on the development of natural resources and hold polluters accountable, according to a statement about her appointment.‚Å†
‚Å†
Porter has become a social media star for her persistent, well-informed takedowns of big business executives, which she often carries out with her now-famous whiteboard as a visual aid. Her speech Tuesday gathered steam online as fans and constituents praised her latest work.‚Å†
‚Å†
See the moment at our link in bio. // üìù @josieharvey // üì∑ Getty Images

Der Linguist Noam Chomsky, mittlerweile 92 Jahre alt, wird nicht m√ºde, Vortr√§ge zu halten, Interviews zu geben und B√ºcher zu schreiben. Sein j√ºngstes Werk tr√§gt den programmatischen Titel: Rebellion oder Untergang!

An zahlreichen Beispielen belegt Noam Chomsky die drohende Gefahr des Untergangs nahezu aller Lebensformen auf diesem Planeten, die Menschen eingeschlossen. Es sei allein schlichten Zuf√§llen oder dem Z√∂gern einzelner Milit√§rs zu verdanken, dass die Welt vor einem vernichtenden Atomkrieg zwischen den USA und der Sowjetunion bewahrt wurde.

Description:
Follow @emergencyc4 for more news about the climate crisis

The number of heritage sites under the highest levels of threat from climate change in England, Wales and Northern Ireland could more than triple over the next 40 years, according to a new interactive map released by the National Trust. ¬†

The tool draws together data from several sources to illustrate how threats from flooding, landslides, coastal erosion and extreme heat and humidity could increase by 2060 if no action is taken to curb greenhouse gas emissions.

The map is split up into 5km hexagonal grids which plot the threat level from 1-5, with 5 (shown in red) representing the highest level of threat.

The charity says the effects of climate change are already noticeable on its sites, from blistering on paintings in its collections to bursting riverbanks and coastal erosion.

The National Trust af the map will help them fight the effects of climate change by helping them tailor interventions to specific sites. These could include tree planting to slow water run-off and provide shade from extreme heat, or restoring peat bogs to hold back water.

#nationaltrust #heritagesites #climate #climatechange #climatecrisis #climateemergency #globalheating #globalwarming #greenhousegasses #carbon

Seg√∫n un √çndice Global de Desperdicio de Alimentos publicado este jueves, en 2019 se generaron unos 931 millones de toneladas de residuos alimentarios en todo el mundo. El informe, publicado por el Programa de las Naciones Unidas para el Medio Ambiente (PNUMA) y la organizaci√≥n ben√©fica brit√°nica WRAP, equivale al 17% de todos los alimentos disponibles para los consumidores.

Con un 61%, la mayor√≠a de los desperdicios se gener√≥ en los hogares. Los sectores del comercio minorista y los servicios de alimentaci√≥n obtuvieron mejores resultados, generando un 13% y un 26% respectivamente. 

El √≠ndice no tiene en cuenta la p√©rdida de alimentos, que difiere del desperdicio en que se produce durante la producci√≥n, el almacenamiento o la transformaci√≥n del producto, que nunca llega al consumidor.

"Si queremos tomarnos en serio la lucha contra el cambio clim√°tico, la p√©rdida de naturaleza y biodiversidad y la contaminaci√≥n y los residuos, las empresas, los gobiernos y los ciudadanos de todo el mundo tienen que hacer su parte para reducir el desperdicio de alimentos", dijo el director ejecutivo del PNUMA, Inger Anderson, en un comunicado de prensa.

Description:
A northern portion of the Gulf Stream and the deep ocean currents it‚Äôs connected to may be slowing, which could lead to global consequences, according to a recent spate of studies.

Almost everywhere around the world, average temperatures are rising‚Äî except southeast of Greenland where a large patch of the North Atlantic has become colder in recent years. This may signal that the northern arm of the Gulf Stream no longer arrives with the same strength to the North Atlantic, that a warming atmosphere, paradoxically, cooled one part of the world.

Consequences could include faster sea level rise along parts of the Eastern United States and parts of Europe, stronger hurricanes barreling into the Southeastern United States, and perhaps most ominously, reduced rainfall across the Sahel, a semi-arid swath of land running the width of Africa that is already a geopolitical tinderbox.

The Gulf Stream is one of the mightiest rivers you will never see, carrying some 30 times more water than all of the world‚Äôs freshwater rivers combined. In the North Atlantic, one arm of the Gulf Stream breaks toward Iceland, transporting vast amounts of warmth far northward. It is but one tentacle of a larger, ocean-spanning tangle of currents called the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation, or AMOC. Without this current ‚Äî a heat pump on a planetary scale ‚Äî scientists believe that great swaths of the world might look quite different.

The science remains relatively new, and not everyone agrees the AMOC is actually slowing. But in both scientific modeling of climate change and in the prehistoric record, a North Atlantic cooling presages a shutdown of the current, which can trigger rapid changes in temperatures and precipitation patterns around the North Atlantic and beyond.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about how climate change is affecting the Gulf Stream.

Video by Jeremy White/The New York Times
ImageText: Scientists Fear the Warming Atmosphere is Causing The Gulf Stream To Weaken Ge.

Description:
Klingt wie ein Scherz, ist aber ein offizieller Fraktions-Antrag im Rathaus: Die Freibeuter fordern, in der Hundesteuer den von den Tieren verursachten CO2-Aussto√ü mit einzupreisen.
Das Rathaus in seiner Stellungnahme dazu: Man werde ‚Äûalle kommunalen Abgaben und Steuern im Hinblick auf ihre Auswirkungen auf das Klima analysieren.‚Äù Dabei wird berechnet, um wie viel teurer die Hundesteuer w√ºrde, wenn man das vom #Hund verursachte #CO2 mit berechnet. Anschlie√üend will das Finanzdezernat Vorschl√§ge bringen, welcher Erh√∂hungen denkbar w√§ren.

Hintergrund des Freibeuter-Begehrens ist eine Studie des Instituts f√ºr Umwelttechnologie der TU Berlin. Demnach verursacht ein durchschnittlicher Haushund in seinem Leben 8,2 Tonnen CO2, also 630 kg pro Jahr. Das sind 40‚ÄÖ% der Emmissionen eines Benzin-Pkw (5 Liter Verbrauch, 11‚ÄÖ800 km Laufleistung).
Bei aktuell ca. 23‚ÄÖ000 gemeldeten Hunden in Leipzig kommt ordentlich was zusammen. Zumal sich die Stadt verpflichtet hat, die CO2-Emissionen aller f√ºnf Jahre um 10 % zu senken ...

Das Finanzdezernat gab aber zu bedenken, dass die Steuer (96 Euro/Jahr) nicht unermesslich steigen darf. Sonst w√ºrden Hunde abgeschafft, was zu sinkenden Einnahmen (derzeit 2 Mio. Euro j√§hrlich) f√ºhren w√ºrde.

Description:
Follow @EmergencyC4 for more stories like this‚Å†
‚Å†
The world needs to cut its annual carbon emissions at rates similar to those brought by the unprecedented national lockdowns in 2020, new research suggests.‚Å†
‚Å†
The pandemic response which put a temporary hold on most travel and industrial activity led to a global 7% in 2020 carbon dioxide levels compared to 2019 levels, the research published today in Nature Climate Change revealed.‚Å†
‚Å†
The 7% drop amounted to 2.6 gigatonnes of CO2 globally. The researchers said that world needs to cut its emissions by 1-2 gigatonnes each year throughout the 2020s to limit global heating to 1.5C or 2C - both headline targets of the Paris climate agreement.‚Å†
‚Å†
In response to the findings Dr Robin Lamboll from the Grantham Institute, who wasn't an author on the study, said: ‚ÄúA drop in emissions for one or two years doesn‚Äôt really have a long-term effect on climate change. The question for the future is to what extent the emissions reduction indicates a change of culture, and to what extent government assistance is going towards growing a greener economy rather than rebooting fossil fuels.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
Follow @emergencyc4 ‚Å†
‚Å†
The number of larger bodied moths has dropped by a third in the UK over the last 50 years, indicating a much broader decline in biodiversity across the country which has concerned researchers.‚Å†
‚Å†
A report released today by the Butterfly Conservation Charity found there was a greater decline in larger moth numbers in the south of the UK, which saw a 39 per cent decrease compared to a drop of 22 per cent in the north. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The dramatic decline is linked to a range of detrimental human activity, including habitat destruction, climate change and light pollution. ‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúThis decline is worrying because moths play a vital role in our ecosystems," said Dr Richard Fox, the lead author of the report.‚Å†
‚Å†
"Because moths are dwindling, we can be pretty sure that other wildlife are also in decline and that our wider environment is deteriorating.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
The charity is calling for the "expansion, restoration and creation of habitats that support wildlife" to improve the abundance and species richness of months.‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
Here, a section of the Pacific Coast Highway is seen from above after it collapsed into the Pacific Ocean near Big Sur, Calif. on Jan. 31, 2021.‚Å†
‚Å†
Frequent damage has long plagued the PCH. Most recently, in January, yet another chunk fell into the ocean following intense rainstorms, which created a debris flow that overwhelmed water drains more than 100 miles south of San Francisco.‚Å†
‚Å†
This time, a 150-foot piece of road broke off, the state Department of Transportation said.‚Å†
‚Å†
As global temperatures warm because of human-caused climate change, University of California-Santa Cruz professor Gary Griggs says the conditions that lead to this kind of damage will only increase. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The PCH's days are numbered, Griggs said. It's "inevitable‚Äù one day the fixes and repairs won't be enough or will be too costly to save the highway.‚Å†
‚Å†
Repairs for the recent damage are scheduled to be complete in early summer. For now, travelers must turn around when they reach the gaping hole ‚Äì there's no bypass in that remote stretch of road.‚Å†
‚Å†
Tap our link in bio to read more about how climate change is affecting one of the most scenic highways in America. ‚Å†

El pasado 19 de septiembre cruzaron el R√≠o Bravo las primeras mariposas monarca en su viaje migratorio de m√°s de 5.000 kil√≥metros desde Canad√° hasta los bosques de Michoac√°n, en M√©xico, donde se protegen del invierno colgadas de los √°rboles en enormes racimos. La fecha ha llamado la atenci√≥n de las autoridades ambientales mexicanas, porque representa un adelanto en la temporada tradicional de migraci√≥n, que es en octubre. Pero lo que m√°s les ha desconcertado es una disminuci√≥n en el n√∫mero de hect√°reas de bosque que este a√±o ocupan las mariposas, una de las m√°s bajas registrada desde 2018. Los ambientalistas ponen sus ojos en las temperaturas extremas generadas por La Ni√±a ‚Äîun fen√≥meno en el que desciende la temperatura global y que est√° cada vez m√°s agudizado por el cambio clim√°tico‚Äî y la deforestaci√≥n registrada en la reserva que es el santuario de la mariposa para explicar este cambio de comportamiento, que aumenta los temores sobre su preservaci√≥n. Si esta tendencia contin√∫a, las autoridades temen que se llegue a la situaci√≥n de 2014, cuando las colonias de mariposas disminuyeron en un 95%. El santuario de la monarca, que es compartido entre los Estados de Michoac√°n y de M√©xico, est√° amenazado por el auge del cultivo del aguacate, fruto que tiene una gran demanda en Estados Unidos y del que Michoac√°n es el primer productor mundial.

Description:
Los #osospolares (Ursus maritimus) son #animales magn√≠ficos, reconocidos mundialmente por su caracter√≠stico pelaje, su gran tama√±o y por ser considerados los reyes del #√Årtico.

Esta fascinante especie, clasificada dentro de los mam√≠feros marinos, es un √≠cono del polo norte y son esenciales para mantener el equilibrio de la #biodiversidad de su #ecosistema.

En la actualidad, los #osos polares enfrentan un grave peligro que pone en riesgo sus vidas: el #cambioclim√°tico, fen√≥meno que afecta directamente a su hogar y forma de vida. Al depender en gran medida del hielo marino del √Årtico para cazar #focas, estos osos tienen que esperar cada vez m√°s tiempo sin alimentarse, pues √©ste se est√° derritiendo antes en la #primavera y se forma de manera m√°s tard√≠a en el #oto√±o.

Con el paso de los a√±os, esta situaci√≥n se ha vuelto cr√≠tica, pues la dificultad para conseguir comida es cada vez mayor ya que implica un gasto de energ√≠a muy elevado para soportar el ayuno prolongado por el que deben pasar.

El cambio clim√°tico tambi√©n est√° provocando una mayor fragmentaci√≥n de su #h√°bitat, y a medida que el hielo del √Årtico se derrite se evidencia un aumento del transporte mar√≠timo, asociado, por ejemplo, a la explotaci√≥n de #petr√≥leo y #gas.

A lo largo de las d√©cadas, la relevancia de estos superdepredadores ha crecido exponencialmente, volvi√©ndose un √≠cono de la batalla contra el cambio clim√°tico. En Rusia y Alaska, WWF enfrenta este desaf√≠o apoyando los esfuerzos locales para proteger a las personas y a los osos polares.

Description: Ya s√© c√≥mo saldremos al final de esto. Saldremos mareados. La pandemia es una monta√±a rusa. Un mont√≥n de gente jugando a la ruleta rusa en los vagones de una monta√±a rusa salvaje. La ruleta rusa es la superpoblaci√≥n. Somos m√°s de siete mil millones de balas en un solo cargador. A este juego tambi√©n se le llama el cambio clim√°tico. Somos siete mil setecientos millones de personas comiendo ensaladilla rusa a bordo de una monta√±a rusa. Como le siente mal a unos cuantos, la que se puede liar. La luz al final del t√∫nel nos revela que la monta√±a rusa es el tren de la bruja. Pero aqu√≠, en vez de escobazos dan vacunas. Ya falta menos para salir. Esta impaciencia por llegar al final, la curiosidad de ver c√≥mo ser√° la salida, si poco a poco, o todos a la vez. Quiz√° se parezca a cuando termina la guerra en el cine, y la gente se abraza en las trincheras y baila en la calle y grita de alegr√≠a. Me acabo de acordar de una foto, sal√≠a en Historia 16, de la proclamaci√≥n de la Segunda Rep√∫blica espa√±ola. Se ve√≠a una manifestaci√≥n en la calle de hombres y mujeres muy contentos, y un se√±or tocaba el acorde√≥n andando. Una vez, me compr√© una concertina porque quer√≠a ser aquel hombre de la foto. La tienda donde la compr√© estaba en las Ramblas y ya no existe. En Barcelona no queda nada que no forme parte del parque de atracciones. Pero ahora se les llama parques tem√°ticos. A medida que se ha impuesto el tema, se ha perdido la atracci√≥n. Por las noches, arden las calles en el centro de Barcelona. En otras ciudades de Europa, los disturbios se producen en la periferia. Son rabias diferentes, mitolog√≠as distintas. Ni siquiera hay lo mismo en los contenedores. Lo que brilla al final del t√∫nel es el temblor de un fuego. Da miedo. Para que se acabe la monta√±a rusa, hay que salir del parque.

Description:
The U.S. military's reach is vast and empire-like.‚Å†
‚Å†
For decades, the U.S. has enjoyed global military dominance, an achievement that has underpinned its influence, national security and efforts at promoting democracy.‚Å†
‚Å†
Yet today, amid a sea change in security threats, America's military might overseas may be less relevant than it once was, say some security analysts, defense officials and former and active U.S. military service members. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The most urgent threats to the U.S., they say, are increasingly nonmilitary in nature. Among them: cyberattacks; disinformation; China's economic dominance; climate change; and disease outbreaks such as COVID-19, which ravaged the U.S. economy like no event since the Great Depression.‚Å†
‚Å†
To read more on the U.S. military empire and whether or not the country still needs it, click the link in our bio.

Description:
Follow @EmergencyC4 for more stories like this‚Å†
‚Å†
The UN has said the world is "very far" from its goal to limit global heating to 1.5¬∞C.‚Å†
‚Å†
In a stark warning, head of UN Climate Change Patricia Espinosa said: "At the moment it is like we are walking into a minefield blindfolded. What we need is much more radical and transformative than we have now. We need concrete plans to phase out fossil fuels as fast as possible."‚Å†
‚Å†
Under the Paris climate agreement, countries are supposed to give updated pledges on national emissions reductions every five years. The first targets were set in 2015, with more ambitious updates due by the end of 2020.‚Å†
‚Å†
Today's interim report from the UN takes stock of those updated pledges. Together they would only account for a global cut in emissions of less than 1 per cent by 2030 compared to 2010 levels. By contrast, the UN's science advisory body says around a 45 per cent cut by 2030 is needed to keep within the 1.5¬∞C heating limit, or around 25 per cent for 2¬∞C.‚Å†
‚Å†
While the UK is one of a few countries to have submitted a more ambitious updated pledge in recent months, corralling other countries to do the same is one of its key tasks as president of the COP climate conference being held in Glasgow later this year.‚Å†
‚Å†
All eyes are on the world's largest two emitters, China and the US, as they submit their updated 2030 pledges in the coming months.‚Å†
‚Å†
#emergencyc4 #channel4news #news #currentaffairs #international #climate #climatechange #climatecrisis #climateemergency #globalheating #globalwarming #greenhousegasses #carbon #emissions #fossilfuels #co2 #netzero #politics #science #climatescience #sustainability #nature #environment
ImageText: The world needs to cut emissions by 45% by 2030. Right now, t's on 1%. "Current levels of climate ambition are very far from putting US on a pathway that will meet our Paris Agreement goals." Patricia Espinosa, Executive Secretary of UN Climate Change @emergency

Description:
Jennifer Granholm used her first statement as the newly-dubbed secretary of the Department of Energy to call out climate change ‚Äî and the social and economic impact it has on the U.S.‚Å†
‚Å†
"Climate change is intensifying and ravaging our communities.," Granholm said in a video statement. "...We have the tools to put America on an irreversible path to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050...We're going to make sure that every worker and every community can benefit from and see their future in these clean energy solutions."

Description:
The U.S. has enjoyed global military dominance for decades. But in the face of emerging threats, some say a new strategy is in order.‚Å†
‚Å†
The most urgent threats to the U.S., they say, are increasingly nonmilitary in nature. Among them: cyberattacks; disinformation; China's economic dominance; climate change; and disease outbreaks such as COVID-19, which ravaged the U.S. economy like no event since the Great Depression.‚Å†
‚Å†
Trita Parsi, co-founder of the Quincy Institute for Responsible Statecraft, a Washington-based think tank that lobbies for U.S. military restraint overseas, said maintaining a large fighting force thousands of miles from U.S. shores is expensive, unwieldy and anachronistic.‚Å†
‚Å†
"It was designed for a world that still faced another military hegemon," Parsi said.
ImageText: ‡¶ï. JUMLIE Now, pandemics, climate chaos, artificial intelligence and 5G are far more important for American national security than having 15 bases in the Indian Ocean. Trita Parsi Quincy Institute for Responsible Statecraft USA TODAY

Description: En noviembre del 2019 el artista visual Patrick Hamilton inaugur√≥ en la Galer√≠a Patricia Ready la muestra ‚ÄúEl ladrillo‚Äù, un trabajo que alud√≠a al texto hom√≥nimo que se transform√≥ en la base del experimento neoliberal en Chile. Description:
Con una tuber√≠a pl√°stica y la manguera de una secadora, el estudiante Jonathan Walker, de un instituto de Panama City, en el noroeste de Florida, invent√≥ un filtro para los tubos de escape de veh√≠culos que convierte en ox√≠geno las contaminantes emisiones de di√≥xido de carbono.

El alumno, que fue reconocido por la Agencia de Protecci√≥n Medioambiental (EPA, en ingl√©s) de Estados Unidos y la Asociaci√≥n de Ciencias e Ingenier√≠a de la Universidad de Yale, logr√≥ una gran reducci√≥n de los contaminantes en las primera treinta pruebas que hizo con el dispositivo.

Detall√≥ al diario News Herald de Panama City que la concentraci√≥n promedio de di√≥xido de carbono cay√≥ del 14,6 % al 3 % con el uso del dispositivo.

Por otro lado, sin el filtro hab√≠a un promedio de 0,49 % de ox√≠geno, que subi√≥ hasta 12,65 %.

Preocupado por el cambio clim√°tico, el joven se√±al√≥ al diario que buscaba crear alg√∫n elemento que no solo mitigara las emisiones, sino que las purificara para liberar algo a√∫n mejor.

Los veh√≠culos son uno de los mayores contribuyentes de gases de efecto invernadero del planeta, lo cual se ha constatado en esta pandemia del COVID-19, con la reducci√≥n global, en el primer semestre de 2020, de un promedio del 8 % de emisiones de estos contaminantes debido a las cuarentenas con respecto al a√±o anterior.

Walker, estudiante de la secundaria Rutherford, se√±al√≥ al peri√≥dico que espera tramitar pronto la patente del invento, que considera de gran viabilidad.

El joven inventor us√≥ para el filtro tubos de PVC (policloruro de vinilo), de goma (para almacenar las emisiones de carbono) y una manguera de ventilaci√≥n de una secadora. Tambi√©n utiliz√≥ calcio, carb√≥n activado y luces LED, entre otros elementos, para la transformaci√≥n del contaminante en ox√≠geno.

El estudiante explic√≥ que el "concepto" ya est√° probado y que ahora la idea es reducir el tama√±o del dispositivo.

El alumno, que fue reconocido por la Agencia de Protecci√≥n Medioambiental (EPA, en ingl√©s) de Estados Unidos y la Asociaci√≥n de Ciencias e Ingenier√≠a de la Universidad de Yale, logr√≥ una gran reducci√≥n de los contaminantes en las primera treinta pruebas que hizo con el dispositivo.

Walker, estudiante de la secundaria Rutherford, se√±al√≥ al peri√≥dico que espera tramitar pronto la patente del invento, que considera de gran viabilidad.

A few days after President Biden won the presidential election, a San Diego company quietly asked federal officials for permission to send 5 million tons of #naturalgas each year across the Mexico border.¬†

The #Biden administration‚Äôs decision on the gas export project may offer a preview of how aggressively it will confront the #climatecrisis.¬†

Biden campaigned on a promise to put the entire economy on a path to net zero carbon emissions by 2050. But there are early indications his administration might look kindly on American companies eager to ship natural gas overseas.¬†

Description:
A pesar de la crisis del #Covid19, a nivel mundial la preocupaci√≥n sobre el #cambioclim√°tico no ha disminuido; por el contrario, en algunos pa√≠ses la percepci√≥n que tienen las personas sobre el impacto de sus actos en el #medioambiente incluso ha aumentado. As√≠ lo revela el estudio respecto al cambio clim√°tico elaborado por segundo a√±o consecutivo por #EDF e #IPSOS que recoge la visi√≥n de m√°s de 24 mil personas en 30 pa√≠ses.

En #Chile, el 72 % de los encuestados se√±ala que el #coronavirus los hizo ser m√°s conscientes respecto del impacto de sus acciones sobre el medioambiente, superando ampliamente el promedio mundial (60 %). A su vez, 71 % cree que existe un v√≠nculo entre la pandemia y los efectos negativos de la actividad humana en la naturaleza y su entorno (frente al 62 % global).

Description:
Klimaklagen ‚Äì mit Hilfe der Gerichte wollen Umweltverb√§nde wie Greenpeace, Germanwatch oder die Deutsche Umwelthilfe eine aktivere Klimapolitik durchsetzen. Der Weg f√ºr eine erfolgreiche Klimaklage ist jedoch steinig, die Voraussetzungen daf√ºr, dass eine solche Klage zul√§ssig ist, sind hoch. 
.
Der Regensburger Rechtsprofessor Alexander Graser meint aber, dass solche strategischen Klagen in vielen F√§llen zu einer Bereicherung der politischen Debatte f√ºhren w√ºrden. Rechtskonflikte w√ºrden durch die √∂ffentliche Aufmerksamkeit in einem guten Sinne politisiert, sagt Graser.
.
Und auch f√ºr Caroline Schroeder von der Umweltorganisation Germanwatch gehen Klimaklagen √ºber die rein rechtliche Bedeutung weit hinaus:
‚ÄûEs ist ja nicht nur dieses rechtliche Verfahren mit der Anw√§ltin vor Gericht, mit den Schrifts√§tzen und so weiter, sondern es geht ja so ein bisschen darum, diese Geschichten zu erz√§hlen, von diesen Kl√§gern, aus ihrem Alltag: Inwieweit sind die betroffen? Was macht die Klimakrise eigentlich? Was hat das mit den Grundrechten zu tun?‚Äú
.
Den Beitrag finden Sie √ºber den Link in unserer Bio.
.
.
.

Description:
Pastor Aaron Trigg was at home when the creek near downtown Rainelle, W. Va., jumped its banks on the evening of June 23, 2016. "You could hear the water up in the mountains just crashing trees," Trigg remembers. ‚Å†‚Å†
‚Å†‚Å†
Trigg fielded calls from his displaced congregants for months after the flood. "A lot of people in Rainelle were poor, and they didn't have any insurance.‚Äù With no money to repair their homes, many took what they could salvage and left town for good.‚Å†‚Å†
‚Å†‚Å†
Rainelle is one of hundreds of small towns where climate-driven flooding potentially poses an existential threat. Sea level rise and heavier rainstorms driven by global warming are sending more water into residential neighborhoods from the Gulf Coast to New England to Appalachia to the Pacific Northwest. And new data make it clear that many households and communities cannot afford the mounting costs.‚Å†‚Å†
‚Å†‚Å†
To see how climate change could cause expensive flooding where you live, tap the link in our bio. (Images: @rjckseen/NPR)‚Å†‚Å†
‚Å†‚Å†
1. Pastor Aaron Trigg worked himself to exhaustion trying to help Rainelle recover after the destructive 2016 flood. ‚Å†‚Å†
‚Å†‚Å†
2.Rainelle, W. Va. is a small town in a steep valley. The city government saw a 10% decrease in water utility customers, a proxy for population loss.‚Å†‚Å†
‚Å†‚Å†
3. Before the flood, Trigg says, there were baseball games and kids playing on the playground near his house in Rainelle. After the flood, that changed. "Now, it was just silence," he remembers. "It affected the spirit of the town.‚Äù‚Å†‚Å†

Description:
Un lujo que una gran cantidad de personas poseen en la actualidad, es tener lavadora, sin embargo, para que los jabones hagan m√°s espuma y limpien m√°s r√°pido, se le suman a su composici√≥n tres elementos altamente contaminantes: fosfatos, nitraros y tensioactivos.

Las consecuencias las puedes ver f√°cilmente, ya que ambos compuestos son los responsables del tono verdoso del agua de los r√≠os, adem√°s, estimulan el crecimiento de algas, por lo que agotan el ox√≠geno del agua provocando la muerte de peces y otros organismos acu√°ticos.

Es ante esta realidad que dos mujeres chilenas decidieron hacer algo al respecto: Andrea Moraga y Carolina Urrutia, dos j√≥venes comprometidas con detener el cambio clim√°tico, quienes, en siete a√±os de trabajo, lograron reducir 10.000 kilos de pl√°stico y ahorrado 21 millones de litros de agua, lo cual equivale a 44.000 horas de riego. Adem√°s, Carolina fue elegida dos a√±os consecutivos (2018 y 2019), como una de las 100 mujeres l√≠deres de Chile.

Por esta raz√≥n es que, en un nuevo Mujeres Inolvidables, el especial semanal en donde destacamos las importantes haza√±as de mujeres de la historia y el presente, visibilizamos el impacto de ambas emprendedoras.

Description:
Rentiere auf duÃànnem Eis! ü¶å FuÃàr die Nomaden und ihre Rentiere in Sibirien aÃàndert sich durch den Klimawandel so einiges: Ihre alten Wanderrouten sind nicht mehr sicher, die UÃàberquerung des zugefrorenen Flusses wird zum unkalkulierbaren Risiko. 

"Erlebnis Erde" jetzt in der ARD-Mediathek ansehen! (Link siehe Bio)

Der Klimawandel hat die Nenzen und ihre Rentiere erreicht. Seit Jahrtausenden ziehen die Nomaden mit ihren Herden durch die Tundra im arktischen Sibirien. Das riesige Gebiet am russischen Polarkreis liegt wie im Fieber. Ureinwohner und Wildtiere spuÃàren die Folgen der ErwaÃàrmung. 

Wissenschaftler versuchen das Ausma√ü und die Konsequenzen der VeraÃànderungen zu erfassen. Riesige Krater, wie der Kessel von Batagai, oÃàffnen sich im tauenden Permafrostboden und legen Urzeitknochen sowie Urzeitgefahren durch Viren und Bakterien frei. WaldboÃàden trocknen aus wie Zunder und die Taiga geraÃàt in Flammen. Die Packeisfelder vor den KuÃàsten schmelzen und nehmen EisbaÃàren den Lebensraum. Hungrige BaÃàren dringen in menschliche Siedlungen vor oder wildern Kolonien der extrem seltenen ElfenbeinmoÃàwen. Doch es gibt nicht nur Verlierer. Mit dem Abschmelzen des Eises wird das groÃà√üte Land der Welt auch noch ein bisschen groÃà√üer.

"Rentiere auf duÃànnem Eis" zeigt in beeindruckenden und bedruÃàckenden Bildern bereits real existierende Auswirkungen, PhaÃànomene und unheilvolle Verkettungen der ErderwaÃàrmung.
