Description:
Primer d√≠a de trabajo. El presidente de Estados Unidos, Joe Biden, firma sus primeras √≥rdenes ejecutivas en el Despacho Oval de la Casa Blanca.

Los ritos, los s√≠mbolos, la coreograf√≠a. El arraigo de los estadounidenses por las tradiciones envolvi√≥ ayer la ceremonia de toma de posesi√≥n de Joe Biden como presidente de un aura de normalidad tan necesario como extraordinario. El escenario, las escalinatas del Capitolio asaltadas hace dos semanas por una turba de insurgentes, fue a la vez el recordatorio silencioso del dram√°tico contexto en que el dem√≥crata llega a la Casa Blanca.

Una Casa Blanca a la que lleg√≥ con la primera dama, Jill Biden, sus hijos y nietos tras caminar a pie los √∫ltimos metros hasta el complejo presidencial, protegido por un enorme per√≠metro de seguridad.

No hubo baile, pero s√≠ fuegos artificiales y trabajo, mucho trabajo. Esa misma noche, Biden, se sent√≥ ya en el despacho oval para firmar 17 √≥rdenes ejecutivas con las que deshacer algunas de las medidas m√°s pol√©micas de la administraci√≥n Trump, como la salida del Acuerdo de Par√≠s sobre cambio clim√°tico.

Lee la cr√≥nica de @beanavarro, corresponsal de La Vanguardia en Washington üì≤ https://bit.ly/3iweyFB üì∏ AFP / Reuters

Description: US President Joe Biden has begun to undo some of Donald Trump's key policies, hours after being sworn in. President Biden signed 17 executive orders, memorandums and proclamations aimed at boosting the federal response to the coronavirus crisis. Other moves will reverse the previous administration's stance on climate change, immigration and race relations. He rejoined the Paris climate agreement, stopped construction on the US-Mexico border wall, and cancelled the Keystone XL Pipeline. Tap the link in our bio for more about what President Biden intends to do in office. #POTUS #JoeBiden #OvalOffice #ClimateChange #BBCNews

The US abandoned the agreement late last year on then-President Donald Trump's orders. Experts say that rejoining the agreement is a significant step by the Biden administration to reverse the climate policies of the last four years. Tap the link in our bio to learn more.‚Å†

Description:
Hours after taking the oath of office, President Biden sat down for the first time in the Oval Office, moving to undo former President Trump‚Äôs legacy. 

Sitting at the Resolute Desk, the president signed 17 executive orders meant to target and dismantle policies that he said caused ‚Äúthe gravest damage‚Äù to the nation. These orders will sweep aside Trump‚Äôs pandemic response, reverse much of his environmental agenda, tear down his anti-immigration policies, bolster the sluggish economic recovery and restore federal efforts aimed at promoting diversity.

Biden recommitted the U.S. to the Paris climate agreement, the international accord designed to avert catastrophic global warming, and ordered federal agencies to start reviewing and reinstating more than 100 environmental regulations that Trump weakened or rolled back. Also on Wednesday, Biden rescinded the construction permit for the Keystone XL oil pipeline, which would have helped transport carbon-heavy oil from the Canadian oil sands to the Gulf Coast.

Biden, too, terminated Trump‚Äôs efforts to leave the World Health Organization, sending Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nation‚Äôs top infectious disease specialist, to participate in the group‚Äôs annual executive board meeting on Thursday. On the immigration front, Biden repealed two Trump-era proclamations that established a ban on travel to the U.S. from several predominantly Muslim and African countries, ending one of his predecessor‚Äôs earliest actions to limit immigration.

And, in a move that will reverse one of Trump‚Äôs signature initiatives, Biden halted construction of Trump‚Äôs border wall ‚Äî which was devised to keep migrants out of the country ‚Äî while his administration examines the legality of the wall‚Äôs funding and its construction contracts.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the 17 executive orders Biden signed on his first day as president. Photo by @nytmills
ImageText: President Biden Signs 17 Executive Orders on First Day

Description:
President Joe Biden wasted little time Wednesday in working to undo President Donald Trump's policies that were anathema to Democrats during his four years in office.‚Å†
‚Å†
By quickly reversing several Trump policies, experts say Biden wants to show the world the U.S. has turned the page.‚Å†
‚Å†
Sitting in the Oval Office, Biden signed an order requiring masks and social distancing on federal property, followed by an order to provide support to underserved communities. As part of the third order he signed, Biden rejoined the Paris Agreement on climate change, a treaty the U.S. formally exited in November after Trump withdrew in 2017.‚Å†
‚Å†
Biden was expected to sign 15 executive orders and other directives Wednesday, with several more coming over the next 10 days.‚Å†
‚Å†
#joebiden #biden #politics #president
ImageText: BREAKING President Biden issues executive orders to swiftly reverse Trump's "most egregious moves" on the pandemic, immigration and others on his first day in the White House. USA TODAY

Description:
Joe Biden has moved to reinstate the US to the Paris climate agreement just hours after being sworn in as president, as his administration rolls out a cavalcade of executive orders aimed at tackling the climate crisis.

Biden‚Äôs executive action, signed in the White House on Wednesday, will see the US rejoin the international effort curb the dangerous heating of the planet, following a 30-day notice period. The world‚Äôs second largest emitter of greenhouse gases was withdrawn from the Paris deal under Donald Trump.

Biden is also set to block the Keystone XL pipeline, a bitterly contested project that would bring huge quantities of oil from Canada to the US to be refined, and halt oil and gas drilling at Bears Ears and Grand Staircase-Escalante, two vast national monuments in Utah, and the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge wilderness. The Trump administration‚Äôs decision to shrink the protected areas of Bears Ears and Grand Staircase-Escalante will also be reviewed.

The flurry of first-day action on the climate crisis came after Biden, in his inauguration speech, said America needed to respond to a ‚Äúclimate in crisis‚Äù. The change in direction from the Trump era was profound and immediate ‚Äì on the White House website, where all mentions of climate were scrubbed out in 2017, a new list of priorities now puts the climate crisis second only behind the Covid pandemic. Biden has previously warned that climate change poses the ‚Äúgreatest threat‚Äù to the country, which was battered by record climate-fueled wildfires, hurricanes and heat last year.

via @guardian_us
ImageText: Biden returns US to G Paris climate accord hours after becoming president

Description:
En Chile, la #crisisclim√°tica se ha hecho sentir con fuerza. El 18 de mayo del a√±o pasado, el pa√≠s fue el primero de la regi√≥n en alcanzar el d√≠a de sobregiro #ecol√≥gico, es decir, agot√≥ antes que todos los pa√≠ses sudamericanos sus recursos naturales disponibles para usar durante todo el a√±o. Esta situaci√≥n ha provocado que las mujeres, debido a los roles impuestos ligados al cuidado de las personas, est√©n tomando una posici√≥n activa para sobrellevar la crisis, no solo por ellas, sino por su entorno.

Desde liderar comit√©s para la entrega de casas ecol√≥gicas, hasta ser las principales participantes de capacitaciones medioambientales y alegrarse por tener agua caliente para lavar a sus hijos, son parte de las escenas que ha visto la investigadora y doctora en Econom√≠a de Recursos Naturales de la Universidad de Cambridge, Nicola Borregaard.

‚ÄúA pesar de que las mujeres no est√°n plenamente informadas del cambio clim√°tico, cuando se les dice que as√≠ es, est√°n m√°s dispuestas a hacer un sacrificio‚Äù, se√±al√≥ la participante de la nueva edici√≥n de @congresofuturo , evento que busca destacar a expertos en distintas √°reas del saber.

En una entrevista exclusiva para @elmostrador_braga , la investigadora profundiz√≥ en el rol activo de las mujeres en plena crisis clim√°tica y su destacada participaci√≥n en distintos proyectos ecol√≥gicos que ha llevado a cabo. Adem√°s, evalu√≥ el panorama actual del problema medioambiental en Chile y la falta de una mirada ‚Äúfemenina‚Äù de quienes tienen el poder.

Description:
Joe Biden was sworn in as the 46th president on Wednesday, bringing to an end one of the most unorthodox, turbulent presidencies in U.S. history.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúToday, we celebrate triumph not of a candidate but of a cause: the cause of democracy,‚Äù Biden said moments after taking the oath of office. ‚ÄúThe people, the will of the people has been heard.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúWe have learned again that democracy is precious, democracy is fragile,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúAnd at this hour, my friends, democracy has prevailed.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
In his roughly 25-minute speech, Biden called for national unity and pledged to tackle ‚Äúwith purpose and resolve‚Äù the monumental issues plaguing the country, including the COVID-19 pandemic, systemic racism and climate change.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúWe can treat each other with dignity and respect,‚Äù Biden said. ‚ÄúWe can join forces, stop the shouting and lower the temperature. For without unity, there is no peace, only bitterness and fury. No progress, only exhausting outrage.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts led Biden in the oath of office, using a Bible that has been in the president‚Äôs family since 1893. His son Beau Biden used the same Bible when he was sworn in as Delaware attorney general in 2007.‚Å†
‚Å†
Minutes earlier, Kamala Harris was sworn in as vice president by Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor, the first Latina member of the court. Harris used a Bible that once belonged to Thurgood Marshall, the first Black Supreme Court justice.‚Å†
‚Å†
Read more at our link in bio. // üì∑ Getty Images
ImageText: IHUFFPOSTI " Democracy is precious. Democracy is fragile. And at this hour, my friends, democracy has prevailed.' President Joe Biden

Description:
Kamala Harris is now the first woman ‚Äî and the first woman of color ‚Äî sworn into the office of vice president. The history-making moment is a milestone for Americans who have fought tirelessly for generations to see faces that resemble their own in the government‚Äôs executive branch.

But Harris‚Äôs role in the new administration will be much more than a symbolic one.

With the Senate now split evenly between Democrats and Republicans, Harris may find herself casting the decisive vote in many crucial moments, as the vice president wields tiebreaking power. Ambitious legislation on the coronavirus, the economy, climate change and other policy matters will be high on President Biden‚Äôs agenda, and her vote may prove critical. One of her first official acts in her new role will be to swear in three new Democratic senators.

On Wednesday, 232 years after John Adams became the nation‚Äôs first vice president, Kamala Devi Harris was sworn in by Justice Sonia Sotomayor, her hand on a Bible that once belonged to Thurgood Marshall, the civil rights icon and Supreme Court justice. Harris‚Äôs ascension made her the highest-ranking woman in the history of the United States and the first Black American and first person of South Asian descent to hold the nation‚Äôs second highest office.

Tap the link in the bio for live coverage of the inaugural ceremonies.  Photo by @erinschaff
ImageText: Kamala Harris Is First Woman to Be Vice President

Description:
Would this push you to make the switch to electric?

Batteries capable of fully charging in five minutes have been produced in a factory for the first time, marking a significant step towards electric cars becoming as fast to charge as filling up petrol or diesel vehicles.

Electric vehicles are a vital part of action to tackle the climate crisis but running out of charge during a journey is a worry for drivers.

The new lithium-ion batteries were developed by the Israeli company StoreDot and manufactured by Eve Energy in China.

The batteries can be fully charged in five minutes but this would require much higher-powered chargers than used today. Using available charging infrastructure, StoreDot is aiming to deliver 100 miles of charge to a car battery in five minutes in 2025.

Follow the link in our bio to read more about the tech behind these new batteries - and the race for fast-charging batteries.

Description:
Trump‚Äôs four year presidency in photos.

1. President Donald Trump met Russian President Vladimir Putin at the G20 Summit following claims that Russia interfered in the 2016 election.

2. Police officers used tear gas to disperse peaceful Black Lives Matter protesters, so Donald Trump could stage a photo op outside the St John's Episcopal Church in Washington, holding a Bible.

3. US President Donald Trump welcomes 11-year-old Frank Giaccio as he cuts the grass at the White House in Washington.

4. President Trump speaks during an interview with Reuters in the Oval Office.

5. Trump waved and gave the thumbs up to his supporters in a surprising drive-by in front of Walter Reed National Military Medical Center, where he was being treated for coronavirus.

6. Press conferences throughout his term were lively with Trump often calling the media 'fake news'. Here Trump had a particularly heated exchange with CNN journalist Jim Acosta.

7. Climate change activist Greta Thurnburg didn't looked pleased when she saw President Trump at the UN's climate change summit.

8. President Trump triumphantly held up a newspaper with the headline 'ACQUITTED', after the Senate acquitted him following his first impeachment by Congress.

9. Donald Trump with Queen Elizabeth II, inspects the Guard of Honour at Windsor Castle. The controversial state visit was met with protests in the UK and a Trump baby blimp.

10. Amy Coney Barret is sworn in as a Supreme Court Justice. Barret‚Äôs nomination was rushed through by Trump‚Äôs administration following the death of Ruth Bader Ginsburg.

#Trump #president #presidenttrump #whitehouse #unitedstates #queen #royal #supremecourt #gretathunberg #coronavirus #pandemic #covid19 #putin #russia #election #biden #uselection #inauguration

Description:
This notorious protest blimp has found a home at the Museum of London.‚Å†
‚Å†
The balloon first took to London skies in protest against President Donald Trump‚Äôs 2018 visit to the UK.‚Å†
‚Å†
It‚Äôs flown in other countries, including Ireland, France, Argentina and Denmark.‚Å†
‚Å†
The blimp will join the museum‚Äôs protest collection, which features artefacts from climate change rallies and the Suffragette movement.‚Å†
‚Å†
Sharon Ament, the museum‚Äôs director, said: ‚ÄúBy collecting the baby blimp, we can mark the wave of feeling that washed over the city that day and capture a particular moment of resistance.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúFrom the Suffragettes of the early 20th century to the anti-austerity marches, free speech and Black Lives Matter most recently ‚Äì the capital has always been the place to have your say.‚Äù
ImageText: Trump baby blimp to join Museum of London collection

Description:
2020 was a year that laid bare hard truths in the US: about existing inequalities made unbearably worse by the Covid-19 pandemic, about a democratic system vulnerable to its own institutional weaknesses, about the proliferating catastrophes heading our way if we don‚Äôt act with urgency to stop the climate crisis.

While off to a difficult start, it‚Äôs our hope that 2021 will offer something new ‚Äì if we dare say it, something better. It‚Äôs certainly an opportunity for fresh ideas. @guardian_us asked nine experts to share one, concrete way to address some of America‚Äôs most intractable challenges.

Read their answers in full by following the link in our bio.

Description: üî¥ El 2020 ha sido el a√±o m√°s c√°lido, junto a 2016, confirm√≥ este jueves la #ONU, y el mundo se dirige hacia un "aumento catastr√≥fico" del #calentamiento en este siglo, augura su secretario general, Antonio Guterres. Seg√∫n una recopilaci√≥n de cinco grandes bases de datos internacionales efectuada por la Organizaci√≥n meteorol√≥gica mundial (OMM), agencia de la ONU, 2020 iguala a 2016 como a√±o m√°s c√°lido en el mundo, todo ello durante una d√©cada de temperaturas r√©cord. Este calentamiento r√©cord se ha logrado pese al enfriamiento causado a fin de a√±o por el fen√≥meno oce√°nico natural de La Ni√±a. En cambio, 2016 estuvo marcado por un fuerte episodio, El Ni√±o, fen√≥meno oce√°nico natural que genera un alza de las temperaturas. "Es extraordinario que las temperaturas de 2020 hayan sido pr√°cticamente equivalentes a las de 2016, cuando en ese a√±o asistimos a uno de los mayores calentamientos atribuidos a El Ni√±o", subraya el secretario general de la OMM, Petteri Taalas. "Es por lo tanto evidente que el cambio clim√°tico inducido por el hombre es ahora tan poderoso como la fuerza de la naturaleza", agrega.
ImageText: EN EL SIGLO 21 El mundo se dirige hacia un calentamiento "catastr√≥fico" meganoticias.cl

Description:
üåé Global warming didn't take the year off in 2020: The planet was near record hot again last year, climate groups announced.‚Å†
‚Å†
While NASA said that 2020 essentially tied with 2016 as the Earth's warmest year on record, other groups, such as the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, said it was the second-warmest year. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The burning of fossil fuels such as oil, natural gas and coal releases greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide and methane into the Earth's atmosphere, causing the globe to warm to levels that cannot be explained by natural causes.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre in a position where we‚Äôre pushing the climate system out of the bounds that it‚Äôs been in for tens of thousands of years, if not millions of years."‚Å†
‚Å†
In this photo from June on 2020, vendors and rickshaw drivers sleep out in the open early on a hot summer morning in Karachi, Pakistan as the region experienced an intense heat wave. üì∏ @apnews‚Å†
ImageText: (empty)

Description:
2020 was effectively tied with 2016 for the hottest year on record, as global warming linked to greenhouse gas emissions showed no signs of letting up. The findings were released Thursday in an analysis of global temperatures by the NASA Goddard Institute for Space Studies.

With the 2020 results, the last seven years have been the warmest since the beginning of modern record-keeping nearly a century and a half ago, the institute‚Äôs director, Gavin Schmidt, said in an interview.
 
‚ÄúWe are now very, very clear about the underlying long-term trends,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe understand where they come from. It‚Äôs because of the greenhouse gases being pumped into the atmosphere.‚Äù

Other analyses issued Thursday, one by @noaa and another by Berkeley Earth, an independent research group in California, found that 2020 was slightly cooler than 2016, as did an analysis published last week by the Copernicus Climate Change Service in Europe. But the difference was small enough not to be statistically significant.
 
As climate scientists have predicted, the world is seeing an increase in heat waves, storms and other extreme weather as the planet warms, and in disasters like droughts, floods and wildfires that result. Last year offered no respite, with record fires in Australia and California, high temperatures in Siberia and the Arctic, and severe drought in central South America and the American Southwest. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the consequences of a warming world.
ImageText: 2020 Tied with 2016 As the Hottest Year On Record 2020 Global average temperature compared with the mid- mid-20th century average Warmer Cooler 1880 Source: NASA Goddard Institute for Space Studies

El 2020 ser√° dif√≠cil de olvidar, no solo por los efectos de la COVID-19 en todo el mundo, sino porque se confirm√≥ que cambio clim√°tico no para ni en pandemia. 

#cambioclimatico #planeta #desastresnaturales #retrocesoambiental #a√±omascalienteenlahistoria #covid_19 #pandemia #noticierostelevisa

Description:
Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è US carbon emissions fell 10.3% in 2020 because of the pandemic, preliminary estimates by the Rhodium Group show. But the dip came at a great economic cost ‚Äî and experts warn emissions will bounce back quickly unless climate action becomes a priority. It's not just the US ‚Äî Global Carbon Project estimates that emissions of heat-trapping gases decreased by around 7% globally last year. That might look like a significant drop, but it won't make any meaningful difference to climate change. Carbon dioxide remains in the atmosphere for centuries, and last year's decline is little more than a blip on the graph. Tap the link in our bio to learn more.‚Å†
‚Å†
(üì∏: Mark J. Terrill/AP)
ImageText: CNN US carbon emissions fell 10% in 2020 because of the pandemic The drop, which is helping the country meet one of its long-standing climate targets, is the largest drop in annual emissions in the post-World War II era

Description:
La #agricultura convencional est√° basada en fertilizantes solubles y en #pesticidas. Adem√°s, el suelo est√° expuesto constantemente a arados profundos, que junto con la utilizaci√≥n de fertilizantes sint√©ticos y pesticidas, generan la p√©rdida de la materia org√°nica del suelo, lo que trae serias implicancias para el medio ambiente y el cambio clim√°tico. El uso de la tierra para fines agr√≠colas, silv√≠colas y de otra √≠ndole generan alrededor del 23% de las emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero, como di√≥xido de carbono, metano, entre otros, seg√∫n recoge el informe de 2019 publicado por el Grupo Intergubernamental de Expertos sobre el Cambio Clim√°tico (IPCC).

Una pradera sana requiere que el suelo contenga los minerales y microorganismos adecuados para su desarrollo. Para esto es esencial la #materiaorg√°nica, que por lo dem√°s, es la principal responsable de la retenci√≥n de agua en el suelo y proviene de la descomposici√≥n de los residuos de plantas, animales y microorganismos del subsuelo y micorriza (ambiente que rodea a las ra√≠ces).

Lo anterior ha motivado un mayor inter√©s en el mundo por la producci√≥n de #algod√≥n org√°nico regenerativo, y empresas como Patagonia, Kering y Prana, apuestan por este sistema agr√≠cola que mantiene y restaura la fertilidad del suelo, sin el uso de pesticidas y fertilizantes t√≥xicos y persistentes. Adem√°s, se preocupa de fomentar un trabajo digno y un trato adecuado con los animales que participan en el proceso. 

El algod√≥n en la mira

Para hacerse una idea, el algod√≥n representa el 30% de las fibras consumidas en la industria textil a nivel mundial. De acuerdo con un reporte de la Organizaci√≥n de las Naciones Unidas de la Alimentaci√≥n y la Agricultura (FAO), se estima que estos cultivos ocupan alrededor de 30 millones de hect√°reas en todo el planeta, donde el 50% de la producci√≥n es bajo riego y constituye la fuente de ingreso de 350 millones de personas en toda su cadena de producci√≥n. 

üëâcontin√∫a leyendo en el link de la bio ‚ùó
ImageText: La nueva apuesta por el algod√≥n org√°nico regenerativo que se abre camino dentro del mundo textil por √Ångeles Biancani 11 enero, 11enero,202 2021

De acuerdo con un reporte de la Organizaci√≥n de las Naciones Unidas de la Alimentaci√≥n y la Agricultura (FAO), se estima que estos cultivos ocupan alrededor de 30 millones de hect√°reas en todo el planeta, donde el 50% de la producci√≥n es bajo riego y constituye la fuente de ingreso de 350 millones de personas en toda su cadena de producci√≥n.

Los datos informados por el Servicio de Cambio Clim√°tico Copernicus (C3S) indican que el planeta gan√≥ al menos 1,1 ¬∫C respecto a la era preindustrial y Europa, por su parte, registr√≥ el a√±o m√°s c√°lido, con +0,4 ¬∫C respecto a 2019.

Description:
2020 has joined 2016 as the hottest year ever recorded, continuing an exceptionally warm trend over the past six years brought by the climate crisis.‚Å†
‚Å†
The EU's Copernicus Climate Change Service confirmed the data today, compiled using its satellite network. It found that 2020 was 0.6¬∞C warmer than a reference period of 1981-2010 and around 1.25¬∞C above the 1850-1900 pre-industrial period.‚Å†
‚Å†
2016, which equalled 2020's heat, had its temperatures raised by a naturally occurring periodic climate event known as El Ni√±o. Without this, it's likely 2020 would have been the hottest ever.‚Å†
‚Å†
The scientists also said that 2020 was Europe's hottest year recorded, 0.4¬∞C warmer than 2019, Europe's last hottest year.‚Å†
‚Å†
The largest regional heat difference from recent years was in Arctic and northern Siberia, which averaged 6¬∞C above the 1981-2010 period.‚Å†
‚Å†
Carlo Buontempo, director of the Copernicus Climate Change Service, said: "2020 stands out for its exceptional warmth in the Arctic and a record number of tropical storms in the North Atlantic. It is no surprise that the last decade was the warmest on record, and is yet another reminder of the urgency of ambitious emissions reductions to prevent adverse climate impacts in the future."‚Å†
‚Å†
‚Å†
Image source: Copernicus Climate Change Service, ERAS‚Å†
‚Å†

Description:
Do you sometimes feel like the climate crisis is out of our hands?

Scientists have some hopeful new findings that show the climate disaster could be lessened within a couple of decades if net zero emissions are reached.

For many years it was assumed that further global heating would be locked in for generations even if emissions were rapidly cut. But more recent understanding of the implications of getting to net zero emissions has offered some hope.

More than 100 countries have pledged to get to net zero by 2050, which means they will emit no more carbon dioxide than is removed from the atmosphere by, for example, restoring forests. Should this be achieved globally, ‚Äúsurface temperatures stop warming and warming stabilizes within a couple decades,‚Äù said Michael Mann, a climate scientist at Pennsylvania State University.

Follow the link in bio to read more about this promising new study.
ImageText: G Global heating could stabilise if net zero emissions achieved, scientists say œâ

Die NASA hat in beeindruckenden Vorher-Nacher-Fotos festgehalten, wie sehr sich die Klimakrise √ºber die Jahre auf unsere sch√∂ne Natur ausgewirkt hat.

Der Acuelo See in Chile hatte mal eine Fl√§che von zw√∂lf Quadratkilometern und war sechs Meter tief. Er war bei Wassersportlern sehr beliebt. Seit 2018 gibt es ihn nicht mehr. Denn die Gegend dort ist zwar Trockenheit gewohnt ‚Äì aber seit 2010 leidet sie unter einer Mega-D√ºrre.

Auch der Wasserverbrauch der wachsenden Besiedlung hat zum Ende des Sees beigetragen. Wer also mal ein Haus am See hatte, hat jetzt nur noch eins an einer Pf√ºtze. Wenn √ºberhaupt ‚Ä¶

Description:
Raphael Warnock has beaten Republican senator Kelly Loeffler and made history as Georgia‚Äôs first Black senator, a state shaped by the legacy of the civil war, Jim Crow and the civil rights movement. 

Warnock, 51, has not held elected political office before. Since 2005, he has been the senior pastor of Atlanta‚Äôs Ebenezer Baptist church, where Martin Luther King Jr grew up as a member of the congregation and later preached.

Warnock is known for campaigning against the death penalty and economic inequality, and for women‚Äôs reproductive rights, LGBTQ+ rights, police reform, and action on the climate crisis.

Follow @guardian_us for more US politics updates
ImageText: G Raphael Warnock wins Georgia election, becoming state's first Black senator

Description:
Follow @cnnclimate for more ‚û°Ô∏è
2020 was supposed to be the watershed moment for action on climate change, the year the world woke up to the challenge and started taking it seriously. Instead, it has symbolically topped a decade of wasted climate promises. The year brought near-constant reminders of the severity of the crisis we face: A record-breaking Atlantic hurricane season, the most devastating wildfires in recent history, and droughts, deadly floods and heatwaves that swept through communities worldwide, leaving death, destruction and disruption in their wake.
ImageText: GO THERE Voice of: Cyril Vanier CNN Anchor

Description:
Deutschland hat aufgrund der Corona-Krise offenbar doch noch sein Klimaziel f√ºr 2020 erreicht.

Das geht aus einer Analyse der Organisation ‚ÄûAgora Energiewende‚Äú hervor, aus der die Deutsche Presse-Agentur zitiert. Demnach wurden vergangenes Jahr rund 42 Prozent weniger Treibhausgase ausgesto√üen als 1990. Das Ziel der Bundesregierung lag bei 40 Prozent. Zuletzt waren Experten davon ausgegangen, dass es nicht mehr zu erreichen ist.

Ohne die Pandemie h√§tte die Reduktion nur rund 38 Prozent erreicht, so dass das Ziel verfehlt worden w√§re, hei√üt es in der Analyse. Echte Klimaschutzeffekte habe es nur im Stromsektor gegeben, weil dort mehr Erneuerbare Energien eingesetzt wurden.

Im vergangenen Jahr wurde der Auswertung zufolge in Deutschland erstmals mehr Strom aus Windkraft produziert als aus Kohle. Im Hinblick auf das n√§chste Klimaschutzziel f√ºr 2030 reiche der Ausbau aber bei weitem noch nicht aus, erkl√§rte der Leiter der Organisation, Graichen.

Description:
Hace un a√±o que Fulvio Giovannini volvi√≥ a nacer. Este top√≥grafo italiano es un gran amante de los deportes de monta√±a y en medio de una excursi√≥n por uno de los glaciares de la cadena monta√±osa de los Dolomitas, en el noreste de Italia, el suelo de nieve y hielo comenz√≥ a resquebrajarse, lo que provoc√≥ una fuerte avalancha sin darles tiempo alguno para poder ponerse a salvo. Giovannini qued√≥ completamente enterrado en la nieve, donde estuvo atrapado alrededor de 50 minutos, pero gracias a que es un monta√±ista experimentado, llevaba consigo un sistema transceptor de avalanchas, lo que facilit√≥ que un equipo de rescate le pudiera localizar. Lo normal en este tipo de sucesos es que si se supera los 15 minutos atrapados en la nieve, las opciones de sobrevivir sean m√≠nimas, debido al alto riesgo de hipotermia. Pero Giovannini, a pesar de superar 3 veces esa cantidad de tiempo, consigui√≥ ser rescatado sin apenas da√±os. Desgraciadamente el cambio clim√°tico est√° provocando que las avalanchas sean cada vez m√°s normales en esta zona de los Alpes, pero esto no evita que Givannini siga disfrutando de estos impresionantes paisajes que una vez estuvieron a punto de jugarle una mala pasada.

Description: Die Social-Media-Redaktion der @sz blickt auf das Jahr zur√ºck - und stellt Bilder, Zitate und Ereignisse vor, die ihr aus 2020 besonders in Erinnerung geblieben sind. Heute mit Franziska D√ºrmeier:  "Dieser SZ-Post war einer der ersten im Jahr 2020, genauer vom Morgen des 2. Januar. Ich hatte meinen ersten Dienst nach Silvester, wir fuhren noch t√§glich in die Redaktion, das Coronavirus schien noch fern - und das Thema jener Tage waren die Br√§nde in Australien. Eine Familie entkommt den Flammen per Boot, der 11-j√§hrige Sohn sitzt am Steuer. Alles ist in dicke Rauchschwaden geh√ºllt, die Sonne ist verdeckt.  Dieses apokalyptische Rot wird sp√§ter im Jahr wieder auftauchen, etwa in San Francisco. Und im Laufe der Monate wird ein Rekord den n√§chsten jagen: Rekordtemperaturen im Death Valley, in der Arktis, in der Antarktis. Doch dann kam Corona - und dann gab es erstmal nur noch Corona. Aus heutiger Perspektive sticht auf dem Bild sofort die Maske ins Auge, eines der gro√üen Symbole des Jahres. Damals wirkte sie eher nebens√§chlich. Das Rot daf√ºr umso bedrohlicher.  Jetzt, nach diesem Jahr der Corona-Krise und den ersten Jahresbilanzen, f√§llt auf, wie sehr die Klimakrise in den Hintergrund ger√ºckt ist. Dabei sind die Zahlen weiterhin alarmierend: Das Jahr 2020 ist vorl√§ufigen Ergebnissen zufolge in Deutschland das zweitw√§rmste seit Beginn der Aufzeichnungen, meldete der Deutsche Wetterdienst. Und auch hierzulande brannte es nach langanhaltender Trockenheit und D√ºrre.  Doch was man in diesem Jahr auch sehen konnte: Eine Ver√§nderung des Gewohnten und sogar des bisher Undenkbaren ist m√∂glich - wenn das Thema denn Priorit√§t hat. Viele Pendelfahrten, Dienst- und Fernreisen fielen weg und die Regierungen nahmen f√ºr Ma√ünahmen viel Geld in die Hand und trafen zeitnah Entscheidungen. Ein Jahr sp√§ter ist das Foto also eine Erinnerung an die andere gro√üe Krise, an die andere gro√üe Aufgabe f√ºr 2021."  Mehr zum Thema Klima finden Sie unter sz.de/klimazentrale  #klimakrise #klima #fridaysforfuture

Description: The remarkably preserved carcass of an Ice Age-era woolly rhino has been unearthed by locals in eastern Siberia. With most of its internal organs intact, the rhino, which is believed to have lived more than 20,000 years ago, is among the best-preserved animals ever found in the region.   Recent years have seen major discoveries of the remains of mammoths, woolly rhinos, several puppies and cave-lion cubs in parts of Siberia. Discoveries of this kind are becoming more frequent as global warming melts the permafrost across vast areas of Russia's extreme north and eastern regions.   Tap the link in our bio to learn more. #BBCNews #ClimateChange #IceAge #Animals

Description: Os dez desastres clim√°ticos mais caros do mundo em 2020 viram danos segurados no valor de US$ 150 bilh√µes, superando os n√∫meros de 2019 e refletindo um impacto de longo prazo do aquecimento global, de acordo com um novo relat√≥rio da ONG Christian Aid.  As cat√°strofes, que v√£o dos inc√™ndios florestais australianos a furac√µes no Atl√¢ntico, ceifaram pelo menos 3.500 vidas e provocaram o deslocamento de mais de 13,5 milh√µes de pessoas.  Os preju√≠zos ca√≠ram desproporcionalmente sobre as na√ß√µes pobres, de acordo com a contagem anual da Christian Aid.  Cinco dos desastres mais caros em 2020 estavam vinculados a uma temporada de mon√ß√µes particularmente rigorosa na √Åsia.  Embora as cat√°strofes naturais existam desde antes da interfer√™ncia da Humanidade, ficou claro, atrav√©s da an√°lise da temperatura e de precipita√ß√µes durante mais de um s√©culo, que a a√ß√£o humana sobre a superf√≠cie do planeta est√° aumentando a frequ√™ncia e intensidade de eventos extremos.  Grandes tempestades tropicais ‚Äî furac√µes, tuf√µes e ciclones ‚Äî agora t√™m maior probabilidade, por exemplo, de serem mais fortes, durar mais, carregar mais √°gua e passar por √°reas al√©m de seu alcance hist√≥rico.  O n√∫mero recorde de furac√µes no Atl√¢ntico em 2020 ‚Äî com pelo menos 400 fatalidades e US$ 41 bilh√µes em danos ‚Äî sugere que o mundo tamb√©m poderia ver mais tempestades desse tipo.  Os inc√™ndios florestais que queimaram √°reas recordes na Calif√≥rnia, Austr√°lia e at√© mesmo no interior da Sib√©ria, dentro do c√≠rculo √°rtico, tamb√©m indicam um mundo mais quente e com previs√£o de piorar conforme as temperaturas sobem.  A temperatura m√©dia da superf√≠cie do planeta subiu pelo menos 1,1 grau Celsius em m√©dia em compara√ß√£o com o final do s√©culo XIX, com grande parte desse aquecimento ocorrendo na √∫ltima metade do s√©culo.  #JornalOGlobo  Foto: JOSH EDELSON/AFP

Description: Climate anxiety and other #mentalhealth struggles are rampant among young Californians, according to experts who warn that the youth are growing up in the shadow of looming catastrophe ‚Äî and dealing with the emotional and psychological fallout that comes with it.  The scope of the problem is enormous.  Without reducing those emissions, #climatechange will make natural disasters, food shortages and rising sea levels even worse, experts say. The world is not yet on track to make the changes necessary to ameliorate its worst effects.  Such dire predictions can affect mental health, particularly among young people. Polls have found that climate change-related stress affects daily life for 47% of America‚Äôs young adults; over half of teenagers feel afraid and angry about climate change; and 72% of young adults are concerned that it will harm their community.  #Climate depression played a central role in teenage activist Greta Thunberg‚Äôs political awakening, and according to Varshini Prakash ‚Äî executive director of youth-focused climate activism group the Sunrise Movement ‚Äî it‚Äôs not uncommon for her group to meet kids who have contemplated suicide over the #climatecrisis.  Read more about the impact of climate change on #California‚Äôs youth at link in bio. üì∏: Justin Sullivan / Getty Images
ImageText: For young Californians, climate change is a mental health crisis too Hilotie FARTH WA LiVE RE

Description: Contaminated by Libby amphibole, a highly toxic mixture of asbestos fibers unleashed by a former mine that has killed hundreds of area residents, a section of Kootenai National Forest of northwest Montana is an officially designated hazardous waste zone ‚Äî Superfund Operable Unit 3 of the Environmental Protection Agency‚Äôs Libby Asbestos Site.‚Å† ‚Å† With wildfires heightened by climate change threatening 234 Superfund sites across the country, according to the federal government, the OU3 Libby Asbestos Site presents a kind of worst-case scenario in which a wildfire could send asbestos-contaminated ash into nearby communities.‚Å† ‚Å† A yearlong investigation by Inside Climate News, @nbcnews and The Texas Observer, based on interviews with dozens of current and former EPA officials and firefighting authorities, found that the threat presented by wildfires is exceeding authorities‚Äô ability to adequately prepare and respond, given recent steep increases in wildfires, particularly in the West.‚Å† ‚Å† Read more at the link in our bio.‚Å† ‚Å† üì∑ Courtesy Nolan Buckingham

Description: Climate change is propelling enormous human migrations, transforming global agriculture and remaking the world order. But for a few nations, climate change will present an unparalleled opportunity, as the planet‚Äôs coldest regions become more temperate.   There is plenty of reason to think that those places will also receive an extraordinary influx of people displaced from the hottest parts of the world as the climate warms. Human migration, historically, has been driven by the pursuit of prosperity even more so than it has by environmental strife. With climate change, prosperity and habitability ‚Äî haven and economic opportunity ‚Äî will soon become one and the same.   And no country may be better positioned to capitalize on climate change than Russia.  Russia has the largest land mass by far of any northern nation. It is positioned farther north than all of its South Asian neighbors, which collectively are home to the largest global population fending off displacement from rising seas, drought and an overheating climate. Like Canada, Russia is rich in resources and land, with room to grow. And whether by accident or strategy (or some combination of the 2), the steps its leaders have steadily taken have increasingly positioned Russia to regain its superpower mantle in a warmer world.   The lyrics to Russia‚Äôs modern anthem suggest that at least some of its leaders have anticipated this moment: ‚ÄúWide spaces for dreams and for living are opened for us by the coming years.‚Äù  For 2 years, the reporter Abrahm Lustgarten has been documenting a great global climate migration that is already underway. Tap the link in our bio to read this final installment of a 3-part series for @NYTMag and ProPublica, in which he focuses on the country that benefits the most ‚Äî Russia. Photos by @sergeyponomarev

Description: President-elect Joe Biden introduced former Democratic primary rival Pete Buttigieg as his nominee for Transportation secretary.  Buttigieg, who served two terms as mayor of South Bend, Ind., would be the first openly gay person confirmed by the Senate to a Cabinet post. Biden hailed that milestone and said that by the time he‚Äôs done filling out his new administration‚Äôs top positions, it will have more women and people of color than ever, promising ‚Äúa Cabinet of barrier breakers.‚Äù  The nomination was applauded by union leaders, transportation industry officials, LGBTQ activists and Democratic lawmakers as a solid pick by Biden.  If confirmed, Buttigieg will have much on his plate right out of the gate. He‚Äôll be tasked with putting in place Biden‚Äôs proposals to spend billions making major infrastructure improvements and on retrofitting initiatives that can help the United States fight climate change.  Read more about Buttigieg and what he would face as Transportation secretary at link in bio.

Description: El Valle de Zongo, en Bolivia, esconde 20 especies nuevas de flora y fauna ¬∑ Conocido como el coraz√≥n de Bolivia, el Valle de Zongo esconde secretos hasta ahora desconocidos en el mundo. En lo alto de los Andes, los investigadores descubren hasta 20 nuevas especies de flora y fauna, como la "rana liliputiense", casi imposible de detectar por su color marr√≥n camuflado y su min√∫sculo cuerpo de apenas un cent√≠metro. A este refugio de vida silvestre se suman nuevas mariposas, as√≠ como plantas y orqu√≠deas que desconoc√≠amos. Aunque m√°s emocionante a√∫n es el redescubrimiento de cuatro ejemplares que se cre√≠an extintos, como la "rana de ojos de diablo", de piel negra y ojos rojos. Es posible que algunos de estos animales no se encuentren en ning√∫n otro lugar del mundo, por lo que es esencial proteger lugares como el Zongo frente al cambio clim√°tico.  #ValleDelZongo #Bolivia #Naturaleza #Animales #Fauna #Flora #NuevasEspecies

Description: President-elect Joe Biden will nominate Pete Buttigieg, the former mayor of South Bend, Indiana, to lead the Department of Transportation, said a person familiar with Biden‚Äôs deliberations. If confirmed by the Senate, Buttigieg would become the first openly-gay person to serve as a cabinet secretary.   Buttigieg, 38, fought a fierce battle for the Democratic nomination but bowed out and endorsed Biden in his bid for the presidency. The two men bonded during the general election campaign and the president-elect made it clear that he wanted to find a place for the former mayor in his administration.  A Navy veteran, Buttigieg could have led the Department of Veterans Affairs. But Biden decided instead to put him in charge of transportation, which is likely to become a key part of the administration‚Äôs efforts to combat climate change with aggressive actions on emissions.  Tap the link in our bio for the story. Photo by @travisdovephoto
ImageText: Biden Picks Buttigieg for Transportation Secretary

Description: Scientists have discovered a climate crisis refuge for coral reefs off the coast of Kenya and Tanzania, where species are thriving despite warming events that have killed their neighbours.  The coral sanctuary is a wildlife hotspot, teeming with spinner dolphins and boasting rare species, including prehistoric fish and dugongs.   The study shows that while warming waters may devastate surrounding reefs, this area could become an incredibly important sanctuary where marine species big and small will flock to find refuge from climate change.  Researchers believe its location in a cool spot in the ocean is helping to protect it and the surrounding marine life from the harmful effects of the climate crisis.  Unfortunately the climate crisis is not the only threat to the area‚Äôs biodiversity and the newly discovered refuge. Unsustainable fishing continues, and there are future plans for coastal development, including a port in northern Tanzania.  Photos: Michael Markovina + Gabriel Barathieu & Simon Pierce

Description: El ins√≥lito caso de las islas que emergen a pesar de la subida del nivel del mar.  La isla Jeh, situada en las Islas Marshall, ha aumentado su superficie terrestre en un 13% desde 1943 desafiando toda l√≥gica del cambio clim√°tico. Situada en el atol√≥n Ailinglaplap, Jeh es uno de los 29 atolones de arrecifes de coral que forman la Rep√∫blica de las Islas Marshall, a medio camino entre Haw√°i y Australia.  Islas como Jeh han sido consideradas entre las m√°s amenazadas del mundo debido a los posibles efectos del aumento del nivel del mar. Pero, por extra√±o que parezca, Jeh no para de crecer.  Un nuevo estudio de la Universidad de Auckland (Nueva Zelanda), y publicado en Geophysical Reserch Letters, asegura que "en contra de las predicciones, la cobertura de los medios populares y las proclamas pol√≠ticas, estudios recientes han demostrado que la mayor√≠a de las islas de arrecifes estudiadas se han mantenido estables o han aumentado de tama√±o desde mediados del siglo XX‚Äù.  Las islas de atolones como las de las Islas Marshall son dep√≥sitos bajos de sedimentos derivados de arrecifes depositados en los √∫ltimos 500 a√±os o menos. A pesar del aumento del nivel del mar, los cient√≠ficos han observado un crecimiento en el √°rea terrestre de la mayor√≠a de los atolones desde mediados del siglo XX, lo que sugiere que pueden acumular el sedimento necesario para expandirse.  M√°s infromaci√≥n aqu√≠ üì≤ https://bit.ly/2JUtYqp ‚úç Neus Palou  üì∏ Geophysical Reserch Letters  #islas #JehIsland

Description: Das Pariser Klimaabkommen sollte der Startschuss sein, um das Klima nach jahrzehntelanger Unt√§tigkeit doch noch retten. Doch es war ein Startschuss, dem kein Rennen folgte, meint Georg Ehring in seinem Kommentar zum Klimaschutz. . Am 12. Dezember 2015 haben sich die meisten L√§nder der Erde zu engagiertem Klimaschutz verpflichtet. Mit dem Pariser Abkommen formulierten 195 Nationen das Ziel, die Klimaerw√§rmung auf deutlich unter zwei Grad, wenn m√∂glich auf unter 1,5 Grad zu begrenzen.  . Das UN-Umweltprogramm habe nun seinen Bericht zum Klimaschutz herausgegeben. Danach ist die Welt auf dem Weg in eine katastrophale Erw√§rmung um 3,2 Grad ‚Äì und auch das nur, wenn alle Staaten tun, was sie im Klimaschutz versprochen haben, sonst werden es noch mehr.  Die Wetterkatastrophen dieser Jahre geben eine Ahnung davon, was auf uns zukommt, sagt Georg Ehring: Hitzewellen und D√ºrren, immer verheerendere Wirbelst√ºrme und ganze Weltregionen, die zu hei√ü und trocken sein werden f√ºr menschliches Leben. Klimabedingte Migrationswellen, auch und gerade nach Europa. Ein steigender Meeresspiegel l√§sst Millionenst√§dte an den K√ºsten rund um die Welt versinken. Der n√∂tige Ernst, um die Katastrophe zu verhindern, sei trotzdem noch nirgendwo in Sicht. . . . #klima #klimakatastrophe #klimawandel #klimaschutz #umwelt #natur #erderw√§rmung #globalwarming #wetter #wetterkatastrophen #hitze #d√ºrre #wirbelsturm #meeresspiegel #permafrost #verbrennungsmotor #kohlenstoffdioxid

Description: El papa Francisco afirm√≥ que "ha llegado el momento de un cambio de rumbo" en la defensa del medioambiente "para no robar a las nuevas generaciones la esperanza en un futuro mejor", durante un v√≠deo enviado a la Cumbre de Ambici√≥n Clim√°tica 2020 que se celebra hoy de forma virtual.  En su discurso, el papa destac√≥ que "la actual pandemia y el cambio clim√°tico, que tienen una relevancia no s√≥lo ambiental, sino tambi√©n √©tica, social, econ√≥mica y pol√≠tica, inciden, sobre todo, en la vida de los m√°s pobres y fr√°giles".  Y que por ello, "apelan a nuestra responsabilidad de promover, con un compromiso colectivo y solidario, una cultura del cuidado, que ponga en el centro la dignidad humana y el bien com√∫n".  Por lo que afirm√≥ que "adem√°s de adoptar algunas medidas que no pueden aplazarse m√°s, es necesaria una estrategia que reduzca a cero las emisiones netas (net-zero emissions)".  En ese sentido, el papa adelant√≥ que el Vaticano se compromete a reducir a cero las emisiones netas antes de 2050, intensificando los esfuerzos de gesti√≥n ambiental.

Description: Hace unos d√≠as el pr√≠ncipe Harry dio un discurso sobre la importancia de cuidar el agua. Pero su discurso no fue bien recibido por todos, ya que hay personas que acusaron al duque de Sussex de hip√≥crita tras conocerse que su mansi√≥n en California cuenta con 16 ba√±os. El periodista Piers Morgan en su programa "Good Morning Britain" de la cadena ITV le dijo a Harry "practica lo que predicas". "El pr√≠ncipe estaba de vuelta dici√©ndonos a todos que deber√≠amos ser como una gota de lluvia. Se trata de curar el mundo del calentamiento global, obviamente, desde su mansi√≥n californiana, que casualmente, hablando de gotas de lluvia, tiene 16 ba√±os", dijo Morgan. "Aparentemente cada ba√±o, yo calcul√© esto, cada ba√±o usa 4.5 millones de gotas de lluvia. Sus 16 ba√±os, si se usa cada d√≠a, usar√≠an 72 millones de gotas de lluvia al d√≠a", anunci√≥ el presentador brit√°nico. "¬øDe qu√© est√° hablando? As√≠ es como puede detener los problemas del cambio clim√°tico, as√≠ es como puede ayudar realmente, Harry. No me importa ser una gota de lluvia si te hace sentir mejor, ser√© una gota de lluvia", le dijo al pr√≠ncipe. "Tomar√≠a mejor las conferencias sobre las gotas de lluvia si no vinieran de alguien que usa aviones privados como un servicio de taxi. Ese es mi punto. Eso es algo que realmente me irrita. En serio, 16 ba√±os, aviones privados como taxis", dejando entrever las contradicciones de Harry. Para finalizar la cr√≠tica, Morgan le pidi√≥ al duque que deje de usar aviones privados, ya que son una de las formas de transporte con la mayor huella de carbono.
ImageText: "PRACTICA LO QUE PREDICAS" Periodista encara al principe Harry luego que pidiera cuidar el agua meganoticias.cl

Description: El secretario general de la ONU, Ant√≥nio Guterres, pidi√≥ hoy a los pa√≠ses declarar una "emergencia clim√°tica hasta que se alcance la carbono neutralidad", en su intervenci√≥n en la Cumbre sobre Ambici√≥n Clim√°tica 2020, organizada junto con el Reino Unido y Francia.  En su discurso en el evento virtual, donde participaron m√°s de 75 dirigentes y organizaciones, Guterres record√≥ que 38 Estados ya han reconocido "la urgencia" de la situaci√≥n e inst√≥ a todos a adoptar el objetivo de reducir a cero neto las emisiones de gases contaminantes para 2050 y en un 45 % para 2030.  En el quinto aniversario del Acuerdo de Par√≠s, cuando se adopt√≥ la meta de limitar el calentamiento global a un m√°ximo de 2¬∫C sobre niveles preindustriales, el experto portugu√©s avis√≥ de que "no se avanza en la direcci√≥n correcta" y que, "si no se cambia de rumbo", "podr√≠an superarse los 3¬∫C este siglo".

Description: Covid-19 und das Klima haben uns an einen Punkt gebracht, von dem aus wir nicht mehr zur alten Normalit√§t aus Ungleichheit und Fragilit√§t zur√ºckkehren k√∂nnen. Description: Im Jahr 2015 hatten sich die Staaten bei der UN-Klimakonferenz in Paris auf ein Abkommen verstaÃàndigt: Die ErderwaÃàrmung sollte moÃàglichst unter zwei Grad gehalten werden. Am vergangenen Freitag haben die EU-Staats- und Regierungschefs in BruÃàssel nun das dazugehoÃàrige CO2-Reduktionsziel verschaÃàrft. Der Aussto√ü von Treibhausgasen soll um mindestens 55 Prozent unter den Wert von 1990 zu senken. Bisher galt ein Wert von minus 40 Prozent.  ‚ÄûLeider sind wir in den letzten fuÃànf Jahren da nicht wirklich vorangekommen‚Äú, sagte Annalena Baerbock im Dlf. Die Weltklimakonferenz von 2015 sei dennoch keineswegs vergeblich gewesen, erlaÃàuterte die Bundesvorsitzende der GruÃànen. Vieles sei seitdem angesto√üen und auf den Weg gebracht worden, aber die Klimakrise mache deutlich, dass es einfach so nicht weitergehe. . Das Interview mit Annalena Baerbock finden Sie uÃàber den Link in der Bio.  . .  #Klimakrise #Klimawandel #Zukunft #Energiewende #Deutschland #Europa #dlf

Description: North Atlantic hurricanes are retaining far more of their strength when they hit land because of global warming, scientists say. Previously, experts believed these storms died down quickly once they made landfall. But over the past 50 years, the time it takes for hurricanes to dissipate on the coast has almost doubled. Researchers say that climate change gives the storms more energy, which continues to power them over land, likely making hurricanes more damaging further inland in years to come. Via @bbcworldservice   #Atlantic #Hurricane #GlobalWarming #Typhoon #ClimateChange #Science #BBCNews

Description: Vor f√ºnf Jahren, am 12. Dezember 2015, beschlossen 195 Staatsvertreter den Entwurf f√ºr das Pariser Klimaabkommen und einigten sich darauf die Erderw√§rmung zu begrenzen, um die Klimakrise abzumildern.  F√ºnf Jahre sp√§ter sollte die Klimakonferenz 2020 in Glasgow stattfinden und die Ambitionen des Pariser Abkommens weiter vorantreiben. Die weltweite Corona-Pandemie macht dieses Vorhaben unm√∂glich. Statt der Konferenz in Glasgow gibt es eine verkleinerte virtuelle Konferenz. Tats√§chlich verhandelt wird bei dieser Mini-Konferenz allerdings nicht.   Eigentlich sollten alle Staaten des Pariser Abkommens bis zum Klimagipfel neue und verbesserte nationale Klimaschutzpl√§ne abliefern. Das soll k√ºnftig im F√ºnf-Jahres-Rhythmus passieren und es soll zus√§tzlich zwischendurch eine Bestandsaufnahme geben, die deutlich zeigt, ob die Pl√§ne ausreichen. Bisher tun sie das n√§mlich nicht. Statt deutlich unter zwei Grad wie im Abkommen vorgesehen, w√ºrde sich die Erde Stand jetzt bis Ende des Jahrhunderts eher um rund drei Grad erw√§rmen. Im Vergleich zur vorindustriellen Zeit kam schon gut ein Grad dazu - und schon das hat dramatische Folgen - Hitzewellen und D√ºrren, zerst√∂rerische Wirbelst√ºrme und √úberschwemmungen, Korallenbleiche und schmelzendes Eis rund um die Pole und auf Bergen sind nur einige Beispiel. Die Klimabewegung Fridays for Future und viele andere pochen daher darauf, dass bei 1,5 Grad Schluss sein muss.  #klimakonferenz #pariserabkommen #klimagipfel #erderw√§rmung #klimaschutz  #rtlde
ImageText: Pariser Klimaabkommen Vor 5 Jahren wurde 1,5-Grad-Ziel gesetzt RTL.DE

Description: In a rare visit, a flock of pink flamingos settled on a lake in Sevastopol, Crimea, on Thursday. The birds usually fly farther south, but biologists believe that climate change may be driving them to new areas.

Description: California‚Äôs epic wildfires in 2020 took deadly aim at the state‚Äôs most beloved trees.   In a relative instant, countless ancient redwoods, hundreds of giant sequoias and more than 1 million Joshua trees perished.   These 3 species are what scientists call charismatic megaflora. People travel from around the world simply to walk among them in wonderment.  Resiliency is key to their magnetism. They survive where others would not. They stand their ground, with panache. Sequoias and redwoods can live thousands of years on their way to dwarfing most everything around them. Joshua trees are the most good-natured of desert plants, frozen in dance poses as they endure the harshest of environments with flair.  Each of these species already faced a rising onslaught of threats to long-term survivability, from drought to development, blanketed by the unknowable future effects of climate change.  But this year‚Äôs wildfires that burned more than 4 million acres in California ‚Äî fueled by a century‚Äôs worth of forest mismanagement and the quickening pace of global warming ‚Äî threatened them as never before.  The blackened wreckage sends a clear message. These trees are in the fight of their lives.   ‚ÄúIt‚Äôll never come back like it was,‚Äù one botanist said, standing among destroyed Joshua trees that stretched to the horizon. ‚ÄúNot with climate change.‚Äù  Tap the link in our bio to read about these charismatic megaflora, which are among the oldest living things in the world, and the people trying to protect them. Photos by @maxwhittaker. Video by @nationalparkservice ‚Äî @mojavenp, @u.s.forestservice ‚Äî @sequoianationalforest and @calfireczu

Description: Aus Gro√übritannien kommt die Nachricht, dass man mit Bier und Chips die Welt retten kann. Wie die BBC berichtet, hat eine britische Chips-Firma eine Technik entwickelt, mit der sie durch die Verkn√ºpfung von Bier- und Chips-Produktion ihren CO‚ÇÇ-Aussto√ü um 70 Prozent reduzieren kann.   Durch die G√§rung in einer Brauerei entsteht CO‚ÇÇ, das normalerweise in die Atmosph√§re gelangt. Beim neuen Verfahren wird das CO‚ÇÇ mit Kartoffelabf√§llen aus der Chips-Herstellung vermischt und zu D√ºnger verarbeitet - der wiederum das Wachstum von Kartoffeln f√∂rdert, zuk√ºnftigen Chips also.  Den Klimawandel bek√§mpfen, indem man auf dem Sofa chillt und ungesundes Zeug snackt? Daf√ºr sollten die britischen Forscher den Chemie-, Wirtschafts- und Friedensnobelpreis bekommen. Description: What does college sound like? For the past two years the NPR Student Podcast Challenge has been open to students in grades 5-12. We've heard podcasts about climate change and racism and what it's like to be young at this moment.‚Å† ‚Å† And now, today, we're opening the contest up to higher education. We want to hear the ideas, the issues, the discussions that are bubbling up on campus ‚Äî the stories that will make us laugh or cry, and everything in between.‚Å† ‚Å† The NPR Student Podcast Challenge: College Edition opens today, Dec. 1, and will close on Feb. 15, 2021. You can submit here. The middle and high school edition begins Jan. 1. Find out more through our link in bio. (Illustration: LA Johnson  @neoncatdc / NPR)

Description: President-elect Joe Biden has laid out an ambitious climate plan with the goal of reaching net-zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050. It includes a $1.7 trillion investment in clean energy and green jobs, and calls for an end to fossil fuel subsidies and a ban on new oil and gas permits on public lands. He has also promised on his first day in office to rejoin the Paris climate accord, a landmark international deal to combat the climate crisis that Trump pulled out of in 2017. CNN's @billweircnn reports on how Biden's plan will impact the climate crisis.
ImageText: (empty)

Description: The International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) has revealed that the European bison, Europe‚Äôs biggest land mammal, is beginning to recover in numbers thanks to conservation efforts and breeding programmes.  But destructive fishing methods have caused freshwater dolphins to be threatened with extinction all over the world.  Another 31 species have been newly listed as extinct altogether, including three frogs species in central America.  The IUCN also found that plants are coming under increasing threat. A third of oak tree species around the world are threatened with extinction, falling victim to disease, invasive species and the impacts of the climate crisis.
ImageText: An updated record of species at risk shows continued losses around the globe

Description: La naturaleza abri√©ndose camino ganadora del concurso de foto Earth Photo 2020.  'Teatro de Abkhazia' de Jonk, ha sido el trabajo ganador de la edici√≥n 2020. Este fot√≥grafo autodidacta se ha centrado en la relaci√≥n de los seres humanos con la naturaleza. Sus im√°genes tienen como objetivo concienciar sobre la crisis ecol√≥gica a la que se enfrenta la humanidad.  Fascinado por los lugares abandonados donde la naturaleza reclama su lugar en 2018 public√≥ 'Naturalia: A Chronicle of Contemporary Ruins', donde se plantea la pregunta fundamental: ¬øcu√°l es el lugar de los humanos en la Tierra y su relaci√≥n con la naturaleza?  Earth Photo, el concurso y exposici√≥n internacional creado por Forestry England y la Royal Geographical Society, tiene como objetivo fomentar el debate sobre el medio ambiente contando historias sobre el mundo natural, sus habitantes y nuestro tratamiento de ambos.  Se trata de un concurso muy joven, con tan solo tres ediciones, pero que goza de muy buena salud. En esta edici√≥n han participado m√°s de 2.600 fotograf√≠as llegadas de todas partes del planeta. De esta gran cantidad de fotos se seleccionaron 54 finalistas, cuyos trabajos mostraban el impacto del cambio clim√°tico y las consecuencias del comportamiento humano en nuestro planeta.  Todas las fotos finalistas en el link de la biograf√≠a üì≤ https://bit.ly/36ZN8DZ üì∏ Jonk / Earth Photo 2020

Description: El agua, la base de la vida en la Tierra, comenz√≥ este lunes (07.12.2020) a cotizar en el mercado de futuros de materias primas debido a la escasez de este bien, cuyo precio fluctuar√° ahora como lo hacen el petr√≥leo, el oro o el trigo, inform√≥ el CME Group.  El √≠ndice Nasdaq Veles California Water Index, con el "ticker" NQH2O, se basa en un indicador de precios de los futuros del agua en California que hoy cotizaba a unos 486,53 d√≥lares por acre-pie, una medida de volumen utilizada normalmente en Estados Unidos equivalente a 1.233 metros c√∫bicos.  El precio del agua en California se ha duplicado en el √∫ltimo a√±o seg√∫n este indicador y con la mayor escasez de este bien, junto al aire clave para la vida, la llegada al mercado de materias primas permitir√° seg√∫n los expertos una mejor gesti√≥n del riesgo futuro vinculado a este bien.  Agricultores, fondos o municipios podr√°n protegerse o especular ante los cambios en el precio del agua.  China y Estados Unidos son los principales consumidores del mundo de agua y seg√∫n Naciones Unidas 2.000 millones de personas viven en pa√≠ses con graves problemas de acceso al agua, mientras que en los pr√≥ximos a√±os dos tercios del planeta podr√≠an experimentar escasez de agua y millones de personas verse desplazadas.  La explotaci√≥n excesiva de este recurso por el sector primario, la industria y el consumo humano, as√≠ como el cambio clim√°tico, han llevado a que este recurso sea cada vez m√°s escaso.

Description: O ministro do Meio Ambiente, Ricardo Salles, anunciou nesta ter√ßa-feira que o Brasil assumiu o compromisso de zerar as emiss√µes de gases do efeito estufa at√© 2060. A meta est√° inclu√≠da na Contribui√ß√£o Nacional Determinada (NDC), um conjunto de metas que o Brasil deve enviar √† Conven√ß√£o-Quadro das Na√ß√µes Unidas para a Mudan√ßa Clim√°tica e que prev√™ que a√ß√µes os pa√≠ses tomar√£o ap√≥s 2020 para evitar ou mitigar os efeitos do aquecimento global.  No an√∫ncio, Salles tamb√©m disse que o Brasil poder√° ‚Äúconsiderar‚Äù antecipar essa meta se passar a receber US$ 10 bilh√µes por ano de pa√≠ses ricos.  A meta apresentada pelo Brasil √© igual √† da China, que recentemente anunciou que tamb√©m pretende zerar as suas emiss√µes dos gases do efeito estufa at√© 2060. Pa√≠ses da Uni√£o Europeia, no entanto, anunciaram que pretende zerar as suas at√© 2050.  O an√∫ncio feito por Salles n√£o detalhou de que forma o Brasil pretende atingir essa meta. Os detalhes dever√£o ser apresentados na quarta-feira pelo Minist√©rio das Rela√ß√µes Exteriores (MRE).  Salles deixou claro que o Brasil pode antecipar sua meta se passar a receber recursos internacionais por meio de mecanismos previstos no Acordo de Paris, entre eles, o pagamento por servi√ßos ambientais.  O ministro, no entanto, n√£o quis dizer para quando a meta poderia ser antecipada. Segundo ele, "s√≥ as condi√ß√µes do ano a ano √© que determinar√£o".  Na avalia√ß√£o do secret√°rio-executivo do Observat√≥rio do Clima (grupo que agrega 56 ONGs que atuam na defesa do meio ambiente), M√°rcio Astrini, a meta apresentada pelo Brasil √© ‚Äúfraca e vazia‚Äù.  "Essa meta √© fraca porque ela n√£o considera o que pa√≠ses desenvolvidos como os da Uni√£o Europeia e Reino Unido j√° anunciaram, que √© zerar as emiss√µes at√© 2050. Isso tira o Brasil do jogo. E √© vazia porque vem de um governo que incentiva desmatamento e queimadas. S√£o dois anos de governo Bolsonaro e dois anos de aumento no desmatamento", afirmou Astrini.  #JornalOGlobo  Foto: Florian Plaucheur / AFP

Description: En estado cr√≠tico la Gran Barrera de Coral de Australia ¬∑ Nos fijamos en los corales blanquecinos en la costa noreste de Australia. Ese feo color y blanqueamiento solo habla de una cosa: la Gran Barrera de Coral est√° en estado cr√≠tico. Adem√°s la salud de los arrecifes y la diversidad de animales han empeorado debido a ese blanqueamiento mayor en los a√±os 2016, 2017 y 2020. La Gran Barrera de Coral, declarada Patrimonio de la Humanidad en 1981 por la UNESCO, es el ecosistema de arrecifes de coral m√°s extenso y espectacular del planeta y est√° cada d√≠a m√°s amenazado.   #BarreraDeCoral #Australia #Naturaleza #PatrimonioDeLaHumanidad

Description: There is a race against time to save one of Mexico‚Äôs battered coral reefs from climate change.‚Å£  ‚Å£ In an unusual experiment, a coral reef, which runs 28 kilometers south of Canc√∫n, is now insured against hurricanes. The policy provides money for a team of locals known as ‚Äúthe Brigade‚Äù to repair corals, piece by piece, in the days after storms.‚Å£  ‚Å£ The Brigade, an assortment of tour guides, diving instructors, park rangers, fishermen and researchers, are ‚Äúlike paramedics,‚Äù said Mar√≠a del Carmen Garc√≠a Rivas, a leader of the group and director of the national park that manages the reef.‚Å£  ‚Å£ ‚ÄúThe more days that pass, the less chance they have of survival,‚Äù she added.‚Å£  ‚Å£ The race to repair the reef is more than an ecological fight; it‚Äôs also a radical experiment in finance. The reef could be the first natural structure in the world with its own insurance policy. And this year, Hurricane Delta‚Äôs force triggered the first payout ‚Äî about $850,000 to be used for the reef‚Äôs repairs.‚Å£  ‚Å£ In this area of Mexico, like so many parts of the world, humans have weakened coral, tiny tentacled animals that secrete layers of limestone to build outer skeletons for themselves. Rising sea temperatures, ocean acidification, sewage pollution and overfishing leave coral more vulnerable to hurricane damage.‚Å£ And hurricanes themselves are becoming more severe because of climate change. This year, the Atlantic has seen the most named storms on record.‚Å£ Tap the link in our bio to read more about the team‚Äôs efforts to restore the reef, and how environmentalists and insurance companies behind the policy hope it becomes a model for protecting other far-flung coastlines. Photo by @danielberehulak‚Å£

Description: Numerous studies have linked bigger wildfires in America to climate change from the burning of coal, oil and gas. Scientists have said climate change has made California much drier, meaning trees and other plants are more flammable.‚Å† ‚Å† Orange County fire officials say the Bond Fire started as a house fire, but powerful winds pushed the flames.‚Å† ‚Å† The fire, about 50 miles southeast of Los Angeles, is burning near the same area of October‚Äôs Silverado Fire, which forced tens of thousands of people to evacuate.‚Å† ‚Å† The new blaze broke out as Southern California utilities cut the power to tens of thousands of customers to avoid the threat of wildfires during the notorious Santa Anas.‚Å†

Description: La vulnerabilidad del delta del Ebro frente a un mar que le sigue ganando terreno se ha evidenciado una vez m√°s. Ya no hacen faltan borrascas descomunales, como el Gloria, para recordar la necesidad de tener un plan de acci√≥n global frente a los efectos de la crisis clim√°tica.  El √∫ltimo temporal, con rachas continuadas de viento de 40 kil√≥metros hora durante 16 horas, ha azotado varios de los puntos m√°s vulnerables de la l√≠nea de costa. Uno de las m√°s evidentes e impactantes, la rotura parcial de la barra del Trabucador, el fr√°gil istmo de arena de seis kil√≥metros que une el Delta con la reserva natural de la Punta de la Banya, una pen√≠nsula. Pero no es el √∫nico.  La fuerza del mar ha castigado la Illa de Buda, tambi√©n de gran valor medio ambiental; la zona de la playa de la Marquesa, en Deltebre, que ya sufri√≥ graves inundaciones de arrozales (3.000 hect√°reas) con el Gloria; o la Bassa de l'Arena y el Arenal.  La afectaci√≥n en el Trabucador, con un canal abierto por el mar de unos 150 metros de ancho, obligar√° al ministerio para la Transici√≥n Ecol√≥gica a actuar con la en√©sima aportaci√≥n de arena. Fuentes del mismo ministerio destacan que el litoral deltaico esta vez "ha aguantado razonablemente bien con excepci√≥n del Trabucador" y estiman que se deber√°n aportar 150.000 m¬≥ m√°s de arena en este punto. La actuaci√≥n se realizar√° en "unos meses", a√±aden.  Despu√©s del Gloria, el Gobierno ya gast√≥ alrededor de un mill√≥n de euros para aportar 350.000 m¬≥ de tierra para reconstruir parte del Trabucador. Las roturas son continuas y varios grupos ecologistas, incluida la Plataforma en defensa de l'Ebre, advierten que la soluci√≥n est√° r√≠o arriba, para hacer bajar por el Ebro los sedimentos retenidos en los pantanos.  #deltadelebre #deltadelebro #crisisclimatica #terresdelebre #terresdelebrenatural

Description: Un pa√≠s solo prosperar√° en la medida que se respete el conocimiento. Una antigua premisa que Chile no ha puesto en pr√°ctica en los √∫ltimos a√±os y que se agudiza una vez m√°s, con la inversi√≥n en Ciencia que establece el Presupuesto 2021, por estos d√≠as discutido en el Congreso.  Entre otras cifras, los recursos podr√≠an disminuir de 0,38% a un 0,34% del PIB. Esto supone una baja del 9%, equivalente a $65 mil millones. Las universidades, por su parte, pierden m√°s de $42 mil millones. Antes de la pandemia, nuestro pa√≠s ten√≠a el menor presupuesto en I+D y 1/8 del promedio de cient√≠ficos de la OCDE.  Se trata, a todas luces, de una medida absolutamente incomprensible y carente de visi√≥n. ¬øCu√°l es el Chile que queremos construir a futuro? Los impactos ser√°n profundos y de largo plazo. Uno de ellos, por ejemplo: estamos arriesgando perder a toda una generaci√≥n de investigadores formados con recursos p√∫blicos en nuestro territorio y en el extranjero.  La inversi√≥n p√∫blica ‚Äìy por cierto tambi√©n la privada‚Äì es fundamental para impulsar proyectos de investigaci√≥n y financiar la infraestructura y equipamiento necesario para el trabajo de estos cient√≠ficos. El pa√≠s enfrenta enormes desaf√≠os, claves para su desarrollo, y la generaci√≥n de conocimiento no puede estar por detr√°s de ellos.  El cambio clim√°tico, el impulso a las energ√≠as renovables, las enfermedades cr√≥nicas, el consumo de alcohol y drogas en poblaciones juveniles, la obesidad infantil‚Ä¶ todos estos retos demandan personas capaces de comprenderlos. Con mayor masa cr√≠tica de personas generando conocimiento en todas las √°reas vamos a poder avanzar mucho mejor como pa√≠s hacia un desarrollo integral.  No se entiende que el pa√≠s disminuya el fomento a la ciencia, la innovaci√≥n y la tecnolog√≠a, especialmente despu√©s de lo que hemos vivido en los √∫ltimos meses. La red universitaria ha sido un pilar de la capacidad de testeo del pa√≠s, las universidades han contribuido a dise√±ar ventiladores y otras soluciones y cient√≠ficos lideran estudios cl√≠nicos en vacunas para covid-19 en Chile.
ImageText: OPINI√ìN Presupuesto de Ciencia: ¬øQu√© Chile queremos construir? por Cecilia Hidalgo 29 de noviembre de de 2020

Description: @elmostrador_cultura La diversa extensi√≥n del territorio terrestre y marino de Chile hace indispensable conocer en profundidad el funcionamiento de sus ecosistemas, para la toma de decisiones informada por el conocimiento cient√≠fico. Esto cobra especial relevancia en los momentos cr√≠ticos que enfrenta el pa√≠s, con la crisis sanitaria y socio-ambiental adem√°s del cambio clim√°tico, donde variadas voces han hecho el llamado a repensar el futuro del pa√≠s hacia un desarrollo sostenible. Para lo cual se requiere mayor inversi√≥n en ciencia, tecnolog√≠a e innovaci√≥n (CTI).  Sin embargo, el Presupuesto de la Naci√≥n 2021 presentado por el Gobierno, si bien contempla un aumento de 9,5% respecto al 2020, implica diversos ajustes, siendo uno de los m√°s comentados la reducci√≥n presupuestaria en el √≠tem correspondiente a los programas del Ministerio de Ciencia y Tecnolog√≠a. Un ejemplo de ello es que los recursos destinados al Fondo de Innovaci√≥n, Ciencia y Tecnolog√≠a (FONDECYT) decrecieron alrededor de 16.000 millones de pesos.  Esta situaci√≥n gener√≥ preocupaci√≥n en la Red chilena de Sitios de Estudio Socio-ecol√≥gicos de Largo Plazo (LTSER-Chile), Fundaci√≥n sin fines de lucro que re√∫ne 9 sitios de estudio que realizan investigaciones ecol√≥gicas de largo plazo, proveyendo un registro continuo y de alta calidad de variables biol√≥gicas y f√≠sicas relevantes, adem√°s de indicadores de tendencias clim√°ticas y ambientales en ecosistemas representativos del sur de Sudam√©rica. Por otro lado, cada sitio tiene interacciones con los habitantes del territorio donde se emplazan, que van desde la educaci√≥n ambiental y a divulgaci√≥n cient√≠fica, hasta iniciativas para solucionar problemas socio-ecol√≥gicos locales.  üëâcontin√∫a leyendo en el link de la nota ‚ùóÔ∏è#presupuesto #ciencia #chile

Description: The climate impact of flying may be three times worse than previously thought, EU researchers have said.  Flight contrails, the long lines left in the sky by soaring planes, are the planet-heating culprit. They contain gasses and particles including nitrogen oxides, water vapor and soot which have an understudied warming impact. "Aviation emissions are currently warming the climate at approximately three times the rate of that associated with CO2 emissions alone," the study by EU aviation regulator EASA said.  Official estimates of aviation's carbon impact currently only include carbon dioxide, which the study suggests may only account for a third of the actual climate heating effect. The report has been submitted to the European Commission this week as it considers how to regulate aviation in the coming decades.  Jo Dardenne, aviation manager at campaign group Transport & Environment, said: ‚ÄúIt confirms that carbon emissions are only the tip of the iceberg when accounting for aviation‚Äôs climate impact. Contrails and other non-CO2 effects of aviation need to be urgently tackled to avert climate crisis."
ImageText: The climate impact of flying may be three times what we thought @channel4news

Description: Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è President-elect Joe Biden on Monday appointed John Kerry as his special presidential envoy for climate, underscoring his commitment to tackling the global crisis and offering a symbolic rebuke to President Trump's lack of leadership on the issue. The appointment previews a shift in policy and approach from Trump‚Äôs repeated denial of the scientific reality of the crisis and systematic rollback of environmental policies. Kerry, who was President Barack Obama's secretary of state, will be a Cabinet-level official in Biden's administration and will sit on the National Security Council. "This marks the first time that the NSC will include an official dedicated to climate change, reflecting the president-elect's commitment to addressing climate change as an urgent national security issue," the Biden transition team said. Tap the link in our bio to learn more.‚Å† ‚Å† (üì∏: Pablo Blazquez Dominguez/Getty Images Europe)
ImageText: CNN Biden prioritizes the climate crisis by naming John Kerry special envoy for climate Kerry, who was Obama's secretary of state, will be a Cabinet-level official in Biden's administration and will sit on the National Security Council

Description: Joe Biden‚Äôs transition to the presidency has formally begun.  On Tuesday, Biden introduced 6 of the top officials he has selected to serve as part of his national security team, saying that together they would reinstate the U.S. as a global leader countering terrorism, extremism, the climate crisis and nuclear proliferation.  ‚ÄúAmerica is back,‚Äù said Biden, surrounded by the team on a socially distanced stage in Wilmington, Del. He said the officials were ‚Äúready to lead the world, not retreat from it.‚Äù  Biden highlighted a number of ‚Äúfirsts‚Äù on the team, including Avril Haines, a former deputy director of the C.I.A., who would be the first woman to serve as director of national intelligence if she is confirmed, and Alejandro Mayorkas, who would be the first Latino and first immigrant to lead the Department of Homeland Security. And Biden chose former Secretary of State John Kerry as his climate envoy, a role that does not require Senate confirmation, ensuring that for the first time, a principal on the National Security Council would have a full-time job fighting climate change.  Biden‚Äôs transition teams began reaching out across Washington on Tuesday, after President Trump‚Äôs administration formally cleared the way for an orderly transfer of power. After more than a 2-week delay after Biden‚Äôs victory in the election, there are just 57 days left until his inauguration. Biden has said the holdup of the transition threatened national security by depriving his team of critical briefings. And he warned that distribution of vaccines to combat the coronavirus would be at risk if his advisers could not work side-by-side with current health officials. Tap the link in our bio for the latest updates.

Description: Is it a dog kennel?üêï¬†Is it a house?üè†¬†Nope, it‚Äôs actually a very sophisticated satellite.üõ∞Ô∏è¬†Sentinel-6 "Michael Freilich" has blasted skyward from California, US, and will be critical in helping us understand climate change. Not only will it track sea levels, it will measure the shape of the world‚Äôs oceans AND reveal how the great mass of waters is moving around the globe. The 1.3-tonne satellite was taken aloft from the Vandenberg base on a SpaceX Falcon-9 rocket. Click the link in our bio to find out more. (üì∑Nasa) #Nasa #Space #ClimateChange #BBCNews

Description: A week after it sent four astronauts to the International Space Station for the first time, SpaceX launched the first of two satellites Saturday that will monitor sea level rise over the next decade.‚Å† ‚Å† NASA's Sentinel 6-Michael Freilich oceanography satellite ‚Äì a joint venture with the European Space Agency ‚Äì began a five-and-a-half-year mission to collect "the most accurate data yet on global sea level and how our oceans are rising in response to climate change," according to NASA.‚Å† ‚Å† The mission also will collect information on atmospheric temperature and humidity to improve weather forecasts and climate models.‚Å† ‚Å† The satellite headed into orbit on a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket, which launched from California's Vandenberg Air Force base at 12:17 p.m. ET Saturday. ‚Å† ‚Å† #nasa #space #satellite #rocket #spacex
ImageText: NASA USA TODAY SpaceX launched the first of two satellites.

Description: @revistageneracionm Una pradera sana requiere que el suelo contenga los minerales y microorganismos adecuados para su desarrollo. Para esto es esencial la materia org√°nica, que por lo dem√°s, es la principal responsable de la retenci√≥n de agua en el suelo y proviene de la descomposici√≥n de los residuos de plantas, animales y microorganismos del subsuelo y micorriza (ambiente que rodea a las ra√≠ces).  Actualmente, casi la mitad de los suelos (49,1%) de Chile presentan erosi√≥n, especialmente en la zona centro de nuestro pa√≠s y de acuerdo con los estudios que existen sobre el tema, el sector agropecuario es uno de los principales emisores de gases de efecto invernadero, que junto con los efectos del uso de tierras, est√°n entre las principales causas del calentamiento global.  Adem√°s, la agricultura y la ganader√≠a contribuyen directamente a las emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero por medio de las t√©cnicas empleadas para el cultivo de granos y monocultivos, y la cr√≠a de ganado.  A ra√≠z de esto, en Pirque se levant√≥ un centro de ganader√≠a regenerativa, impulsado por el equipo de la Estaci√≥n Experimental Agr√≠cola Julio Ort√∫zar Pereira, el cual que tiene como objetivo revertir efectos generados por el cambio clim√°tico mediante la restauraci√≥n de la materia org√°nica y la biodiversidad del suelo: incrementando as√≠ la capacidad de almacenamiento de carbono en el mismo. üëâcontin√∫a leyendo en el link de la nota ‚ùóÔ∏è#ganaderia #animales
