Description: Arsenal have become the first Premier League football team to sign up to a United Nations plan to help tackle the climate crisis.   The club hopes to inspire fans across the world to be more sustainable after joining the UN Sports for Climate Action Framework, which includes five key principles aimed at reducing carbon footprints and promoting sustainability.  Arsenal have implemented several "green schemes" in the past. Their home ground, the Emirates Stadium, has energy-saving LED lighting and saves 20,000 single-use plastic cups per game through a reusable cup scheme.

Description: Tackling the #climate crisis will once again take center stage under Joe #Biden, but with an important shift. Although the #energy #politics of the last dozen years were defined by #coal ‚Äî with President #Obama working to accelerate its decline and President #Trump trying and failing to revive it ‚Äî the fiercest battles of the Biden era are likely to revolve around another fossil fuel, natural #gas.  The president-elect campaigned on 100% climate-friendly electricity by 2035, a timeline that could squeeze natural gas ‚Äî currently the nation‚Äôs largest power source ‚Äî off the power grid in the next 15 years. The short list of climate priorities on Biden‚Äôs transition website also includes ‚Äúdirect cash rebates and low-cost financing to upgrade and electrify home appliances,‚Äù which could mean replacing gas furnaces, water heaters and stoves with electric alternatives.  It‚Äôs an ambitious agenda that‚Äôs sure to expose fault lines in the Democratic Party. The battle is already underway, with rumors circulating that President Obama‚Äôs second-term Energy secretary, Ernest Moniz, is a top candidate to get his old job back under President Biden.  üì∏ = @alschaben  ‚úçÔ∏è = Sammy Roth  #democrats #energy #electric #naturalgas #powersource #climatechange #climatecrisis #climateaction #powergrid
ImageText: The 'war on coal' is over. The next climate battle has just begun

Description: Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è Amazon founder Jeff Bezos announced Monday that he will give $791 million in grants as part of his Bezos Earth Fund to 16 organizations that are working to protect the environment. The fund is part of the CEO's $10 billion pledge to support scientists, activists, NGOs and organizations working to protect the environment. "I've spent the past several months learning from a group of incredibly smart people who've made it their life's work to fight climate change and its impact on communities around the world," Bezos wrote in an Instagram post on Monday announcing the news. "I'm inspired by what they're doing, and excited to help them scale." The full list of grantees are a mix of big name NGOs, labs, reforestation and climate justice groups. Description: The most powerful Atlantic hurricane of 2020 has hit Nicaragua, just two weeks after the country bore the brunt of another devastating storm. Hurricane Iota made landfall as a category four storm near the town of Puerto Cabezas, where patients had to be evacuated from a makeshift hospital after its roof was ripped off. Residents took cover in shelters, and there are fears of food shortages. "I haven't eaten. I don't know where I'm going to sleep," 80-year-old Prinsila Glaso told AFP news agency in the wake of the storm. The US National Hurricane Center said¬†Iota was now a category two storm,¬†but warned it could bring life-threatening storm surges, catastrophic winds, flash flooding and landslides. Scientists expect climate change to make Atlantic storms stronger. Hurricanes are powered by warm seas and warmer air means that storms can dump more water on land, increasing their destructive power. The hurricane is forecast to move inland across the country before hitting southern Honduras. (Reuters/Getty/Nasa) #Iota #Storm #Hurricane #Weather #Nature #Nicaragua #Climate¬†#bbcnews

Description: @revistageneracionm El estudio "Determinaci√≥n del riesgo de los impactos del cambio clim√°tico en las costas de Chile", dirigido por Patricio Winckler, experto en cambio clim√°tico, calentamiento global y construcciones costeras, determin√≥ que 18 mil horas de cierres han generado las marejadas los √∫ltimos diez a√±os. Son ocho los principales puertos chilenos con aguas abiertas m√°s afectados, tanto estatales  como concesionados: Arica, Iquique, Antofagasta, Coquimbo, Quintero, Valpara√≠so, San Antonio y San Vicente.  El acad√©mico de la Escuela de Ingenier√≠a Civil Oce√°nica de la Universidad de Valpara√≠so asegura que ‚Äúlos cierres de puertos generan un impacto econ√≥mico alt√≠simo a los armadores de las naves, concesionarios, empresas que conforman la cadena log√≠stica y, a fin de cuenta, a quienes compramos los productos que por all√≠ transitan‚Äù.  S√≥lo este a√±o el puerto de San Antonio ha debido realizar cerca de cuarenta cierres, lo cual provoca trastornos importantes a juicio del experto, ya que seg√∫n explica ‚Äúmuchos de esos buques se han debido desviar a Valpara√≠so, causando complicaciones en la operaci√≥n log√≠stica y costos adicionales en la transferencia de carga‚Äù.  ‚ÄúEl problema es que en la zona central hay pocas bah√≠as abrigadas en forma natural y los puertos de Quintero, Valpara√≠so y San Antonio tienen un grado de abrigo parcial ante las marejadas generadas frente a la zona central de Chile‚Äù, se√±ala Winckler.  Desde la l√≥gica de la adaptaci√≥n al cambio clim√°tico, el acad√©mico asegura que ‚Äúexisten estrategias de adaptaci√≥n a corto y largo plazo en t√©rminos de mejorar la operatividad de los sitios de atraque y garantizar el desempe√±o de la infraestructura portuaria‚Äù.
ImageText: Cambio clim√°tico: estudio en costas chilenas se√±ala que marejadas de los √∫ltimos 10 a√±os provocaron 18 mil horas de cierres de puertos por Generaci√≥n M 17 noviembre, 2020

Description: Could Brazil's president soon suffer the same fate as his populist international ally Donald Trump?   In what has been described by one Brazilian newspaper as "the Bolsonarista breakdown‚Äù, Bolsonaro suffered several setbacks in recent local elections after candidates he championed performed poorly against the mainstream parties.  The elections were the first opportunity to measure the strength of his anti-establishment movement since his 2018 election victory.  Bolsonaro, who has yet to publicly recognise Joe Biden‚Äôs election victory, has been accused of catastrophically mishandling the coronavirus epidemic, which has left more than 165,000 Brazilians dead.   His record on the climate crisis has also drawn criticism, having slashed environmental protections at a time of devastating wildfires in the Amazon.
ImageText: Brazil's president Jair Bolsonaro suffers setback after poor results in local elections G

Dort, wo sie auch stattfindet. Es ist ja nicht nur ein Problem von Aktivisten und Wissenschaftlern. Sondern von uns allen‚Äú, sagt Neubauer.¬† Auf die Frage, ob die Corona-Pandemie die Klima-Bewegung lahmgelegt habe, entgegnet die Aktivistin: ‚ÄûEs macht die Arbeit schwieriger und verlangsamt vieles. Description: Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è President-elect Joe Biden‚Äôs climate plan could put the Paris Agreement‚Äôs goal of limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius ‚Äúwithin striking distance,‚Äù says the Climate Action Tracker, a non-profit analysis group. Biden‚Äôs plan includes a pledge to reach net-zero emissions by 2050, a $1.7 trillion investment in clean energy and green jobs, and calls for an end to fossil fuel subsidies and new oil and gas permits on public lands. If fulfilled, Biden‚Äôs plan would decrease global warming by 0.1 degrees Celsius by the end of the century, the Climate Action Tracker found. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about Biden‚Äôs climate plan. (üì∏: Tasos Katopodis/Getty Images)‚Å†
ImageText: CNN Experts say Biden climate plan could put Paris goals 'within striking distance' Biden's plan includes a pledge to reach net-zero emissions by 2050, a $1.7 trillion investment in clean energy and re-entry into the Paris Agreement

Description: As news broke that Joe Biden had defeated Donald Trump in the race for the White House, Democratic supporters took to the streets across the US to celebrate.  Biden spent his first full day as US president-elect determined to hit the ground running, as he confronts the fast-spreading coronavirus, high unemployment, systemic racism, the climate crisis and a bitterly divided nation.  Trump has still refused to concede defeat, insisting he would press ahead with legal challenges from Monday.

Description: Ahora somos nosotros quienes podr√≠amos decirle al replicante de Blade Runner "hemos visto cosas que t√∫ no creer√≠as". Hemos visto y seguimos viendo c√≥mo una pandemia cierra el planeta entero, deja una millonaria cuenta de muertos, altera nusetras existencias y arruina las econom√≠as. Hemos visto y seguimos viendo c√≥mo nuestros gobernantes hacen poco m√°s que improvisar ante la tragedia o peor a√∫n, la utilizan con prop√≥sitos electoralistas. Hemos vistos y seguimos viendo c√≥mo un presidente de Estados Unidos se subleva contra la democracia desde la mism√≠sima Casa Blanca. Hemos visto pavorosos incendios en Australia y en la costa oeste de Estados Unidos, quiz√° un anticipo de lo que traer√° el cambio clim√°tico. Hemos visto que nuestras sociedades se asientan sobre un equilibrio muy precario y que ni en las peores circunstancias logramos ponernos de acuerdo unos con otros. De esto no saldremos necesariamente mejores ni peores, pero s√≠ saldremos distintos. Lo que est√° ocurriendo este a√±o tendr√° un enorme impacto en nuestras vidas, tanto en la esfera p√∫blica como en la privada. Al igual que en anteriores cambios de √©poca, los efectos de 2020 ir√°n percibi√©ndose a lo largo de a√±os y d√©cadas. Podemos estar seguros al menos de una cosa: todo esto que hemos visto no se perder√° en el tiempo como l√°grimas en la lluvia.
ImageText: AVIVIR que son d√≠as 'TODOO No SE PERDERA EN EL TIEMPO COMO L√ÅGRIMAS EN LA LLUVIA' SER ENRIC GONZALEZ Âûã

Description: President-elect Joe Biden accepted the job Saturday night in a speech from his home state of Delaware, promising to rebuild a country torn apart by multiple crises after four years of chaotic rule from President Donald Trump.‚Å† ‚Å† ‚ÄúI pledge to be a president who does not seek to divide, but unify, who doesn‚Äôt see red states or blue states, only sees the United States,‚Äù Biden said, adding later: ‚ÄúThe Bible tells us that to everything there is a season ‚Äî a time to build, a time to reap, a time to sow. And a time to heal. This is the time to heal in America.‚Äù‚Å† ‚Å† Biden made clear in the speech he has two major priorities: slowing the spread of the coronavirus pandemic and reuniting a country torn apart by heavily polarized politics and Trump‚Äôs harsh rhetoric. He promised to unveil a task force of top advisers on the pandemic on Monday, and has previously promised to aggressively expand testing capacity once in office.‚Å† ‚Å† Biden boasted he had put together the ‚Äúbroadest, most diverse coalition in history‚Äù in order to win key swing states including Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, and suggested he would use his time in office to combat climate change, improve health care coverage and battle systemic racism.‚Å† ‚Å† He also directly addressed Trump supporters: ‚ÄúI understand your disappointment tonight. I‚Äôve lost a couple of times myself,‚Äù Biden said. ‚ÄúBut let‚Äôs give each other a chance.‚Äù‚Å† ‚Å† Read more at our link in bio. // üì∑ AP Photo
ImageText: IHUFFPOSTI " Too many dreams have been deferred for too long. We must make the promise of this country real for everybody, no matter their race, their ethnicity, their faith, their identity, or their disability." President-Elect Joe Biden

Description: In her first public address as vice president-elect, an emotional Kamala Harris thanked voters on Saturday night for ‚Äúturning out in record numbers to make your voices heard‚Äù and in so doing, ushering in a ‚Äúnew day for America.‚Äù‚Å† ‚Å† Speaking in Wilmington, Delaware, ahead of President-elect Joe Biden, Harris offered a glimpse into her and Biden‚Äôs hopeful vision for the country. ‚Å† ‚Å† ‚ÄúNow is when the real work begins. The good work. The necessary work. The essential work ‚Äï to root out systemic racism in our justice system and society, to combat the climate crisis, and to unite our country and heal the soul of our nation,‚Äù she said.‚Å† ‚Å† Harris has made history as the first woman and person woman of color to be named vice president-elect. In her speech, Harris remembered her mother ‚Äï Shyamala Gopalan Harris, a scientist and immigrant from India ‚Äï and paid tribute to the ‚ÄúBlack women, and Asian, white, Latina and Native American women, who throughout our nation‚Äôs history have paved the way for this moment tonight.‚Äù‚Å† ‚Å† ‚ÄúAnd while I may be the first woman in this office, I will not be the last,‚Äù she said to loud cheers.‚Å† ‚Å† Read more at our link in bio. // üì∑ AP Photo

Description: Today the US has become the first and only country to leave the most important international collaboration to tackle the climate crisis, the Paris Agreement. How long the US departure lasts will depend on who wins the presidency.‚Å† ‚Å† The Paris Agreement was made between countries at the UN in 2015. Being a signatory means countries set their own targets for how they'll cut their carbon emissions over time. The US was a key negotiator five years ago and has been signed up since the beginning.‚Å† ‚Å† Donald Trump says the deal is unfair on America, however, and said he'd exit the agreement in 2017. But through a quirk of administration, the earliest date any country could officially depart was today, the day after the US election.‚Å† ‚Å† But Joe Biden has promised to rejoin the agreement immediately if he wins the election. He could do so by sending a letter to the UN, after which 30 days are needed before it's official. In this scenario it's unlikely there would be a material impact on the US' carbon emissions.‚Å† ‚Å† If Trump wins, the US will remain the only country to have left the Paris Agreement, and will sit beside Turkey and Iran as the few countries that have shunned international commitments on climate action.
ImageText: The US has officially left the Paris Climate Agreement 187 countries signed and ratified One country withdrawn 8 countries signed but not ratified @channel4news

Description: Greta Thunberg has become so firmly entrenched as an icon ‚Äî perhaps the icon ‚Äî of ecological activism that it‚Äôs hard to believe it has been only two years since she first went on a school strike to draw attention to the climate crisis.  In that short time, @gretathunberg, a 17-year-old Swede, has become a figure of international standing, able to meet with sympathetic world leaders and rattle the unsympathetic. Her compelling clarity about the scale of the crisis and moral indignation at the inadequate political response have been hugely influential in shifting public opinion.  An estimated 4 million people participated in the September 2019 global climate strikes that she helped inspire. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs this false image that I‚Äôm an angry, depressed teenager,‚Äù says Thunberg, whose rapid rise is the subject of ‚ÄúI Am Greta,‚Äù a new documentary on Hulu. ‚ÄúBut why would I be depressed when I‚Äôm trying to do my best to change things?‚Äù  Tap the link in our bio to read her interview with @nytmag. Description: These wetlands helped stop flooding from Hurricane Sandy. Now a wholesale big-box store may move in.‚Å£ ‚Å£ A group of Staten Island residents concerned about climate change is challenging the project. To nearby residents fighting to preserve their wetlands, the parcel is a bulwark against disaster. The 28 acres are part of a network of wetlands that in 2012 helped protect the area from the deadliest floods of Hurricane Sandy, which devastated New York City and killed 43 residents. More than half of those people were in Staten Island.‚Å£ ‚Å£ But the land‚Äôs developer has a different vision: a giant BJ‚Äôs Wholesale Club. His company said the project would create at least 200 local jobs, protect 11 acres of the wetlands and include rain gardens and holding tanks to curb flooding. State and city authorities have approved plans for the membership-only warehouse club chain and an 800-car parking lot on the site. ‚Å£ ‚Å£ ‚ÄúWhere does it stop? It‚Äôs like Manifest Destiny for developers,‚Äù said Gabriella Velardi-Ward, who lives in the Mariners Harbor neighborhood surrounding the site and leads a group of residents challenging the project in court. ‚ÄúIn torrential rains, the water moves through our condo community to the wetlands.‚Äù‚Å£ ‚Å£ Tap the link in our bio to read more about this controversial project. Photo by @amr.alfiky.‚Å£

Description: En Chile llevamos m√°s de 15 a√±os esperando que el Congreso avance en una ley de protecci√≥n glaciar. En un contexto de cambio clim√°tico, todos los antecedentes cient√≠ficos nos indican que el principal impacto en Chile ser√° el estr√©s h√≠drico, y en gran proporci√≥n, debido al impacto del cambio clim√°tico sobre los glaciares, de los cuales depende directamente nuestra disponibilidad de agua dulce. A√∫n as√≠, y aunque suene impensado, actualmente los glaciares a√∫n pueden ser destruidos, afectados y hasta constituir derecho de aprovechamiento sobre ellos. Acabamos de vivir un plebiscito hist√≥rico, donde la amplia mayor√≠a de las chilenas y chilenos aprob√≥ un cambio estructural a las bases del modelo de desarrollo, que destruye el medioambiente y refleja inequidades e injusticias que se hicieron insostenibles socialmente. El acceso, goce y cuidado de nuestros bienes comunes es un tema central para una nueva constituci√≥n. La demanda por proveernos de seguridad en el acceso al agua, es un hecho constatado en distintas encuestas, donde la amplia mayor√≠a se√±ala estar preocupada y consciente de este tema. Sin embargo, quienes han liderado el status quo han negado por 15 a√±os el avance de un proyecto que proteja a los glaciares, incluso anotando esta semana aplazar por m√°s d√≠as la votaci√≥n de este proyecto. Una vez m√°s, el Consejo Minero, representado como sindicato o como el Instituto de Ingenieros en Minas, presenta los mismo argumentos que hoy resultan inexplicables al sentido com√∫n.
ImageText: OPINI√ìN Una ley glaciar para la protecci√≥n de la vida porJosefina Correa 1 noviembre, 2020

Description: üëèüåä La Uni√≥n de Agua Potable Rural (APR) Cuenca del R√≠o Petorca, la zona m√°s afectada por la sequ√≠a que azota a Chile hace 10 a√±os, es una de las tres finalistas en la categor√≠a "Agua" del concurso internacional "Ciudades Transformadoras", que realiza anualmente la ONG del mismo nombre con sede en Amsterdam (Pa√≠ses Bajos) y que premia - a trav√©s de votaci√≥n popular online- experiencias innovadoras del mundo en temas de sustentabilidad y medio ambiente.   La iniciativa nominada, "Agua Para Todos", tiene por objetivo luchar contra la privatizaci√≥n del agua y el impacto del cambio clim√°tico.  Se trata de un sindicato rural de proveedores de agua comunitarios que genera soluciones sostenibles a la crisis h√≠drica mediante el fortalecimiento de la movilizaci√≥n comunitaria, la utilizaci√≥n de tecnolog√≠a socialmente adecuada para conservar y recuperar el agua, y la educaci√≥n ambiental, detall√≥ la Fundaci√≥n Superaci√≥n de la Pobreza, que apoya el proyecto, en un comunicado.

Description: üü° LA CONTRA ‚ÄúAhora todos piden protecci√≥n al Estado y sin ella no hay obediencia‚Äù  Paolo Gerbaudo es profesor del King‚Äôs College y autor de ‚ÄòThe great recoil‚Äô (El gran retroceso). "Tengo 41 a√±os: vivo en Londres y la pandemia me hace descubrir ahora que tambi√©n estamos presos del lugar: apenas hay vuelos a mi Italia".  - Qu√© nos ense√±a lo que vivimos?  + Que esta pandemia es otro cap√≠tulo de la crisis de la globalizaci√≥n, que empez√≥ con la recesi√≥n en el 2008, y ahora topa con el calentamiento global, que ha dejado inoperante el modelo globalizador cl√°sico.  - ¬øLa globalizaci√≥n no ha sacado tambi√©n del hambre a millones de personas?  + Pero el horizonte neoliberal ya no consigue explicar, y menos a√∫n gestionar, sus propias crisis. Es parecido a lo sucedido en los a√±os setenta cuando el paradigma keynesiano fue incapaz de explicar la recesi√≥n y remediarla.  - Pero hoy se vuelve a insistir en grandes inversiones p√∫blicas keynesianas.  + Me refiero a que cuando las tasas de inter√©s ya no se pueden bajar, porque est√°n a cero, y la inflaci√≥n tambi√©n, pero el paro se dispara, los instrumentos cl√°sicos de la doctrina econ√≥mica liberal ya no funcionan.  - ¬øY no funcionar√°n de nuevo cuando acabe la pandemia y vuelva la actividad?  + Veremos, pero mientras lo que hay es una ingente masa de capital especulativo cuyos gestores no saben d√≥nde invertir, y as√≠ acaban sobrevalorando las tecnol√≥gicas...  üì∏ Llibert Teixid√≥, La Vanguardia ‚úçÔ∏è Lee la entrevista completa de Llu√≠s Amiguet en el link de nuestra bio üì≤ https://bit.ly/37VzUcc  #LaContra #entrevistas #LaVanguardia

Description: Nos hab√≠amos convencido de que lo peor que pod√≠a ocurrirle a la econom√≠a era una recesi√≥n como la de 2008. Nos hab√≠amos acostumbrado a pensar que nuestra sanidad p√∫blica era tan buena que pod√≠a soportar cualquier recorte. Cre√≠amos que ciertas personas disparatadas nunca podr√≠an ejercer ciertos cargos pol√≠ticos y que la pol√≠tica, despu√©s de todo, no era m√°s que un reparto de cargos y un emocionante espect√°culo de banderitas. Est√°bamos seguros de que las grandes cat√°strofes como los accidentes nucleares o los tsunamis o los terremotos masivos o las epidemias mortales, siempre ocurr√≠an lejos y que amenazas tan graves como el cambio clim√°tico eran una simple hip√≥tesis remota. Cuando recib√≠amos un aviso general, como lo fue el SIDA, prefer√≠amos ignorarlo. Mi vida, dec√≠amos, es algo que organizo yo privadamente. Evit√°bamos mirar de frente a la realidad o eleg√≠amos de ella solamente la parte que nos conven√≠a. El caso es que ahora la realidad nos ha agarrado por las solapas y nos est√° zarandea de mala manera. Y todav√≠a nos cuesta reaccionar. No s√© cu√°ntos bofetones m√°s tendr√° que darnos la realidad para quitarnos de la cabeza tanta tonter√≠a. __ En @avivir

Description: "These are towns that will be completely wiped away if nothing is done to prevent it." Emerson Boutte is 18 and lives in Jean Lafitte, just outside New Orleans, which has just been hit by Hurricane Zeta. Fifteen years ago, Hurricane Katrina devastated the area, with more than 1,500 people losing their lives in the state of Louisiana alone. But with coastal erosion, hurricanes and flooding all becoming more common and more damaging in towns like this along the Louisiana coastline, climate change is an important factor for many of the people who live there ahead of the US election. Donald Trump and Joe Biden have both focused on jobs in the oil industry when speaking about climate change during the presidential campaign. But Emerson tells @BBCNewsbeat that if one of the candidates "would directly address the climate change... happening in Louisiana, I think that would definitely sway my vote for them". #ClimateChange #USElection #US #Louisiana #BBCNews

Description: In August, the Montanos' house was destroyed by the LNU Lightning Complex Fire, one of more than 10,000 structures lost in record-breaking blazes across the West this year.  The children start walking around the pile that remains. Almost nothing is recognizable. The fridge is a charred metal box. Jennifer Montano pulls up a tangle of wires and realizes it used to be their piano. "Our goal is to make sure they feel this as little as possible," she says.  The family left home when two emergency responders showed up late at night at their house. With the fire moving in fast, the responders told the Montanos they only had 10 minutes to evacuate.  "Once you see fear in a firefighter's eyes," Ryan Montano says, "that's when you know things aren't good."  When they moved here seven years ago, the Montanos loved the views of grassy hillsides and oak trees. The possibility of wildfire didn't occur to them. After wildfires struck other parts of California in recent years, they considered what to take with them if one hit, but they didn't expect a fire to overrun their home and strip everything away.  The Montanos are among millions of people in the West who move into fire-prone landscapes without getting any warning about that risk from the government, real estate agents or sellers. Almost 60 million homes were within less than a mile of a wildfire between 1992 and 2015. And those numbers only continue to grow as climate change increases the risk of bigger, more frequent blazes in the American West.  Tap the link in our bio for the full story as well as six questions you can ask yourself about flood and wildfire risk where you live. (Images: Lauren Sommer/NPR)

Description: It's been a week of bold environmental statements in East Asia with both Japan and South Korea committing to go carbon neutral by 2050.  South Korea is one of the world‚Äôs most fossil fuel-reliant economies, but despite this, the country's president vowed to ‚Äúactively respond‚Äù to the climate emergency.  Earlier this week, Japan's prime minister confirmed the world's third biggest economy would introduce a bolder approach to tacking the climate crisis.  These pledges bring both countries in line with the European Union, which set itself a similar target last year, while China recently announced it would become carbon-free by 2060.
ImageText: South Korea and Japan vow to go carbon neutral by 2050 G

Description: About 15 million properties in the U.S. are prone to flooding, but patchwork and ineffective disclosure laws mean most people get little to no information about flood risk before they move.  A growing body of research suggests that the lack of transparency and growing flood risk due to climate change are leading millions of Americans to put their safety and their financial futures in jeopardy. In fact , studies in multiple states have found that most people living in harm's way did not understand their home's flood risk until after they purchased it. (Images: @rjckseen ‚Ä¢ Ryan Kellman/NPR)  Tap the link in our bio for more on why most Americans get little or no information about flood risk when they move to a new place.  1. A truck sits in still water after Hurricane Laura swept through Cameron Parish, La. The hurricane inflicted at least $8 billion in damage to southwest Louisiana when it hit in late August. 2. Tracye Neldare lives with her husband, Tramelle, in a Baton Rouge, La., home that has been passed down in her family for generations. It flooded in 2016, but they have no plans to move. 3. Lachlan (left) and Lillian Barilleau play in the backyard of their home in Central, La. They were displaced from the house for months after a flood in 2016. Their mother, Loren Barilleau believed they were purchasing a house that would be safe from floods. In fact, federal flood maps obscured the risk, she says. 4. Kevin and Susan Boudreaux have always known about flood risk in Cameron Parish, however, they believe the benefits outweigh the risks. "I tell everybody, my roots are deep. Where would we go? This is home."  5. Akouete Yemey of Roanoke, Va., didn‚Äôt find out that his home was in a flood plain until shortly before he closed on it. Now he keeps emergency bags packed in case his family needs to evacuate. 6.  21 states do not require any information about flood risk to be disclosed to homebuyers, according to the Natural Resources Defense Council. Some of those states are among the most vulnerable to rising seas and climate-driven extreme rain, including Florida, Virginia and Massachusetts.

Fue entonces cuando los plant√≠grados, atra√≠dos por el olor de la basura, empezaron a registrar el veh√≠culo. Incluso cuatro de los ejemplares adultos consiguieron subirse a la carrocer√≠a.  Durante el asedio el conductor del veh√≠culo permaneci√≥ dentro de la cabina llamando a alguien por tel√©fono mientras uno de los osos se apoyaba en el parabrisas.  Aunque todos los osos que aparecen en las im√°genes parecen estar sanos y bien alimentados, el autor del v√≠deo sugiere que el hambre es la principal hip√≥tesis de este asedio. ‚ÄúMiren lo que est√° pasando, los osos tienen hambre. ¬°Ahora el cuarto est√° trepando adentro!‚Äù, exclama el hombre mientras toca el claxon en un intento de ayudar al conductor atrapado dentro del veh√≠culo. Description: Lemurs have found a private refuge in Madagascar. But climate change is forcing conservation scientists to rethink traditional ways of saving this rare and endangered species.  Since 2012 the International Union for Conservation of Nature has named lemurs, which are found only in Madagascar, as the world‚Äôs most endangered group of animals, with 95% either threatened or endangered. Poaching, farming, charcoal cultivation and illegal logging have placed enormous pressure on the country‚Äôs wildlife. The next looming danger is climate change. Warming temperatures threaten to push wildlife out of the conservation areas created to protect it.  ‚ÄúParks and large tracts of land are the core of how we save stuff,‚Äù said Timothy Male, the executive director of a Washington, D.C., environmental think tank. But, he added, small local parks ‚Äútend to be where a lot of dynamism happens.‚Äù  According to conservationists, the most important questions in conservation today lie outside the large protected areas like Makira Natural Park, a rainforest larger than Yosemite National Park. Although these are crucial refuges, half of the remaining rare lemurs, including the silky sifaka, indri and ruffed lemur, eke out their survival in smaller, less pristine places. As habitats shift with the climate, these marginal populations may become just as important to species survival as those in the large parks.  Tap the link in our bio to read more about the conservation of lemurs in Madagascar. Photo by @erikvance.

Dabei fuÃàhrt die Summe all dieser jetzt weltweit getroffenen Entscheidungen zu einer VeraÃànderung des Klimas von morgen. Description: Late-season wildfires are rampaging through Colorado.‚Å£ ‚Å£ Scenes of panic and destruction played out across Northern Colorado on Thursday as a wildfire exploded through the parched woods and valleys around Rocky Mountain National Park, offering a grim example of how climate change is making fire seasons longer and more destructive across the West.‚Å£ ‚Å£ ‚ÄúThis is the worst of the worst of the worst,‚Äù said Sheriff Brett Schroetlin of Grand County, where the East Troublesome Fire had burned about 170,000 acres by Thursday evening.‚Å£ ‚Å£ Fire crews and residents were staggered by the wildfire‚Äôs speed and ferocity. It grew at a pace of 6,000 acres per hour, racing into Rocky Mountain National Park, forcing the park to close down, and jumping over the Continental Divide. By Thursday afternoon, the fire was menacing the resort town of Estes Park, on the eastern side of the national park, turning skies smoky yellow and forcing rounds of mandatory evacuations there.‚Å£ ‚Å£ Firefighters are also battling to contain the Cameron Peak Fire, north of Rocky Mountain National Park, which has burned since August and this week grew into the largest fire recorded in Colorado history.‚Å£ ‚Å£ Tap the link in our bio to read more about the fires in Colorado and how, after a season of hellish wildfires throughout the West, there is new evidence that climate change and rampant growth are creating perfect breeding grounds for fire. Photo by Jessy Ellenberger, via @apnews

Description: Snow, storms and tornados were some of the spectacular natural phenomena captured in this year‚Äôs Royal Meterological Society's Weather Photographer of the Year award. He took the photo on Manhattan's Brooklyn Bridge in 2018, as a demonstration of how El Nino was affecting the world's climate. He told the RMETS he hoped his images could encourage the fight against climate change.  üì∑: Rudolf Sulgan, Emma Rose Karsten, Alexey Trofimov, Vu Trung Huan, Maja Kraljik, Kolesnik Stephanie Sergeevna / @rmets_   #Weather #Photography #WPotY

Description: Two years ago, California saw its most devastating wildfire history - in a town called Paradise.  Year after year, record-breaking flames sweep through the forests of the Golden State and in 2018, claimed 86 lives in Paradise alone.  Meanwhile, the president says he doesn‚Äôt believe in the science and recently rejected California‚Äôs request for disaster relief aid.  Ayshah Tull is in California, where she meets a man who spent 30 hours defending his house from the wildfire and the couple who have rebuilt their decimated home.  These are the Californians on the frontline of climate change.

Description: US President Donald Trump and Joe Biden clashed in the final debate of the US election campaign. ¬† The debate covered six sections including #COVID19, national security, American families, race in America, climate change and leadership. The candidates' microphones were switched off this time while their rival made a two-minute introductory statement on the six topics. ¬† Joe Biden told the debate in Nashville, Tennessee: "Anyone who's responsible for that many [COVID-19] deaths should not remain president of the United States of America‚Äù to which Trump responded by saying, "We're rounding the corner. It's going away". ¬† On the topic of race in America, Biden called the current president "one of the most racist presidents we've had in modern history", with Trump claiming he was the "least racist person in this room". ¬† #Election #US #Trump #Biden #Debate #Tennessee #coronavirus #pandemic #race #climatechange #America #campaign

Description: President Trump and Joe Biden delivered starkly divergent closing arguments to the country in the final presidential debate on Thursday, offering opposite prognoses for the coronavirus pandemic and airing irreconcilable differences on rescuing the economy, bolstering the health care system, fighting climate change and reshaping immigration policy.  Of all the disagreements between the two candidates, none blazed more brightly than their assessments of the American experience battling the coronavirus.  The president did say for the first time, ‚ÄúI take full responsibility‚Äù for the impact of the virus. Then he quickly sought to skirt blame. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not my fault that it came here ‚Äî it‚Äôs China‚Äôs fault,‚Äù he said.  Biden responded, ‚ÄúAnyone who‚Äôs responsible for that many deaths should not remain as president of the United States of America,‚Äù and added: ‚ÄúI will end this. I will make sure we have a plan.‚Äù  Trump stuck to the sunny message he has delivered at recent campaign rallies, promising a vaccine in short order and citing his own recovery from a bout with the virus as an example of medical progress. The president boasted that he was now ‚Äúimmune‚Äù to the disease and insisted that the virus was fading away in states like Texas and Florida, even as case counts are on the rise across the country. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been congratulated by the heads of many countries on what we‚Äôve been able to do,‚Äù Trump said, without offering specifics.  Biden, in response, pressed a focused and familiar line of attack against the president, faulting him for doing ‚Äúvirtually nothing‚Äù to fend off the pandemic early this year and heading into the coldest part of the year with no defined plan to control the virus. Holding up a mask, Biden said he would encourage all Americans to don one and would ramp up rapid testing on a national scale.  Tap the link in our bio for complete coverage of the final presidential debate.
ImageText: If we just wore these masks, evernmen

Description: Por primera vez desde que existen registros, el mar √°rtico de Siberia no ha comenzado a congelarse en octubre.  Seg√∫n The Guardian, el retraso de este fen√≥meno en el mar de Laptev ha sido provocado por un calor anormalmente prolongado en el norte de Rusia. Sin embargo, los cient√≠ficos agregaron que esto se debe adem√°s a la intrusi√≥n de las aguas del Atl√°ntico.  Zachary Labe, investigador postdoctoral de la Universidad Estatal de Colorado, afirm√≥ que la falta de congelaci√≥n hasta ahora este oto√±o (en el hemisferio norte) no tiene precedentes en la regi√≥n √°rtica de Siberia y precis√≥ que estos registros est√°n en l√≠nea con el impacto esperado del cambio clim√°tico provocado por la actividad humana.

Description: 95 million cows make up nearly 2% of total greenhouse gas emissions in the U.S. ‚Äî changing what they eat could help reduce methane emissions and global warming.   Cattle have a multichambered stomach where microbes ferment grass and other tough fibrous vegetation, making it digestible. But this process, called enteric fermentation, also produces methane, a potent planet-warming gas that the cattle mostly belch into the air.  Researchers within and outside the industry are working on ways to reduce emissions from fermentation, through feed supplements or dietary changes. Other efforts aim to lower emissions from the animals‚Äô waste ‚Äî a source of methane as well as another powerful greenhouse gas, nitrous oxide ‚Äî through improved manure storage and handling.  Cattle are far from the largest source of greenhouse gases, which include carbon dioxide, methane and others. Their total contribution is dwarfed by the burning of fossil fuels for electricity, transportation and industry. But considering methane separately, livestock are among the largest sources of that particularly powerful planet-warming gas.  Tap the link in our bio to learn more about cattle feed‚Äôs impact on the climate. Photos and video by @geosteinmetz

Description: The true value of money being raised for poor countries to help them resist the climate crisis is just a third of what rich countries say it is, according to new research by Oxfam.‚Å† ‚Å† As well as being overestimated, the money is often making poor countries poorer, the research argues. That's because up to 80 per cent of finance for poor countries is in the form of loans with interest, meaning they're saddled with even more debt.‚Å† ‚Å† Climate finance is the name given to money which is raised for poor countries to help them cut carbon emissions or adapt to effects of global heating, like flooding or coastal erosion. Under an agreement made at the UN, $100 billion per year was supposed to have been made available for poor countries by this year.‚Å† ‚Å† Oxfam says that the overall target is on track according to what rich countries report. But its analysis found that of the $59.5 billion per year reported in 2017 and 2018, the latest climate finance figures available, only $19-22.5 billion actually funded climate action once loan repayments and interest were taken out.‚Å† ‚Å† Tracy Carty, one of the report authors at Oxfam, said climate finance can be a "lifeline for communities facing record heatwaves, terrifying storms and devastating floods" but that the "excessive use of loans in the name of climate assistance is an overlooked scandal."‚Å† ‚Å† "The world‚Äôs poorest countries, many of whom are already grappling with unsustainable debts, should not be forced to take out loans to respond to a climate crisis not of their making,‚Äù she said.
ImageText: Climate finance help to poor countries 'making them poorer' ulone @channel4news

Description: The world‚Äôs largest tropical wetland has become an inferno.‚Å£ ‚Å£ This year, roughly a quarter of the vast Pantanal wetland in Brazil, one of the most biodiverse places on Earth, has burned in wildfires worsened by climate change. What happens to a rich and unique biome when so much is destroyed?‚Å£ ‚Å£ The wetland, which is larger than Greece and stretches over parts of Brazil, Paraguay and Bolivia, also offers unseen gifts to a vast swath of South America by regulating the water cycle upon which life depends. Its countless swamps, lagoons and tributaries purify water and help prevent floods and droughts ‚Äî they also store untold amounts of carbon, helping to stabilize the climate.‚Å£ ‚Å£ For centuries, ranchers have used fire to clear fields and new land. But this year, drought worsened by climate change turned the wetlands into a tinderbox and the fires raged out of control.‚Å£ ‚Å£ ‚ÄúThe extent of fires is staggering,‚Äù said Douglas C. Morton, who leads the Biospheric Sciences Laboratory at @nasagoddard and studies fire and food production in South America. ‚ÄúWhen you wipe out a quarter of a biome, you create all kinds of unprecedented circumstances.‚Äù‚Å£ ‚Å£ His analysis showed that at least 22% of the Pantanal in Brazil has burned since January, with the worst fires, in August and September, blazing for 2 months straight.‚Å£ ‚Å£ Scientists are scrambling to determine an estimate of animals killed in the fires. While large mammals and birds have suffered casualties, many were able to run or fly away. It appears that reptiles, amphibians and small mammals have fared the worst. In places like California, small animals often take refuge underground during wildfires. But in the Pantanal, scientists say, fires burn underground too, fueled by dried-out wetland vegetation.‚Å£ ‚Å£ Tap the link in our bio to read more. Photos by @mariamagdarre.‚Å£

Description: Wenn MaÃàdchen wegen des Klimawandels nicht mehr zur Schule gehen duÃàrfen.  Bei #Afghanistan denken die meisten vor allem an Kriege und Konflikte. Eine andere gefaÃàhrliche Entwicklung wird dabei oft vergessen: der Klimawandel.   Schon jetzt zaÃàhlt #Afghanistan zu den am staÃàrksten gefaÃàhrdeten LaÃàndern der Welt, die mit den Auswirkungen des Klimawandels konfrontiert sind. Viele Familien koÃànnen sich aufgrund der Ernteeinbu√üen die Schulkosten ihrer Kinder nicht mehr leisten, darunter leiden vor allem die MaÃàdchen. Hinzu kommt: Die Sturzfluten und UÃàberschwemmungen haben viele der schulischen Einrichtungen beschaÃàdigt. Auch unter der Taliban-Herrschaft lag das afghanische Bildungssystem nahezu brach. SchaÃàtzungsweise 3,7 Millionen Kinder gehen nicht zur Schule. Das sind fast die HaÃàlfte aller schulpflichtigen Kinder in Afghanistan. FuÃàr viele Kinder gehen damit NormalitaÃàt und Struktur in einem ohnehin krisengebeutelten Leben verloren.  Die iranische Fotografin @solmazdaryani hat die Folgen des Klimawandels in Afghanistan und die Auswirkungen auf die BevoÃàlkerung dokumentiert. "Es war wirklich ein Schock fuÃàr mich, das Ausma√ü der Katastrophe zu sehen", schreibt die Fotografin Daryani.  Alle Fotos jetzt auf www.spiegel.de #klimawandel #climatechange #klimaschutz #climatecrisis

Description: A cross-border fight over water has erupted in Mexico.  ‚ÄúThis is a war to survive, to continue working, to feed my family,‚Äù said Victor Velderrain, a Mexican farmer who helped lead the takeover of a local dam that supplied water to the U.S.  The Mexican government has been sending water to Texas, leaving growers like Velderrain next to nothing for their thirsty crops. So farmers seized the La Boquilla Dam (above) near Delicias, Chihuahua, one of the border region‚Äôs most important bodies of water. They have refused to allow any of the water to flow to the U.S. for more than a month.  This has been one of the driest years in the past 3 decades for Chihuahua, the Mexican border state responsible for sending the bulk of the water that Mexico owes the U.S. The standoff is the culmination of longstanding tensions over water between the 2 countries that have recently exploded into violence, pitting Mexican farmers against their own president and the global superpower next door.  Negotiating the exchange of water has long been strained. But rising temperatures and long droughts have made the shared rivers along the border more valuable than ever. The dam‚Äôs takeover is a stark example of how far people are willing to go to defend livelihoods threatened by climate change ‚Äî and of the kind of conflict that may become more common with increasingly extreme weather.  Tap the link in our bio to read more about the standoff at La Boquilla Dam and how climate change is exacerbating tensions along the U.S. border with Mexico. Photo by @danielberehulak.

Description: Donald Trump's Supreme Court pick Amy Coney Barrett said climate change is a "a very contentious matter of public debate" at her Supreme Court Hearing. ‚Å† ‚Å† She made the comment in response to questioning from Democratic vice presidential candidate Kamala Harris. ‚Å† ‚Å† Barrett argued that Harris's question was an attempt to elicit her opinion on a "matter of public policy" - despite having confirmed that she agreed with the scientific consensus that Covid-19 is infectious and that smoking causes cancer. ‚Å† ‚Å† The ideologically conservative attorney was nominated to a lifetime post on the court by President Donald Trump, to replace the liberal Justice Ruth Bader Ginsberg who died last month.

Description: "There is no time to lose." That's the message from scientists who have examined Australia's Great Barrier Reef. They say it's lost more than half of its corals since 1995 because of warmer seas driven by climate change. A study - conducted by marine scientists at the ARC Centre of Excellence for Coral Reef Studies in Queensland - found all types of corals had suffered a decline across the world's largest reef system. Prof Terry Hughes, a study co-author, said the area had been "worst affected" by back-to-back mass bleachings which damaged two-thirds of the reef. The process occurs when corals under stress release an algae - known as zooxanthellae - which sees them losing their colour. Corals can recover if normal conditions return, but it can take decades. Tap the link in our bio to find out more about the study and the future of the reef. (üì∑ BBC/ Getty Images) #Coral #GreatBarrierReef #ClimateChange #BBCNews

Description: @agendapais2030 En medio del cambio clim√°tico y de una la sequ√≠a que ha afectado a la zona central en los √∫ltimos a√±os, los caudales del r√≠o Maipo, la principal fuente de agua para la Regi√≥n Metropolitana, se ver√°n disminuidos en meses de verano y primavera hacia mediados y fines de este siglo.  Por eso es necesario replantear el consumo de agua de la ciudad de Santiago, donde a√∫n no hay medidas concretas proyectadas hacia un futuro donde el recurso sea mas escaso.  Natalia Dasencich es la encargada de Asuntos Legales de la Junta de Vigilancia del R√≠o Maipo, una organizaci√≥n de usuarios en torno al R√≠o Maipo, enfocada en resguardar y cuidar el correcto uso y distribuci√≥n del recurso h√≠drico en la Regi√≥n Metropolitana, que abastece de agua potable a m√°s de 7 millones de personas.  "En los √∫ltimos 10 a√±os en la zona central de Chile hemos estado azotados por una sequ√≠a bastante prolongada y extrema que se vino a agudizar muy fuertemente en el a√±o 2019 en que tuvimos que redistribuci√≥n de agua en plena √©poca de riego", plantea  La redistribuci√≥n consiste en tomar agua de usos menos prioritarios para poder abastecer el agua potable de Santiago. "Si bien esa redistribuci√≥n est√° contemplada en la ley, esta temporada que pas√≥ nos encontramos con situaciones bastante extremas porque tuvimos que sacarle al sector de la agricultura del R√≠o Maipo cerca del 50% de sus caudales para entreg√°rselos a la ciudad", advierte Dasencich.  Santiago consume un tercio del caudal en √©poca normal y un 60% en sequ√≠a. El problema es que "en mayo pasado llegamos a destinar a la ciudad hasta el 80% de los caudales y eso trajo como consecuencia un perjuicio bastante para la agricultura y nos revel√≥ ciertos desequilibrios que se dieron dentro del consumo de la ciudad, como usos excesivos, suntuarios y de derroche". #sequia #agua #consumo üëâve la entrevista en el link de la bio‚ùóÔ∏è
ImageText: Natalia Dasencich y la sequ√≠a que afecta al R√≠o Maipo y el agua potable: "Existen desequilibrios dentro del consumo de la ciudad" orLoreto Santiba√±ez 14 octubre, 2020 elme

Description: More than half the corals on Australia's Great Barrier Reef have died over the past 25 years because of rising sea temperatures caused by climate change, according to a new study. ‚Å† ‚Å† A study led by scientists in Australia and published in the science journal Proceedings of the Royal Society found the reef is "increasingly compromised and in decline."‚Å† ‚Å† Branching and table-shaped corals were "the worst affected by record-breaking temperatures that triggered mass bleaching in 2016 and 2017," said co-author professor Terry Hughes. ‚Å† Coral bleaching occurs when water is too warm and corals expel the algae living in their tissues - causing them to turn completely white. ‚Å† ‚Å† The reef is internationally recognised for its outstanding biodiversity. But the loss of corals means a loss of habitat for fish and other sea life. ‚Å† ‚Å† The report included a warning from the authors: "There is no time to lose - we must sharply decrease greenhouse gas emissions asap."‚Å†
ImageText: Half the Great Barrier Reef's coral has died since 1995 @channel4news

Description: La Gran Barrera de Coral australiana podr√≠a perder la capacidad de recuperarse del calentamiento global. Si no se toman medidas r√°pidas a escala global para reducir las emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero, "no nos quedar√° una Gran Barrera de Coral reconocible", advierte Terry Hughes, profesor del Centro de Excelencia ARC para Estudios de Arrecifes de Coral en la Universidad James Cook. #arrecife #coral #calentamientoglobal #efectoinvernadero #aumentodetemperatura #medioambiente #mar #Australia

Description: The German icebreaker and research vessel "Polarstern" arrives at the harbour of nothern German town of Bremerhaven, on Oct. 12, 2020, after a year-long mission, the biggest Arctic expedition in history, bringing home observations from scientists that sea ice is melting at a "dramatic rate" in the region. ‚Å† ‚Å† The researchers' observations have been backed up by US satellite images showing that in 2020, sea ice in the Arctic reached its second-lowest summer minimum on record, after 2012. The Polarstern mission, dubbed MOSAIC, spent 389 days collecting data on the atmosphere, ocean, sea ice and ecosystems to help assess the impact of climate change on the region and the world.‚Å† ‚Å† üì∑: Patrik Stollarz, AFP via @gettyimages‚Å†

Description: El mundo sufri√≥ 6.681 desastres naturales relacionados con el clima en las dos primeras d√©cadas del siglo XXI, un aumento del 80 por ciento con respecto a los 3.656 registrados en los √∫ltimos 20 a√±os del siglo XX, desvela hoy un estudio de la ONU que muestra una vez m√°s los negativos efectos del cambio clim√°tico.  La investigaci√≥n, elaborada por la Oficina de la ONU la Reducci√≥n del Riesgo de Desastres (UNDRR), muestra que entre 2000 y 2019 murieron 1,23 millones de personas en desastres naturales (incluyendo los de origen clim√°tico y los geol√≥gicos, tales como terremotos), que afectaron a 4.200 millones de personas.  En contraste, entre 1980 y 1999 las cat√°strofes naturales, que no incluyen epidemias o pandemias, causaron la muerte de 1,19 millones de personas y afectaron a 3.250 millones. EFE
ImageText: ONU ADVIERTE QUE LOS DESASTRES CLIM√ÅTICOS AUMENTARON UN 80 % EN EL SIGLO XXI 24

Description: Nach einem Jahr im Nordpolarmeer hat der deutsche Forschungseisbrecher Polarstern seinen Heimathafen Bremerhaven erreicht. Damit ging der erste Teil der "Mosaic"-Expedition zur Erforschung des Klimasystems in der zentralen Arktis zu Ende.  Die Polarstern war am 20. September 2019 vom norwegischen Troms√∏ aus nach zehnj√§hriger Planungsphase zur bislang gr√∂√üten Arktis-Expedition aller Zeiten aufgebrochen. Unter Leitung des Bremerhavener Alfred-Wegener-Institutes (AWI) waren Hunderte Wissenschaftler in wechselnden Crews aus 20 L√§ndern an Bord des Schiffs. Mehr als 80 Forschungsinstitute waren beteiligt.  Das Schiff driftete 3400 Kilometer mit einer gewaltigen Eisscholle im Zickzackkurs durch das Nordpolarmeer. W√§hrenddessen sammelten die Forscher bei bis zu minus 42,3 Grad Celsius Daten in den f√ºnf Teilbereichen Atmosph√§re, Meereis, Ozean, √ñkosystem und Biogeochemie.  Im virtuellen Logbuch notierte die Besatzung, die R√ºckkehr sei nur ein erster Schritt. Ihm folgten nun Jahre von Analysen, Aufarbeitung, Diskussionen und Publikationen, um den Klimawandel und seine Auswirkungen auf die Erde besser verstehen und erkl√§ren zu k√∂nnen.  Lesen Sie mit SZ Plus mehr unter sz.de/instagram (Link in Bio).  #arktis #polarstern #expedition #forschung

Description: The World Food Programme has won this year‚Äôs Nobel Peace Prize.  The United Nations agency was honoured for its efforts to combat hunger, its contribution to bettering conditions for peace in conflict-affected areas, and for acting as a driving force in efforts to prevent the use of hunger as a weapon of war and conflict.  There were 318 candidates - 211 individuals and 107 organisations - nominated for the award, including teenage climate change campaigner Greta Thunberg, New Zealand PM Jacinda Ardern, the World Health Organisation, and Saudi activist Loujain al Hathloul.

Description: New England‚Äôs forests are sick, and there is a shortage of arborists who can help them.   The region is roughly 75% forest, and to the untrained eye, it all looks green and good. But climate change is taking a toll on woodlands in the Northeast, and even a quick tour of a New England-picturesque town common can reveal a lot about the deteriorating condition of the area‚Äôs trees.   ‚ÄúPeople look at that and say, ‚ÄòOh look, fall is coming early, it is going to be a colorful fall!‚Äô one arborist said of a young maple with red and yellow leaves. ‚ÄúNo. This is happening early because the trees are very stressed out.‚Äù   Many species ‚Äî including ash, oak, maple, hemlock, elm and white pine ‚Äî have their own particular pest or disease threatening them, with more on the horizon. And many trees are stressed by bouts of drought or intense rain, by rising temperatures and changing season length, by extreme weather ‚Äî all the various manifestations of climate change. The list of threats is long, synergistic and growing rapidly, which means that trees do not have sufficient time to recover and adapt.   Tap the link in our bio to read more about how arborists are working to overcome these challenges. Photos by @george_etheredge from western Massachusetts.

Description: This September was the hottest on record, bringing sea ice cover in the Arctic to nearly the lowest point ever.‚Å† ‚Å† EU scientists confirmed the records on Tuesday. Globally, September averaged 0.05¬∞C warmer than September 2019 - which was the previous warmest on record. This year, September was 0.63¬∞C hotter than the average September temperatures between 1981-2010.‚Å† ‚Å† So far the whole of 2020 has been warmer up to the same date in 2019, and has been similar to the previous whole-year record of 2016. It's not certain whether this year will become the hottest ever yet, but scientists say it could be.‚Å† ‚Å† The high temperatures caused sea ice in the Arctic to melt more than normal, reaching its second lowest point on record. September is always when sea ice is at its least, and the coverage this September was only ever less in 2012. Back then, it wasn't as warm, but a midsummer storm broke up much of the sea ice - which meant it melted more easily. By comparison, it's thought this year's melt was likely to be driven more by the high temperatures.‚Å† ‚Å† Carlo Buontempo, director of Copernicus Climate Change Service in charge of the records, said: ‚ÄúIn 2020, there was an unusually rapid decline in Arctic sea ice extent during June and July, in the same region where above average temperatures were recorded, preconditioning the sea ice minimum to be particularly low this year."‚Å† ‚Å† ‚Å† Image source: Copernicus Climate Change Service, ECMWF
ImageText: 'Rapid decline' of Arctic ice after hottest September on record @channel4news

Description: Sophia-Marie Pott, Sprecherin von Fridays for Future, hat das neue Klimaschutzgesetz der EU-Kommission scharf kritisiert. Diese will die CO2-Emissionen bis 2030 um 60 Prozent reduzieren.  . Die 16-j√§hrige Pott sagte im Dlf, 80 Prozent seien n√∂tig, um das 1,5-Grad-Ziel gerade noch zu erreichen. Dies sei wissenschaftlich belegt. Sie f√ºhrte aus: ‚ÄûDas Problem ist, dass wir 40 Jahre lang wirklich wenig getan haben, um den Klimaschutz tats√§chlich umzusetzen, und jetzt haben wir nicht die Zeit, da auch noch in lange Verhandlungen zu gehen. Es geht um jedes einzelne Minigrad und da k√∂nnen wir uns nicht mehr streiten, ob wir 55 oder 60 Prozent beschlie√üen sollen ‚Äì vor allem, weil wir ja mit dem Paris-Abkommen schon 1,5 Grad bekannt haben. Und wenn wir das umsetzen wollen, dann m√ºssen wir da hochgehen. F√ºr diese Abstimmung hatten wir uns ganz klare 65 Prozent gew√ºnscht, selbst wenn 80 Prozent wissenschaftlich notwendig w√§ren.‚Äú . Das komplette Interview finden Sie √ºber den Link in unserer Bio. ‚¨ÜÔ∏è . #fridaysforfuture #climatechange #klimakrise #co2 #klimastreik #neustartklima #emissionen #keingradweiter #climatejustice #klimagesetz #eukommission @sophiamariepott @fridaysforfuture.de @eukommission @europeancommission

Description: Conservationists are hoping a ‚Äúrewilding‚Äù project could see Tasmanian devils reintroduced to the Australian mainland.  About 30 devils, free of the devil facial tumour disease that devastated the wild population in Tasmania, have been released into a predator-free sanctuary in the Barrington Tops national park, north of Sydney.  The animal preservation project Aussie Ark will use tracking devices to monitor how the animals fare in their new environment. The eventual goal is to release them into the broader landscape to see whether it will help restore the ecology of forests devastated by foxes, cats and other invasive predators.  Tasmanian devils used to inhabit mainland Australia. The exact point at which they became extinct there is uncertain, but scientists have suggested dates ranging from 500 to 5,000 years ago, their extinction being attributed to factors including climate change and hunting.
ImageText: Tasmanian devils released G into Australian sanctuary in step towards rewilding'

Description: @agendapais2030 El secretario general de la Organizaci√≥n de las Naciones Unidas (ONU), Ant√≥nio Guterres, indic√≥ la necesidad de que la naturaleza est√° saludable para el bienestar de las personas y las futuras generaciones. ‚ÄúLa humanidad est√° librando una guerra contra la naturaleza, y necesitamos reconstruir nuestra relaci√≥n con ella‚Äù, expres√≥.  As√≠ fue como Guterres inici√≥ la primera Cumbre de las Naciones Unidas sobre Biodiversidad. Encuentro que se destaca por el t√©rmino del periodo de diez a√±os de los compromisos de Tokio el 2010, que ten√≠an relaci√≥n con medidas para desacelerar el da√±o al medio ambiente.  Este a√±o la reuni√≥n se realiz√≥ en un contexto importante a nivel global, en donde -adem√°s de encontrarnos en una pandemia- los incendios forestales, las altas temperaturas, la contaminaci√≥n ambiental y los animales en peligros de extinci√≥n, han puesto en duda la efectividad de las medidas actuales.  ‚ÄúLa emergencia planetaria est√° sobre nosotros impulsada por las amenazas de la crisis clim√°tica y el colapso de la biodiversidad, la vida en el planeta est√° amenazada. Estamos en guerra con la naturaleza y la naturaleza est√° contraatacando, los desastres de la biodiversidad est√°n ocurriendo ahora mismo, con derrames de petr√≥leo que est√°n devastando muchos ecosistemas y los incendios forestales que est√°n matando personas y destruyendo h√°bitats, adem√°s de dejar p√©rdidas econ√≥micas incalculables‚Äù, afirm√≥ el secretario general dos d√≠as antes de este encuentro.  El presidente de la Asamblea General, Volkan Bozkir, afirm√≥ derechamente que ninguno de los objetivos declarados hace una d√©cada fue cumplido en su totalidad. Frente a esto, se reafirm√≥ la necesidad de que la acci√≥n sea mucho mayor, por parte de los gobiernos y de los actores locales de cada pa√≠s.  ‚ÄúPerm√≠tanme ser claro: la degradaci√≥n de la naturaleza no es un problema puramente ambiental. Abarca la econom√≠a, la salud, la justicia social y los derechos humanos. Descuidar nuestros preciosos recursos puede exacerbar las tensiones y los conflictos geopol√≠ticos‚Äù, indic√≥ Guterres.  üëâcontin√∫a leyendo en el link de la bio‚ùóÔ∏è
ImageText: Ant√≥nio Guterres: "La humanidad est√° librando una guerra contra la naturaleza y necesitamos reconstruir nuestra relaci√≥n con ella" por Agenda Pa√≠s 6 octubre, 2020

Description: "Es gibt so viele Dinge, die du in Zukunft einfach nicht mehr finden wirst, wenn du sie jetzt nicht richtig erhaÃàltst", sagt Hung Hsin-chieh. Description: Researchers are warning that a large part of the Amazon could be on the verge of losing its distinct nature and switching from a closed canopy rainforest to an open savannah with far fewer trees as a result of the climate crisis.  Rainforests are highly sensitive to changes in rainfall and moisture levels, and fires and prolonged droughts can result in areas losing trees and shifting to a savannah-like mix of woodland and grassland.  New research shows that this tipping point could be much closer than previously thought. As much as 40% of the existing Amazon rainforest is now at a point where it could exist as a savannah instead of as rainforest, according to a study published in the journal Nature Communications.  Brazil‚Äôs president, Jair Bolsonaro, has been previously warned that the continued destruction of the Amazon by fire and loggers would bring the region closer to a tipping point. This year‚Äôs fires in the Amazon are the worst in a decade, with a 60% increase in fire hotspots compared with last year.
ImageText: Amazon near tipping point of switching from rainforest to savannah

Description: Tasmanian devils have been released back onto the Australian mainland for the first time in 3,000 years.‚Å† ‚Å† Conservation group Aussie Ark have released 26 carnivorous devils into a 500 hectare, predator-free sanctuary in Barrington Tops national park, a few hours north of Sydney.‚Å† ‚Å† Conservationists have been eager to reintroduce the carnivorous marsupial back onto the mainland as a control measure for feral pests and to restore forest ecology damaged by foxes, cats and other non-native predators.‚Å† ‚Å† It is not clear exactly when the Tasmanian devil went extinct on the Australian mainland but scientists suggest dates ranging between 500 and 5,000 years.‚Å† ‚Å† Their disappearance in all states but the island of Tasmania has been attributed to various factors such as climate change, hunting and the introduction of the dingo.‚Å† ‚Å† The first 15 devils were released in March and after showing positive signs, another 11 were released in September.‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† #tasmaniadevils #barringtontops #newsouthwales #australianconservation #ecology #marsupial #predator #tasmania #science #nature #animals #conservation #animal #wild #animalsofinstagram #wildlife #environment #earth #climatechange #australia #natural #eco
ImageText: Tasmanian devils have beer released back onto the Australian mainland for the first time in 3,000 years Se @channel4news

Description: In 2015, the landmark Paris agreement was reached to reduce the risks and impacts of climate change.  Christiana Figueres, who was the UN climate chief at the time, said that: ‚Äúwithout the work of the Guardian the delivery of the Paris agreement would have been far harder or perhaps even impossible."  Bill McKibben, the leading climate writer and campaigner, echoes her words: ‚ÄúThere is nothing in the English-language press that comes close to matching the scope and the commitment of the Guardian‚Äôs coverage of climate change.‚Äù  We don't share these quotes to trump our own horn, but to highlight the role journalism plays in protecting our planet.  Independent, expert journalism generates awareness of the problems ‚Äì as well as the solutions. It galvanises protest and resistance, putting pressure on government and industry to make positive changes.  More than a million readers have made a contribution to Guardian journalism so far. If you are one of them, thank you for your generosity. If you haven't yet and you'd like to support our work, head to the link in bio. No amount is too small.

Description: @revistageneracionm ‚ÄúLos meses de desfase que tenemos con el hemisferio norte nos han dado tiempo para reaccionar y preparar nuestra estrategia‚Äù, dijo el jefe de la Divisi√≥n Fomento e Inversi√≥n de la Subsecretar√≠a de Turismo, Crist√≥bal Forttes, quien llam√≥ a los emprendedores de turismo rural del pa√≠s a adaptarse sin dilaciones al actual escenario sanitario y enfocar su oferta en los viajeros nacionales, en especial grupos familiares y de amigos, millennials (21 a 40 a√±os) y bommers (41 a 54), que hoy ‚Äúest√°n muy estresados y desesperados por salir‚Äù.  Forttes dict√≥ la charla ‚ÄúTurismo rural y Covid-19: expectativas y oportunidades‚Äù, organizada por INDAP en el marco de la Expo Chile Agr√≠cola 2020, donde afirm√≥ que la crisis sanitaria mundial trajo consigo cambios de h√°bitos, donde lo primordial es ofrecer experiencias innovadoras, sustentables y c√°lidas a buen precio, entregar una informaci√≥n de calidad de los servicios y digitalizarse, ya que la mayor√≠a de los viajeros planificar√° sus viajes v√≠a web debido a la explosiva adopci√≥n tecnol√≥gica.  Seg√∫n dijo, hay consenso en que la recuperaci√≥n econ√≥mica vendr√° de la mano del turismo interno, raz√≥n por la cual los esfuerzos de promoci√≥n deben ir en esa l√≠nea. Tener una estructura sanitaria que brinde seguridad a los visitantes -nuevo est√°ndar para seleccionar un destino por sobre otro- y saber adaptarse con flexibilidad a la demanda de servicios, ‚Äúson aspectos fundamentales que los emprendedores de turismo rural deben tener en consideraci√≥n‚Äù, expres√≥.  ‚ÄúExperiencias ligadas al bienestar, como termas, turismo aventura y turismo rural, ir√°n creciendo considerablemente, lo que traer√° consigo un importante incremento de la demanda en el mediano plazo, tanto en zonas rurales como alrededor de parques y √°reas silvestres protegidas. Tambi√©n el turismo sustentable tomar√° un rol m√°s activo, no solo a ra√≠z del cambio clim√°tico, sino tambi√©n por razones sanitarias‚Äù, dijo.  Otras claves para enfrentar con √©xito estos nuevos desaf√≠os son trabajar en forma asociativa en los territorios, tematizar nuevas experiencias, marcar diferencias y visibilizar la cultura y las tradiciones locales.  #turismo #chile üëâlink en la bio‚ùóÔ∏è

Description: Venecia se salva de la primera inundaci√≥n del a√±o gracias a su nuevo sistema de diques.  La bas√≠lica de San Marcos, tan da√±ada por las temidas 'acqua alta' de los √∫ltimos dos a√±os, ayer permaneci√≥ seca. Los diques funcionan. Venecia levant√≥ con √©xito las compuertas del M√≥dulo Experimental Electromec√°nico (MOSE), un sistema fara√≥nico de ingenier√≠a que ha tardado m√°s de quince a√±os en construirse. Tras m√°s de una hora se pusieron en funcionamiento y lograron proteger la ciudad de los canales de la primera inundaci√≥n de la temporada. ‚ÄúEs una jornada hist√≥rica‚Äù, celebr√≥ el reci√©n reelegido alcalde, Luigi Brugnaro.  Las sirenas de la ciudad italiana sonaron a primera hora de la ma√±ana para anunciar una marea que se preve√≠a de m√°s de 130 cent√≠metros al mediod√≠a, con lo que habr√≠a inundado de nuevo por lo menos la plaza de San Marcos. El sistema de barreras submarinas MOSE ‚Äìen italiano significa Mois√©s, el profeta que separ√≥ las aguas del mar Rojo‚Äì funcion√≥ correctamente en las tres salidas naturales de la laguna y evit√≥ que Venecia volviera a sufrir un fen√≥meno de acqua alta , que cada a√±o son m√°s violentos presumiblemente a causa del cambio clim√°tico.  La obra ha tenido un coste de m√°s de 5.500 millones de euros y ten√≠a que haberse puesto en funcionamiento en el 2016, pero varios problemas t√©cnicos y un escandaloso caso de corrupci√≥n han retrasado su estreno.  üì∏ ZUMA Press / AFP / AP ‚úçÔ∏è Anna Buj, Roma. #Venecia #Venezia #serenissima #acquaalta #internacional

Description: Venecia ha levantado este s√°bado por primera vez el enorme sistema de diques mec√°nicos y ha conseguido proteger la isla y la laguna de la subida del nivel del mar, evitando as√≠ la temida 'acqua alta' que tantos da√±os ha provocado a lo largo de la historia. El Mose (acr√≥nimo de M√≥dulo Sperimentale Elettromeccanico, que juega con el nombre en italiano de Mois√©s, el profeta que separ√≥ las aguas del mar Rojo) levant√≥ sus brazos y la laguna de Venecia qued√≥ separada del mar Adri√°tico. Las 78 compuertas de acero amarillo instaladas bajo el mar se elevaron por la ma√±ana sin problemas en lo que ha sido la primera prueba de fuego.  üì∏ Andrea Merola (Efe)  üìå Lee la historia completa en el link de la bio.   #aquaalta #venezia

Description: @agendapais2030 La pandemia de Covid-19 ha alterado la vida de la personas. Algunos investigadores han postulado que la actual crisis sanitaria y econ√≥mica podr√≠a reducir nuestra preocupaci√≥n por el cambio clim√°tico. Una posible explicaci√≥n es que la gente tiene una reserva limitada de preocupaci√≥n.  Investigaciones en diferentes pa√≠ses muestran que cuando las econom√≠as caen en recesi√≥n, la preocupaci√≥n por el cambio clim√°tico tiende a disminuir. Dada la amplitud y gravedad de la actual situaci√≥n de la pandemia, cabr√≠a esperar un efecto similar.  Preocupaci√≥n por el cambio clim√°tico antes y despu√©s de Covid-19  Aqu√≠ presentamos algunos resultados preliminares obtenidos en dos encuestas realizadas a nivel nacional en agosto de 2019 y junio de 2020 en Espa√±a. Cada encuesta tuvo unos 2 000 participantes.  Un primer an√°lisis (figura 1) permite sacar dos conclusiones:  Primero, vemos que hay un porcentaje similar de personas que dicen estar al menos bastante preocupadas por el cambio clim√°tico: 79 % en 2019, frente al 77 % en 2020. Segundo, hay un cambio en la distribuci√≥n de las respuestas sobre la preocupaci√≥n entre 2019 y 2020: hay m√°s personas que marcaron bastante y menos much√≠simo. Esta reducci√≥n de la proporci√≥n de personas preocupadas por el cambio clim√°tico es estad√≠sticamente significativa. En general, estos resultados parecen apoyar la idea de que las personas tenemos una reserva limitada de preocupaci√≥n.  üëâcontin√∫a leyendo en el link de la bio‚ùóÔ∏è

Description: Wildfires are continuing to burn in California. The Glass Fire currently raging in the famous wine-producing Napa Valley has burned 51,266 acres of land according to NBC News. Climate change is driving the scale and impact of wildfires in the region, say scientists. Their¬†analysis¬†finds an "unequivocal and pervasive" role for global heating in boosting the conditions for fire. Dozens of blazes have burnt their way through swathes of the US West Coast over the last couple of months, killing more than 30 people and forcing tens of thousands from their homes. Description: Our recycling methods could be dramatically changing in the next few years - thanks to a scientific breakthrough involving plastic-eating bugs.  In 2016, scientists found two enzymes in a plastic-eating bug discovered at a Japanese waste site. By linking the two together, they've come up with a super-enzyme that can break down plastic six times faster than previous enzymes!  Researchers also believe that combining the plastic-eating enzymes with ones that break down natural fibres could allow mixed materials to be fully recycled for the first time.  Plastic pollution has contaminated the whole planet, from the Arctic to the deepest oceans, and people are now known to consume and breathe microplastic particles.  While the scientific breakthrough has been welcomed, campaigners have emphasised that reducing the use of plastic is still key to fighting the climate crisis.  Tap the link in bio to read more about this breakthrough.
ImageText: G jaqusy ESOURCE nqus A new super-enzyme super can degrade plastic bottles six times faster than before

Description: "We have a responsibility... even if there's only a fragment of hope left".  Sir David Attenborough has one message to people: "Don't waste". Speaking to BBC Breakfast, the naturalist warned humanity has overrun the planet, inflicting "appalling damage" upon the natural world.  As unprecedented wildfires engulf the US and Brazil's Amazon rainforest, the veteran broadcaster, 94, who recently became the fastest person to reach one million followers on Instagram, said the support of young people was the "great.. most important hope" in the fight against climate change.  "It's their world and it's their tomorrow, I won't be there, they will be."  @davidattenborough @bbcbreakfast #DavidAttenborough #ClimateChange #Environment #BBCNews

Description: The Government Accountability Office warned in a report last year that French Limited was among 945 Superfund sites across the US vulnerable to hurricanes, flooding, sea level rise, increased precipitation or wildfires, all of which are intensifying as the planet warms.‚Å† ‚Å† Far from a theoretical future threat, the Superfund sites are a clear and present danger.‚Å† ‚Å† But the Trump administration no longer makes reference to climate change in addressing these risks at Superfund sites, InsideClimate News, the Texas Observer and @nbcnews found in an investigation of the Superfund program and the EPA‚Äôs response to climate-related threats.‚Å† ‚Å† Reporters interviewed more than 50 experts inside and outside of government, reviewed thousands of pages of EPA records and analyzed federal data on Superfund sites to determine the extent of the danger to human health and the environment and the missed opportunities to mitigate it.‚Å† ‚Å† Tap the link in our bio to read more. (2/3)‚Å† ‚Å† üì∑ Spike Johnson
ImageText: (empty)

Description: Barrett, Texas, a historically Black town founded in 1889, shares a wooded area with the hazardous waste French Limited Superfund site. That toxic dump was built so close to the Barrett family homestead that, as a young man, Fred Barrett could hear the rumble of tractor-trailers hauling chemical waste, including carcinogens, down the Gulf Pump Road to a foul pond.‚Å† ‚Å† Like the San Jacinto Waste Pits, another hazardous waste site, the French Limited site was also inundated by Hurricane Harvey in 2017, leading Barrett, 67, and his neighbors to worry that its contaminants had spread. The EPA did not report any leakage, but he and other residents wondered what the floodwaters could have carried offsite.‚Å† ‚Å† ‚ÄúWhat happened back there?‚Äù Barrett said. ‚ÄúIt was Harvey that made it seem more crucial. We wanted to know: What contaminants are still there ‚Äî and where is it going once it got out of its banks? Who‚Äôs watching the chicken coop?‚Äù‚Å† ‚Å† Those questions highlight the perils pose by the nation‚Äôs industrial wastelands as they are increasingly battered by extreme weather worsened by climate change.‚Å† ‚Å† Tap the link in our bio to read more. (1/3)‚Å† ‚Å† üì∑ Spike Johnson

Description: ‚ÄúSiete a√±os, ciento dos d√≠as y 12 horas‚Äù ‚è≥üåéü§Ø, de esta manera comenz√≥ el conteo regresivo en un reloj ubicado en Nueva York, Estados Unidos, el cual refleja el tiempo que le queda a la Tierra antes de que el calentamiento global y la contaminaci√≥n generen efectos irreversibles. Este reloj que est√° cerca de Union Square, comenz√≥ a funcionar esta semana y ha llamado la atenci√≥n de los habitantes y usuarios de internet, quienes con solo verlo se alarman por el ‚Äúpoco tiempo‚Äù que le queda a nuestro planeta. Aunque la pieza es parte de una instalaci√≥n art√≠stica, muchos sintieron curiosidad por c√≥mo marcaba la ‚Äúcuenta regresiva‚Äù. Algunos creyeron que estaba fallando, pero la realidad es que esa extra√±a forma de dar la "hora" tiene un prop√≥sito: Generar conciencia a las personas de lo cerca que estamos de un cambio irreversible.El c√°lculo del tiempo fue realizado con base en el Instituto de Investigaciones de Mercator sobre Cambio Clim√°tico, ubicado en Berl√≠n de acuerdo a informaci√≥n de CNN Espa√±ol. La inauguraci√≥n de esta cuenta regresiva inici√≥ con un anuncio importante: ‚ÄúLa Tierra tiene una fecha l√≠mite‚Äù y tras pocos segundos, salieron los n√∫meros: 7:103:15:40:07. ¬øQu√© te parece? üëÄüëá

Description: The UK's decision to field an all-male team to host a vital UN climate summit next year has angered activists and observers, who say the lack of gender balance threatens progress on key issues.   All of the politicians who will host the Cop26 talks for the UK in Glasgow are men, including the business secretary Alok Sharma, who will act as president of the summit.   Women are represented at a more junior level, working on some subsections of the negotiations. But the absence of women in the top team was sharply criticised by leading figures and activists.  Women in developing countries are among those worst and most immediately hit by climate breakdown, as they have fewer resources and fewer formal rights. A report this year by the IUCN found the climate crisis was also fuelling violence against women around the world.   At Cop26, countries must come up with strengthened commitments to cut greenhouse gas emissions, if the goals of the landmark Paris agreement of 2015 are to be fulfilled.

Description: La activista ambiental Mya-Rose Craig sostiene un cartel que dice 'Huelga de j√≥venes por el clima' en un t√©mpano de hielo a cientos de millas sobre el C√≠rculo Polar √Årtico.  J√≥venes de m√°s de medio millar de ciudades de pr√°cticamente todo el planeta han participado en las acciones en defensa del clima, denunciando la gravedad de la crisis clim√°tica global y la escasa respuesta de los gobiernos y las instituciones internacionales.  ‚ÄúVivimos en medio de una pandemia, pero el cambio clim√°tico es una crisis tan grande como siempre lo ha sido. ‚ÄúLos √∫ltimos meses han dejado a√∫n m√°s patentes las debilidades y contradicciones de una econom√≠a depredadora que se encuentra al l√≠mite del colapso; de un sistema neoliberal que precariza los servicios p√∫blicos y crea grandes desigualdades; de un sistema patriarcal que infravalora e invisibiliza los trabajos de cuidados necesarios para la vida‚Äù, destacan los organizadores de la protesta.  üì∏ Natalie Thomas / Reuters. #crisisclimatica #medioambiente #artico #circulopolar #cambioclimatico #oceano #mar
