Description: We made wildfire an enemy for 110 years ‚Äî but it could have been an ally.  The U.S. efforts to suppress wildfires, particularly in the American West ‚Äî as seen here in Oregon in 1955 ‚Äî have often resembled military campaigns, in both their approach and their equipment.   Starting with what became known as the Big Blowup ‚Äî a massive fire in 1910 that scorched 3 million acres and killed 78 firefighters in the Northern Rockies ‚Äî the U.S. Forest Service‚Äôs strategy mostly has been to put out fires as fast as possible.   Several thousand soldiers were called out to help fight the 1910 fires, and in subsequent decades the @u.s.forestservice‚Äôs would align itself ever more closely with military tactics. Smoke jumpers held the same pride of place as elite paratroopers; hotshots resembled on-the-ground infantry. The agency gladly made itself the second home of the U.S. military‚Äôs castoff tankers, helicopters and jeeps. The fallen firefighters of 1910 were cast as selfless martyrs in a great national struggle.  But with climate change and shifting populations, we‚Äôre losing that war. Tap the link in our bio to read more. Photo by J R Eyerman/The LIFE Picture Collection, via Getty Images

Description: "The main hope is, as always... that people will start becoming more aware".  Greta Thunberg joined demonstrators outside Sweden's parliament to¬†relaunch the Fridays For Future movement, after it was put on hold due to the coronavirus pandemic. The 17-year-old environmentalist's solo protest in front of the building in 2018 inspired people around the world to hold weekly mass rallies. Its popularity sparked controversy for causing many students to walk out of school in an effort to force leaders in action.  Posting on Instagram earlier this week Greta, who has since become a figurehead for action against climate change, said 2,500 strikes were planned around the world.  Tap the link in our bioüëÜ to learn more about the planned day of socially-distanced environmental action. ( üì∏Getty Images). #GretaThunberg #ClimateChange #Environment #BBCNews

Description: From rock art to pyramids along the River Nile, Africa has many historic landmarks that are thousands of years old. But because of the impact climate change is having on some of the sites, researchers from around the world are calling for a "significant intervention" to protect them from a rise in sea levels and extreme weather conditions. 1. Archaeologists in Sudan have been trying to stop floodwater from the River Nile from reaching the pyramids at al-Bajrawiya. 2. The Comoros, a volcanic collection of islands off the East African coast is one of the places "most threatened" by sea level rise in Africa. 3. Climate change can increase humidity in relatively barren areas, breeding fungi that can damage rock face drawings. That's what's happening at Twyfelfontein in Namibia's Kunene region, home to one of the largest concentrations of rock art. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the sites under threat from climate change across Africa. (Getty Images). #Africa #WorldHeritageSite #ClimateChange #BBCNews

Description: Una joven protesta en el √Årtico contra el cambio clim√°tico ¬∑ Mya-Rose Craig es una adolescente brit√°nica que se ha unido a la lucha por el clima. Ella, como muchos otros de su generaci√≥n, cree firmemente que los adultos no han tomado las medidas urgentes necesarias para abordar el calentamiento global. Por eso, a sus 18 a√±os, se ha dirigido al C√≠rculo Polar √Årtico para concienciar a gobiernos y sociedades del grave problema medioambiental que vivimos en la actualidad. Craig llama a una 'huelga juvenil por el clima', para reivindicar un tema cada vez m√°s preocupante: el calentamiento en el √Årtico redujo el hielo que cubre el oc√©ano polar este a√±o a su segundo nivel m√°s bajo en cuatro d√©cadas. Craig tard√≥ un mes y medio en llegar a su destino, tras una cuarentena de dos semanas en Alemania, seguida de un viaje de tres hasta el borde del hielo marino. Esta joven activista afirm√≥ que aquellos que tratan las protestas juveniles como una fase rebelde de su generaci√≥n est√°n equivocados, y quiere que los que est√°n en el poder dejen de tratar el cambio clim√°tico como un tema de baja prioridad.  #MyaRoseCraig #ClimateChange #CambioClim√°tico #C√≠rculoPolar√Årtico #Deshielo #CalentamientoGlobal #MedioAmbiente #NoHayPlanetaB

Description: Climate disruption is now locked in ‚Äî the next moves will be crucial.‚Å£ ‚Å£ America is now under siege by climate change in ways that scientists have warned about for years. But there is a second part to their admonition: Decades of growing crisis are already locked into the global ecosystem and cannot be reversed.‚Å£ ‚Å£ This means the kinds of cascading disasters occurring today ‚Äî drought in the West fueling historic wildfires that send smoke all the way to the East Coast, or parades of tropical storms lining up across the Atlantic to march destructively toward North America ‚Äî are no longer features of some dystopian future. They are the here and now, worsening for the next generation and perhaps longer, depending on humanity‚Äôs willingness to take action.‚Å£ ‚Å£ Conversations about climate change have broken into everyday life, to the top of the headlines and to center stage in the presidential campaign. The questions are profound and urgent. Can this be reversed? What can be done to minimize the looming dangers for the decades ahead? Will the destruction of recent weeks become a moment of reckoning, or just a blip in the news cycle?‚Å£ ‚Å£ The Times spoke with 2 dozen climate experts, including scientists, economists, sociologists and policymakers, and their answers were by turns alarming, cynical and hopeful.‚Å£ ‚Å£ Their most sobering message: The world still hasn‚Äôt seen the worst of it. Gone is the climate of yesteryear, and there‚Äôs no going back.‚Å£ ‚Å£ ‚ÄúWhat we‚Äôre seeing today, this year, is just a small harbinger of what we are likely to get,‚Äù said Jonathan Overpeck, a climate scientist at the @uofmichigan. Things are on track to get ‚Äútwice as bad‚Äù as they are now, he said, ‚Äúif not worse.‚Äù‚Å£ ‚Å£ Tap the link in our bio to read more about the future of climate change and the crucial next steps the world must take. Photos by @ek_the_pj, @bdentonphoto, @ericthayer, @alishajucevic and Richard Coleman/Agence France-Presse ‚Äî Getty Images.‚Å£

Description: Emphasizing that #California must stay at the forefront of the fight against climate change, Gov. Newsom on Wednesday issued an executive order to restrict new car sales in the state to only zero-emission vehicles by 2035 and threw his support behind a ban on the controversial use of hydraulic fracturing by oil companies.  Newsom did not take executive action to ban the controversial oil extraction method known as #fracking but called on the state Legislature to do so, setting up what could be a contentious political fight when lawmakers reconvene in Sacramento next year.  Taken together, the two climate change efforts would accelerate the state‚Äôs already aggressive efforts to curtail carbon emissions and petroleum hazards and promise to exacerbate tensions with a Trump administration intent on bridling California‚Äôs liberal environmental agenda.   Link in bio. üì∏ @robgauthier

Description: California is burning through the grand finale of its¬†worst #fire decade on record, with smoke clouds choking most of the state for much of the last month. Description: Once ice-covered landscapes are rapidly turning green across the Arctic, according to a new study.‚Å† ‚Å† The research, published yesterday in the journal Nature Communications, is the first to track vegetation changes in the Arctic tundra, which ranges from Alaska and Canada across to Siberia, using satellite data across several decades.‚Å† ‚Å† Tundra greenness increased at around 38 per cent of all sampling sites from 1986 to 2016. Only 3 per cent showed the opposite "browning" effect, which would mean fewer actively growing plants.‚Å† ‚Å† Logan Berner, assistant research professor at Northern Arizona University who led the research, said: "This Arctic greening we see is really a bellwether of global climatic change. "‚Å† ‚Å† While more plants might seem like a good thing, it's worrying scientists that they're proliferating so fast in the Arctic. There are complicated trade-offs here: although vegetation absorbs carbon from the atmosphere, which in theory reduces the rate of climate change, it also absorbs heat and can trap snowfall. This means that the thaw of permafrost in the region is accelerating, releasing huge amounts of CO2 and methane that were once sealed inside it. As a net effect, more greenhouse gases are released overall.‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† #arctic #tundra #climatechange #climatecrisis #climateemergency #globalwarming #ice #satellite #plants #carbon #permafrost #snow #nature #earth #planet #environment #polarice #world
ImageText: The Arctic is turning green, fast, because of climate change 2000-2016 Greening No change 80¬∞ N Browning 60¬∞ N

Description: Was im Internet bestellt und anschlie√üend zur√ºckgesandt wird, landet oft beim Versandh√§ndler im M√ºll. Das ist f√ºr diesen h√§ufig g√ºnstiger, als die Ware zum Neuverkauf aufzubereiten. Die Bundesregierung will H√§ndlern dieses Verhalten per Gesetz so schwer wie m√∂glich machen. Der Bundestag hat √Ñnderungen etwa am Kreislaufwirtschaftsgesetz am Freitag (19.09.20) zugestimmt.  Viola Wohlgemuth von @greenpeace.de gehen die beschlossenen √Ñnderungen nicht weit genug. Sie begr√º√üt die Novellierung des Gesetzes, spricht allerdings von einem ‚Äûallerersten Schritt‚Äú. H√§ndler w√ºrden damit nicht zur Offenlegung verpflichtet. Sie sollten ‚Äûwirklich Zeugnis ablegen, wie viel Ware √ºbrig bleibt‚Äú.  Ihrer Ansicht nach braucht es daf√ºr vor allem ein ‚ÄûTransparenzgebot‚Äú. Wie viele Waren in Deutschland unverkauft vernichtet werden, ist n√§mlich nicht ganz klar. In einer aktuellen Studie der Universit√§t Bamberg ist von etwa vier Prozent die Rede. Diese beruhe aber nur auf freiwilligen Angaben einiger H√§ndler, Angaben gro√üer Vertreter der Branche fehlten, etwa des Marktf√ºhrers im Onlinehandel, kritisiert Wohlgemuth. Sie bezieht sich auf eine andere Recherche und Insiderangaben und geht von bis zu 30 Prozent der Retouren aus, die nicht mehr als A-Ware angeboten w√ºrden und deren Verbleib ungekl√§rt sei. Vermutlich werde ein gro√üer Teil davon vernichtet.  Das vollst√§ndige Interview finden Sie √ºber den Link in unserer Bio.  #umwelt #m√ºll #konsum #kapitalismus #recycling #internet #online #onlinehandel #umweltschutz #wirtschaft #√∂kologie #√∂konomie #klima #klimawandel #politik #gesellschaft #instapolitics #gr√ºne #cdu #spd #linke #afd #fdp #greenpeace #deutschland #deutschlandfunk #dlf

Description: @agendapais2030 Esta semana se public√≥ un reporte de la organizaci√≥n internacional Oxfam -en conjunto al Instituto de Medio Ambiente de Estocolmo- que da cuenta de las emisiones de di√≥xido de carbono (CO2) relacionadas a los ingresos econ√≥micos a nivel global.  En √©l se muestra que el 10% m√°s rico de la poblaci√≥n mundial (630 millones de personas app.) gener√≥ el 52% de las emisiones de CO2 acumuladas entre los a√±os 1990 y 2015; mientras que, el 50% m√°s pobre (3100 millones de personas app.), produjo tan solo el 15%.  El aumento de las emisiones del primer grupo durante ese periodo, fue tres veces m√°s grande que el del segundo.  Los investigadores afirmaron que esta desigualdad de las emisiones es parte importante de la crisis que estamos viviendo con el cambio clim√°tico. A pesar de que este a√±o -debido a la pandemia de covid-19 y las restricciones que ha implicado- se han visto disminuidas las emisiones de CO2, esta reducci√≥n no tendr√° ning√∫n efecto si los Estados no toman medidas restrictivas a los principales causantes de estas altas cifras como el transporte a√©reo y terrestre.  El Acuerdo de Par√≠s adoptado a finales de 2015 en la Cop21, fij√≥ ciertos par√°metros urgentes para la lucha contra el cambio clim√°tico. Uno de los puntos centrales fue mantener el aumento de temperatura -calentamiento global- mucho menor a los 2¬∞C durante este siglo, tratando de mantenerlo por debajo 1,5¬∞C.  En el √∫ltimo tiempo, algunos expertos ya han mostrado su preocupaci√≥n sobre la dificultad de mantenerse bajo estas cifras. Esto se confirma tras la publicaci√≥n de Oxfam, en el que se ve que ‚Äúentre 1990 y 2015, las emisiones anuales se incrementaron en un 60 %, y las emisiones acumuladas se duplicaron‚Äù. #emisionescarbono #cambioclimatico #medioambiente #chile üëâlink en bio‚ùóÔ∏è

Description: China will be carbon neutral by 2060, President Xi Jinping has told the UN.‚Å† ‚Å† It's a new and ambitious target which could have a rippling effect around the globe. China has the largest annual carbon emissions of any country, and with the climate crisis so low on the agendas of leaders like Donald Trump and Jair Bolsonaro, the world has been looking to China for leadership ahead of a UN climate conference in Glasgow next year.‚Å† ‚Å† Speaking to the UN General Assembly in New York via videolink yesterday, President Xi also said that China's carbon emissions will peak before 2030. Experts pointed out that this is only a marginal change from a previous pledge, however.‚Å† But the new long term 2060 goal is a "significant step forward", said Richard Black from the Energy and Climate Intelligence Unit.‚Å† ‚Å† ‚ÄúChina isn‚Äôt just the world‚Äôs biggest emitter but the biggest energy financier and biggest market, so its decisions play a major role in shaping how the rest of the world progresses with its transition away from the fossil fuels that cause climate change," he said.‚Å† ‚Å† The devil, as ever, will be in the detail. China is still in the process of building rafts of new coal fired power plants, which are some of the most carbon-heavy forms of energy around. Yesterday's announcement will either mean an alteration to these plans, heavy investment in still-unproven technologies that remove carbon before it's emitted, or a rapid expansion of offsetting schemes such as tree planting.‚Å† ‚Å† The precise significance of yesterday's announcement will depend on these details. All eyes will now be on President Xi's next five-year plan for the period 2021-25, to be announced later this year, for signals on which path toward the new climate goals China takes.‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† #climate #climatechange #climatecrisis #climateemergency #globalheating #globalwarming #carbon #co2 #emissions #pollution #report #netzero #carbonneutral #oil #gas #renewables #UN #diplomacy #newyork #china #nyc #fossilfuels #petrochemicals #investment #energy #industry

Description: üî¥ El casquete polar √°rtico registr√≥ este verano boreal (hemisferio norte) su segunda menor superficie desde que comenzaron los registros hace 42 a√±os. Este a√±o la superficie m√≠nima se constat√≥ el 15 de septiembre, en 3,74 millones de km2, seg√∫n el Centro Nacional de Nieve y Hielo de la universidad de Colorado Boulder. Pero... ¬øqu√© es el casquete polar √°rtico? ü§î Es la capa de hielo que se forma en el mar en esas altas latitudes y cada a√±o, una parte se derrite en verano para volver a formarse en invierno. El problema actual surge porque debido al #calentamientoglobal, cada verano se derrite una porci√≥n mayor que no alcanza a recomponerse en el invierno, reduciendo cada vez m√°s su superficie. Los sat√©lites observan estas √°reas con mucha precisi√≥n desde 1979, y la tendencia a la baja es clara. "Ha sido un a√±o loco en el norte, con el hielo marino casi en el nivel m√°s bajo de la historia, olas de calor (...) en Siberia y enormes incendios forestales", dijo Mark Serreze, director del NSIDC. "Nos enfilamos hacia un Oc√©ano √Årtico sin hielo estacional", lament√≥, remarcando que Groenlandia se est√° calentando dos veces m√°s r√°pido que el resto del planeta.

Description: ‚ö†Ô∏èüî¥IM√ÅGENES SENSIBLES. Descubren por fin la causa de las misteriosas muertes de 330 elefantes en Botsuana.  Despu√©s de m√°s de tres meses de revisi√≥n de los 330 casos mejor documentados, los responsables del departamento de Vida Salvaje y Parques Nacionales de este pa√≠s africano han indicado que la muerte de paquidermos aparentemente sanos y sin se√±ales de violencia est√° relacionada con al contaminaci√≥n del agua que bebieron estos animales en el medio natural con cianobacterias (bacterias potencialmente t√≥xicas conocidas antiguamente como algas verdeazules porque los filamentos que forman tienen una apariencia similar a las algas -en realidad no son algas).  Por lo general, este tipo de bacterias no producen problemas graves a los animales, pero la cosa cambia cuando, por condiciones ambientales como el aumento de la temperatura (y el cambio clim√°tico es un multiplicador potencial) o la concentraci√≥n de nutrientes, se producen floraciones repentinas o bloom de cianobacterias, con la aparici√≥n de toxinas que pueden afecta a diversos √≥rganos. Una de las circunstancias m√°s extra√±as de este caso es que, aparentemente, los elefantes han sido los √∫nicos grandes animales intoxicados. Ninguna otra especie silvestre se vio afectada por el agua t√≥xica en el √°rea estudiada, cerca del famoso delta del Okavango en Botswana, indico Taolo.   üì∏ AFP/ Reuters Lee toda la informaci√≥n en el link de nuestra bio üì≤ #elefantes #Botwsana #natural #fauna #africa  https://bit.ly/32OX4xU

Description: Are you Gen Z? Registered to vote?‚Å†‚†Ä ‚Å†‚†Ä Roughly 24 million members of Generation Z will have the opportunity to cast a ballot in November, according to the Pew Research Center. Gen Zers are those born after 1996 and combined with Millennials, ages 24 to 39, the two generations make up most of the U.S. population, according to a 2019 analysis by the Brookings Institution that showed nearly 51% of U.S. residents were under age 40.‚Å†‚†Ä ‚Å†‚†Ä Gen Z, the most racially and ethnically diverse generation, is also known for political engagement and activism not seen since the 1960s, and they're particularly concerned with climate change and its threat to the future.‚Å†‚†Ä ‚Å†‚†Ä Registering to vote is a quick and easy process. (And it‚Äôs #NationalVoterRegistrationDay, so there‚Äôs no reason not to!) Check your status at vote.usatoday.com, which you can get to in our link in bio. It takes less than two minutes. ‚Å†‚†Ä ‚Å†‚†Ä #Election2020 #donaldtrump #joebiden #vote #politics

Description: ‚ÄúChile: el rechazo al Acuerdo de Escaz√∫ acaba con la aspiraci√≥n de liderazgo ambiental‚Äù se titula un reportaje de Deutsche Welle que pone el foco en la resistencia del Gobierno de Sebasti√°n Pi√±era a suscribir el Acuerdo de Escaz√∫, el primer gran acuerdo ambiental en Latinoam√©rica y el Caribe. La nota del medio p√∫blico alem√°n subraya que a cinco d√≠as de que finalice el plazo para firmar el tratado, Chile mantiene su negativa de rubricarlo. ‚ÄúLa gran contradicci√≥n de todo este asunto es que Chile, bajo el primer mandato de Pi√±era (2010-2014), fue el principal impulsor y negociador para elaborar el Acuerdo de Escaz√∫‚Äù junto a Costa Rica, se√±ala el reportaje.  DW a√±ade que los argumentos del Gobierno para no firmar el tratado internacional no convencen a los expertos consultados. ‚ÄúEl Gobierno chileno parece darle prioridad al sector privado por sobre la protecci√≥n medioambiental‚Äù, se√±ala, recordando adem√°s que ‚Äúel pa√≠s suramericano est√° suscrito al Acuerdo de Par√≠s y presidi√≥ la Conferencia de las Naciones Unidas sobre el Cambio Clim√°tico de 2019 (COP25) que se realiz√≥ en Madrid, evento en el que el liderazgo chileno en materia ambiental fue duramente criticado‚Äù.

Description: The Earth has a deadline. And the Climate Clock in New York City is keeping time.  Metronome‚Äôs digital clock in Union Square has been reprogrammed. Now, instead of measuring 24-hour cycles, it is measuring what two artists, Gan Golan and Andrew Boyd, present as a critical window for action to prevent the effects of global warming from becoming irreversible. According to the clock, there is a little more than 7 years.  ‚ÄúThis is arguably the most important number in the world,‚Äù Boyd said. ‚ÄúAnd a monument is often how a society shows what‚Äôs important, what it elevates, what is at center stage.‚Äù  The artists‚Äô goal of creating a large-scale clock was influenced in part by the Doomsday Clock, maintained online by the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, and by the National Debt Clock near Bryant Park in Manhattan. The artists said it was based on calculations by the Mercator Research Institute on Global Commons and Climate Change in Berlin.  Golan and Boyd decided that it would have the most impact if it were displayed in a conspicuous public space and presented like a statue or an artwork. It will be on display until Sept. 27, but the creators say their aim is to arrange for the clock to be permanently displayed, there or elsewhere.  Tap the link in our bio to read more about the Climate Clock. Photo by @jeenahmoon

Description: Calentamiento global, el responsable de la muerte de cientos de elefantes en Bostsuana.   De acuerdo con el Departamento de Vida Silvestre y Parques Nacionales, las elevadas temperaturas a nivel mundial causaron toxinas en el agua, producidas por cianobacterias, que provocaron la muerte de m√°s de 300 cuadr√≠pedos entre mayo y julio de 2020.  ‚ÄúEstas condiciones est√°n coincidiendo cada vez m√°s a menudo, por lo que estamos viendo m√°s de estas proliferaciones t√≥xicas en todo el mundo‚Äú, dijo Patricia Glibert, profesora del Centro de Ciencia Medioambiental de la Universidad de Maryland. Description: The mystery deaths of hundreds of elephants in Botswana has been solved. The alarm was raised when elephant carcasses were spotted in the country's Okavango Delta between May and June. Wildlife officials say toxins made by microscopic algae in water caused a total of 330 elephants to die. They ingested cyanobacteria - a toxic bacteria which can occur naturally in standing water and sometimes grow into large blooms known as blue-green algae. Scientists warn that climate change could be making these incidents - known as toxic blooms - more likely, because they favour warm water. Tap the link in our bio to read the full story.  Photo: EPA/Reuters  #Elephants¬†#Botswana¬†#Animals¬†#Nature¬†#Conservation¬†#bbcnews

Description: La playa de Boulders Beach lo tiene todo. Sol, arena blanca, aguas c√°lidas de color turquesa... Esta podr√≠a ser parte de la descripci√≥n de cualquier playa paradis√≠aca, ideal para pasar un d√≠a tranquilo lejos de aglomeraciones. Pero si uno viaja hasta all√≠, lo que va a encontrar es una enorme colonia de ping√ºinos africanos.    Y es que desde que en 1983 una pareja se instalara en esta playa de Simon‚Äôs Town, un pueblo pesquero situado a unos 40 kil√≥metros de Ciudad del Cabo, procedente de la isla de Dyer, unos 60 kil√≥metros al sur, las aves se han reproducido, convirti√©ndose en unos residentes de lujo. Se trata de ping√ºinos africanos, considerablemente m√°s peque√±os que otras especies m√°s comunes -miden de media alrededor de 60 cent√≠metros-, conocidos en el mundo anglosaj√≥n cono ping√ºinos Jackass (asno), por el tipo de ‚Äúrebuzno‚Äù que emiten. Viven en las costas rocosas del extremo sur del continente -de Namibia a Sud√°frica- y se encuentran en peligro de extinci√≥n, amenazados por la contaminaci√≥n y el cambio clim√°tico.   Boulders Beach se ha convertido en la actualidad en un excelente h√°bitat para estas aves. Incluida en el √°rea protegida del parque nacional de Table Mountain, en ella conviven ba√±istas y ping√ºinos sin aparente conflicto.  üì∏ iStock  Lee el art√≠culo completo en el link de nuestra bio üì≤ https://bit.ly/32MxXMb #ping√ºinos #natural #viajes #fauna

Description: "We are facing a crisis, and one that has consequences for us all." That's how Sir David Attenborough opens his new film, Extinction: The Facts. Britain's favourite naturalist takes a very serious tone in the programme, which issues a stark warning about the damage humanity is doing to the natural world. It features some of the species in this artwork including the northern white rhino, which has been declared functionally extinct with only a single pair left in existence. They're protected 24-hours a day by armed guards in Kenya after poaching and civil wars had a devastating impact on numbers. The pink-headed Rapa fruit-dove and rusty patched bumble bee are also endangered, with numbers expected to continue to drop due to habitat loss and climate change. While the North Atlantic right whale is no longer hunted, it is critically endangered with an estimated 409 whales left. They're threatened by entanglements in fishing gear and ship strikes. Tap the link in our bio for more about the animals featured in the programme and details of David Attenborough's warning. Viewers in the UK can also watch Extinction: The Facts on BBC iPlayer. (Illustrations by Rohan Dahotre)  #Nature #Wildlife #Extinction #DavidAttenborough #ClimateChange #AnimalsOfInstagram #Illustration #BBCNews

Description: ¬øCoincidencia? No lo creo üôÑ Cientos de p√°jaros fueron encontrados muertos en el estado de Nuevo M√©xico, Estados Unidos. Description: La primera semana de septiembre, Francisca Castillo sembr√≥ un ensayo de trigo en la Estaci√≥n Experimental Agropecuaria Austral, UACh-Valdivia, con distintos niveles de termotolerancia en campo.  Ella es investigadora postdoctoral del Instituto Milenio de Biolog√≠a Integrativa iBio en el Laboratorio de Nutrici√≥n y Gen√≥mica de Plantas, donde se ha planteado el desaf√≠o de avanzar en el conocimiento sobre el cultivo de trigo, espec√≠ficamente sobre los mecanismos que permiten a los cultivos soportar las alzas de temperatura en un contexto de cambio clim√°tico. Esto, considerando que los eventos extremos, como las olas de calor, son cada vez m√°s frecuentes y constituyen una seria amenaza a la productividad de cultivos a nivel global.  La bioqu√≠mica y doctora en Ciencias Agrarias recuerda que el trigo es uno de los cereales m√°s consumido en el mundo. ‚ÄúProvee alrededor de un 20% de las calor√≠as diarias, y por cada 1¬∞C de aumento por encima de las temperaturas √≥ptimas en etapas clave del desarrollo del cultivo, se generan p√©rdidas de un 5-6% en la productividad de trigo, por esto su investigaci√≥n resulta clave para la seguridad alimentaria global‚Äù, coment√≥.  Por eso sembr√≥ 14 l√≠neas de trigo que provienen del Centro Internacional de Mejoramiento de Ma√≠z y Trigo (CIMMYT). Estas se caracterizan por presentar distintos niveles de termotolerancia en campo, que es la capacidad de un cultivo de mantener su productividad en condiciones de estr√©s por altas temperaturas.  En este experimento preliminar se evaluar√° la expresi√≥n basal de algunos genes candidatos involucrados en procesos de termotolerancia, y se medir√° el rendimiento de cosecha que se realizar√° a fines de enero 2021. En un pr√≥ximo ensayo, explica Castillo, se llevar√°n a cabo tratamientos de choque t√©rmico para evaluar la respuesta fisiol√≥gica / molecular de estas l√≠neas de trigo en nuestro ambiente, lo que permitir√° complementar los resultados del proyecto. üëâcontin√∫a leyendo en el link de la bio‚ùóÔ∏è
ImageText: Estudian termotolerancia del trigo para mejorar los cultivos en un contexto de aumento de temperatura a consecuencia del cambio clim√°tico por Agenda Pa√≠s 20 septiembre, 2020

Description: Patagonia  is getting lots of attention for a cheeky, hidden message that appears only on the tag of a limited-edition pair of shorts, in tiny print. But the label was only the latest Trump-era call to action from Patagonia. The company has responded to the federal government‚Äôs environmental rollbacks with increasingly vocal campaigns to protect the country‚Äôs public lands ‚Äî and yes, it says the four-word message applies to the president, along with other politicians who refuse to act on climate change. Patagonia is also making¬†‚Äúrecommendations‚Äù¬†for 22 of the 35 Senate seats up for grabs in November based on the candidates‚Äô stances on climate change, public lands and environmental justice.  Read more about Patagonia's history of climate and political activism via our link in bio.  ‚úçÔ∏è: @sammy_roth   #patagonia #outdoors

Description: @revistageneracionm Seg√∫n la Encuesta Nacional del Medio Ambiente de 2018, un mill√≥n y medio de chilenos llevaban hasta ese entonces una dieta vegetariana. Hoy, en medio de las celebraciones de Fiestas Patrias son muchos m√°s quienes buscan opciones de origen vegetal para pasar las celebraciones de una forma mucho m√°s saludable y emp√°tica con los animales.  Y es que ayudar a los animales, reducir el impacto en el medio ambiente y para mejorar su estado de salud, son las principales razones por la que las personas deciden ser veganas. Seg√∫n datos entregados por la organizaci√≥n Vegetarianos Hoy, el 73% de los participantes en campa√±as de alimentaci√≥n en base a plantas son menores de 30 a√±os.  Hace 10 a√±os el veganismo ya estaba presente en Chile, pero no ocupaba espacio ni en los medios ni en los muebles de los supermercados. Hoy la realidad es distinta, existiendo varias organizaciones que promueven este estilo de vida y una gran diversidad de productos disponibles debido al alza de la demanda.  Los j√≥venes, entendidos como personas de 15 a 25 a√±os, son el principal grupo etario que ha optado por el veganismo. En los √∫ltimos dos a√±os esto ha aumentado, surgiendo diversas campa√±as en torno a la alimentaci√≥n en base a plantas.  La campa√±a Semana Mundial Sin L√°cteos fue creada por Vegetarianos Hoy para acercar a las personas a una alimentaci√≥n basada en plantas, inst√°ndolos a conocer la diversidad de productos que sustituyen a los l√°cteos tradicionales. Esta se llev√≥ a cabo en diferentes pa√≠ses, tanto el 2019 como el 2020, siendo Chile el que cuenta con una mayor cantidad de inscritos.  Este a√±o la campa√±a cont√≥ con 3.314 inscritos, de los cuales el 73% son menores de 30 a√±os. ‚ÄúLos j√≥venes actuales tienden a ser m√°s conscientes con los animales y el medio ambiente. Tienen mayor acceso a la informaci√≥n sobre c√≥mo la industria alimenticia es uno de los principales causantes del cambio clim√°tico, extinci√≥n de especies y por supuesto el sufrimiento de millones de animales‚Äù, coment√≥ Camila Ahumada, coordinadora de campa√±as Vegetarianos Hoy. @vegetarianos_hoy #vegano #vegetariano üëâcontin√∫a leyendo en el link de la p√°gina ‚ùóÔ∏è

Description: These pictures show the damage caused by the deadly wildfires which have been burning their way through the US West Coast over the last month. More than 30 people have been killed and tens of thousands have been forced from their homes. Lightning strikes in August sparked a number of the blazes, while warm temperatures and dry conditions have fuelled others. Scientists say the region's wildfires are the worst in 18 years and have linked their increasing prevalence and intensity to climate change. However, US President Donald Trump has blamed poor forest management for the blazes. Tap the link in our bio for a visual guide to what's happening - a month on from a state of emergency being declared in California. (üì∏Maxar Technologies, Getty Images) #Fires #Wildfires #Oregon #US #ClimateChange #Environment #bbcnews

Description: Los gigantescos incendios forestales de los √∫ltimos meses en California, Oreg√≥n, Nevada y otros estados de la costa oeste de Norteam√©rica est√°n liberando a la atm√≥sfera cantidades sin precedentes de di√≥xido de carbono (gas asociado al cambio clim√°tico) y contaminaci√≥n por part√≠culas en suspensi√≥n (con efectos directos sobre la salud humana).  La gruesa capa de humo de los incendios ha cruzado Estados Unidos de costa a costa, ti√±endo de gris los cielos de Nueva York, y la agencia pronostica que llegar√° al norte de Europa a fines de esta semana.  Los fuegos, que comenzaron a mediados de agosto y contin√∫an activos, han consumido m√°s de 5 millones de acres (unos 2,02 millones de hect√°reas) en toda la costa oeste, dejando decenas de v√≠ctimas fatales, destruyendo viviendas y empeorando la calidad del aire. Una plaga de escarabajos que ha devastado m√°s de 150 millones de √°rboles solo en California ha dejado enormes cantidades de yesca, que alimenta las llamas. Eso, junto con las condiciones c√°lidas y secas, est√° provocando una de las peores temporadas de incendios en la regi√≥n.  üì∏ Reuters

Description: Greenpeace‚Äôs Arctic Sunrise ship is seen navigating through floating ice in the Arctic Ocean.  Drone footage taken by the team aboard the ship shows the vast ice floes of the Arctic Circle.  Climate change has been driving up Arctic temperatures and shrinking the once-solid sea ice cover.  Scientists say the ancient ice sheet sitting atop Greenland shed approximately a 113 square kilometre chunk of ice last month.  They are also warning that the dwindling ice cover means an uncertain future for animals like seals and polar bears.  The Greenpeace ship is in the Arctic to witness and document the sea ice minimum ‚Äì which is when the ice reaches its smallest extent at the end of the summer melting season.  #climatechange #globalwarming #arctic #arcticcircle #ice #greenpeace
ImageText: (empty)

Description: ‚ÄúDespite our modern 2020 world, with an app for everything, there is no app for digging fire lines,‚Äù said Holly Krake, a @u.s.forestservice spokeswoman working on the Riverside Fire in Oregon.  The basic techniques for fighting wildfires have changed little in decades. Along with using helicopters and tanker aircraft to drop the water and flame retardant, there is arduous labor on the ground. Some of it requires carefully burning areas in the path of an advancing fire to try to rob it of the fuel it needs to keep progressing. It can also involve dousing flames with water brought in by truck ‚Äî or, in rough country, hiked in along with hoses and pumps.  At the most fundamental, though, it means workers using hand tools to dig the fire lines ‚Äî the borders, cleared of trees and shrub, that can stop a fire from advancing by removing all vegetation and scraping down to the ‚Äúmineral soil,‚Äù the bare dirt.  Many of the people who take on this backbreaking task are seasonal workers, and some are prison inmates. Their tool kits include low-tech implements of destruction, some of which are familiar, like chain saws and shovels. Others are odd yet exquisitely shaped to their purpose, like the Pulaski, which has a head with an ax at one side and an adz on the other that can break up packed dirt.  But today‚Äôs expanded fire seasons and raging wildfires brought on by climate change could render current firefighting approaches obsolete.  Tap the link in our bio to read how wildfires are fought. Photos by @maxwhittaker, @ericthayer, @chrismatography and @punkeykid

Description: More than a week after wildfires began blazing in Oregon, Washington and California, false and exaggerated claims about the fires‚Äô origins are still rampant.  The latest, most viral rumor involves Domingo Lopez Jr., a 45-year-old man who was arrested in Portland, Ore., on suspicion of starting a series of small fires. During one of these arrests, the police photographed a bottle with a wick attached, a Molotov cocktail they said Lopez had used to start one of the fires.  But these fires were unrelated to the larger blazes. Local news reports noted at the time that all of the fires Lopez was suspected of setting had been quickly extinguished, and that no people or buildings were harmed. They also noted that Lopez was taken for a mental health examination after his arrests.  Law enforcement agencies, including the FBI, have dispelled the rumor that arsonists or antifa sympathizers are responsible for the wildfires, and scientists say that climate change is the primary factor behind the blazes.  We‚Äôre tracking viral misinformation ahead of the 2020 election. Times reporters will chronicle and debunk false and misleading information that is going viral online. Tap the link in our bio to read tech columnist @kevinroose‚Äôs reporting that extinguishes the latest rumor. Photo by @iancbates
ImageText: No, a Molotov Cocktail Didn't Start the West's Wildfires

Description: The number of acres burned in this year's California wildfires is the highest on record, according to the state fire department.‚Å† ‚Å† Figures from Cal Fire show almost 3.4 million acres have been scorched in this year's devastating blazes - around 12 times the area burned last year. The state fire department says 25 people have died since mid-August and thousands of buildings have been destroyed, with dozens of major fires still burning across the state. ‚Å† ‚Å† Elsewhere on the US West Coast, 1.6 million acres of land have been burned across Oregon and Washington state since 7th September, destroying several small towns and claiming at least 34 lives.‚Å† ‚Å† Scientists say climate change has extended the wildfire season and made the blazes more intense, as higher temperatures have left vegetation drier for longer.‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† #wildfires #california #oregon #washington #globalwarming #climatechange #climatecrisis #climateeemergency

Description: Opinion contributor Dr. Thomas Ken Law writes: "Coupled with climate change, heat waves and forest overgrowth, the lightning storms were the catalyst to the worst wildfire season the West Coast has seen in decades. Lives and property have been lost directly to the out-of-control fires; here in the Bay Area, the resulting smoke and ash has blanketed everything. Walking outside is like stepping into a crowded cigarette-smoke filled bar where they are barbecuing and have coincidentally also just launched fireworks. There are days where every breath leaves an ashy taste in the mouth and eyes watering."‚Å† ‚Å† Tap our link in bio to read more. ‚Å† ‚Å† ----------------------------------------------------‚Å† ‚Å† Dr. Thomas Ken Lew is an assistant clinical professor of medicine at the Stanford University School of Medicine and an attending physician of Hospital Medicine at Stanford Health Care ‚Äî ValleyCare.

Description: Millions of people in the U.S. will be displaced by climate change. Where will they go?  Of all the devastating consequences of a warming planet ‚Äî changing landscapes, pandemics, mass extinctions ‚Äî the potential movement of hundreds of millions of climate refugees stands to be among the most important.  This summer has seen more fires, more heat, more storms, all of it making life increasingly untenable in larger areas of the nation. Already, droughts regularly threaten food crops across the West, while destructive floods inundate towns and fields from the Dakotas to Maryland, collapsing dams in Michigan and raising the shorelines of the Great Lakes. Rising seas and increasingly violent hurricanes are making thousands of miles of shoreline along the coasts nearly uninhabitable.  For years, Americans have avoided confronting these changes in their own backyards. The decisions made about where to live are distorted not just by politics that play down climate risks, but also by expensive subsidies and incentives aimed at defying nature. People have largely gravitated toward environmental danger, building along coastlines and settling across the cloudless deserts of the Southwest.  Once you accept that climate change is fast making large parts of the U.S. nearly uninhabitable, the future looks like this: With time, the bottom half of the country grows inhospitable, dangerous and hot. The millions of people moving north will mostly head to the cities of the Northeast and Northwest, which will see their populations grow by roughly 10%, according to one model.  To read more from this investigation published in @nytmag, tap the link in our bio. Photos by @meridithkohut.

Description: "Scientists believe our destructive relationship with nature is actually putting us at greater risk of pandemic diseases.‚Äù  David Attenborough looks at how the human impact on nature may be sparking more infectious diseases - from Ebola to Covid-19 - in his latest BBC special.  From our greater human exposure to wildlife through livestock markets, to animals losing their habitat due to deforestation and climate change, disease experts explore the warning signs facing humanity.  As the world continues to fight coronavirus, Attenborough says that if we continue on our current path "then what we've experienced this year might not be a one off event". UK viewers can watch ‚ÄòExtinction: The Facts‚Äô presented by Sir David Attenborough on BBC iPlayer.  #Nature #AnimalsOfInstagram #DavidAttenborough #Extinction #Pandemic #Coronavirus #Covid19 #BBCIplayer #BBCNews

Description: The wildfires raging on the West Coast became an all but inescapable crisis around the country on Tuesday, with a death toll of at least 27 across 3 states, fires and evacuations starting in Idaho, milky smoke clouding the skies over Michigan, and haze reaching as far as New York City.  In the states where the fires are burning worst ‚Äî Oregon, California and Washington State, which have had  more than 5 million acres charred so far ‚Äî the authorities were trying to adapt to a disaster with no clear end in sight, under conditions deeply exacerbated by climate change.  The Bay Area, under a choking blanket of smoke for 4 weeks, set another record for consecutive warnings about hazardous air. The Oregon State Police established a mobile morgue as teams searched incinerated buildings for survivors and the dead. Alaska Airlines suspended flights out of Portland, Oregon, and Spokane, Washington, citing ‚Äúthick smoke and haze.‚Äù And @oregongovbrown requested a presidential disaster declaration, saying late Monday, ‚Äúto fight fires of this scale, we need all the help we can get.‚Äù  As the fires rage, climate change has taken center stage in the race for the White House. On Monday @joebiden called @realdonaldtrump a ‚Äúclimate arsonist‚Äù while the president said that ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think science knows‚Äù what is actually happening.  Tap the links in our bio for the latest updates, a map of the fires and Trump‚Äôs visit to California. Photos by @alishajucevic, @ericthayer, @erinschaff and @nytmills

Sein langes Schweigen rechtfertigte er damit, dass er zumindest den Notstand f√ºr die Gebiete erkl√§rt habe, um Mittel freigeben zu k√∂nnen.  Im Gespr√§ch mit kalifornischen Regierungsvertretern gab sich Trump dennoch weniger zur√ºckhaltend. Wade Crowfoot, Chef des Amtes f√ºr Bodensch√§tze und nat√ºrliche Ressourcen, beschrieb dem Pr√§sidenten die Situation im Bundesstaat. Description: President Trump has a head-scratching solution for the California wildfires: "It will start getting cooler."‚Å† ‚Å† Trump touched down in California on Monday to survey the wildfire damage and immediately launched into his usual talking points about poor forest management while denying the role of climate change. ‚Å† ‚Å† Trump arrived in Sacramento as more than two dozen major wildfires burned across the state. More than 2 million acres in the state have burned this year, a nearly 2,000% increase in land burned compared to this time last year.‚Å† ‚Å† At a roundtable discussion about the wildfires, California Secretary for Natural Resources Wade Crowfoot said Trump‚Äôs focus on forest management was obscuring the grim reality that climate change was behind the historically high temperatures and years of drought.‚Å† ‚Å† ‚ÄúIt will start getting cooler. You just watch,‚Äù Trump fired back at Crowfoot.‚Å† ‚Å† "I wish science agreed with you," Crowfoot replied.‚Å† ‚Å† ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think science knows actually,‚Äù Trump concluded. Read more at our link in bio.

Description: Five cyclones are swirling around the Atlantic Ocean at the same time. As far as our records go, this has only ever happened once before in 1971.‚Å† ‚Å† Out of storms Paulette, Rene, Sally, Teddy and Vicky, two have strengthened into hurricanes as they head towards the US.‚Å† ‚Å† People were ordered to evacuate on Monday as Hurricane Sally hurtled across the Gulf of Mexico towards Louisiana and Mississippi. The storm is expected to bring "extreme life-threatening" flash flooding, storm surge and strong winds when it hits later today, according to the US National Hurricane Center.‚Å† ‚Å† It's the second major storm to hit the region within a month, following Hurricane Laura in August which killed dozens of people in the US and the Caribbean and caused widespread devastation.‚Å† ‚Å† Hurricane Paulette made rare landfall in Bermuda on Monday night. The island has been hit directly by fewer than 10 hurricanes since records began in the 1850s. No deaths, injuries or serious damage were reported.‚Å† ‚Å† There have been 20 hurricanes in the Atlantic storm season so far this year - so many that forecasters are running out of names for them. Once all the names on the list are used up, further storms will be named after letters of the Greek alphabet.‚Å† ‚Å† Scientists say the climate crisis and rising global temperatures are increasing the intensity of cyclones and affecting where in the world they form.‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† #hurricane #cyclone #extremeweather #hurricanesally #hurricanepaulette #climatecrisis #climatechange #climateemergency #storm #floods #louisiana #mississippi #bermuda
ImageText: There are five tropical cyclones raging in the Atlantio Ocean at the same time. It's only the second time it's happened on record. @channel4news

Description: The #Bobcatfire has managed to outwit firefighters, even in the absence of powerful Santa Ana winds that failed to materialize as predicted last week. Instead, officials say, the Bobcat fire‚Äôs power lies in two factors: its location and an inadequate supply of firefighters. But climate experts warn there are larger factors at play.  ‚ÄúThis fire was man-made on many levels,‚Äù said Bill Patzert, a climatologist who spent several decades at the NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory in La Ca√±ada Flintridge. Record heat, population growth, fossil fuels and other factors related to climate change have contributed not only to the state‚Äôs unprecedented fire season, Patzert said, but also to the particular challenges of the Bobcat fire. Description: Die WaldbraÃànde an der WestkuÃàste der USA sorgen auch fuÃàr politischen Streit: Auf der einen Seite die Demokraten, die die Ursache der BraÃànde im Voranschreiten des Klimawandels sehen, und US-PraÃàsident Trump auf der anderen Seite glaubt, die betroffenen Bundesstaaten seien an den verheerenden BraÃànden selbst schuld. Man halte dort naÃàmlich die WaÃàlder nicht richtig instand.  Wald-Experte Peter Wohlleben sagt dazu: ‚ÄûWenn ich WaÃàlder ramponiere, ausraÃàume, heizt sich das Lokalklima auf ‚Äì unabhaÃàngig vom Klimawandel. Es wird trockener. Wenn dann der Klimawandel noch dazu kommt, findet das Feuer natuÃàrlich ganz leicht Nahrung in diesen ausgetrockneten ehemaligen intakten OÃàkosystemen.‚Äú  Peter Wohlleben ist unter anderem Buch durch sein Buch "Das geheime Leben der BaÃàume" bekannt geworden. Auch im Deutschlandfunk setzt er sich fuÃàr eine oÃàkologische Waldwirtschaft ein: ‚ÄûDiese ramponierten WaÃàlder - durch Holzeinschlag, durch Rodungen der vergangenen Jahrhunderte, das ist kein neues PhaÃànomen - sind so klein und zerstuÃàckelt und mit geringer Biomasse ausgestattet, dass die nicht mehr richtig funktionieren in Bezug auf die WasserkreislaÃàufe.‚Äú  Das ganze Interview finden Sie uÃàber den Link in unserer Bio ‚¨ÜÔ∏è  #wald #waldbrand #brand #feuer #waldsterben #baum #baÃàume #nature #natur #klimawandel #kalifornien #usa #amerika #instapolitics @peter_wohlleben

Description: A big chunk of ice has broken away from the Arctic's largest remaining ice shelf - 79N, or Nioghalvfjerdsfjorden - in north-east Greenland. The section covers about 110 square km and satellite imagery shows that it‚Äôs shattered into many small pieces. The loss is further evidence of the rapid climate change taking place in Greenland, scientist say. "The atmosphere in this region has warmed by about 3C since 1980," said Dr Jenny Turton. "And in 2019 and 2020, it saw record summer temperatures," the polar researcher at Friedrich-Alexander University in Germany told BBC News. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the shattered ice and the impact a warming climate is having. (Copernicus Data/ESA/Sentinel-2b) #ClimateChange #Environment #Greenland #Satellite #bbcnews

(It isn't. But we all need to change, Lopez writes.)  ‚Ä¢ Columnist Erika D. Smith wants to know if you're as confused as she is about all of these ‚Äúcomplex‚Äù fires? She reports how in normal times, fires were named after landmarks. But these are abnormal times.  ‚Ä¢ Culture columnist and critic Mary McNamara reflects on life in California and how this moment shows how the state's residents are tough ‚Äî much tougher than you may think.  ‚Ä¢ Metro reporter and Essential California newsletter author Julia Wick explains how there's actually a word for the climate change-induced despair you may be feeling and traces its origin. Description: Wildfires are common in California, but as the state has heated up, they have burned further, for longer.‚Å† ‚Å† Parts of the sunshine state have warmed 2C in the past century, compared to the global average of 1C, and earlier this year its Death Valley had the highest global temperature on record, reaching 54.4C. ‚Å† ‚Å† The link between wildfires and climate change is simple, though quantifying it is harder: hotter air means more areas of drier vegetation, which act as a tinderbox.‚Å† ‚Å† The ten largest California fires since 1932 have all occurred since 2000 and this year‚Äôs have already hit a new record, having arrived much earlier than usual.‚Å† ‚Å† Read more via the link in bio‚Å† ‚Å† #Californiawildfires #SanFrancisco #climatechange #naturaldisaster #California #firefighters ‚Å†

Description: Oregon is experiencing its¬†worst fires in memory, with at least three deaths and swaths of two small cities burned to the ground. Hundreds of homes and other structures have been destroyed. Skies have turned bright orange or dark gray across the western part of the state, which is experiencing some of the worst air quality ever recorded.  Scientists say roaring winds were the equivalent of the notorious Santa Anas of Southern California. Their rare appearance in the rainforests of the Pacific Northwest is almost certainly due to climate change, according to researchers. And like the winds that race down the mountainsides near #LosAngeles each fall, gaining heat and fanning the flames as they go, the gales that struck #Oregon over the weekend have turned small #fires into infernos. More in our bio. üì∏: Kathryn Elsesser / AFP - @gettyimages
ImageText: Climate change brings Santa Ana-like winds and explosive wildfires to Oregon

Description: As deadly wildfires continue to devastate America's north-west, Washington governor Jay Inslee has blamed abnormally dry conditions and high temperatures fuelled by climate change for making the fires "so explosive."  Fires in Oregon have turned the sky blood orange red and forced hundreds of thousands of people to flee their homes. In Washington state, 600,000 acres have burned while hot, dry weather conditions in northern California have made the spread of multiple blazes easier.  The wildfires are estimated to be six times greater than they were at this time last year.  Inslee, who ran for the Democratic presidential nomination on a ticket that put the climate crisis as the number one issue facing America and the world, has now urged a rethink about how the wildfires are reported on.
ImageText: G We talk about this as wildfires, but we have to start thinking about it as more of a climate fire. Jay Inslee, Washington governor

Description: The world's wildlife populations have fallen by an average of 68% in just over four decades, with human consumption behind the devastating decline, the World Wildlife Fund warned in a new report. Latin America and the Caribbean are the world's worst-affected areas, with an average drop of 94%, the report said. Experts say that while the climate crisis is not yet the biggest cause of biodiversity loss, in the coming years, the climate crisis will become a key driver of species decline unless world leaders take action.‚Å† (üì∏: Getty Images)‚Å†
ImageText: CNN Human activity has wiped out two-thirds of world's wildlife since 1970, report says The report says that the kinds of steep wildlife populatior decreases the Earth has seen in recent decades have not been seen for millions of years

Description: Lung-damaging ozone #pollution in L.A. reached its highest levels in a generation and set records in other parts of Southern California during the blistering Labor Day weekend heat wave, air quality readings show.  Ozone pollution spiked to 185 parts per billion in downtown L.A. at midday Sunday, according to South Coast Air Quality Management District monitoring data. It was the highest hourly reading in Southern California since 2003 and the highest in downtown L.A. in 26 years.  Air quality officials said the high pollution readings were a result of intense heat combined with stagnant weather conditions and winds that were too weak to sweep away much pollution.   In the big picture, climate change is an underlying cause, according to air quality experts. Scientific studies have found that rising temperatures are making smog harder to control by speeding up the photochemical reactions that generate ozone gas.  Link in bio. üì∏: Allen J. Schaben/ Los Angeles Times

Description: It‚Äôs been another hellacious week in #California. Extraordinary heat. Out-of-control #fires. Dangerous rescues. A faltering power grid. Ash falling from darkened, orange skies. All of it influenced by the invisible hand of climate change, by way of the greenhouse gases we pump into the atmosphere when we fill our cars with oil, burn coal and natural gas for electricity, and chop down forests.  Even knowing how polarized American politics have become, it‚Äôs hard to imagine two candidates as diametrically opposed on any issue as Joe Biden and Donald Trump are on climate change. Description: More than one hundred regular members of the public have come together to hear from experts and give recommendations on how the government should tackle the climate crisis.‚Å† ‚Å† The UK has a legally binding target to reach net zero carbon emissions by 2050 - a transition which will require such huge changes that MPs instigated the Climate Assembly UK to give a representative sample of the UK population a say in how it happens.‚Å† ‚Å† The results of 60 hours worth of meetings over six months are published today. The recommendations, including on specific policy as well as overarching principles, are being sent to the Prime Minister, with responses from both government and MPs expected in the coming months.‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† #climateassembly #climatepolicy #climatechange #climatecrisis #climateemergency #transport #agriculture #renewables
ImageText: Members of of the public have given the UK government their ideas ideas on how to tackle climate change. Here's what they said. @channel4news

Description: Wildfires are worsening ‚Äî but the way we manage them isn‚Äôt keeping pace.‚Å£ ‚Å£ In the U.S., wildfires are ravaging the West. In California alone, 5 of the largest blazes on record have all struck in just the past 4 years, serving as a deadly reminder that the nation is far behind in adopting policies widely known to protect lives and property, even though worsening fires have become a predictable consequence of climate change.‚Å£ ‚Å£ Colorado, Washington and Oregon are facing record fire seasons. And California, with 2.5 million acres burned so far, has 14,000 firefighters working to contain 25 major wildfires even though ‚Äúthis year‚Äôs fire season has another four months to go,‚Äù according to @calfire.‚Å£ ‚Å£ The worsening wildfire disasters mean the U.S. needs to drastically rethink its approach to managing fire in the decades ahead, experts warn. ‚ÄúThe first step is to acknowledge that fire is inevitable, and we have to learn to live with it,‚Äù said David McWethy, a fire scientist at @montanastateuniversity.‚Å£ ‚Å£ A century of federal policy to aggressively extinguish all wildfires rather than letting some burn at low levels, an approach now seen as misguided, has left forests with plenty of fuel for especially destructive blazes. This is all in an era when global warming is creating a hotter, drier environment, loading the dice for more extensive fires.‚Å£ ‚Å£ Some cities and states have taken important steps, such as imposing tougher regulations on homes built in fire-prone areas. And there has been movement toward using prescribed fires to scour away excess vegetation that can fuel runaway blazes in forests and grasslands.‚Å£ ‚Å£ But these changes are still happening too slowly, experts say, and have been overtaken by the rapid increase in wildfires.‚Å£ ‚Å£ Tap the link in our bio to see the latest from the wildfires and to read more about the changes experts say are needed amid worsening fires. Photos by @maxwhittaker from the North Complex Fire in California. ‚Å£

Description: The San Francisco Bay Area awoke to a disorienting sight on Wednesday morning: deep orange skies and a smoky darkness lingered hours after sunrise, serving as a stark reminder of the wildfires still raging across California.‚Å†‚†Ä ‚Å†‚†Ä The phenomenon ‚Äï which was also seen in Oregon on Tuesday ‚Äï is a result of 16 different fire complexes burning in the region, dispersing smoke with the help of gusty wind. ‚Å†‚†Ä ‚Å†‚†Ä ‚ÄúStrong winds over the past few days transported ash from fires in northern California and the Sierra Nevada into the region,‚Äù the Bay Area Air District, the region‚Äôs air quality control agency, explained in a tweet.‚Å†‚†Ä ‚Å†‚†Ä ‚ÄúIf smoke becomes too thick in a certain area, most of the light will be scattered & absorbed before reaching the surface, which may cause dark skies.‚Äù A thick layer of marine fog below the smoky skies aided the effect. ‚Å†‚†Ä ‚Å†‚†Ä The National Weather Service‚Äôs Bay Area branch warned that even though the air quality in the region was moderate on Wednesday morning, the ‚Äúunprecedented smoke‚Äù hanging high in the air will likely descend closer to street level as the day goes on, making the air more dangerous to breathe.‚Å†‚†Ä ‚Å†‚†Ä It‚Äôs a familiar warning for Californians. Uncontrolled blazes across the state this year have so far burned a historic 2.3 million acres, representing a nearly 2,000% increase in land burned compared with this time last year, according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection.‚Å†‚†Ä ‚Å†‚†Ä ‚ÄúThis is yet another reminder though that we‚Äôre living with the effects of climate change in real time,‚Äù San Francisco Mayor London Breed tweeted Wednesday morning. ‚Å†‚†Ä ‚Å†‚†Ä Here are some images of Wednesday‚Äôs orange skies, which many compared to a scene from Mars. // üì∑ The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

Description: A project to create a wall of vegetation in Africa three times the size of Australia's Great Barrier Reef is not currently on track to be delivered by its target date in 2030, according to a UN report.   The Great Green Wall is a planned 100-million-hectare area of trees and plants stretching from Senegal to Djibouti to hold back the spread of desert into fertile land. Desertification is being sped up by climate change, reducing the amount of land suitable for grazing livestock and growing crops and affecting around 1.5 billion people globally, according to the UN.   A status report published yesterday examined the progress 11 countries in the Sahel had made since the project began in 2007. The Sahel is one of the regions most severely affected by drought and deterioration of soil quality and vegetation cover.  Although participating countries have restored around 18 million hectares of land, just 4 million hectares were planted within the Great Green Wall target area. To hit the 2030 deadline, more than twice that area will need to be restored every year at a cost of $4.3 billion annually.   Ethiopia has restored the biggest area so far, with 5.5 billion plants and seedlings produced. Other countries have been slower to make progress due to differences in geography, governance and economic development.  The report authors say more funding and technical support along with better governance and monitoring are needed for the project to be successful. . . . . . . . #reforestation #desertification #climatechange #climatecrisis #climateemergency #drought #trees #plants #africa

Description: New satellite images show the full extent of the devastating damage caused by the recent Australian wildfires.‚Å† ‚Å† Last year hundreds of fires burnt through an estimated 5.5 million hectares in New South Wales (NSW) during what's now been dubbed the 'Black Summer'. It killed at least 33 people, destroyed thousands of homes and affected billions of animals. ‚Å† ‚Å† The NSW government commissioned aerial analysis company Geospatial Intelligence to capture images both before and after the 2019 fire season. The images provide useful monitoring information about the landscape that could help with future bushfire recovery and mitigation activities.‚Å† ‚Å† The final report from an inquiry into the bushfires published at the end of July found Australia should expect even worse fire seasons in years to come as climate change intensifies. ‚Å† ‚Å† Image credit: Geospatial Intelligence Pty Ltd‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† #wildfires #australia #newsouthwales #bushfires #satellite #climatechange #climateeemergency #climatecrisis

Description: @elmostrador_cultura Un grupo de cient√≠ficos y expertos elabor√≥ el primer an√°lisis exhaustivo a nivel global sobre cu√°les son las √°reas terrestres esenciales para la biodiversidad y la resiliencia clim√°tica, y cuya conclusi√≥n es que estas representan el 50,4% de la superficie del planeta. El reporte se public√≥ ayer en la revista Science Advances y se titul√≥: ‚ÄúLa ‚ÄòRed de Protecci√≥n Global‚Äô para revertir la p√©rdida de la biodiversidad y estabilizar el clima de la Tierra‚Äù (1). El reporte destaca la importancia de salvaguardar y restaurar el mundo natural para poder abordar tres crisis convergentes: el cambio clim√°tico, la p√©rdida de biodiversidad y la aparici√≥n de nuevos virus, como el COVID 19.  El equipo de especialistas estuvo liderado por la organizaci√≥n de investigaci√≥n cient√≠fica RESOLVE, en colaboraci√≥n con la Universidad de Minesota, la Universidad Estatal de Arizona, Globa√Øa y otras m√°s, con el apoyo de One Earth. Los datos compilados para la Red de Protecci√≥n Global - Global Safety Net (GSN1) est√°n disponibles a trav√©s de una aplicaci√≥n web interactiva y desarrollada por One Earth en asociaci√≥n con Google Earth Engine. Los usuarios pueden dar clic sobre un pa√≠s, estado o ecorregi√≥n para conocer la conformaci√≥n de las zonas de importancia biol√≥gica para cada una de las regiones.  üëâcontin√∫a leyendo en el link de la bio‚ùóÔ∏è #ciencia #clima #chile

Description: Despu√©s de varias d√©cadas, Galicia recupera a sus ballenas. Esta semana, un velero de la armada se topaba con un grupo de orcas en r√≠as baixas. Description: @elmostrador_cultura Contin√∫a el Ciclo de Entrevistas Pioneros del Cambio de Fundaci√≥n Hypatia. El cuarto conversatorio online se titula ‚ÄúDi√°logo y Transformaci√≥n de Conflictos‚Äù y contar√° con la presencia de Alfredo Zamudio, director ejecutivo del Centro Nansen para la Paz y el Di√°logo y destacado facilitador de procesos de di√°logo a nivel global, con m√°s de 30 a√±os de experiencia en gesti√≥n de derechos humanos, emergencias humanitarias y transformaci√≥n de conflictos. En las √∫ltimas d√©cadas ha contribuido a la construcci√≥n de la paz en lugares como Colombia, Sud√°n, Timor Oriental, entre otros. Desde el 2019, Alfredo Zamudio ha dado charlas en nuestro pa√≠s y con el equipo Nansen en Chile, han apoyado capacidades de di√°logo. Esta quinta versi√≥n del Ciclo de Entrevistas de Fundaci√≥n Hypatia est√° co-organizada y patrocinada por el Centro Cultural de Espa√±a ‚ÄìCCE-Santiago‚Äì y realizada en alianza con El Mostrador. Las invitadas e invitados al ciclo son agentes de cambio relevantes de Chile y el mundo en temas de desarrollo humano, √©tica, cambio clim√°tico, regeneraci√≥n, equidad de g√©nero, paz, di√°logo y cuidado medioambiental.  La periodista Aleka Vial, directora de Fundaci√≥n Hypatia, facilita las conversaciones del ciclo en el que ya han participado los fil√≥sofos Gast√≥n Soublette y Ziley Mora; la climat√≥loga Maisa Rojas, el investigador en regeneraci√≥n Ronald Sistek, la presidenta de Comunidad Mujer, Mercedes Ducci y la directora ejecutiva de Hay Mujeres, Mai-Ni√© Chang.

Description: As the second major #heatwave in weeks bears down on Southern California, experts and authorities are warning the public to take seriously the health dangers of extreme temperatures that are only getting worse due to #climatechange.‚Äâ ‚Äâ ‚ÄúHeat of this magnitude is rare, dangerous and very possibly deadly,‚Äù the National Weather Service warned.‚Äâ ‚Äâ #Wildfires, elevated #smog levels and possible power outages may pose additional threats. The #pandemic, meanwhile, could make this #LaborDay weekend especially deadly, as #coronavirus restrictions have closed many of the cooled indoor spaces that usually offer relief.‚Äâ ‚Äâ Exacerbating it all is climate change, which researchers say is increasing the frequency and intensity of extreme heat events. As greenhouse gases continue to rise globally, heat spells of this severity are an unfortunate reality that Californians will increasingly have to get used to, they say. Visit the link in our bio to read more. üì∏: @luissinco

Description: 72 people have been arrested after trying to prevent a number of national newspapers from reaching people this morning.‚Å† ‚Å† Over 100 Extinction Rebellion protesters used bamboo structures and trucks to block roads outside printworks in Broxbourne, Hertfordshire, and Knowsley near Liverpool.‚Å† ‚Å† The group has accused some of the papers for failing to report on climate change.‚Å† ‚Å† They said: ‚ÄúThe right-wing media is a barrier to the truth, failing to reflect the scale and urgency of the crisis and hold governments to account.‚Å† ‚Å† ‚ÄúCoverage in many of the newspapers printed here is polluting national debate on climate change, immigration policy, the rights and treatment of minority groups, and on dozens of other issues.‚Äù‚Å† ‚Å† Five major national newspapers including the Sun, the Times and the Daily Mail were affected.‚Å† ‚Å† Boris Johnson condemned the protest group's actions in a Tweet, stating: "A free press is vital in holding the government and other powerful institutions to account on issues critical for the future of our country, including the fight against climate change.‚Å† ‚Å† "It is completely unacceptable to seek to limit the public‚Äôs access to news in this way.‚Å†" ‚Å† The Sun has refuted Extinction Rebellion‚Äôs claims - tweeting a climate change piece by Sir David Attenborough that featured their paper today.‚Å†  üì∑ Extinction Rebellion .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† #climate #climatecrisis #climateemergency #climatechange #environment #nature #globalwarming #sustainability #earth #extinctionrebellion #protest #protesters #media #newspapers  #climateaction #hertfordshire #merseyside #davidattenborough

Description: A seis meses de iniciada la pandemia en Chile, pareciera que todo puede cambiar. Dicen que se apret√≥ el acelerador, reduciendo a solo algunos meses aquel tiempo de las transformaciones que para muchos iban a tomar 10 a√±os. Lo que antes parec√≠a imposible, hoy es una necesidad para afrontar la realidad. Y los cambios acelerados traen incertidumbre, una sensaci√≥n que no para de repetirse dentro de las consultas ciudadanas que desarrollamos desde la plataforma "Tenemos que Hablar de Chile", iniciativa impulsada desde las universidades Cat√≥lica y de Chile, junto a otras varias organizaciones, que ya cuenta con las opiniones, anhelos e ideas de m√°s de 40.000 personas a lo largo de todo el pa√≠s. ¬øC√≥mo saldremos de todo esto? ¬øQu√© va a pasar con nuestras vidas? Son preguntas que no tienen respuestas certeras, pero que s√≠ rondan nuestras reflexiones diarias, especialmente en las de aquellas personas que viven situaciones de mayor dificultad y precariedad. La historia se est√° escribiendo saltando de crisis en crisis, desde el calentamiento global, pasando por la crisis sanitaria, la social y la econ√≥mica. La sensaci√≥n de incertidumbre va a marcar el comienzo de una nueva d√©cada y, quiz√°s, de una nueva era tanto para el mundo como para Chile. üëâcontin√∫a leyendo en el link de la bio‚ùóÔ∏è

Description: El mar de Bering sufre el mayor deshielo de los √∫ltimos (por lo menos) 5.500 a√±os.   El mar de Bering, porci√≥n del oc√©ano Pac√≠fico entre Alaska y Siberia, no se escapa al deshielo que afecta la mayor parte de la regi√≥n √°rtica. Un nuevo estudio internacional publicado este mes de setiembre en la revista Science Advances indica que en los inviernos de 2018 y 2019 se registr√≥ en la isla San Mateo (Alaska, EE.UU.), en la zona central del mar de Bering, el nivel m√°s bajo de hielo marino (flotante) en los √∫ltimos 5.500 a√±os (periodo estudiado, no se descarta que el r√©cord afecte a muchos m√°s a√±os atr√°s).  El equipo de este estudio analiza la alta sensibilidad de los hielos de esta zona √°rtica a las variaciones de concentraci√≥n de di√≥xido de carbono en la atm√≥sfera, uno de los procesos que actualmente est√° provocando el cambio clim√°tico.  Los datos de los sat√©lites ofrecen una clara imagen de c√≥mo ha cambiado el hielo marino en las √∫ltimas cuatro d√©cadas en la regi√≥n entre el √Årtico y el norte del oc√©ano Pac√≠fico. M√°s all√°, los √∫nicos registros de hielo disponibles son los de barcos y otras observaciones.  ‚úçÔ∏è Joaquim Elcacho üì∏ Mark Ralston  Toda la informaci√≥n en el link de nuestra bio üì≤ https://bit.ly/2DpqMzA  #mardebering #cambioclimatico #deshielo

Description: Extinction Rebellion (XR) activists are into a third day of demonstrations in London.  A 10-day series of "mass rebellions" started outside the Houses of Parliament on 1 September with gatherings planned across the UK during that time. Nearly 300 people have been arrested since the start of protests in the capital. Some XR supporters staged a sit-in while others, calling themselves Animal Rebellion, locked themselves on top of a pink slaughterhouse truck parked sideways across a road in central London. The campaigners said they are demanding "a plant-based food system as a means to mitigate the worst impacts of the climate crisis and reduce the risk of future pandemics". (Getty Images) #Protests #ClimateChange #BBCNews

Description: Se abre un nuevo ‚Äòcr√°ter‚Äô gigante de 50 metros de profundidad en la tundra √°rtica.   Aunque viendo las im√°genes nos pueda parecer algo extraordinario, de hecho este es el agujero n√∫mero 17 que se registra en Siberia. Este tipo de ‚Äòcr√°ters‚Äô se llaman hidrolacolitos o bulgunnyakhs y son causados por la acumulaci√≥n de gas metano en bolsas de permafrost descongelado debajo de la superficie.  Este es uno de los agujeros m√°s impresionantes que han aparecido en los √∫ltimos a√±os a medida que el permafrost se derrite, supuestamente por culpa del calentamiento global.  Seg√∫n los expertos, estos cr√°teres aparecen porque se forman cavidades saturadas de gas en el permafrost. En un sentido literal, un espacio vac√≠o lleno de gas a alta presi√≥n. La capa de cobertura se distiende, cuyo espesor es de 5 a 10 metros aproximadamente.  Bogoyavlensky afirma que las actividades humanas, como la extracci√≥n de gas de las vastas reservas de Yamal, podr√≠an ser un factor en la aparici√≥n de mont√≠culos y las erupciones, como las que han formado estos enormes agujeros.  üì∏ Vesti Yamal #yamal #siberia #rusia #cr√°ter #medioambiente #crisisclimatica #calentamientoglobal

Description: Eighty-one Nobel Prize winners endorsed Joe Biden for president in an open letter on Wednesday, citing the former vice president's "willingness to listen to experts" and his "deep appreciation for using science to find solutions." The Nobel laureates, winners of the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, Medicine and Physics, stressed the importance of elected leaders making decisions based on science, particularly during a global pandemic. "I support Joe Biden because of his long record of making policy, informed by science, to deal with large, complicated issues like cancer, climate change and nuclear proliferation," said Barry Barish, the 2017 Nobel Prize winner in physics. "More immediately, we absolutely must elect Joe with his science-based approach to successfully lead us out of the Covid-19 pandemic." (üì∏:Saul Loeb/AFP/Getty Images)‚Å†
ImageText: CNN 81 Nobel laureates endorse Biden for president Text UNITED to 30330 BIDEN HARRIS The Nobel laureates stressed the importance of elected leaders making decisions based on science, particularly during a global pandemic

Description: Scientists already knew that the climate crisis is melting glaciers fast, and that this form can form lakes. But now for the first time they‚Äôve quantified it.  Research published in Nature this week found that the number of glacier lakes has increased worldwide by 53 per cent, from 9,414 to 14,394, between 1990 and 2018.  The area of land the lakes cover has increased too, by 51 per cent, as well as the amount of water they hold, by 48 per cent, the research said.  One example is the Inja Lake near Mount Everest in Nepal, which only appeared in the 1950s as the surrounding glacier started to melt. Its rapid growth in the past few decades has meant that the military recently had to intervene with engineering works to control the threat it posed to people living below it.  Image credit: NASA . . . . . #climate #climatecrisis #climateemergency #climatechange #globalwarming #globalheating #greenhouse #co2 #lake #nature #research #science #nasa #engineering #atmosphere #glacier #ice #nepal #mounteverest
ImageText: The climate crisis is melting glaciers so fast that the size of their lakes has increased by 51 per cent in less than 30 years 1989 98 Lake 1990

Description: At least 65 people have been arrested at climate change protests organised by Extinction Rebellion.  The activist group has planned ten days of demonstrations across the UK to urge the government to tackle the climate crisis.  Around 1,000 campaigners gathered in Westminster as ministers returned to parliament after the summer recess. Protestors blocked a road near the Houses of Parliament before police carried them away to vans parked nearby.   Organisers said other "key institutions of power" would be targeted in the coming days, encouraging protesters to respect social distancing due to the coronavirus pandemic.  Last year, more than 1,700 people were arrested during a similar 10-day Autumn Uprising, which caused widespread disruption.   Extinction Rebellion wants the government to back a proposed Climate and Ecological Emergency Bill. It aims to speed up the UK's progress on reducing its carbon emissions, increase conservation efforts and create a Citizen's Assembly to discuss how to tackle climate change.  . . . . . . #climatechange #climatecrisis #climateemergency #extinctionrebellion #london #manchester

Description: At least five Extinction Rebellion protesters have been arrested after blocking a road near the Houses of Parliament on the first day of protests. ¬† The environmental¬†campaign group have started their ten day long protests in several places across the UK. ¬† Four marches converged on Parliament Square after the environmental group planned rallies to go ahead at several landmarks in the capital. ¬† Some campaigners sat in the middle of the road next to Parliament Square, which forced traffic to stop. It prompted dozens of police officers to take them away to vans parked nearby, as the rest of the group danced, cheered and chanted. ¬† The Metropolitan Police had already imposed conditions against protests planned for Tuesday and said gatherings could only take place off the main roads at Parliament Square Gardens between 8am and 7pm. ¬† Extinction Rebellion co-founder Dr Gail Bradbrook told Sky News the public had "got the message" over the urgency of fighting climate change and apologised for any disruption. ¬† #XR #ExtinctionRebellion #protest #climate #change #crisis #global #warming #UK #Lodnon #action #group #capital #parliamnet #enviroment #enviromental #march

Description: Big Oil is in trouble. Its plan: flood Africa with plastic.  Confronting a climate crisis that threatens the fossil fuel industry, oil companies are racing to make more plastic. But they face two problems: Many markets are already awash with plastic, and few countries are willing to be dumping grounds for the world‚Äôs plastic waste.  The industry thinks it has found a solution to both problems in Africa.  According to documents reviewed by The New York Times, an industry group representing the world‚Äôs largest chemical makers and fossil fuel companies is lobbying to influence U.S. trade negotiations with Kenya to reverse its strict limits on plastics ‚Äî including a tough plastic-bag ban. It is also pressing for Kenya, one of Africa‚Äôs biggest economies, to continue importing foreign plastic garbage, a practice it has pledged to limit.  Plastics makers are looking well beyond Kenya‚Äôs borders. ‚ÄúWe anticipate that Kenya could serve in the future as a hub for supplying U.S.-made chemicals and plastics to other markets in Africa through this trade agreement,‚Äù Ed Brzytwa, the director of international trade for the American Chemistry Council, wrote in an April 28 letter to the Office of the United States Trade Representative.  The U.S. and Kenya are in the midst of trade negotiations and the Kenyan president, Uhuru Kenyatta, has made clear he is eager to strike a deal. But the behind-the-scenes lobbying by the petroleum companies has spread concern among environmental groups that have been working to reduce both plastic use and waste.  Tap the link in our bio for more. Photo by @farahkhad.
