Description: El gato patinegro, el ‚Äòadorable‚Äô felino m√°s letal del mundo.  Si te lo encuentras, dan ganas de achucharlo. Sin embargo, mejor que no lo hagas porque el gato patinegro (Felis nigripes) es solitario y m√°s bien letal para todo el que se acerque a hacerle caranto√±as pensando que podr√≠a dejarse hacer como un gato dom√©stico com√∫n. Este tipo de felino es el gato salvaje m√°s peque√±o de √Åfrica, pero que no te enga√±e su adorable aspecto, es un cazador nato, con una tasa de mortalidad en sus presas superior a la de cualquier otro felino, y eso incluye leones y tigres. Hablando de leones, no esperes que este tipo de gato emita maullidos adorables, porque sus rugidos son roncos, como los de los grandes felinos con los que convive.  Con machos adultos que pueden alcanzar hasta los 2,5 kilos de peso y hembras de 1,6 kilos, deben su nombre al color de sus patas inferiores, de color negro, que contrasta con su pelaje en tonos marrones y machas como si fuese un leopardo.  Suele encontrarse en pa√≠ses como Namibia, Botsuana, Sud√°frica y algunas zonas del extremo sur de Angola, pero lamentablemente este animal se encuentra en peligro de extinci√≥n. Sus principales amenazas son el veneno y las trampas que se ponen para otros depredadores, as√≠ como la p√©rdida de su h√°bitat natural por culpa del cambio clim√°tico y la deforestaci√≥n.  üì∏ Charles Barilleaux / Flickr / Jonathan Kriz #gato #felino #africa #gatosalvaje #libertad #peligroextinci√≥n #lovecats #loveanimals

Description: For those who love it, the appeal of the wine industry is that it doesn‚Äôt change fast. In a world that's chaotic and fast moving, wine is a faithful Dobbin. More than 8,000 years have passed since the first amphorae of wine were produced in the Caucasus. The Romans replaced them with barrels. In the 17th century glass was introduced but it wasn‚Äôt until the 1820s that wine bottles started to look like those we use today. ‚Å† ‚Å† Reputations are not made overnight, but built over generations. It takes hundreds of years to create a success story like champagne. ‚Å† ‚Å† Things may not move fast, but there is an acknowledgement within the wine world that change is coming. ‚Å† ‚Å† Online sales of wine boomed during lockdown but the bigger picture is one of consumption decline. In 2015 around 29.5 million people were drinking wine at least once a month, and around 80 per cent of these people were drinking wine at least once a week. Today, data by Wine Intelligence suggests that the overall monthly drinking population has fallen by about 1 million, to 28.5 million.‚Å† ‚Å† With craft beer growing in popularity and a post-Covid world looming, is wine in an inexorable state of slow decline? Read more at the link in bio

Description: @agendapais2030 El pasado martes 25 de agosto, tras casi un mes de su aprobaci√≥n, el Presidente Sebasti√°n Pi√±era firm√≥ el reglamento que establece criterios de protecci√≥n de humedales urbanos. En este se establecen 10 criterios que buscan asegurar la protecci√≥n de los humedales y entregar las herramientas para cuidar y conservar estos ecosistemas.   El reglamento establece cuatro grupos de criterios: formas de resguardar las caracter√≠sticas ecol√≥gicas y el funcionamiento de los humedales, mantener el r√©gimen y conectividad hidrol√≥gica tanto superficial como subterr√°nea, el uso racional de humedales urbanos y la gesti√≥n sustentable y gobernanza de estos.   Ignacio Rodr√≠guez, director del Centro de Humedales R√≠o Cruces, se refiri√≥ al reglamento, se√±alando que existen modificaciones respecto a la propuesta presentada por el centro. ‚ÄúDe los 14 criterios que nosotros propusimos, al menos tiene 10 que tienen otras frases, que son un poco m√°s suaves de lo que nosotros hab√≠amos propuesto. Pero de todas maneras es un paso muy importante‚Äù.   ‚ÄúAca tienes la definici√≥n internacional de humedales, eso ya es un gran paso. Luego vienen estos criterios que no son perfectos pero son bastante buenos. Ahora el desaf√≠o que viene es la implementaci√≥n, porque el papel aguanta mucho y ahora tenemos que ver c√≥mo lo implementamos‚Äù, coment√≥ Rodr√≠guez. El reglamento, que hoy se encuentra en la Contralor√≠a General de la Rep√∫blica, debe ser revisado por el Contralor para luego ser publicado en el Diario Oficial. Tras ello, el reglamento podr√° comenzar a ser implementado. #humedales #chile üëâcontin√∫a leyendo en el link de la bio ‚ùóÔ∏è

Description: New research reveals melting ice on Antarctica may break up the continent‚Äôs outer edges - in a process which may make sea level rise faster than we thought.  Antarctica is around twice the size of Australia and almost entirely covered in ice. The majority of this, its ice sheets, sits above land, while much of its outer limit floats on the sea as ice shelves.  Around 60% of these shelves may already be vulnerable to fracturing by climate change-induced melting of the upper ice sheets, according to research published this week in Nature.  Researchers‚Äô understanding of ‚Äòhydrofracturing‚Äô, where existing crevices in surface ice are made deeper and break apart after an influx of water, is only just emerging.  The precise scale of impact isn‚Äôt known, but scientists believe the fracturing of the shelves may exacerbate the melting of the ice sheets themselves - increasing the amount of water flowing into the ocean.  Sea level rise is one of the most direct impacts of climate change. Without drastic reduction of current carbon emissions, even conservative estimates say that coasts could be met with 26 to 77 centimetres of higher tides by the end of this century - eroding the edges of cities from New York to Dhaka.  Ching-Yao Lai from Columbia University, who led the research, told Channel 4 News: "We still need a lot of work to understand how fast and how much ice surface melting links to sea levels, but our result confirms the trend is worrying."  Image credits: 1) NASA  2) Ching-Yao Lai, Nature . . . . . . #climate #climatechange #climatecrisis #climateemergency globalwarming #globalheating #earth #nature #planet # science #research #ice #fossilfuels #Columbia #antarctica
ImageText: 60% of Antarctica's ice shelves an area roughly four times the size of the UK is at risk of breaking apart due to climate change Antarctica Locations of fractures 500 km @channel4news

Description: Climate change is piling on to the hazards already faced by California farm laborers ‚Äî some of the country's poorest, most neglected workers.   Summer days are hotter than they were a century ago in the already scorching San Joaquin Valley. The nights, when the body would normally cool down, are warming faster. Heat waves are more frequent. And across the state, fires have burned over a million acres in less than 2 weeks.   Still, hundreds of thousands of men and women there continue to pluck and pack produce for the nation, as temperatures soar into the triple digits for days at a time and the air turns to a soup of dust and smoke, stirred with pollution from truck tailpipes and chemicals sprayed on the fields.   The San Joaquin Valley Air Pollution Control District urged residents to stay indoors. Good advice, in theory, Leonor Hern√°ndez, a mother of 3, said. ‚ÄúBut we need to work, and if we stay indoors we don‚Äôt get paid,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe have bills for food and rent to pay.‚Äù   The problem of intensifying heat underscores that issue: You work fewer hours, you make less. And for those who get paid at piece rates ‚Äî wine grape pickers generally get paid by the bin ‚Äî there can be a perverse incentive to work as fast as possible, even if it means skipping a water break.   ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the price of cheap food,‚Äù said Armando Elenes, secretary-treasurer of the United Farm Workers of America, which was an advocate for heat standards in California 15 years ago after a spate of farmworker deaths. The union is pushing for similar national legislation. Tap the link in our bio to read more. Photos by @brianlfrank

Description: Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è More than 650 wildfires, many sparked by lightning, have burned more than 1.25 million acres in California since August 15. That's more than six times the size of New York City. The fires have left at least seven people dead and more than 1,400 buildings destroyed, Cal Fire said. Summer temperatures are rising well above-average. In Death Valley last week, the temperature rose to a sweltering 130 degrees Fahrenheit ‚Äî the hottest temperature recorded in the world since 1913. "If you don't believe in climate change, come to California," tweeted California Gov. Gavin Newsom.  (üì∏::Josh Edelson/AFP/Getty Images, Noah Berger, AP, Jeff Chu/AP, Marco Jose Sanchez/AP)

Description: La activista del clima Greta Thunberg volvi√≥ al colegio luego de tomarse un a√±o libre, en el que emergi√≥ como la voz de los j√≥venes que intentan salvar al planeta del calentamiento global y cuestion√≥ a los pol√≠ticos por ser demasiado lentos para hacer un cambio.  Al publicar una foto suya con una mochila y empujando una bicicleta, la joven sueca de 17 a√±os twitte√≥: "¬°Mi a√±o sab√°tico de la escuela termin√≥ y se siente tan bien estar finalmente de regreso en la escuela!".  Thunberg, quien desat√≥ un movimiento de protesta mundial liderado por j√≥venes despu√©s de hacer huelga frente al Parlamento sueco en 2018, ha pasado el √∫ltimo a√±o reprendiendo a los pol√≠ticos sobre el aumento de las temperaturas y lo que ve como su incumplimiento de los acuerdos consagrados en el Acuerdo Clim√°tico de Par√≠s de 2015.  Thunberg, tambi√©n fue elegida Persona del A√±o de la revista Time en 2019, y habl√≥ en el Foro Econ√≥mico Mundial de Davos y en la cumbre del clima COP25 en Madrid durante los √∫ltimos 12 meses, pidiendo acciones urgentes para prevenir un desastre clim√°tico.

Description: Greta Thunberg vuelve al cole tras su a√±o de activismo‚†Ä ‚†Ä La activista medioambiental sueca vuelve a clase despu√©s de viajar por el mundo para concientizar de la importancia de la lucha contra la crisis clim√°tica. ‚†Ä ‚†Ä As√≠ lo ha anunciado en sus redes sociales: "¬°Mi a√±o sab√°tico ha terminado, y me siento muy bien de volver por fin a la escuela!", ha publicado la joven de 17 a√±os en su cuenta de Twitter. ‚†Ä ‚†Ä Thunberg no ha revelado en qu√© ciudad o escuela continuar√° sus estudios, que fueron paralizados en junio de 2019.‚†Ä ‚†Ä üì∑ @gretathunberg‚†Ä  ‚†Ä #GretaThunberg #activismo #cambioclim√°tico #vueltaalcole

Description: @agendapais2030 Los parques y √°reas protegidas han demostrado beneficios insospechados para muchas personas, como su contribuci√≥n a la salud mental, a frenar el cambio clim√°tico e incluso a la prevenci√≥n de enfermedades de origen animal, que han dado origen a pandemias.  En Chile, la institucionalidad ambiental a√∫n est√° incompleta en cuanto a las √°reas protegidas y saldar esta deuda con la la naturaleza del pa√≠s no puede seguir esperando.  As√≠ lo destacaron desde WWF Chile en el contexto del D√≠a Internacional de los Parques Nacionales, que se celebra este lunes 24 de agosto. ‚ÄúAunque muchos no lo saben, en Chile nuestras √°reas protegidas a√∫n no est√°n debidamente resguardadas, al menos no en su institucionalidad. En este d√≠a debemos reflexionar sobre el crucial aporte que realizan estos espacios naturales a la salud del planeta y tambi√©n de los seres humanos, y en Chile es importante movilizarnos para acelerar la toma de decisiones y finalizar un proceso que ya lleva demasiados a√±os, arriesgando incluso que nunca se materialice. Es por eso que levantamos un llamado al Congreso a aprobar el Servicio de Biodiversidad y √Åreas Protegidas (SBAP), cuyo primer proyecto de ley fue ingresado en 2011‚Äù, se√±ala Rodrigo Catal√°n, director de Conservaci√≥n de la organizaci√≥n ambientalista.  ‚ÄúJunto a otras ONGs hemos propuesto indicaciones para mejorar el proyecto, esperamos que estas sean acogidas y resaltamos que la tramitaci√≥n no puede seguir extendi√©ndose en un contexto de crisis clim√°tica, p√©rdida de biodiversidad y necesidad de una reactivaci√≥n econ√≥mica verde que ponga en valor nuestra naturaleza en lugar de destruirla‚Äù, agrega el experto.  El proyecto de ley que crea el SBAP, que se encuentra con suma urgencia desde junio en la C√°mara de Diputados, contempla la creaci√≥n de un servicio p√∫blico dependiente del Ministerio del Medio Ambiente (MMA) que tendr√° por objetivo la conservaci√≥n de la biodiversidad del pa√≠s, administrando el sistema nacional de √°reas protegidas, tanto marinas como terrestres. #parquenacionales #medioambiente #chile üëâlink en la bio‚ùóÔ∏è
ImageText: D√≠a Internacional de los Parques Nacionales: por qu√© Chile debe contar con un Servicio de Biodiversidad y √Åreas Protegidas por Agenda Pa√≠s 24 24 agosto, 2020

Description: La  Tierra ha llegado a su fecha de sobrecapacidad natural, es decir, el 22 de agosto es el d√≠a en el que se terminan todos los recursos naturales que el planeta es capaz de regenerar en el t√©rmino de un a√±o. Para terminar con esta ‚Äúhipoteca‚Äù en 2050, WWF pide cambios profundos tanto colectivos como individuales en el sistema de producci√≥n y consumo mediante la campa√±a 'Acuerdo por la Naturaleza y las Personas'. Concretamente, insta a poner freno a la p√©rdida de especies, la destrucci√≥n del h√°bitat y a reducir la huella ecol√≥gica e insta a los Gobiernos a impulsar "nuevas pol√≠ticas" y que aprovechen los fondos que se invertir√°n en la reconstrucci√≥n econ√≥mica para impulsar aprovechen los fondos una transici√≥n verde justa y resiliente. El coordinador de conservaci√≥n de WWF, Luis Su√°rez, ha explicado en declaraciones a Europa Press que los planes deber√°n impulsar actividades que contribuyan a la descarbonizaci√≥n de la econom√≠a, reducir las emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero y hacer frente al cambio clim√°tico, pero tambi√©n cambios individuales. En concreto, ha precisado que este 2020 el conocido como D√≠a de la Sobrecapacidad de la Tierra, es decir el d√≠a en que se han consumido "todos los recursos naturales que el planeta es capaz de regenerar en un a√±o" se ha aplazado hasta el 22 de agosto, a consecuencia de la pandemia del COVID-19, ya que en los √∫ltimos a√±os la fecha era el 31 de julio.  #Tierra #MedioAmbiente #WWF

Description: Already contending with climate change, the tourism operators who depend on the Great Barrier Reef have been walloped by the pandemic.‚Å£ ‚Å£ Under the ocean, among the parrotfish and green turtles, Russell Hosp, a local reef guide, said, ‚Äúyou could almost forget what was going on in the world.‚Äù But aboard the boat, the harsh reality of the virus‚Äôs impact came flooding back.‚Å£ ‚Å£ ‚ÄúIt was a bit surreal,‚Äù Hosp said of spending hours at sea unaccompanied by the usual enthusiastic visitors. In that moment, he said, he realized just how much the coronavirus ‚Äúhad changed the world.‚Äù‚Å£ ‚Å£ The pandemic has fast-forwarded a looming reckoning for Cairns, a city of 150,000 people in far northeastern Australia that is the main gateway to the reef and the base for Hosp and many others whose livelihoods depend on it.‚Å£ ‚Å£ Tour operators were already fighting a perception that the reef is in its death throes, as warming waters cause repeated mass bleaching that has robbed some corals of their vivid colors. But where climate change has in reality been more of a creeping threat to the reef‚Äôs survival and thus to Cairns‚Äôs tourism lifeblood, the coronavirus has delivered a hammer blow.‚Å£ ‚Å£ Foreign and local tourists, already deterred by last summer‚Äôs devastating bush fires and now locked out by Australia‚Äôs travel bans, have all but vanished, grinding a $4.6 billion industry built around the world‚Äôs largest living structure to a near halt.‚Å£ ‚Å£ ‚ÄúWe‚Äôd never stopped running before ‚Äî the global financial crisis, terrorism attacks, airline strikes; you name it, the world has thrown it at us,‚Äù Hosp said. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt know if we‚Äôll ever get back to normal.‚Äù‚Å£ ‚Å£ Tap the link in our bio to read the latest dispatch from the Great Barrier Reef. Photos by @nataliegrono.‚Å£

Description: @agendapais2030 En el Archipi√©lago de Chilo√© no existen suministros de agua dulce proveniente de los deshielos de las monta√±as como en el continente, sino que sus napas subterr√°neas se alimentan del agua lluvia acumulada en un tipo de humedal llamado ‚ÄúTurberas‚Äù. Este libera lentamente estas aguas a los acu√≠feros donde crece el musgo Sphagnum magallanicum, conocido como ‚ÄúPomp√≥n‚Äù, que es capaz de absorber hasta 20 veces su peso en agua.  Pero desde hace algunos a√±os el musgo se extrae sin control hasta llevar este recurso a pasos de volverse escaso y as√≠ tambi√©n el agua dulce que en temporada de verano disminuye cada vez m√°s en Chilo√©.  Por esto la mesa ‚ÄúHumedales de Chilo√©: Patrimonio de Todos‚Äù, instancia p√∫blico-privada que vela por la importancia de conservar estos fr√°giles ecosistemas, est√° fomentando una serie de iniciativas para la protecci√≥n de los humedales costeros y terrestres.  Su vocera es Gabriela Navarro, ec√≥loga y encargada de la Unidad de Extensi√≥n Cient√≠fica de la Sede Puerto Montt de la U. Austral de Chile, y actualmente convoca ideas, medios y gente en b√∫squeda de soluciones aunadas para el cuidado de los humedales de Chilo√©, como el inventario que hizo la Universidad mediante un proyecto Corfo y la implementaci√≥n de un Centro de Interpretaci√≥n sobre Humedales en la Localidad de Yaldad, comuna de Quell√≥n.  Pero nada de esto es suficiente, si no se complementa con una adecuada regulaci√≥n en materia de extracci√≥n del denominado Sphagnum magallanicum. Navarro destaca que en Chilo√© existen condiciones muy especiales pues es un territorio que adem√°s de estar aislado geogr√°ficamente cada a√±o sufre importantes problemas de sequ√≠a durante la temporada estival.  ‚ÄúDebido a la crisis h√≠drica que afecta al planeta producto del cambio clim√°tico, que en el archipi√©lago se agudiza, pues no contamos con cordilleras nevadas como reservas de aguas dulce en estado s√≥lido. Es por ello que la exploraci√≥n extensiva del musgo Sphagnum provoca un impacto directo en las personas al ser un ecosistema √∫nico que protege y nutre los acu√≠feros que proveen de agua dulce del cual depende toda la poblaci√≥n de Chilo√©‚Äù, sostiene. üëâlink en la bio‚ùóÔ∏è#chiloe #pompon
ImageText: Sustentabilidad Extracci√≥n ie indiscriminada de musgo "pomp√≥n" hace peligrar el agua en Chilo√© por Agenda Pa√≠s 22 agosto, 2020

Description: The Greenland ice sheet lost a record amount of ice in 2019, equivalent to a million tonnes per minute across the year.  Satellite data shows that the climate crisis is heating the Arctic at double the rate in lower latitudes, and the ice cap is the biggest single contributor to sea level rise, which already imperils coasts around the world.  The ice sheet shrank by 532bn tonnes last year as its surface melted and glaciers fell into the ocean. These could have filled seven Olympic-sized swimming pools per second.  Snowfall in Greenland was low in 2019, also due to the blocking pattern, meaning relatively little new ice was added. If the entire Greenland ice sheet melts, sea level would rise by six metres.  But despite the rapid melting, the Greenland ice sheet isn't necessarily doomed to melt entirely. Firstly, as glaciers retreat they lose contact with warmer ocean waters and therefore melt less. Secondly, the melting of the sheet with warm air takes centuries, during which time we might be able to reverse the rise in global temperatures.  . . . . . . .#Greenland #Glacier #Ice #Climatecrisis #Arctic #GlobalHeating
ImageText: G Greenland ice sheet lost a record 1m tonnes of ofice per minute in 2019

Description: The wildfires that continued to rip across Northern California on Thursday have so far killed 5 people and forced at least 62,000 from their homes as firefighters struggle to contain the blazes.‚Å£ ‚Å£ At least 4 bodies were recovered Thursday, the authorities said, including 3 from a burned house in a rural area in Napa County and a man found in Solano County. On Wednesday, a helicopter pilot on a water-dropping mission died in a crash in Fresno County.‚Å£ ‚Å£ The fires, burning across more than 500,000 acres, were ignited by lightning during an extraordinary period of more than 10,800 lightning strikes over several days, which caused hundreds of fires, including nearly a dozen major ones. As flames raced toward homes this week, smoke worsened an already oppressive heat wave, lightning strikes sparked new fires, the electrical grid struggled to keep up with demand, and the coronavirus threatened illness in evacuation shelters.‚Å£ ‚Å£ Firefighters have struggled to contain the largest fires. One group of fires, called the LNU Lightning Complex, doubled in size Wednesday and nearly doubled again on Thursday, growing to 219,067 acres as it stretched across Napa and 4 surrounding counties. The fires in that grouping have destroyed nearly 500 homes and other buildings.‚Å£ ‚Å£ Governor @gavinnewsom of California, in a video message for the @demconvention on Thursday, called the state‚Äôs wildfires an ‚Äúunprecedented challenge‚Äù and linked them to global warming. ‚Å£ ‚Å£ ‚ÄúIf you are in denial about climate change, come to California,‚Äù he said.‚Å£ ‚Å£ Tap the link in our bio for the latest from the wildfires. Photos by @maxwhittaker.‚Å£

Description: On the final night of the @demconvention, Joe Biden officially accepted the Democratic presidential nomination.‚Å£ ‚Å£ Speaking before a row of flags in his home state, Delaware, Biden gave a speech urging Americans to have faith that they could ‚Äúovercome this season of darkness,‚Äù and pledged that he would seek to bridge the country‚Äôs political divisions in ways President Trump had not.‚Å£ ‚Å£ ‚ÄúThe current president has cloaked America in darkness for much too long ‚Äî too much anger, too much fear, too much division,‚Äù Biden said. ‚ÄúHere and now, I give you my word: If you entrust me with the presidency, I will draw on the best of us, not the worst. I will be an ally of the light, not the darkness.‚Äù‚Å£ ‚Å£ The party has offered @joebiden less as a traditional partisan standard-bearer than as a comforting national healer, capable of restoring normalcy and calm to the U.S. and returning its federal government to working order. He has campaigned as an apostle of personal decency and political conciliation, and as a transitional figure who would take on some of the worst American crises ‚Äî not just the coronavirus outbreak but also economic inequality, climate change and gun violence ‚Äî before handing off power to another generation.‚Å£ ‚Å£ That rising generation, defined by its diversity and in many cases by its liberalism, was evident on Thursday, as it has been throughout the week ‚Äî the program leading up to Biden‚Äôs address included speakers such as @senduckworth, an Asian-American military veteran; @keishabottoms, one of the country‚Äôs most prominent Black mayors; and @pete.buttigieg, the first openly gay major presidential candidate. And after his acceptance speech, Biden and his wife, Jill, were joined by his running mate, Senator Kamala Harris, and her husband, Douglas Emhoff on stage.‚Å£ ‚Å£ The former vice president said that while he is a Democratic candidate, he will be ‚Äúan American president.‚Äù And in an implicit contrast with Trump, Biden said he would ‚Äúwork hard for those who didn‚Äôt support me.‚Äù‚Å£ ‚Å£ ‚ÄúThis is not a partisan moment,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThis must be an American moment.‚Äù‚Å£ ‚Å£ Tap the link in our bio to read Biden‚Äôs full speech and for more from the DNC. Photo by @erinschaff.

Description: @elmostrador_cultura Los ping√ºinos se originaron hace 22 millones de a√±os, en un h√°bitat muy distinto al que imaginamos com√∫nmente. Nada de aguas congeladas ni hielos a su alrededor, sino un ecosistema templado muy lejos de la Ant√°rtica, situado en las costas de Nueva Zelanda y Australia. Esta historia, que transcurri√≥ en los comienzos del Mioceno, ser√≠a el punto inicial de largas y exitosas trayectorias de migraci√≥n para este grupo de aves marinas que, actualmente, se distribuyen a lo largo y ancho del oc√©ano austral. ¬øC√≥mo se pudo concluir esto?   Una investigaci√≥n multinacional, encabezada por un equipo chileno, y que fue recientemente publicada en la Revista PNAS -Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the USA-, entreg√≥ pistas sobre el origen de estos innatos buceadores. Tambi√©n participaron de los hallazgos, cient√≠ficos de Brasil, Estados Unidos, Espa√±a, Francia, M√≥naco, Reino Unido, Australia y Sud√°frica.  El trabajo, liderado por Juliana Vianna de la Universidad Cat√≥lica de Chile, e investigadores del Instituto de Ecolog√≠a y Biodiversidad IEB, analiz√≥ el genoma completo de todas las especies de ping√ºinos que actualmente se conocen. Gracias a esta informaci√≥n, se logr√≥ conocer la historia de su diversificaci√≥n en nuevos grupos o linajes, y la adaptaci√≥n de estos animales a diferentes entornos.  El equipo nacional, que adem√°s forma parte del proyecto anillo ‚ÄúGenomics antarctic Biodiversity‚Äù del Programa de Investigaci√≥n Asociativa ANID, estima que estos conocimientos tambi√©n pueden contribuir al estudio de escenarios ambientales presentes y futuros, marcados por el cambio clim√°tico.   #cambioclimatico #pinguinos #chile
ImageText: CULTURA CIENCIA Investigadores de Chile revelan origen de los ping√ºinos en aguas templadas, fuera de la Ant√°rtica porEl Mostrador Cultura 21 agosto, 2020

Description: Sat√©lites de la NASA demuestran que este est√° siendo el peor verano para el hielo del √Årtico.  El verano de 2020 en el hemisferio norte todav√≠a tiene recorrido por delante -de calor, sin duda- pero, por lo que sabemos de momento, el hielo del oc√©ano √Årtico est√° viviendo sus peores momentos, por lo menos desde que se disponen de datos fiables en tiempo real. La Nasa, a trav√©s de su servicio especializado en el estudio de la superficie terrestres -Earth Observatory- presentaba este 6 de agosto como Imagen del D√≠a un fotomontaje en el que se comparan im√°genes captadas desde sat√©lites en estas mismas fechas del verano en los a√±os 2000, 2010 y 2020.   Las im√°genes no dejan lugar a dudas: la situaci√≥n empeora de forma notable y r√°pida. La crisis clim√°tica est√° m√°s que clara en el regi√≥n del Polo Norte. Los mapas comparados muestran la extensi√≥n del hielo marino en el oc√©ano √Årtico en los meses de 2020. La extensi√≥n se define como el √°rea total en la que la concentraci√≥n de hielo es de al menos el 15%: cantidad m√≠nima a la que las mediciones basadas en el espacio proporcionan una medici√≥n confiable, especifica la Nasa desde el punto de vista t√©cnico. El contorno amarillo de cada mapa muestra la extensi√≥n media de 30 a√±os para los meses de julio.  üì∏  NASA Lee toda la informaci√≥n en el link de nuestra bio üì≤ https://bit.ly/3l84l38  #NASA #Artico #deshielo #calor

Description: El exvicepresidente dem√≥crata Joe Biden se reivindic√≥ este jueves como el l√≠der que unir√° de nuevo al pa√≠s y acabar√° con una ‚Äútemporada de oscuridad‚Äù de la que responsabiliz√≥ a Donald Trump, el pol√©mico empresario republicano que, contra pron√≥stico, lleg√≥ a la presidencia m√°s poderosa del mundo hace cuatro a√±os. ‚ÄúAcepto con humildad y una gran honor la nominaci√≥n a presidente de Estados Unidos‚Äù, dijo al principio de su discurso, y culmin√≥ as√≠ una carrera de 30 a√±os, los que han pasado desde la primera vez que este hijo de un vendedor de coches, nacido en el cintur√≥n industrial de Pensilvania, se postul√≥ para la Casa Blanca. La historia ha querido hacerle candidato en unas elecciones extraordinarias, en medio de una pandemia que ha matado a 170.000 personas solo en EE UU y desatado una grave crisis mundial. ‚ÄúAqu√≠ y ahora os doy mi palabra: si me confi√°is la presidencia, sacar√© lo mejor de nosotros mismos, no lo peor. Ser√© un aliado de la luz, no de la oscuridad. Es el momento de que nosotros, el pueblo, nos unamos. No os equivoqu√©is, unidos podemos superar y superaremos esta temporada de oscuridad. Elegiremos la esperanza frente al miedo‚Äù, clam√≥ en la cuarta y √∫ltima noche de convenci√≥n dem√≥crata. Joseph Robinette Biden J√∫nior (Scranton, Pensilvania, 1942) gan√≥ sus primeras elecciones al Senado a los 29 a√±os, convirti√©ndose en uno de los miembros m√°s j√≥venes de la historia en llegar a la C√°mara alta. Si vence a Trump el 3 de noviembre, ser√° ahora, a los 77, el mayor en llegar a la presidencia. Son extremos posibles en una larga vida pol√≠tica, que sirve tanto de aval como de losa en esta elecci√≥n. El vicepresidente de Obama apel√≥ a la ‚Äúesperanza‚Äù y prometi√≥ sacar a los ciudadanos de la cu√°druple crisis que atraviesa el pa√≠s: la peor pandemia en un siglo, el mayor declive econ√≥mico desde la Gran Depresi√≥n, las manifestaciones contra el racismo m√°s intensas en 50 a√±os y la aceleraci√≥n de la crisis clim√°tica. ‚ÄúDespu√©s de todo este tiempo‚Äù, denunci√≥, ‚Äúel presidente a√∫n no tiene ning√∫n plan. Yo lo tengo‚Äù.

Description: Up to a quarter of the world's future food demand could be met with sustainably farmed fish, new research says.‚Å† ‚Å† Eating meat is a major source of carbon emissions which the world needs to cut down on to protect the climate, the UN has said. But how we feed a growing global population without further heating the planet is a major concern for scientists.‚Å† ‚Å† In research published in Nature yesterday, scientists at the University of California looked at data from 4,702 wild fisheries and identified how changes in policy, management and technology could make them more sustainable. This could include better management of overfished stocks so they can grow again, while increasing production in other stocks that are currently under-utilised.‚Å† ‚Å† The research found that food from the ocean could increase by up to 74% in 30 years' time. Around a third of current fish stocks monitored by the UN are overfished to unsustainable levels.‚Å† ‚Å† Eating more plants is the most obvious way to cut down on future carbon emissions from food. But this presents its own problems. The growth of some crops is predicted to become more difficult due to competition for scarce land resources and water, as well as drought and extreme heat.‚Å† ‚Å† The report says that fisheries will not be immune to the effects of climate change and will also need to adapt, but that "the sea can be a much larger contributor to sustainable food production than is currently the case."‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† #fishing #fisheries #food #foodsecurity #climatechange #climatecrisis #climateemergency #sustainability #science #nature #ocean #sea
ImageText: We could be eating 74% more seafood 2050, scientists say as we try to cut down on meat to combat climate change @channel4news

Description: @revistageneracionm En los √∫ltimos a√±os se ha generado un intenso debate sobre la necesidad de cambiar nuestros h√°bitos alimentarios por diversos motivos, entre los que se encuentra la preservaci√≥n de los ecosistemas y los equilibrios planetarios.  En el origen de estos debates hay varios informes y art√≠culos cient√≠ficos. En ellos se alerta sobre las consecuencias negativas de mantener las actuales tendencias de producci√≥n y consumo de alimentos, y se informa de las opciones para mantener los sistemas alimentarios dentro de los l√≠mites planetarios.  La alimentaci√≥n es una de las actividades humanas con un mayor impacto ambiental. No es la √∫nica, pero s√≠ una de las m√°s importantes. Por eso es urgente cambiar nuestros patrones actuales para mejorar el estado del planeta, al tiempo que obtenemos beneficios econ√≥micos y de salud.  La cara B de la alimentaci√≥n  Uno de los impactos que m√°s preocupan de los actuales sistemas agroalimentarios es su gran contribuci√≥n al cambio clim√°tico. La alimentaci√≥n en su conjunto es responsable del 26 % de las emisiones globales de gases de efecto invernadero.  Estas emisiones se producen en toda la cadena de valor, desde la producci√≥n animal y vegetal (52 % y 29 % del total de los sistemas alimentarios, respectivamente), su procesado y empaquetado (9 %) y el transporte y distribuci√≥n (9 %). Un tercio de estas emisiones corresponden a p√©rdidas y desperdicios alimentarios.  Adem√°s, la forma en que producimos y consumimos alimentos en la actualidad est√° afectando gravemente a los ecosistemas y a la biodiversidad. Se estima que desde inicios del siglo pasado la abundancia de especies nativas se ha visto reducida en un 20 % a nivel global, en gran medida por la sobreexplotaci√≥n y degradaci√≥n de los ecosistemas derivadas de la producci√≥n agroalimentaria. #alimentacion #consumoconsciente üëâcontin√∫a leyendo en el link de la bio ‚ùóÔ∏è

Description: üêß Si cre√≠ste que los ping√ºinos siempre han estado en las g√©lidas aguas de la Ant√°rtica, te equivocas. As√≠ lo confirma un estudio realizado por la Universidad de California en Berkeley y liderado por la acad√©mica UC Juliana Vianna.   Para poder realizar el seguimiento a trav√©s de los a√±os, los investigadores analizaron y compararon genomas de 18 especies diferentes de ping√ºinos. La trazabilidad les permiti√≥ determinar que el origen de estas aves tan caracter√≠sticas de la Ant√°rtica, se llev√≥ a cabo en Australia y Nueva Zelanda, hace 22 millones de a√±os.   El estudio publicado en la revista Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, se√±ala que los ping√ºinos ocuparon en primera instancia ambientes templados, para luego migrar a las fr√≠as aguas del ant√°rtico. Los expertos advierten que, si bien los ping√ºinos pueden adaptarse a climas oscilantes, la velocidad del cambio clim√°tico moderno podr√≠a tener un efecto negativo en la prosperidad de la especie.

Description: Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è Death Valley in California and Nevada was the hottest place on Earth on Sunday, hitting 130 degrees Fahrenheit, according to the National Weather Service. If verified, it could be the hottest temperature recorded in the world since 1913. It's been a sweltering summer for much of the US. Last month was the hottest July on record for seven states along the East Coast, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. As the global average temperature rises due to the man-made climate crisis, extreme heat and record temperatures become more frequent while extreme and record lows become less frequent.‚Å† (üì∏: Efrain Padro / Alamy Stock Photo)
ImageText: CNN Death Valley just recorded the hottest temperature on Earth The national park in California and Nevada recorded a preliminary high temperature of 130 degrees Fahrenheit on Sunday, according to NWS

Description: Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è Interior Secretary David Bernhardt on Monday announced plans for an oil and gas leasing program in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, clearing the way for drilling in the remote Alaskan area. Bernhardt said future leases of the federally-owned land will make the entire 1.5 million acre Coastal Plain area available. Environmental activists have sounded the alarm that drilling the Arctic could harm the environment and exacerbate the climate crisis. Climate change has been a key issue in the upcoming 2020 election, and Joe Biden, who is set to accept the Democratic presidential nomination this week, has called for a ban on new oil and gas permits on public lands. Tap the link in our bio to learn more. (üì∏: Bill Weir/CNN)
ImageText: CNN Trump administration announces plans to drill in Arctic National Wildlife Refuge BREAKING NEWS Interior Secretary David Bernhardt announces plans for oil and gas leasing program in the Alaskan arctic, clearing the way for drilling in the remote area

Description: The Trump administration finalized a plan to open up the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil and gas development, which will probably spur a legal battle over the fate of a vast, remote Alaska habitat.  The Interior Department said on Monday it had completed its required reviews, clearing the way for the government to auction off leases later this year to companies interested in drilling inside the refuge‚Äôs coastal plain, which is believed to sit atop enough oil to fill billions of barrels but is prized by environmentalists for its pristine landscapes and wildlife.  Companies that bought leases could begin the process of exploring for oil and gas, although actual production would still require additional permitting and is unlikely to occur for at least a decade, if at all.  Drilling opponents are expected to file lawsuits to try to delay or block the leasing plan. Environmental groups have already been arguing that the Interior Department failed to adequately consider the effects that oil and gas development in the region could have on climate change and local wildlife such as caribou and polar bears.  Tap the link in our bio to read more.  Photo by Christopher Miller.
ImageText: Interior Dept. Finalizes Plan to Open Arctic Refuge to Oil and Gas Companies

Description: @agendapais2030 Simon Anholt es un asesor pol√≠tico que lleva m√°s de veinte a√±os trabajando con diferentes l√≠deres del mundo, colaborando con gobiernos de 56 pa√≠ses hasta el momento. El 2005 comenz√≥ una encuesta de opini√≥n (National Brand Index) en la que le preguntaba a veinte mil personas de veinte pa√≠ses distintos, las percepciones que ten√≠an sobre otras naciones, entre las que se inclu√≠a Chile.  Este contenido lo analiz√≥ el 2012. Y dos a√±os despu√©s realiz√≥ el primer √≠ndice The Good Country, el cual present√≥ en una charla TED. En el trabajo sobre esta materia el autor se ha dado cuenta que las autoridades generalmente se preocupan de mostrar cu√°n maravilloso es su pa√≠s, ya sea por su calidad de vida, historia o √©xito. Lo cual no le importa realmente al resto del mundo, sino que lo que les parece relevante a las personas de otros lugares es cu√°nto contribuye ese pa√≠s al resto del mundo o a las personas mismas.  ‚ÄúLo que estaba claro es que los pa√≠ses con una imagen poderosa y positiva encuentran que todo puede ser f√°cil o barato, entonces es una forma de atraer turistas o inversi√≥n, es f√°cil y no cuesta nada. Pero si tu pa√≠s tiene una imagen negativa todo va a ser dif√≠cil y todo va a ser caro, el explicarte ante el resto de la gente cuesta m√°s. Es por eso que la imagen del pa√≠s es muy importante y es significativa para el progreso y la prosperidad del pa√≠s en un mundo globalizado‚Äù, expres√≥ Anholt en una charla online organizada por Imagen de Chile.  Por lo tanto, a un porcentaje muy importante de la poblaci√≥n le importar√≠a m√°s lo bueno que es un pa√≠s con otros, en t√©rminos de generosidad. Lo que contribuye y le entrega al resto; o lo que aporta en la lucha contra el cambio clim√°tico o el terrorismo: ‚ÄúSi estoy en otro pa√≠s, quisiera saber que hace Chile por m√≠. Es exactamente lo mismo que dicen las empresas sobre la responsabilidad social, y es la lealtad de sus clientes. Necesitan ser responsables, ser un buen vecino, contribuir a la comunidad en la que est√°n‚Äù. üëâcontin√∫a leyendo en el link de la bio ‚ùóÔ∏è#cambioclimatico #pandemia #sustentabilidad
ImageText: Simon Anholt: "Si no colaboramos, vamos a perder todos; el cambio clim√°tico, la pandemia, todo nos va a ganar" por Sof√≠a Roblero Valenzuela 16 agosto, 2020 Simon Anholt

Os cientistas estudaram 234 geleiras em todo o territ√≥rio √°rtico por 34 anos at√© 2018 e descobriram que as nevascas anuais j√° n√£o eram mais suficientes para reabastecer os blocos de gelo perdidos no derretimento durante o ver√£o. Description: El √Årtico perder√° en 30 a√±os su hielo marino estival si sigue derriti√©ndose al ritmo actual. Es la triste conclusi√≥n de uno de los √∫ltimos estudios que se han hecho. Gracias al hielo marino del √Årtico podemos saber el impacto de la crisis clim√°tica y adem√°s ejerce una funci√≥n clave en la regulaci√≥n del clima de todo el planeta. Por eso, que este hielo de vital importancia se derrita tan r√°pido supone una enorme preocupaci√≥n. Nuevos estudios han constatado que la reducci√≥n fue tres veces mayor en verano de 2018 que hace 40 a√±os, este deshielo tan r√°pido podr√≠a ser como consecuencia de fen√≥menos clim√°ticos como El Ni√±o. Seg√∫n los autores del estudio, si este escenario contin√∫a como hasta ahora tendr√° un impacto en todo el mundo, provocando alteraciones clim√°ticas m√°s agresivas en latitudes muy alejadas del c√≠rculo polar √°rtico. üì∏ Getty Para m√°s informaci√≥n clica en la bio üì≤ #crisisclim√°tica #deshielo #calentamientoglobal https://bit.ly/2PRQnnr

Description: Wind and solar energy has doubled since the world signed the Paris Climate Agreement.  In the first half of this year, the world generated just under 10 percent of its electricity from renewable wind and solar. In 2015, when the landmark Paris Climate Agreement was signed, the figure was just 4.6 percent.  That's according to a new analysis by climate think tank Ember, which found that the amount of energy generated globally from wind and solar climbed by 14 percent in the past year alone.  The world's energy mix is changing. Wind and solar produced around the same amount of power as nuclear, the report found, and that there was an 8.3 percent drop in coal generation in the first half of 2020 from the same period of 2019. This was due to a mixture of long term trends and a reduced energy demand during the coronavirus pandemic.  ‚ÄúCountries across the world are now on the same path ‚Äì building wind turbines and solar panels to replace electricity from coal and gas-fired power plants. But to keep a chance of limiting climate change to 1.5 degrees, coal generation needs to fall by 13 percent every year this decade," said Dave Jones, one of the report's authors.  "The fact that, during a global pandemic, coal generation has still only fallen by 8 percent shows just how far off-track we still are," he added.  For renewables, there is still significant variation between countries. With 33 percent, the UK's wind and solar power generation sits only behind Germany with 42 percent. China is on 10 percent, while the US is on 12 percent. Russia lags behind on 0.2 percent.  #climate #climatecrisis #climateemergency #wind #solar #coal #renewables #UK #2020 #energy #paris #glasgow #cop #globalwarming #globalheating
ImageText: Solar and wind has doubled in five years while globally the use of coal is falling- but is it fast enough for the climate crisis? @channel4news

Description: El diputado del Partido Socialista, Juan Santana, present√≥ un proyecto de ley que pide incluir men√∫ vegano en las alternativas que entrega la Junaeb en los recintos del pa√≠s.  Seg√∫n indic√≥ el parlamentario, la iniciativa permite establecer el reconocimiento de alternativas veganas y vegetarianas en los Programas de Alimentaci√≥n suministrados por la Junta Nacional de Auxilio Escolar y Becas a trav√©s de las empresas privadas que se adjudican las licitaciones.  ‚ÄúQuienes suscribimos el presente proyecto afirmamos que la incorporaci√≥n de programas de alimentaci√≥n veganos y vegetarianos en los establecimientos educacionales es coherente con el deber del Estado de garantizar el ejercicio de la libertad de conciencia, la igualdad ante la ley y el derecho a la integridad ps√≠quica, y, adem√°s, permite avanzar en la concientizaci√≥n sobre el cambio clim√°tico y crueldad animal‚Äù, dijo el congresista, quien adem√°s es integrante de la comisi√≥n de Educaci√≥n de la C√°mara.  Para el diputado, la iniciativa permite que "las y los estudiantes tengan una amplia gama de posibilidades de poder elegir una alimentaci√≥n saludable que cumpla con los est√°ndares nutricionales y que adem√°s, sea de manera responsable".  Mauricio Serrano, fundador de la ONG Internacional Animal Libre indic√≥ que "estamos muy contentos con esta iniciativa que refleja un trabajo que llevamos haciendo por a√±os, permitiendo que el Congreso comience a discutir sobre la importante necesidad de que los ni√±os, ni√±as y adolescentes vegetarianos y veganos con Beca Junaeb puedan alimentarse de manera saludable y acorde a sus estilos de vida".

Description: This massive Arctic ice shelf is shattering because of climate change. Its latest split has formed a¬†free-floating "ice island" some 80¬†sq¬†km (30¬†sq¬†miles) off the northern side of Canada‚Äôs¬†Ellesmere Island. It has since ruptured in two, with both parts drifting into the Arctic Ocean. Due to a warming climate, this is one of many break-up events the Milne Ice Shelf has had to endure in recent years. It is currently under 500¬†sq¬†km in area when, at the start of the 1900s, the ice structure around Ellesmere Island covered 8,600¬†sq¬†km. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the ice shelf, and how melt ponds covering its surface are causing them to weaken. (üì∑¬†Planet Labs Inc) #Arctic #Globalwarming¬†#bbcnews

Description: @agendapais2030 El Presidente Sebasti√°n Pi√±era se refiri√≥ a los aspectos sustentables en los que el gobierno est√° trabajando y las metas que se tienen. Mat√≠as Asun, director nacional de Greenpeace, responde a estos desaf√≠os desde la perspectiva de la organizaci√≥n social ambientalista, considerando las dificultades ambientales actuales, revisaron la factibilidad y precisi√≥n de los anuncios y prioridades del gobierno. Frente a esto, destac√≥ la Pol√≠tica Nacional de Parques Urbanos latente desde el 2018, afirmando que ya se han entregado veinte parques en once regiones y que hay otras en dise√±o y construcci√≥n.  ‚ÄúEvidentemente uno tendr√≠a que felicitar la protecci√≥n y creaci√≥n de √°reas verdes urbanas. Sin embargo, el problema central hoy es transformar a las ciudades en lugares m√°s habitables y, por lo tanto, las √°reas verdes son parte de un problema mucho m√°s integral, en t√©rminos de convivencia, uso del espacio p√∫blico‚Äù, comenta al respecto el director de Greenpeace.  Efectivamente, desde la ONG destacan esta iniciativa del gobierno, pero aseguran que no es suficiente para la transformaci√≥n de las ciudades. Agregan la importancia de tener en cuenta la mala calidad de aire en muchas ciudades de Chile y la urgencia de garantizar planes de descontaminaci√≥n. ‚ÄúIncluso antes que las √°reas verdes, uno podr√≠a decir, es urgente resolver una vulnerabilidad que, y la pandemia lo demostr√≥, tienen buena parte de las grandes ciudades y principales poblados del pa√≠s, que es la contaminaci√≥n ambiental, la contaminaci√≥n atmosf√©rica‚Äù.  Plan Carbono Neutral antes del a√±o 2050  Al momento de enfrentar el cambio clim√°tico y el calentamiento global, el presidente destac√≥ el plan que busca hacer de Chile un pa√≠s carbono neutral -con emisi√≥n neta cero- antes del 2050. üëâcontin√∫a leyendo en el link de la bio ‚ùóÔ∏è#cuentapublica #greenpeace #medioambiente @greenpeacecl

Description: @elmostrador_cultura La conversaci√≥n con Mercedes Ducci y Mai-Ni√© Chang versar√° alrededor de la equidad de g√©nero como un derecho humano fundamental y base fundacional para un mundo pac√≠fico, pr√≥spero y sostenible. Description: The Wellcome Photography Prize celebrates visual stories that challenge mental health stigmas, highlight social inequalities in medicine and show how individuals care for themselves and others. Here are some of the top photos for 2020:‚Å£ ‚Å£ 1Ô∏è‚É£ Photographer Sameer Satchu captured the moment a Ugandan midwife listened to a fetus's heartbeat using a 19th-century Pinard horn. Health care can be difficult to access and clinics often lack resources in rural Uganda.  (üì∏: Sameer Satchu/Wellcome Photography Prize 2020)‚Å£ ‚Å£ 2Ô∏è‚É£ While documenting the day-to-day lives of children being treated for cancer, Marijn Fidder snapped this image of an 11-year-old who has a brain tumor. She‚Äôs in her bedroom and surrounded by cards from loved ones. The caption says the girl ‚Äútakes joy in the knowledge that she's not alone.‚Äù  (üì∏: Marijn Fidder/Wellcome Photography Prize 2020) ‚Å£ ‚Å£ 3Ô∏è‚É£ Photographer Maite Caram√©s documented her friend‚Äôs battle with breast cancer. "When you go through this you have to find ways to maintain your courage, your mood, your dignity, and even your identity," wrote Caram√©s.  (üì∏: Maite Caram√©s/Wellcome Photography Prize 2020)‚Å£ ‚Å£ 4Ô∏è‚É£ Nyancho NwaNri captured a mother carrying her child to school as floodwaters nearly reached her knees. In Lagos, Nigeria, flooding has been exacerbated by rising sea levels caused by the climate crisis.  (üì∏: Nyancho NwaNri/Wellcome Photography Prize 2020)‚Å£ ‚Å£ 5Ô∏è‚É£ This portrait taken by Tom Merilion shows a woman in Scotland resting during her daily swim routine, which she keeps up as a balm for her anxiety and depression.  (üì∏: Tom Merilion/Wellcome Photography Prize 2020) ‚Å£

Description: Sind wir in Sachen Klimawandel auf dem Weg in ein "Worst-Case-Szenario"? So beschreibt es zumindest eine Studie des US-Klimaforschers Christopher Schwalm, die im Moment viel diskutiert wird. Demnach k√∂nnten sich bodennahe Luftschichten um durchschnittlich f√ºnf Grad Celsius gegen√ºber der vorindustriellen Zeit erw√§rmen.   Elmar Kriegler vom Potsdam-Institut f√ºr Klimafolgenforschung geht zumindest davon aus, dass es zu einer "massiven Ver√§nderung" kommen wird, die in den Regionen unterschiedlich ausgepr√§gt auftritt. Wir Menschen w√ºrden das mit vielen Konsequenzen bezahlen, "weil wir eben an dieses andere Klima nicht angepasst sind, sondern an das heutige Klima."  Das gesamte Interview finden Sie im Link in der Bio ‚¨ÜÔ∏è  #klima #klimawandel #erderw√§rmung #welt #forschung #permafrost #deutschlandfunk #umweltschutz #globalwarming #antarktis #dlf #interview
ImageText: ‚ÄûWenn es statt f√ºnf Grad in 2100 dann 3,5 Grad werden, ist das auch noch ein massiver Klimawandel und sehr schlimm. Insofern muss es darum gehen, deutlich mehr zu tun, als im Moment getan wird." Elmar Kriegler, Potsdam-Institut f√ºr f√ºr Klimafolgenforschung im Deutschlandfunk C Caspar Getty

Description: Descubren nuevas colonias de ping√ºinos emperador.  Gracias al sat√©lite de la ESA, han sido descubiertas nuevas colonias de esta especie de aves en el litoral ant√°rtico. Los datos documentados a partir de im√°genes de sat√©lite (con ayuda posterior de datos sobre el terreno) muestran once nuevas colonias de ping√ºino emperador (Aptenodytes forsteri), tres de las cuales se hab√≠an identificado anteriormente, pero no hab√≠an sido confirmadas. Las im√°genes desde el espacio ayudan a localizar grupos peque√±os de estas aves que cr√≠an a 40 ¬∫C bajo cero.  Sin embargo, el futuro de estos ping√ºinos sigue siendo muy negro. Lo m√°s probable es que el crisis clim√°tica los haga desparecer. Si se aplican los modelos medios sobre cambio clim√°tico para las pr√≥ximas d√©cadas y no se reducen sustancialmente las emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero, se estima que para fines de este siglo todas las colonias de ping√ºino emperador disminuiyan de tama√±o. Description: Eleven new colonies of emperor penguins üêß have been discovered in Antarctica, scientists have revealed. ¬† Researchers say the "exciting discovery" means the known population of the birds has swelled by around 5%-10% to more than half a million. ¬† It offers an important boost for the future of the species, whose favoured breeding ground is sea ice, which is vulnerable to climate change. ¬† The colonies were revealed in a study using satellite mapping technology, which showed evidence of bird droppings in areas not previously known to be home to the animals.  #Animals #Climate #ClimateChange #World #Nature #Penguins #Antarctica #News #SkyNews
ImageText: (empty)

Description: A wildfire raging through California forced around 7,800 people to evacuate their homes over the weekend.  The Apple Fire, named after a lane near where the blaze started east of Los Angeles, has scorched more than 26,000 acres since last Friday.  Investigators say the blaze was probably sparked by burning soot from the exhaust of a diesel truck.  Wildfires are almost always started by human activity and accidents like this. But scientists say that one of the major impacts of the climate crisis is that the resulting fires burn for longer, and often more intensely.  Because of this, long periods of drought and prolonged stretches of extreme heat mean that the wildfire season in the Western United States has worsened in recent years.  Satellite imagery from NASA . . . . . #wildfires #climatechange #california #drought #applefire #heat #climateemergency #climatecrisis
ImageText: (empty)

Description: Satellite images have revealed a throng of previously unknown emperor penguin colonies in Antarctica.  The discovery boosts the number of known colonies of the imperilled birds by 20%.  Emperor penguins are the only penguins that breed on sea ice, rather than land, making them especially vulnerable to the climate crisis.  All the new colonies are in areas that are at risk and researchers say these will be the ‚Äúcanaries in the coal mine‚Äù as global heating increasingly affects Antarctica.  Previous studies have estimated that 90% of known colonies will be lost by the end of the century if no further action is taken to cut the greenhouse gas emissions that drive global heating.
ImageText: 11 new penguin colonies have been spotted from space

Description: Scientists are really excited that they've found some penguin poo. üêßüí©  Satellite images have shown new Emperor penguin breeding grounds which are identifiable by large patches of sea-ice stained by the birds' poo, or guano. The discovery has a big impact on the global Emperor population, lifting it by 5-10%, to perhaps as many as 278,500 breeding pairs. It's a welcome development given that this iconic species is likely to come under severe pressure this century as the Antarctic warms due to climate change. Swipe through to see the satellite images, and tap the link in our bio to read all about the discovery and the threats the species faces. (üì∏: Science Photo Library/British Antarctic Survey) #Penguin #Antarctic #Nature #Animals¬†#science¬†#ClimateChange #Conservation¬†#bbcnews
ImageText: (empty)

Description: Scientists have pinpointed the human influence on melting glaciers for the first time.  It‚Äôs been accepted that the climate crisis has sped up the melting of glaciers for some years - but the exact effect has never been quantified.  But this week scientists looking at ‚Äúextreme annual glacier mass loss‚Äù in New Zealand‚Äôs Southern Alps said that a record melt in 2018 was 10 times more likely because of climate change, and that another in 2011 was six times more likely.  Rising global temperatures due to the burning of fossil fuels are leaving an ‚Äúincreasingly visible human fingerprint‚Äù on large ice loss events like these, the authors said.  The research was published in the journal Nature Climate Change yesterday.  #climate #climatechange #climatecrisis #climateemergency #globalwarming #climatescience #science #sciencenews #newzealand #glacier
ImageText: Scientists warn of "increasingly visible human fingerprint" on melting glaciers @channel4news

Description: @elmostrador_cultura El problema es uno de los temas del libro recientemente aparecido, ‚ÄúEl cambio clim√°tico y la biolog√≠a funcional de los organismos‚Äù, editado por Francisco Bozinovic y Lohengrin Cavieres de la Universidad Cat√≥lica, que re√∫ne el trabajo de destacados investigadores en el √°rea de la biolog√≠a funcional aplicada al actual proceso de calentamiento global. Entre las enfermedades reemergentes destacan la tuberculosis y la malaria, la extensi√≥n del dengue, el resurgimiento de la plaga del c√≥lera y las enfermedades transmitidas por garrapatas. Por otra parte, entre las enfermedades emergentes se encuentran por ejemplo los virus Marburg ‚Äìque causa una enfermedad hemorr√°gica severa‚Äì, el famoso √©bola, el s√≠ndrome pulmonar por hantavirus (HCP) y la cepa de E. coli O157-H7, entre otros. üëâlee la nota en link de la bio‚ùóÔ∏è#cambioclimatico #medioambiente #chile

Description: There's been a big increase in rainforest fires in the Amazon - sparking fears that last year's wildfire crisis could happen again. ‚Å† ‚Å† Brazil's space research agency Inpe says 6,803 fires were recorded in the region in July compared to 5,318 in the same month last year - that's a jump of 28 per cent. ‚Å† ‚Å† On 30 July alone, more than 1,000 fires were recorded - the highest number for a single day since 2005, according to analysis by Greenpeace Brasil. ‚Å† ‚Å† "It's a terrible sign," says Ane Alencar, science director at Brazil's Amazon Environmental Research Institute. "We can expect that August will already be a difficult month and September will be worse yet."‚Å† ‚Å† Uncontrollable fires swept the planet's biggest rainforest last year, provoking an international outcry. About 30,900 fires were recorded at its peak in August. The forest is an important defense against climate change, as it absorbs the greenhouse gases that are causing it. ‚Å† ‚Å† Fires are common in the Amazon during the second half of the year, but environmentalists claim Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro's policies are making them worse.‚Å† They claim he's emboldened illegal loggers, miners and land speculators to clear the land by burning vegetation. The president has defended his plans to encourage mining and farming in protected areas as a way to lift the region out of poverty. ‚Å† ‚Å† Following international pressure to act last year, Bolsonaro sent the military to tackle the fires and banned setting fires in the region for 120 days. ‚Å† ‚Å† NASA has also warned that warmer than average sea surface temperatures are increasing the risk of fires in the southern Amazon. "Warmer surface waters near the equator draw moisture northward and away from the southern Amazon," the organisation's website says. ‚Å† ‚Å† "As a result, the southern Amazon landscape becomes dry and flammable, making human-set fires used for agriculture and land clearing more prone to growing out of control and spreading."‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† #wildfires #amazon #climatechange #brazil #rainforest
ImageText: The Amazon rainforest is still burning. There are 28% more fires than last July. @channel4news

Description: Zu viel Hitze, zu wenig Regen: Der deutsche Wald leidet. Insbesonders die Fichten sterben seit einigen Jahren massenhaft ab. Sie leiden unter Wassermangel und werden gesch√§digt durch den Borkenk√§fer, der sich in dem zunehmend trockenen und hei√üen Klima vermehrt. ‚†Ä In der Holzwirtschaft gebe es daher bereits Ideen, die Fichte durch andere Nadelh√∂lzer zu ersetzen, wie die Tanne und die Douglasie. Doch auch andere Baumarten k√§men mit dem zunehmend trockenen und hei√üen Klima nicht klar, so Maike Wanders von der Schutzgemeinschaft Deutscher Wald. ‚†Ä ‚¨ÜÔ∏è Das komplette Interview finden Sie uÃàber den Link in der Bio. ‚†Ä ‚†Ä ‚†Ä #deutschlandfunk #dlf #wald #baum #tree #trees #forest #forests #klima #klimawandel #co2 #hitze #trockenheit #climatechange #mensch #natur #regen #fichte #deutschland #hitze #wassermangel #wasser

Description: Korallenriffe aufforsten ‚Äì ist das die L√∂sung? üê† üê° . Der Klimawandel erw√§rmt die Meere, der Meeresspiegel steigt, die Unwetter werden st√§rker. Description: @elmostrador_cultura Un equipo de ocean√≥grafos del Centro de Investigaci√≥n Din√°mica de Ecosistemas Marinos de Altas Latitudes (IDEAL) de la Universidad Austral de Chile (UACh), del Centro de Investigaci√≥n en Ecosistemas de la Patagonia (CIEP) y otras cinco instituciones nacionales y extranjeras, realiz√≥ diversas expediciones a una de las zonas menos muestreadas en el mundo: la Isla Madre de Dios. Este es un lugar √∫nico por su contrastante geolog√≠a. Una fracci√≥n de la isla se conforma de caliza de alta pureza (carbonato de calcio, la formaci√≥n de caliza m√°s austral del hemisferio sur), y la otra granito (principalmente s√≠lice). Estas caracter√≠sticas hacen de los archipi√©lagos del lugar un sistema singular. Los resultados de las investigaciones fueron publicados en la revista Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science. üëâcontin√∫a leyendo en el link de la bio ‚ùóÔ∏è#cambioclimatico #chile

Description: MacKenzie Scott, the ex-wife of Jeff Bezos, said Tuesday she has donated nearly $1.7 billion to more than 100 charitable organizations following her divorce from the Amazon founder last year.   Scott wrote in a lengthy blog post that she was troubled by the events of this year but had worked with a group of advisers to support nonprofits linked to human rights, environmental and social causes. The move comes after she signed the Giving Pledge, a public promise among the world‚Äôs richest people to donate at least half of their wealth throughout their lifetimes.  ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no question in my mind that anyone‚Äôs personal wealth is the product of a collective effort, and of social structures which present opportunities to some people, and obstacles to countless others,‚Äù Scott wrote in the post. ‚ÄúLike many, I watched the first half of 2020 with a mixture of heartbreak and horror. Life will never stop finding fresh ways to expose inequities in our systems.‚Äù  To date, Scott has donated more than $586 million to racial equity initiatives, $46 million to LGBTQ groups, $133 million to gender equity causes and $125 million to climate change efforts. Her list of beneficiaries includes major nonprofits including Lambda Legal, The Nature Conservancy and the National Urban League, as well as Seattle-based charities including the United Way of King County.  ‚ÄúI recommend these organizations to anyone similarly excited by the idea of empowering leaders well-positioned to accelerate progress,‚Äù Scott wrote. ‚ÄúEvery one of them is tackling complex challenges that will require sustained effort over many years, while simultaneously addressing consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic.‚Äù  All of the donations were unrestricted unless groups asked otherwise, Scott noted, in order to provide organizations with ‚Äúmaximum flexibility.‚Äù  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs surreal,‚Äù Angelique Albert, executive director of the American Indian Graduate Center and a beneficiary of Scott‚Äôs giving, told The Seattle Times. ‚ÄúThe fact that it is unrestricted really speaks to [Scott‚Äôs] trust in us to really promote racial equity and justice. It empowers us to do what is right for our community.‚Äù  Read more at our link in bio. // üì∑ Getty
ImageText: spring a r HUFFPOSTI MacKenzie Scott Has Donated $1.7 Billion Since Divorce From Jeff Bezos

Description: High temperatures in the Norwegian islands of Svalbard have broken a 41-year-old record.‚Å† ‚Å† The town of Longyearbyen reached heights of 21.7 degrees on Tuesday - beating a previous record of 21.3 degrees from 1979.‚Å† ‚Å† A tweet by the Norwegian Meteorological Institute said: ‚ÄúA 41-year-old heat record has been broken in Longyearbyen Svalbard!‚Å† ‚Å† ‚ÄúWe measured 21.7 degrees, which is 0.4 degrees above the old record from July 16, 1979.‚Äù‚Å† ‚Å† Usually the region would see temperatures of 5-8 degrees.‚Å† ‚Å† Svalbard‚Äôs local wildlife includes wild reindeer and polar bears - which have been affected by the changing climate.‚Å† ‚Å† It‚Äôs also home to the Doomsday vault - a vault that has collected over 930,000 varieties of food crops in the event of a global crisis.‚Å† ‚Å† In 2016, the structure needed 20 million euros of work done due to thawing permafrost in 2016.‚Å† ‚Å† Studies show global warming is happening in the Arctic twice as fast as the rest of the planet.‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† .‚Å† #norway #svalbard #norwaynature #climatechange #climatecrisis #environment #polarbear #nature #earth #globalwarming #sustainability  #arctic #wildlife  #climateaction  #planet #world  #green #conservation

Description: After decades of negotiations, all 197 nations in the world decided to voluntarily cut the heat-trapping pollution that is causing the climate crisis by signing the Paris climate agreement. Only a handful of countries have not ratified the deal.  But on 4 November, in a coincidence of timing just 24 hours after its presidential election, the US will formally exit the agreement, joining Iran and Turkey as the only major countries not to participate in the pact, which is seen by many as the minimum effort the world needs to make on cutting emissions.  The Guardian's environment reporters Emily Holden and Oliver Milman look at why Donald Trump wants to leave the agreement, whether the deal can be successful without the US and what is at stake for the planet without America's cooperation.

Description: Follow ‚û°Ô∏è @cnnclimate ‚û°Ô∏è Nearly three billion animals were killed or displaced by Australia's devastating bushfires ‚Äî almost triple the figure estimated in January ‚Äî according to a report released Tuesday. The figure includes an estimated 143 million mammals, 2.46 billion reptiles, 180 million birds, and 51 million frogs, a report commissioned by the World Wide Fund for Nature found."The interim findings are shocking. It's hard to think of another event anywhere in the world in living memory that has killed or displaced that many animals," said WWF-Australia CEO Dermot O'Gorman. "This ranks as one of the worst wildlife disasters in modern history." The report will give other countries a ‚Äúwindow into the future of mega fires and their devastating impact on wildlife," said O'Gorman, which is important as extreme fires become more common due to climate change. Tap the link in our bio to learn more. (üì∏: John Moore/Getty Images)
ImageText: CNN Nearly 3 billion animals were killed or displaced by Australia's fires The figure includes an estimated 143 million mammals, 2.46 billion reptile 180 million birds, and 51 million frogs, according to researchers

Description: Nearly three billion animals were affected by one of the "worst wildlife disasters in modern history", according to the World Wide Fund for Nature. Mega blazes swept across every Australian state last summer, scorching land and killing at least 33 people. Mammals, reptiles, birds and frogs died in the flames or from loss of habitat. "When you think about nearly three billion native animals being in the path of the fires, it is absolutely huge - it's a difficult number to comprehend," said Prof Chris Dickman, who oversaw the project by 10 scientists from Australian universities. Limitations on data meant that some groups - such as invertebrates, fish and turtles - were not included in the estimates. A commission set up by the government to look into the fires has heard overwhelming evidence from scientists who said the unprecedented frequency and severity of the blazes were a result of climate change. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the devastating impact the fires have had on wildlife. #Australia #Nature #Animals #Ecology #Wildlife #ClimateChange #bbcnews
ImageText: BBC BB EWS Almost three billion animals killed or harmed during Australia's "devastating" bushfires

Description: En el segundo cap√≠tulo de ‚ÄúInfluyentes‚Äù, la periodista Paula Escobar convers√≥ con Maisa Rojas, climat√≥loga, doctora en F√≠sica Atmosf√©rica de la Universidad de Oxford y acad√©mica de la Universidad de Chile, quien se refiri√≥ a los nuevos desaf√≠os que enfrentara la humanidad: el cambio clim√°tico, y c√≥mo las consecuencias del COVID-19 se relacionan con un cambio en el escenario actual del calentamiento global.  "Esta pandemia nos da la oportunidad de acelerar el cambio de rumbo. No es una exageraci√≥n cuando digo que las decisiones que vamos a tomar para salir de la crisis econ√≥mica post pandemia van a ser cr√≠ticas para poder llegar a las metas del acuerdo de Paris", explic√≥.   Respecto al manejo de la situaci√≥n en Chile, Rojas declar√≥ que "a m√≠ me pasa de que no me puedo sentir contenta con la idea de que una vez que se levanten las cuarentenas vamos a volver a un Santiago contaminado. No quiero, ser√≠a terrible. Aprendamos algo de esto".  Revive el cap√≠tulo nuestro sitio web CNNChile.com

Description: ü•∫  Um estudo realizado pela Universidade de Toronto, no Canad√°, e publicado na revista cient√≠fica Nature, na √∫ltima segunda-feira (20), alerta que o urso polar pode ser extinto at√© 2100 devido ao aquecimento global. Segundo a pesquisa, a previs√£o √© que a temperatura global aumente at√© 4¬∫ C no final do s√©culo, provocando, assim, o derretimento do gelo e afetando diretamente a ca√ßa de focas, principal alimento dos ursos polares. Atualmente, cerca de 26 mil ursos polares j√° sofrem com altera√ß√µes fisiol√≥gicas causadas pelo aumento da temperatura do planeta, pois, durante os per√≠odos mais quentes no Polo Norte, os animais ficam sem comer pelo m√°ximo de tempo que conseguirem, chamado de estiva√ß√£o. At√© ent√£o, devido a aus√™ncia de dados demogr√°ficos das 19 subpopula√ß√µes de ursos polares, era dif√≠cil estipular prazos de dura√ß√£o da esp√©cie. Os pesquisadores reproduziram uma abordagem adotada por cientistas clim√°ticos entre as d√©cadas de 1980 e 1990 nas √°reas de Hudson Bay, no Canad√°. Para cada um dos 19 subgrupos, foram combinadas estimativas da extens√£o do gelo ocupadas pelos ursos com a quantidade de gordura que precisa ser ingeridas por eles antes da estiva√ß√£o. O resultado foi a cria√ß√£o de um modelo computacional que projeta por quanto tempo eles ser√£o capazes de continuar se reproduzindo, e consequentemente, sobrevivendo. Dos 19 subgrupos, foi poss√≠vel calcular a estimativa de vida de apenas 13, pelo fato de n√£o haver modelos clim√°ticos que fossem suficientes para os outros seis. Para os pesquisadores, no entanto, n√£o h√° ind√≠cios de que os grupos faltantes responderiam diferentemente dos demais. O estudo aponta, ainda, que se a emiss√£o de gases de efeito estufa fosse cortada de forma dr√°stica e o aquecimento global fosse mantido a menos de 2¬∫, o resultado seria apenas um pouco menos pior do que o esperado. #PortalR7 #R7 (üì∏: Pixabay)

Description: Designs for the world's largest underwater research station and habitat have been unveiled by aquanaut Fabien Cousteau and Industrial designer Yves B√©har. The 4,000-square-foot modular lab, named Fabien Cousteau's Proteus, will sit 60 feet under water off the coast of Cura√ßao, a Carribean island. The station will help scientists and researchers studying the effects of climate change on the ocean, new marine life and searching for medicinal breakthroughs. Powered by wind and solar energy, and ocean thermal energy conversion, the structure will also feature the first underwater greenhouse for growing food, as well as a video production facility. It will take three years until Proteus is installed, according to Cousteau. For more, follow @cnnstyle. (üì∏:Courtesy Proteus/Yves B√©har/Fuseproject)

Los invitados de esta semana son Alejandro Aravena y Maisa Rojas. La idea es abordar c√≥mo ser√° el nuevo Chile, desde el punto de vista de la vivienda y la arquitectura urbana, y tambi√©n desde la perspectiva del cambio clim√°tico.¬† #InfluyentesCNN

Description: El webinar ‚ÄúMedioambiente y biodiversidad despu√©s de la pandemia‚Äù, abord√≥ ‚Äìentre otros temas‚Äì el contexto de la actual crisis, el cambio clim√°tico y global, y los desaf√≠os a nivel econ√≥mico, ecol√≥gico, medioambiental y cient√≠fico. Respecto a esto √∫ltimo, la mirada y mensajes de la invitada fueron elocuentes, asegurando que la ciencia debe bajar de su pedestal y recuperar la humildad y capacidad de di√°logo.   Casada con Adriana y madre de dos hijas, Brigitte se considera persona no binaria y una amante del conocimiento que se vive desde la experiencia, la interdisciplina y el contacto piel a piel con la naturaleza. El jard√≠n de su casa en Bogot√° se ha convertido en uno de sus territorios predilectos para observar e interactuar con otras especies. ‚ÄúTengo un √°rbol parecido a la guayaba, al que llegan los p√°jaros y picaflores a polinizar. As√≠ que aprendemos ecolog√≠a en el patio, ah√≠ donde tambi√©n conviven las babosas‚Äù.  En el a√±o 2018, propuso el concepto de ‚Äúnaturaleza queer‚Äù, que alude a la idea de naturaleza como un escenario que produce diferencias y est√° abierto a la transgresi√≥n, expres√°ndose tambi√©n a trav√©s de su enorme biodiversidad. Tal vez por eso es que en sus antebrazos tiene tatuadas las palabras trans y formaci√≥n, frase que tambi√©n ha marcado hitos en su vida, como ser una de las primeras personas en Colombia en cambiar su g√©nero en la c√©dula de identidad.   Brigitte Baptiste tambi√©n ha sido acad√©mica en varias universidades y dirigi√≥, por varios a√±os, el Instituto Alexander von Humboldt, dedicado a la investigaci√≥n y conservaci√≥n de la biodiversidad colombiana. Asimismo, ha representado a su pa√≠s en m√∫ltiples entidades internacionales, entre ellas, la plataforma IPBES https://ipbes.net/

Description: El glaciar m√°s antiguo de los Alpes est√° cubierto un verano m√°s por grandes s√°banas blancas para evitar que se derrita. La tr√°gica situaci√≥n del glaciar del R√≥dano, situado en Gletsch (Suiza) es una muestra m√°s del drama de la crisis clim√°tica.  Hace ya varios veranos que las autoridades suizas protegen del calor a este glaciar. Los turistas pueden recorrer los caminos delimitados por estas enormes s√°banas blancas.  En Suiza, se celebr√≥ una "marcha f√∫nebre" en septiembre pasado para conmemorar la desaparici√≥n de uno de los glaciares alpinos m√°s estudiados: el Pizol, evaporado por el efecto del calentamiento global.  üì∏ AP / EFE  #glaciares #Suiza #crisisclim√°tica #calentamientoglobal #Alpes #GlaciarDelR√≥dano #Gletsch

Today, 1% of the world is a barely livable hot zone. By 2070, that portion could go up to 19%. Billions of people call this land home, but where will they go?‚Å£‚Å£ ‚Å£‚Å£ According to a pathbreaking recent study, the planet could see a greater temperature increase in the next 50 years than it did in the past 6,000 years combined. New research suggests that climate change will cause humans to move across the planet at a huge, destabilizing scale. The result will almost certainly be the greatest wave of global migration the world has seen. ‚Å£‚Å£ ‚Å£‚Å£ As their land fails them, hundreds of millions of people from regions such as Central America, Sudan and the Mekong Delta will be forced to choose between flight or death. But the picture on the ground is scattered. To better understand the forces and scale of climate migration over a broad area, @nytmag and @ProPublica joined with the @pulitzercenter in an effort to model, for the first time, how people will move across borders.‚Å£‚Å£ ‚Å£‚Å£ Tap the link in our bio for our interactive report from Central America, where, in the most extreme climate scenarios, more than 30 million migrants would head toward the U.S. border over the course of the next 30 years. Photos by @meridithkohut.‚Å£‚Å£

Young climate activists like Jamie Margolin are building a movement while growing up ‚Äî planning mass protests from childhood bedrooms and during school.   When adults ask her, as they often do, when she first became worried about climate change, @jamie_s_margolin has a go-to answer: Climate change, she explains, is like Beyonc√©. When you‚Äôre a member of her generation, both are facts of life, things you just know, fundamental to the way the world functions.    For Margolin and her peers, Beyonc√© has simply always existed ‚Äî and so has the fear of growing up and making a life in a world rendered unrecognizable by climate change.   At 18, Margolin is the founder of @thisiszerohour, a group advocating for climate action. She has met with politicians and celebrities, helped plan international protests from her high school and joined a group of children suing her home state, Washington, for violating their constitutional rights by contributing to climate change.   ‚Äò‚ÄòThe story shouldn‚Äôt be, Oh, isn‚Äôt it cute that these kids are standing up for something,‚Äô‚Äô she said. ‚Äò‚ÄòIt should be, What are they standing up for?‚Äô‚Äô Tap the link in our bio to read more from @nytmag. Photo by @hollyandres

The deadly secret of China‚Äôs illegal fishing armada: It‚Äôs killing impoverished North Korean squid fishermen.‚Å† ‚Å† The battered wooden ‚Äúghost boats‚Äù drift through the Sea of Japan for months, their only cargo the corpses of starved North Korean fishermen whose bodies have been reduced to skeletons. Last year more than 150 of these macabre vessels washed ashore in Japan.‚Å† ‚Å† For years the grisly phenomenon mystified Japanese police, whose best guess was that climate change pushed the squid population farther from North Korea, driving the country‚Äôs fishermen dangerous distances from shore, where they become stranded and die from exposure. An @NBCNews investigation, based on new satellite data, has revealed what researchers now say is a more likely explanation: China is sending a previously invisible armada of industrial boats to illegally fish in North Korean waters, violently displacing North Korean boats.‚Å† ‚Å† Tap the link in our bio to read more. ‚Å† ‚Å† Produced in partnership with the Outlaw Ocean Project.‚Å† ‚Å† üì∑ Kyodo / @reuters

Seventeen-year-old Swedish climate change activist Greta Thunberg recently won the Gulbenkian Prize for Humanity ‚Äî and a huge sum of money she said she‚Äôll use to support environmental causes.‚Å† ‚Å† The Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation, a Portuguese philanthropic institute, awarded the School Strike for Climate founder 1 million euros ($1,153,330) along with her prize.‚Å† ‚Å† In a video she tweeted on Monday, Thunberg called the sum ‚Äúmore money than I can even begin to imagine‚Äù and said she would donate it all to charities fighting climate change.‚Å† ‚Å† ‚ÄúThis means a lot to me,‚Äù she continued. ‚ÄúAnd I hope it will help me do more good in the world.‚Äù‚Å† ‚Å† Thunberg said that the SOS Amazonia Campaign would receive some of her prize money. The initiative is currently helping Indigenous communities in the Amazon fighting to preserve the rainforest to address a worsening COVID-19 crisis.‚Å† ‚Å† Thunberg also said the Stop Ecocide Foundation would receive funds to support making ecocide, the mass destruction of the environment, an international crime.‚Å† ‚Å† Read more at our link in bio. // üìù@magooing_it // üì∑ Getty Images
ImageText: HUFFPOSTI Greta Thunberg To Donate Million-Euro Humanitarian Prize To Climate Causes

Description: ¬°Tremenda! üôå La activista sueca de 17 a√±os, #GretaThunberg, fue galardonada con un mill√≥n de euros por los organizadores del Premio Gulbenkian para la Humanidad, seg√∫n inform√≥ BBC News. Thunberg es la fundadora de School Strike for Climate, un movimiento ambientalista que realiza huelgas todos los viernes en contra del cambio clim√°tico. Es en este sentido que se√±al√≥ que donar√° el dinero del premio a proyectos que combaten "la crisis clim√°tica y ecol√≥gica". "Me siento extremadamente honrada de recibir el Premio Gulbenkian para la Humanidad. Estamos en una emergencia clim√°tica y mi fundaci√≥n donar√° todo el dinero del premio de un mill√≥n de euros lo m√°s r√°pido posible para apoyar a organizaciones y proyectos que luchan por un mundo sostenible", indic√≥ la activista. ¬øQu√© te parece? üëá
